DOC.HEADLINE: VISITING U.S. CADET CLEARED OF WRONG DOING

TEXT.P: The General Headquarters of the Army said in a press release that an investigation conducted Friday by a ten-member investigation panel led by Maj. Gen. Chen Liang-pei, president of the Republic of China Military Academy (ROCMA), found that the U.S. cadet neither raped the woman nor forced her to have sex with him. The woman who was present at the investigation didn't take exception to the panel's finding, according to the press release.
According to Wednesday's United Daily News, the cadet from West Point who is in the ROCMA on an exchange program was accused by a local woman of having sex with her without her consent.

The woman told the paper that she was introduced to the West Point cadet in a pub in Tainan City last Friday night by a friend studying at the ROCMA, identified by his surname as Chuang, who was in charge of receiving the West Point cadet during his stay in Taiwan for a short-term exchange program at the ROCMA.

The woman claimed that Chuang and the West Point cadet kept encouraging her to drink and that they brought her out of the pub soon after midnight, when she had become "half drunk" after consuming about three bottles of beer.
Chuang then left her with the West Point cadet, who later brought her to the city's Evergreen Laurel Hotel, the woman said.

As they entered the hotel room, the cadet began stripping off her clothes, the woman claimed, adding that he then engaged in sexual intercourse with her before she "even had a chance to resist" as she was not fully conscious due to the effects of the alcohol she had consumed, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM MIGHT HAVE INTERFERED IN TAIWAN'S INTERNAL AFFAIRS: CEPD

TEXT.P: Officials from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Thursday that the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei might have interfered with Taiwan's internal affairs by blasting the government in its 2007 Taiwan White Paper.

Responding to the just-released Taiwan White Paper, CEPD officials admitted that problems such as "inconsistent enforcement of regulations and inadequate governmental transparency" that the White Paper criticized might well be true, but said its urging for direct cross-Taiwan Strait transport links -- which is not a matter the government can control -- made CEPD officials feel that AmCham is trying to back-seat drive in terms of Taiwan's own business.

Speaking at a news conference unveiling the 2007 AmCham Taiwan White Paper, AmCham Executive Director Richard Vuylsteke warned that Taiwan's economy will "get into a big trouble" next year if the government still refuses to deregulate cross-strait exchanges and remove trade barriers, and said that he sees neither of the two candidates the ruling and opposition parties might field for the 2008 presidential election as determined to turn Taiwan's sagging economy around.

Regarding direct cross-strait transport links, the White Paper says that "nothing can be said that hasn't been said repeatedly before about how the failure to act on this issue has isolated, constrained and damaged Taiwan's economy."
"So on cross-strait links, the AmCham message to the Taiwan government remains clear and unequivocal: Just do it!"

The White Paper stresses Taiwan's regulatory morass and said that AmCham's complaints fall into several categories, including inadequate transparency, violation of due process, legislator interference on behalf of private interests, insufficient consultation with industry players, inconsistent interpretations and enforcement, and regulations inconsistent with international best practices.

Describing the 2007 AmCham Taiwan White Paper as a record of a "health checkup for the Taiwan tiger, " AmCham President Jane Hwang said in a press conference that AmCham is concerned that Taiwan appears to be falling behind the other "aging" Asian tigers -- Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea -- in economic competitiveness, while other "new" Asian tigers, including China, India and Vietnam, are rapidly gaining strength.

Hwang said she will be leading an AmCham delegation to Washington, D.C. in 10 days to discuss the 2007 AmCham Taiwan White Paper with American officials and elected representatives in a projected 30 meetings with the goal of encouraging stronger trade and business links between the United States and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WILL WEIGH WHETHER PUTTING SPEAKER AT TOP OF AT-LARGE SEAT LIST

TEXT.P: The decision on whether to place Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng at the top of the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) list of at-large legislators will have to take into account the feelings of the public, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih said Thursday.

Wu made the remarks after Wang turned down an offer by KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou earlier the same day to serve as his running mate, finally ending months of speculation that the two would pair up to boost the party's chances of winning in the 2008 presidential election.

Wang said he wants to remain in the legislature, adding that for the sake of political stability as well as the interests of the people, he decided to turn down the offer. He did agree to cooperate with Ma.

Asked whether the KMT will put Wang directly at the top spot on the list of the party's at-large nominees in the year-end legislative elections so that he can continue to vie for the legislative speakership, Wu answered with an unequivocal "No." Wang is already a three-term legislative speaker.
Wu said that the party will have to consider several things: the response of the "pan-blue alliance" led by the KMT; and the wishes of Ma and Wang himself.
"Only after taking these three things into consideration will the party make its initial decision," Wu said.
The year-end legislative elections will be especially fierce as they will be held under a new "single-member constituency, two-vote" electoral system that will also halve the number of seats to 113.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA CHIEF WINS F.A. COTTON MEDAL

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Chi-huey Wong has won the 2008 F.A. Cotton Medal for Excellence in Chemical Research, a renowned award named after one of the greatest chemists of the 20th Century, according to a press release issued Thursday by the institution.
Wong will attend the formal award ceremony -- to be held next spring at Texas A&M University (TAMU) -- and give a speech at the event, according to the press release.

Wong went into chemistry in the 1970s, when he was an undergraduate at National Taiwan University. He received a doctoral degree in chemistry from Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1982 and then joined the faculty of TAMU, where he became a professor in 1987.

Wong returned to Taiwan in 2003 to take the position of director of the Genomic Research Center at Academia Sinica. Late last year, he succeeded Lee Yuan-tseh as the head of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institution.

Frank Albert Cotton (1930V2007) -- the former chair of the W.T. Doherty-Welch Foundation and a Distinguished Professor of Chemistry at TAMU -- is widely recognized for his research into the chemistry of transition metals.

Cotton authored more than 1,600 scientific papers and received 29 honorary doctorates and important awards such as the U.S. National Medal of Science, the Wolf Prize and the Priestley Medal, as well as the American Chemical Society's highest recognition.
The F.A. Cotton Medal was initiated by the American Chemical Society and TAMU in 1995. Every year, one chemist with distinguished achievements is selected by the board to receive the award.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECTOR OF STONE THEATER DIES AFTER ACCIDENTAL FALL
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou County, central Taiwan, May 31 (CNA) 06/01/07 10:35:21 (By Han Hai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The young director of the Stone Theater -- a troupe based in Taichung, central Taiwan -- died Thursday of head injuries he suffered in an accidental fall from the ceiling of a theater June 25.
Cheng Jen-po, 25, is survived by his parents. The young director was trying to adjust the lights in the Puli Arts and Cultural Center before a performance when he fell head-first to the ground.
Doctors at the Puli Christian operated on him twice but were unable to save him.

Cheng graduated from National Tsing Hua University in Hsinchu with a major in information engineering in 2005, but found that he loved playwriting and directing more than information science after taking a course in drama in 2004.
In 2005, he joined the Stone Theater, which aims to combine theater with everyday life and foster the growth of theater in the community.

The stage play titled Witch Ulala's Crystal Ball, which he wrote and directed for children, proved so successful in 2005 and 2006 that the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs awarded him a grant to give 10 extra performances around Taiwan.
The performance in Nantou was the first of these shows.
Cheng's parents told reporters that they will watch the June 2 show in Hsinchu County's Chutung township and attend a memorial afterwards.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 1, or the 16th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte, emperor of France from 1804 to 1814, swears fidelity to the French Constitution. His military and political might gripped Continental Europe but failed to encompass Great Britain.
1868: James Buchanan, the 15th president of the United States, dies at the age of 77. The first bachelor to be elected president, he tried to maintain a balance between pro-slavery and anti-slavery factions, but his moderate views angered radicals in both North and South, and he was unable to forestall the secession of South Carolina on Dec. 20, 1860.
1926: Marilyn Monroe, the American actress who led a turbulent life and became an icon after her death, is born. She appeared in several motion pictures, including "Some Like it Hot" and "The Misfits."
1929: A state funeral for China's Dr. Sun Yat-sen is held in Nanking at the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum on Mount Tzuchinshan.
1931: The Provisional Constitution for the Period of Political Tutelage of the Republic of China is promulgated.
1941: British forces are finally withdrawn from Crete with heavy losses. Some 3,000 Australians are also killed in the evacuation.
1946: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. is established in Shanghai.
1946: The Land Bank of Taiwan is inaugurated.
1957: Chiang Ching-kuo becomes chairman of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen under the ROC Executive Yuan.
1958: The ROC wins the football championship at the Third Asian Games in Tokyo.
1958: General Charles de Gaulle becomes prime minister of France.
1960: O.K. Yu (Yu Hung-chiun), governor of the Central Bank of China, dies at the age of 65. Yu had formerly served as governor of Taiwan and premier of the ROC.
1968: Helen Keller, the blind and deaf American author and teacher, dies at home in Easton, Connecticut, at the age of 87, ending a life of outstanding courage that brought hope and inspiration to thousands.
1968: The Joint Service Committee for Overseas Chinese and Foreign Investors is established in Taipei.
1972: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Fredrick F. Chien as director-general of the Government Information Office; Chen Kuei-hua as director of the Personnel Administration Office; Hsieh Tung-min as governor of Taiwan; Chang Feng-hsu as mayor of Taipei; C.C. Chang as chairman of the Economic Planning Council; and Yang Chia-lin as chairman of the Administrative Research and Evaluation Committee of the Executive Yuan.
1973: Lt. Gen. Chaveng Youngcharoen, commandant of the Royal Thai War College, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: The ROC opens regular shipping service to Indonesia.
1975: An automated terminal radar system is installed at Taipei International Airport.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan confers the Order of Propitious Clouds with Special Grand Cordon on Leabua Jonathan, prime minister of the Kingdom of Lesotho, and the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Lesotho Foreign Minister Charles D. Molapo.
1978: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Lin Yang-kang as governor of Taiwan Province, and of Lee Teng-hui as mayor of Taipei City.
1979: Rhodesia takes the name Zimbabwe, with Bishop Abel Muzorewa as its first black prime minister, ending 89 years of white rule.
1979: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to raise NT$28.82 billion before 1980 for the construction of the South Link Railroad which is planned for completion in December 1990. Upon completion of the project, a trip around the island will take only a day.
1989: Lee Huan is sworn in as premier of the ROC.
1990: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sign a bilateral agreement to stop producing chemical arms and to start destroying existing stocks by the end of 1992.
1999: Dr. Lien Wen-pin, chief physician of President Lee Teng-hui at National Taiwan University Hospital, says the president, now 77 years old, has the body of a 60-year-old and is in extremely good health.
1999: Francisco Flores, 39, is sworn in as the youngest-ever president of El Salvador.
2000: After four years of lackluster operations, the EVA Airways Corporation suspends its flights on the Taipei-Panama City route.
2001: The Republic of China Directorate General of Posts (DGP) issues a set of memorial stamps in commemoration of Canadian missionary doctor George Leslie Mackay, who died in Taiwan 100 years
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure derived from the study and criticism of the polite arts, pleasure in admiring and speaking of the excellent qualities of men, and pleasure in having many friends of virtue and talent: these pleasures are beneficial." ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DECORATES SAUDI ARABIAN PRINCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with Saudi Arabian Prince Alwaleed Bin Talal Bin Abdulaziz Alsaud late Thursday and decorated the visiting Arabian "king of business" with one of the highest honors bestowed by the Republic of China government.

Chen conferred the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon on Alwaleed in a ceremony held at the Presidential Office in recognition of Alwaleed's contributions to cementing bilateral exchanges between Taiwan and Saudi Arabia.

Chen lauded Alwaleed as not only a shrewd financial player, whose global investments include a large stake in the Citibank Group, but also a hardworking manager who often spends more than 18 hours a day shuttling among four countries for business rendezvous.

The president told the major shareholder of Citibank -- one of the largest full service banks in the world -- that the Citigroup Taiwan's transactions exceed US$100 million a year, making it the leading foreign bank operating in Taiwan.
Chen also offered congratulations to Alwaleed for the construction of the soon to be inaugurated Four Seasons Hotel in Taipei, in which Alwaleed's business group has invested.
The president added that total foreign investment in Taiwan has exceeded US$70 billion and that the amount of foreign capital in Taiwan's bourse has surpassed US$120 billion.
The Saudi Arabian prince arrived in Taipei late Thursday for a brief visit on the fourth leg of his whirlwind Asian business tour, which has also taken him to Brunei, Vietnam and Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
KAOHSIUNG MAYOR EXPECTED TO BE DISCHARGED FROM HOSPITAL NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, who has been hospitalized for more than a month since suffering a minor stroke Apr. 26, is expected to be discharged from hospital next week to allow her to return to work, Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Chiu Tai-san said Friday.
Chiu said the mayor has been recovering well, spending most of her time exercising, including riding a stationary exercise bike and climbing staircases, in order to strengthen her muscles.

According to Chiu, Chen's doctors at the Kaohsiung Medical University Hospital, where Chen has been recuperating and undergoing rehabilitation, have asked the mayor to lose some weight as "the essential means" to tackle her problems of chronic high blood pressure and heart disease, which were the main causes of her minor stroke.
Chiu said that Chen has asked to be discharged from the hospital and that her doctors are assessing the feasibility of granting her request.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70% OF TAIWAN ADULTS EAT OUT FREQUENTLY: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Seventy percent of Taiwan adults eat out frequently, with a higher ratio of men doing so than women, according to the results of a recent survey released by the Global Views Monthly magazine.
The magazine estimated that 3.3 million of Taiwan adults eat out everyday.

The trend is most common among those in the 20-29 age group, which includes students and young office workers, with more than 35 percent of people in this group not having meals at home everyday, according to the survey.

Citing tallies from the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the magazine noted that each Taiwan family spent some NT$50,000 (US$1,515) on average eating out last year, meaning that the total spending by Taiwan's more than 7 million households on eating out amounted to NT$36 billion for the year.

The survey found that lunch is the meal that the largest percentage of respondents enjoy outside the home frequently, with 78.7 percent doing so, followed by breakfast, with 66.8 percent of respondents usually eating this meal outside the home.

As to the places where people eat out for lunch, 59.6 percent of respondents mentioned boxed lunch sellers, noodle eateries and snack bars. Other popular choices mentioned included cafeterias, restaurants and luncheonettes, as well as roadside food stands and food wagons.

Meanwhile, the oyster omelet was selected by the largest number of respondents as the snack best representing Taiwan, followed by pearl milk tea, oyster vermicelli, stinky tofu and braised pork rice. Other items mentioned included rice meat balls, rice dumplings, tan-tsai noodles, beef noodles, small steamer buns, rice noodles, and bowl cakes, according to the survey.
The survey, conducted via telephone from May 4-9 on 500 men and 500 women around Taiwan, is said to have a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT AWARDED GOTO PRIZE IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 1 (CNA) 06/01/07 16:31:08 (By Mike Chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui was awarded Friday the first Shimpei Goto Prize by a Japanese publisher for his contribution to Taiwan's urbanization and democratization.

The event was organized by Fijiwara Shoten's Goto Shimpei Organization to mark the 150th anniversary of the birth of the late Japanese colonial administrator Shimpei Goto. The prize is awarded to people who have contributed to national or regional development.

Delivering a speech titled "Shimpei Goto and Me" during the ceremony, Lee noted that Goto made a great contribution to Taiwan's modernization during his service as the chief of civil administration under the Japanese colonial government in Taiwan between 1898 and 1906.
Lee said that although his life hardly overlapped with that of Goto, he personally has been profoundly influenced by Goto's achievements in Taiwan and his extraordinary philosophy of life.

"It is not an exaggeration to say that Taiwan's development has moved forward along the track paved by Goto, " Lee said, adding that the Japanese education that he received allowed him to become mayor of Taipei City, governor of Taiwan Province, vice president and even president.

On what he takes pride in the most, Lee pointed to his success in transforming Taiwan's political system from a military dictatorship into a democracy without a single drop of blood being shed in his 12 years as president.

According to Lee, there are two kinds of politicians: those who engage in the pursuit of power and those who aim to serve the people. He added that politicians who are not subject to the temptation of power do not become corrupt.
Just like Goto, Lee said, he exercised self-restraint and was always ready to relinquish power during his presidency.
Claiming that faith is one of the most important qualities of a leader, Lee said love and justice are what he believes in as a Christian.
Lee further said that although he and Goto may be different in terms of their religious beliefs, having strong faith is what they have in common and what connects them spiritually.
This is Lee's third trip to Japan since his presidency ended in May 2000. However, this is his first visit to Tokyo and the first time that he has made a public speech in Japan.

In addition to receiving the prize, another highlight of Lee's current trip is a planned "oku no hosomichi" tour covering the prefectures of Miyagi, Yamagata, Iwate, Akita and Gunma, retracing a similar journey made by haiku poet Matsuo Basho in 1689 based on which his famous work "Oku no Hosomichi, " or "Narrow Road to the Interior," was written.

Lee will also visit Akita International University and Takushoku University and has indicated his desire to visit the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo to pay respects to his older brother who died fighting for the Japanese colonial government during World War II.
The former president is scheduled to hold a news conference in Tokyo before his departure June 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG LAND DEVELOPMENT PLAN PUT ON TRACK

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with Jason Hu, mayor of the central city of Taichung, at the Presidential Office Friday for a hour-long talk, during which a long-stalled plan to develop a massive plot of land in the greater Taichung area was put on the fast track.

Chen instructed that NT$7 billion (US$212 million) be allocated out of a military barracks reconstruction fund to facilitate the relocation of the Air Force Second Logistic Command Center away from the site of the former Shuinan Airport so that development projects on the vast plot of land covering approximately 250 hectares can kick off.

Chen instructed the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the Ministry of National Defense and the Taichung City Government to collaborate and jointly form a task force on the development plan so as to enable the Air Force Second Logistic Command Center to be fully relocated by the end of this year, paving the way for the launch of the mammoth land development plan at the beginning of 2008 at the earliest.

The Shuinan development plan -- potentially involving the development of a modern urban hub that will house a university city, a trade exhibition center, an up-scale residential district and a forest park -- put Taichung on the map in March this year after Richard Li, a Hong Kong business tycoon whose father, Li Ka-shing, is Asia's richest man, paid a visit to the site for a fact-finding tour.

Meanwhile, according to Taichung City Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi, who was also present at the Chen-Hu meeting, the president also instructed the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration to talk with the DPP legislative caucus to reach a consensus on the issue of whether the Act on Local Government Systems should be further amended to enable Taichung City to be upgraded to a special municipality.

During the Chen-Hu meeting, according to Hsiao, Mayor Hu also suggested that the Chingchuankang Airport, now known as the Taichung Airport, be allowed to operate cross-strait charter flight services during the Chinese New Year and other major holidays.
Chen instructed the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to study the feasibility of Hu's suggestion, according to Hsiao.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO BUILD CLEAN, SAFE ENVIRONMENT FOR ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: New Premier Chang Chun-hsiung pledged Friday to aggressively work to create a clean and safe election environment ahead of two major elections -- the year-end legislative election and the presidential election in 2008.
Chang, who assumed office May 21, said he believes that "cracking down on money politics" and "eradicating vote-buying" are what the people expect a clean government to do.

Chang made the pledge while delivering an administrative policy report at the Legislative Yuan. In the report, he reiterated that "replacing conflict with cooperation" and "building nests instead of walls" are the fundamental guiding principles of his administration.

It is the ongoing conflict between the ruling and opposition parties that has blocked the central government's 2007 general budget bill from clearing the Legislative Yuan, slowed down the nation's economic growth, and brought about a rise in unemployment, Chang said. In a humble and sincere manner, the premier asked the Legislative Yuan to pass the budget bill as soon as possible.

Speaking on the economy, Chang said that the Executive Yuan will continue promoting financial reform while making efforts to carry out his "Taiwan Priority" policy aimed at encouraging overseas Taiwanese business people to invest in their homeland.

Besides working to make Taiwan more prosperous, Chang said his administration will also continue to work on implementing the series of "Mega Warmth" social welfare programs initiated by his predecessor, Su Tseng-chang, and will do its utmost to resolve problems related to the development of small and medium enterprises, economic development in the less-developed central and southern Taiwan regions, and the livelihood of the lower class.

On the topic of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, the premier said Taiwan should display its determination in defending its sovereignty, adding that to this end, the government should actively work to push for military reforms and carry out military arms procurement projects while bidding for the country's entry into international organizations, including the United Nations, under the name of Taiwan.

Mentioning the upcoming 2008 Beijing Olympic Games, Chang said Taiwan sincerely hopes that the international sporting festival which is widely seen as a symbol of "peace" and "friendship" will help the two sides of the strait resume dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 104.95 points to close at 8,249.9.

The bourse opened at 8,236.76 and fluctuated between 8,224.28 and 8,261.67 during the day's trading. A total of 4.2 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$129.95 billion (US$3.9 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement issues moving up the most at 2.4 percent, followed by plastic and chemical issues at 1.7 percent, banking and financial stocks at 1.5 percent, machinery and electronics stocks at 1.3 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent.
Meanwhile, textile issues dropped 0.5 percent, and construction shares slid 0.3 percent. Foodstuff issues remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 642 to 478, with 228 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS RESPOND WARMLY TO PROPOSED NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE

TEXT.P: A no-confidence vote called by Chen Chin-de, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker, had gained positive responses from his DPP peers as of Friday, with over half of the party's lawmakers endorsing the proposal.

The no-confidence vote proposed earlier this week by Chen was endorsed by 46 lawmakers, all of the DPP -- only 27 short of the one-third legal threshold required to allow it to become a motion. The DPP controls 84 seats in the Legislative Yuan.

Speaking in a news conference, Chen urged lawmakers of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) to honor their previous pledges by joining the move to topple the Cabinet led by Premier Chang Chun- hsiung so as to permit President Chen Shui-bian to dissolve the parliament and elect new legislators who could vote on several key bills stonewalled in the legislature.

The long-term disorder in the "pan-blue alliance"-dominated Legislative Yuan has seriously hobbled administrative operations and now is the time to put an end to the farce, Chen said, adding that he has strong confidence that his no- confidence proposal will pass the legal threshold and be put on the legislative agenda next Tuesday for a vote within five days.

Despite Chen's explanation as to why he wants the legislature dissolved, PFP spokesman Lee Hung-chun questioned why the DPP does not instead propose a motion to recall the president instead of taking aim at the premier, as Chang was appointed by the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER HOPES TO STEP UP COOPERATION TO COMBAT DRUG PROBLEM

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin expressed hope Friday that Taiwan can learn from the drug-control experience of other countries and step up international cooperation to deal with its drug problem.

Shih made the remarks when he presided over the opening of an international drug control symposium sponsored by the ministry. More than 30 anti-drug officials and experts from 10 countries, including the United States, Canada, France and Australia, took part in the symposium.
He noted that the government formulated a new policy on drug control last year and that a major concept under the new policy is to treat drug addicts as patients rather than criminals.
The government is also providing the drug addicts with clean needles and taking cues from the United States, Australia and Hong Kong to use methadone to treat heroin addicts.
Methadone is a rigorously tested medication that is safe and efficacious for the treatment of narcotic withdrawal and dependence, Shih claimed.
The government also divides drug control work into four major areas: drug- prevention, drug-rejection, drug rehabilitation and drug crackdowns.
The central government is also working with local governments, with drug- prevention centers established in every city and county, he went on.
He pointed out that the government is adopting a multi-pronged approach to drug control, with four drug rehabilitation centers set up in Taipei, Taichung, Kaohsiung and Taitung.
On drug crackdowns, Shih said Taiwan is working with Thailand, Vietnam, Japan, Malaysia and Australia to form a regional drug prevention network.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved up 61 points to close at 8,232, with 30,878 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for July gained 56 points to finish at 8,175, with 774 contracts traded, while September futures increased 54 points to end at 8,036, with 165 contract transactions. December futures grew 84 points to close at 8,050, with 41 contracts traded, while March futures moved up 80 points to finish at 8,042, with 12 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 8,171 for June, 8,119 for July, 7,982 for September, 7,966 for December and 7,962 for March.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

June TE futures moved up 4.85 points to close at 353.7, with 3,246 contracts traded, while July TE futures increased 5.5 points to finish at 351.2, with 69 contract transactions. September TE futures moved up 4.45 points to close at 343.95, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December and March.

June TF futures moved up 4.2 points to close at 965.2, with 2,260 contracts traded, while July TF futures slid 3.2 points to finish at 964, with 139 contract transactions. September TF futures rose two points to end at 958, with 19 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: `LIVING FOSSIL' HORSESHOE CRABS SIGHTED ON CHIAYI COAST

TEXT.P: Asian horseshoe crabs, known as one of the few "living fossil" species in the Taiwan area, have been sighted on the coast of the southern county of Chiayi recently, opening another wildlife conservation door, Chiayi County officials said Friday.

Five adult and 32 young Asian horseshoe crab tachypleus tridentatus, whose appearance on Earth can be dated back to 200 million years ago, have been sighted on the coast of Putai, Chiayi, making Chiayi County the third place in Taiwan to witness the appearance of the crabs after sightings were reported on the outlying island of Kinmen and in the Penghu archipelago, the officials said.

The Chiayi county authorities are collaborating with researchers from the Research Center for Biodiversity, Academia Sinica (RCBAS) to protect the rare species and its habitat near the Putai coast, the officials said.

Other members of several wildlife conservationist groups will also join the RCBAS researchers and Chiayi officials on a field trip to a saltmarsh in Putai Saturday to witness the erection of a netted area to allow the adult crabs to spawn and the babies to be nurtured, making the area an exclusive breeding zone for the crabs.
Meanwhile, the officials went on, the protection of Asian horseshoe crabs will also be arranged as one of the activities to attract tourists to Chiayi County.
In 2006, some 70,000 baby Asian horseshoe crabs bred in captivity were released into the wild off the coast of Kinmen as part of efforts to conserve the "living fossil" species.

With its distinctive domed carapace shaped like a horseshoe and a stiff pointed tail, the Asian horseshoe crab was nearly extinct in waters surrounding Taiwan proper as a result of development and environmental change until it occasionally began to be seen near Penghu a couple of years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Food safety fears over animals fed to animals
Tests to allow the remains of animals to be reintroduced into farm feed for the first time since the BSE crisis are being carried out by European scientists, The Times has learnt.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN SHARE COMMON DESTINY: FORMER PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 1 (CNA) 06/01/07 18:30:20 (By Mike Chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui urged Japanese politicians Friday to recognize "the fact" that Japan shares a common destiny with Taiwan although the two countries maintain no diplomatic relations.
Under this circumstance, it would be in Japan's benefit to enhance its ties with Taiwan, Lee said.
The former president said that although he has retired from politics and does not hold any political power, he will try to promote the relations between the two countries in a private capacity.
Lee made the remarks during a news conference held after he was presented with the first Shimpei Goto Prize in Tokyo.

On the question of Taiwan's democratization, Lee said the country started to develop toward a democracy as early as 1990 when the first round of constitutional reforms were launched, although Taiwan's democratic transformation was not well-known to the world until the first popular presidential election held in 1996.
The prize was awarded to Lee by the Japanese publisher Fijiwara Shoten's Goto Shimpei Organization in recognition of his contribution to Taiwan's urbanization and democratization.
The event attracted approximately 160 participants, including opinion leaders from various sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR QUICK PASSAGES OF KEY BILLS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called Friday for the quick passage of two key bills out of grave concern over national development and the people's livelihoods.
Chen made the remarks during an award ceremony at the Presidential Office for outstanding engineers.
Saying that economic issues must be free from political meddling, Chen said that the 2007 central government budget bill must clear the Legislative Yuan as soon as possible.

The annual budget bill has been stonewalled for more than six months in the Legislative Yuan due to an "irrational" boycott of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (DPP), Chen said, blaming them for tying its passage to that of the draft Central Election Commission (CEC) Organic Law.

Now that the ruling and opposition camps have reached initial agreement over the draft CEC Organic Law, Chen said, the budget bill should be approved as soon as possible and he expressed his hope that no more disputes will arise to further complicate the situation.
The Legislative Yuan has been in a gridlock over the two bills, which are of respective significance to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition "pan-blue alliance."

The KMT and the PFP made it clear that they will never agree to the annual budget bill's passage unless the DPP is willing to accept a proportional representation system proposed by the "pan-blue alliance" concerning the lineup of the 17-member CEC.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG GRANTS DISCOUNT TO LESS PRIVILEGED HOMEBUYERS

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government announced Friday that its public housing plan for the less privileged will be extended to cover physically or mentally disabled and low-income residents.

A spokesman for the city government pointed out that the plan, launched three years ago, has been granting a 20 percent discount to single-parent families that buy public housing units and that Mayor Chen Chu has decided to allow low- income families and residents with physical or mental disabilities to enjoy the same privilege.
The spokesman said that from June 1, less privileged people can apply to buy housing units in five different locations, provided they have been residents in Kaohsiung for one year.

He added that eligible applicants are entitled to 30-year low-interest loans, in addition to other benefits including paying their downpayments in 24 installments interest-free and a mortgage rate at 2.86 percent per annum for NT$2.2 million of the loan.
Information about the housing plan can be viewed by accessing the city government's Urban Development Bureau Web site at http://urban- web.kcg.gov.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS KEY TO PRESIDENT'S LEGACY: GROUP

TEXT.P: Whether President Chen Shui-bian can deliver on his pledges regarding constitutional reforms in the last year of his presidency will be a test of what his legacy will be, a civic group said Friday.
The Taiwan Association of University Professors made the remarks during a news conference to unveil a mid-term report on Taiwan's political situation.

According to the report, the public is "generally positive" about Chen's performance in the areas of strengthening Taiwan-centric consciousness and promoting a pluralistic democracy and financial reforms.

But in the areas of constitutional reforms, ecological preservation and the realization of social fairness and justice, the president has yet to meet expectations, the report says, adding that whether he can realize those goals in the last year of his presidency will affect his legacy.

Hsu Chu-feng, a lecturer at National Chi Nan University, said that compared with the turbulent street protests by the "red-clad" protesters last year to demand that Chen to step down in the wake of a series of corruption scandals surrounding his family members and top aides, this year seems to be calmer.

"But the ideological rivalry is even fiercer, " he said, adding that the ruling and the opposition parties have continued their ethnic mobilization with winning the presidential election next year as their major concerns.

On Taiwan's relations with China, National Taiwan University Professor Chen Chun-sheng said the opposition Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China (CPC) has held cross-Taiwan Strait trade forums, agricultural cooperation forums and trade and cultural forums since 2005.
Chen said this is China's attempt to join forces with Taiwan's private sector to drive a wedge between the Taiwan government and its people.
China's two-pronged approach -- courting Taiwan's private sector on one hand and bashing Taiwan relentlessly internationally -- will only antagonize the Taiwan people, according to the professor.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO HURRY TO SELECT RUNNING MATE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said Friday that he is not in a hurry to pick his running mate for the 2008 election.
Hsieh made the remarks on the sidelines of an activity organized the Taipei- based Chinese Institute of Engineers.
He said that he did not want to decide on who to pair up with so early, adding that "I will have to see the development of the political situation as well as other matters before making a decision."

On President Chen Shui-bian's instruction earlier that day to upgrade Taichung City to that of a special municipality like Taipei and Kaohsiung, he said he is not opposed to the upgrade, although Taiwan should have "longer-term planning."
He said Taiwan should be divided into six provinces or states, each of about 4 million people, which he claimed would be "most favorable to international competition."
It could also avoid the disputes over which cities get to be promoted to the level of a special municipality and which cities do not.

According to earlier remarks by Hsieh, Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County and Pingtung County can be integrated into one province; Yunlin County, Chiayi County and Tainan County can form the second province; Taichung County, Changhua County, Nantou County the third province; Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County and Miaoli County the fourth province; Taipei County, Keelung City and Yilan County the fifth province; and a special administration can encompass Hualien County and Taitung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG LISTED IN CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER SERVICE PLAN: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the central government will definitely include Taichung in its direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter services.
Chen made the remarks while talking to Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, whom he had invited to a meeting at the Presidential Office to discuss the central city's long-term development.

Stressing that he will never forget promises he made to Taichung citizens -- building an international airport, constructing a science park and upgrading the city's administrative status -- Chen pledged that he will do his utmost to help the municipal authorities achieve the three goals during his last year in office.
"The greater Taichung area will never be absent from the central government's cross-strait charter flight service program along with Taipei and Kaohsiung, " Chen vowed.
For his part, Hu voiced his hope that Chingchuankang Airport in neighboring Taichung County could be converted to an international airport as soon as possible.

Describing it as very important that an international airport be built in central Taiwan for the some 6 million people living there, Hu, however, pointed out that the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has yet to include Taichung in its program for opening direct cross-strait charter flights.

Hu told the president that the central government should help upgrade Chingchuankang Airport to international standards so as to offer both cargo and passenger charter flights between Taiwan and China as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI HOSTING 2007 INTERNATIONAL KARATE INVITATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taipei International Karate Invitational Championship will take place Saturday at the Taipei Gymnasium, with some 250 karate practitioners from seven countries competing.
The competitors, who come from the United States, the United Kingdom, Thailand, Malaysia, India, Japan and Taiwan, will vie for titles in the kumite and kata categories.
The event will be held in conjunction with the National Shotokan Karate Championship.
The organizers of the two events have invited world-renowned shotokan karate master Hirokazu Kanazawa, 77, and his son Fumatoshi Kanazawa to the two championships.

Hirokazu Kanazawa will appear at the competition and sign books he has written on karate for fans. The Chinese versions of two of his books -- Stronger Karate in Six Weeks and Karate, My life -- were recently released in Taiwan.
He is currently the chief instructor and president of the Japan-based Shotokan Karate-do International Federation, an organization he founded after he left the Japan Karate Association in 1979.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Bush Proposes Goal to Reduce Greenhouse Gas Emissions
President Bush, fending off international accusations that he was ignoring climate change, proposed for the first time on Thursday to set "a long-term global goal" for cutting greenhouse gas emissions, and he called on other high- polluting nations to join the United States in negotiations aimed at reaching an agreement by the end of next year.
If carried through, such an agreement would be the first in which the United States, the world's biggest source of the emissions that scientists say are warming the planet, has committed itself to a specific target for cutting them.
Wall Street Journal: Seeking Lift, Coke Turns Focus Back to Bottlers
This spring, Coca-Cola Co. Chairman and Chief Executive Officer E. Neville Isdell visited here to put a struggling local bottler into what he calls the "hospital ward."
Filipinos drink more soda per capita than people in just about any other emerging market, a habit cultivated by more than 40 years of American colonial rule. But hamstrung by a lack of investment and weak marketing practices, Coke's Philippine bottler saw sales plummet. Poor results in the country, Coke's 11th- largest market, shaved a full percentage point off the company's global volume growth in 2006, which was 3.9%.
Mr. Isdell's plan to fix the Philippines is central to his strategy for reversing nearly a decade of sluggish performance at the soft-drink giant.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.K. OFFICIAL IMPRESSED BY PERFORMANCE OF TAIWANESE STUDENTS

TEXT.P: A visiting British education official said Friday that he was impressed by the high levels of performance of Taiwanese students and encouraged more Taiwanese students to go to U.K. to pursue higher education.
Taiwanese students can attain high levels of performance, particularly in mathematics and science subjects, said Andrew Adonis, U.K. Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for Schools.

Adonis was speaking during a private visit to Taipei to look at the strengths of the Taiwanese education system, in particular the factors that explain the sustained high attainment of Taiwanese children in standard international tests.

The schools he visited -- Jianguo Senior High School and Renai Junior High School -- have seen substantial increases in creativity education in their curricula, as well as self-directed learning and life skills learning, Adonis said, adding that this is something the U.K. education system can learn from.

He also spoke at National Chengchi University about the U.K. experience of education reform, noting that there are moves to give schools greater autonomy in school management and to give parents greater choice in terms of the types of schools on offer.

The U.K. government has placed "great emphasis on education" since Prime Minister Tony Blair assumed office 10 years ago, he claimed. One of the key priorities in U.K. education reform has been to "get the right leadership and teachers in schools, " Adonis said.

Among the practical measures taken are increasing teachers' salaries by 20 percent and those of principals by 25 percent, he said. Currently there are 40,000 more teachers than there were 10 years ago, he added.
In terms of higher education, the U.K. government is seeking to expand the numbers of universities and work-related degree courses and to increase funding and investment on leading-edge science.
Adonis visited Hong Kong and Singapore prior to his arrival in Taiwan. On Saturday he is scheduled to discuss aspects of Taiwan's education reform with academics and experts.

DOC.HEADLINE: `DREAM BEAUTY' RICE HARVEST KICKS OFF IN CHANGHUA

TEXT.P: Agricultural officials, rice farmers and traders held a ceremony Friday in Pitou rural township in Changhua County, central Taiwan, to kick off the year's first harvest Japanese "Dream Beauty" rice.
In the ceremony, Changhua Magistrate Chuo Puo-yuan and other local officials reaped rice from the middle of a paddy as part of a symbolic harvest.

The county's director of agricultural affairs, Chiu Shi-ping, said half of the total production from the 70-hectare contracted rice fields growing "Dream Beauty" will be sold to Japan after a series of strict pesticides tests.

The plantation is a cooperative program between a local rice marketing company and a Japanese enterprise to grow the premium strain of Japanese rice in Taiwan. Chiu explained that rice production in Japan often fails to meet domestic demand because there is only one harvest per year in that country.

Japanese businesses therefore seek other countries in which they can grow their own rice, Chiu said, noting that the contract for Pitou to grow "Dream Beauty" has provisions that the soil, water and farmers' agricultural techniques are as good as those in Japan.
While 250 tons, or 50 percent of the rice will be marketed in Japan in the form of small packages, consumers in Taiwan are expected to be able to purchase the rice by July in local markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW KEELUNG COUNCIL SPEAKER SWORN IN

TEXT.P: The new Keelung city council speaker was sworn in Friday soon after winning a by-election by a razor-thin margin of 16-15 over her rival.
Chang Fang-li beat former Keelung Council Vice Speaker Tseng Shui-yuan to become the city council's first female speaker.
Following the victory, Chang immediately announced that she had decided to give up her opposition Kuomintang (KMT) membership to serve as a non-partisan speaker.
The by-election was held after former Speaker Chang Tong-rong won the Keelung mayoral by-election last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSC FORGES DEAL WITH BRAZILIAN IRON MINING COMPANY

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung-based China Steel Corp. (CSC) signed a four-year contract Friday with Samarco, a Brazilian mining company, under the terms of which the Brazilian firm will sell CSC 1.9 million tons of iron ore pellets from 2008 to 2011.
CSC officials said the contract will ensure 25 per cent of CSC's annual iron ore pellet demand.

The two companies have maintained good commercial relations since 1998, when CSC first contracted Samarco to buy iron ore pellets, according to CSC, a state- operated company that produces 11 million tons of raw steel per year.
Samarco is the world's second-largest iron ore pellet exporter, selling the product to 15 countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: VECO HAILS INTERRACIAL MARRIAGE BROKERAGE BAN

TEXT.P: The ban on interracial marriage brokerage to be implemented by the government is "the right thing to do, " but accompanying measures and enforcement of the law are even more important, a Vietnamese representative in Taiwan said Friday.

The Vietnamese government has always opposed interracial marriage brokerage, said Nguyen Cong Manh, deputy head of the Vietnam Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (VECO) -- the Vietnamese representative office in Taiwan.

Nguyen was responding to an amendment to the Immigration Law in which legislators agreed Thursday to put an end to the controversial interracial marriage brokerage industry. Effective immediately, cross-border marriage brokers will be banned from doing business and offenders will be subject to punishment.
There are approximately 100,000 Vietnamese women married to Taiwanese men living in Taiwan at present, and one in three foreign spouses in Taiwan comes from Vietnam, Nguyen said.

"While most of them have happy marriages, there's no denying that problems such as abuse, fraudulent marriages and human smuggling are happening, which is why we, as a government, agree with the amendment, " he said.

The number of cross-border marriages between Taiwan and Vietnam reached a very high level from 1993-2003 before the Taiwan and Vietnam governments started implementing stricter regulations on marriage applications, Nguyen said, adding that the number has been stable ever since.

However, the demand was always there and Nguyen stressed that the governments of both sides will have to cooperate and work out a solution for those Taiwanese men who want to legally marry Vietnamese women.
"Otherwise, most of the brokerage companies will go `underground' and still do the same things under the guise of travel agencies or friendship societies," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE TO EMBARK ON ISLANDWIDE TOUR

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh will embark on an islandwide tour in three stages starting Saturday as a high-profile warm-up for the 2008 election.

Hsieh's campaign office staff said the first leg of the tour will last until mid-June. He is scheduled to visit Jenwu township in Kaohsiung County, Hsinpu township in Hsinchu County, Shengkang township in Taichung County, Wanan township in Penghu County, and Taitung County.
Hsieh will be showing his concern for the aboriginal and Hakka peoples, the outlying island and the distinctive industry of each place, according to his office.
In every place, Hsieh will speak at temples, hold a meeting under trees or meet local people to listen to their views for reference in chartering his platforms.

His tour will be in stark contrast to that of opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou, the staff said, noting that Ma's "bicycle around the island" tour last month, which covered 675 km from southern Taiwan to northern Taiwan, made only fleeting stops in each place.
Hsieh, who visited more than 200 villages and counties prior to the May 6 DPP presidential primary, will include the remaining villages and townships during his upcoming tour, his aides said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 INTERNATIONAL ATHLETICS MEET OPENS IN HSINCHU COUNTY

TEXT.P: The 2007 International Track and Field Invitational Meet is scheduled to open Saturday at the Hsinchu County Stadium, with more than 130 athletes from around the world taking part in two days of competition.
The athletes are from 12 countries, including Australia, Iran, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Thailand and the United States.

Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin held a press conference Friday to introduce some of the more well-known athletes from abroad, including Rosanna Ditton, a woman pole vaulter from Australia; Mohammed Samimi, a discus thrower from Iran; and Nobuharu Asahara, a Japanese athlete who specializes in the 100-meter sprint and the long jump.

Hsinchu County's stadium, completed in June 2005, is the only stadium in Taiwan that has won an environmentally "green" certification from the Helsinki-based International Association of Athletics Federations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEXT LEGISLATIVE ELECTION SET TO BE HELD JAN. 12: CEC

TEXT.P: The next legislative elections are set to take place next Jan. 12, a spokesman for the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Friday.
CEC Deputy Secretary-General Teng Tien-you made the announcement after a CEC commissioners meeting.

As the tenure of the current legislators will expire Jan. 31, 2008, Teng said, the next Legislative Yuan must be elected before Jan. 21 to meet the provision of the current Public Officials Election and Recall Act that succeeding public functionaries must be elected 10 days before the expiration of incumbents' tenure.

According to a proposed amendment to the Public Officials Election and Recall Act being mulled by the legislature, only those who have resided in a specific constituency for six months are eligible to vote.
Against this backdrop, Teng said, the voting date for the next legislative election must be decided six months in advance. As a result, Dec. 1 this year will have to be excluded.

A consensus reached at a special meeting held by the Executive Yuan last October to review electoral affairs concluded that the voting date for central and local elections should be set either for the second or fourth Saturday of the selected month.
"Taking all these factors into account, Jan. 12 is the most suitable day for the next legislative election," Teng explained.

As to whether the next legislative and presidential elections should be held simultaneously, Teng said it will be put forward for the next CEC commissioners to decide. The term of the present CEC commissioners will expire June 16.
Lawmakers from both the ruling and opposition camps generally approved of the CEC's choice of Jan. 12 for the next legislative elections.

As to whether the legislative and presidential elections should be held on the same day, Hsu Shao-ping, a main opposition Kuomintang legislative caucus whip, said the KMT would support either option so long as consensus is reached among lawmakers of all political stripes.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers had yet to reach consensus on the issue. According to DPP Legislator Wang Shu-hui, her colleagues from southern Taiwan constituencies tend to support the combination of the two critical elections to save social costs, while DPP lawmakers from northern districts generally oppose the proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL FEDERATION OF JOURNALISTS BACKS TAIWAN COVERING WHA
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, June 1 (CNA) 06/01/07 23:16:16 (By Chang Hung-kuang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: The International Federation of Journalists (IFJ) passed a resolution Friday in support of Taiwanese reporters' rights to cover the World Health Assembly (WHA).
The IFJ also condemned the United Nations for discriminating against Taiwanese reporters in this regard.

The moves came after the Association of Taiwan Journalists (ATJ) initiated a proposal at the IFJ World Congress in Moscow to win the IFJ's backing of Taiwanese reporters' rights to cover the annual WHA, the decision-making arm of the World Health Organization (WHO).
More than 100 member countries passed the proposal, while issuing a condemnation on the U.N.'s refusal to give Taiwanese journalists WHA press passes.

The U.N. has refused to issue the press passes since 2004 on the grounds that Taiwan is not a U.N. member and is thus not allowed to enter any U.N. building, ATJ President Chen Hsiao-yi said at the congress.
The U.N. has violated the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and sacrificed the freedom of the press, Chen said, adding that the Taiwan people should be entitled to such rights.

Also noting that Taiwan withdrew from the U.N. in 1971, but the U.N. waited until 2004 to shut Taiwan out of the WHA, Chen attributed the reason to the fact that the U.N. came under pressure from China.

The IFJ passed the proposal unanimously and agreed to continue to mount pressure on the U.N. and to ask the U.N. to agree to allow Taiwanese reporters with international press passes issued by the IFJ to cover the WHA.
Delegates from China attended the congress but make no comments.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE AIRPORTS MIGHT BE INCLUDED IN CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER SERVICES: MAC

TEXT.P: Apart from the two major international airports in northern and southern Taiwan, airports in other parts of the country will also be assessed for future direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Friday.
MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun made the comment during a routine news conference.

Liu's remarks came after President Chen Shui-bian told Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu earlier in the day during a meeting at the Presidential Office that the central government will definitely include Chingchuankang Airport in Taichung County for evaluation for its cross-strait charter service plan.
"The greater Taichung area in central Taiwan must not be excluded from the central government's cross-strait cargo and passenger charter service program," Chen pledged.

In response to the president's comments, Liu said that airports in the rest of Taiwan, such as Chingchuankang Airport and Makung Airport on the outlying island of Penghu, will also be included in the program if their facilities can be improved to international standards.

However, he went on, Taoyuan Taiwan International Airport and Kaohsiung International Airport have to date been the two major airports considered for opening direct cross-strait charter services. Taiwan and China have held seven rounds of negotiations concerning the issue.

"More airports in Taiwan could be included in the cargo and passenger charter service program in the future after the ongoing bilateral negotiations surrounding the two main airports in Taiwan and their counterparts in China have wrapped up, " Liu said, adding that "it will be more pragmatic to touch on other airports only after the talks centered on the Taoyuan and Kaohsiung airports are complete."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES FUNDS FOR PANAMA TO BUILD SCHOOLS, REPAIR ROADS
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, June 1 (CNA) 06/02/07 01:27:59 (By Ramon Huang and Sofia)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has donated funds for the Panamanian government to build elementary schools in remote rural regions, repair highway surfaces and expand prison facilities as part of a bilateral cooperation program between the two countries.
Hou Ping-fu, the Republic of China ambassador to Panama, presented the funds on behalf of the ROC government in a ceremony held at Panama's Ministry of Foreign Affairs Thursday.

Panamanian first lady Vivian Fernandez de Torrijos, Minister of Public Works Benjamin Colamarco and Minister of the Interior and Justice Olga Golcher received the donations on behalf of the Panamanian government. All of them delivered "thank-you" speeches at the ceremony in appreciation of the ROC government's generous aid.

A portion of the aid will finance construction of 90 elementary schools in remote countryside as the Panamanian government is actively promoting compulsory education in the country's rural and distant communities, Hou said.

The fund will also be used to finance a project to repair a 20-kilometer section of a highway leading to the indigenous community of Darien in eastern Panama, Hou said, adding that the repair project will make it easier for aborigines to go to see doctor in urban areas and help improve their living conditions.
As many of Panama's prisons are overcrowded, Hou said the remaining fund will be used to foot the bills for a prison facility expansion and renovation project.
"All of these aid projects are based on humanitarianism aimed at helping disadvantaged children receive education as well as assisting in renovating Panama's public facilities," Hou added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 2, or the 17th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1886: Grover Stephen Cleveland, the 22nd and 24th president of the United States, marries Francis Folsom in the White House. He was known as an honest independent president opposed to corruption and the "spoils" system.
1896: Italian engineer and inventor Guglielmo Marconi patents in London his wireless telegraph apparatus, a device that transmits spoken messages over long distances without the aid of wires or cables. He shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics after transmitting long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean in 1901.
1904: Johnny Weissmuller, American and Olympic swimming champion, is born. He later turned to acting, playing Tarzan in many films.
1922: Hsu Shih-chang resigns as president of the Beijing government.
1927: Wang Kuo-wei, a master in the study of Chinese literary classics, commits suicide at the age of 50 by jumping into Kunming Lake in the Yi-ho Garden in Beijing. The garden was built by Empress Dowager Tsu Hsi at the end of the Ching dynasty.
1942: Chinese Foreign Minister T.V. Soong and U.S. Secretary of State Cordell Hull sign the Sino-American Lend-Lease Agreement in Washington.
1953: The Archbishop of Canterbury at London's Westminster Abbey lowers the crown of St. Edward onto the head of Princess Elizabeth Alexandra Mary, making her Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The ceremony marks the first televised coronation.
1964: The Palestine Liberation Organization is formed in Jerusalem.
1966: Surveyor I, a U.S. automated spacecraft, lands in the southwest sector of the moon's Oceanus Procellanum and begins sending back the first close-up pictures of the moon's surface.
1969: The Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne collides with the U.S. destroyer Frank E. Evans in the South China Sea, killing 74 American sailors.
1973: A three-nation invitational basketball tournament opens in Taipei.
1974: China Airlines starts all-cargo services to the United States' West Coast.
1974: Jig Singhi Wangchuk, 18, is crowned king of Bhutan, becoming the youngest monarch in the world.
1976: Dr. Adnan Khasoggi, chairman of the Saudi Arabian Triad Holding Corporation, and a party of 20 members arrive in Taipei to explore investment possibilities.
1979: Pope John Paul II, the first non-Italian to be elected pope in 456 years, sets foot again on the soil of his native Poland to an emotional welcome. The pope's visit marks a major opening-up in the relationship between the Roman Catholic church and the countries of the Communist bloc.
1983: The ROC Executive Yuan approves a revision to raise by tenfold the compensation for "wrongful detentions and executions."
1984: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Chiu Chuang-huan, former vice premier, as commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly and, concurrently, as governor of Taiwan Province.
1985: English football clubs are banned indefinitely from playing in Europe because of hooliganism by English fans abroad.
1985: Hu Nai-yen, an ROC violinist residing in the United States, wins an international music contest held in Belgium.
1990: British actor Sir Rex Harrison dies at the age of 82. He is best remembered for his role as Professor Henry Higgins in the musical "My Fair Lady," a part that he played both on Broadway and on the London stage as well as in the 1964 film version, for which he won a Tony and also an Academy Award.
1992: Representatives from 185 nations take part in the world's largest environmental summit in Rio De Janeiro, Brazil.
1999: Women in Japan finally win the right to use the birth control pill.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh accepts President Chen Shui-bian's appointment to head a supra-party task force on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
2000: Kaohsiung Mayor Hsieh Chang-ting is the sole candidate in the running for Democratic Progressive Party chairman, as the official registration deadline ends today.
2001: The Chinese-Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) and the Mongolian Olympic Committee sign a sports cooperation and exchange agreement in Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure in dissipation, in extravagance, in mere conviviality, are injurious."

: The Straits Times: Climate change a long-term security threat: PM.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong yesterday highlighted a new dimension to the problem of climate change. He sees it as a potential long- term threat to world security, not just an economic or environmental worry.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Climate change may provoke the international conflict: warned PM Lee.
