Between countries, competition for scarce resources and displacement of populations across borders can deepen tensions, and provoke conflict and wars, warned Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong yesterday in his speech at sixth Asia Security Conferencel.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEXT LEGISLATIVE ELECTION SET TO BE HELD JAN. 12: CEC

TEXT.P: The next legislative elections are set to take place next Jan. 12, a spokesman for the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Friday.
CEC Deputy Secretary-General Teng Tien-you made the announcement after a CEC commissioners meeting.

As the tenure of the current legislators will expire Jan. 31, 2008, Teng said, the next Legislative Yuan must be elected before Jan. 21 to meet the provision of the current Public Officials Election and Recall Act that succeeding public functionaries must be elected 10 days before the expiration of incumbents' tenure.

According to a proposed amendment to the Public Officials Election and Recall Act being mulled by the legislature, only those who have resided in a specific constituency for six months are eligible to vote.
Against this backdrop, Teng said, the voting date for the next legislative election must be decided six months in advance. As a result, Dec. 1 this year will have to be excluded.

A consensus reached at a special meeting held by the Executive Yuan last October to review electoral affairs concluded that the voting date for central and local elections should be set either for the second or fourth Saturday of the selected month.
"Taking all these factors into account, Jan. 12 is the most suitable day for the next legislative election," Teng explained.

As to whether the next legislative and presidential elections should be held simultaneously, Teng said it will be put forward for the next CEC commissioners to decide. The term of the present CEC commissioners will expire June 16.
Lawmakers from both the ruling and opposition camps generally approved of the CEC's choice of Jan. 12 for the next legislative elections.

As to whether the legislative and presidential elections should be held on the same day, Hsu Shao-ping, a main opposition Kuomintang legislative caucus whip, said the KMT would support either option so long as consensus is reached among lawmakers of all political stripes.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers had yet to reach consensus on the issue. According to DPP Legislator Wang Shu-hui, her colleagues from southern Taiwan constituencies tend to support the combination of the two critical elections to save social costs, while DPP lawmakers from northern districts generally oppose the proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL FEDERATION OF JOURNALISTS BACKS TAIWAN COVERING WHA
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, June 1 (CNA) 06/02/07 12:52:41 (By Chang Hung-kuang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: The International Federation of Journalists (IFJ) passed a resolution Friday in support of Taiwanese reporters' rights to cover the World Health Assembly (WHA).
The IFJ also condemned the United Nations for discriminating against Taiwanese reporters in this regard.

The moves came after the Association of Taiwan Journalists (ATJ) initiated a proposal at the IFJ World Congress in Moscow to win the IFJ's backing of Taiwanese reporters' rights to cover the annual WHA, the decision-making arm of the World Health Organization (WHO).
More than 100 member countries passed the proposal, while issuing a condemnation on the U.N.'s refusal to give Taiwanese journalists WHA press passes.

The U.N. has refused to issue the press passes since 2004 on the grounds that Taiwan is not a U.N. member and is thus not allowed to enter any U.N. building, ATJ President Chen Hsiao-yi said at the congress.
The U.N. has violated the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and sacrificed the freedom of the press, Chen said, adding that the Taiwan people should be entitled to such rights.

Also noting that Taiwan withdrew from the U.N. in 1971, but the U.N. waited until 2004 to shut Taiwan out of the WHA, Chen attributed the reason to the fact that the U.N. came under pressure from China.

The IFJ passed the proposal unanimously and agreed to continue to mount pressure on the U.N. and to ask the U.N. to agree to allow Taiwanese reporters with international press passes issued by the IFJ to cover the WHA.
Delegates from China attended the congress but make no comments.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE AIRPORTS MIGHT BE INCLUDED IN CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER SERVICES: MAC

TEXT.P: Apart from the two major international airports in northern and southern Taiwan, airports in other parts of the country will also be assessed for future direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Friday.
MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun made the comment during a routine news conference.

Liu's remarks came after President Chen Shui-bian told Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu earlier in the day during a meeting at the Presidential Office that the central government will definitely include Chingchuankang Airport in Taichung County for evaluation for its cross-strait charter service plan.
"The greater Taichung area in central Taiwan must not be excluded from the central government's cross-strait cargo and passenger charter service program," Chen pledged.

In response to the president's comments, Liu said that airports in the rest of Taiwan, such as Chingchuankang Airport and Makung Airport on the outlying island of Penghu, will also be included in the program if their facilities can be improved to international standards.

However, he went on, Taoyuan Taiwan International Airport and Kaohsiung International Airport have to date been the two major airports considered for opening direct cross-strait charter services. Taiwan and China have held seven rounds of negotiations concerning the issue.

"More airports in Taiwan could be included in the cargo and passenger charter service program in the future after the ongoing bilateral negotiations surrounding the two main airports in Taiwan and their counterparts in China have wrapped up, " Liu said, adding that "it will be more pragmatic to touch on other airports only after the talks centered on the Taoyuan and Kaohsiung airports are complete."

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD DRUG BUSTERS MEET IN TAIPEI ON ANTI-NARCOTICS COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Narcotics hazard control officers and experts from major countries around the world gathered in Taipei Saturday to discuss strategies for the promotion of international cooperation in drug-fighting.

It was the fifth forum held as part of the 2007 International Drug Control Symposium co-sponsored by the Ministry of Justice (MOJ), the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Education and the Department of Health.

Saturday's forum, moderated by MOJ Bureau of Investigation Director Yeh Sheng- mao, focused on developments and trends in drug-related crime in East Asia as well as on the promotion of international cooperation in narcotics hazard control.

Drug-fighting officers and experts from the United States, Canada, France, Australia, Japan and major Southeast Asian countries were invited to address related topics and exchange experiences in fighting relevant criminal activities.

Among the keynote speakers were Datuk Mohd Bakri bin Mohd Zinin, deputy director of the drug crime investigation division of the Royal Malaysian Police; Sukhum Opasniputh, a division chief under Thailand's Narcotics Control Commission; and Eiyoshi One, a Japan Coast Guard division chief in charge of international organized crime.
The trio delivered speeches on the latest drug crime trends and their countries' drug-fighting policies and achievements.
Wang Hua-fu, director of the Bureau of Investigation's narcotics control center, spoke on cross-border drug trafficking trends and Taiwan's response measures.
In addition to holding the international seminar, the MOJ will call a national meeting on narcotics hazard prevention and control Sunday to mark the traditional June 3 Opium Suppression Movement Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROCUREMENT DELEGATIONS TO VISIT D.C. NEXT WEEK
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 1 (CNA) 06/02/07 13:48:29 (By Michelle Tsai and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Two procurement delegations formed by Taiwan's agricultural and industrial sectors respectively are scheduled to visit Washington D.C. next week, officials at Taiwan's representative office in the United States said Friday.

During their stay in the U.S. capital June 5-7, the delegations will call on U.S. government officials and members of Congress and sign letters of intent or agreements with their U.S. counterparts for the procurement of various agricultural and industrial products, the officials said.

The agricultural delegation is expected to sign four letters of intent with the U.S. side for the procurement of soy beans, corn, wheat and beef for 2008 and 2009 -- deals worth a total of US$3.9 billion, up US$800 million compared with the amount for 2006 and 2007, the officials said.
The industrial delegation will sign agreements with the U.S. side for the procurement of seven industrial products worth a total of US$127.09 million, the officials said.

The officials noted that Taiwan is the fifth largest overseas market for U.S. agricultural products and that this is the sixth time that Taiwan has sent similar agricultural delegations to the United States.

The latest agricultural delegation, comprised of 18 members led by World Vegetable Center Chairman Paul Sun, is scheduled to visit the United States from June 4-16. Other members of the delegation include representatives from the Taiwan Vegetable Oil Manufacturers Association, the Taiwan Feed Industry Association, the Taiwan Flour Mills Association, Uni-President Enterprises Corp. and Game Meat Industrial Co.

The industrial delegation, which is visiting the United States from May 28 to June 8, is being led by Bureau of Foreign Trade Director-General Huang Chih- peng. While in Washington, D.C., Huang is expected to hold round-table discussion with U.S. business representatives to seek their support for the establishment of a Taiwan-U.S. free trade agreement.
Other members of the 10-member delegation include executives of Aerospace Industrial Development Corp., CPC Corp., China Steel Corp., and Taiwan Power Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUG-RELATED CRIME SERIOUS IN TAIWAN: INVESTIGATION BUREAU

TEXT.P: The rampant drug trafficking activities and rising repeat rate of drug-related crime in Taiwan remain major challenges for law enforcement authorities in the country, an Investigation Bureau official said Saturday.

Speaking during the 2007 International Drug Control Symposium held in Taipei, Wang Hua-fu, director of the bureau's narcotics control center, noted that heroin, amphetamine and ketamine accounted for the largest amount among all the kinds of illicit drugs seized by Taiwan police over the past four years.
In the most recent two years, the amount of ketamine seized by police has been increasing rapidly, making it the most common abused substance in the country, Wang said.
According to Wang, since China stepped up its crackdown operations against amphetamine abuse in 2000, many amphetamine producers have moved back to Taiwan or to Southeast Asian countries.
The fact that the Investigation Bureau has arrested many amphetamine makers over the past several years in Taiwan indicates that amphetamine production is still very prevalent here, Wang said.

Meanwhile, new kinds of abused substances, such as ecstasy pills, flunitrazepam, nimetazepam, zolpidem and surazepam, have been discovered by police during their raids on bubble tea houses, KTV parlors, bars and night clubs, Wang said, adding that there is a rising trend among drug users to take several kinds of illicit drugs at one time to enhance the intoxicating effect.

Compared with traditional drugs, the emerging synthetic drugs are cheaper and more lucrative because of their low production costs, which increases their potential of being abused by a greater number of people in the future, he warned.

Over the last five years, the ratio of repeat or serial drug-related crime has averaged more than 65 percent, and it is rising every year, with the ratio registering more than 70 percent for 2005, he said.

The symposium was organized by the Ministry of Justice, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Education and the Department of Health, with the participants including drug-fighting officers and experts from the United States, Canada, France, Australia, Japan and major Southeast Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Seeking to quell a fresh row in his fratious ruling coalition, Italian Premier Romano Prodi announced Friday after an emergency meeting of his Cabinet that Vice Finance Minister Vincenzo Visco had renounced his mandate over tax police and that tax police chief Roberto Speciale was to be moved to a new post. Speciale accused Visco of pressuring him to transfer several of his officers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-GREEN CAMP' YET TO DECIDE ON COMBINING ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The 'pan-green camp" led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has yet to forge a consensus on whether to hold the next legislative and presidential elections simultaneously.

Wang Tuoh, a major whip in the party's legislative caucus, said Saturday that although he expects the DPP to support a combining of the elections, the party has yet to reach a consensus on the matter.
Wang's remarks came one day after the Central Election Commission (CEC) decided that the next legislative elections will be held Jan. 12, 2008.
As the term of the present CEC commissioners will expire June 16, they left the question of whether to hold the legislative elections alongside the 2008 presidential election to the next CEC.

Wang said the DPP should approve the combining of the elections, otherwise the party will face difficulties in the legislative elections, especially because the party's legislative candidates produced through a controversial primary may not have a broad base of support and will have to rely on the presidential election to build up the momentum of support for the party.

If the two elections are held separately, the DPP will have difficulty winning more than half of the seats in the streamlined legislative elections, which in turn will be detrimental to the party's chances in the presidential election, according to Wang.

Kuo Lin-yung, a major party whip of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, said that the legislative elections are traditionally held in December, and the CEC's decision to hold the legislative elections later than usual is probably due to the fact that it is working in tune with the wishes of the DPP.
Kuo urged the DPP to coordinate with his party, saying that holding the elections simultaneously will be favorable to the major political parties fielding presidential candidates.
The major opposition Kuomintang should also coordinate with its ally, the People First Party, on the matter, Kuo added.
However, DPP Legislator Jao Yung-ching said that for caution's sake, it is better to discuss the matter thoroughly.

Jao said that if a new president is elected in January, he will have to wait for four months to assume the presidency in May, which the legislator noted will pose problems for the current president as well as cause difficulties in the transferring of power.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Warning over fake high street medicines Thousands of patients taking a life-saving cancer medicine have been warned that counterfeits have entered the supply chain.
Drug regulators issued the alert yesterday after the discovery of fake batches of Casodex, a prostate cancer drug, after an alarming surge in counterfeit medications for critical conditions. The alert is the third in a week involving blockbuster drugs, which have also included a schizophrenia drug and a blood- thinning agent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-LANGUAGE SMOKING CESSATION WEB SITE SET TO OPEN JUNE 3

TEXT.P: A Chinese-language smoking cessation Web site set up by the John Tung Foundation will officially open Sunday, foundation officials said Saturday.

Foundation CEO Chou Yi-heng said the group came up with the idea of establishing the Web site to help smokers quit the habit after seeing that many anti-smoking organizations in Canada, Australia, Britain and the United States have made similar moves.
However, as most of the existing smoking cessation Web sites are in English, they are of little help to ethnic Chinese communities, Chou said.
He said the Web site to be launched by the foundation targets the 350 million smokers in China, 5 million in Taiwan and 800,000 in Hong Kong.
In the initial stage, the Web site can only be viewed in traditional Chinese characters, and the simplified Chinese character version will be available in October, Chou said.
In one of the services to be provided, the Web site has prepared a total 56 letters written by smoking cessation experts for delivery to smokers planning to quit smoking, he said.
With each smoker expected to receive one letter a day, the service is aimed at helping smokers overcome the physical or mental discomfort experienced in the process of quitting the habit, Chou said.
Kuo fei-jang, a family physician at National Taiwan University Hospital, pointed out that the assistance of experts is essential for smokers to persist in their efforts to quit the habit.

While less than 5 percent of smokers can succeed in quitting smoking on their own within six months, the success rate increases to 10 percent for those that have consulted with doctors, and further to 20 percent for those who participate in a smoking cessation program provided as part of the outpatient service at certain hospitals, Kuo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER AGAINST REDUCING CITIZENSHIP WAITING PERIOD FOR PRC SPOUSES

TEXT.P: A legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday that for the sake of national security, the waiting period for Chinese spouses of Taiwan nationals to obtain ROC citizenship should not be shortened to four years from the present eight years.

DPP Legislator Chang Ching-hui made the remarks as a Legislative Yuan committee is set to review an opposition-initiated draft amendment to the Statute Governing the Relations between the Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area June 6 to cut the waiting period in half.
Chang said that the DPP, as the ruling party, should consider the views of the Mainland Affairs Council and the Ministry of the Interior before deciding on how to deal with the issue.

She said that in addition to considering national security, one should also consider the cross-strait situation and the population density in Taiwan, adding that she has reservations about the amendment, especially in the wake of reports of Chinese women coming to Taiwan to engage in prostitution under the guise of marriage to Taiwan citizens.

The current regulations state that Chinese spouses of Taiwan citizens can apply to stay in Taiwan as a dependent after being married for two years. After an additional four years of residing in Taiwan for at least 183 days in each of those years, they can apply for a long-stay visa. After two more years, they can apply for citizenship, if they do not have a criminal record.
Main opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chu Feng-chi, who is one of the authors of the draft amendment, said that the waiting period should be shortened based on human rights considerations.

Another KMT legislator, Lee Chin-an, noted that under the current immigration law, foreign spouses of Taiwan citizens can obtain ROC IDs after four years, questioning why Chinese spouses have to wait for eight years.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CAR-FREE' TOUR LAUNCHED TO RAISE ENVIRONMENTAL AWARENESS

TEXT.P: To promote the idea of a "Car-free Asia" and environmental awareness, 20 people from around the world, including eight from Taiwan, will launch a four-month "car-free" tour from Beijing to Paris, traveling on bicycle most of the way, on June 10 at Beijing's Tiananman Square.

The "Beijing to Paris (B2P) Car-free" tour is about "celebrating better mobility, " said Wu Yi-ting, one of the participants in the event, along with New Zealander Olly Powell, at a press conference. As the first group of participants have already started their tour, in April, Wu said, the second group will start the 100,000-kilometer expedition June 10, adding that they expect to arrive in Paris in October.

In 1907, three Italians completed the first Beijing-Paris trip by automobile. Wu and Powell came up with the idea of traveling the same route because "automobile transportation has changed the world in many ways and changed people's way of life, led to over-consumption of energy, and destroyed the environment, " said Wu, who has been living a carefree life and who has cycled across South America.

"This event will draw attention to one of the most important issues today. Nothing is more important than the issue of global warming. If we don't change the way we live, we'll have to build a memorial hall for the life we lost, " said Canadian composer Matthew Lien, who has been vocal on environmental issues and who has voiced support for the event.

The goal of this activity is to travel without cars or "support vehicles, " but it's up to the individual participants to make their travel plans and choose their routes. Most participants have indicated they will cycle all the way. Others will take trains and ferries on some sections of the journey.

Thus far, there are three likely three routes that will be traveled. Some participants are planning to go via the "middle route" -- through China, Kyrgystan, Kazakhstan, Russia and Poland. Wu and the other participants from Taiwan will take a more northern route to avoid visa complications in Eastern Europe and will enter Europe via Finland. Some participants have suggested that they will take the classic Silk Road route, via Central Asia, Iran and Turkey.

"This event gives me the opportunity to fulfill my lifelong dream of cycling from Asia to Europe and to raise environmental awareness among Taiwanese, " said 32-year-old Aaron Huang, who quit his job of 15 years as an Air Force mechanic to take part in the activity.
"Hopefully, I can arrive in Paris on September 22 -- which is World Car-free Day, " Huang said.
A number of representatives of environmental groups, as well as the chairman of Mongolia's Green Party Erdenechuluun Zorigt, also attended the press conference to show their support for the event.
"This initiative by a Taiwanese girl gives us a perfect example of Taiwan's meaningful participation in international affairs, " said Pan Hen-sheng, secretary-general of the Green Party Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOLUNTEERS TO HELP NEW IMMIGRANTS ADJUST TO LIFE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: More than 80 volunteers will start paying home visits in July to new immigrant families in Taipei City and Taipei County in a program that seeks to help new arrivals adjust to Taiwan's environment and culture, organizers said Saturday.

The volunteers, who are mostly retired workers, will try to collect information and learn about the problems that foreign spouses face and tell stories to children in their upcoming home visits under the program organized by the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, said Huang Juo-sung, executive director of the foundation.
Four foreign spouses -- three from Vietnam and one from Indonesia -- and two men who are married to Vietnamese women are among the most notable volunteers in the program.

Huynh Trang Phuong Thuy, who came to Taiwan five years ago when she was just 20, said she decided to join the program because she understands how difficult it is adjusting to a new environment. As happy and comfortable as she is now, Huynh said she felt the urge to reach out a helping hand to her "Vietnamese sisters."
Lin Jian-chung, who is married to a Vietnamese women, also joined the program, determined to help thousands of new immigrant families like his own.
Meanwhile, Yen Wei-te, a graduate student at National Taiwan University, said he joined the program "to involve myself more in social activities, rather than just focusing on studying."

Volunteers like Huynh Trang, Lin and Yen will be assigned to different regions, such as Sanchong and Sindian, and provide counseling, story-telling and Chinese-language learning book distributing services. Having received just three days of training and being fully aware of the possibility of being turned away at the door on their visits to the homes of new immigrants, the volunteers said they are still upbeat about the task they will embark upon Saturday.
"This is only the beginning of a massive and important project that tries to respond to a national issue, " said Huang.

According to Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) statistics, an estimated average of 12,000 Vietnamese women arrive in Taiwan every year in mixed marriages, Huang said, adding that currently, one out of every four babies born in Taiwan is born into a new immigrant family.

"The new immigrant issue has been ranked in the top three of the ten most important social issues of the future by analysts and observers, which means the government and civil groups have to look at and deal with the issue seriously as soon as possible, " he noted.
The program is mainly being sponsored by Cathay Life Charity Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TO REMAIN IN HOSPITAL FOR TWO MORE WEEKS

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, who has been hospitalized since suffering a minor stroke April 26, will remain in hospital for two more weeks for further rehabilitation, a city government official said Saturday.

According to Hsiao Yu-cheng, director of the Kaohsiung City government's Department of Information, Chen's doctors at the Kaohsiung Medical Hospital advised Chen to build up strength in her right leg and lose more weight before being discharged from the hospital.

"Accepting her doctors' advice, the mayor has decided to stay at the hospital until mid-June," Hsiao said, adding that Chen originally asked to be discharged June 4 in order to be able to attend the closing ceremony of the city council's current session on June 7.
Hsiao said Chen has been recovering well. Quoting an assessment by Chen's medical team, Hsiao said Chen can now easily walk 100 to 200 meters.

"But the doctors hope that the mayor can stay for two more weeks to gain more strength in her right leg so that she will be able to stand for longer periods of time and walk farther, " Hsiao said, adding that the doctors also want to see Chen shed some pounds before being discharged from the hospital.
Hsiao said Chen now attends three rehabilitation sessions per day, including cycling on a stationary bike, walking up and down a set of stairs, and embroidering.
Noting that all these rehab programs have borne satisfactory results, Hsiao said Chen's condition has greatly improved. "She now can read and sign official documents as usual," he added.

At present, Hsiao said, important documents are forwarded to Chen by Deputy Mayor Chiu Tai-san. In some cases, department chiefs are required to brief the mayor on certain key projects to avoid delay in processing.
Over the past month, Hsiao said, Chen has occasionally made inspection tours of some city development projects in the company of her aides and security guards or visited her personal friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:U.S. Puts Limits on Lenders' Ties to Universities @ The Education Department, criticized for lax oversight of student loans, released proposed rules yesterday that would set new standards for universities and ban lenders' marketing practices that have resulted, in some cases, in loan company payoffs to university officials.
The 225-page package represents a change in direction by the department, which for years had ignored calls by its inspector general, Democratic lawmakers and even some loan-industry officials for it to be more aggressive in policing the $85 billion student loan industry.
Wall Street Journal: Behind the Bancrofts' Shift at Dow Jones
When members of Dow Jones & Co.'s controlling Bancroft family gathered 10 days ago for a meeting at a Boston hotel, they expected a fight. Some wanted to entertain a $5 billion bid for the company by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp., but Michael Elefante, a powerful Dow Jones director and family trustee, had opposed it.
Instead of a rebuff, the family members got a huge surprise: Mr. Elefante had switched sides. @ Mr. Elefante, a partner at a law firm that had represented the family for decades, told the group that for Dow Jones to remain competitive, he now believed the family needed to explore a sale to Mr. Murdoch or another bidder, according to people familiar with the presentation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MEDICAL EQUIPMENT EXPORTS UP 10.77 PERCENT IN Q1

TEXT.P: Taiwan exported NT$6.79 billion (US$205.75 million) worth of medical equipment in the first quarter of this year, up 10.77 percent over the level for the same period last year, the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) of Taiwan said Saturday.

ITRI analyst Wu Hsin-jui said the growth was due mainly to an increase in export orders, noting that international medical equipment giants have continued to subcontract their orders to counterparts in the Pacific and that demand in emerging markets has continued to increase.

Taiwan's main medical equipment exports included vehicles for disabled people, accounting for NT$630 million, or 15.1 percent, of the total, as well as parts and accessories for medical instruments, other equipment for experimental use or medical treatment, and contact lenses.

Taiwan also imported NT$8.52 billion worth of medical equipment in the first quarter, down 0.93 percent from NT$8.6 billion for the same period last year. Taiwan mainly imported catheters, canular, contact lenses, artificial dialysis equipment, artificial bones, parts and accessories for dentistry and other physiotherapy massager.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW GROUP FOUNDED TO AROUSE YOUTH PASSION FOR TAIWAN IDENTITY

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Taiwan Society launched a new organization Saturday to promote Taiwan-centric consciousness among young people.
The new organization, named Taiwan Youth Society, will focus on recruiting people aged between 18 and 35 as its members, Taiwan Society President Wu Shu- ming said.

According to Wu, the Taiwan Society comprises more than 100 like-minded social groups, with glorifying Taiwan culture and deepening Taiwan identity as its main purposes. These lofty goals, however, cannot be materialized without the participation of young people, he added.
"Therefore, we decided to form the Taiwan Youth Society to arouse youth passion and love for Taiwan identity, " Wu said at the new group's inaugural ceremony.

Wu said he keenly hopes that the new society can succeed in attracting young people to join its ranks as Taiwan badly needs a new generation of leaders who are broad-minded, forward-looking and full of fresh ideas and new visions to help break diplomatic isolation imposed by China.

Hsu Shun-pin, president of the Taiwan Youth Society, said the new society will help young people better understand Taiwan while promoting Taiwan identity through cultural, arts, musical and historical studies.

Many young politicians, including National Youth Commission Chairwoman Cheng Li- chun, Legislator Julian Kuo of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Lee Wen-ying, a DPP Taipei city councilor, attended the inaugural ceremony to throw their weight behind the new society.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 3, or the 18th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1839: China's Ching Commissioner Lin Tse-hsu orders the burning of the more than 20,000 chests of opium handed in by foreign merchants in Kwangtung, sparking the Opium War between China and the British. Since 1930, June 3 has been observed in China as Opium Suppression Movement Day.
1896: The Ching court and Russia sign a treaty in Moscow forming a defensive alliance for 15 years and granting Russia the rights to operate railways in northern Manchuria.
1899: Johann Strauss the Younger, Austrian conductor and composer of waltzes, dies at the age of 74. He is sometimes called "the Waltz King" and is best remembered for his numerous waltzes such as "The Blue Danube."
1924: Austrian writer Franz Kafka dies in a sanitarium in Kierling, near Vienna, at the age of only 40 after losing a seven-year battle with tuberculosis. The writer, whose stories include "The Trial" and "Metamorphosis," exerted a huge influence on modern writers.
1925: American actor Tony Curtis is born as Bernard Schwartz. His many films include "Some Like It Hot," "The Boston Strangler," "Spartacus" and "The Vikings."
1937: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the adoption of the KMT's party song as the national anthem of the Republic of China. The words of the ROC national anthem were first issued by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as his opening instruction to the students of Whampoa Military Academy on June 16, 1924.
1937: The Duke of Windsor, formerly King Edward VIII of Great Britain, marries his American sweetheart, Wallis Warfield Simpson, in Paris.
1942: The Battle of Midway, a turning point for the Allies in the war in the Pacific, begins. The U.S. Navy launches an attack against the Japanese fleet, sinking four Japanese aircraft carriers and battleships as well as six transport ships.
1946: Chen Kung-po, former acting president of the Nanking government, is executed for treason. The puppet regime had been established in China by breakaway government official Wang Ching-wei on March 29, 1940, and reorganized by Japan on Nov. 19, 1940.
1946: The first bikini goes on show in Paris.
1959: Singapore gains internal self-government under a new constitution, with Lee Kuan Yew, leader of the People's Action Party, as prime minister.
1965: Astronaut Edward H. White becomes the first American astronaut to take a walk in space when he steps outside his Gemini 4 spacecraft.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan, who was elected president of the Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement Committee to succeed late President Chiang Kai-shek, urges members of the committee to follow the example of the late president in propagating traditional Chinese culture.
1976: Shyzo Toda, president of the Japanese Chuo (Central) University, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: The 445,000-ton tanker Burmah Endeavour, built by the China Shipbuilding Corp. for U.S. Gatx Oswego, is launched at Kaohsiung. It is the world's third largest vessel.
1985: ROC nationals Chen Chi-le and Wu Tun are sentenced to life in prison by the Taiwan High Court for the murder of outspoken writer Liu Yi-liang, also known as Chiang Nan, in the United States.
1987: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves a revised draft of the ROC National Security Law.
1989: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, spiritual leader and head of the state of Iran, dies at the age of 86.
1991: Mt. Unzen erupts in Japan, killing some 40 people.
1994: An earthquake rocks Java, Indonesia, killing more than 170 people.
1998: A train derails in Lower Saxony, Germany, killing 98 people.
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen visits the offshore islands of Tungyin and Matsu, his first visit to the frontline islands since he assumed the post on May 20.
2001: Chang Jung-kung, director of the Kuomintang's Mainland Affairs Department, says that the 1989 crackdown on the unarmed pro-democracy students in Beijing's Tiananmen Square is a major factor which has driven the Chinese communists toward a more open society.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three kinds of errors to which men are liable when in the presence of their superiors. First, to speak out when one is not called upon to speak: that is called being forward. Second, to keep silent when called upon to speak: that is called being disingenuous. Third, to speak out without taking into consideration the expression in the eyes of the person spoken to: that is called blindness."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW GROUP FOUNDED TO AROUSE YOUTH PASSION FOR TAIWAN IDENTITY

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Taiwan Society launched a new organization Saturday to promote Taiwan-centric consciousness among young people.
The new organization, named Taiwan Youth Society, will focus on recruiting people aged between 18 and 35 as its members, Taiwan Society President Wu Shu- ming said.

According to Wu, the Taiwan Society comprises more than 100 like-minded social groups, with glorifying Taiwan culture and deepening Taiwan identity as its main purposes. These lofty goals, however, cannot be materialized without the participation of young people, he added.
"Therefore, we decided to form the Taiwan Youth Society to arouse youth passion and love for Taiwan identity, " Wu said at the new group's inaugural ceremony.

Wu said he keenly hopes that the new society can succeed in attracting young people to join its ranks as Taiwan badly needs a new generation of leaders who are broad-minded, forward-looking and full of fresh ideas and new visions to help break diplomatic isolation imposed by China.

Hsu Shun-pin, president of the Taiwan Youth Society, said the new society will help young people better understand Taiwan while promoting Taiwan identity through cultural, arts, musical and historical studies.

Many young politicians, including National Youth Commission Chairwoman Cheng Li- chun, Legislator Julian Kuo of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Lee Wen-ying, a DPP Taipei city councilor, attended the inaugural ceremony to throw their weight behind the new society.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REMAINS OPEN ON NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Sunday that he is open to the notion of a no- confidence vote by the Legislature to topple the Cabinet under his leadership.

Chang said he respects the ideas of the lawmakers and President Chen Shui-bian whether his Cabinet should be toppled so as to permit the president to dissolve the Legislature and have new legislators elected.
Chang made the remarks when he talked to reporters at Grand Hotel where he attended a national drug control conference.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Chen Chin-de -- indignant at long-term stand-off in the opposition-dominated Legislature, which he said has in turn seriously impeded administrative operations -- proposed last week a no-confidence vote so that the Chang-led Cabinet could be toppled to pave the way for President Chen to dissolve the Legislative Yuan.
Chen Chin-de's proposal was favorably received by DPP lawmakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAMESE WOMAN DEDICATED TO NARROWIING TAIWAN-VIETNAM GAP

TEXT.P: A Vietnamese woman married to a Taiwanese man is challenging the widely held idea among the Taiwanese that Southeast Asian wives are poor women with low education who can hardly speak Mandarin, as she has just earned a master's degree from the Graduate School of Family Studies and Child Development at Shih Chien University in Taipei and has vowed to serve as a cultural bridge between Taiwan and her homeland.

The circumstance that led Tran Thi Hoang Phuong to her master's began a decade ago when she was a student at the National Law School of Ho Chih Minh City in Vietnam. She worked part-time after school and encountered a young Taiwanese man, Chien Chih-chung, who was posted there by a Taiwanese firm.
She married Chien in 1993 and raised two children in Ho Chih Minh City until 2001, when she moved to Taipei with her husband.

As a university graduate with a bachelor's degree in law, Tran Thi has good command of Chinese language because of the affinity between Vietnamese law and Chinese law, which stood her in good stead while trying to adapt to life in Taipei.

However, she was annoyed by local news stories about "foreign brides" -- a term used by local people to refer to Southeast Asian women who married to Taiwanese -- as most of them are negative, portraying these women as being treated by their in-laws as tools for breeding, caring for disabled family members, earning money, or working as prostitutes.
In order to help those foreign brides, Tran Thi began to serve as a voluntary interpreter at the Women and Children's Hospital in Taipei, which has opened a clinic exclusively for foreign brides.

Tran Thi's experiences at the hospital offered her a chance to make friends with many Vietnamese women who confided in her about their miserable lives in Taiwan, mainly relating to getting along with husbands and in-laws, raising children, adapting to local society and obtaining social support.

From these women's stories, one gets the impression that Taiwanese are unfriendly, shameless and cruel, but Tran Thi thought this could not be right as she had seen many Taiwanese volunteers in the hospital who are generous, considerate and compassionate.

Believing the cause of the problem lies in the lack of understanding between Taiwanese men and their foreign spouses -- such men do not get to know their wives but simply buy them from brokers -- Tran Thi began to teach Vietnamese language voluntarily to help local people to know about her homeland, first in classes opened by the Taipei city government at the Wanhua Household Registration Office, then at the Chungshan Community College, National Open University and National Chen Chi University.
Her students include Vietnamese womens' husbands and children, businessmen interested in exploring the Vietnamese market and university students engaged in Southeast Asian studies.

At the same time she decided to enroll at the Shih Chien University graduate program because she wanted to offer professional counselling to foreign brides who encounter difficulties in marriage rather than just giving them a sympathetic ear.

While studying at Shih Chien University, she organized the Development Association of Vietnamese Women in Taipei and published the Vietnam Women monthly catering to her female compatriots living in Taiwan.
Tran Thi said local people should value the alien culture brought in by these foreign brides and put it to good use in enriching the culture of Taiwan.
The foreign brides, Tran Thi said, should be proud of their own culture and teach their children to treasure their opportunities of being exposed to two different cultures.
After getting the master's degree this summer, Tran Thi plans to pursue adoctoral degree so that she can help more people, not least the foreign brides.

DOC.TEXT:
: Bush's Push on Immigration Tests His Base
President Bush's advocacy of an immigration overhaul and his attacks on critics of the plan are provoking an unusually intense backlash from conservatives who form the bulwark of his remaining support, splintering his base and laying bare divisions within a party whose unity has been the envy of Democrats.
It has pitted some of Mr. Bush's most stalwart Congressional and grass-roots backers against him, inciting a vitriol that has at times exceeded anything seen yet between Mr. Bush and his supporters, who have generally stood with him through the toughest patches of his presidency. Those supporters now view him as pursuing amnesty for foreign law breakers when he should be focusing on border security. enditem

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER OPEN TO IDEA OF HOLDING NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Sunday that he is open to the notion of the Legislative Yuan holding a no-confidence vote against him to topple the Cabinet.

Legislator Chen Chin-de of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party proposed the no-confidence motion last week with the aim of toppling the Cabinet so as to allow President Chen Shui-bian to dissolve the legislature.

Premier Chang, speaking to reporters at the Grand Hotel after attending a national drug control conference, said he respects the ideas of the lawmakers and President Chen on whether the Cabinet should be toppled to pave the way for President Chen to dissolve the Legislature.
According to the Constitution, the president may, within 10 days after legislative approval of a no-confidence vote against the premier, dissolve the legislature.

As of Friday, a total of 46 of the 83 DPP lawmakers had endorsed Legislator Chen's motion, leaving it 26 signatures short of the one-third threshold required to send the motion to the legislature. Chen has said that he will continue to work to get more DPP lawmakers onboard.

On the reasons behind introducing the motion, Chen said that the long-term disorder in the "pan-blue alliance"-dominated Legislative Yuan has seriously hindered administrative operations, adding that "now is the time to put an end to the farce."
However, several DPP legislators have expressed doubts about the no-confidence motion proposal, which has also drawn flak from opposition lawmakers.

Ker Chien-ming, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said Saturday that it is strange that lawmakers from the ruling party are trying to topple the Cabinet, stressing that any major decision involving the party should be debated and passed by the DPP legislative caucus.
Lee Hung-chun, a spokesman for the opposition People First Party, asked the DPP Friday why it is aiming to hold a no-confidence vote against the premier, instead of against the president himself.

Meanwhile, Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) Central Policy Committee, said Sunday that the KMT will not make any response to the no-confidence motion proposal until it determines whether the proposal is "just a political facade" on the part of the DPP.

Responding to these reactions to his proposal, Chen Chin-de said Sunday that it is constructive that the DPP members have different opinions on issues, adding that this reflects the "nature of the DPP as a great party."
Chen, however, reiterated his resolve to continue working to get the required number of endorsement signatures for his no-confidence vote motion to be sent to the legislature.
According to the Constitution, a no-confidence vote should be held within three days after the motion is sent to the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH SPEED RAIL WELCOMES 5 MILLIONTH PASSENGER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) welcomed its 5 millionth passenger Sunday, five months after it launched its passenger service between Taipei and Kaohsiung, the two largest cities in Taiwan.

A 70-year-old passenger, identified as Chen Feng-hsiung, walked out of Panchiao Station a happy man after receiving his prizes -- a model high speed train and 10 business-class tickets valid for one year -- at a ceremony from Chia Hsian- teh, a deputy manager of the THSRC in charge of public relations.

Chen was traveling with his family and a group of 40 friends from his neighborhood in Changhua in central Taiwan. He said that he had booked the tickets for himself and his family at the end of May for a one-day sightseeing trip from Wujih in Taichung County to Panchiao and that he was surprised to be informed on the train that he was the 5 millionth passenger.
Chen said he had already ridden a high speed train six times and felt quite comfortable with the services, adding that he will use the 10 open-end tickets for more sight-seeing trips with his family.

The THSRC, which began its passenger service Jan. 5 this year, has twice increased the number of trains each day to enhance its services. On March 31, it increased the number of trains going in each direction from 19 to 25 per day. On June 1, the company again increased the number of trains in both directions from 25 to 31 daily.
THSRC executives said they estimate that the total number of high speed train passengers transported since Jan. 5 will surpass the 10 million mark in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-LEARNING GRANTS TO HELP BOLSTER INT'L EXCHANGES: GIO

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) defended its program to help foreign news workers study Chinese-language in Taiwan with scholarship Sunday, saying that it will help bolster international exchanges and eventually increase foreign media's understanding of the country.

The GIO is collaborating with the Ministry of Education to offer monthly grants of NT$25,000 (US$757) to each of the initial 10 recipients beginning in April, GIO Deputy Minister Yih Jung-tzung said in a written statement.

The Chinese learning program will let members of international media outlets perceive that Taiwan is the best place in the world to learn the Chinese language and gain a better understanding of Taiwan's democratization, the diversity of Taiwan society and amiability of the Taiwan people, Yih said.
As of April this year, Yih said, journalists from seven renowned media outlets in the United States, the United Kingdom, Germany, Japan, Turkey and Thailand had applied for the scholarships.

Yih described as "farfetched" an Apple Daily report Sunday claiming that the GIO is trying to "curry favor" with foreign reporters by offering them a three-month grant of NT$75,000 for the Chinese learning program, which at normal language centers operated by several leading universities would cost only around NT$30,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'YILAN RICE' WITH TASTE VALUE LABEL TO HIT MARKET

TEXT.P: The Yilan County government has decided to designate all the county grown rice to be harvested after July as "Yilan Rice" before putting it on the market as part of its efforts to develop the county's own brand, government officials said Sunday.

In addition to designating the rice as "Yilan Rice, " the government will also require that information about the rice be included, such as the "rice taste value, " on the package labels in order to enhance consumer confidence in the safety and quality of the products, according to the official.
The "rice taste value is obtained by using a near-infrared grain analyzer to study the chemical composition of the rice samples, the spokesman explained.

At present, there are many varieties of Yilan rice packaged under different names, including Dongnung Rice and Shanshui Rice by the Dongshan Farmers' Association, and Yuekuang Rice and Wunung Rice by the Wuchie Farmers' Association, making it difficult to ensure the quality of the rice products, the spokesman said.

Besides the package labeling requirement, the county government has also decided to adopt stricter measures to regulate the amount of chemical substances used in growing rice to further protect consumers, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL-EDITION DOLLS OF TAIWAN PITCHERS TO GO ON SALE

TEXT.P: A set of limited edition Wang Chien-ming and Kuo Hong-chih bobblehead dolls will be put up for sale islandwide beginning June 9 at 13 branches of the nation's largest retailer, the Shin Kong Mitsukoshi Department Store.

A spokesman for the department store chain said Sunday that Shin Kong Mitsukoshi has gained permission from U.S. Major League Baseball Properties to sell the dolls of Taiwan-born New York Yankees pitcher Wang and Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher Kuo in Taiwan.

A total of 1,000 special-edition Wang dolls and 1,000 Kuo dolls will be available in Taiwan, with another 6,500 Wang dolls and 4,000 Kuo dolls to be sold in other countries around the world, the spokesman added.

He also noted that sales of the dolls will be limited to one of each type per customer, adding that payment must be made in advance of June 9 and that the dolls will be delivered to customers in July.

He added that anyone hoping to get either doll with the serial number 1 will have to head to the Hsinyi New Life Square at the Shin Kong Mitsukoshi's Hsinyi branch for the chance of being the lucky customer, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF DRUG ABUSERS DECLINING SUBSTANTIALLY: JUSTICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The number of drug abusers in the country has substantially declined over the past one year following the launch of a new anti-narcotics program in June 2006, Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin said Sunday.

Eleven months after its implementation, the program -- focusing on reducing demand for illicit narcotics, rather than supply -- has helped cut the number of drug abusers put under observation in substance abuse prevention centers by 2,699, or 22.6 percent, Shih said in a speech at the opening of the 2007 National Drug Control Conference.
The program has also witnessed a decline in the number of drug abusers placed in substance abuse treatment programs at the centers by 355, or 12 percent, Shih added.
He said that the administration declared war on illicit drugs in 1993 but that it has only had limited success in its campaign.

The Executive Yuan Drug Control and Prevention Committee submitted a proposal last June to allow the government to adopt a new strategy to control and prevent illicit narcotics, and the sharp decline in the number of drug abusers over the past 11 months has proved that the strategy works, Shih noted.

Also held on the sidelines of the National Drug Control Conference at the Grand Hotel in Taipei was an international drug control symposium in which officials and narcotics control specialists from Thailand, Vietnam, Australia, the United States and Taiwan participated.
The foreign participants included Anselmo S. Avenido Jr., head of the Dangerous Drugs Board of the Philippines, and John Herron, chairman of the Australian National Council on Drugs.
The National Drug Control Conference was jointly sponsored by the Ministry of Justice, the Ministry of Education and the Department of Health.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHYSICAL PUNISHMENT STILL OCCURRING IN SCHOOLS DESPITE BAN: SURVEY

TEXT.P: More than 27 percent of elementary and junior middle school pupils in Taiwan have experienced physical punishment in school in the first half of this year, according to the results of a survey released Sunday.

The Humanistic Education Foundation conducted the survey between mid-April and the end of May among 1,817 students from 302 elementary schools and 62 students from 161 junior middle schools around Taiwan. The survey has a margin of error of plus or minus two percentage points at a 95 percent level of confidence.

Executives of the foundation deplored the widespread use of physical punishment in schools despite the fact that the Education Basic Law was amended near the end of 2006 to ban any form of corporal punishment in school.
The survey shows that 27.3 percent of the respondents said they were punished with blows to the body, such as flogging, spanking, slapping of the face, pinching or jabbing.
Some teachers ordered other pupils to hit their classmates for their misbehaviour or asked pupils being punished to slap each other's face.
Although the 27.3 percent represented a substantial drop from the 51 percent physical punishment rate for 2005, foundation officials indicated that they take no satisfaction in the figure.

In addition to physical punishment, 35 percent of the pupils said they were subjected to a mild form of punishment -- standing in a corner for 10 minutes or longer. Another 15 percent said they were deprived of food and water or not allowed to go to the restroom, while 12.3 percent said they were ordered to do squat jumps or pushups as punishment.
The survey also found that Taichung County has the highest physical punishment rate at 69.1 percent, while Taipei City's rate of 36.7 percent is the lowest among all cities and counties in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME HAS COME FOR KMT TO RETURN TO POWER: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng urged Taiwan's voters to put the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) back in power by voting for the party's presidential candidate, Ma Ying-jeou, in the 2008 election.

At a luncheon with more than 100 university principals and professors, Wang said it is time that the KMT replaced the Democratic Progressive Party as the ruling party because the people of Taiwan expect it.
Wang said that although he turned down Ma's offer at the end of last month to serve as his running mate, he will do his best to help Ma with his election campaign.
He said the most important thing for the near future is to unite voters in different sectors of society to help Ma get elected in March 2008.
Wang added that after Taiwan's first "rotation of political power" in 2000, the time has now come for a second rotation to answer the people's wish that the KMT return to power.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE VOWS TO OPEN DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou's promise to negotiate with Beijing to launch direct flights across the Taiwan Strait if elected was made based on concerns that Taiwan faces the serious threat of being marginalized, a KMT executive explained Sunday.

Chang Jun-kung, deputy executive director of the KMT's policy committee, made the remarks in response to a report in the Chinese-language United Daily News Sunday that Ma claimed in a recent interview with foreign media that if elected president in 2008, he will immediately engage in negotiations with China for the opening of direct cross-strait flights within one year after assuming office.

Noting that Ma had said on previous occasions that he would make direct cross- strait flights a reality within two years after assuming the presidency, Chang explained that Ma moved up the deadline to one year as most of the political concerns related to direct links with China have been alleviated with KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan's three visits to China over the past three years and because the success of direct cross-strait charter flights during holiday periods has made direct flights year-round more feasible.

Chang further said that foreign enterprises operating in Taiwan have frequently called for the government to move forward with opening direct cross-strait flights, adding that the United States has even stated that it has no willingess to sign a bilateral free trade agreement with Taiwan if the government refuses to do so. He said the government has turned a deaf ear to Washington's calls, which he claimed is stunting the island's economic competitiveness.

Chang added that Ma has also come up with an effective policy to open Taiwan up to Chinese tourists with the goal of developing its economy and avoiding Taiwan becoming marginalized in terms of regional economic integration.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF VESSELS PLYING 'MINI THREE LINKS' ROUTE INCREASING

TEXT.P: The number of vessels plying the routes between the Taiwan-held islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the Chinese ports of Mawei and Xiamen has increased 85 percent per year on average since the "mini three links" were launched six years ago, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

The statistics show that 28,002 vessels sailed on the routes between Matsu and Mawei, Fujian Province in southern China and between Kinmen and Xiamen, also in Fujian Province, between the start of 2001 and the end of 2006.

Taiwan vessels accounted for 74.5 percent of the total number of vessels sailing the routes in 2001, with the figure dropping to 37 percent in 2005, while Chinese vessels accounted for 11.6 percent of the total in 2001 and 63 percent in 2005.

The total number of passengers traveling to and from China via Kinmen and Matsu reached 670,000, or 1,833 passengers per day on average, for 2006, marking an increase of 20.6 percent over the previous year's figure. Taiwan passengers accounted for 86.5 percent of the total, while Chinese passengers accounted for 12.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT PANNED FOR ACCEPTING PRIZE HONORING JAPANESE COLONIST

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui, who is currently in Japan on an 11-day visit, was panned here Sunday for accepting a prize named after a late Japanese administrator in Taiwan.

Koo Kwang-ming, who is a former senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian and who had lived in Japan as a political exile for 25 years, said that Shinpei Goto might have contributed a lot to Taiwan while serving as the chief civil administrator under the Japanese colonial government in Taiwan between 1898 and 1906 but that it was inappropriate for Lee, as a retired head of state of Taiwan, to accept an award set up in Goto's honor.

Koo, who is a close friend of Lee's, said he was not aware before Lee's departure for Japan that the former president would receive the prize during his visit, adding, however, that if he had known about it, attempting to change the mind of someone as stubborn as Lee would have been in vain.
Lee received the prize in Tokyo on June 1 for his contribution to Taiwan's urbanization and democratization.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DEPUTY SECRETARY-GENERAL TO BE CHANGED

TEXT.P: Hsu Jen-tu, a confidant of Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, will be named as DPP deputy secretary-general replacing Tsai Huang-liang who has tendered his resignation, DPP sources said Sunday.

The sources said, Hsu who acts as chief of Hsieh's Southern Taiwan Office had served as DPP deputy secretary-general during Hsieh's term as DPP chairman between 2000 and 2002. His new post at DPP headquarters will provide Hsieh a better grip on the party apparatus during his presidential campaign.

Tsai who was a four-term lawmaker before being named by DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun as DPP deputy secretary-general in 2006 tendered his resignation last week. He has been listed by DPP as DPP first choice for lawmaker at large and thereby is almost certain to resume his role as a lawmaker after Jan. 12 legislative elections, according to the sources.
