DOC.HEADLINE: PRECISION INSTRUMENT INDUSTRIAL PARK IN THE OFFING IN CHIAYI

TEXT.P: A new industrial park for precision instrument makers is expected to be developed in Chiayi County beginning this year to create another high-technology manufacturing arm in southern Taiwan, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen said Monday.

As of the start of this month, 24 companies have expressed an interest in investing in the new industrial park, and these companies are scheduled to meet with Chiayi County officials June 7 to sign letters of intent on their planned investment, Chen said.

A potential industrial park covering an area of 439 hectares in Tapumei, Talin township near the Chungshan Freeway's Meishan Interchange was first zoned by the Ministry of Economic Affairs in 2000 as the future site of a high-technology industrial park.

The development project, however, failed to get off the ground until last year, when the Chiayi County government decided to alter its plans and make the area into a center for biotechnology manufacturing and precision instrument production, Chen said.
A total of 86 hectares of land at the site was rezoned as a future biotech manufacturing center, with land preparation work then getting underway in June 2006, Chen noted.
He added that some 150 hectares of land at the site was recently rezoned as the base to house precision instrument manufacturing companies.

Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen and executives of the Republic of China Instrumental Machinery Association are expected to travel to Talin June 7 to witness the signing of letters of intent, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
FORMER PREMIER PLANNING TO ORGANIZE NEW 'MIDDLE WAY' GROUP

TEXT.P: Former Premier Tang Fei is planning to organize a new "middle way" political group representing middle-class individuals and intellectuals who are not supporters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) or any of the opposition parties.

Tang, who was the first premier of the DPP administration after Chen Shui-bian became the first DPP president in 2000, is organizing the new "Taiwan Future Prospects Society" and calling for members of the middle class and intellectuals who have lost hope in the current state of Taiwan politics to "grasp their future in their own hands."

Wang Hsin-nan, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said he offers his blessing to Tang over the initiative but added that he is afraid that Tang's new group may not survive given the tense situation in Taiwan's current political climate.

Also commenting on Tang's plan, DPP Legislator Tsai Chi-chang said Tang's ambition to solve the long-term deadlock between the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, and the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and its ally, the People First Party, is applaudable. However, he added that if Tang is unable to tackle the issue of national identity, his "middle way" advocacy will lead his followers nowhere.

Meanwhile, Hsu Shao-ping, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, also offered her blessing to Tang, saying that Tang's call for "rational middle voters" to step forward to cast their votes in the 2008 presidential election is more well- intentioned than the mentality harbored by the group calling for people not to go to the polls at all.

Chou Shou-hsun, a deputy convener of the KMT legislative caucus, said that Tang's initiative is welcome, particularly at a time when all the country's citizens are disillusioned with the sitting DPP administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: 20 M troop to schools today
Some 20 million public and private elementary and secondary students will troop to some 43,000 schools nationwide today.
The Philippine Daily InquirerG Education Crisis Deepens
MANILA, Philippines -- The official figures remain grim as some 20 million students troop back to classrooms on Monday at the opening of the new school year. Out of 10 students entering Grade 1, six will complete the elementary course, four will get through high school and two will enter college, according to the Department of Education (DepEd).
The Philippine StarG Final Namfrel tally: 8-2-2 for opposition
Namfrel chairman Edward Go said they have tabulated a total of 197,084 election returns which represented 87.69 percent of votes cast in 224,748 precincts across the country.
The Manila TimesG Palace urges polls for 13th Senate slot
A Malacanang official on Sunday urged the Commission on Elections to declare one Senate seat vacant to pave the way for special polls to determine who would fill it.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Arrests Made in Alleged JFK Plot.
Federal investigators on Saturday said they had disrupted a plot by Islamic extremists to blow up buildings, fuel tanks and pipelines at John F. Kennedy International Airport, another alleged plan aiming at America's air travel system and a landmark in its largest city. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Abe may let 'defectors' go to S. Korea
Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe suggested Sunday he is willing to grant the desire of four people believed to be North Korean defectors to go to South Korea, while Seoul indicated it's ready to accept them.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Opposition urges President Napolitano to intervene in Visco-tax police row.
Opposition leaders urged President Giorgio Napolitano to intervene in disputes between Vice Finance Minister Vincenzo Visco and the tax police. Seeking to quell a fresh row in his fratious ruling coalition, Italian Premier Romano Prodi announced last Friday to move tax police chief Roberto Speciale to a new post, while Visco renounced his mandate over the tax police. Speciale accused Visco of pressuring him to transfer his officers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAVELERS TO CANADA ADVISED TO GET VACCINATED AGAINST MUMPS

TEXT.P: Taipei City health officials on Monday advised people who are preparing to travel to Canada in the near future to get vaccinated against mumps before their departure as that country is experiencing an outbreak of the highly infectious disease, with about 300 cases being reported in May.

Mumps is an acute viral disease which is spread among human beings by saliva droplets or direct contact with articles contaminated with infected saliva. Children aged nine or younger are prone to the disease. While symptoms are generally not severe in children, nearly 30 percent of male adults who are infected with mumps develop orchitis, while about 5 percent of female patients develop ovaritis.

Lin noted that Taiwan began free inoculation services against mumps in 2004. Since then, the infection rate of the disease has significantly decreased on the island, with only five cases being reported in 2006.

Although mumps is usually not a fatal disease, Lin said, the disease is used as a public health indicator. He advised that all infants aged 12-15 months should be vaccinated against the disease and that anyone planning to travel to affected areas get vaccinated at least two weeks before departing on their trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post: Backers of Immigration Bill More Optimistic; Resistance Fading, Lawmakers Say. After a week at home with their constituents, the Senate architects of a delicate immigration compromise are increasingly convinced they will hold together this week to pass an overhaul of the nation's immigration laws, with momentum building behind one unifying theme: Today's immigration system is too broken to go unaddressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved up 25 points to close at 8,257, with 24,926 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for July gained 30 points to finish at 8,205, with 645 contracts traded, while September futures moved up 29 points to end at 8,065, with 131 contract transactions. December futures grew 33 points to close at 8,083, with 18 contracts traded, while March futures moved up 23 points to finish at 8,065, with four contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 8,232 for June, 8,175 for July, 8,036 for September, 8,050 for December and 8,042 for March.

Trade in electronics (TE) futures all recorded gains, while that in financial (TF) futures all lost grounds. They are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks.

June TE futures moved up 3.2 points to close at 356.9, with 2,937 contracts traded, while July TE futures increased 5.6 points to finish at 356.8, with 58 contract transactions. September TE futures moved up 3.2 points to close at 348, with six contracts traded, while December TE futures rose 6.3 points to end at 348.65, with one contract transaction. March TE futures moved up 5.25 points to finish at 347.9, with one contract transaction.

June TF futures dropped 6.6 points to close at 958.6, with 2,065 contracts traded, while July TF futures moved down 7.6 points to finish at 956.4, with 104 contract transactions. September TF futures fell 7.6 points to end at 950.4, with 11 contracts traded, while December TF futures slid 6.6 points to close at 952, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Putin raises spectre of nuclear war in Europe
President Putin has warned the US that its deployment of a new anti-missile network across Eastern Europe would prompt Russia to point its own missiles at European targets and could trigger nuclear war.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, VIETNAM SIGN MOU ON HIGH-TECH COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Vietnam signed a memorandum of understanding Monday aimed at bolstering high-technology exchanges and cooperation between the two countries, the non-profit Institute for Information Industry (III) reported.

The memorandum -- mainly calling for increased Taiwan investment in Vietnam's information technology industry -- was inked by III Chairman Ke Chih-sheng; Hoang Le Minh, deputy director of Ho Chi Minh City's Department of Posts and Telecommunications, and Pham Ngoc Tuan, an executive manager of the Saigon High- Tech Park, in a ceremony held at the III headquarters.

Relocating part of Taiwan's investments to Vietnam will help reduce the risks from concentrating too much investment in China and create a win-win situation for Taiwan and Vietnam, Ke said during the ceremony.

Ke, who led III officials to Vietnam for a fact-finding trip in January, said that Vietnam, with a hardworking labor force, has witnessed ever-expanding economic growth over the past several years, averaging 7-8 percent annually.

He quoted International Telecommunication Union tallies as indicating that Vietnam has registered the world's second highest growth in the telecommunication industry in recent years, behind only China.
The III head attributed Vietnam's success mainly to the fact that the country has abundant and inexpensive human resources.
Taiwan, which remains the largest investor in Vietnam, will also benefit by continuing to increase its investment in Vietnam, Ke noted.
For his part, Pham said that Vietnam, a relative "newcomer" to the high- technology industrial sector as compared to Taiwan, hopes to strengthen exchanges with Taiwan in this regard.

According to III tallies, as of the end of November 2006, Taiwanese companies had channeled US$8.128 billion into Vietnam for various investment projects, constituting 13.74 percent of all foreign investment in Vietnam. The figure made Taiwan the largest foreign investor in Vietnam.

Vietnam applied to join the World Trade Organization at the end of 2006 and gained entry into the organization at the beginning of this year. The country's entry into the WTO has so far attracted investment from Japan, South Korea, Europe and the United States amounting to over US$12 billion, III officials said.

Besides, they said, the Vietnamese government has announced that it will lower import tariffs on 330 categories of information technology and telecommunication products between 2008 and 2010 to attract more foreign investment to help accelerate the development of its high-tech industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTRY OF JUSTICE ORDERS CLAMPDOWN ON WATER GATE THEFT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has asked all levels of investigation authorities to wipe out the theft of water gates that has had a serious impact on farmland irrigation and flood prevention, an MOJ official said Monday.

The spokesman said each local district prosecutors office set up a team in February 2005 to clamp down on this type of crime involving public property including water gate theft, but the MOJ has made major efforts to curb such thefts more effectively.

The MOJ has asked the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office to supervise investigations by local district prosecutors offices on water gate thefts and work out plans and strategies for effective prevention and investigation, the spokesman said.

Local district prosecutors offices will need to help local police departments to establish teams to reinforce contacts with investigation authorities, and will need to appoint a prosecutor to be in charge of water gate theft investigation cases, if necessary, he went on.

All investigations need thorough follow-ups in order to find out if the thefts are being committed by criminal gangs, as stealing huge public facilities like water gates is unlikely to be easily done by individuals, the spokesman said, adding that investigations also need to shed light on other irregularities related to the theft of the high-value steel gates.

Local district prosecutors offices should also enhance monitoring of people with criminal records and should assist local police departments to find out where the stolen gates are being sold, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EASY CARDS TO BE ACCEPTED BY TAXIS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Easy Cards issued by the Taipei Smart Card Corp. to pay fares on the city's metro system and buses, as well as to pay for municipal parking fees, will also be good for paying taxi fares in a trial period beginning November.

In a briefing to Mayor Hau Lung-bin Monday, the company's general manager, Lin Chih-ying, said they are seeking 1,000 taxis in the city willing to accept payment with Easy Cards, which would allow discounts for the physically challenged, and senior citizens.

In order to encourage taxi drivers to join the program, the corporation is mulling the idea of paying the cost of installing card readers, which are NT$18,000 (US$543) per unit, Lin said, adding that this would need to be approved by the city government, which controls the card corporation.
Technically, Lin said, there would be no difficulty using Easy Cards to pay taxi fares.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPROVAL RATING FOR KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE RISING

TEXT.P: The public approval rating for the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) presidential candidate, Ma Ying-jeou, is rising and has far surpassed that for Frank Hsieh, his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rival, according to poll results released Monday by a local newspaper.

After Ma promised to set up direct transport links within one year upon his election and his recent announcement that he will not pair up on a presidential ticket with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng after Wang rejected his offer to act as his running mate, the public approval rating for Ma has recently surged to 59 percent, from 43 percent in early May, the United Daily News reported.
At the same time, Hsieh's public approval rating has dropped to 17 percent from the 28 percent he enjoyed in early May when he won the DPP's presidential primary, according to the report.

Upon learning of the poll results, Ma said following a seminar with 40 chairmen and representatives of China-based Taiwan businessmen's associations that he will find out the reasons behind the change and work out a policy framework on major issues and select a suitable running mate based upon that foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC ATTACKED FOR SETTING DATE FOR LEGISLATIVE POLLS

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) held a news conference Monday to accuse the Central Election Commission (CEC) of creating chaos by setting the date for the seventh legislative elections for Jan. 12, 2008.

Hsu Shao-ping, KMT legislative caucus whip, said at a Legislative Yuan news conference that electoral affairs regarding the coming legislative and presidential elections should be decided by the next CEC, as current CEC members have to step down June 16 -- the expiry date of their terms given that a draft CEC Organic Law concerning the lineup of body has yet to clear the Legislative Yuan.

The CEC set the date during a June 1 meeting and said that it will soon notify the Executive Yuan of its decision to put off the legislative elections, originally scheduled for Dec. 11 this year, to next January.
The outgoing CEC members should not make any major decisions on either the coming legislative elections or the 2008 presidential race, Hsu argued.

KMT lawmaker Wu Yu-sheng accused CEC Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung of "going too far" in making the important decision without having followed a due process, especially when there is little time left of his tenure.
The CEC, which lacks a legal foundation, is not entitled to make major policy shifts aimed at serving the interests of a particular political party, he said.

According to Wu, the KMT legislative caucus whip is not opposed to altering the date of any election as long as the CEC observes the legal process. The decision unilaterally made by the CEC is questionable, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA TO BAN ORGANIZATIONS FROM USING DISPOSABLE CUPS FROM JULY 1

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) plans to ban all government agencies, schools and hospitals from using disposable cups from July 1 to further reduce the amount of solid waste generated, EPA officials said Monday.

The officials noted that although all government agencies and Taiwan's 978 schools have already stopped using disposable tableware in their dining halls since July 1 and Sept. 1 last year, respectively, in observance of a ban by the EPA, the use of disposable cups outside dining halls has continued.
According to EPA estimates, the ban on disposable tableware is expected to reduce the solid waste generated in Taiwan by 2,600 metric tons each year.
The EPA will conduct inspections to enforce the ban and violators will be liable to fines of between NT$1,200 and NT$6,000 under the Waste Disposal Act, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE VOWS TO TALK WITH BEIJING ABOUT TAIWAN'S SPACE

TEXT.P: The 2008 presidential candidate of the opposition Kuomintang said Monday that if he is elected as the next president of the Republic of China, he will talk seriously with Beijing about Taiwan's space and status in the international community.

Speaking at a workshop with representatives of Taiwanese business associations in China, Ma Ying-jeou said Taiwan's diplomatic resources should not be wasted "for nothing" any longer and that if elected, he would strive to negotiate with the Beijing leadership to reach an agreement on Taiwan's participation in more global organizations.
That agreement, Ma said, would not be a zero-sum consensus but a pragmatic problem-solver.

Ma said his campaign team has hammered out bilateral and multilateral solutions on the issue. For example, he noted, Taiwan should first try to gain accession into the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

Meanwhile, he went on, the first thing he would like to talk with Beijing is about the cross-Taiwan Strait security issue, adding that he would seek to negotiate with Beijing officials based on the so-called "92 consensus" in order to reach an agreement on cross-strait security.
That agreement, he said, would mainly feature a mutual trust military mechanism aimed at ending cross-strait hostility in the shortest possible period.

Ma said that if he is elected, he will definitely improve business and trade ties across the strait, normalize business and trade relations, negotiate over the opening of direct air links and allow Taiwan's banking institutions to operate in China.
He said he will also seek agreements with China on investment guarantees, double-taxation exemption and related measures to facilitate the establishment of a cross-strait common market.

He expressed hope that Taiwan will increase cultural and educational exchanges with China, including mutual recognition of academic degrees conferred by schools on both sides and allowing Taiwan institutes to recruit students from China.

Ma accused the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration of failing to do anything constructive for the Taiwan people over the past seven years, saying that the DPP is simply an electioneering machine that never delivers its campaign promises.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROBES INTO DPP OFFICIALS' `SPECIAL ALLOWANCE FUND' CONTINUING: PANEL

TEXT.P: Probes into alleged misuse of discretionary "special allowance funds" by several prominent figures in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are continuing and are being conducted in an impartial way, a special investigation panel under the Supreme Prosecutors Office said Monday.

Chen Yun-nan, director of the panel, said the investigations into DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, Vice President Annette Lu, former Premier Su Tseng-chang, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and Tan Sun Chen, former secretary-general to President Chen Shui-bian, have not stalled.

He made the remarks during a news conference after Minister of Justice Shih Mao- lin instructed the Supreme Prosecutors Office to explain the progress of the probes that day. Fielding questions at a legislative committee May 31, Shih was asked by legislators why the probes seem to be progressing slowly.

Chen noted that other high-profile probes into the alleged misuse of the "special affairs fund" involving President Chen Shui-bian and first lady Wu Shu- jen, as well as the "special allowance fund" involving main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou, took several months before the prosecutors formally pressed charges.

"An individual case takes several months, let alone the investigations into several cases simultaneously, " Chen said, adding that some of the allegedly misused funds were claimed over a period of seven or eight years, which will take even more time to investigate.
"The special investigation panel has not been dragging its feet," Chen said, adding that "there are no political considerations in the probes."

He said the panel has followed the principle of caution during the investigations and has not explained the progress at any time, which he said could be the reason leading to the impression of a slow pace.
Chen said that since the panel assigned the cases April 14 to a team of three prosecutors including Hou Kuan-jen, the team has been working assiduously.

Hou is the key figure behind the March 13 indictment of Ma, a former Taipei mayor, over his alleged misuse of the "special allowance fund" during his mayoral term between 1998 and 2006. The indictment forced Ma to resign as KMT chairman, although he has denied any wrongdoing.

Chen noted that since the cases were assigned, they have asked the Ministry of Audit to provide original invoices or receipts for verification and have instructed financial institutions as well as relevant companies to provide transaction records.
The prosecutors have to pore over all relevant documents, which he pointed out is both time-consuming and laborious.

Chen also said the prosecutors have so far summoned various accountants and cashiers to testify 52 times in an attempt to shed light on the use of the previously little-understood "special allowance fund," although he admitted that none of the targeted DPP officials had yet been summoned by the prosecutors.

All executives holding public office are given a special allowance fund every month. Although the spending of the money is left up to the administrative chief's discretion, half of the fund can be reimbursed without any proof of spending, while use of the other half must be substantiated with invoices or receipts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's barometer, moving up 44.89 points to close at 8,294.79.

The bourse opened at 8,310.09 points and fluctuated between 8,282.79 and 8,317.60 during the day's trading. A total of 4.05 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$116.87 billion (US$ 3.54 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics stocks moving up the most at 1 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues and plastic and chemical issues, both at 0.4 percent.

Meanwhile, textile issues dropped 1.9 percent and construction shares moved down 0.9 percent. Cement issues and foodstuff issues both slid 0.6 percent, followed by banking and financial stocks at 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 642 to 501, with 209 remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTEX TAIPEI TO OPEN TUESDAY WITH 130,000 VISITORS EXPECTED

TEXT.P: Computex Taipei 2007 will open Tuesday at the World Trade Center, with some 130,000 people expected to visit the world's second-largest computer show, including 30,000 potential buyers, according to the organizer, the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).
TAITRA officials estimated Monday that the value of orders placed during the June 5-9 fair is expected to surpass US$15 billion.

A total of 2,926 stalls have been set up at the Computex venues, which cover three exhibition halls of the World Trade Center and the Taipei International Convention Hall, with most of Taiwan's leading businesses in the sector, including Acer Inc., AsusTek Computer Inc. and the Foxconn Technology Group, having a presence at the show.

TAITRA Deputy Secretary-General Yeh Ming-shuei said that as the annual Computex is defined as a professional trade fair, it won't be open to the general public until the last day of the exhibition. He noted that buyers usually place their orders during the fair for the up-to-date products showcased in CeBIT, the world's largest computer exposition held every spring in Hanover, Germany.
Under the trend, trading deals valued at US$12.7 billion in total were forged during the 2006 Computex, Yeh said, assessing that the value of orders will grow significantly this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, decreasing NT$0.04 to close at NT$33.005.
A total of US$9.4 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.989, and fluctuated between NT$32.960 and NT$33.040.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES MORE TO JOIN DRUG-FIGHTING EFFORTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the country's anti-drug war will be long and tough, and he urged more people to join the authorities' efforts to stamp out illegal drugs.
Chen made the remarks while receiving individuals and groups who have contributed to drug-fighting efforts over the past year.

He said that although the government's efforts to combat narcotics have borne some fruit, crime related to narcotics, as well as ensuing problems, have become more complex. This, coupled with new types of narcotics available, means that "no-one should let down their guard" and more people should take part in anti- drug efforts, he said.
Chen noted that the government has set 2005-2008 as "the years for waging war against narcotics."
The government has also set a new anti-drug strategy since last year which he said put the emphasis on cutting the demand for narcotics.
The government now divides drug control work into four major areas: drug- prevention; drug-rejection; drug rehabilitation; and drug crackdowns, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC URGED NOT TO USE YUCHANG HIGHWAY

TEXT.P: The public was urged Monday not to use the newly built Yuchang highway in the eastern county of Hualien as the highway is not yet officially open for public use, according to officials from the Directorate General of Highways.
The remarks came after the officials found that barricades blocking either end of the highway had been removed and that people were using the road.
Although safety inspections of the highway have been completed, the officials said, the public should not use it, in order, they claimed "to prevent accidents."
However, local police said that as no stop signs have been set up at the entrances to the highway, they cannot impose penalties on anyone choosing to use the road.
Those responsible for constructing the highway should set up warning signs, or will be held responsible for any accidents that occur on the highway, the police officials noted.

The 16.26-km highway links Yuli township in Hualien County and Changbin township in the neighboring county of Taitung. The highway is expected to reduce the drive time between the two places from 90 minutes to 20-30 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB WARNS AGAINST EXTREMELY HEAVY RAIN IN MOST OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Most areas of Taiwan can expect "extremely heavy rain" until Tuesday because of a plum rain front that has remained stationery over Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau predicted Monday.

CWB meteorologists warned that people in northern, northeastern, eastern, western and central regions of Taiwan could see tremendous downpours in short periods and that residents in central Taiwan, expecially Hsinchu and Miaoli counties, should watch out for lightning strikes, falling rocks, landslides and mudflows.
Taiwan's plum rain season this year began May 17 and is expected to last through early to mid-summer.
Formed by moist air over the Pacific meeting the cooler continental air mass, the front often brings prolonged precipitation to East Asian countries.
By extremely heavy rain, the CWB refers to an area's accumulated rainfall exceeding 130 mm within a 24-hour period.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEETING OF TAIWAN'S LODGING ASSOCIATIONS TO BE HELD JUNE 5

TEXT.P: Associations of lodginghouse owners will have a two-day meeting in the Chiayi County mountain resort of Alisha n June 5-6 for exchanges of views on futurecooperation, an official of the county's Tourism Bureau said Monday.
The meeting, organized by the county's lodging association, is aimed at promoting cooperation in the lodging industry among different areas of the country, the official said.

According to the official, lodging house owners in Yilan, Hualien, Taipei, Miaoli, Taichung, Yunlin and Chiayi counties have been invited to attend the meeting. The Tourism Bureau, the Alishan National Scenic Area Administration and the Chiayi County Tourism Bureau will also have representatives present at the meeting.

Wang San-hua, director-general of the organizing association, said the lodging industry is an indicator of an area's tourism development and that as the county's lodging industry is still growing, the association hopes to hold more exchange activities to boost the industry.

There will be keynote speeches on the development of Taiwan's lodging industry and an introduction to Alishan's tea industry during the meeting. Participants will also visit the county's scenic spots, including a national park and a restored old street to gain a better understanding of the county, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE TO VISIT INDIA, SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou is scheduled to visit India and Singapore June 11-15, Ma's office said in a press release Monday.
The office said Ma will call on business and industrial leaders during his visit to India before heading for Singapore to meet with business leaders and visit economic facilities there.

The press release said that over the past seven years under the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration, Taiwan's economy has undergone dramatic regression, and claimed that this has been due to the DPP's "obsession with ideology and its incompetence in good governance."

Taiwan's economic growth ranked at the bottom among Asia's Four Little Dragons, which also include Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore, and even trailed behind those of Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia and Vietnam, it claimed.
The DPP's maneuvering over the issue of a "de jure Taiwan independence" has also turned the island into a "troublemaker" internationally, the press release claimed.

Ma thinks that only by adopting a more flexible and pragmatic "dynamic economy, " lowering the ideological struggle and strengthening exchanges in economy, trade, culture and tourism with other Asian countries, can it break out of its isolation and re-invent its economic miracle, the press release said.

Accompanying Ma will be high-tech industry expert Steve Hsieh, financial expert Yin Chii-ming, online newspaper DigiTimes President Huang Ching-yang and former ROC Ambassador to the Dominican Republic John Feng.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE PROMISES CHINA LINKS

TEXT.P: The presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) vowed Monday to implement direct charter flight services on weekends between Taiwan and China should he be elected president in 2008.

Former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who was nominated May 2 by the KMT as its candidate for the 2008 presidential election, made the pledge after attending a seminar with more than 40 chairmen and representatives of China-based Taiwan businessmen's associations.

As opening direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait has become an issue of major concern among a variety of Taiwan people, Ma said that he will do his best to implement direct charter flights between the two sides should he win the election and that he will immediately start two-way talks on establishing full airlinks across the strait.
If the KMT regains power in 2008, Ma said, the party will get rid of ideological strife and bear down to implement a wholly liberal economic policy.

Under the rule of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) over the past seven years, Taiwan's economy has rapidly worsened, taking the country to the bottom among the four "Asian Little Dragons," he claimed.

According to Ma, if he is elected president, the KMT will aim to boost the annual economic growth rate from the current level of 5 percent to 6 percent and raise the per-capita annual income to US$20,000 by 2011. The KMT harbors an ambition to make the country a global business operations hub for Taiwan businessmen and an Asia-Pacific operations center for foreign businessmen, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAFT AMENDMENTS TO ANTI-MONEY LAUNDERING LAW PASSES 1ST READING

TEXT.P: A package of draft amendments to the Anti-Money Laundering Law cleared a legislative committee Monday with the aim of allowing the country to better contribute to global anti-terrorism and anti-money laundering efforts.

The law amendment will also list suspects engaged in money laundering of more than NT$5 million as criminals, a tightening of the previous level of NT$20 million that is designed to crack down on economic crime.
The package will also criminalize the financing of terrorist acts, including murder, arson, hijacking of trains, ships and airplanes or planting bombs for religious, racial or ideological reasons.
In addition, people caught profiteering through fraud or scams will also be charged as major economic criminals.

The draft package further requires financial institutions to record and report the identities of customers engaging in suspicious deals or currency transactions to units under the Executive Yuan and to keep receipts of all such transactions.

Both outbound and inbound travelers must declare their holdings in foreign currency and travelers checks above a certain ceiling set by the government to customs authorities. Under the current law, departing or entering passengers cannot carry more than US$10,000 with them.

According to government officials, the law revision is expected to help Taiwan solidify its position in the Egmont Group, as it is feared that China might try to force a name change of Taiwan in the group. They pointed out that the group wrote to its 20 members in early May asking them to complete relevant legislation or face suspension of their membership rights.

To better help the international battle against money laundering, the Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice joined the Egmont Group in 1998 under the designation of "MLPC (Money Laundering Prevention Center), Taiwan," the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2007 AIMS TO BE WORLD'S TOP ICT PROCUREMENT PLATFORM

TEXT.P: Computex Taipei 2007, the largest computer trade show in Asia and the second- largest in the world, will open Tuesday for a five-day run with more than more than 1,300 domestic and international exhibitors showing off their latest products, organizers said Monday in a press conference.

The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , one of two main organizers, estimated that over 130,000 visitors and buyers will attend the annual exhibition, whose 2,926 booths will occupy four Taipei World Trade Center halls and will run from June 5 - 9.

The exhibition is aimed at providing buyers with their ideal source for the best products. It is ranked alongside CeBIT Germany as the world's top two information and communication technology (ICT) events.

The primarily professional business-to-business (B2B) exhibition is targeting on-site orders and sales that organizers hope will exceed US$14.5 billion, said TAITRA Executive Vice President Walter Yeh, adding that the show will highlight Taiwan's position as "the world's leading ICT procurement platform."

"It was not easy to achieve the 2 percent growth in the number of exhibitors for this year's event, " said Li Chang, Deputy Secretary-General of the Taipei Computer Association (TCA), who also described the show as "the Golden Week" for Taiwan's information technology (IT) industry.

The year opened a new era for global 4C (computers, communications, consumer electronics and digital content) products in the IT industry, as all four major categories have been upgrading, according to a COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2007 press release.
The show is reserved exclusively for international buyers, Yeh said, adding that it will only be open to the general public on the last day.

DOC.HEADLINE: CITIZEN PARTICIPATION ENCOURAGED IN NEW MILLENNIUM LIVING WORKSHOP

TEXT.P: Citizen participation has been long overlooked but will be an important factor in our living in the new millennium as well as an integral part of urban design and community infrastructure establishment, a German architect said Monday in an international workshop.

Three groups of workshop participants presented their ideas and plans on the themes of rivers, garden city and community public spaces in the final presentation of a five-day workshop titled "Living and Housing in the 3rd Millennium: Ideas and Strategies for Better Living in Taipei" that was guided by German architect Klaus Luig.

"All human beings are responsible for our future with the objective of enhancing quality of life. While nature and sustainable growth know no borders, it's essential to exchange ideas, " Luig said, adding that modern day urban development often ignores the citizens.

The workshop, organized by the German Cultural Center in Taipei, brought together participants from different generations, nationalities and professional backgrounds to work on ideas for Taipei's future during five days of discussions and brainstorming.

"Taiwanese architecture and urban design are dominated by elitism and ignore civic participation, " said Janice Chen, who was in a group that developed a plan to better make use of the riverside park on the Hsintien river.
"It's time to let the real users -- the citizens -- participate in the development, management and design of their communities and environments, " she added.
The other groups worked out plans to redevelop New Garden City, an old community in suburban Taipei, and the sustainable utilization and management of community public spaces in Taipei.

"Some of the ideas these participants came up with are actually workable and will be a very good source and reference for the government, while some of them are pretty idealistic, " Luig commented after the presentation.
"Don't forget, however, the building of a wall starts with the first brick. This is a good start, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAXI FARES TO INCREASE IN KAOHSIUNG FROM JULY 1

TEXT.P: The flagfall taxi fare in the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung will rise from NT$70 to NT$85 (US$2.57) from July 1, the Transportation Bureau under the Kaohsiung city government announced Monday.
Wang Kuo-tsai, head of the Transportation Bureau, said the city government agreed to the taxi industry's proposal for a price hike after most respondents polled in a survey endorsed the proposal.
According to Wang, the move will be formally sanctioned during a city government meeting next week.
Wang pointed out that the taxi fare in Kaohsiung has not been adjusted for the past six years and that an increase is needed to reflect rising fuel costs.
He added that the rate following the NT$85 basic fare for the first one- and-a-half kilometers will remain unchanged at NT$5 per 250 meters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES STILL AHEAD OF SOUTH KOREA'S: CBC

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to retain its third-place ranking in terms of foreign exchange reserves, ahead of South Korea's, officials of the Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) said Monday.
CBC officials made the prediction on the eve of its announcement of the nation's foreign exchange reserves as of the end of May.

As the CBC has in recent days continued to sell its U.S. dollars to stem a further slide in the New Taiwan dollar against the greenback, May's foreign exchange reserves are expected to be further down from those in April, although still be higher than South Korea's, the officials said.
South Korea announced Monday that its foreign exchange reserves stood at US$250.74 billion as of the end of May, up US$3.48 billion from the end of April.

Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves stood at NT$266.54 billion at the end of April, ranking third in the world behind only China -- which stood at US$1.2 trillion at the end of March -- and Japan's US$915.6 billion at the end of April.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Commanders Say Push in Baghdad Is Short of Goal
Three months after the start of the Baghdad security plan that has added thousands of American and Iraqi troops to the capital, they control fewer than one-third of the citys neighborhoods, far short of the initial goal for the operation, according to some commanders and an internal military assessment.
The American assessment, completed in late May, found that American and Iraqi forces were able to "protect the population" and "maintain physical influence over" only 146 of the 457 Baghdad neighborhoods.
Wall Street Journal: How H-P Reclaimed Its PC Lead Over Dell
Hewlett-Packard Co. is riding high today as the world's undisputed leader of personal-computer sales, but that's not how Todd Bradley found things when he joined the company in 2005.
Dell Inc. was the top PC maker that year, when H-P Chief Executive Mark Hurd hired Mr. Bradley to run the company's PC business. H-P's PC operations were barely profitable, morale was foundering and some investors were suggesting H-P get out of PCs altogether.@

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL GROUP LAUNCHES `PLANT A TREE FOR ME' PROGRAM

TEXT.P: A local environmental group launched a "plant a tree for me" program Monday to encourage local people and corporations to make donations for tree planting as part of efforts to protect Taiwan's climate and natural environment.

Under the program, National Taiwan University's (NTU's) Experimental Forest Administration will plant a tree for every individual or corporation who makes a donation of NT$500 (US$15.15) , said a spokesman for the Environmental Quality Protection Foundation (EQPF).

According to EQPF Chairman Liu Ming-lung, the foundation will cooperate with the NTU Experimental Forest Administration in encouraging local people to join forces to help slow global warming and protect Taiwan's climate by contributing funds for tree planting.

The "plant a tree for me" program is also a response to the "Plant for the Planet: Billion Tree Campaign" launched by the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) earlier this year aimed at encouraging countries around the world to plant a total of 1 billion trees in the fight against global warming, Liu said.

Noting that the program spotlights the vital importance of voluntary collective action in the fight against climate change, Liu said that taking small but practical steps to combat global warming by planting trees is critical to protecting Taiwan's climate from drastic changes.

Wang Ya-nan, director of the NTU's Experimental Forest Administration (EFA) , said tree planting can bring about multiple benefits, including reducing carbon dioxide, promoting the ecological balance, providing additional tourist attractions, slowing global warming and facilitating soil and water preservation.

According to Wang, the EFA has designated a plot of land covering 55 hectares for the "plant a tree for me" program under which a seedling of Taiwan endemic plant species will be planted for anyone who donates NT$500.

"All the trees planted under the program will be incorporated into the national forestry system to ensure their survival for at least 40 years, " Wang explained, adding that a hectare of land can accommodate 1,500 trees.
Noting that the first five months of the year are the best period for planting trees, Wang said the EFA will not begin carrying out the program until next March.

A single tree can reduce an average of 465 kg of carbon dioxide during a 40-year life span, Wang said, adding that the forest to be created under the "plant a tree for me" program will be tentatively named "Protect Taiwan Climate Commemorative Forest."
Prospective donors are welcome to deposit donations in the EFA's bank account at the Chang Hwa Commercial Bank's Chushan Branch with aoount number 59490400372610.

Donors will be presented with a "Friends of Climate Protection" card on which each specific tree's carbon dioxide reduction rate will be recorded. Donors will also be invited to take part in EFA's tree planting activities March 12 -- Taiwan's Arbor Day -- every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CANDIDATE CANVASSES SUPPORT IN KAOHSIUNG COUNTY

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said Monday that he hopes to win at least 60 percent of the vote in the southern city and county of Kaohsiung in the 2008 presidential election.
Hsieh made the remarks while visiting the southern county as part of a nationwide campaign tour.

He expressed appreciation to the people in the county's Renwu township for supporting him in the DPP's presidential primary, saying that in the 2004 presidential election, President Chen Shui-bian won 55 percent of the vote in Kaohsiung County and over 58 percent in Kaohsiung City.

The former premier said that Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing has promised to serve as chief of his election campaign headquarters in Kaohsiung and that he hopes the vote percentage can be raised to 60 percent.
Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou is "unable to unify his party" and often uses opinion polls to show that he is in the lead at critical moments, Hsieh claimed.

Claiming that he knows better than Ma how to protect Taiwan, Hsieh said Ma supports the opening of direct links between Taiwan and China, but his own belief is that there should be "complementary measures" and that both sides should negotiate on an equal footing.

In response to Ma's criticism that the DPP only have slogans but nothing of substance, Hsieh said the DPP government has solved flooding problems in flood- prone areas, has cleaned up the Love River in Kaohsiung City, and will complete Kaohsiung City's mass rapid transit (MRT) system soon.
On the other hand, Taipei Mayor Hau Long-bin is still talking about cleaning up the Tamshui River, which his predecessor Ma also talked about eight years ago, Hsieh said.

Rebutting Ma's remarks that Taiwan should learn from Singapore, Hsieh pointed out that the city state is not as democratic as Taiwan, and that Taiwan should learn how Singapore became independent instead.
In his capacity as premier in 2005, Hsieh said he introduced an eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.42 billion) flood-prevention project to take care of minority groups.
In addition, he initiated a four-year, NT$40 million plan to improve old classrooms in central and southern Taiwan, rather than in northern Taiwan, where he claimed "there are no old classrooms."
If elected president, he vowed to continue to take care of the disadvantaged and seek "transitional justice," Hsieh went on.

Claiming that Ma does not understand the hardships of the people, even though he recently embarked on a bicycle tour around the island, Hsieh said a national leader should be capable of solving people's problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CALLS KMT CANDIDATE'S CROSS-STRAIT PLATFORM `CAMPAIGN GIMMICK'

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou's cross- Taiwan Strait platform has neither feasible assessments nor detailed action plans, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Monday, describing the platform as a "campaign gimmick."
The remarks came after Ma said that if elected next year, he will immediately embark on negotiations with China and hopes to reach a peace accord on the basis of the so-called "1992 Consensus."

The 1992 Consensus, which the KMT claims was reached in Hong Kong between Taiwan and China during its rule, refers to an understanding that there is only one China, but with both sides free to make their own interpretations of what "one China" really means.
Ma proposed his platform at a meeting in Taipei with Taiwanese businessmen operating in China.
The MAC official responded that the normalization of cross-strait relations has always been the government's stance and that the government has "an overall plan to promote the policy goal."
Any issues can be promoted through formal negotiations between the two sides, the official said.
However, Beijing insists on basing talks on cross-strait exchanges and interaction on its "One China" principle.

Under this principle, relations between Taiwan and China are part of China's "internal affairs, " and cross-strait dialogue and negotiations can only be conducted under the political framework set by Beijing, the official said, adding that this is unacceptable to a majority of Taiwan people.
Negotiations over direct flights and further trade cooperation between the two sides should require no political premise, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILLING TO RE-NEGOTIATE TORCH RELAY ROUTE: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan is willing to re-negotiate the Olympic torch relay route, the nation's top China policy charter said Monday.

Chen Ming-tong, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks when he was interviewed by the Hong Kong China News Agency, set up in 1956 in Hong Kong to offer news services to newspapers in Chinese in Hong Kong, Macau and foreign countries, as well as newspaper supplements.

Reports quoted Chen as saying that after Taipei rejected the torch relay route, Jiang Xiaoyu, executive vice president of Beijing Organizing Committee for the Games of the XXIX Olympiad, said there is still a year before the start of the relay and both sides could talk about the matter.
Chen said Taiwan is willing to re-negotiate and is now waiting for Beijing to float a new proposal and convey sincerity in wishing to restart the talks.

Chen said that when both sides of the Taiwan Strait discussed the torch relay route early this year, they signed meeting minutes. The Taiwan delegate brought back the planned route for study and gave written agreement to the plan in March, although the plan at the time did not include Macau.
Chen said Macau is not a member of the International Olympic committee (IOC) and that the route plan turned Taipei into a "domestic leg" of the relay.
Beijing's reference of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee as "Taipei, China" is also unacceptable, Chen said.
But he also said that "taking part in IOC-sponsored activities is our right as a member of the IOC and we'll surely attend the 2008 Games."
He said that when Beijing bid for the 2008 Olympics, Taipei also cast a "yes" vote, but the torch relay route shows that Taiwan's goodwill gesture has not received a reciprocal response from China.

According to China's plan when it announced the torch relay route in April 26, the Olympic torch will travel from Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City to Taipei and then continue on to Hong Kong, Macau and several other Chinese cities before arriving in the host city, Beijing.
Taiwan rejected the route planning at that time, saying that the route is unacceptable as it deliberately downgrade Taiwan's sovereign status.
Taiwan wants the torch to come to Taipei via a third country and travel on to another country.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPUTY REPRESENTATIVE TO U.S. NAMED

TEXT.P: Huang Wei-feng, a former Mainland Affairs Council vice chairman, will serve as the country's deputy representative to the United States, government sources said Monday.
According to the sources, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung already approved Huang's new assignment.

Huang, who is now an associate researcher at the Institute of European and American Studies under Academia Sinica, Taiwan's foremost academic institution, has a master's degree from Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a Ph. D. in political science from Oxford University. He is scheduled to depart for Washington, D.C. to assume his new post in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 5, or the 20th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1723: Adam Smith, the Scottish political economist and philosopher, is born. His "Wealth of Nations" was the foundation of classical free-market economic theory.
1883: British economist John Maynard Keynes is born. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, could be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces in China.
1945: The supreme commanders from the United States, Great Britain, France, and the Soviet Union sign a statement in Berlin that divides Germany into four occupation zones under their respective controls.
1947: An Outer Mongolian cavalry battalion, aided by planes with Soviet insignia, attack Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang.
1947: U.S. Secretary of State George Marshall announces his plan to help Europe recover financially from the effects of World War II.
1963: King Bhumibol Adulyadej and Queen Sirikit of Thailand arrive in the Republic of China for a state visit.
1967: The Six-Day War, which lasts for 132 hours and 30 minutes, breaks out between Israel and the neighboring countries of Egypt, Jordan, and Syria.
1968: Five years after the assassination of his brother, President John Kennedy, Senator Robert Kennedy is shot in the head and shoulder and dies at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles. He was 42.
1972: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Greece.
1976: A joint communique pledging close cooperation between Lesotho and the ROC is issued as Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan ends a five-day visit to Taipei.
1976: Gen. Carlos Manuel Arana Osorio, former president of the Republic of Guatemala, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1988: Kay Cottee sails into Sydney harbor, becoming the first woman to sail nonstop around the world alone.
1989: The Solidarity party defeats the communists in the first free Polish elections since World War I.
1989: U.S. President George Bush suspends government sales and private military exports to mainland China to protest the Chinese army's crackdown on student demonstrations in Beijing.
1996: President Lee Teng-hui appoints Vice President Lien Chan to serve concurrently as ROC premier. The Cabinet is reshuffled three days later.
1999: Yugoslav and NATO officers meet in Macedonia to discuss the withdrawal of Serb forces from Kosovo.
2000: Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew turns down an offer of a job as a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: Chen Poh-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, says that in addition to financial aid, the Republic of China is to offer economic advice to its allies in the same way the United States helped the island some 50 years ago.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a wise and good man holds in awe. He holds in awe the Laws of God, persons in authority, and the words of wisdom of holy men. A fool, on the other hand, does not know that there are Laws of God; he, therefore, has no reverence for them; he is disrespectful to persons in authority, and condemns the words of wisdom of holy men."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER VICE PREMIER DECLINES DECORATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian conferred medals on former Premier Su Tseng-chang and other former officials in a ceremony held at the Presidential Office Tuesday, with the notable absence of former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen, who declined the honor.
Tsai's staff said she declined the honor because she "doesn't have the habit of accepting medals."

President Chen bestowed medals on Su, former Executive Yuan Secretary-General Liu Yu-shan as well as former Minister of National Defense Lee Jye in recognition of their contributions to the nation. Su, who stepped down shortly after losing the Democratic Progressive Party's presidential primary May 6, led his Cabinet to resign en masse last month.
Officials of the Presidential Office said the president affirmed Tsai's contribution to the nation, but Tsai informed them that she is not accustomed to receiving medals.

The officials noted that Tsai had also declined a medal offered by then-Premier Yu Shyi-kun in 2004 when she ended four years' service as the chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council, the nation's top China policy-planning body.
Tsai expressed her appreciation to the president but declined to accept the honor, the officials said, adding that the president "understands and respects" her decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
WHITE PAPER PROPOSES CHILD-RAISING SUBSIDY TO BOOST BIRTH RATE

TEXT.P: The government may begin offering child-raising subsidies as part of efforts to stave off a looming low birth rate crisis, population administration officials said Tuesday.

According to the officials, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) is scheduled to release a white paper on population policy late this month, in which a child- raising subsidy is proposed as a measure to encourage married couples to have more children.

Referring to practices adopted by advanced countries, the MOI-drafted white paper proposes a progressive child-rearing subsidy system, under which families with children aged six and under will be entitled to a monthly child-raising allowance, the officials said.

In terms of the initial MOI proposal, families with a child aged under six will be offered a monthly subsidy of NT$2,000 (US$60.6) , while those with two young children will be given a monthly allowance of NT$3,000. Those with three or more young children will receive a monthly subsidy of NT$5,000.

MOI officials said the child-raising subsidy proposal is based on the findings of a series of public opinion polls conducted by the ministry and major academic institutions, in which more than 50 percent of the respondents consistently advocated the financial support measure as an effective step to encourage childbirth.

The population policy white paper also proposes many other feasible ways and incentives to boost childbirth, with the goal of boosting the fertility rate from the present 1.2 children born to each woman over the course of her life to 1.6 children born to each woman over a period of 10 years, the officials said, adding that when the goal is achieved, the number of newborns will reach an estimated 300,000 a year.

As the MOI has received letters from many concerned citizens asking for early disclosure of the contents of the white paper, the officials said, the MOI will hold public hearings in northern, central and southern Taiwan, respectively, from Tuesday.

The MOI will refer to all the expert views and public opinions presented at the hearings when putting the final touches on the population white paper, which the ministry has spent NT$8 million preparing, the officials said.

According to measures proposed in the white paper, families with three or more young children will be given a special identification card for their cars so that they can enjoy either deductions or exemptions for roadside parking and freeway tolls.
Families with multiple children will also be offered preferential rates in using public educational, recreational and entertainment facilities, the officials said.

The white paper also suggests that men who have deferred performing their mandatory military service because of education and who have children can opt for alternative services without lot drawing and can choose to serve at military bases adjacent to their homes.

The white paper proposes that over the long run, equal maternity and paternity leave benefits be offered to both female and male employees. By so doing, the report says, the cost of employing male and female workers will be almost the same, which will ultimately contribute to gender equality in employment.

Japan will promote new aid programs to help developing countries take steps that not only cut greenhouse gas emission but also address development issues such as pollution and poverty, government officials said Monday.
