: Washington Post: Metro Costs For Overtime Are Up 56% Since 2002.
Every weekday, Metro pays overtime to a group of bus drivers whose regular shifts include being on standby in case of accidents or other emergencies. Many workers at the transit agency are able to double their salaries with overtime. Metro retirees enjoy annual pension payments that are sometimes higher than their on-the-job salaries because overtime is included in their benefit calculations. (By Jorge Liu}

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS MIXED ON HSIEH-SU TICKET

TEXT.P: Reactions were mixed among ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers to reports Tuesday that President Chen Shui-bian is coordinating between DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and former Premier Su Tseng-chang for them to form a ticket to run in the 2008 presidential election.
Hsieh won the DPP presidential primary May 6 by beating three other hopefuls, including Su, who finished second.

Hsieh has yet to announce his running mate, although there has been much speculation that he will choose Yeh Chu-lan, a former vice premier and former acting Kaohsiung mayor, given their longstanding cooperation as well as the fact that Yeh is a woman and Hakka.
The Hakka people represent the second largest ethnic group in Taiwan, behind only the Hoklo people.

The China Times, a local newspaper, reported Tuesday that the president has suggested that Hsieh pair up with Su in the belief that their cooperation will help mend fences after the bitterly contested presidential primary and that Su will complement Hsieh in terms of expanding support base to boost Hsieh's chances of winning the presidential election next year.
DPP Legislator Kao Chien-chih, who is a protege of Hsieh, said that Yeh would be the best partner for Hsieh.
DPP Legislator Kuan Bi-ling said in Hakka that Hsieh has no need "to pronounce" his running mate right now, adding that too much talk will be harmful in terms of future cooperation.

DPP Legislator Wang Shih-chien, yet another of Hsieh's proteges, said that if most of the Hakka people support Yeh, then Yeh will be the best choice, although he added that the most important factor will be the strategy employed for the presidential campaign, and not who will run with Hsieh.

Meanwhile, DPP Legislator Wu Ping-Jui, who is a protege of Su, said that although one should respect Hsieh's views in choosing a running mate, Su would definitely be a boost to the DPP presidential candidate's chances of winning the 2008 election.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER TO VISIT MALAWI TO ATTEND FIRST LADY'S FUNERAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian named former Premier Su Tseng-chang Tuesday as his envoy to attend the funeral of Malawian first lady Ethel Mutharika.

Mutharika, wife of Malawian President Bingu wa Mutharika, passed away Monday after battling an unspecified illness, Wang Chien-yeh, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), quoted a brief statement from the Malawian presidential office as saying.

Su will head a delegation to the southeast African country June 7 to attend the funeral on behalf of the Republic of China government. The funeral is scheduled to be held June 9. The delegation will make a transit stop in Johannesburg, South Africa en route to Malawi, Wang said, adding that the delegation is scheduled to return home June 13.

This will be Su's second visit to Malawi -- one of Taiwan's five diplomatic allies in Africa. His first visit was in July 2002 when he accompanied President Chen on a diplomatic tour to Senegal, Sao Tome and Principe, Swaziland and Malawi, according to the MOFA. Senegal switched diplomatic ties from Taipei to Beijing in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE PROTESTS DOWNGRADING OF TAIWAN'S OIE MEMBERSHIP

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan adopted a resolution Tuesday to express strong protest against a recent move by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) to downgrade Taiwan's membership to the level of a "non-sovereign regional member" under pressure from China.
Also, the legislature condemned China for resorting to political manipulation to dwarf Taiwan's status as a sovereign country and suppress the country's participation in international organizations.
As an organization prompting animal health, the OIE should not have discussed and even voted on any political motions that violate its mission, the legislature said in the resolution.
Noting that there aren't any so-called "non-sovereign regional members" in the existing OIE charter, the legislature claimed the OIE's decision is totally illegitimate.
The legislature urged the OIE to correct its decision and ensure that Taiwan's membership rights are not undermined to facilitate the prevention and control of animal diseases around the world.

On May 25, the 169-member, Paris-based OIE voted in favor of a resolution according to which Taiwan is requested to continue its participation in the OIE as a "non-sovereign regional member" under the new name of "Chinese Taipei."
Taiwan gained accession to the OIE in 1954 under the name of "Republic of China (Taiwan) " but was forced to change the name to "Taipei China" after Beijing was admitted to the organization in 1992.

However, China remains dissatisfied with the alteration. In an attempt to push the OIE to make further concessions on changing Taiwan's membership name, China has refused to participate in OIE activities and pay its membership fees.

To try to resolve the problem, the OIE International Committee adopted a resolution in 2003 to change Taiwan's membership name from "Taipei China" to "Separate Quarantine Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu. "
At that time, Taiwan made clear that it would accept the new name, but China refused to accept the resolution and did not take part in the final vote on the issue.
Since then, the two sides have been using their membership names that were chosen in 1992.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Tuesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved down three points to close at 8,254, with 33,482 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for July dropped two points to finish at 8,203, with 607 contracts traded, while September futures increased one point to end at 8,066, with 161 contract transactions. December futures lost 13 points to close at 8,070, with 16 contracts traded, while March futures moved down 26 points to finish at 8,060, with eight contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 8,257 for June, 8,205 for July, 8,065 for September, 8,083 for December and 8,086 for March.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

June TE futures remained unchanged at 356.9, with 2,199 contracts traded, while July TE futures dropped 2.6 points to finish at 354.2, with 145 contract transactions. September TE futures moved down 1.7 points to end at 346.3, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for December and March.

June TF futures increased 1.4 points to close at 960, with 2,067 contracts traded, while July TF futures gained 2.4 points to finish at 958.8, with 119 contract transactions. September TF futures moved up 2.6 points to end at 953.4, with 16 contracts traded, while December TF futures remained unchanged at 952, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange were higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 9.2 points to close at 8,303.99.

The bourse opened at the day's high of 8,321.42 and dipped to a low of 8,267.59 during the day's trading. A total of 4.29 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$134.26 billion (US$4.07 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 2.5 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.3 percent, foodstuff issues at 1 percent, construction issues at 0.9 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.6 percent.
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares increasing 0.3 percent and plastics and chemicals shares moving up 0.2 percent.
Banking and financial shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 736 to 412, with 198 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER HOPES TO SET UP INTEGRATED DRUG-FIGHTING UNIT

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin has expressed the hope of setting up an integrated drug-fighting unit to boost efforts to stamp out drug trafficking and abuse.

Shih made the remarks Monday in reply to a suggestion made by Taoyuan District Prosecutor Ho Tzu-shun after holding a discussion with individuals and groups that have made contributions to drug-fighting efforts.

The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) had made a proposal in the past to the central government to set up an integrated drug-fighting unit, but the proposal was not approved, Shih said, adding that the MOJ did not give up on the plan and that it has continued working on it.

Shih also mentioned that future anti-drug efforts will focus on prevention and education, rather than on stiffening penalties, as experts in drug-fighting have suggested that teaching people about the harmful effects of drugs is a more effective way to encourage people to say no to drugs.

The MOJ will also enhance cooperation with the Council of Labor Affairs in providing job opportunities and offering training courses to drug addicts in treatment in order to help them begin a normal life, Shih added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUNICIPAL GOV'T TO LAUNCH 'TAIPEI GOOD IMAGE' PROJECT

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government has worked out an integrated image improvement- oriented program as part of efforts to showcase the beauty of the capital of Taiwan, Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced Tuesday.

Hau also said after he presided over an administrative meeting at the city hall that carrying out the "Taipei Good Image" program will be one of his administration's key tasks over the next six months.
The program "is not a mirage, nor does it cost a lot," Hau said, explaining that it will allow the city's residents to see a changing Taipei while feeling the city's beauty and prosperity.

The program is comprised of six major projects, including the inauguration of the Maokung cable car system -- the first of its kind in the city -- in the tea- growing Mucha district, which is slated for the end of June.

In the other major projects, efforts will be made to integrate the cultural landscape in the area that surrounds the National Palace Museum and to expand the facilities of the Water Park in the Kungkuan district in a drive to create an "Off Off Broadway" stage for performing art in the busy business district that attracts young people.
Hau said that his administrative team will also work to improve walking paths on hills in suburban districts, as well as the lighting in MRT stations and vehicle tunnels around the city.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN ASKS TAIWAN SALT NOT TO RAISE PRICES

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has asked Taiwan Salt Industrial Corp. not to raise the price of salt, Cabinet Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun said Tuesday.
Chen was responding to reports that quoted Taiwan Salt Vice President Huang Ching-ju as saying that the company is considering hiking salt prices by between 10 percent and 15 percent.

Huang noted that the company has not raised the price of salt for over 20 years. Even after the company became privatized, it has continued the no price hike policy, although soaring world raw material prices have pushed the cost of production higher since early this year, according to reports.

Chen said he called Taiwan Salt Chairman Lin Ching that day to point out that salt is a basic daily necessity and that if the price is raised, it could trigger a wave of price increases of other daily necessities.
Taiwan Salt promised not to raise the price and will explain other complementary measures, Chen added.

According to reports, Taiwan people consume around 100,000 tons of salt a year. Even after the opening to foreign salt imports in 2004, salt produced by Taiwan Salt still has a domestic market share of 85 percent.

Salt products account for only 47 percent of Taiwan Salt's revenues. But as the prices of salt have been kept low, low net profits have been registered for salt, although products the company has diversified into, such as cosmetics, have seen much healthier profits.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI-VLADIVOSTOK CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICES TO BEGIN

TEXT.P: Taipei-based Trans Asia Airways will from July 3 start offering charter flight services from Taipei to Vladivostok in Russia's far east, company officials said Tuesday.

The aviation company will use 147-seat A320 planes on the route between Taipei and Vladivostok, Russia's largest port city on the Pacific Ocean, providing Taiwan tourists with another exotic option, company officials said.

The flights, twice a week on Wednesday and Saturday, will take around four hours. The aviation company is also cooperating with a travel agency to market a group tour during the July-October period for Taiwanese tourists hoping to experience something very different.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW REVISION ALLOWS FOR MORE POLICE TO MAINTAIN SOCIAL ORDER

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan gave its final approval to a law amendment Tuesday, allowing the police to devote more manpower to stepping up rule of law.

Lawmaker Wu Yu-sheng, who proposed the draft amendment, said that its passage will permit the police authorities to shift more manpower to maintaining social order from their previous household population checks.

According to Wu, police officers spend at least 20 hours per month checking households. With the policy shift, an additional 3,341 policemen can be deployed each month to help maintain public order, he said.

In the future, he said, policemen will strengthen their checks of criminals on parole, those who have had sentences commuted and those who are listed as prone to crime, instead of spending time on checking up on families.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE TO VISIT INDIA, SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) presidential candidate, will depart for a visit to India and Singapore next week.

According to Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials, the ministry, including its outposts in the two countries, will provide assistance to Ma, although technical details involving the trip have been worked out by Ma's aides.

Ma is slated to depart for India June 11 and will visit Indian officials and business leaders through June 13 before proceeding to Singapore later that day. Ma will return to Taipei June 15 after meeting Singaporean political and business leaders.
Ma, a former KMT chairman who stepped down from the party's top post in February, was nominated in early May by the KMT as its presidential candidate, despite corruption charges against him.
He is charged with embezzlement involving a special municipal monthly allowance earmarked for his discretionary use during his two terms as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW AMENDED TO PROTECT RIGHTS OF MENTAL PATIENTS

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Mental Health Law Tuesday to protect the rights of mental patients.
The amendment saw the removal of an article in the original law that allowed for the chemical castration of mental patients.

The amended law forbids people from deserting mental patients, abusing patients physically or mentally, leaving mental patients with self-care disability in dangerous environments, coercing or beguiling the patients into marriages, committing crimes against the patients and using the patients to commit crimes.

Offenders can be fined up to NT$150,000, with their names being publicized, while the authorities can also require that offenders accept domestic education and guidance lessons for up to 50 hours, the law stipulates.
In addition, the law prohibits the media from using discriminatory references and descriptions while making reports about mental illness.
Reports that are not based on fact and those that can mislead their readers or audience into discriminating against mental patients are also forbidden, according to the law.

Media organizations that violate these rules can be fined up to NT$500,000 and can be ordered to make corrections. Those who fail to comply within a deadline can be fined repeatedly, the law stipulates.

Meanwhile, the law states that health authorities around the country should set up community mental health centers that will be responsible for educating the public about mental health, training mental health professionals, providing counseling and transfer services for mental patients and carrying out the prevention and control of suicide and substance abuse.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Wang Jung-chang said the amendment is the first step toward the development of community-based mental health care, in the hope that an up-to-date model can be established to serve the needs of mental patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINIMUM WAGE INCREASE TO BE FINALIZED THIS WEEK

TEXT.P: The amount of the minimum wage increase will be finalized this week and put into practice July 1, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun said Tuesday.

Chen said the Executive Yuan is now listening views from all quarters, taking into consideration a proposal by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , the views of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, and suggestions by business and industrial groups.

According to the CLA's proposal, the minimum wage should be raised from the present NT$15,840 (US$476) by 9.09 percent to NT$17,280 per month, while the hourly wage should be raised from the current NT$66 to NT$95, although trade groups that visited the Executive Yuan that day complained that the level of increase is "much too high."
The CLA believes that the level of hourly wage increase should not be separate from that of the monthly increase, and should be increased at one time, not in a piecemeal way.
But to lessen the burden of the employers and for the sake of a comprehensive plan, the CLA has also proposed several sets of complementary measures.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung recently said that the minimum wage is aimed at protecting the livelihoods of laborers and maintaining their purchasing power, noting that the minimum wage has remained unchanged since 1997.
He further said the minimum wage hike will take into consideration the basic needs of laborers, the impact on Taiwan's industrial competitiveness and consumer price fluctuations.
However, major business and industrial groups called for a minimum wage increase of no more than 5 percent, with a minimum hourly wage of no more than NT$82.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHERY TRAINING BOAT SETS SAIL FOR OCEAN PATROL

TEXT.P: Fishery training boat the Yu Hsun No. 2 set sail Tuesday from Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan for a 183-day patrol of the Pacific and Indian oceans.
Fisheries Agency Director Hsieh Ta-wen presided over a ceremony as the boat embarked to assist in maintaining international fishing order.

Addressing the mission that was formed with the cooperation of the Fisheries Agency and the Coast Guard Administration, Hsieh said the Yu Hsun No. 2 is expected to travel about 35,000 nautical miles before it returns home.

The main purpose of the voyage is to monitor Taiwan fishing boats in the Pacific and Indian oceans in a drive to enhance Taiwan's oceanic fishery management on the one hand, and to show Taiwan's efforts in oceanic fishery management on the other.
The boat is staffed with fisheries inspectors and coast guard personnel in addition to its regular crew. The vessel is armed.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.070 to close at NT$33.012.
A total of US$900 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.935 and peaked at NT$33.024.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW FISH LADDER HELPFUL IN PRESERVING ENDANGERED SPECIES: ECOLOGISTS

TEXT.P: The newly-built fish ladder in Shinwulu Creek, Taitung County has been helpful in preserving the endangered Varicorhinus alticorpus -- a species of fish endemic only to Taiwan, ecologists based in the eastern county reported Tuesday.

The species of fish was discovered in 1920 by Japanese researchers. Since that time, its numbers have been decreasing around the island due to overfishing and habitat destruction caused by human activity. Shinwulu Creek and Beinan River in Taitung have remained as the only two unthreatened major habitats for the fish species in recent years.
However, members of local environment groups noted that "the environment along Shinwulu Creek has been in jeopardy since a water intake reservoir was built some years ago."

"Since that time, " they continued, "fish have died in large numbers every summer in the creek, including the rare Varicorhinus alticorpus, because the badly-designed reservoir often leads fish into following dead-end courses."
In order to prevent further mass die-offs, the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs appropriated funds last year to build a fish ladder to help fish bypass the reservoir.
After several months of observation, the local ecologists claimed that the number of trapped fish has declined since the construction of the fish ladder was completed early this year.
"However, there is still much more that can be done to save the Varicorhinus alticorpus, " they noted, adding that "these measures should be taken before the species becomes extinct."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SALT CHAIRMAN PROMISES NOT TO RAISE PRICES

TEXT.P: Taiwan Salt Industrial Corp. Chairman Lin Ching promised Tuesday not to increase salt prices during his term in order to ease consumers' worries.
Lin said Taiwan Salt has not raised prices for about 20 years, even after its privatization in 2003.

Production costs of salt have increased due to soaring world raw material prices, Lin said, adding that Taiwan Salt will not increase its salt prices and will follow the government's policy of stabilizing domestic raw material prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Tax police chief refuses offer of new post.
Italian tax police chief Roberto Speciale refused the offer of a new post with the state audit court and was planning to go to court to fight the government's decision to oust him as tax police head.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO CELEBRATE DRAGON BOAT FESTIVAL JUNE 17-19

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government will hold a series of activities June 17-19 to celebrate this year's Dragon Boat Festival in Taipei's Dajia Riverside Park.

Nine dragon boat teams from the United States, South Africa and the Philippines will join 116 teams from all over Taiwan in an international dragon boat race, with the final competition scheduled for June 19.
Visitors to the carnival-like festival will be able to savor a variety of delicacies and buy artifacts at 150 stalls in the park.
They can also enjoy jazz music played by a band of the Taipei American School and watch performances by street artists and new immigrants in Taiwan.
Parents and their children can participate in a "parent-child iron man triathlon" -- a fun game designed for entire families.
At exactly 12 noon of the Dragon Boat Festival, which falls on the fifth day of the fifth lunar month, or June 19, visitors will be invited to join a competition to stand raw eggs on end.

The Dragon Boat Festival originated from activities commemorating the death of a highly esteemed poet, Chu Yuan, who served as a minister in the state of Chu during China's Warring States Period (475-221 B.C.) . He committed suicide by drowning himself in a river to protest his dismissal by a corrupt prince. Fishermen nearby raced their boats in an attempt to save him but were unable to recover his body.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Crackdown on middle class wine drinkers Middle-class wine drinkers will be the focus of government plans to make drunkenness as socially unacceptable as smoking, The Times has learnt.
Under the plans published today, a fresh audit is to be conducted by the Government into the overall costs of alcohol abuse to society and the National Health Service.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS GAP BETWEEN GROWTH FIGURES, POPULAR PERCEPTION

TEXT.P: A majority of respondents to a public opinion poll complained about lingering economic doldrums, declining income, inflating consumer prices and the widening wealth gap, pollsters said Tuesday.

According to the results of the survey conducted by the China Times, a Taipei- based Chinese-language daily, 69 percent of the respondents said they feel the domestic economy is in bad shape, while 21 percent said the economy is "so-so," and only 4 percent gave the economy a positive review, with 6 percent refusing to answer the question.
The telephone poll was conducted from May 30-June 1 among randomly chosen adults, with 829 valid samples collected and a margin of error of 3.5 percent recorded.

Compared with the findings of a similar survey conducted by the newspaper in mid-February, the ratio of those who perceived the economy as "sluggish" rose 21 percent while the percentage of those who felt the economy was "in good shape or robust" decreased 13 percent.

The survey findings marked a sharp contrast to official growth figures. According to statistics released by the government, the country's gross domestic product (GDP) posted a 4.15 percent gain year-on-year in the first quarter of this year.

Superficially, Taiwan's economy has continued to grow, but the poll found that few respondents are upbeat about their economic well-being. According to the poll results, 47 percent said they are worried about a possible decrease in their real household income; 36 percent said they expect their family income to remain almost the same as last year; while only 9 percent said they think their income is likely to increase.

While the government has often touted a steady decline in the unemployment rate, but fear of job losses has continued to haunt many wage earners. The survey results show that 54 percent of the respondents said they are afraid of losing their jobs, compared to 43 percent who said they have no such worries.

Asked about their views on the current consumer price levels, 56 percent said they can hardly endure the present upward spiral; 32 percent said they perceive the price hikes to be moderate; 7 percent said they feel the price levels have remained almost unchanged; and only a tiny number of respondents said they feel consumer prices are falling.

The increasing wealth gap between rich and poor is now widely perceived, according to the poll. Up to 88 percent of those surveyed said they think the rich-poor gap has been widening seriously while only 5 percent said the problem is not very serious.

Asked about Taiwan's current socio-economic structure, 56 percent perceived themselves as middle class in the social hierarchy, compared to 1 percent who perceive themselves as upper class and 35 percent who said they are at the bottom of society.

Meanwhile, 81 percent said they agree with the comment that Taiwan's middle class has disappeared, with wealth getting more concentrated among fewer people, while the poor are getting poorer. However, 11 percent said they disagree with the observation.

Generally speaking, 46 percent said their current livelihoods are roughly same as the previous year; 40 percent said their living standards have declined and only 13 percent said their living quality has improved.

As for major obstacles to Taiwan's economic development, 42 percent said "government inaction due to partisan strife" is the most serious problem hindering economic development; 32 percent said official corruption and incompetence is to blame; 7 percent attributed the current woes to international competition; and 6 percent said cross-Taiwan Strait issues are the main hindrance.

Economists also attributed the gap between bright economic growth figures and bleak popular perception to a combination of factors, including the country's excessive reliance on exports for economic growth, relocation of a number of manufacturing industries to China and other areas to lower production costs, flagging private consumption and investment, zero growth in salaries for a large number of wage earners; and most of the economic growth benefits enjoyed by capitalists and corporate owners.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG PHILANTHROPIST GETS HONORARY DOCTORATE FROM NTNU

TEXT.P: National Taiwan Normal University (NTNU) awarded an honorary doctoral degree to Hong Kong philanthropist Tin Ka-ping Tuesday in recognition of his longstanding support for education advancement in Hong Kong, China and Taiwan.
NTNU Principal Kuo Yi-hsiung presented the honor to 88-year-old Tin during a ceremony marking the university's 61st founding anniversary.
Tin, a celebrated entrepreneur and long-time donor to more than 150 schools and some 800 charitable projects, announced at the ceremony that he will donate NT$10 million (US$302,020) to NTNU.
NTNU will use the money to strengthen its programs at the College of International Studies and Education for Overseas Chinese located on its Linkou campus.

Tin, who settled in Hong Kong in 1958, is chairman of TinsChemical Corp. and founder of the K.P. Tin Foundation. He is known as the "father of 100 schools" because of his generous contributions to primary schools, secondary schools and universities. More than 40 schools in China are named after him.

He has also donated to hundreds of hospitals and charitable organizations in China. A recipient of many honors and awards, Tin has been made a Member of the Order of the British Empire, honorary citizen of over 30 provinces, cities and counties in China and has been conferred honorary doctorates and professorships by more than 30 universities.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVENUES OF DOMESTIC AIRLINES CONTINUE TO DECLINE: CAA

TEXT.P: Revenues of domestic airlines plying western Taiwan routes have continued to decline, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) reported Tuesday.

CAA officials made the observation despite the fact that domestic airlines have been trying to attract more passengers with major discounts aimed at closing the gap with fares on the high speed railway and that four domestic airlines allow their air tickets to be used on each other's flights on the Taipei-Kaohsiung route.

The officials said domestic airlines have been badly affected by soaring oil prices and the slower economy in recent years. Since the launch of the high speed rail system earlier this year, which cut the rail travel time between Taipei and Kaohsiung to 90 minutes from the previous four-and-a-half hours, the impact was even more serious.

The number of air passengers in western Taiwan has continued to drop over the past three months, the officials said, noting that the number of passengers was 207,000 in March, dropping to 189,000 in April and to 173,000 in May.
The Taipei-Kaohsiung route has the largest share of air passengers. The number of passengers on the route was 137,000 in March, 124,000 in April and 113,000 in May, the officials said.
Faced with the dwindling revenues, the airlines can do little, the officials noted.

As the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. said it will increase the number of trains in September, while world oil prices have continued to be high, domestic airlines will have little leeway for further price cuts, the official said.

Mandarin Airlines stopped flying the Taipei-Taichung route last month. Although no other airlines have stopped flight routes so far, the officials expressed worry that their competitiveness might be getting weaker and that even if they do not suspend flights altogether , they may have to cut the number of flights, the officials added. ENDITEN/J

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREAN COUPLE ARRESTED FOR HEROIN SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: A Singaporean couple were arrested Monday at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport for attempting to smuggle heroin from Thailand into the country, customs officials said Tuesday.
According to the officials, the smuggled heroin, weighing about 3.7 kg, was found hidden inside a tapestry in the couple's luggage when they arrived on a flight from Bangkok.
The couple told police that they contacted drug dealers in Bangkok and were to deliver the smuggled heroin to someone in Taiwan.

The old-fashioned smuggling technique of hiding contraband in tapestries has made a comeback because now is the peak season for drug demand due to the summer vacation, the officials said, adding that the customs and aviation police will reinforce drug detection work.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Military Judges Dismiss Charges for 2 Detainees
The governments new system for trying Guantanamo detainees was thrown into turmoil Monday, when military judges in separate decisions dismissed war crimes charges against two of the detainees.
The rulings, the latest legal setbacks for the governments effort to bring war crimes charges against detainees, could stall the militarys prosecutions here.
Wall Street Journal:In Murdoch's Career, A Hand on the News
As Rupert Murdoch advances in his bid to buy The Wall Street Journal and its parent, Dow Jones & Co., a central issue is whether he will preserve the independence of its news operations -- and keep his own views and commercial interests from coloring what appears in the paper's news pages.
Since his $5 billion offer became public last month, some members of the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones, have expressed skepticism about his promise to preserve the paper's independence. Another big shareholder, James Ottaway Jr., declared that Mr. Murdoch has long "expressed his personal, political and business biases through his newspapers and television stations." Even as the family shifted last week from opposing the bid and met with Mr. Murdoch yesterday to discuss his offer, it began talking about ways to set up a mechanism for safeguarding the paper's editorial independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAY CPI DROPS 0.03% YEAR-ON-YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) for May dropped 0.03 percent from the same month of last year, marking the first time that the CPI has declined after rising for six consecutive months, according to tallies released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Compared with April, the CPI for May increased 0.21 percent, DGBAS officials said.
For the first five months of this year, the CPI gained 0.72 percent over the same period of last year, the officials went on.
For May, the core CPI -- excluding fruit, vegetables, fish, shellfish and energy -- went up 0.65 percent year-on-year, they said.
By category, medical costs for May jumped 4.93 percent year-on-year; food prices climbed 2.54 percent; clothing prices rose 1.86 percent; and housing costs increased 0.7 percent, they said.
Wu Chao-ming, a section chief at the DGBAS's Third Department, said Taiwan's current consumer prices remain at a moderate level and that the chances of comprehensive hikes are slight.
Wu attributed the hike in food prices for May to the rise in imported crops such as corn and soybeans.
However, because of the good weather so far this year, the prices of fruit and vegetables for May dropped 18 percent over the same month of last year, Wu said.
Other items that became cheaper in May also include communication equipment, digital cameras and televisions, whose prices declined 12.6 percent, 10.1 percent and 9.4 percent, respectively, he said.

Meanwhile, the wholesale price index (WPI) for May soared 7.59 percent compared with the same month of last year, owing to hikes in the prices of primary metals, chemicals, and oil- and coal-based products, according to the DGBAS.

While the prices of domestically produced products intended for domestic consumption rose 5.96 percent year-on-year in May, the prices of imports jumped 10.31 percent, due to a 4.53 percent year-on-year depreciation of the new Taiwan dollar against the U.S. dollar for the period, the officials said.
The prices of exports climbed 6.57 percent, they added.

For the first five months of this year, the WPI moved up 7.39 percent over the year-earlier level, they said, adding that the DGBAS has predicted that the WPI for the whole of 2007 will rise 3.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPARTING MALAYSIAN REPRESENTATIVE VISITS KINMEN

TEXT.P: Departing Malaysian Representative to the Republic of China Ku Abdul Rahman visited the outlying island of Kinmen Tuesday and described it as a "unique and fantastic place."
Ku Abdul Rahman, president of the Malaysian Friendship and Trade Center in Taiwan, and his deputy, Shahril Effendi Abd. Ghany, were greeted on the island by Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng.
It was the Ku Abdul Rahman's first visit to Kinmen since he assumed the post nearly 30 months ago, and his last before he steps down and returns to Malaysia June 10.

After visiting traditional villages, relics left from the war between Taiwan and China and popular tourist spots, Ku Abdul Rahman said he was very impressed by Kinmen, especially upon learning of the deep relations and links between Kinmen and Malaysia.
Lee told Ku Abdul Rahman that many Malaysian people, including several well- known business leaders, are descendants of immigrants from Kinmen.
According to Lee, more than 100,000 Malaysian nationals are descended from Kinmen immigrants -- a number that well exceeds the present number of Kinmen residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTRY PROMOTES ENERGY EFFICIENCY CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long and representatives of 16 large enterprises signed an endorsement for an energy efficiency campaign Tuesday, promising to wear casual dress in the office and to turn down air conditioning by one degree Celsius in both the workplace and in their homes.

During the signing ceremony held by the Bureau of Energy (BOE) to mark World Environment Day, which falls on June 5, Chen claimed that the measures could lower Taiwan's electricity consumption by 2.5 billion kilowatt hours in summer, noting that this would be enough to power Penghu County for 7.5 years.
Saving this much energy is also equivalent to avoiding 1.73 million tons of carbon dioxide emissions, Chen added.

He reiterated Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's recent call for government officials to wear casual dress to the office unless they need to host meetings with foreign guests. Chang also suggested that air conditioning in offices be maintained at 26-28 C as part of efforts to promote the Summer Energy Efficiency campaign.

Under the BOE's assessment, the power load for air conditioning accounts for 30 percent of the total peak load in summer. Based on research, the air conditioning for people wearing suits and ties has to be 1.6 C lower than that of people wearing casual clothing, the BOE said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE, VIETNAMESE INFORMATION INDUSTRIES FORGE ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese and Vietnamese information industries forged the 2007 APEC Digital Opportunity Center (ADOC) Information and Communications Technology (ICT) Alliance Monday in Taipei with the aim of taking part in international digital development projects, industry sources said Tuesday.
Industry representatives from the Vietnam Electronic Industries Association and the Taipei Computer Association (TCA) signed the agreement with the ADOC Secretariat.

The signing ceremony was presided over by Hoang Le Minh, deputy director of Ho Chi Minh City's Department of Posts and Telecommunications; Wang Chien- ping, director of the Multilateral Trade Affairs Division under Taiwan's Bureau of Foreign Trade; TCA Secretary- General Enoch Du; and Eva Yueh, deputy director of the Institute for Information Industry.

Wang said the ADOC program was originally proposed by former Academica Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh at the 11th APEC Economic Leaders' Meeting in Bangkok in 2003 to bridge the digital divide and upgrade e-capability throughout the Asia- Pacific region.

He added that the 2007 ADOC Alliance was formed to integrate Taiwanese and Vietnamese information industry resources and professional experience to help ADOC members extend their international markets.

Since the ADOC program was launched three years ago, Taiwan has set up 19 ADOCs in Vietnam, Indonesia, the Philippines, Chile, Peru and Papua New Guinea, while adding one ADOC and two tele-centers in Thailand last month and planning to promote ADOC programs and train 1,300 people in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG COUNTY FARMERS CALL FOR MONKEY CULL

TEXT.P: Farmers in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung are urging the government to control the population of protected Formosan macaques in order to lessen the damage they cause to crops.

Making the appeal on behalf of the farmers during a county council meeting Tuesday, Councilor Lin Fu-pao called for government-supervised action to cull the monkeys that roam freely in the county's rural townships and ravage fruit and other crops.

Lin pointed out that a colony of the monkeys ruined nearly 3,000 banana plants on a farm in a single night, while guava and mango orchards in Chishan and Liukuei townships also lost all their fruit to the animals.
He said the government should work out a system to permit monkey culls during specific seasons.

When told by agriculture officials that Article 21 of the nation's Wildlife Conservation Law allows farmers to catch or kill the monkeys that ravage their crops but must report their actions to local authorities, Lin said farmers cannot do the killing because the law does not allow them to own firearms.
He said the county government should form a task force to help farmers catch or shoot the monkeys.

The Formosan rock monkey is a species of macaque endemic to Taiwan. Under the Wildlife Conservation Law, those who hunt or trap the animals -- other than people coveredd under Article 21 of the law -- face up to five years in prison and fines of up to NT$1 million (US$30,200).
According to an estimate by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture in 2001, Taiwan's rock monkey population totaled about 250,000 at that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FARMERS PARTY TO BE INAUGURATED JUNE 15

TEXT.P: A new political party is scheduled to be launched in the southern county of Kaohsiung June 15 to push for the establishment of an agriculture ministry, organizers said Tuesday.
The new party, to be named the Taiwan Farmers Party, will not install a chairman and will instead opt for collective leadership, organizers said.

In the initial stage, a 20-to-30-member group will be formed to lead the party. The group will be composed of scholars, experts, representatives of grassroots farmers and disadvantaged people, organizers said.

Claiming that the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture is not powerful enough to protect and boost farmers' interests and rights, Chang Yung-cheng, secretary- general of the Taiwan Provincial Farmers Association, said the new party will give priority to pushing for the creation of a ministry of agriculture to map out sustainable agricultural development policies and better protect farmers' rights and interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO HEAD FOR VENICE TO PROMOTE TAIWANESE ARTS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin will depart for Venice Wednesday to attend the 52nd Venice Biennale activities and preside over the opening of the Taiwan Pavilion at the exhibition, city government sources said Tuesday.
According to the sources, Hau will head a group of Taiwan artists to take part in a variety of arts activities that form the Venice Biennale.

In addition to presiding over the opening of the Taiwan Pavilion, Hau will also help promote artworks on display in the pavilion. The artworks are all created by a new generation of Taiwan artists, the sources said, adding that Hau will also study glassware and other creative industries in the Venice area before wrapping up his visit June 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALARM BELL RINGING ON ROC-COSTA RICA TIES: MOFA

TEXT.P: Alarm bells are ringing on relations between the Republic of China and its Central American ally of Costa Rica, a senior Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official warned Wednesday.
According to the official, the longstanding ROC-Costa Rican diplomatic ties are at a crossroads and may see a change in the near future.
"Both the MOFA and the ROC diplomatic staff stationed in Costa Rica have been on full alert and are keeping close tabs on relevant developments," said the official who preferred anonymity.

Costa Rica has been in close contact with China in recent years as it needs China's support to realize its goal of becoming a non-permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, the official analyzed, adding that the vast Chinese market is yet another incentive to draw Cost Rica closer to Beijing.

Last September, the official recalled that Costa Rican President Oscar Arias held a tete-a-tete with then-Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing while both of them were attending the annual U.N. General Assembly.

On May 14 this year, the Costa Rican ambassador to the World Health Organization (WHO) even cast a "no" vote in the world health regulatory body's annual assembly in Geneva on the issue whether to include Taiwan's membership application into its meeting agenda.

"All these incidents were bad omens for our bilateral ties" the official said, adding that the latest intelligence collected by the ROC Embassy in San Jose also shows that Costa Rica indeed intends to accelerate normalization of its relations with China.
Against this backdrop, the official said, Taiwan must be prepared for any worst- case scenario.
Costa Rica established diplomatic ties with the ROC in 1944 and the two countries have since maintained a cordial relationship until recently.

When Arias, a Nobel Peace Prize laureate, was elected president for a second time in May 2006, he declared that his administration will review its policy toward China based on Costa Rica's national interest. His declaration was seen a signal of the activation of Costa Rica's move toward normalizing ties with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 6, or the 21st day of the fourth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1901: Sukarno, Indonesia's first president, is born. He led the country's independence movement against the Dutch colonists.
1916: Yuan Shih-kai dies at Hsinhua Palace in Beijing at the age of 58, and the republican form of government is restored. Yuan, who forced the Congress to elect him president on Oct. 6, 1913 and annulled the provisional constitution on May 1, 1914, proclaimed himself emperor on Dec. 1915.
1934: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is established to protect the interests of investors.
1944: Under the supreme command of U.S. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, around one million Allied troops in 4,000 ships disembark for the coast of Normandy, France to launch the largest military invasion in the world's history and begin the final campaign to defeat Nazi Germany.
1946: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek accepts General Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1967: Egypt closes the Suez Canal during the Six-Day Arab-Israeli War. The canal remained closed to international shipping for eight years.
1974: A three-year agreement on the exchange of science information is signed by the Republic of China and South Korea.
1976: Paul Getty, the American oil billionaire who made his first million by the time he was 22, dies in London at the age of 83. He amassed one of the world's largest fortunes through the oil business.
1978: The 7th Sino-American Conference on Mainland China draws 50 American and 38 Chinese scholars plus four observers from Hong Kong, Canada, the United States and South Korea. The main theme of the meeting is "Mainland China in the Post-Mao Period."
1981: Seven coaches of an overcrowded passenger train are blown off the tracks into the River Kosi in Nihar, India, killing some 3,000 people.
1988: In New York City, Davis Stern becomes the blower of the world's biggest bubble when he blows one measuring a record 15.24 meters in length.
1994: A Chinese airliner on a domestic flight from the tourist center of Xian crashes, killing all 160 people on board.
1994: An earthquake rocks Colombia, killing some 1,000 people and leaving thousands of others homeless.
1994: Mainland Chinese air pirate Chou Weichiang hijacks a Southern Airlines passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: Premier Lien Chan pays the first visit by a high-ranking ROC official to Mexico in the 23 years since the two countries severed diplomatic relations.
1995: Japanese Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama and his ruling coalition agree to express "deep remorse" for Japan's acts of aggression in World War II.
1998: The United Nations Security Council votes to condemn both India and Pakistan for their nuclear weapons tests.
1999: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, leading a 59-member delegation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day official visit.
1999: The ROC bans meat, poultry and other agricultural products from Belgium in the wake of a dioxin contamination in that European country.
2000: The acting chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, Lien Chan, says that the "mini three links" between the ROC's outlying islands and mainland China should serve a political purpose.
2001: An army battalion stationed at the Chengkungling base in Taichung County is quarantined after one of its soldiers died from spinal meningitis the previous day.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The highest class of men are those who are born with a natural understanding. The next class are those who acquire understanding by study and application. There are others again who are born by nature dull, but who by strenuous efforts, try to acquire understanding: such men may be considered the next class. Those who are born by nature dull and yet will not take the trouble to acquire understanding are the lowest class of people."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAYI COUNTY RECEIVES 116.5 MM OF RAINFALL IN LESS THAN 9 HOURS

TEXT.P: Chiayi County in southern Taiwan received 116.5 mm of rainfall between midnight Tuesday and 8: 30 a.m. Wednesday, marking the largest amount of rainfall around the island during that period of time, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported.
The amount of rainfall nearly met the CWB's definition of "extremely heavy rain, " which means that a place receives over 130 mm of rain within 24 hours, CWB meteorologists said.
Taiwan is currently under the influence of a plum rain season frontal system, with torrential rainfall expected in western and northeastern regions of the island, the meteorologists forecast.
The frontal system will continue to linger until next week, they said, warning of possible flooding in low-lying areas and possible landslides in mountainous areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINIMUM WAGE TO BE RAISED 9.09 PERCENT ON JULY 1

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced Wednesday that the minimum wage will be raised by 9.09 percent on July 1.
With the hike, the minimum wage will be NT$17,280 per month and the hourly wage will be NT$95, Chang said during a regular Cabinet meeting at the Executive Yuan.

Relevant administrative units, including the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , and the Council for Economic Planning and Development, are planning to hold a press conference later in the day to explain the new measure and their preparations for the possible impact of the adjustment, according to the Executive Yuan.
In response to business groups' opposition to a hike exceeding 5 percent, the CLA has proposed several sets of complementary measures to lessen the burden on employers.
Chang recently said that the minimum wage is aimed at protecting the livelihood of laborers and maintaining their purchasing power, noting that the minimum wage has remained unchanged since 1997.
However, major business and industrial groups called for a minimum wage increase of no more than 5 percent, with a minimum hourly wage of no more than NT$82.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. URGED TO MAINTAIN 'STRATEGIC AMBIGUITY' POLICY ON TAIWAN ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 5 (CNA) 06/06/07 12:19:51 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States should continue its policy of "strategic ambiguity" on the Taiwan issue, former U.S. Secretary of State James Baker said Tuesday.
Baker noted that since the U.S. government switched recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979, Washington has adopted "strategic ambiguity" as its guiding principle in dealing with Taiwan.

Under this policy, Washington will not specify what action it will take on the question of China's possible use of force against Taiwan, while making clear to both sides of the Taiwan Strait that the United States expects a peaceful resolution of the Taiwan issue, Baker said.
According to Baker, the Taiwan issue will find its own resolution eventually, and what the United States needs to do is to maintain the cross-strait status quo.
Baker reasoned that as long as the trade and business activities between Taiwan and China continue, cross-strait relations will develop in a positive direction and reach a resolution in the end.

Baker, who served as secretary of state between 1989 and 1992 in the administration of then U.S. President George Bush, made the remarks in response to a question from a reporter, after delivering a speech titled "The Future of Sino-American Relations" during a U.S.-China Business Council luncheon in Washington, D.C.

Baker's remarks came in the wake of observations made by many American think tanks that the cross-strait policy of the administration of President George W. Bush is turning from one of "strategic ambiguity" to one of "strategic clarity."

In a report titled "U.S.-China Relations: An Affirmative Agenda, A Responsible Course" released in April, the New York-based Council on Foreign Relations suggested that the United States continue the policies of "dual restraint" and "dual assurance" toward Taiwan.

These mean "deterring Chinese aggression and opposing Taiwan's steps toward independence while at the same time assuring China that the United States does not seek to perpetuate Taiwan's separation from the mainland and assuring Taiwan that the United States does not seek to pressure it into negotiating a final resolution, " according to the report.

Meanwhile, in an annual report on China's military power published in May, the U.S. Defense Department pointed out that although the principal focus of China's military modernization in the near term appears to be preparing for potential conflict in the Taiwan Strait, Beijing is increasingly surveying the strategic landscape beyond Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$100 MILLION WORTH OF HIGH-GRADE HEROIN SEIZED IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) arrested two drug "mules" and a "fund provider" in Taichung City, central Taiwan Wednesday, confiscating 28 bricks of high-grade heroin with an estimated street value of nearly NT$100 million (US$3 million) in the process.

According to officials from the CIB central Taiwan operations, Lin Jui-yi, a behind-the-scene fund provider, sent a huge sum of money to a drug dealer in Vietnam in early May for the purchase and process of the heroin bricks.

Wang Hsien-min and Wu Chun-chieh, the two traffickers, then traveled to Vietnam to pick up the heroin. Wang and Wu reportedly first packed the heroin bricks in the bellies of fish, then froze the fish and sent the "frozen seafood" to a Taiwan-bound fishing boat heading for the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Unaware that a CIB mobile unit had been monitoring them since late May, Wang, Wu and Lin were arrested in Taichung City Tuesday while the shipment of fish containing the heroin was being delivered from Kaohsiung to a house located on Taichung City's Loyeh Street where they were expecting to receive the shipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND NOT OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CHINA REMOVING MISSILES

TEXT.P: A senior defense official said Wednesday that it is not optimistic that China will remove its missiles targeting Taiwan to pave the way for cross-strait talks.

Vice Chief of the General Staff Peng Sheng-chu made the remarks while giving a report on how to cope with high-tech development of the military at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee.

Legislator Lin Yu-feng of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) noted that KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said recently that China removing the missiles is a prerequisite for the holding of cross-strait talks, asking Peng to give his comment on Ma's remarks.
Peng said that he cannot give his personal opinion but that the Ministry of National Defense (MND) is not optimistic that China will easily remove the missiles.
Lin also noted that China has 11 guided missile bases at which missiles aimed at Taiwan have been deployed, asking Peng which of the bases poses the greatest threat to Taiwan.
Peng said that the point is not which base poses the greatest threat, noting that any missiles that can reach Taiwan proper represent a threat.

President Chen Shui-bian recently called for China to honor the Olympic spirit of fostering world peace by removing all the nearly 1,000 missiles it has deployed against Taiwan. Beijing will host the 2008 Olympic Games.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPOSED AMENDMENT WOULD STIFFEN PUNISHMENT FOR ANIMAL ABUSE

TEXT.P: Lawmakers reviewed Wednesday a proposed amendment to the Animal Protection Law that would increase the penalty for abusing or deserting animals.

The bill, which was discussed by the Legislative Yuan's Economics and Energy Committee, would introduce a jail sentence of up to one year, in addition to a fine of up to NT$50,000 in the current law, as punishment for perpetrators of various offensive or violent acts against animals that result in severe injuries or death of the animals. These would include pet owners who allow their pets to be harassed, abused or harmed; pet owners who desert their pets; and people who harass, abuse or harm animals.
Repeat offenders would also be subject to the prison sentence, even if their acts do not cause severe injuries or death of the animals.

Other repeat offenders subject to the jail sentence would include pet owners who fail to provide necessary health care for injured or ill animals and anyone caught slaughtering animals in public places without permission from relevant authorities.
Meanwhile, people could be sentenced to one year behind bars, in addition to being fined up to NT$10,000 as stipulated under the current law, if they commit the following acts twice in five years.

These include failure by pet owners to register their pets' birth, ownership, transfer, loss or death information within a set deadline; violation of rules concerning the transportation of animals; and allowing pets to visit public places in the absence of care by a person above seven years of age or without proper protective measures.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim said the bill signifies a major step forward in animal protection in the country, which she said will raise awareness among the public that it is unlawful to abuse animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA PUTS FORWARD FIVE MEASURES TO COPE WITH WAGE HIKE'S IMPACT

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) put forward five measures Wednesday to help alleviate the impact on small- and medium-size enterprises of the 9.09 percent minimum wage hike announced earlier the same day by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung.

CLA Chairman Lu Tien-lin said that lower class workers and their families are expected to benefit when the country's minimum wage is hiked to NT$17,280 (US$523.64) per month and the hourly wage is raised to NT$95 on July 1, but he added that the hike may have a negative impact on small- and medium-size enterprises.

To offset the expected negative impact, Lu said, the CLA has decided to subsidize owners of certain businesses, including fast-food chains, restaurants, supermarkets and gas stations, with a working staff of less than 50 people. The owners will be entitled to subsidies of NT$10 per hour per head when the staff members work less than 32 hours a week. This subsidy incentive will be implemented for one year on a trial basis, he added.

The CLA has also decided to offer subsidies of NT$5,000 per month per head to owners of companies which employ disadvantaged workers, including physically and mentally challenged people and senior citizens.

To deal with the possibility that many workers may lose their jobs because of the hike in the minimum hourly wage, the CLA will also work to help disadvantaged workers find employment, receive vocational training and receive unemployment subsidies, Lu noted.
The CLA will also see to it that the food and accommodation allowance provided to foreign laborers working in Taiwan is raised from the current NT$4,000 per month to NT$5,000.
CLA vocational training subsidies will also be raised as the fifth measure to deal with the impact of the hike in the minimum wage, which has remained unchanged since 1997, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT TO ADDRESS JAPAN'S FOREIGN CORRESPONDENTS CLUB
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/07 16:25:01 (By Mike Chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui has been invited to address the Foreign Correspondents Club of Japan (FCCJ) this weekend, FCCJ officials said Wednesday.
Lee will speak on Japan's foreign policy and then take questions from the media, the officials said.
The event will replace an original plan by Lee to hold a news conference June 9, the same day he is scheduled to wrap up his 11-day visit and return to Taiwan.
The change in itinerary indicates that his Japan visit has attracted a high level of media attention, observers said.
The FCCJ was founded in 1945 and has more than 300 members. It often invites Japanese or foreign celebrities to speak at the club.
President Chen Shui-bian held a video conference with the club in July 2005, and opposition Kuomintang then-Chairman Ma Ying-jeou addressed the club during a visit to Japan in July 2006.
This is Lee's third trip to Japan since his presidency ended in May 2000. However, the trip marks the first time he has visited Tokyo and the first time he has made a public speech in the country.

On June 1, he addressed an audience in Tokyo after he was awarded the first Shimpei Goto Prize by the Japanese publisher Fijiwara Shoten's Goto Shimpei Organization in recognition of his contribution to Taiwan's urbanization and democratization.
Lee was scheduled to deliver a speech at Akita International University Wednesday on the final stop of a tour of northeastern Japan, after which he was expected to return to Tokyo.
On Thursday, he will visit Takushoku University in Tokyo and address the Friends of Lee Teng-hui Club on the global situation in 2007 and after.

He has also indicated his desire to visit the controversial Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo to pay his respects to his older brother who died fighting for the Japanese colonial government during World War II. It was uncertain if Lee will realize the plan. The shrine also reveres executed Japanese war criminals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CANCELS TRIP TO VENICE DUE TO HEAVY RAINFALL FORECAST

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin has decided to cancel his planned trip to Venice, Italy, for which he was scheduled to leave Wednesday evening, city officials said.

Hau's assistants said that the chances of the mayor departing on the trip over the next few days are low because torrential rainfall has been forecast in the city. They added torrential rainfall caused flooding in many low-lying areas of the city early Wednesday morning.

Citing a Central Weather Bureau (CWB) report, City Fire Department Director Hsung Kuang-hua said northern Taiwan monitoring stations detected storm clouds over the Zhuzihu district on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei, as well as over the districts of Shipai, Guandu, Tienmu, Shilin and Waishuangxi early in the morning.

CWB meteorologists have therefore forecast more rainfall over the next several days and warned people living in low-lying areas of possible flooding, Hsung said during a disaster control meeting presided over by Hau at the fire department.
Hau had planned to depart for Venice Wednesday evening to attend the 52nd Venice Biennale activities and preside over the opening of the Taiwan Pavilion at the exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
KMT LAWMAKERS CONCERNED OVER `DOMINO EFFECT' IN FOREIGN TIES

TEXT.P: Members of the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) legislative caucus voiced grave concern Wednesday over a possible "domino effect" in Taiwan's foreign relations following reports of a likely change in Taiwan-Costa Rica ties.

KMT lawmakers, including legislative caucus whip Hsu Shao-ping, Su Chi and John Chiang, issued the warning in a Legislative Yuan news conference after Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials revealed the previous evening that "two-way Taiwan-Costa Rica relations might undergo a twist in the near future."
According to the MOFA officials, the Republic of China Embassy in that Central American country has swung into full alert and is closely watching developments.

Chiang, who is a former foreign minister, said he is worried that a "domino effect" might take place among Taiwan's diplomatic partners, mostly in Central and South America and Africa, if Costa Rica shifts its diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China.

Costa Rica, which has maintained diplomatic links with Taiwan for 63 years, is a symbolic stronghold of Taiwan's diplomatic offensive in the region, Chiang said, adding that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) administration should apologize to the Taiwan people over the uncertainty in bilateral ties.

KMT lawmakers also predicted that the DPP is very likely to rehash the issue of the country's bid to join the United Nations in the name of "Taiwan" prior to the legislative and presidential elections.

The DPP taking such an approach to fuel political issues instead of devoting energy to improving Taiwan's economy will not benefit Taiwan's people and will only further squeeze the country out of the international community, they contended.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA WILL NEVER BUDGE ON ISSUE OF SOVEREIGNTY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian predicted Wednesday that China will never budge on the issue of Taiwan's sovereignty and said it will have to be Taiwan that capitulates and surrenders its own sovereignty.
The president made the remarks when he received a delegation of U.S. China experts led by David M. Lampton at the Presidential Office.
"As Taiwan's president, I can't forego the national sovereignty of Taiwan," Chen said.
He also told the presidential candidates for the 2008 presidential election that they must not harbor any illusions about any softening of China's basic stance.

According to Chen, China's obstruction of Taiwan has always been relentless irrespective which party is in power and he claimed that the plight has "remained unchanged" from the period of the late presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo down to former President Lee Teng-hui.

He noted that the National Unification Council (NUC) -- a government agency to promote Taiwan's eventual unification with China -- was founded in 1990 during Lee's time as president, but China still test fired missiles into waters near Taiwan ahead of the country's first popular presidential election in 1996.
Chen scrapped the NUC in early 2006, along with the National Unification Guidelines.
He said his own experience over the past seven years has taught him never to harbor any illusions about China.

China's basic stance is "clear, steadfast and has never changed over the years," which is that Taiwan is not a sovereign state and that Taiwan is part of the People's Republic of China, the president said.
"For China, Taiwan is a local government, a special administrative region and a second Hong Kong," he said.

He noted that China is doing its best to marginalize Taiwan, citing the examples of Taiwan's setback in bidding for World Health Organization membership due to China's obstruction and a recent move by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) to downgrade Taiwan's membership to the level of a "non-sovereign regional member" under pressure from China.
"The question now is whether or not to insist on Taiwan's sovereignty, whether or not to resist the notion of Taiwan as a part of the People's Republic of China," Chen said.
Since he assumed the presidency in 2000, his administration has rejected the "one China" principle espoused by China, as well as eventual unification with China, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange were higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 10.69 points to close at 8,314.68.

The bourse opened at 8,330.72 and fluctuated between 8,376.97 and 8,313.59 during the day's trading. A total of 4.77 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$168.01 billion (US$5.09 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 2.4 percent, followed by construction issues and textile stocks both at 1.3 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, plastics and chemicals shares decreased 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 587 to 580, with 186 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL, BUSINESS SECTORS FRET OVER WAGE HIKE

TEXT.P: Members of the country's trade and industrial sectors were at loggerheads with the administration Wednesday over the issue of a 9.09 percent minimum wage hike, fretting that the increase might trigger an industrial exodus.

Commenting on Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's announcement earlier in the day that the country's minimum wage is to be hiked to NT$17,280 (US$523.64) per month and the hourly wage raised to NT$95 July 1, Ho Yu, a standing board member of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) , said the business sector will bear the brunt of the wage hike but the impact will in turn send shockwaves through the industrial manufacturing sector, which could eventually cause an industrial exodus.

Ho said that although the minimum wage is poised to be raised by 9.09 percent, business and industrial operators are expected to witness an increase of 11 percent in their salary and benefit payments to their workers as premiums for labor insurance and health insurance will be hiked and contributions to employees' retirement pensions will also be raised.
This incur upon them an extra financial burden to the tune of NT$36 billion nationwide each year, Ho estimated.
He added that the 9.09 percent hike is not expected to affect the industrial manufacturing sector too seriously, with only about 70,000 people impacted.

However, operators of retail businesses, including department stores, restaurants, chain stores and supermarkets, are expected to be affected the most, because most of them employ part-time or hourly paid workers.

Ho said members of the CNFI groups will not organize street protests over the issue but warned that they will simply lay off workers and change their business strategies in order to lower their operational overheads.
Meanwhile, Huang Mao-hsiung, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, also expressed worry over the imminent wage hike.

Huang said the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) should make more careful studies when trying to put forward coping measures to help alleviate the impact of the hike on small- and medium-sized enterprises.

CLA Chairman Lu Tien-lin said that same day that about 1.41 million "marginal" members of the country's workforce -- including foreign laborers, part-time workers, senior citizens who have returned to the employment arena after retirement and female workers -- are expected to benefit from the wage hike.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCTU TO ESTABLISH `INTELLIGENT PROSTHETICS RESEARCH CENTER'

TEXT.P: National Chiao Tung University (NCTU) in Hsinchu City is to establish a new research center for intelligent prosthetics, specializing in assisting the physically impaired with advanced bionic devices or biomedical technology, NCTU President Wu Chung-yu announced Wednesday at a press conference in Taipei.

Wu also noted that the center will be headed by Liu Wen-tai, a professor at the University of California, Santa Cruz. Liu, who has been devoted to the research and development of electronic eyes for years, said that with the help of the center, the improvement project on the existing generation of electronic eyes should provide fruitful results.

The first generation of electronic eye -- developed and tested in the United States -- employs a 16-pixel chip as an artificial light receptor. When implanted into the eye, the device can replace a dysfunctional retina, providing partial vision to the patient.

For the second-generation work, the light-sensing matrix will be expanded to 8x8 pixels to provide wider vision and the power will be provided by wireless transmission to allow greater head movements. The improved version will soon enter human testing both in the U.S. and Taiwan, according to Liu.

Besides visual enhancement devices, Liu noted that the center will also focus on non-medical electronic devices, such as ones that can help paralyzed patients regain body control by invigorating body parts with electric currents, or ones that can alleviate syndromes related to depression by stimulating certain areas of the brain.

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved up 31 points to close at 8,285, with 43,403 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for July rose 27 points to finish at 8,230, with 1,744 contracts traded, while September futures increased 24 points to end at 8,090, with 218 contract transactions. Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were higher.

September TE futures increased 3.85 points to end at 350.15, with four contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: POP SINGER FACES PENALTY, CIVIL LAWSUIT FOR DRUNK DRIVING

TEXT.P: Local pop singer Lin Hsiao-pei is facing severe punishment for drunk driving and a possible civil lawsuit after her car hit a 41-year-old nurse while she was driving drunk Wednesday in downtown Taipei.

The nurse died in hospital from serious wounds. Police said that because of the death and the fact that Lin's blood alcohol concentration was at 1.1 mg per liter, far above the limit of 0.55 mg, she will face charges of involuntary manslaughter and offenses against public safety.

However, despite killing a pedestrian, Lin will be subject to a maximum of just three years of imprisonment according to the Criminal Code, along with a maximum fine of just NT$60,000 (US$1,810). She will also have her license revoked.
The victim's family will also have the right to file a civil lawsuit against Lin to claim compensation of up to NT$10 million, according to city police.
