DOC.HEADLINE: METHADONE SUBSTITUTION PROGRAMS IN TAINAN AREA BEARING FRUIT

TEXT.P: Programs being offered by hospitals in Tainan city and county to help heroin addicts kick their habits with methadone substitution have achieved good results, a doctor at National Cheng Kung University Hospital said Wednesday.

Wang Yu-ting, who has been treating heroin addicts with the methadone substitution program at Cheng Kung University Hospital, quoted statistics as showing that from September 2006 until February this year, hospitals in the Tainan area had treated 225 heroin addicts with methadone.

Before joining the programs, 67 percent of the 225 drug abusers had committed criminal offenses, but after receiving the methadone treatment, the criminal recurrence rate dropped to 0.02 percent, Wang pointed out.

He added that Cheng Kung University Hospital has treated 35 new heroin addicts in the past two months but has found that about 70 percent of them have contracted HIV, hepatitis or syphilis -- mostly through intravenous injection of opiates.

Noting that intravenous injection has replaced sexual contact as the No. 1 cause of HIV transmission in Taiwan, Wang cited statistics, saying that more than 2,000 people in Taiwan contracted HIV in 2005 from using contaminated needles or syringes to inject heroin.

Methadone substitution is a relatively inexpensive method used by many countries to treat opiate addiction. Unlike heroin, which must be smoked or injected, methadone can be prescribed as a liquid syrup or in the form of pills. It is designed to suppress chronic addicts' narcotic withdrawal and reduce their dependence on heroin.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER HALF OF TAIWAN FAMILIES COMBINE CHINESE, WESTERN, FOLK THERAPY

TEXT.P: Over half of Taiwan's families have tried Chinese medicine, Western medicine and folk therapy as medical treatment options have become more diversified, official of National Cheng Kung University hospital said Wednesday.

Family medicine Dr. Huang Ying-hsiang said that a study on the medical treatment of 2,000 families around the country found that nearly half of rural families and nearly two-thirds of urban families have sought the three different forms of treatment.

Western medicine is still the mainstream therapy in Taiwan, although traditional Chinese medicine has become the most commonly sought after treatment after Western medicine, while the use of subsidiary and alternative therapies have also become popular.
The results of a survey conducted in 2003 show that three-quarters of the respondents said they would seek at least one kind of subsidiary or alternative therapy.

Those who have received higher education, are middle class and in poor health, and those who are women, who suffer from anxiety, chronic pain or urinary problems, are more often likely to seek alternative therapy, the study found.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OPPOSES REDUCING ID WAITING PERIOD FOR CHINESE SPOUSES

TEXT.P: An opposition-initiated draft amendment to a statute that would halve the waiting period for Chinese spouses of Taiwan nationals seeking identification cards would be "too lax" and would be "unfair, " the nation's top China policy- planning body said Wednesday.

The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) expressed the view as a Legislative Yuan committee was set to review the amendment to the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area later that day that would cut the waiting period from eight years to four.

MAC officials said that according to the amendment, Chinese spouses would in fact have to stay in Taiwan for only one-and-a-half years before they get ID cards, compared with women from other foreign countries married to Taiwanese men, who would have to stay here for two-and-a-half years before getting ID cards.

MAC officials noted that foreign women married to Taiwanese men have to reside in Taiwan continuously for three years to get ROC nationality, and then only if they give up their original nationalities and pass naturalization tests. After that, they can get ID cards after actually staying in Taiwan for more than two- and-a-half years, they said.
The officials said that foreign women married to Taiwanese men and Chinese spouses are different immigrants, noting that the statute does not demand that Chinese spouses pass naturalization tests.
"This is why we should not take the example of `foreign spouses' as reference for adjusting the system for Chinese spouses, lest it cause chaos," the officials added.

The number of Chinese spouses has exceeded 290,000, while the number of foreign women married to Taiwanese men has exceeded 130,000, the officials said. If the waiting period for Chinese spouses to obtain ID cards is shortened, the number will balloon, which will seriously impact Taiwan's social welfare resources, job market and social security overall.

Moreover, if the Chinese spouses obtain ID cards, they can apply for their direct kin aged over 70 and under 12 to come to Taiwan, so that the ensuing influx of Chinese will increase dramatically, the officials said.
The officials said that at present, the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are wide apart in terms of cultural background, social and education environment, living conditions and core values.

In addition, the problem of bogus marriages, or marriages of convenience among people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, is still serious, while statistics released by the Ministry of the Interior show that the number of divorces in cross-strait marriages exceeds 7,000 couples over the past two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIES WITH TAIWAN REMAIN UNCHANGED: COSTA RICA FOREIGN MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/07 19:51:52 (By Ramon Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Costa Rican Foreign Minister Bruno Stagno denied Wednesday news reports that alarm bells are ringing on diplomatic relations between Costa Rica and the Republic of China, saying that Costa Rica's ties with Taiwan remain unchanged.
Stagno said Costa Rica will continue to cement ties with Taiwan but will not exclude the possibility of continued strengthening of business exchanges with China.
Stagno also rebutted recent news reports that Costa Rica and Taiwan are in a spat over several matters.

An AFP Spanish-language report said the day before that Costa Rica and Taiwan have been at odds recently because on May 14, the Costa Rican ambassador to the World Health Organization (WHO) cast a "no" vote in the world health regulatory body's annual assembly in Geneva on the issue of whether to include Taiwan's membership application on its agenda.

Defending his nation's position on that incident, Stagno said Costa Rica has rendered its support for Taiwan every year since 1993 on Taiwan's bids to join the WHO and the United Nations. However, he went on, Taiwan changed its strategies in its WHO and U.N. bids this year without giving Costa Rica sufficient advance notification.

Instead of applying for admission into the World Health Assembly -- the top decision-making body of the WHO -- as an observer, Taiwan directly filed for full membership in the WHO in the name of "Taiwan" this year.

Meanwhile, Rafael Ramirez, a consultant to the Costa Rica Chamber of Exporters, said during an interview with the AFP recently that Costa Rica has maintained a "strategically important" relationship with Taiwan that should not be changed under any circumstances.
Ramirez added that although China has a seductively huge market, many expectations are only "illusory."
Costa Rica established diplomatic ties with the ROC in 1944 and the two countries have since maintained cordial relations until recently.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CANADA RENEW MEMORANDUM OF COOPERATION ON EDUCATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Canada renewed a memorandum of cooperation Wednesday to continue educational and academic exchanges between the two countries.
The new three-year pact was signed between the Ministry of Education and the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei after the first two-year memorandum of cooperation signed in 2004 expired May 14.

According to the Bureau of International Cultural and Educational Relations under the Ministry of Education, the new agreement will allow Taiwan to enlist Canadian assistance to bring in more qualified English language teachers for Taiwan's schools.
Canada was the first country to sign an agreement to provide English language teachers for Taiwan's schools.

The new agreement will also enable the two countries to promote bilateral exchanges through a variety of educational and academic programs, said officials at the Bureau of International Cultural and Educational Relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF RESERVED ABOUT RULE CHANGES ON CHINESE SPOUSES

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong voiced reservations Wednesday about proposals to shorten the time needed to allow Chinese spouses and citizens to gain residence permits and partake in state examinations, saying that it would do no good to make the change precipitously.

Chen made the comments while answering inquiries from reporters after two proposed amendments to the Statute Regarding the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the People of the Mainland Area, put forward respectively by main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers Wu Chih-yang and Lee Chiang-an to serve that end, failed to pass a legislative meeting for substantial screening.

One of the amendments called for a shortening of the existing requirement of eight-year residence in Taiwan to four years for Chinese spouses to gain Republic of China ID cards, while the other proposed that Chinese immigrants be given the right to take part in state examinations so long as they have had their household registered in Taiwan for more than 10 years.

According to Chen, it is not prudent to rashly push for policy shifts at the current time as the existing rules have been in place for years, and a sudden change may bring additional complications due to the special and delicate relations between Taiwan and China.

The two amendments were boycotted by "pan-green" lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, and the meeting was dismissed following a vote by the "pan-green" camp to adjourn the session.

I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney and one of the principal architects of President Bush's foreign policy, was sentenced Tuesday to 30 months in prison for lying during a C.I.A. leak investigation that became part of a fierce debate over the war in Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: STARTING PAY OF COLLEGE GRADS IN 2006 LOWER THAN 8 YEARS AGO: CLA

TEXT.P: The average starting salary of Taiwan's college graduates in 2006 was NT$26,700 (US$ 808) , which was NT$762 lower than it was eight years ago, a Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) official said Wednesday.

Quoting the results of a survey conducted by the CLA, the official said the average starting pay of job seekers with masters degrees or above in the same year was NT$31,567, higher than the NT$30,388 of eight years ago.

The official said Taiwan's average unemployment rate was higher than 4 percent during 2001 to 2005, which had an impact on college graduates' starting pay. In addition, a research report compiled by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) shows that the global economy and Taiwan's industry relocation also affected domestic employment and salary growth.

The CLA survey also shows that new job seekers spent an average of 1.9 months to find their first jobs. Among them, college graduates spent 1.8 months and university graduates took 1.8 months, while job seekers with master degrees or above spent 1.1 months finding their first jobs.
Some 18.1 percent of workers aged 20-24, and 4.8 percent of workers aged 25-29 were part-time workers, showing that job stability grows with age and work experience, the official went on.

Moreover, some 60 percent of workers under the age of 30 have occupational certifications, with 32.5 percent of them having technician certification and 16.4 percent having computer skill certifications, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE OLYMPIC FIGURE SKATING GOLD MEDALLIST TO PERFORM IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Japanese figure skater Shizuka Arakawa, the 2006 Turin Winter Olympics gold medallist in the Women's Singles event, and the 2004 World Champion, will perform in Taiwan for the first time in August, organizers announced in a press conference Wednesday.

Arakawa and other well-known Japanese figure skaters, including Takeshi Honda and Junko Yaginuma, will skate in six shows of the Prince Ice World 2007 Tour in Taipei, to be held Aug. 3 - 5 at the Taipei Arena.

Arakawa, 26, is the first female skater born in Asia to win the Olympic gold medal in figure skating, and the second oldest woman to win the Olympic figure skating gold. She announced her retirement from amateur figure skating and turned professional in May 2006, joining the Prince Ice World Team.

Speaking to a large group of reporters, Arakawa said she would like to promote the beauty of figure skating to the people of Taiwan through this tour. She also encouraged young Taiwanese skaters to "endure the pain and handwork in daily practices with a positive attitude."
"The basic approach to sports is to enjoy the happy side of it and forget the pain and sorrow, " she said.
Arakawa, one of the tallest female figure skaters at 5 feet 6 inches, is known for her spins and jumping ability, especially her triple-triple combination.
By winning the gold medal in Turin, the Prince Ice World Team said, Arakawa helped once again make ice skating one of the most popular sports in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-TAIWAN FTA 'A MATTER OF TIME': REPRESENTATIVE TO U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 5 (CNA) 06/06/07 21:37:48 (By Michelle Tsai and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative to the United States, Joseph Wu, said the signing of free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and U.S. is "a matter of time," and that Taiwan has to wait patiently until the time is ripe.
Wu made the remarks at Twin Oaks estate in Washington, D.C. where he feasted Taiwanese agricultural and industrial delegations visiting U.S. to solicit the support of U.S.enterprises on FTA matters.
The feast was attended by about 80 people, including representatives of Taiwan and U.S.enterprises like Uni-President Corp., Taiwan Power Co., U.S. Wheat Associates, and Westinghouse Electric Corp.

Wu told reporters that the visiting agricultural delegation will sign a letter of intent to pursue a procurement project worth of US$3.9 billion, and the industrial delegation, which will sign a contract for a procurement project costing US$127.09 million, will also propose another cooperative project worth US$ 11.34 billion.

Wu said Taiwan has been importing more goods from the U.S. since 1993 and has since become increasingly tied to American agricultural market, with 95 percent of Taiwan's imported cereals coming from the U.S.

Director-general of Foreign Trade Bureau Huang Chih-peng, who is leading the industrial delegation to the U.S., said the idea of an FTA between Taiwan and the U.S. has the support of American media outlets and enterprises, and there is still a chance to sign an FTA with America, because the American government has not rejected the idea, though nor has it said yes to it, Huang added.

Sun Ming-hsien, Taiwan's ambassador at-large who is leading the agricultural delegation to U.S., said he hopes that Taiwan's frequent agricultural cooperation with America will contribute to the bilateral FTA which should bring economic benefits to both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL LOSSES ESTIMATED AT NT$11.4 MILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agricultural losses due to torrential rains for the current plum rain season were estimated at NT$11.4 million as of June 6, a Council of Agriculture official said Wednesday.
According to the official, the two counties most seriously affected are Changhua County, with losses of NT$11.16 million, and Miaoli County, with losses of about NT$242,000.
Some 255 hectares of farmland have seen 28 percent of the area damaged, which is the equivalent of 72 hectares of farmland rendered useless due to the heavy rains, the official said.
The most seriously damaged farms were those producing watermelon, green onion, cabbage, or wax gourd, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUNKEN DRIVING NOW NO. 1 CAUSE OF ROAD DEATHS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Drunken driving has become the No. 1 cause of deaths on Taiwan's public roads, according to statistics in a report released by the Ministry of Transportation of Communications Wednesday.
The ministry indicated in the report that 727 people had died in 2006 as a result of drunken driving-related road accidents, making drinking and driving the leading cause of road deaths.
The report pointed out that in 2001, drunken driving ranked third among all causes of road deaths before becoming the second leading cause in 2002.

Since 2004, the number of road accidents due to drunken drinking increased about 30 percent each year from 2,502 in 2004 to 2,999 in 2006, accounting for 16.7 percent and 36.5 percent of the yearly road traffic accidents, respectively.
The number of road deaths caused by drunken driving also rose steadily from 454 in 2004 to 547 in 2005, and to 727 in 2006.
The report also said that most drunken driving-related accidents occur during the nine hours between 6 p.m. and 3 a.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAY COACHES TO HELP TAIWANESE SOCCER WITH TRAINING PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Four Paraguayan soccer coaches started their 10-day training program schedule Wednesday in the eastern county of Taitung in hopes of developing more professional grassroots coaches to establish asolid foundation for Taiwanese soccer.
These coaches will provide their expertise in conditioning, techniques, tactics and psychology in the three-day program, which will be held in Taitung, Pingtung and Taichung from June 6 - 16.
The coaching clinic is the result of collaboration between the Embassy of the Republic of Paraguay, the Ministry of Education (MOE) and National College of Physical Education and Sports (NCPES).

Paraguay is proud of its long soccer history and achievement, the Paraguayan Embassy said, and believes the program will help the development of Taiwanese soccer thanks to the efforts of coaches Gustavo Alcibiades Blaires Ucedo, Ramon Duarte, Julio Vera Torres and Guido Armoa.

Taiwan currently ranks 167th in the FIFA (Federation of International Football Association) global ranking while Paraguay ranks 35th. The Central American country boasts seven World Cup appearances and has advanced to the final sixteen on three occasions.
According to a MOE statistics, there are more than 600 soccer teams of all levels in Taiwan, with more than 500 of them being primary school teams.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ASKS CHINA TO RESUME TALKS ON CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan has asked China to resume negotiations on three bilateral issues and is awaiting Beijing's reply, according to the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong.
Whether the issues can be resolved will serve as an indicator of the possibility of opening discussions on other cross-Taiwan Strait issues, Chen stressed.
Chen made the remarks Monday during an interview with Hong Kong China News Agency.

Chen said that soon after assuming his position he twice used existing channels to ask China to return to the stalled negotiations on allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan, as well as on cargo and passenger chartered flights.

Before assuming his chairmanship, Chen said that the MAC had engaged in seven rounds of negotiation on cargo and passenger chartered flights, and five rounds on allowing visitors from China to Taiwan.
Basic technical problems have been resolved, according to Chen, however, the two sides cannot reach an agreement on the wording of the agreement.
During the fourth round of talks, Beijing included a statement saying that "residents in mainland China visit Taiwan, China" in their version of agreement, Chen noted.

Also, Jia Qinglin, chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), said late April that private visits between Taiwan and China are not journeys between two countries, Chen continued.
Taiwan regarded the statement and Jia's remarks as unacceptable "political framework," Chen stressed.

Taipei proposed its own version of the agreement in the wake of the fourth round held early February, and has yet to receive any response from Beijing, Chen said, adding that the Taipei version uses neutral, non-contentious wording.
Chen also responded to China's Taiwan Affairs Office spokesman Li Weiyi's May 16 remarks by reiterating that Taiwan has made two requests to resume the talks with China and is awaiting a reply.
Li said that Taiwan has not yet replied to Chinese proposals made during the fifth round of talks.

Describing the three issues as "very important, " Chen said that allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan will increase the mutual understanding of peoples on both sides of the strait and that the opening of the chartered flights could act as a prelude to cross-strait direct transport.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAY SOCCER COACHES TRAIN TAIWAN COUNTERPARTS, STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Four soccer coaches from Paraguay began to pass on their expertise to their Taiwanese counterparts and students Wednesday as part of the Taiwanese government's efforts to promote the sport at local schools.
The coaches will provide guidance to local trainers and students at three training camps in eastern, southern, and central Taiwan, June 6-16.
The camps are part of a collaboration between Taiwan and its South American ally, Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng announced a day earlier at a press conference.

The Ministry of Education (MOE) hopes that the exchange will help enhance the quality of instruction offered by local soccer coaches so that the ministry can achieve its goal of successfully promoting the sport in schools at all levels, Tu said.
President Chen Shui-bian once proposed the idea of sending 20 student soccer players to Brazil, a plan that is still being studied by the Chinese Taipei Football Association, Tu noted.
Currently, the first step is to invite soccer coaches from advanced countries to offer instruction to provide a boost to the sport in Taiwan, Tu went on.
Tu said that he has never played soccer, but thinks that soccer is a good sport because it builds one's physical strength and endurance.
Soccer is also a suitable sport for Taiwanese players because height is not an essential factor, Tu said.
Taiwan now has over 600 soccer teams, Tu said, adding that 500 of these are based in primary schools.
The MOE hopes that the promotion of the sport can begin in primary schools, according to the minister.
Paraguay's national soccer team currently ranks 16th in the world, and 3rd in South America.

Paraguayan Ambassador Ramon Antero Diaz Pereira, who has contributed to the soccer exchange, said he believes that the four distinguished coaches from his nation will be conducive to the development of soccer in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH MINISTER ARRIVES IN SYDNEY TO ATTEND APEC MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Sydney, June 6 (CNA) 06/06/07 23:22:12 (By Chen Ming-lung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Health Minister Hou Sheng-mou arrived in Sydney Wednesday at the head of a delegation of health officials and medical professionals to attend a ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

Hou said Taiwan delegates will share Taiwan's experience in fight against contagious diseases and promote cooperation with other APEC members in epidemic control during the two-day APEC health ministers meeting scheduled for Thursday through Friday.

"We'll speak on three topics, namely interdisciplinary cooperation, regional and global cooperation in avian flu prevention, and socio-economic impact of AIDS in the Asia-Pacific area, " Hou said, adding that the Taiwan delegation will share Taiwan's successful experience in stemming spread of AIDS in addition to expressing its hope for further cooperation with other countries in avian flu prevention.

According to Hou, Taiwan has succeeded in driving down the number of new AIDS infections through intensified efforts in containing spread of the deadly virus among drug addicts by providing them with clean syringes.

Over the past few years, Hou said, the Department of Health has cooperated closely with the Narcotics Hazard Control Center and Drug Control Center in curtailing AIDS spread among drug addicts. "We feel compelled to provide our experience in this regard for other APEC countries to emulate," he added proudly.
Hou said he will also suggest other countries to step up inspection of carry-on luggage to avert spread of communicable diseases.

As Taiwan's cooperation with Australia and several other APEC member states in avian flu prevention drill last year was a great success, Hou said he will suggest that similar exercise be held again this year to hone emergency or disaster response skills.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA GOING ALL OUT TO MAINTAIN TIES WITH COSTA RICA: MINISTER

TEXT.P: The government is pulling out all the stops to stabilize diplomatic relations with Costa Rica amid signs that the Central American country may switch its allegiance to Beijing, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Wednesday.

Briefing media outlets on the latest diplomatic situation, Huang said the country's relations with Costa Rica are at a "sensitive" stage and that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is doing "everything within our power" to consolidate bilateral ties.
At present, Huang said, various bilateral communications channels still function smoothly.

"Taiwan and Costa Rica have maintained diplomatic relations for more than six decades. As both are democratic countries, we harbor high expectations of future cooperation. We'll do everything in our power to keep the ties, " Huang said, adding that given its good international reputation, Costa Rica is not expected to do anything that could seriously impair Taiwan's national interest.

Although the Republic of China's ambassador to Costa Rica, Wu Tzu-dan, has offered to resign to assume political responsibility for the recent disturbance and uncertainty in ROC-Costa Rican relations, Huang said he has rejected Wu's offer.
For the sake of boosting diplomatic staff's morale, Huang said, the ministry has no personnel replacement plan at this critical juncture.
Even though Costa Rica has been in frequent contact with China, it has invariably stressed in its public statements its willingness to maintain friendly ties with Taiwan.

Nevertheless, Huang said relations between the two countries are indeed at a crossroads. It is hoped that the two countries can communicate in a frank and sincere manner, Huang said, adding that the MOFA is eager to know the discrepancies between Costa Rica's publicly stated goals and its real thinking or stance.
"So far our ties with Costa Rica are OK, but there have been some unusual signs lately that we should closely monitor and be on our guard," Huang said.

Among the warnings was Costa Rica's unexpected "no" vote at the World Health Organization's annual assembly in Geneva in mid-May on a proposal to include Taiwan's membership application into its discussion agenda.
For all the pall over the ROC-Costa Rican ties, Huang said the government is unlikely to take the pre-emptive move to ditch Costa Rica as some media outlets have speculated.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER TO HOLD NEWS CONFERENCE AT 9 A.M. ON COSTA RICA TIES

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang will hold a news conference at 9 a.m. Thursday to brief the press on the government's response to Costa Rica's decision to switch diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing.

According to a CNA report from Panama City, Costa Rican President Oscar Arias announced his administration's decision to establish diplomatic relations with China shortly after urgently summoning Republic of China Ambassador Wu Tzu-dan to inform him of the decision.
While announcing his government's decision to forge ties with China, the CNA report said, Arias said that his government will maintain unofficial ties with Taiwan.
According to foreign wire service reports, Arias announced at 5: 15 p.m. Wednesday (local time) that Costa Rica has broken diplomatic ties with Taiwan and established relations with China.

Arias' announcement came a day after Costa Rican Foreign Minister Bruno Stagno was quoted by a Spanish-language wire service report as having denied that his country's relations with Taiwan would have a "major twist" soon.
Wu said China has relentlessly strive to use its economic clout to lure away Taiwan's diplomatic allies, including Costa Rica.

Since he assumed the ambassadorial post, Wu said pro-China Costa Rican politicians and celebrities have shuttled between San Jose and Beijing to boost bilateral engagements. Over the past year, Wu said, Costa Rican and Chinese diplomats have held many rounds of meetings in private.

Before the opening of the World Health Organization's (WHO) annual assembly in Geneva May 14, Wu recalled that he had held three rounds of meeting with Stagno and two rounds of talks with the Costa Rican health minister on Taiwan's decision to apply for WHO membership. Both of them promised to support Taiwan's bid, but they backed off the promise. The Costa Rican ambassador to the WHO gave an unexpected "no" vote at the WHO assembly on a proposal to include Taiwan's membership bid into its discussion agenda.

Costa Rica established diplomatic ties with the ROC in 1944. A Taiwanese diplomat stationed in Central America said he is worried that Costa Rica's switching of diplomatic recognition could trigger a "domino effect" and affect Taiwan's ties with its other Central American allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 7, or the 22nd day of the fourth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1893: Indian leader Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of passive resistance begins when he is thrown off a segregated train in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, where he had lived for 21 years.
1905: Norway declares its independence from Sweden.
1909: Jessica Tandy, American actress, is born in England. She became the oldest person to receive an Oscar at the age of 80 in 1990 for her role in "Driving Miss Daisy."
1939: King George VI and Queen Elizabeth cross from Canada into America to become the first British monarchs to visit the United States.
1973: The Far East Senior League baseball play-offs open in Taipei.
1974: A memorandum to strengthen economic ties between the Republic of China and Saudi Arabia is signed by Sheik Mahmond Talba, deputy minister of commerce and industry, and Wang Yi-ting, director-general of the Chinese Board of Foreign Trade.
1975: The last two U.S. combat aircraft based on Taiwan are pulled out.
1976: Dr. Arthur J. Barsky, founder of the International Rehabilitation Center for Disabled Children, arrives in Taipei to discuss establishing a rehabilitation center for Southeast Asia.
1979: The ROC Cabinet names Dr. James Soong director general of the Government Information Office.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui leads a 10-member delegation to the United States to attend the annual meeting of American city mayors.
1982: Israel mounts major air and ground attacks against Beirut, Tryre and Sidon on the second day of its invasion of Lebanon to destroy the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1983: The Legislative Yuan approves the Firearms Control Law during its third reading, tightening controls on the manufacture, possession or use of firearms and other weapons. Punishments for violating the law are to range from 7 years to life imprisonment.
1989: A Surinam Airways DC-8 on a flight from Amsterdam crashes near Paramaribo's international airport, killing 169 of the 182 people on board.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China arrives in the United States for a reunion at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: At his first press conference as vice president and premier, Lien Chan indicates that the ROC has not ruled out the possibility of the two sides of the Taiwan Straits exchanging visits by high-ranking officials. He also emphasizes the need to reopen channels to allow cross-strait talks.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui announces that the ROC will donate US$300 to help Kosovar refugees rebuild their homes.
2000: A Taiwan hospital reports the first case of Costello Syndrome, a debilitating genetic disease that causes a host of physical abnormalities.
2001: Samuel C. Ting, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, gives a speech at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan on the composition of the universe.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are nine objects which a wise man aims at. In the use of his eyes, his object is to see clearly. In the use of his ears, his object is to hear distinctly. In the expression of his look, his object is to be gracious.
"In his manners, his object is to be serious. In what he says, his object is to be sincere, In business, his object is to be earnest. In doubt, his object is to seek information. In anger, his object is to think of consequences. In view of personal advantage, his object is to think of what is right."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER OFFERS TO RESIGN OVER DIPLOMATIC SETBACK

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Thursday he has offered to resign to assume responsibility for the latest diplomatic setback, namely Costa Rica's switch of diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing.
Huang said he had informed President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun- hsiung of his decision to resign, but he didn't say whether his superiors have agreed to his offer.
Huang just said President Chen and Premier Chang have instructed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to handle the aftermath properly.

Costa Rican President Oscar Arias announced his administration's decision to forge diplomatic relations with China 5:15 p.m. Wednesday (local time) shortly after he urgently summoned Republic of China Ambassador to Costa Rica Wu Tzu-dan to inform him of the decision.

According to Huang, Chinese Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi and his Costa Rican counterpart Bruno Stagno already signed a joint communique in Beijing June 1 on establishing formal diplomatic ties. However, the Costa Rican government failed to inform Taiwan of such an unfriendly event until 4:00 a.m. Thursday (Taipei time).
For the sake of upholding national interest and dignity, Huang said, the ROC government has decided to terminate formal relations with Costa Rica and cease all bilateral cooperation projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SEVERS DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH COSTA RICA (UPDATE-1)

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang announced Thursday the government's decision to sever diplomatic relations with Costa Rica after the Central American nation proclaimed the establishment of diplomatic ties with China.
Huang expressed regret at Costa Rica's decision, which he called the result of "threat and financial temptation" by China.

"For the sake of upholding national interests and dignity, the government of the Republic of China (Taiwan) has decided to terminate formal relations with the Republic of Costa Rica and cease all cooperation projects between the two countries, " Huang said, reading from a prepared statement during a news conference.
Since forging diplomatic relations with Costa Rica in 1944, Taiwan had actively assisted Costa Rica in improving its infrastructure and promoting national development, Huang said.

However, with disregard for the longstanding friendship with Taiwan, Costa Rican President Oscar Arias has held several secret talks with China on the establishment of diplomatic ties since his inauguration in May 2006, Huang noted.

Huang said despite Taiwan's efforts to communicate with the government of Costa Rica with utmost sincerity, Costa Rica still decided to cling to its own way and chose to "discard the universal values of peace, freedom and human rights commonly treasured by Taiwan and Costa Rica, and to turn to ally with the totalitarian communist China."

Huang claimed that Arias's move goes against the founding spirit of Costa Rica and the ideals of the Nobel Peace Prize, which Arias won in 1987 for his efforts to end civil wars then raging in several Central American countries.

Huang further condemned China for resorting to checkbook diplomacy to suppress Taiwan's participation in the international community, a practice which he said "seriously hurts the feelings of the Taiwanese people."
He pledged that Taiwan will continue to promote pragmatic diplomacy to enhance the country's international profile and to safeguard the country's interests and its people's well-being.
Costa Rica signed a joint communique on the establishment of diplomatic relations with China June 1 but did not publicize the news until June 6.
After severing formal diplomatic ties with Costa Rica, Taiwan now has a total of 24 diplomatic allies around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA EXPECTS NO 'DOMINO EFFECT' FROM COSTA RICA'S SWITCHING OF TIES

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Thursday that Costa Rica's decision to swith diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing is not expected to have a "domino effect" on Taiwan's overall diplomatic standing.

Huang made the optimistic forecast after announcing the government's decision to break off diplomatic relations with Costa Rica following the Central American country's establishment of official ties with China earlier in the day.

Claiming that China has spent an astronomical amount of money to lure Costa Rica to shift diplomatic allegiance, Huang said Taiwan has no intention of waging a "checkbook diplomacy" battle with China.

Asked whether Costa Rica's unfriendly move would spark a "domino effect, " Huang said he believes that Costa Rica's decision is only an isolated case, adding that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has ordered all of the country's overseas diplomatic missions to cement relations with diplomatic allies.

According to Huang, Chinese Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi and his Costa Rican counterpart, Bruno Stagno, already signed a joint communique in Beijing June 1 on establishing formal diplomatic ties. However, the Costa Rican government failed to inform Taiwan until 4:00 a.m. Thursday, Taipei time.

Huang said that for the sake of upholding the nation's dignity and interests, the ROC government has decided to terminate formal relations with Costa Rica and cease all bilateral cooperation projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REJECTS FOREIGN MINISTER'S RESIGNATION OFFER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that he has rejected Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang's offer to resign over Costa Rica's switching of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

"Given China's unmerciful suppression of Taiwan in the international arena, Taiwan's diplomatic staff face an unusually tall order in carrying out their work, " Chen said, adding that "we need to give more encouragement and support to them."

Chen made the remarks during an inspection tour in the southern county of Yunlin after Huang said at a press conference earlier in the day that he had informed President Chen and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung of his intention to resign over Costa Rica's establishment of diplomatic relations with China.
Chen said Huang has done his utmost "to safeguard the country's diplomatic territory and should not be blamed for the setback."

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICA ACCUSED OF 'CHEATING' TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 7 (CNA) 06/07/07 14:08:08 (By Y.F. Low and Ramon Huang)

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang accused Costa Rica Thursday of repeatedly "cheating" Taiwan in the process of its forging diplomatic relations with China.
Huang described the manner in which Costa Rican President Oscar Arias handled the matter as an irony, considering the fact that Arias is a Nobel Peace Prize winner.
Huang pointed out that even before his inauguration in May 2006, Arias had harbored the idea of establishing diplomatic ties with China.

In what were considered alarm signals of possible change in Taiwan-Costa Rica relations, Arias met with Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing during last year's United Nations meeting held in September, and Costa Rica opposed Taiwan's bid to gain membership in the World Health Organization during this year's World Health Assembly held in May, Huang said.
Even before flying secretly to Beijing in late May, Costa Rican Foreign Minister Bruno Stagno lied to the media that his country's relations with Taiwan remained unchanged, Huang noted.

Stagno signed a joint communique on the establishment of diplomatic relations between Costa Rica and China with his Chinese counterpart, Yang Jiechi, in Beijing June 1. But Costa Rica did not publicize the news until June 6.
In response to the development, Huang on Thursday announced Taiwan's decision to sever diplomatic ties with Costa Rica and cease all cooperation projects between the two countries.
In Costa Rica Wednesday, Taiwan's embassy in the Central American nation lodged a strong protest over the Costa Rican government's "extremely unfriendly" move of switching recognition to Beijing.
"The Costa Rican government should bear the responsibility and all consequences for betraying the 63-year-long friendship with Taiwan," the embassy said in a written statement.
Taiwan will close down its embassy in Costa Rica, terminate all aid projects for the Central American nation and recall its technical corps there, according to the statement.
