DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORKS WITH U.S. TO BUST CROSS-BORDER HUMAN TRAFFICKERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has cooperated with the United States to break up a cross-border human trafficking ring and arrest 12 suspects, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) reported Thursday.
CIB agents said the ring is suspected of smuggling Taiwan women to the United States and other countries for prostitution and other forms of sexual exploitation.
The agents said the ring's mastermind, Lin Ming-tang, his accomplice Chen Jung- kee and 10 others were arrested in raids in Taoyuan, Taipei and Keelung a day earlier.
The suspects included those who are from Tu's group, a major pornography ring associated with Lin's ring.

They noted that U.S. customs and immigration authorities in San Francisco have since February 2006 caught 12 Taiwanese women engaging in prostitution, leading them to suspect that these women might have been "exported" by human traffickers.

The United States, which has stepped up screening measures on foreign visitors in the wake of the 911 terrorist attacks, sent officials to call on CIB Commissioner Huang Mao-sui to seek his assistance in helping to track down the human traffickers.
The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations, also looked into the visa application and auditing procedures of the women.

The CIB set up a task force which confirmed that the women were cheated and threatened by the ring and that they used forged papers to get visas under the name of tourists or students, allowing them to travel to major U.S. cities.
The task force also found that women repatriated by the United States and Japan numbers more than 100, although the actual number could be higher.

Agents found that Lin's ring set up "phantom" companies between 2005 and 2006 that helped the women use forged work papers to apply for visas from AIT. The task force found that the ring had used the method to obtain more than 100 U.S. visas.
Lin also extended his operations to Britain, Canada, Japan, Australia and Guam, and collaborated with Tu's group, the country's largest pornography supplier.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING ACCOUNTABLE FOR COSTA RICA FIASCO: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that Beijing should be held accountable for the severing of Taiwan-Costa Rica ties.

Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang announced earlier the same day Taipei's termination of diplomatic relations with Costa Rica shortly after the Central American country's formal announcement of establishment of diplomatic links with Beijing.

Although Lu said that the development was "predictable" due to Taiwan's difficult situation in the international community as a result of Beijing's suppression, she added that many people in Taiwan are turning a blind eye to this and are seeking to placate Beijing.

She said Beijing's international isolation of Taiwan is a severe problem that Taiwan's people have to face up to, and questioned how a certain opposition presidential candidate can attempt to tie Taiwan's fate to Beijing's control. She also voiced her grave concern that the candidate will be unable to lead Taiwan through the many difficulties and challenges ahead if he is elected head of state.

"It is not prudent to pass the buck to the government, as Beijing is expected to further pressure Taiwan and aggressively challenge Taiwan on a wide range of fronts," Lu said, urging Taiwan's people to maintain cool heads and draw a clear line between the two sides.

As Lu is slated to visit Paraguay in July at the invitation of Paraguay's vice president and parliament speaker to mark the 50th founding anniversary of the Republic of China (Taiwan) -Paraguay diplomatic partnership, she promised to help explore and solidify Taiwan's diplomatic standing on the tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT PAYS RESPECTS TO BROTHER AT JAPAN WAR SHRINE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 7 (CNA) 06/07/07 17:50:34 (By Mike Chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui visited a controversial Japanese shinto shrine for war dead Thursday to pay his respects to his older brother, who died fighting for the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II.

Lee entered the Yasukuni Shrine -- where the name of his deceased brother is listed -- in the company of his wife and Japanese writers Ayako Sono and Miura Shumon. He stayed there for approximately 40 minutes.
According to Lee's companions, Lee, who is a Christian, did not perform any shinto rites but only bowed and prayed silently in memory of his brother.
While explaining his decision to visit the shrine earlier that day, Lee said the visit was personal and had nothing to do with political or historical issues.

The Yasukuni Shrine is dedicated to 2.5 million soldiers who died fighting for Japan during World War II, including more than 28,000 from Taiwan which was under Japan's colonial rule at that time. It has drawn controversy mainly because executed war criminals are also enshrined there.
For Asian countries such as China and South Korea which were affected by Japanese invasions, the shrine is a symbol of Japanese imperialism.
Over the past few years, Taiwan's aboriginal representatives have made several trips to Japan to demand that the Japanese government remove the names of their ancestors from the shrine.
Lee's visit attracted a crowd of nearly 100 Japanese and foreign reporters, and some Japanese television stations even sent helicopters to cover the event.
Japanese Cabinet spokesman Yasuhisa Shiozaki declined to comment on Lee's visit to the shrine, on the grounds that it was a private activity.

Reiterating that Lee is in Japan for cultural and academic activities, Shiozaki said his visit to the shrine would not affect a planned meeting between Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Chinese President Hu Jinto slated for June 8 in Germany on the sidelines of the G8 summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA WILL NOT RELAX SUPPRESSION FOR NEW TAIWAN LEADER: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that China will not relax its suppression of Taiwan when the country's new president is elected next year.
Chen said China's diplomatic suppression of Taiwan has been consistent irrespective of which political party is in power and it is unlikely to change with a new president.

The president's remarks came in a news release as Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang announced earlier that day the decision to sever diplomatic relations with Costa Rica after the Central American country switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, ending a 63-year diplomatic relationship.

Chen said the changes in diplomatic ties with Costa Rica did not come as a surprise, noting that there were warning signs in that Costa Rican President Oscar Arias met with then-Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing during last year's United Nations meeting in September, while Costa Rica opposed Taiwan's bid to gain membership in the World Health Organization (WHO) during this year's World Health Assembly conference last month.
The president said that in addition to stepping up its military threat against Taiwan, China has also used every means to block and contain the country diplomatically.

"China is attempting to blot Taiwan out of the international community completely by luring away all its diplomatic allies, containing any maneuvering space of Taiwan and squeezing all its bargaining chips in negotiations," Chen said.
He also said that faced with the suppression, isolation and downgrading attempts by China, he has "engaged in diplomatic battles with China daily" since first assuming the presidency in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIALS TO HOLD TIFA PREP MEETING WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 6 (CNA) 06/07/07 18:57:18 (By Michelle Tsai and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: The United States will send two senior officials to Taiwan later this month to hold preparatory talks with their local counterparts for a sixth round of Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) negotiations scheduled for the second half of the year, a Taiwanese official said in Washington, D.C. Wednesday.

Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade, made the remarks at a press conference before leading a delegation to visit the Office of the United States Trade Representative (USTR) and U.S. lawmakers.

The U.S. and Taiwan plan to convene the TIFA meeting in Washington later this year, Huang said, adding that John C.C. Teng, the chief negotiator of Taiwan's Office of Trade Negotiations, will lead adelegation to the U.S. for the event.
It is not clear that whether the U.S. Congress will extend the Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) , which will expire June 30, Huang pointed out.
The TPA gives President George W. Bush the authority to negotiate trade agreements with other nations.

In this situation, Taiwan will continue to express willingness to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with the U.S., Huang noted, adding that the sixth round of TIFA talks is critical because its success can further U.S.-Taiwan substantive relations.
Both sides have fully discussed the agenda for the TIFA talks, while the specific date for the negotiations will be announced following confirmation with the U.S., according to Huang.
Despite no progress having been made in the bid for an FTA, Huang said both sides are satisfied with the results of last year's TIFA meeting.

Taiwan has assured the U.S. that it takes the interests of U.S. companies seriously with regard to intellectual property rights and drug reimbursement costs of Taiwan's National Health Insurance (NHI) program, Huang said.
The TIFA negotiations will focus on the signing of a bilateral investment agreement, an avoidance of double taxation agreement and a government procurement agreement, Huang continued.
Aside from face-to-face meetings, both sides have also held three videoconferences on the bilateral investment agreement, and will also hold videoconferences on the two other agreements, Huang said.
There is no timetable for the signing of the three agreements, according to Huang, although he added that the two sides are willing to carry on the talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA ESTABLISHES `LED STANDARDS AND QUALITY R&D ALLIANCE'

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) initiated Thursday an "LED lighting standards and quality R&D alliance" both to boost the market share of locally made LED lighting equipment and to integrate the upstream and downstream manufacturers in the industry, Economics Minister Steve R.L. Chen announced at a press conference that day.

Chen also announced that the ministry has appropriated NT$170 million (approximately US$5 million) to establish Taiwan's first comprehensive LED lighting measuring system that will facilitate technological improvements in LED packaging and lighting.

LEDs, or light emitting diodes, are described as an eco-friendly and energy- saving method of lighting. As the global demand for LED lighting equipment has surged in recent years, Taiwan's total production value for LED lighting topped NT$21 billion last year, representing 10 percent of the global market value.
Chen also noted that LED lighting equipment can be a niche for Taiwan-based manufacturers, as well as a superb instrument for better energy efficiency around the nation.

"If all traffic lights were replaced with LEDs, it would mean power savings of 85 percent, " Chen continued. "If all streetlamps were replaced with LEDs, it would lead to power savings of 41 percent," he added.
"The energy saved in both areas could equal 10.7 billion kilowatt-hours, or the annual output volume of an entire nuclear power generating unit," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG The future of house prices: 10 times pay
The next generation of first-time buyers will face house prices equivalent to ten times their average incomes, putting home ownership out of reach for the majority of young people, a new government agency says today.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE ENVOY VISITS PENGHU COUNTY

TEXT.P: Japan's Interchange Association (IA) Kaohsiung Office Director Hiromichi Kambe wound up a two-day visit to Penghu County Thursday that he made to gain a better understanding of the offshore county's tourist industry.

Kambe visited Penghu County Magistrate Wang Chien-fa the previous day and exchanged views with him on the county's tourism development and its "mini three links," which allow Penghu residents to travel to China's Fujian Province via direct ferry routes through Taiwan-held outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu.

Wang told Kambe that environmental protection and marine resource preservation have been taken by the county government and local residents as important directions for the development of tourism. The protection of natural beauty should attract more tourists to visit the county's world-class attractions such as its basalt columns, Wang added.

He noted that a delegation of the county's cross-Taiwan Strait exchange association visited Fujian in April via the "mini three links" to promote Penghu tourism, and added that a group of about 119 members to be led by Fujian officials will visit Penghu County June 11.
He also said construction of many five-star hotels will be completed within two years.

Kambe suggested that in addition to five-star hotels, the county government could consider building clubs to provide comfortable long-stays with lower prices to backpackers. He also promised to help promote Penghu tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABLE CHANNEL PLANS TO PRODUCE 100 DIGITAL FILMS IN FIVE YEARS

TEXT.P: Videoland Movie Channel, Taiwan's first cable television channel dedicated to showing Chinese-language films, announced Thursday that it will set aside NT$1 billion (US$30.18 million) to produce 100 digital films over the next five years.
Hu Kuan-chen, president of Videoland Movie Channel, told reporters that her company will also spend millions to recruit writing talent.
Hu, 38, is a former actress who has starred in 18 films. She made the announcement two days after the channel celebrated its 15th anniversary.

Her deputy, Yao Ching-kang -- a playwright who has written 36 plays -- said Videoland will begin to shoot films in different genres in Hong Kong, Taiwan and China this year, and that the company will place more emphasis on good plays than on the latest stars.

Videoland has a library of more than 1,200 Chinese-language films and shows an average of about 120 titles each month. In 2004, the channel ventured into the production of digital films and scored success with two titles -- "Bodyguard for a Corpse" and "Dear Corpse" -- followed by two more hits in 2005 -- "Playful Ghost" and "Ghost Mama." In 2006, Videoland Movie Channel produced "Puppy Love" and "My Schoolboy's Day."
The company plans to produce about 20 titles a year in various categories including comedy, kung-fu, puppet theater and children's movies.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO VISIT PARAGUAY IN JULY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that she will visit Paraguay, Taiwan's only South American ally, to attend a ceremony in July celebrating the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the two countries.
Lu said she will lead a delegation to attend the ceremony, but added that the itinerary in Paraguay has not yet been settled.
Interviewed by reporters at the Presidential Office that day, which was also Lu's 63rd birthday, she said her birthday wish is a better international situation for Taiwan.
Lu said she will try to strengthen diplomatic ties with Paraguay in the midst of a difficult diplomatic period caused by Costa Rica's switching of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

The fact that Costa Rica recognized China was the consequence of China's suppression of Taiwan in the international arena, therefore, it is not reasonable to blame Taiwan government for this, Lu said.

The offer to resign by Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang is an act of showing political responsibility and administrative ethics, Lu said, adding that to accept or refuse Huang's resignation will be a decision for President Chen Shui- bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING CEC HEAD DEFENDS LEGISLATIVE ELECTION DATE

TEXT.P: Outgoing Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung denied Thursday that a "conspiracy" was behind the CEC's decision to hold the next legislative election Jan. 12.
Chang brushed off the allegation while answering questions from lawmakers after having reported on the CEC's programming of the next legislative and presidential elections.

In response to main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers' suspicion that the date for the seventh Legislative Yuan has been put off to Jan. 12, 2008 from the originally projected December this year to hobble KMT supporter turnout, Chang replied that the date was set based on a majority agreement after thorough study and discussion by CEC members.
"There is absolutely not any conspiracy behind the decision and it is the best date among all those that have been assessed, " Chang said.

Commenting on the possibility that the date for the legislative election could be overturned by the next CEC as the current CEC members are set to step down from their posts June 16, Chang said that the new CEC is entitled to make changes in this regard.

As to the question of whether the legislative and presidential elections should be held at the same time, Chang said that is an issue for the new CEC to decide, but that such a development is feasible.
The next presidential election is tentatively scheduled for early 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC BLASTS BEIJING'S SUPPRESSION OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) issued a statement Thursday condemning Beijing's constant suppression of Taiwan, saying that China's bullying of Taiwan will only drive the two countries further apart.

The MAC statement came after the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced earlier in the day the termination of Taiwan-Costa Rica diplomatic ties after the Central American nation proclaimed its establishment of diplomatic links with Beijing hours earlier.

Commenting on the severance of Taiwan-Costa Rica diplomatic ties -- Taiwan's latest setback in its diplomatic war against China -- the MAC called on the public not to harbor any illusions about China, given Beijing's apparent ambition to swallow up the country.

Beijing's objectives of making Taiwan a province of China and excluding Taiwan from the international arena is obvious, it said, pointing out that Beijing's growing military buildup aimed at Taiwan and its increasing squeeze of Taiwan internationally are the prime barriers to any improvement in bilateral ties.

Beijing's two-pronged approach -- paying lip service to two-way exchanges to court the Taiwan people while seeking to impose a full blockade of Taiwan on the world stage -- is ubiquitous, the MAC said, adding that "some people's wishful thinking" of holding negotiations with China will only provide Beijing with a pretext to further suppress Taiwan.

Beijing's series of "uncouth and barbarian" reactions against Taiwan are doomed to fuel resentment among Taiwan's people and the communist Chinese regime must be held responsible for the growing alienation between the two sides, according to the MAC.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN TRADE OFFICE TO ORGANIZE BUSINESS MATCHING EVENT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A business matchmaking event will take place in Taipei July 12 - 13 in hopes of boosting trade relations between Taiwanese and German companies from the federal state of Baden-Wurttemberg, a German Trade Office spokesman said Thursday.

Several German companies in the selected health care, environmental protection, renewable energy and automotive industries will come to Taiwan seeking strong and reliable business partners at the event, which is jointly organized by the German Trade Office, DE International (The German Chamber Network) and Baden-Wurttemberg International, the spokesman said.

Baden-Wurttemberg, located in Southwest Germany, is the third largest of Germany's 16 states in terms both of areas and population (10.7 million) . The capital city, Stuggart, the University City, Heidelberg, as well as the Rhine river are all well-known to Taiwanese.

Economically, Baden-Wurttemberg is the No. 1 export state in Germany. Over 40 percent of Germany's domestic production comes from this federal state alone. Not surprisingly, the state boasts the highest economic growth rate in Germany.

One in five machines in the world are produced in Germany and the majority of them come from Baden-Wurttemberg. Global players such as Daimler-Chrysler, Bosch, Porsche, Heidelberger Druckmaschinen, SAP and many others are based in the state.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Biologists Make Skin Cells Work Like Stem Cells
In a surprising advance that could sidestep the ethical debates surrounding stem cell biology, researchers have come much closer to a major goal of regenerative medicine, the conversion of a patient's cells into specialized tissues that might replace those lost to disease.
The advance is an easy-to-use technique for reprogramming a skin cell of a mouse back to the embryonic state. Embryonic cells can be induced in the laboratory to develop into many of the body's major tissues.
Wall Street Journal:As Insurers Flee Coast, States Face New Threat
As hurricane season gets under way, a dramatic shift in the way homeowners insure against disasters could pose a big financial risk in several coastal states.
Private insurers have been fleeing the shoreline, wary of costly storms and often fed up with government regulations that prevent them from pushing rates higher. In more than a dozen states -- from Texas along the Gulf of Mexico and up the East Coast to Massachusetts -- an odd breed of carriers known as "insurers of last resort" is filling the void.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL CULTURAL AWARDS WINNERS ANNOUNCED

TEXT.P: The National Cultural Association announced six winners of the fourth annual Presidential Cultural Awards Thursday, with two individuals and four groups receiving awards.
The winners will each be granted prize money of NT$1 million (US$30,273) and certificates signed by President Chen Shui-bian at an award ceremony Oct. 17.

The winning groups are the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, Hualien County's Niouli community interchange association, the International Headquarters Search and Rescue, and the Homemaker's Union and Foundation.
The two individual winners are Chiang Shu-sheng and Lin Chang-tzuo.

Secretary-general of the National Cultural Association Tchen Yu-chiou said these winners were selected for their contributions in the fields of social service, international peace, environmental protection, artistic creation, or cultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCKU LAUNCHES 'HOUSE OF QUALITY LIFE'

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) Thursday launched an innovative "house of quality life" that brings together advanced technologies, user-friendly interfaces, and creative interior designs to present a vision of a better living space, according to the Tainan-based university.

Yang Jar-ferr -- director of NCKU's Institute of Computer and Communication Engineering -- explained that the house is the result of collaboration between seven departments and institutes at NCKU, and is representative of the university's integrated interdisciplinary capabilities.

The house features flexible walls and partitions, a wireless sensing network, large 3-dimension display, user-oriented lighting and appliance control, and "virtual" windows that can remember user's preference and adjust automatically to favored "comfortable" conditions, according to NCKU.

Broadband Internet access and full-graphic, interactive interfaces are also attached to most household electronic appliances, allowing users browse the Web, gather weather information, or communicate with others via the Internet from virtually anywhere in the house.

NCKU officials said that the house is currently only open for several hours during weekdays, however, the university plans to offer "lodging services" in the future, making possible short overnight stays by visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REGISTERS US$1.59 BILLION TRADE SURPLUS

TEXT.P: Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$1.59 billion in May, the 15th consecutive month in which the country recorded a trade surplus since March 2006, the Ministry of Finance said Thursday.
Financial officials cited customs' tallies to show that exports in May totaled US$19.58 billion, up 3.5 percent month-on-month. The figure was the seventh largest for a single month.
Imports in May totaled US$18.19 percent, down 0.1 percent from the same month last year, or the third largest total in years.

Officials attributed the increased exports in May to greater exports to China, six member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and Europe, which rose 5.2 percent, 3.3 percent and 12.5 percent, respectively.

Although Taiwan increased its imports from China, the United States and Europe by 14.0 percent, 12.5 percent and 12.2 percent respectively in May over the same month the year before, imports from the six member countries of the ASEAN and the Middle East decreased by more than 11.0 percent, and crude oil imports from Angola, Africa decreased by 40.2 percent.

Officials said that exports in the first five months of this year totaled US$93.86 billion, up 6.8 percent year-on-year, mainly because exports to Asia increased by 7.5 percent, including increased exports to China, Japan, South Korea and six member nations of the ASEAN by 6.7 percent, 3.1 percent, 7.1 percent and 10 percent, respectively.
Exports to Europe also increased by 10.9 percent, although exports to the United Stated were cut by 2.5 percent.
Imports in the first five months totaled US$84.73 billion, up 4.1 percent over the same period last year.
One noteworthy phenomenon is that information and telecommunication product exports in May were down by 15.1 percent from the same month last year, the officials said.

They said that negative growth has become a norm since July 2006 due to outflow of manufacturers, and that double-digit decreases have become the norm, with a decrease as high as 22 percent in November.

Electronic product exports in May showed an unusual decrease of 2.5 percent from the same month last year, which the officials attributed to the high comparison base of last year's performance. Last year's electronic product exports averaged a 23.16 percent increase over the previous year.

DOC.HEADLINE: UA RESUMES DAILY TAIPEI-SAN FRANCISCO DIRECT FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: United Airlines (UA) of the United States will resume daily nonstop passenger and cargo service between Taipei and San Francisco beginning June 8, while ceasing its daily passenger service between Taipei and Nagoya in Japan, the company's Taiwan office announced Thursday.

The Taipei-San Francisco route will be served by Boeing 777s, UA officials in Taipei said, adding that the service will provide outbound passengers from Taiwan with access to more than 200 destinations in the United States.

The Chicago-based carrier began to fly the Taipei-San Francisco route in 1987 but suspended the service in April 2003 and folded its operations in Taiwan five months later because of an outbreak of the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) in East Asia, which set off a global health crisis.
UA decided to resume the Taipei-San Francisco route after the company's recent assessment confirmed a market demand.

The airline opened its Taipei-Nagoya passenger service in April 2005 because of a growing demand from visitors to the 2005 Aichi World Exposition. However, fierce competition from Taiwan's two major carriers -- China Airlines and EVA Air -- operating the same route prompted UA to halt the service.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.K. VISA APPLICATIONS IN TAIWAN TO REQUIRE BIOMETRIC DATA

TEXT.P: The collection of biometric data -- finger scans and digital photographs -- will be required for all U.K. visa applicants in Taiwan from July 26, the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) in Taipei announced in a press conference Thursday.

The introduction of the new visa application process is to help combat visa fraud, the abuse of the U.K.'s immigration and asylum system and a part of anti- terrorism measures, BTCO Director Michael Reilly said.

The new process means two changes in the way BTCO deals with visa applications. All applicants will have to lodge their applications at new visa application centers in Taipei and Kaohsiung and applications will not be accepted at the BTCO in Taipei after July 20, said Reilly.

Second, all visa applicants, regardless of nationality, will need to apply in person to have their fingerscans and digital photographs taken. The whole procedure should take no more than five minutes, he said.

"Biometric visa data provides a higher standard for security and will in time make entry clearance into the U.K. simpler and easier. We have introduced the new process in 64 countries and are confident it will work smoothly here in Taiwan, " Reilly said.
Applicants will be able to track their application status online and will have shorter waiting times and more payment options, he said.
Current valid U.K. visa holders will not be asked to provide biometric data when they enter the U.K., Reilly added.

Taiwan and the Philippines are among the first Asian countries to implement the new application process, he said, adding that by the end of the year, the process will be rolled out to other Asian countries such as Japan, China and South Korea.
All member states of the European Union are expected to implement biometric visas in the spring of 2008, he noted.
The U.K. issued about 36,000 visas to Taiwanese visitors in 2006, including 9,653 Taiwanese student visas, Reilly said. The U.K. accounts for around 30 percent of the Taiwanese overseas study market.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING, DPP BLAMED FOR COSTA RICA FIASCO

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) presidential candidate Thursday expressed his deep regret over the termination of Taiwan-Costa Rica diplomatic ties, blaming both Beijing and Taiwan's ruling party for the development.

Ma Ying-jeou, a former KMT chairman who stepped down from the post in February and was nominated in early May to run as the party's candidate in the 2008 presidential election, made the comments in a press release issued by his campaign office.

Calling it a major setback for Taiwan to sever its 63-year-long diplomatic partnership with the Central American state known worldwide for its democracy and openness, Ma ascribed the event to China's ubiquitous suppression of Taiwan and to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) populist brand of diplomacy.

Ma blamed China for hurting the feelings of the Taiwanese people by using its growing economic clout to block Taiwan in the international arena, and also criticized the DPP for practicing so-called "hit-and-run" diplomacy since it came to power in 2000.

China's relentless efforts to muscle Taiwan off of the world stage have seriously shaken the foundation of mutual trust, while the populist diplomatic strategy adopted by the DPP has caused many of the country's diplomatic allies to lose faith in Taiwan, Ma claimed.

While urging Beijing to stop bullying Taiwan and try to build better two-way relations, Ma also urged the DPP to take the initiative and contact China in a pragmatic and professional style so as to best serve the Taiwan people's interests.

Speaking earlier the same day at a Legislative Yuan news conference, KMT lawmaker John Chiang, a former minister of foreign affairs, voiced grave concern that Panama and Nicaragua might follow in Costa Rica's footsteps by breaking off diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
Following the loss of Costa Rica, Taiwan maintains diplomatic links with 24 countries, most of whom are in Latin America, the South Pacific and Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAREWELL PARTY FOR OUTGOING TAIWAN ENVOY IN NEW YORK

TEXT.P: Staff of Taiwan government agencies and private enterprises posted in New York hosted a farewell luncheon Wednesday for Andrew Hsia, director-general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in New York, who will be transferred to serve as the country's representative to India.

Hsia, who has served as chief of the TECO in New York for six years, said during the luncheon that the smooth handling of several significant activities organized by TECO was the result of collaboration among all public and private sectors stationed in the city.

The New York TECO is staffed by representatives of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Bureau of Foreign Trade, the Ministry of Education, the Council for Cultural Affairs, the Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission and the Financial Supervisory Commission.

The executive chiefs of these agencies hold meetings bimonthly with leading figures of major Taiwanese state-owned and private corporations, including China Airlines, EVA Airways, Yang Ming Marine Transport Inc. and many Taiwan-based banks posted in the city to boost partnerships.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Immigrant Measure Survives Challenges; Senate Vote Could Come Tomorrow.
The plan to overhaul the nation's immigration system survived its most serious challenges yesterday, when the Senate defeated amendments to disqualify hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants from legalization and to extend visas to hundreds of thousands more relatives of U.S. citizens and green-card holders.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALA, EL SALVADORE TO MAINTAIN DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, June 7 (CNA) 06/07/07 21:29:04 (By Ramon Huang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Two of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America, Guatemala and El Salvadore, have each announced that they will maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
The two countries made their announcements after Costa Rica, formerly another ally of Taiwan in Central America, switched its diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing Wednesday.

According to Spanish news reports by the Associated Press, Salvadoran President Antonio Saca said at a news conference Wednesday that his nation would like to develop relations with China, but only on the condition that China not ask his country to cut its ties with Taiwan.

Guatemalan Presidential Office Spokeswoman Crista Kepfer told the EFE--the leading Spanish news agency-- that Guatemala's government has no comments on Costa Rica's diplomatic decision, but added that Guatemala will maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan. She also said that Guatemalan President Oscar Berger will visit Taiwan June 17 at the invitation of the Taiwanese government.

Berger's visit to Taiwan later this month aims to strengthen relations with Taiwan and to enhance bilateral cooperation on infrastructure construction and free trade, Kedpfer said, adding that the two countries signed a free trade agreement last year.
Moreover, Kepfer said Berger has indicated repeatedly that Guatemala will not sacrifice its ties with Taiwan to seek better trade relations with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISM BUREAU CHIEF DEPARTS FOR JAPAN TO PROMOTE TOURISM

TEXT.P: Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai said Thursday that she will promote Taiwanese tourism during her visit to Japan, and expressed hope that the total number of Japanese visitors to Taiwan will exceed 1.23 million this year.
Lai made the remarks at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in the northern county of Taoyuan before leading a delegation to Hokkaido, Japan.

Lai said that she will visit the tourism sector in Japan and introduce Taiwanese tourist spots and delicious foods to Japanese citizens in the hope that more people from Hokkaido will visit Taiwan in the second half of the year.

Hokkaido has been a popular tourist destinations for Taiwanese people over the past decade, Lai said, adding that the total number of Taiwanese visitors to Hokkaido every year increased from 50,000 10 years ago to 250,000 last year.
Taiwanese tourists accounted for half of the total foreign visitors to Hokkaido, according to Lai, however, fewer than 50,000 people from Hokkaido travel to Taiwan every year.
With that in mind, the bureau began to collaborate with private travel promotion organizations in Hokkaido in recent years as part of efforts to increase two-way exchanges and visits, Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$30 MILLION DONATED TO HELP LESS PRIVILEGED STUDENTS

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese entrepreneur has donated NT$30 million (US$905,470) in scholarships to help 300 less-privileged students in various stages of schooling, Vice President Annette Lu disclosed Thursday.

Lu said the anonymous donor is a young industrialist who started his enterprise from scratch and wishes to use his money to help 100 junior middle school students, 100 high school students and 100 university students.

She added that a committee in charge of the "Little Scholars After-School Study Program, " which she and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng launched in January to help pupils from low-income and less-privileged families, will begin to accept applications for the scholarships in September.
She also said the legislative speaker had mustered NT$9 million to help the after-school study program's 128 classes throughout Taiwan to continue operating.

Lu pointed out that the program, entirely supported by private donors, has attracted some 2,500 less-privileged students who meet three or four times each week at selected locations in their communities to receive help from teachers of different courses.
The vice president pledged that she will continue to look for philanthropists among Taiwan's successful entrepreneurs to support the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH SPEED RAIL CORP. TO HOLD INAUGURAL CEREMONY OCT. 24

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) will hold a grand ceremony Oct. 24 to celebrate reaching full daily service capacity, the company's top executive said Thursday.
THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing said that currently trains are making 31 daily runs in each direction on the north-south high-speed railway between Taipei and Kaohsiung, the country's two largest cities.
Full utilization of the system's capacity will raise that total to 88 commercial and maintenance daily train runs, she explained.

The number of daily trips in each direction on the high-speed rail system is scheduled to increase to 41 or 42 per day in July, Ing said, adding that the number will expand further to 61 in September to meet the requirements set forth in the build-operate-transfer (BOT) contract the company signed with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications in the late 1990s. The high-speed rail is the country's first infrastructure project built under the BOT formula.
"Ultimately, we hope to expand the total number of daily train runs in each direction to 88, " Ing said, adding that the company will be able to break even when the number of daily runs reaches 60.

Ing said the company plans to invite 600 to 800 dignitaries from home and abroad to attend the Oct. 24 ceremony, which is likely to be held at high-speed rail station in either central or southern Taiwan.
The grand ceremony is also designed to mark the 99th anniversary of the inauguration of north-south train service in Taiwan, Ing said.

The high-speed railway, which uses Japan's Shinkansen "Bullet Train" core system, began commercial service Jan.5 this year. Despite some early technical problems, it has become increasingly popular among local travelers. On June 3, it welcomed the rail system's 5 millionth passenger.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH SPEED RAIL CORP. TO HOLD INAUGURAL CEREMONY OCT. 24

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) will hold a grand ceremony Oct. 24 to celebrate reaching full daily service capacity, the company's top executive said Thursday.
THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing said that currently trains are making 31 daily runs in each direction on the north-south high-speed railway between Taipei and Kaohsiung, the country's two largest cities.
Full utilization of the system's capacity will raise that total to 88 commercial and maintenance daily train runs, she explained.

The number of daily trips in each direction on the high-speed rail system is scheduled to increase to 41 or 42 per day in July, Ing said, adding that the number will expand further to 61 in September to meet the requirements set forth in the build-operate-transfer (BOT) contract the company signed with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications in the late 1990s. The high-speed rail is the country's first infrastructure project built under the BOT formula.
"Ultimately, we hope to expand the total number of daily train runs in each direction to 88, " Ing said, adding that the company will be able to break even when the number of daily runs reaches 60.

Ing said the company plans to invite 600 to 800 dignitaries from home and abroad to attend the Oct. 24 ceremony, which is likely to be held at high-speed rail station in either central or southern Taiwan.
The grand ceremony is also designed to mark the 99th anniversary of the inauguration of north-south train service in Taiwan, Ing said.

The high-speed railway, which uses Japan's Shinkansen "Bullet Train" core system, began commercial service Jan.5 this year. Despite some early technical problems, it has become increasingly popular among local travelers. On June 3, it welcomed the rail system's 5 millionth passenger.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 8, or the 23rd day of the fourth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: German composer Robert Alexander Schumann is born. He is known particularly for his song cycles, piano works, and symphonies. A leading romanticist and a noted critic, he encouraged Chopin and influenced Brahms.
1845: Andrew Jackson, the seventh president of the United States, dies at the age of 78. As a general in the war against the British, he defeated British forces at New Orleans in 1815. As president, he opposed the Bank of America and increased presidential powers.
1916: British biologist Sir Francis Crick is born. Along with James D. Watson, he proposed a spiral model -- the double helix -- for the molecular structure of DNA. He shared a 1962 Nobel Prize for advances in the study of genetics.
1928: The National Revolutionary Army, led by commander Chiang Kai-shek, conquers Beijing in its Northern Expedition, formally ending the civil war in China.
1940: The German battle cruisers Scharnhorst and Gneisenau sink the British aircraft carrier Glorious and the destroyers Ardent and Acasta in the Arctic Sea. At least 1,500 men are lost from the three ships.
1941: Israeli military leader and politician Moshe Dayan loses his left eye while serving in the British army when his telescope is shot by French troops under the Vichy regime during World War II. Dayan later directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six-Day War.
1945: The government of the United States declares that in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference, Korea is permitted to gain independence.
1948: Yu Yow-renn is nominated the Control Yuan's first president under the new Constitution of the Republic of China.
1969: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon meets the leader of South Vietnam on Midway Island and announces the withdrawal of 25,000 U.S. troops from Vietnam.
1973: Generalissimo Franco hands over Spain's premiership to Luis Carrero Blanco and remains as head of state.
1976: Wu Chien-hsiung and S.S. Chen, members of the ROC's Academia Sinica, win the U.S. National Medal of Science.
1976: The Fifth Sino-American Conference on mainland China opens in Taipei with nearly 100 scholars and experts from both countries participating.
1980: The ROC-Indonesian Cultural and Economic Association is established in Taipei.
1983: Taylor Wang becomes first Chinese-American astronaut.
1987: ROC Premier Yu Kuo-hua arrives in Singapore for a five-day visit as the guest of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. Yu also called on Singapore President Wee Kim Wee and other government officials.
1987: The governor of the ROC's Central Bank of China, Chang Chi-cheng, announces that the ROC's foreign exchange reserves have exceeded US$60 billion.
1995: Lee Teng-hui becomes the first ROC president to visit the United States, angering Beijing.
1996: Mainland China conducts a nuclear test explosion at the remote Lop Nor test site in northwestern Xinjiang Province.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui receives a delegation headed by Burkina Faso National Assembly Speaker Traore Melegue.
2000: Doctors at the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Kaohsiung carry out a successful 12-hour liver transplant operation, giving Wu Feng-ying, 50, a section of liver donated by her son, Lin Yun-ju, 24.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men who, when they see what is good and honest, try to act up to it, and when they see what is bad and dishonest try to avoid it as if avoiding scalding water: Such men I have known and the expressions of such principle I have heard." "But men who live in retirement in order to study their aims and who practice righteousness in order to carry out their principles: The expression of such principles I have heard, but I have not seen such men."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT CONSIDERING SETTING UP OTHER OFFICES IN COSTA RICA

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not at present consider establishing any other liaison office in Costa Rica now that the two countries have severed formal diplomatic relations, Deputy Foreign Minister Chang Hsiao-yue said Friday.

Speaking at a question and answer session at the Legislative Yuan, Chang said Taiwan announced Thursday that it was severing formal diplomatic relations with Costa Rica and ceasing all cooperation projects between the two countries immediately after the Costa Rican government's "extremely unfriendly" move of switching diplomatic recognition to Beijing earlier the same day.
Despite the diplomatic fiasco, Chang said, the day-to-day lives of Taiwan expatriates in Costa Rica, including Taiwan students studying there, will not be affected.

Answering a question raised by opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Kuo Lin-yung on whether the Foreign Ministry will continue to strive to maintain certain number of countries maintaining formal diplomatic relations with its allies following Costa Rica's decision to sever ties "simply for money, " Chang said the ministry will not engage in a "dollar diplomacy" battle with China.

Meanwhile, Chang said, in addition to continuing to work to safeguard Taiwan's formal relations with its diplomatic allies, the Foreign Ministry will also strive to deepen ties with the United States, Japan and other countries with which Taiwan does not maintain formal diplomatic relations.

Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang accused Costa Rica the day before of repeatedly "cheating" Taiwan in the process of its forging diplomatic relations with China. Huang said it is ironic that Costa Rican President Oscar Arias, who is a Nobel Peace Prize winner, chose to switch diplomatic recognition to Beijing simply because of China's promise to offer "better financial help."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
TAIWAN DELEGATIONS FORGE PROCUREMENT DEALS WITH U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 7 (CNA) 06/08/07 13:57:21 (By Michelle Tsai, Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Two agricultural and industrial delegations from Taiwan signed letters of intent with their American counterparts Thursday for various procurement plans.
The signing ceremony took place on Capitol Hill in Washington D.C., with many members of the U.S. Congress witnessing.

The deals concern a plan by the state-owned Taiwan Power Co. to procure US$100 million worth of nuclear power plant equipment from Westinghouse Electric Corp. and plans by Taiwan's agricultural sector to procure a combined US$3.9 billion worth of soybeans, corn, wheat and beef from the United States.

The Taiwanese signatories of the agricultural deals included the Taiwan Vegetable Oil Manufacturers Association, the Taiwan Feed Industry Association and the Taiwan Flour Mills Association. The American signatories were the U.S. Grains Council, the U.S. Wheat Associates, the American Soybean Association and the U.S. Meat Export Federation.

Sun Ming-hsien, an ambassador-at-large for agricultural affairs who serves as leader of the agricultural delegation, noted that Taiwan and the United States not only maintain close agricultural relations but also share a lot of common values.
Sun expressed the hope that the strong agricultural relations between the two countries will lead eventually to the establishment of a Taiwan-U.S. free trade agreement (FTA).

Bureau of Foreign Trade Director-General Huang Chih-peng, leader of the industrial delegation, noted that all the members of his delegation are representatives of important Taiwan state-owned enterprises and that they are expected to further procure products worth a total of US$11.34 billion from the United States over the next few years.

During the current U.S. visit, the state-owned CPC Corp. signed a memorandum with Honeywell International in Houston for the procurement of petrochemical processing and control equipment worth US$1 billion, while Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. signed various contracts in Los Angeles and New York for the procurement of aircraft components and chemicals worth a total of US$28 million.

Asked during a news conference held in the U.S. capital Thursday whether the U.S. visit by the two procurement delegations will be helpful in paving the way for the establishment of a Taiwan-U.S. FTA, Taiwan's representative to the United States, Joseph Wu, said the visit has helped the United States reconfirm Taiwan's status as an important trade partner.

Wu pointed out that during their visits to various U.S. states, the delegations were received by state governors, members of state legislatures and members of Congress elected from the concerned states, which he said shows that the U.S. side attaches great importance to the country's trade relations with Taiwan.

Wu admitted that establishing a Taiwan-U.S. FTA involves some difficulties and that progress isn't expected in the foreseeable future, adding, however, that this does not mean the goal is unattainable.
According to Wu, U.S. administration officials agree that the United States is not reluctant to start FTA talks with Taiwan but that the timing is a problem.
Wu said Taiwan should continue to work on getting the message across to Washington that a Taiwan-U.S. FTA is not only important to Taiwan but also in the best interests of the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS NO PLAN TO DEVELOP MEDIUM-RANGE MISSILES: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 7 (CNA) 06/08/07 14:29:26 (By Chiehyu Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan doesn't have any plan to develop medium-range missiles or deploy weapons of mass destruction, the Republic of China representative to the United States said Thursday.

Nevertheless, Joseph Wu reminded the United States and the international community that the military balance in the Taiwan Strait is tilting in favor of China whose intensified military buildup is threatening regional peace and stability.

Noting that China is a menace while Taiwan is a defender, Wu said the United States and the international community should demand that China halt its threatening military deployment rather than impose various restrictions on Taiwan.
Wu made the remarks during the representative office's routine monthly news conference.
When Taiwan conducted computerized war games as part of its annual Han Kuang military exercise in late April, then-Defense Minister Lee Jye mentioned that "Taiwan should use medium-range missiles."
However, the United States reportedly disagreed with Lee's views and dissuaded Taiwan from launching such a development project.

At the news conference, Wu was asked whether the representative office has received any information from U.S. authorities concerning the issue. In response, Wu said that he met with Pentagon officials recently, but neither side brought up the medium-range missile issue. Nonetheless, Wu said he has come to know through indirect channels that U.S. officials have indeed expressed concerns about the reported project.
Wu said that to the best of his understanding, Taiwan has no plan to develop any medium-range missiles or deploy or stockpile weapons of mass destruction.

According to Wu, the issue regarding Taiwan's military build-up should be considered from two angles. First of all, he said, Taiwan needs to consult with its strategic partners, particularly the United States, to cope with any possible Taiwan Strait conflicts.

Second, Wu said, the reasons behind Taiwan's mulling of acquiring some offensive or strategic weapons lies in the fact that China has deployed various types of missiles along its southeastern coastline targeting Taiwan and that many of its new naval weapons, such as new destroyers and submarines, are also targeted at Taiwan.
Against this backdrop, Wu said it's unfair to unilaterally restrict Taiwan's access to offensive weaponry systems while assisting or turning a blind eye to China's menacing military build-up moves.
Wu further cited a recent Pentagon report on China's growing military strength and sophistication to stress the gravity of China's military threat to Taiwan.

According to the annual Pentagon report, Wu said, China's success in destroying a satellite in low-Earth orbit early this year represents a threat to the interests of all space-faring nations. The Pentagon also said the People's Liberation Army is building a greater capacity to launch pre-emptive strikes. It cited as examples China's acquisition of long-endurance submarines, unmanned combat aircraft and additional precision-guided air-to-ground missiles. By 2011, China will have aircraft carriers, the report also said.

Taiwan has consistently conveyed similar information to U.S. authorities over the past several years, Wu said, adding that hopefully, the United States and the international community will no longer question Taiwan's strategic thinking about its self-defense plans and instead ask China to cease moves that pose a threat to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIPLOMATIC SETBACK WON'T AFFECT OPERATIONS OF DEMOCRATIC UNION: VP

TEXT.P: Taiwan's setback incurred from the severance of diplomatic relations with Costa Rica will not affect the operations of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) , Vice President Annette Lu said Friday.

Lu, who played an instrumental role in bringing about the establishment of the DPU two years ago, noted the number of countries in the 26-member DPU that do not maintain formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan is greater than the number of countries that do, adding that all countries are welcome to join the DPU so long as they are peace-loving and recognize the value of democracy.

Lu said that in light of Taiwan's latest diplomatic setback -- as a result of Beijing's unmerciful suppression of Taiwan -- the people of the country should close ranks and pay more attention to international affairs and have more concern for the future of Taiwan.

The DPU -- a non-governmental organization designed to serve as a platform for exchanges among the Pacific Rim countries in the promotion of democracy, peace and prosperity, and other common values -- was inaugurated on Aug. 14, 2005.

Lu called for the people of the country, particularly members of the media and the government, to not spend too much time and energy on elections, saying that elections should be left to the candidates. She said the country's people should be more attentive to efforts aimed at making Taiwan a greater and stronger nation.
Lu made the remarks during an interview with media members at I-Shou University located in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS NOT ENGAGED IN CHECKBOOK DIPLOMACY: MOFA

TEXT.P: Recent criticism by Costa Rican President Oscar Arias about Taiwan's foreign aid proves that Taiwan has not engaged in checkbook diplomacy, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Friday.
MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said it is regrettable and "ungentlemanly" of Arias to criticize Taiwan immediately after his country severed diplomatic relations with Taiwan to forge ties with China.

Reiterating that Taiwan has never entered any "financial competition" with China in the international arena, Wang said Arias' remarks indicate that Costa Rica has switched recognition from Taipei to Beijing simply to obtain more aid from China.
According to an AFP report filed in San Jose, Arias told local station Radio Monumental Thursday that Taiwan has provided too little aid to its diplomatic allies.
"I have been critical of Taiwan in the sense that if they have diplomatic relations with fewer than 30 countries, they should be more generous," Arias was quoted as saying.

After maintaining formal ties with Taiwan for decades, Costa Rica secretly signed a joint communique with China on the establishment of diplomatic relations June 1 in Beijing. Arias officially publicized the news Wednesday and announced his country's decision to break relations with Taiwan.

In the wake of Arias' announcement, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang proclaimed in Taipei Thursday the government's decision to terminate formal relations with Costa Rica and cease all cooperation projects between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISTS URGED NOT TO ENTER PROTECTED AREAS FOR GREEN TURTLES

TEXT.P: The season for the endangered green turtle to return to lay eggs on beaches of Penghu has arrived, and tourists should refrain from entering their protected areas, a conservation official warned Friday.

Chen Chin-lung, a section chief with the Penghu County Government's Department of Ecology and Conservation, said that every year between May and October, green turtles come to Penghu's seashore to nest.
Penghu County is the area in Asia where green turtles most regularly come each year to nest, Chen said.

The county has set aside an area of 23.328 hectares in Wanan township for the threatened species to lay eggs undisturbed, hoping to eliminate the interference of the tourists in the turtles' egg-laying and hatching process.
Chen said that tourists are banned from entering the area between May 1 and Oct. 31, and that violators face severe penalties in accordance with the Wildlife Conservation Law.
Although there has been no indications of green turtles coming ashore to lay eggs so far this year, Chen said that they are expected to do so shortly.
He urged local residents and tourists to follow the relevant regulations and not to intrude out of curiosity.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL LOSSES DUE TO PLUM RAINS TOP NT$20 MILLION: COA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agricultural losses caused by downpours during the ongoing plum rain season had reached an estimated NT$21.87 million (US$662,205) as of Thursday, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Friday.

According to the official, the two counties that have been most seriously affected are Changhua County, with losses amounting to NT$12.9 million, and Miaoli County, with losses totalling NT$ 8.95 million.

The official said that 25 percent of 571 hectares of farmland around Taiwan has been damaged by heavy rains, with the most affected crops being watermelon, musk melon, green onion, cabbage and wax gourd.

Thursday's average wholesale price of vegetables in Taipei City was NT$18.6 per kilogram, up 4.5 percent from Wednesday's figure, with a total of 1,183 metric tons of vegetables being traded, down by 169 metric tons over the previous day's level, the official said.

Meanwhile, Thursday's average wholesale price of vegetables in Changhua County, Taiwan's main vegetable producer, was NT$14.5 per kilogram, up 2.8 percent from Wednesday, with a total of 139 metric tons being traded, down 12 percent from a day earlier, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENCE -- FINAL LESSON AT HAITUAN SCHOOL IN TAITUNG

TEXT.P: Eleven six-grade students of Haituan Elementary School in the southeastern county of Taitung bade farewell to their parents and school juniors Friday, setting off for a journey of independence -- the last lesson before their graduation.

The lesson is imparted over a 140-km-long, three-day bicycle trip from the Haituan rural township to Liyutan -- a scenic attraction in neighboring Hualien County in eastern Taiwan -- where the five boys and six girls will be presented with their graduation diplomas.

At around 9: 00 a.m., Wang Lai-kuei, the oldest oracle of the Bunun tribe in Haituan, officiated over a tribal ceremony, praying for blessings for the youths while holding the right hand of each in the hope that they will have a happy journey and return safely.
Haituan Elementary School Principal Lee Chih-kuo stressed that no matter how foul the weather, the journey must continue because it is a test for the tenacity and willpower.
It will be a chance for the students to learn independence, their last lesson before graduation, Lee said.

The students, in the company of their class teacher and the school principal, are to ride north along the Provincial Highway No.9 for 60 km to the rural township of Jueisuei, Hualien, on the first day of the trip. On the second day, they will ride another 70 km to Hualien City where they will spend the night.
On the final day, the brave youths will ride from downtown Hualien to Liyutan, the terminal point of the challenging ride, to collect their diplomas before heading home by bus.

Lee said that before departing for the bike tour, designed to allow the students to know better their hometown and neighboring lands, the boys and girls had all to undergo tough physical training, which included jogging for a distance of 2 or 3 km everyday.

One of the young cyclists, Yu Wen-lung, who stands less than 140 cm tall, rides a borrowed bike which is also the smallest in the group. Nevertheless, Yu said without hesitation that he is confident of riding through the challenge.

Yu's classmate Lee Cho, riding on a leased bike, also expressed confidence in his own ability to finish the journey, for which he has trained by making forth- and-back rides between Haituan to Taitung City and Chipen, in Taitung county.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA REAFFIRMS POLICY TO MAINTAIN TIES WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Costa Rica, June 8 (CNA) 06/08/07 17:37:47 (By Ramon Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Panamanian government reaffirmed Thursday the country's policy to maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

Panama made the move in the wake of the severing of diplomatic ties between Costa Rica and Taiwan, a development that has sparked concerns in Taipei about a possible domino effect impacting Taiwan's diplomatic relations with other Central American nations.

Panama's Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a written statement that the Panamanian government respects the decision of Costa Rica President Oscar Arias to sever ties with Taiwan, but a spokesman at Panama's presidential office affirmed that the administration of President Martin Torrijos will continue to maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan while promoting trade relations with China.

After maintaining formal ties with Taiwan for decades, Costa Rica secretly signed a joint communique with China on the establishment of diplomatic relations June 1 in Beijing. Arias officially publicized the news Wednesday and announced his country's decision to break off relations with Taiwan.

In the wake of Arias' announcement, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang proclaimed in Taipei Thursday the government's decision to terminate formal relations with Costa Rica and cease all cooperation projects between the two countries.
After breaking ties with Costa Rica, Taiwan now has 24 diplomatic allies around the world, 12 of which are in Latin America and the Caribbean region.

DOC.HEADLINE: THSRC TO INAUGURATE ONLINE TICKET BOOKING SYSTEM

Meanwhile, the THSRC will inaugurate computer voice ticket reservation services in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: BULLET TRAIN DELAYED 95 MINUTES, ALL PASSENGERS REFUNDED

TEXT.P: A north-bound bullet train from Zuoying, in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, which should have arrived 90 minutes after departure in Banciao, in northern Taipei county, arrived 95 minutes late, resulting in full refunds for all those aboard.

The Zuoying-departing bullet train, No. 406, was scheduled to arrive in Banciao at 10 a.m. Friday, enabling many passengers to attend a morning meeting in Taipei, but instead arrived at 11: 35 a.m., more than an hour and a half behind schedule.
The delay -- the longest in the six-month history of Taiwan's high speed rail services -- forced the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) to refund in full all of the 800 passengers aboard Train 406.

According to the THSRC authorities, train operators slowed the vehicle when they discovered an abnormal safety reading on a detector monitoring the condition of the bogies -- one of the most important parts of a train -- just after No. 406 passed the Tainan station. Operators then allowed the bullet train to run at a much slower speed until it arrived in Taichung, central Taiwan, where it was found that the abnormal reading did not indicate the presences of any safety issues and the train was accelerated to 120 km per hour.

This delay was followed by a second incident the same day, which saw passengers taking bullet train No. 114 from Zuoying arrive in Banciao 30 minutes behind schedule. All passengers aboard that train received a 50 percent refund.

THSRC officials said that the safety alarm on train No. 114 was triggered when the train passed Miaoli, prompting the operators to bring the train to a halt. The operators resumed the train's journey, at a speed of 45 km per hour, after checking all relevant conditions and finding that slopes supporting the railroad near Miaoli had been eroded by flood, but that the eroded area -- 5 meters long, with a depth of about 25 centimeters -- had occurred in an isolated area, was not running, and would not cause any safety issues, THSRC officials said.
Two other south-bound bullet trains, No. 407 and No 505, were also delayed due to the slope erosion in Miaoli Friday.

The 345-km railway linking Taipei and Kaohsiung, inaugurated in January this year, has reduced rail travel time between Taiwan's two largest cities to 90 minutes from the previous four-and-a-half hours.
