DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE QUESTIONED BY PROSECUTORS

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh was questioned by prosecutors Friday in connection with political donations he received between September and December 2002 while serving as the mayor of Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan.
Accompanied by Lee Ying-yuan, manager of his presidential campaign, Hsieh arrived at the office of the Supreme Prosecutors Office at 9.55 a.m. and left at 11 a.m.

In response to questions from journalists waiting outside the office, Hsieh said the funds at the center of the investigation were donated to an organization of his supporters for the use of his election campaign.

All those funds have been retained in a special bank account since being received and have neither been spent nor transferred to his personal account, which corroborates his claims that this funds were not given in return for any specific favor, Hsieh said.
As the DPP's standard bearer in the upcoming 2008 presidential election, Hsieh said he is willing to subject his integrity to the public scrutiny, and promised to cooperate with the investigators.

However, Hsieh took issue with some media outlets which have urged the prosecution not to drag feet on their probe of Hsieh in light of the fact that former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou who is set to run on the KMT's party ticket in the 2008 presidential elections has been indicted for alleged lining his pocket with public funds.
He urged his critics to come up with convincing evidence when they file complaints with prosecutors against him in order to spare prosecutors the trouble of searching evidence.
Hsieh reportedly sought political donations from businessmen who had been awarded with contracts by the Kaohsiung City government while he served as the city's mayor.

Meanwhile an aide to Hsieh cried foul that some media outlets have been urging prosecutors to accelerate their probe into the case, and that the prosecutor's office leaked its decision to question Hsieh on Friday to the media.

Chao Tien-lin, a spokesman at Hsieh's campaign headquarters, said the leak is obviously an attempt to dampen Hsieh' election campaign and that Hsieh is mulling whether to retain a group of lawyers to defend his interests in the lead up to the presidential elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE:
DOC.TEXT:
Subscribers who published CEP 0036, sent June 7, headlined UA RESUMES DAILY TAIPEI-SAN FRANCISCO DIRECT FLIGHTS, are asked to use the following.
Taipei, June 8 (CNA) In a June 7 story about United Airlines' (UA's) resumption of flights on the Taipei-San Francisco direct route, the CNA reported erroneously that UA has access to more than 200 destinations in the United States, and that it folded operations in Taiwan months after suspending the Taipei-San Francisco service in 2003.
In fact, UA serves more than 200 destinations worldwide, and did not cease operations in Taiwan, although the company did suspend service on its Taipei-San Francisco route in autumn 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: BURNABY, TAICHUNG TO COOPERATE IN HIGH-TECH DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: The Canadian city of Burnaby will cooperate with the central Taiwan city of Taichung in technological and economic development, a Taichung city official said Friday.
Burnaby Mayor Derek Corrigan paid a visit to the Taichung city government Friday at the head of a delegation from the city in British Columbia, the official said.
During the visit, Corrigan and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu signed a joint declaration expressing their determination to cooperate in promoting high technology development.

Hu told Corrigan that Taichung city's economy has been growing quickly thanks to its stable financial condition and development of the Central Taiwan Science Park. Hu added that Taichung City will learn from Burnaby City's experience in becoming a high tech center.
Corrigan promised to promote bilateral trade and technological interchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPATS CALL FOR MAINTAINING MISSION IN COSTA RICA
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Costa Rica, June 8 (CNA) 06/08/07 20:18:06 (By Ramon Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese expatriates in Costa Rica urged the Republic of China government Friday to open a representative office here following the severance of diplomatic ties between the two countries the day before.

Out of a concern that their interests might be affected because of the termination of the 63-year-old diplomatic partnership between Taiwan and Costa Rica, Taiwanese nationals in the Central American state asked the ROC government to set up an economic and cultural office in San Jose to take charge of consular and document verification affairs.
"Establishing a representative office here will help Taiwanese people maintain close links and strong affiliation with the motherland," said one Taiwan businessman.

According to Ku Chung-hsiao, head of a Taiwanese association, the closure of the ROC Embassy and the departure of the ambassador is of great concern to them. "We will feel deserted by the government if it fails to open a representative office here," he said.
Currently, there are some 60,000 ethnic Chinese in Costa Rica, some 4,000 of whom are immigrants from Taiwan and mainly work in the foreign trade, restaurant, sundry and tourism-related sectors.
Taiwan decided to terminate its diplomatic ties with Costa Rica Thursday, hours after Costa Rica announced its establishment of diplomatic links with China.
Following the loss of Costa Rica, Taiwan still maintains diplomatic relations with 24 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES PROMOTING TOURISM FOR TAIWANESE

TEXT.P: The Philippines government is rolling out a series of promotions in the hope of attracting more Taiwanese tourists, an official from the Philippine Department of Tourism said on the sidelines of a Philippines travel guide launch ceremony Friday.

"We will try to present various tour packages to attract different types of Taiwanese tourists. Some of them visit the Philippines purely for sightseeing, while some come to play golf, " said Ireneo H. Reyes, Senior Tourism Operation Officer of the Department of Tourism.

Reyes estimated that more than 100,000 Taiwanese tourists visited the Philippines last year. The latest statistics from this year show a 7 percent increase in the number of tourists from the same period of last year, he said, adding that the bureau is expecting a record-breaking year in 2007.

However, there should be a lot more Taiwanese tourists visiting the Philippines, he said, adding that the low number of tourists is due to Taiwanese lack of understanding about its closest neighbor to the south.

The Manila Economic and Cultural Office collaborated with the China Times Publishing Company to publish the Chinese-language guide titled Inside Guide: Philippines. "We hope that the readers will gain a better understanding of Filipinos," he said.

The book contains features on Philippine history, culture, traditions, faith, way of life and other information collected by the Discovery Channel and Inside Guides -- two of the world's best information providers, he said.
Reyes noted that some of Taiwan's media reports have brought the Philippines a lot of negative publicity and have affected Taiwanese people's views of the Southeast Asian country.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY LAUNCHES AFTERNOON COFFEE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) launched an afternoon coffee program Friday, the first of its kind, in the hope of bringing together people from various fields to share their thoughts and induce innovative thinking.
NCKU President Michael M.C. Lai, who floated the idea, said the program, dubbed "Ecko," takes place at between 3: 30 p.m. and 5 p.m. every Friday.

There will be a speaker each time talking about a specific subject, but they will only speak for five minutes and the rest of the time will be left for participants to mingle and chat over tea or coffee, the U.S.-educated scholar in molecular biology said.

Lai said that he took his cue from the tradition of afternoon tea in Britain, saying that although research funds for British universities are not as big as their counterparts in Taiwan, British students are very innovative in research work, which he attributed to what he claimed is their "afternoon tea practice."
He said starting the university's coffee program is designed to "set up a culture and a concept."
Students can make use of the informal occasion to get to know each other and gain access to areas other than their own, he added.

The program has won the support of business tycoon Hsu Wen-lung, founder of the Chi Mei Group. The first speaker Friday was a member of the Chi Mei Mandolin Orchestra, who spoke about the mandolin. The speaker received a free coffee, while the other attendees got a 40 percent discount on their drinks.
The university welcomes anyone to speak at the "Ecko" time, saying that several NCKU professors have already registered to speak.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROCCOC INITIATES BED AND BREAKFAST LODGING EVALUATION SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China (ROCCOC) initiated a Bed and Breakfast evaluation system in May with the aim of providing standard criteria for consumers in selecting safe and comfortable lodging, ROCCOC Director-general Chang Pen-tsao said Friday.
Chang said the ROCCOC has completed evaluations of 74 Bed and Breakfasts and expects to have evaluated a total of 180 establishments by the end of 2007.

Quoting statistics made by the Tourism Bureau, Chang said Taiwan's Bed and Breakfast establishments have mushroomed in recent years. Nearly 10,000 such small lodgings were established, but only 1,939 were legally registered, of which 1,886 are in operation, Chang added.
Chang said only legal Bed and Breakfasts will be recognized in the evaluation system.

The ROCCOC announced winning design of the Bed and Breakfast service quality certificate Wednesday, Chang said, adding that lodgings which meet the evaluation criteria will be issued the service quality certificates.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO ANGLERS MISSING DURING HEAVY RAINS IN CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Several incidents related to heavy rains were reported in the central county of Taichung Friday, including the one that saw two anglers missing near the Hengliu creek.

It has been raining heavily in the county for several days due to a lingering monsoon frontal system. According to statistics from the Central Weather Bureau (CWB), rainfall amounted to 152 mm in Takeng, Taichung county, between 11: 00 a.m. and 2: 00 p.m. Friday, 136 mm in Tungshih during the same three-hour period, and 119 mm in Shenkang.

The downpour caused flooding which damaged a bridge connecting the aboriginal Chiuan tribe, in the mountains of the county's rural Hoping township, with the outside world. Meanwhile, a wall at an old Marine Corps base in the rural Taya township collapsed during the rains. No casualties have thus far been confirmed.
By noon, the Hoping rural township administration had opened a disaster control center and announced the closure of schools and government offices for the day.

CWB meteorologists forecast that the plum rains frontal system will remain over the island for the next few days. As a result, heavy, or torrential rains might be expected across the country in the short term.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD FIRM ON MAKING TAIWAN 'NORMAL COUNTRY'
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 7 (CNA) 06/08/07 21:13:56 (By S. H. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun asserted Thursday his resolve to make Taiwan a "normal country," describing it as the only way to ensure the country's continued presence on the world stage.

Speaking at a dinner party with DPP supporters in the San Francisco Bay area, he said that "promoting a 'normal country' resolution is the right thing to do and will help boost the chances of the party's candidate in the 2008 presidential election." Yu ascribed the problems that Taiwan faces at present to its lack of status as a "normal country."
"Only by transforming Taiwan into a normal country can the nation continue to survive, " Yu told more than 300 supporters attending the banquet.

In response to suspicions that the DPP has shown signs of division after the party's presidential primary in early May, Yu disagreed and said that time will prove that the DPP can withstand the test of time.

He urged DPP backers to return to Taiwan early next year and cast their ballots for the party's candidates in the presidential election, and vowed to continue to promote the "normal country" resolution for the sake of Taiwan's survival.

Yu first broached the idea that the DPP should adopt a resolution on making Taiwan a "normal country" during his campaign prior to the DPP's May 6 presidential primary, which he lost to Hsieh in a direct vote by party members. He has repeatedly vowed to continue promoting the resolution within the party despite his defeat in the primary.
San Francisco is the first leg of Yu's ongoing overseas campaign that will also take him to other U. S. cities, including Los Angeles, Houston and New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: UA RESUMES SAN FRANCISCO-TAIPEI NONSTOP FLIGHTS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 7 (CNA) 06/08/07 21:31:29 (By Josie Chou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: United Airlines (UA) of the United States resumed nonstop service between San Francisco and Taipei Thursday after a nearly four-year hiatus.

UA organized a gala party in front of the Thursday noon flight's boarding gate to mark the resumption of the daily San Francisco-Taipei nonstop combined passenger and cargo service, which was suspended in the fall of 2003 following an outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) in Taiwan earlier that year.

The party was jointly presided over by Hank Krakowski, vice president of UA parental company's flight operations, and Liao Wei-ping, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco.

Addressing those attending the event, Krakowski said that nearly 600,000 Taiwan citizens visited the United States last year, of whom more than 190,000 visited California. The resumption of San Francisco-Taipei nonstop flights will not only benefit such visitors, but will also help bolster cultural and economic ties between people from the two countries, he added.

Also speaking at the party, Liao called on American passengers taking the nonstop UA flights from San Francisco to Taipei for business reasons to make the most of their time in Taiwan. "Tap into Taiwan's rich tourism resources and Taiwan will touch your heart, " Liao said.

Passengers and others attending the gala party came away with great impression after obtaining brochures highlighting some of Taiwan's top tourist attractions and being treated to Taiwanese snack delicacies, including pineapple cakes and tapioca "pearl tea."

Meanwhile, according to Mark Schwab, vice president of UA's Pacific operations, the UA is delighted to resume nonstop service over the summer season when customers demand for seats to the United States is traditionally high.

The resumption of the UA nonstop Taipei-San Francisco service alsl underscores UA's ongoing commitment to the Asia Pacific region where nearly a quarter of the company's capacity is currently deployed, Schwab said.

UA will continue to offer a daily service from Taipei to Tokyo Narita, which will in turn offer smooth connections to Washington, D.C., Chicago, Seattle, Los Angeles and Honolulu, a UA Taipei spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMAN QUARANTINED AFTER CATCHING MEASLES IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese woman has been quarantined at a medicine center in southern Taiwan after being diagnosed with measles that she caught during a visit to Japan May 16-20.

According to a probe by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) into the case -- the first of imported measles infection in Taiwan this year, the woman fell ill around May 24 after returning home from the trip, which had taken her to Osaka and Kobe in western Japan.

However, the patient was not diagnosed until June 4, CDC officials said Friday, stating that the woman made eight visits to doctors from May 28-June 3, all of whom failed to make an accurate diagnosis.
So far, none of the other members of the woman's tour group, the people who live with her or her co-workers have developed symptoms, according to the CDC probe.
Taiwan began mandatory inoculation against measles in 1978. The patient missed the vaccination because she was born in 1976, CDC officials said.

Japan has been affected by a massive measles outbreak since May, with hundreds of people falling sick. Deputy CDC Director-General Lin Ting suggested that people who are planning to travel to that nation study their personal inoculation history, as the Japanese outbreak has been found mainly to have affected adults.

Lin also advised local doctors to report to the CDC any cases of patients who had visited Japan over the past few weeks developing one or more of the major measles symptoms -- fever, coughing, runny nose and conjunctivitis.
The incubation period for measles ranges from 10 days to two weeks and the disease leaves patients vulnerable to middle ear infections, pneumonia and encephalitis.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Immigrant Bill, Short 15 Votes, Stalls in Senate
The sweeping immigration overhaul endorsed by President Bush crumbled in the Senate on Thursday night, leaving the future of one of the administration's chief domestic priorities in serious doubt.
After a day of tension and fruitless maneuvering, senators rejected a Democratic call to move toward a final vote on the compromise legislation after Republicans complained that they had not been given enough opportunity to reshape the sprawling bill. Supporters of cutting off debate got only 45 of the 60 votes they needed; 50 senators opposed the cutoff.
Wall Street Journal:Western Liquor Makers Eye Rich Indian Market
Vijay Mallya calls himself the King of Good Times, and he has the credentials. The biggest maker of both whisky and beer in India, he wears gold necklaces and a diamond bracelet, surrounds himself with film stars, and holds liquor-soaked parties on his 165-foot yacht, once owned by Elizabeth Taylor.
Such behavior didn't square with the anti- alcohol ethic in India when Mr. Mallya inherited a family liquor business 24 years ago. Some states required a doctor-signed "liquor permit" to buy alcohol.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN FREE FROM WATER SHORTAGE FEARS

TEXT.P: Water supplies for the outlying island of Kinmen have been assured for the coming year, thanks to the large amount of rainfall of recent days, Kinmen water officials said Friday.
Heavy torrential rain that started Thursday evening brought large amounts of water into local reservoirs, securing water supplies for civilian use for the year ahead, the officials said.

Local reservoirs will take in more water if the rain continues, causing Kinmen residents to breathe sighs of relief, as it was feared until recently that several outlying islands, such as Penghu and Kinmen, might be hit by a drought.

According to Kinmen weathermen, 58 mm of rain had fallen over the past 24 hours. The present monsoon season fronts are expected to linger until next Wednesday, with more rain forecast for the coming days, they said, urging the public and farmers to stay on high alert over flooding.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE FAVORS CROSS-STRAIT DIRECT FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said Thursday that he is in favor of expanding direct charter flight services across the Taiwan Strait, but opposed to recognizing diplomas or degrees conferred by Chinese educational institutions.
Hsieh made the remarks while delivering a keynote speech titled "Say Yes Taiwan" at Chung Shan Medical University in the central city of Taichung.

Answering questions on a wide range of topics, he recalled that during his tenure as premier, he voiced his support for expanding direct cross-strait charter flights to avoid controversy over whether direct cross-strait routes should be defined as international or domestic.

Regarding the recognition of Chinese diplomas, Hsieh said it is a much more complicated subject, and as China has a hostile attitude toward Taiwan, he is not favor of any change in this regard in the short term. He added that if Taiwan were to acknowledge Chinese academic degrees, it could hurt Taiwan's national interests and might cause a harmful impact on Taiwan's educational system and school competition for students.
However, he added, all these issues can be resolved only through dialogue, communication and negotiation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROBE WILL NOT ERODE CHANCES OF PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: DPP HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 7 (CNA) 06/08/07 21:59:25 (By Josie Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Yu Shyi-kun, visiting chairman of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , predicted Thursday that a prosecutor's probe into the party's 2008 presidential candidate will not erode his chances of election victory.
Yu made the comments in San Francisco -- the first leg of a swing through the United States to solicit support from Taiwanese expatriates for the DPP in the presidential race.

Yu said he strongly believes in Frank Hsieh's innocence and called for unity to ensure a DPP victory in the election. Hsieh served as premier from 2005 to early 2006 and won the party's May 6 presidential primary.
"I strongly believe that Hsieh's reputation will also be cleared this time around, just like several similar cases in the past, " Yu said.
Meanwhile, Hsieh was questioned by prosecutors in Taipei over his alleged role in a case in connection to political donations he received while serving as mayor of Kaohsiung from 1998-2005.

Hsieh was questioned by prosecutors of a special investigation unit under the Supreme Prosecutors Office for the first time over monetary donations remitted to his special election bank account during the September-December period of 2002.

Speaking after a one-hour probe, Hsieh maintained his innocence and said that he is willing to be subject to the highest standards of scrutiny and that the political donations he received when campaigning for Kaohsiung mayor have so far not been used. He also denied allegations of having received bribes during his nearly two full terms as mayor from 1998-2005.

Hsieh also expressed dissatisfaction with certain media outlets, which he accused of having urged the prosecution to charge him after Ma Ying-jeou, the main opposition Kuomintang's presidential candidate, was indicted in February on embezzlement charges.

Ma was charged by Taipei prosecutors in a case related to his alleged mishandling of a special municipal monthly allowance designated for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUCRATIVE BUSINESS OPPORTUNITIES AHEAD AS POPULATION AGES: CEPD

TEXT.P: As the Taiwan population ages, the increasing number of elderly is expected to bring lucrative business opportunities, the nation's top economic policy charter said Friday.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said that as of March this year, there were 1.25 million people aged between 55 and 59 and 1.65 million aged between 50 and 54. It is estimated that 2.9 million will reach the age of compulsory retirement at 65 within a decade.
The growing number of elderly is expected to bring about lucrative business opportunities, as retired people are usually financially secure and can afford to spend money, CEPD officials said.
They said the elderly attach great importance to safe and comfortable living environments, adequate medical care and travel, and that they have become the emerging spending group in the market.
The officials added that the government's "mega investment, mega warmth" project has heeded the demands of an aging population and will promote related industries.
Medical care has been listed as an emerging industry under the project, and related sectors will include medical equipment, pharmaceuticals and health food for the elderly, they went on.

In a 10-year care program under the project, it is estimated that by 2015, the number of professional and para-professional caregivers, social workers, nurses and therapists will have reached 83,000, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE FORMER TRA WORKERS JOIN ANNIVERSARY CELEBRATION

TEXT.P: Five Japanese who worked for the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) during Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan attended a ceremony Friday to celebrate the TRA's 120th founding anniversary.
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung presented awards to TRA employees who have worked for 50 years or more at the ceremony.
Hikoichi Takahashi, one of the five Japanese former workers, said he came to Taiwan in 1939 to work for the TRA and returned to Japan before the end of World War II.
After the war, he often revisited Taiwan, Takahashi said, adding that he has witnessed the progress Taiwan has made over the years from post-war recession to today's prosperity.
The TRA workers have made a major contribution to the country's prosperity, he noted.
The Minister of Transportation and Communication Tsai Duei, for his part, said the opening of Taiwan's high speed railway this year has impacted the TRA's longer routes.
Overall, however, services have not decreased, Tsai said, although he still urged the TRA to complete its transformation soon to meet the needs of passengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL'S WORDS INDICATE BACKPEDALLING OF HONG KONG `DEMOCRACY': MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday that a Chinese official's remarks that Hong Kong's high degree of autonomy has come from the authorization of the central government indicates a "regression of Hong Kong democracy."

MAC spokesman Liu Teh-shun was referring to remarks by Wu Bangguo, chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress in a seminar on Hong Kong Basic Law in Beijing Wednesday during which he said that "the high degree of Hong Kong autonomy comes from the authorization of the central government" and is not "inherent."
How much power the special administrative region of Hong Kong gets is solely dependent on how much power the central government allows it, Wu pointed out.

Liu said that since the return of the former British colony to Chinese rule in 1997, the authoritarian nature of the Chinese regime and what he described as the democratic system in Hong Kong have run contradictory courses.

Even though China proposed that "Hong Kong people rule Hong Kong and have a high degree of autonomy, " the contradiction of "one country, two systems" is all too apparent, and the conflicts have deepened, according to Liu.

He noted that it has been a decade since Hong Kong reverted to China, but said that "the 10 years have passed in vain in terms of democracy, " adding that what democracy Hong Kong might have had has regressed.
He said the international community, including Taiwan, is willing to offer Hong Kong assistance, but added that the voice of the Hong Kong people for freedom has become weaker.
"We worry that Hong Kong residents have become accustomed to the situation after 10 years," he said.
He expressed hope that the Hong Kong people will fight for democracy and their rights, saying that "their task has yet to be completed and they have ample room for further efforts."

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGEST PASSENGER AIRCRAFT ON DISPLAY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The world's largest passenger aircraft, the Airbus A380, landed at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Friday where it will be on display for three days as part of an Airbus company world tour.

The press and local airline companies will be invited to take a tour of the double-decker superjumbo, which is scheduled to leave Taiwan June 10 and return to Airbus' headquarters in Toulouse, France.
The jet can carry 525 passengers in a three-class configuration or up to 853 passengers in a single-class economy configuration.
However, local airliners might not be interested in placing orders for the A380 because of market concerns, airline sources said.
The only possible route for the A380 in Taiwan would be Taipei-Hong Kong, the sources said.
Moreover, the superjumbo's huge passenger capacity would decrease the number of flights between the two places, which would be inconvenient for travelers, the sources continued.
In addition, there might be changes in the Taipei-Hong Kong route in the future, according to the sources, so that local carriers still need to assess the future of the market.
Airbus has received 160 confirmed orders for the A380 from 14 carriers in Singapore, Thailand, China, France, Malaysia and various other countries.
The French company will deliver the first superjumbo to Singapore Airlines in October, two years behind schedule.
The delivery problem has caused quite a few carriers to switch to Airbus' American rival, Boeing, for their orders.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT PREDICTS SOLID EXPORT GROWTH IN SECOND HALF OF 2007

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports in the second half of the year are expected to continue to register solid growth, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (MOFT) said Friday.
BOFT officials noted that exports in the first five months of this year totaled US$93.86 billion, up 6.8 percent year-on-year. Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$9.13 billion during this period.
The officials said Taiwan's exports to its major trading partners showed various degree of growth except for Brazil, which registered a modest decrease of 5.2 percent.
Taiwan recorded robust growth in exports to India, Spain, Russia, Vietnam and Mexico during the period.
Taiwan has targeted Japan, South Korea, Malaysia and Spain, as well as Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, for promoting exports in the second half of the year.
Taiwan's exports in May totaled US$19.58 billion, while imports totaled US$18.19 billion. Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$1.39 billion in May, up a whopping 95.9 percent month-on-month.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALAN PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN AS SCHEDULED
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Guatemala, June 8 (CNA) 06/08/07 23:28:56 (By Ramon Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Guatemalan President Oscar Berger Perdomo has said his country will not follow in Costa Rica's footsteps by switching diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing, describing Guatemala-Taiwan ties as being in their best shape ever.
Berger made the remarks in an interview with a Guatemalan newspaper which was published Friday.

The Guatemalan president also said in the interview that he will uphold his original schedule to visit Taiwan later this month. Berger is scheduled to depart for Taipei June 17 for a state visit during which he will sign three agreements with President Chen Shui-bian to further boost bilateral cooperation in various fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR PROTECTION OF TAIWAN TEA

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung has urged local tea farmers and tea companies not to be short-sighted by taking quality Taiwanese tea seedlings and know-how to other countries, an act that he said will be detrimental to the long-term development of Taiwan's tea industry.
Chang made the appeal Thursday at a ceremony to award Taiwan's top 10 best tea brands of this year.
He noted that the Council of Agriculture (COA) has been pushing for certification of origin labels for Taiwanese tea products to stem counterfeiting, an effort that he said deserves recognition.

In his capacity as chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), Chang said that he collaborated with the COA and the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) in winning an administrative lawsuit in China against Chinese firms which had registered four origins of renowned Taiwanese tea leaves products as trademarks.
Taiwan is a world-famous tea producer, yielding 20,000 metric tons of tea annually and generating a total output of NT$4.35 billion (US$131 million), Chang said.
Tea tasting has become an important tourism activity in Taiwan, according to Chang, who added that Taiwanese tea has the potential to be marketed around the world.
Thanks to the climate and tea-making techniques, several areas of Taiwan have developed their own unique teas, Chang went on.
The government hopes to work with local tea farmers, tea companies, and other sectors to raise the international profile of Taiwanese tea.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 9, or the 24th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1870: Charles Dickens, British writer known for his tales of Victorian life and times, dies at the age of 59. Immensely popular both then and now, his works include "The Pickwick Papers," "Oliver Twist," and "David Copperfield."
1898: The Ching court signs an agreement with Britain under which Hong Kong is leased to Britain from China for a period of 99 years.
1902: West Point graduates celebrate the 100th anniversary of their alma mater.
1916: Robert McNamara, American industrialist, is born. He was defense secretary during the Vietnam War, and president of the World Bank from 1968 to 1981.
1928: The ROC's Academia Sinica is established with Tsai Yuan-pei as its first president.
1951: The judgment of the Nuremberg court is fulfilled in the United States as the noose slips over the head of the last Nazi condemned by the Nuremberg tribunal to hang for "crimes against humanity." In all, 24 of Hitler's top men were accused on a number of different counts. Twelve men, including Nazis Hermann Goering and Joachim von Ribbentrop, were given the death penalty.
1959: The United States launches the George Washington, the first nuclear submarine with Polaris missiles.
1967: Israel seizes the Golan Heights on the fifth day of war with Syria, Egypt, and Jordan.
1973: Lt. Gen. Richard M. Hoban, vice-commander of the US Air Force Logistics Command, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: The Republic of China terminates its diplomatic relations with the Republic of the Philippines as Manila recognizes the mainland Chinese communist regime.
1982: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo praises US President Ronald Reagan's call for a campaign to promote democracy and consign communism to the "ash heap of history."
1986: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs agreed to use the name "Chinese Taipei" when participating in the women's World Cup basketball championships in Moscow in August.
1989: In mainland China, show trials of the leaders of the demonstrations in Tienanmen Square begin in Beijing.
1991: Mount Pinatubo, a volcano northwest of Manila that had been dormant for more than 600 years, erupts and forces the evacuation of US troops from their airbase nearby.
1995: ROC President Lee Teng-hui delivers a speech titled "Always in My Heart," at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: Thailand celebrates the 50th anniversary of the coronation of King Bhumibol Adulyadej.
1996: Mainland China releases dissident Ren Wanding after seven years in prison for his role in the 1989 democracy demonstrations.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew appoints Yang Chao-hsiang, former vice minister of education and current chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, to succeed Lin Ching-chiang as education minister.
1999: The Macedonian Embassy in the Republic of China is formally inaugurated in Taipei to facilitate bilateral exchanges.
2000: Republic of China Representative to Russia Chang Wen-chung confers a medal upon Oleg Lobov, head of the Moscow-Taipei Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission, in recognition of his contributions to Taipei-Moscow relations.
2001: The Board of the Zoological Park Organization of Thailand and the Republic of China's Taipei Zoo signs a memorandum to promote the exchange of animals between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you do not study poetry, you cannot make yourself agreeable in conversation. If you do not study the arts, you will lack judgment and taste."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Immigration Bill on the Ropes.
The Senate bill to revamp the nation's immigration laws stalled Thursday night after Democrats and Republicans deadlocked over how many more amendments to debate, dealing a major setback to President Bush and the unusual bipartisan team that crafted the complex legislation. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT: The Group of Eight powers agreed Friday to pledge $60 billion to fight AIDS and malaria in Africa on the final day of their annual summit.

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Trade accord with Laos signed
The Philippines and the Lao Peoples Democratic Republic signed yesterday an agreement on the promotion and protection of investments to increase bilateral trade that has remained low between the two members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).
The Philippine Daily InquirerG Pimentel holds on to 12th place
MANILA, PhilippinesXHelped by votes from Lanao del Sur and Norte, Genuine Opposition (GO) candidate Aquilino Koko Pimentel III yesterday firmed up his hold on 12th place, as the fight for the last two Senate slots pitting him against teammate Antonio Trillanes IV and the administrations Juan Miguel Zubiri headed for a nerve-wracking finish.
The Philippine StarG Senators blast JDV for reviving Cha-cha

The Manila TimesG Arrest looms for AWOL canvasser
THE Commission on Elections would order the arrest of the former chief canvasser for Maguindanao if he fails to show up at a hearing in Manila on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
POLL FINDS MOST CHINESE TOURISTS SATISFIED WITH TAIWAN VISITS

TEXT.P: An overwhelming majority of Chinese tourists have been satisfied with their visits to Taiwan, according to the results of an opinion poll released Saturday.
The survey was conducted by the Tourism Bureau as part of its efforts to upgrade travel service quality for Chinese tour groups and ensure their travel safety.

Copies of the questionnaire were distributed from last November to arriving Chinese tourists at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Kaohsiung International Airport along with a tourism publicity leaflet. As of May 18, 960 valid samples had been collected from departing Chinese tourists at the two airports -- Taiwan's two main gateways.
According to the poll results, 95.5 percent of the respondents said they were satisfied with overall services offered by their travel agencies.
Local tour guides' professional attitudes and good customer service skills received the highest approval rating of 98.1 percent, according to the survey.
Moreover, the survey found that 98 percent of the respondents were pleased with tour guides' on-the-spot explanation skills.

Up to 95.1 percent gave a thumbs-up to traffic services and arrangements, while lodging services also received a 91.5 percent approval rating and 89.8 percent said they were generally satisfied with the content of local tour packages.
In comparison, food and beverage services received the lowest rating, but the percentage of those who gave a positive assessment still accounted for 85.6 percent of the total.
The survey also found that travel costs for a seven-day, six-night tour package for Chinese tour groups ranges between NT$34,482 (US$1,046) and NT$43,096 per head.
The number of shopping stops arranged by travel agencies for Chinese tourists mostly ranged between five and six throughout their stays, according to the survey results.
Nearly 40 percent of the respondents said they felt the merchandise prices were generally higher at outlets arranged by travel agencies, while 35 percent said the prices at those outlets were fair.

Meanwhile, 72.2 percent said local tour guides usually took them to stores bearing a "secure shopping guarantee" mark, while less than 2 percent said their tour guides took them to stores bearing no such certificate.

The Tourism Bureau began to implement a new travel cost, service quality and shopping guarantee system last November after a tour bus crash Oct. 2 that year claimed six lives, including five Chinese tourists from Dalian City. Under the new regulatory system, the minimum travel cost for Chinese tour groups is set at US$80 per person per day to ensure good customer service, travel quality and safety.

In a separate survey of 508 randomly chosen Chinese tourists, conducted by the Tourism Bureau last year to explore their shopping and travel preferences, most respondents also gave good reviews of their Taiwan travel experiences. The only unpleasant thing they cited was what they described as the slowness of Taiwan's visa processing.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALAN PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN AS SCHEDULED
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Guatemala, June 8 (CNA) 06/09/07 12:43:30 (By Ramon Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Guatemalan President Oscar Berger Perdomo has said his country will not follow in Costa Rica's footsteps by switching diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing, describing Guatemala-Taiwan ties as being in their best shape ever.
Berger made the remarks in an interview with a Guatemalan newspaper which was published Friday.

The Guatemalan president also said in the interview that he will uphold his original schedule to visit Taiwan later this month. Berger is scheduled to depart for Taipei June 17 for a state visit during which he will sign three agreements with President Chen Shui-bian to further boost bilateral cooperation in various fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT PREDICTS SOLID EXPORT GROWTH IN SECOND HALF OF 2007

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports in the second half of the year are expected to continue to register solid growth, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (MOFT) said Friday.
BOFT officials noted that exports in the first five months of this year totaled US$93.86 billion, up 6.8 percent year-on-year. Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$9.13 billion during this period.
The officials said Taiwan's exports to its major trading partners showed various degree of growth except for Brazil, which registered a modest decrease of 5.2 percent.
Taiwan recorded robust growth in exports to India, Spain, Russia, Vietnam and Mexico during the period.
Taiwan has targeted Japan, South Korea, Malaysia and Spain, as well as Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, for promoting exports in the second half of the year.
Taiwan's exports in May totaled US$19.58 billion, while imports totaled US$18.19 billion. Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$1.39 billion in May, up a whopping 95.9 percent month-on-month.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL'S WORDS INDICATE BACKPEDALLING OF HONG KONG `DEMOCRACY': MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday that a Chinese official's remarks that Hong Kong's high degree of autonomy has come from the authorization of the central government indicates a "regression of Hong Kong democracy."

MAC spokesman Liu Teh-hsun was referring to remarks by Wu Bangguo, chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress in a seminar on Hong Kong Basic Law in Beijing Wednesday during which he said that "the high degree of Hong Kong autonomy comes from the authorization of the central government" and is not "inherent."
How much power the special administrative region of Hong Kong gets is solely dependent on how much power the central government allows it, Wu pointed out.

Liu said that since the return of the former British colony to Chinese rule in 1997, the authoritarian nature of the Chinese regime and what he described as the democratic system in Hong Kong have run contradictory courses.

Even though China proposed that "Hong Kong people rule Hong Kong and have a high degree of autonomy, " the contradiction of "one country, two systems" is all too apparent, and the conflicts have deepened, according to Liu.

He noted that it has been a decade since Hong Kong reverted to China, but said that "the 10 years have passed in vain in terms of democracy, " adding that what democracy Hong Kong might have had has regressed.
He said the international community, including Taiwan, is willing to offer Hong Kong assistance, but added that the voice of the Hong Kong people for freedom has become weaker.
"We worry that Hong Kong residents have become accustomed to the situation after 10 years," he said.
He expressed hope that the Hong Kong people will fight for democracy and their rights, saying that "their task has yet to be completed and they have ample room for further efforts."

DOC.HEADLINE: LUCRATIVE BUSINESS OPPORTUNITIES AHEAD AS POPULATION AGES: CEPD

TEXT.P: As the Taiwan population ages, the increasing number of elderly is expected to bring lucrative business opportunities, the nation's top economic policy charter said Friday.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said that as of March this year, there were 1.25 million people aged between 55 and 59 and 1.65 million aged between 50 and 54. It is estimated that 2.9 million will reach the age of compulsory retirement at 65 within a decade.
The growing number of elderly is expected to bring about lucrative business opportunities, as retired people are usually financially secure and can afford to spend money, CEPD officials said.
They said the elderly attach great importance to safe and comfortable living environments, adequate medical care and travel, and that they have become the emerging spending group in the market.
The officials added that the government's "mega investment, mega warmth" project has heeded the demands of an aging population and will promote related industries.
Medical care has been listed as an emerging industry under the project, and related sectors will include medical equipment, pharmaceuticals and health food for the elderly, they went on.

In a 10-year care program under the project, it is estimated that by 2015, the number of professional and para-professional caregivers, social workers, nurses and therapists will have reached 83,000, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY RAIN LEAVES THREE DEAD, FIVE INJURED

TEXT.P: Heavy rain over the past week have killed three people and injured five others around the country, according to the latest tallies released Saturday by the Cabinet's disaster response center.
All three deaths and four of the injured were victims of a landslide that occurred Friday in northern Keelung City, officials at the center said.
The other injured person was a Taoyuan County resident who was hit by falling rocks while traveling on her motorcycle early Saturday, the officials said.
They said that as the rains are now moderating, flooding in most affected areas is receding.
Damaged transportation facilities and transportation interruption as a result of the rain is expected to be restored within three days, they added.

Meanwhile, forecasters at the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said showers or thunder storms are expected around the country in the coming week owing to the lingering front, and they warned the public to beware of further downpours, lightning strikes, flooding, landslides and mudslides.
Over the past few days, central Taiwan has seen the most rainfall, they said.

From Thursday until 8 a.m. Saturday, accumulated rainfall had registered 529 mm in parts of Nantou County; up to 527 mm in Taichung County; 399 mm in Taoyuan County; and 373 mm in Miaoli County, according to the CWB.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGE-SCALE SEARCH LAUNCHED FOR GOAT-KILLING ANIMAL

TEXT.P: Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, heading a 23-member group, launched a search Saturday in a mountainous area of Linkou rural township in northern Taiwan for an unidentified animal that has been killing domestic goats there.

County police received a report the previous day from a goat farmer in Linkou saying that eight of his 100 goats had been mauled to death by "some kind of large feline" earlier that day, while two others had neck injuries.
A foreign worker who witnessed the incident claimed that she saw an animal "like a tiger, " but could not be 100 percent sure it was actually a tiger, police said.
The killing raised concerns over public safety, prompting Chou to mobilize county officials, police and veterinarians to take part in the search of the area.
County officials said they hoped to catch the animal alive and that they were equipped with a cage, tranquillizer guns, blowpipes and flashlights.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAN.-MAY TAX REVENUES HIT NT$676 BILLION: MOF

TEXT.P: Net tax revenues from January to May reached NT$676 billion (US$20.49 billion), up 11.7 percent over the same period of last year, aMinistry of Finance (MOF) official said Saturday.
MOF Statistics Department Director-General Lee Li-hsue, said the increase is equivalent to NT$70.9 billion.

Among the accumulated tax revenues, income tax showed an increase of NT$66 billion, house tax showed a boost of NT$4.8 billion, land value increment tax gained NT$3.7 billion and securities transactions tax increased NT$1.6 billion, while commodity tax decreased NT$8.8 billion compared with the same period of last year, Lee said.

Lee added that net tax revenues for May alone totalled NT$283.8 billion, an increase of NT$63.2 billion year-on-year, with income tax reaching NT$146.2 billion, up 73.8 percent from last May's figure, business income tax totalling NT$115 billion and individual income tax amounting to NT$31.2 billion.

Securities transactions tax for May was NT$8.4 billion, down 17.9 percent year- on-year, Lee said, adding that securities transactions tax for this June is expected to be higher than last June due to a more brisk stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVENTORS ATTEND INVENTION SHOW IN PITTSBURGH
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 8 (CNA) 06/09/07 16:05:53 (By Lillian Lin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese delegation of inventors from enterprises, colleges, universities and research institutes is showcasing dozens of inventions at the 23rd Invention and New Product Exposition (INPEX) taking place in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania June 6-9.

The group has set up 19 stalls at the venue, displaying innovative products and designs ranging from body-shaping underwear to tandem bikes made from recycled materials. It is the largest Taiwanese group ever to have taken part in the annual show, Chen Chung-tai, chairman of the Taiwan Inventors Association, said Saturday.

The Pittsburgh INPEX, one of the largest shows of its kind in the U.S., is being attended by inventors from 20 countries, who have brought more than 900 innovations, new product ideas and technologies to the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN `TOO COWARDLY' ON YASUKUNI SHRINE CONTROVERSY: EX-PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 9 (CNA) 06/09/07 16:56:49 (By Mike Chang, Yang Ming-chu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui accused Japan Saturday of behaving in a "too cowardly" manner in dealing with the controversy surrounding the Yasukuni Shrine.

Lee addressed the issue during a news conference held at the Foreign Correspondents Club of Japan (FCCJ) to mark the conclusion of his 11-day visit to this country. The event attracted more than 200 journalists.
Lee claimed that the controversy is a product created by China and South Korea owing to their inability to deal with their own domestic problems.

According to Lee, it is a matter of course for politicians to pay their respects "to soldiers who die fighting for their country" and it is unreasonable that Japan should be subject to criticism by foreign governments for visits to the shrine by the country's leaders for such purposes.

Pointing to his own experience, Lee noted that during his 12 years as president, he visited the Martyr's Shrine in Taipei twice a year to pay his respects to the heroes who died in a revolutionary movement against the Ching Dynasty in 1911 in China, even though the movement had nothing to do with Taiwan.

The Yasukuni Shrine is dedicated to the 2.5 million soldiers who died fighting for Japan during World War II, including more than 28,000 from Taiwan, which was under Japan's colonial rule at that time.
The reason for the controversy is that the shrine also honors executed Japanese war criminals who committed inhuman atrocities in China, Korea and many other countries in the Asia-Pacific region.
Lee visited the shrine Thursday to pay his respects to his older brother, who died fighting in the Japanese Imperial Army, and said the move had nothing to do with political or historical issues.
On Taiwan's relations with China, Lee said Taiwan is already an independent country and that it is unnecessary for Taiwan to "declare independence again."
While Beijing claims Taiwan is part of China and the United States "probably thinks so too, " the people of Taiwan are the true owners of Taiwan's sovereignty, Lee said.

He said it is uncertain when and how the cross-Taiwan Strait issue can be resolved, but added that it is very important for the people of Taiwan to stick strongly to "their belief that Taiwan is independent."
He said Taiwan must continue its democratic development and urged China to democratize its political system to grant its people a higher level of freedom.
It was Lee's third trip to Japan since his presidency ended in May 2000. However, the trip marked his first visit to Tokyo in 22 years and the first time he has made a public speech in the country.
Also during the visit, he was awarded the first Shimpei Goto Prize by the Japanese publisher Fujiwara Shoten in recognition of his contribution to Taiwan's urbanization and democratization.
Lee told the FCCJ that the visit has been the most satisfactory among all the foreign tours he has made.

He said he felt very honored to be presented the Shimpei Goto Prize, adding that Goto's contribution to Taiwan's modernization has connected himself spiritually with the late Japanese colonial administrator.

Lee expressed the hope that he will be able to visit Japan again next year or some other time to finish a half-accomplished tour that retraced a journey made by haiku poet Matsuo Basho in 1689 based on which his famous work "Oku no Hosomichi" was written.
Lee said the unique Japanese culture is something to be treasured and that he will continue to study Japanese culture based on what he learned during his trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF PREDICTS EXCESS FOR WHOLE-YEAR TAX REVENUES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance has predicted an excess in whole-year national tax revenues over the expected NT$1.56 trillion (US$47.5 billion) calculated in the central government's general budget, a ministry official said Saturday.
The official said this year's net tax revenues for the first five months reached NT$676 billion, up 11.7 percent from the same period of last year.

According to the official, there have been excesses in whole-year tax revenues every year since 2004, with the figure standing at NT$48.6 billion in 2004, NT$187.7 billion in 2005 and NT$129.5 billion in 2006, which had expected tax revenues of NT$1.43 trillion.
The official said the amount of excess will be more specific after June, but predicted that the amount will not be higher than last year's.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS PLAN TO APPLY FOR U.N. MEMBERSHIP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Saturday the country's plan to apply for full membership of the United Nations under the name "Taiwan" in September.
Chen admitted that the bid might "appear impossible" at present, but he claimed that Taiwan will "eventually" achieve the goal if it makes the first move.
Despite failure in its bid to become a full member of the World Health Organization in May, the country will continue to push forward with the bid next year, he said.
Chen made the remarks while addressing a luncheon to mark the third founding anniversary of the Love Taiwan Association in Tainan City, southern Taiwan.

After failing in its bid to participate as an observer in the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the WHO's decision-making arm -- for the past 10 years owing to China's obstruction, Taiwan applied for full WHO membership for the first time this year.
However, the bid was thwarted as the WHA adopted a motion to exclude the issue of Taiwan's membership from the agenda of its annual meeting held last month in Geneva.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE AMONG COLLEGE GRADS HIGHER THAN THOUGHT: MAGAZINE

TEXT.P: College graduates are finding it more difficult to land jobs than they had imagined and are ending up pursuing further education or preparing for civil service exams rather than entering the job market, a job information magazine reported Saturday.

Chang Sheng-yuan, editor-in-chief of Career magazine, said that according to the survey conducted by the magazine, 80 percent of the college graduates questioned said that they had difficulty landing jobs and that they put off the pressure by pursuing advanced studies at home or abroad or preparing for civil service or other professional examinations.
If this group of graduates is counted, the actual jobless rate among college graduates could be higher than the published figures, he said.

Chang said that many college graduates "look like they have jobs," but do not have full-time jobs. They often receive a monthly salary of less than NT$12,000 (US$364) because they cannot find full-time jobs, or they have to scrape by working at home on short term projects, auctioning items on the Internet or doing odd-jobs.

"Their income is not even on par with the minimum wage level of NT$15,840 (US$480) for foreign laborers," Chang said, adding that "the worsening of the job quality" among college grads is not fully reflected in the jobless rate.
The pace for "non-traditional hiring" has quickened and the number of full-time jobs is falling, Chang predicted on the employment trend for 2007 college graduates.
Chang said government statistics show that the number of hourly wage earners increased drastically to 180,000 in 2006 from 70,000 and that they received on average only NT$14,700 per month.
The number of dispatch or hourly paid jobs has increased drastically as employers try to save costs, Chang went on.
On the personnel recruited by companies, Chang said companies are in need of high-end elite and low-end laborers, and have no need for mid-level talent.

Preparatory programs to nurture future executives has extended from foreign companies to all trades, Chang said, adding that boss are hoping to establish high-quality successor teams through the rigorous screening and training programs.
He said these "para" executives often get promotion 10 or 20 years ahead of regular staff, and the time for "younger executives leading older staff" has come.
He also claimed that Taiwan youths in their 20s are part of an egotistic "me" generation who tend to think only of themselves and change jobs frequently.

They tend to have every excuse when they make mistakes and ask more from others than they are prepared to give themselves. They have no respect for their superiors and have low EQ. They are immature and have trouble getting along with others.
To cope with them, more and more companies have begun to employ aptitude tests, believing that "personality attributes" are as important as "professional ability," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL ROTARIANS TO SEND 50 TRAINED TEENS ABROAD THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Rotary International (RI) District 3520 will send 50 trained teens aged 15-19 abroad this year for cultural exchanges, a representative of the district said Saturday.

Hipo Chen, chairman of the district's Youth Exchange Program, said the students from Taipei city and county have completed their five-month training courses and will leave in August for their host countries.

Among them, Chen said, 48 students are in long-term exchange programs, with 18 heading for North America, 16 for Europe, three for Japan and 11 to Central and South America. Two others are bound for short-term exchange program, he added.
The students will stay at pre-arranged homestays and will learn language and culture at local schools. Each of them will be given a monthly allowance of US$100 during their stays abroad, Chen said.
He said nearly 200 students from Taiwan and about 8,000 from around the world are selected to join the program each year to give them an international perspective.

District 3520 arranged hosting in Taiwan for 29 exchange students from 11 countries last year, Chen said, adding that these students will return to their own countries in June and July to introduce Taiwan's culture to their homelands.
Chen said the opportunity of the Youth Exchange Program is open to all teenagers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO REVIEW PROJECT TO ENCOURAGE INVESTMENT IN LATIN AMERICA

TEXT.P: The nation's top economic planner said Saturday that she will call on Minister of Foreign Affairs James Hung to exchange views on a government project aimed at encouraging investment in Central and South America.

Ho Mei-yueh, chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , was referring to the "co-prosperity" project in the wake of Taiwan's announcement that it had severed diplomatic ties with Costa Rica Thursday after the Central American nation switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
Ho said the CEPD, which is in charge of the project, has examined related investments following the severance of ties.
She said the CEPD will have to review whether Costa Rica's role in the project is diminished or whether to increase investment in other countries in Central and South America.
"The CEPD has no preset stance and will conduct further discussions with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, " she said, adding that the council will work in tune with the country's diplomatic work.

The project was unveiled by President Chen Shui-bian in 2005 at the fifth ROC- Central America summit meeting in Managua, Nicaragua. Under the project, Taiwan earmarks US$250 million for investment in the region, with the money coming from the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) and the Executive Yuan's Development Fund.
The project is aimed at helping Taiwan businessmen invest in sectors with potential in Central and South America, with the ceiling for government investment in each investment case set at 49 percent.

But officials said promotion of the project has not been smooth, noting that so far, only Nien Hsing Textile has been approved to invest in Nicaragua in late 2006, with the Development Fund earmarking NT$900 million and the ICDF earmarking NT$450 million.
The officials said they were elated that the first investment under the project would take place, but Nien Hsing later backed out, citing concern over market development in Nicaragua.
"As of now, the co-prosperity project has not invested any of its funds," they admitted.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 1,000 HIGH SPEED TRAIN PASSENGERS GET REFUNDS

TEXT.P: Two south-bound high speed trains departed from Taipei arrived at their destinations more than 30 minutes late Saturday, and nearly 1,000 passengers received a 50 percent refund for the delay, the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) reported.

THSRC officials said that days of torrential rain have triggered warning signals when trains passed Kueishan Station in Taoyuan County, warning drivers to slow down when passing that station, as well as the Miaoli section, where slopes supporting the railway near the station had been eroded by flooding. A day earlier, 4,500 passengers received a 50 percent or full refunds due to the delays.
The officials said the Saturday train departed from Taipei at 7 a.m. and arrived at Taichung 47 minutes behind schedule. It arrived at Zuoying 44 minutes behind schedule.
Another train departed from Taipei at 7: 30 a.m. and arrived at Taichung station 31 minutes late, but made up the delay by accelerating through the following south-bound stations.
Meanwhile, the north-bound trains arrived at Banciao and Taipei between two and five minutes behind schedule, they added.
The 345-km railway linking Taipei and Kaohsiung, inaugurated in January, has reduced rail travel time between Taiwan's two largest cities to 90 minutes from the previous four-and-a-half hours.

DOC.HEADLINE: PINGTUNG UNIVERSITY KEEPING 17 TIGERS

TEXT.P: National Pingtung University of Science and Technology's wildlife center, described by officials there as "the only place" in Taiwan equipped to shelter wildlife, currently accommodates 17 tigers.
The center, set up 13 years ago, started to accept tigers abandoned by private breeders two or three years after its inauguration.
The officials said that of the 17 tigers, for which the center has created a wildlife environment, 13 came from Taipei Sea World.
They said the tigers have been at the center for a long time and are now around 17 or 18 years old, considered old for tigers.

They said that because of their age and the fact that they have become "domesticated" in view of their incarceration in circuses or parks, the center has no intention of releasing them back to the wild and that they will die in captivity.
Their remarks came amid reports that a "ferocious animal, " suspected to be a tiger, mauled several goats to death on a farm in Linkou, Taipei County a day earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA PRESSURING ROC SOUTH PACIFIC ALLIES VIA AUSTRALIA, NEW ZEALAND

TEXT.P: China is trying to pressure Taiwan's South Pacific allies into severing ties with Taipei through Australia and New Zealand, Vice President Annette Lu claimed Saturday.

Speaking at the opening of a symposium on Taiwan's ties with South Pacific states, Lu said China is trying to win Canberra and Wellington's co-operation in its diplomatic plotting against Taiwan by promising to support them to improve regional stability.

Furthermore, Lu said, Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao promised to offer US$400 million aid over three years to states in the South Pacific during a trip to the region last year in an attempt to attract states into China's fold.

The vice president also accused Beijing of luring Costa Rica to switch allegiance from Taipei to Beijing June 1, citing President Chen Shui-bian as saying that Beijing has offered US$130 million in grants in addition to US$300 million in soft loans to the Central American country.

She derided Costa Rica President Oscar Arias Sanchez, whom Lu said she had accompanied on a trip to Kinmen when he visited Taiwan in 2001, for branding Taiwan "stingy" in granting aid to its allies while explaining his government's decision to desert Taipei for Beijing.
Noting that Arias was the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1987, Lu said Arias has brought shame on himself for terminating his country's 63-year friendship with Taiwan simply for money.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUTUBE CO-FOUNDER ATTENDS INTERNET SUMMIT IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-born co-founder of the popular video sharing Web site YouTube said in a "Web 2.0" summit in Taipei Saturday that the "user first" philosophy has always been his and his company's priority.

Steve Chen said the philosophy could very well be the reason for the success of YouTube. The summit invited heavyweights in the information and communication technology (ICT) industry to discuss various topics such as Web 2.0, Web 3.0, Web services and software/hardware in the Web 2.0 phenomenon.

Chen, who was visiting Taiwan for the first time in two years, questioned the terms of Web 1.0 and Web 2.0, however, saying that while it is difficult to define Web 1.0 and Web 2.0, personalization is the real Web trend.

This, he went on, is why YouTube has always maintained a user-first mentality and why he and his other co-founder Chad Hurley decided to sell the company to Google last year -- because Google also shares the same value and is capable of providing YouTube with solid technical support.
Chen and Hurley sold the company to Google for US$1.65 billion in October 2006.
However, the 29-year-old did not lose his motivation after becoming a billionaire overnight. Chen said his motivation came from always believing in the product and always trying to improve it.
He also predicted that by the end of 2008, a lot more videos will be viewed on mobile devices and said YouTube has been working toward this direction as well.

Chen, who currently holds the position of Chief Technology Officer for YouTube, was born in Taiwan and emigrated to the U.S. with his family aged 15. He left the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign without graduating to work for online e-commerce Web site PayPal, where he met Hurley and Jawed Karim. The three founded YouTube in 2005.

In 2006, he was named by Business 2.0 magazine as one of the "the 50 people who matter now" in business. Earlier this year, he was named by Time magazine as one of the world's most influential people.

The summit participants also included Chunghwa Telecom Chairman Ho Chen Tan, Intel's Director of Marketing and Technical Services in Taiwan Stanley Huang, Google Taiwan's Head of Sales and Business Development Rebecca Kuei and Institute for Information Industry Executive Director Chen Ming-syan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER US$15 BILLION-WORTH OF ORDERS FORGED AT COMPUTEX TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2007 Computex Taipei came to the end Saturday with buyers from around the world placing orders worth at least US$15 billion in total.

According to the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), which organized the event, the fair attracted over 33,000 foreign buyers, representing 10 percent growth compared with the 2006 level.

The top 10 foreign buyers in the five-day computer exposition were the United States, Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, China, Singapore, Germany, Malaysia, India and Indonesia, according to a TAITRA assessment. The organizer also pointed out that the amount of buyers from Mexico, Russia, Brazil, Japan and the United Arab Emirates represented the largest growth, with buyers from Mexico doubling and those from Russia surging 70 percent in comparison with the 2006 level.

To expand the annual event in an effort to further boost trading, Deputy TAITRA Secretary-General Yeh Ming-shuei said the 2008 Computex Taipei will take place not only at the World Trade Center but also at the new large exhibition hall in Nankang, which is capable of housing 2,600 stalls.
The planned 2008 event is scheduled to open June 3-7, with TAITRA expecting even more foreign buyers than this year, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT BLASTS CHINA'S SUPPRESSION OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lambasted Beijing's constant suppression of Taiwan Saturday by means of its military threat and diplomatic schemes and reiterated that Taiwan will not "act as a rich fathead, " while China buys Costa Rica's diplomatic recognition for US$430 million.

Chen said in Tainan City, southern Taiwan that Beijing has never given up the idea of annexing Taiwan by force and noted that China deployed 200 missiles targeting Taiwan in 2000, increasing the number to 988 by 2007.

On the diplomatic front, Chen went on, China has not ceased its efforts to carry out its "clearing out" policy aimed at shutting Taiwan out of the international community by buying off Taiwan's diplomatic allies and destroying all Taiwan's bargaining chips for reciprocal negotiations.

Over the past 11 years, Taiwan has not stopped making efforts to join the World Health Organization (WHO), but is still rejected from WHO activities, even as an observer, due to China's opposition, Chen said.

Furthermore, he added, during the SARS outbreak of 2003, Chinese officials even asked publicly "who cares about you? " in response to Taiwan's request for international assistance in stemming the outbreak.

Speaking of Costa Rica's recent switching of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, the president said China has spent a lot to "buy" diplomatic relations, but claimed that Taiwan would never want to buy friendship even it had the money to do so.

New York Times: Chairman of Joint Chiefs Will Not Be Reappointed
The Bush administration said Friday that it would not reappoint Gen. Peter Pace to a second term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, making him the highest-ranking officer to be a political casualty of the fight over Iraq.
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said the decision was reached in order to avoid bitter hearings in a Democratic-controlled Senate that is already confronting the White House over the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.
Wall Street Journal:Economists See Housing Slump Enduring Longer
Economists are giving up on the idea that the U.S. housing slump will be quick and relatively painless.
Instead, more are concluding, the downturn that began nearly two years ago will last at least through the end of 2007, remaining a major drag on the U.S. economy. The culprits: a glut of homes for sale and growing caution among lenders who now regret being so free with their mortgages during the boom.

DOC.TEXT: The TimesG Airline drives up price of holidays Foreign summer holidays are about to get much more expensive after British Airways raised its fuel surcharge for the second time in six weeks despite opposition from passenger groups. Other airlines are expected to follow with their own price rises, even though the price of oil fell more than 3 per cent yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT RETURNS FROM TRIP TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui returned to Taipei after an 11-day trip to Japan Saturday.
He was greeted at the Taiwan Taoyuan International airport by a group of his supporters, as well as lawmakers of the Taiwan Solidarity Union of which Lee is the spiritual leader.

At the airport, Lee defended his decision to accept the Shinpei Goto Prize in Tokyo on June 1, saying that Shinpei Goto in whose honor the prize was set up has contributed a lot to Taiwan during his term as the chief of the civil administration of Japanese colonial government in Taiwan between 1898 and 1906, adding that he considers Goto one of his spiritual mentors.

"Historians will pass judgment on my decision." Lee said in response to journalists requests for his comment on local critics' claims that it was inappropriate for a former head of the state to accept a prize named after a former colonist ruler of his country.

As to his visit to the controversial Yasukuni shrine in Tokyo, which was considered by many as a symbol of Japan's militarist past, to mourn his late brother who died fighting in the Japanese navy in 1945 when Taiwan was Tokyo's colony, Lee said it is his private business and the public should not consider it from historical or political perspective.

As he was attacked by a Chinese traveler at the Tokyo airport before he boarded an airplane for Taiwan earlier that day, police at the Taoyuan airport was put on high alert and began checking every tour bus arriving at the airport to prevent possible protesters from gathering before his arrival.
