DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE ARCHITECT DELIVERS CHARITY SPEECH IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Japanese architect Tadao Ando, who has long been regarded as one of the greatest living architects in the world, delivered a charity speech on architecture in front of an audience of more than 11,000 Saturday in Taipei.

Ando talked about achieving the harmonious balance between human and architecture, architecture and environment, and the social responsibility of architects in the two-hour speech and forum at Taipei Arena. All the proceeds of the speech will be donated to various charities in Taiwan.

Highlighting the idea of "One Asia, " the 66 years-old architect said modern day architects should pay more attention to environmental protection as environmental issues such as global warming has become a serious concern of all mankind.
"Asia, as a whole, is a unity. While the majority of 6.6 billion global population live in Asia, we have to take the responsibility [to protect the environment], " he said.
Ando underlined the importance of forestation and planting more trees in cities a number of times during his speech and pointed out that more people will visit Taiwan if it decided to do so.

What surprised Ando was his popularity in Taiwan, which has been described as the "Ando fever, " as more than 30,000 people had registered for tickets. Architects, designers, students and professors of Architecture departments, even political heavyweights such as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin were all in attendance.
An audience of 2,300 when he had his first speech in Taiwan in 2004 was already impressive, Ando said, adding that the number of attendance he had in Japan was 2,000 at best.
Born in Osaka, Japan, in 1941, Ando has worked as a truck driver and professional boxer prior to launching his architectural career. He has never received formal school education in architecture.

Ando was well-known for his habitual use of fair-faced concrete in most of his works, his ability to develop a unique spatial aesthetic with the combination of Japanese tradition and Modernism elements, and his special way of creating space with concrete, wood, water and lighting.
In 1995, Ando won the prestigious Pritzker Architecture Prize, which is generally considered to be the equivalent of the Nobel Prize in architecture.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 10, or the 25th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Nikolaus August Otto, the German inventor of the four-stroke internal combustion engine, is born.
1836: Andre-Marie Ampere, the French physicist and mathematician, is born. He formulated Ampere's law, a mathematical description of the magnetic field produced by a current-carrying conductor.
1900: More than 2,000 troops from eight nations -- Britain, Germany, Russia, France, the United States, Japan, Italy and Austria, crush the Boxer Rebellion, killing some 300 boxers at Langfang near Beijing.
1922: American singer and actress Judy Garland is born as Frances Gumm. She starred in such films as "Meet Me in St. Louis," "A Star is Born," as well as "The Wizard of Oz," in which she sang "Somewhere Over the Rainbow," winning an Academy Award for her performance.
1939: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, summons Chou En-lai and Yeh Chien-ying to admonish communist forces to keep their promise to obey orders.
1940: Italy declares war on France and Britain.
1945: U.S. marines invade the Japanese Ryukyu islands, completing their occupation of the islands on June 21.
1947: The Republic of China protests to the Soviet Union against the Soviet invasion of Sinkiang Province in northwestern China.
1967: Israel wins a decisive victory in the Six-Day War against its Arab neighbors and expands its territory by 200 percent.
1971: The United States formally ends its 20-year-old embargo on trade with mainland China.
1972: Chang Feng-hsu assumes office as the new mayor of Taipei, succeeding Henry Kao.
1975: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo, addressing the Kuomintang, pledges to carry out Dr. Sun Yat-sen's Three Principles of the People and the late President Chiang Kai-shek's anti-communist policy.
1976: Lin Yang-kang, commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Reconstruction Department, is appointed mayor of Taipei City by the Executive Yuan.
1980: The Ninth Sino-American Conference on Mainland China opens at the International Hall of the Civic Aeronautic Administration in Taipei with 109 Chinese and American scholars and experts participating.
1982: ROC Premier Sun Yun-suan says that there is no "Taiwan issue," only the "China issue," which relates to whether there is to be a "strong and hostile communist China or a peace-loving non-communist China."
1985: Dr. Chen Hung-ping, 48, a native of Heilungkiang in northern mainland China, defects at the ROC's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport after attending an international academic meeting.
1989: Direct telephone links are opened between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
1992: A revised copyright law goes into effect in the ROC, providing explicit legal protection for intellectual property rights and imposing heavier penalties for copyright infringements.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui meets with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski and reaffirms the ROC's determination to substantiate various exchange and cooperation programs with Macedonia.
2000: The 2000 Taipei International Dragon Boat Race kicks off at Tachia Park, located alongside the Keelung River, with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presiding over the opening ceremony.
2001: The Chinese version of "President Inside the Tiger's Mouth," a new book by the Japanese historian and novelist Fuyuko Kamisaka, has been released in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men by nature are alike; but in practice, they are widely different. It is only men of the highest understanding and men of the grossest dullness who do not change."

DOC.HEADLINE: HAKKA DIALECT BECOMES INCREASINGLY POPULAR

TEXT.P: Learning to speak the Hakka dialect and gaining a better understanding of Hakka culture have become increasingly popular in Taiwan in recent years, Taiwan's top official in charge of Hakka affairs said Sunday.

Lee Yung-teh, chairman of the Council for Hakka Affairs, said both ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou passed a Hakka language proficiency test, beginner's level, during the past two years, demonstrating that not just non-Hakka natives, but politicians have also become increasingly enthusiastic about learning the Hakka dialect, Lee said.

Lee made his remarks at the National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences, southern Taiwan, where he oversaw the 2007 nationwide Hakka language proficiency test. The one-day test was being held simultaneously in all major cities and counties island-wide Sunday.
Commenting on the annual language test, Lee said he feels overwhelming that the number of people attending this year's test increased by some 2,600 people over last year's 5,000.

Meanwhile, he said, the number of test-sitters under 40 years of age increased by 51 percent over last year's level, indicating that the council's efforts to promote Hakka language and culture, particularly among the younger generations, have begun to bear fruit.

Most of the 2007 Hakka language proficiency test takers were civil servants, teachers and students. In addition to Hakka native speakers and Hakka offspring, many non-Hakka people, and even a few foreign nationals, took part in Sunday's test.

According to Lee, only 11.6 percent of Hakka children under the age of 13 could speak their mother tongue in 2002, but in 2004 the percentage rose to 13.8 percent, thanks to the establishment of the Council of Hakka Affairs and the launch of a TV channel that uses Hakka exclusively.
The council has been trying to prevent the Hakka culture and dialect from further waning while also helping enrich the country's cultural diversity, Lee added.

He quoted the results of a demographic census as indicating that the number of people identifying themselves as Hakka natives stood at around 3.8 million in Taiwan in 2004, but that this number increased noticeably to 4.41 million in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP PUSHES FOR 'PEACEFUL INDEPENDENCE','DEMOCRATIC UNIFICATION'

TEXT.P: A group of political activists advocated "peaceful independence" and "democratic unification" Sunday as "concrete" means to secure peace across the Taiwan Strait.

Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan Chief Executive Chien Hsi-chieh said the people of Taiwan should seek to free themselves from the shackles of the political domination of the "pan-green" camp, led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and the opposition "pan-blue" alliance, led by the Kuomintang.

Noting that civic society should not be consumed by "binary confrontation, " Chien said the "pan-greens" and the "pan-blues" have for long monopolized the discourse on issues of unification and independence, and continue to widen the gulf between the camps through their discourse.

Chien said that in order to gain the upper hand in their political struggles, the "pan-green" and the "pan-blue" politicians have ceaselessly manipulated issues concerning ethnic and communal group differences.

He said hopes of cross-strait peace lie not in the balance of military might, nor in the calculation of diplomatic victory or defeat, but in the two sides' ability to communicate and secure societal cooperation.

Chien said that although Taiwan has a preliminary self-defense capability, the country should strengthen its non-military national defense, or civilian-based defense, and educate the Taiwan citizens to resist invaders by means of non- cooperation and civil disobedience rather than armed struggle. Doing so, he said, would allow the peaceful people of Taiwan to more easily gain the support of the international community.
Chien made the remarks at a news conference held in advance of a forum on "Democratic and Peaceful Cross-Taiwan Strait Relations" that the foundation will sponsor later this month.

Also speaking at the news conference, Hsu Si-chien, an assistant researcher with Academia Sinica's Institute of Politics, said that political provocation intended to elicit a harsh response from the other camp is a"cheap aphrodisiac" politicians use to drum up support.

If the pursuit of unification would cause cross-strait or regional conflict, Hsu said, such kind of "unification" would be undesirable; likewise, if pursuit of independence would compromise or harm democratic principles, such kind of "independence" would also be undesirable.

Against this backdrop, Hsu said, the timing to advocate pursuit of democratic unification and peaceful independence would mature when the strife between "pan- greens" and "pan-blues" get ever more intense.

Fan Yun, an assistant professor in sociology with National Taiwan University, said that peace and democracy could form the greatest possible common ground for both Taiwan's major political camps, adding that advocacy of "peaceful independence" and "democratic unification" should form the basis of new guidelines for the administration, worked out from the perspective of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADVOCACY GROUP PROTESTS HIGH COLLEGE TUITION FEES

TEXT.P: An advocacy group staged a protest at the Ministry of Education (MOE) Sunday against the high cost of university education, calling for no tuition hikes in the coming academic year.

Nearly 30 students belonging to the Coalition Against High Tuition in Taiwan protested in front of the MOE headquarters to condemn the increasing commercialization of education, arguing that "education is by no means a commodity" and "tuition fees should not be adjusted in accordance with consumer price index."
The demonstrators condemned a number of colleges and universities in the country for taking special funding from the Education Ministry on one hand while orchestrating fee hikes on the other.
They were referring to 23 universities which have received funding under a five- year, NT$50 billion-dollar higher education subsidy program and a teaching excellence subsidy program.

They chanted slogans and waved posters and banners calling for the government to address the problem of the rising cost of education by levying a tax on corporate dividends and establishing a special educational fund to help the underprivileged.

Responding to the demonstrators' appeal, MOE officials said that the consumer price index, which has seen an average yearly growth of 3 percent, certainly should not be the only figure on which tuition fee hikes are based, and that all school fee hike plans are subject to the ministry's final approval.

Meanwhile, officials said that interest rates for student loans will be further lowered this upcoming academic year, falling 0.35 percent, and those students applying for loans under NT$500,000 to finish their college educations may also ask for an extension of the loan period.

On the demonstrators' suggestion that the government tax private corporations on their dividends, MOE officials said this involves the design and operations of the nation's taxation system and it is not an issue under the control of the Ministry of Education.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO WAIT AND SEE ON DPP PROPOSAL FOR EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: Following a news report that the "pan-green camp" may propose an extra session after the current legislative session adjourns Friday, the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Sunday that the party will take a wait-and-see attitude for the time being.
Kuo Su-chun, a KMT lawmaker and legislative caucus whip, made the comments while answering reporters' questions on the issue.

According to Kuo, the KMT has not even yet started discussing the issue given that the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , should first submit a proposal and gain sufficient support to make a motion if they really hope to hold an extra meeting in late July to address the 2007 central government budget bill.

Before that happens, lawmakers of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) will temporarily hold off addressing the issue, Kuo said, adding that most of the KMT and PFP lawmakers are opposed to holding an extra session next month.

Arguing that the DPP and the TSU lawmakers must not pass the buck for the delayed passage of the annual budget, she said that the "pan-green" lawmakers' boycott of the passage of the draft Central Election Commission (CEC) Organic Law was the major reason behind gridlock in the legislature and the dealy in the passage of the budget bill.
Kuo also said she suspected that the DPP's plan to call for an extra legislative meetings was politically motivated as the legislative and presidential elections are approaching.
Meanwhile, Tseng Tsahn-deng, the TSU's legislative caucus whip, said that his party is supportive of the DPP's idea of holding an extra session in July to deal with the annual budget bill.

Tseng also urged the KMT and the PFP to respond positively to the idea so as to allow the legislature to quickly deal with the annual budget bill, that has been stonewalled for more than seven months.
"Pan-green" and "pan-blue" lawmakers have repeatedly clashed over the 2007 central government budget bill and the draft CEC Organic Law during every legislative sessions in recent months.

The "pan-green camp" accused the "pan-blue alliance" of ignoring the people's livelihoods by deliberately putting off the budget bill's passage in order to push the "pan-greens" to compromise over the passage of the KMT-PFP version of the CEC Organic Law.

On the other side, "pan-blue" lawmakers criticized their "pan-green" peers for insisting on the approval of the DPP-version of the CEC Organic Law, which they characterized as an attempt to influence the coming legislative and presidential polls.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOTAL FERTILITY RATE DROPS BY 60% IN 30 YEARS: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has seen its total fertility rate (TFR) drop by over 60 percent over the last 30 years, as its TFR dwindled from 3.4 children in 1975 to 1.4 in 2005, according to the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

Taiwan's 60.2 percent fall in TFR -- the average number of babies born to women during their reproductive years from 15-49 -- was greater than the world's average 40.7 percent decline during the same 1975-2005 period, from 4.5 to 2.7 children, the DGBAS reported.
In Asia, South Korea registered the largest decrease in TFR, at 71 percent, followed by Hong Kong at 67.5 percent and China at 65 percent, the DGBAS said.
TFR is the single most important factor in determining future population, experts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE CONCERNED OVER LACK OF CHINA LINKS

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, the presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), Sunday voiced his concern over the lack of direct shipping links between Taiwan and China, saying that the development of Taiwan's two key ports will be hobbled if the links are not quickly put in place.
Ma made the comments during a visit to Taipei Port in Taipei County, accompanied by Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei and KMT lawmaker Wu Yu-sheng.

Expressing his deep concern that the development of the Taipei and Kaohsiung ports will be affected markedly should Taiwan fail to open direct maritime links, in particular cargo services, with China, Ma said he is worried that as much as US$100 billion in cross-Taiwan Strait trade will be targeted by other competitors.

According to Ma, Kaohsiung Port has been lagging behind Singapore, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Shenzhen and Busan in recent years, in terms of the cargo handling volumes. Kaohsiung Port, once ranking among the world's top five container ports, has seen its competitiveness rapidly decline due to the lack of direct cross-strait transport links, he said.

Ma promised to break the present cross-Taiwan Strait gridlock and develop Taipei Port in accordance with the blueprint drawn up by the KMT when it was in power before May 2000 and make both Taipei and Kaohsiung ports world-class maritime hubs if he is elected president.

In response to Ma's inquiries, Taipei County officials in charge of managing Taipei Port acknowledged that cargo volumes handled by the port have noticeably dwindled since China's Fujian Province banned gravel exports to Taiwan. Gravel was one of the prime cross-strait transshipment items handled by the Taipei facility.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM SET TO TAP OVERSEAS MARKET: CEO

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Telecom Co. (CTC) will actively tap overseas markets, with serving overseas Taiwanese business people as its main target, the chief executive officer of the partially government-controlled company said Sunday.
CTC Chairman Hochen Tan made the remarks while briefing the media on the findings of his recent overseas market inspection tour that took him to the United States and Sweden.

During his visit in Sweden, Hochen attended a Taiwan-Swedish economic cooperation conference and toured TeliaSonera AB -- the dominant telephone company and mobile network operator in Sweden and Finland and is also active in other countries in Northern and Eastern Europe.

Hochen said he was impressed by TeliaSonera's productivity and competitiveness. The company's work force only outnumbers Chunghwa's by 10 percent, but its annual turnover reaches US$12 billion, an amount that doubles Chunghwa's annual sales, he added.
Noting that TeliaSonera's revenues primarily come from its overseas operations, Hochen said Taiwan's telecommunications service providers should step up exploration of overseas markets.

As Taiwan's largest telephone and mobile network operator, Chunghwa Telecom will take the lead in tapping overseas markets, Hochen said, adding that the company will first focus on exploring markets that have a large concentration of Taiwanese business people.

Given the fact that telecommunication service subscribers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait have similar consumer culture and habits, Hochen said Chunghwa Telecom intends to cooperate with smaller-sized Chinese telecommunications operators or added value service providers to tap the flourishing Chinese market.

As the government still imposes many restrictions on investing in China, Hochen said, Chunghwa Telecom will consult with the Mainland Affairs Council -- Taiwan's top China policy planning agency -- and other relevant government institutions before launching its overseas expansion drive.
Anyway, Hochen said, Chunghwa Telecom will follow legal procedures in tapping the Chinese market.

And Vietnam will be Chunghwa Telecom's another priority target, Hochen said, adding that Vietnam has enjoyed robust economic growth in recent years and that many Taiwan companies have set up footholds there.

As Vietnam's telecommunication infrastructure and management are relatively backward, Hochen said Chunghwa Telecom stands a good chance of tapping into that market and that the company will focus on investing in telecommunication infrastructure construction in Vietnam's large industrial zones.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER NT$29 BILLION SEIZED IN CLAMPDOWN DRIVE ON CORRUPTION: MOJ

TEXT.P: Prosecutor's offices across the country indicted over 9,800 suspects allegedly involved in 3,808 corruption cases during a clampdown between July 2000 and April 2007, seizing over NT$29.1 billion in illegal funds, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) reported Sunday.

Of the 9,889 people indicted during the seven-year period, 3,612 people were convicted, and a total of more than NT$29.14 billion in illegally acquired funds were seized by prosecutors and investigators during the same period, MOJ officials said.
According to MOJ tallies, those indicted included 544 ranking government officials and 591 elected public office holders at various levels.
MOJ officials said the MOJ's efforts to reduce corruption over the past seven years have been effective.

The number of alleged corruption cases received by prosecutors since the anti- corruption campaign was launched July 2000, down 27.11 percent compared with the September 1993-June 2000 period, while the number of indictments fell from 4,029 to 3,808, the officials elaborated.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Microsoft Finds Legal Defender in Justice Dept.
Nearly a decade after the government began its landmark effort to break up Microsoft, the Bush administration has sharply changed course by repeatedly defending the company both in the United States and abroad against accusations of anticompetitive conduct, including the recent rejection of a complaint by Google.
The retrenchment reflects a substantially different view of antitrust policy, as well as a recognition of major changes in the marketplace. The battlefront among technology companies has shifted from computer desktop software, a category that Microsoft dominates, to Internet search and Web-based software programs that allow users to bypass products made by Microsoft, the world's largest software maker

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC PONDERS APPEAL FOR TELECOM OPERATORS TO INVEST IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is mulling over calls for local telecommunication service providers to invest in the booming Chinese market, a senior official said Sunday.

The official made the remarks after Chunghwa Telecom Co. (CTC) Chairman Hochen Tan said earlier in the day that the partially government-controlled company plans to actively explore overseas markets, with areas that have a large concentration of Taiwanese business people as its priority targets.

As China and Vietnam enjoy robust economic growth in recent years and both have a large number of Taiwan-invested companies, Hochen said Chunghwa Telecom will focus on taping those two markets in the initial stage.

Hochen further said that Chunghwa Telecom hopes to cooperate with China's smaller-sized Chinese telecommunication companies or added value telecommunication service operators in developing the Chinese market.
In response, the MAC official said the MAC, the country's top China policy planning agency, is still evaluating the feasibility of such a new opening measure.

Under current regulations, telecommunication service providers are banned from investing in China. Local operators have filed petitions to the MAC, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and other relevant government agencies in the hope of an early lifting of the ban.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC REBUTS CRITICISM ABOUT DELAY IN TAIPEI HARBOR DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Construction of Taipei Harbor, formerly known as Tamsui Harbor, has not been delayed, Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) officials said Sunday.

The officials made the remarks after main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou slammed the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration for what he called snail's-paced construction of Taipei Harbor, which began in 1993 when the KMT was still in power.

According to Ma, the DPP has failed to complete construction of certain expressways linking Taipei Harbor to major cities or neighboring districts. The expressway construction delay has prompted private investors in a container storage center at the harbor under a build-operate-transfer (BOT) contract to ask for NT$4.3 billion in compensation.

Ma said three shipping companies -- Evergreen, Yang Ming and Wanhai -- have signed the BOT contract with the MOTC for the container warehousing project under which seven wharves will be built at the Taipei Harbor.
In terms of the contract, Ma said, the government has to build Pali-Wuku expressway to facilitate Taipei Harbor's traffic services. However, the highway project has lagged far behind the schedule.

In response, Hsiao Ting-hsun, director of the Keelung Harbor Bureau, said the MOTC has not delayed in building the expressway. The budget for the project was not passed until August 2004. Construction began in September that year and is scheduled to be completed late next year.

He also denied that the three shipping companies have asked for a NT$4.3 billion compensation. Acutally, he said, the three firms asked for NT$347 million in damage award. The harbor bureau is still negotiating with the three firms.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC PONDERS APPEAL FOR TELECOM OPERATORS TO INVEST IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is mulling over calls for local telecommunication service providers to invest in the booming Chinese market, a senior official said Sunday.

The official made the remarks after Chunghwa Telecom Co. (CTC) Chairman Hochen Tan said earlier in the day that the partially government-controlled company plans to actively explore overseas markets, with areas that have a large concentration of Taiwanese business people as its priority targets.

As China and Vietnam enjoy robust economic growth in recent years and both have a large number of Taiwan-invested companies, Hochen said Chunghwa Telecom will focus on taping those two markets in the initial stage.

Hochen further said that Chunghwa Telecom hopes to cooperate with China's smaller-sized Chinese telecommunication companies or added value telecommunication service operators in developing the Chinese market.
In response, the MAC official said the MAC, the country's top China policy planning agency, is still evaluating the feasibility of such a new opening measure.

Under current regulations, telecommunication service providers are banned from investing in China. Local operators have filed petitions to the MAC, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and other relevant government agencies in the hope of an early lifting of the ban.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 11, or the 26th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1864: Richard Strauss, German composer, is born. He is known chiefly for his symphonic poems, such as "Don Quixote," and his operas, including "Salome."
1880: Jeannette Rankin, American reformer, pacifist, and politician, is born. A leader in the women's suffrage movement in Montana, she later was elected as a U.S. House of Representatives and was the only legislator to oppose American involvement in both world wars.
1922: Li Yuan-hung resumes the presidency following the resignation of Hsu Shih-chang as president of the Peking government.
1940: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini declares war on the Allies.
1955: Twenty-two years of Liberal rule ends in Canada with the federal election victory of the Progressive Conservatives, headed by John G. Diefenbaker.
1963: Buddhist monk Quang Duc sets fire to himself in Saigon to protest the South Vietnamese government's treatment of Buddhists.
1968: The National Taiwan University Hospital announces that its first kidney transplant operation, performed on May 27, was successful.
1969: Soviet and communist Chinese troops clash on the Sinkiang border.
1972: Chen Ta-ching assumes the office of defense minister of the Republic of China.
1974: The opening ceremony of the 20th Asian Film Festival is held in Taipei and is presided over by Fredrick F. Chien, director-general of the Government Information Office. Nearly 400 performers, directors and producers attend the festival.
1976: China Airlines signs a US$86.4 million loan agreement with an international banking syndicate led by Citibank for the purchase of one Boeing 747SP, one 747, and three 737s.
1979: John Wayne, veteran Hollywood star, dies at the age of 72. Known as "Duke," the American actor played tough heroes in cowboy movies such as "Stagecoach," "Red River" and "True Grit," winning an Academy Award for his role in the latter.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo promulgates an order to resume in December the election of additional central parliamentarians, suspended Dec. 16, 1978 when the United States announced the severance of diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.
1981: A strong earthquake rocks Iran, killing more than 1,000 people and destroying the town of Golbaf in Kerman province.
1983: Zhu Jianhua, an athlete from mainland China, breaks the men's high jump record by clearing 2.37 meters.
1989: Michael Chang, 17, an ethnic Chinese American, beats Stefan Edberg of Sweden and becomes the youngest-ever winner of the French Open tennis championships.
1993: President Lee Teng-hui receives former Philippine President Corazon Aquino.
1995: International Business Machines of the United States purchases and merges with the Lotus corporation after investing US$3.52 billion.
1999: The United States, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and the European Union sign a new, multilateral joint statement on semiconductors designed to ensure fair and open global trading in the chips industry.
1999: The Chinese-Taipei taekwondo team returns to Taipei from the 1999 World Taekwondo Championships in Canada with two gold and four bronze medals.
2000: Officials from 30 Asian-Pacific cities reach an agreement at "the 2000 Asia-Pacific Cultural Summit" in Taipei to establish a mechanism for the promotion of cultural exchanges.
2000: An earthquake measuring 6.7 on the open-ended Richter scale hits the central Taiwan county of Nantou, injuring 16 people.
2004: The Legislative Yuan passes amendments to the Labor Standard Law to allow laborers to open portable pension account.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you are considerate to others, you will win the hearts of the people. If you are trustworthy, men will trust you. If you are diligent, you will be successful in your undertakings. If you are generous, you will find plenty of men who are willing to serve you."

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGHWAY CONSTRUCTION IN COSTA RICA WILL CONTINUE: TAIWAN BUILDER
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Costa Rica, June 10 (CNA) 06/11/07 12:48:36 (By Ramon Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The construction of a highway in Costa Rica that was initiated with aid from Taiwan in 2005 will continue in accordance with related contracts despite the severance of diplomatic ties between the two countries, the highway builder said Sunday.

Chang Chih-kang, an official of Taiwan-based Ret-Ser Engineering Corp. who is heading the project, said that unless Taipei issues new directives, Ret-Ser will continue to carry out the contracts to finish the building of the Carretera Naranjo-San Carlos Highway -- a 29.73-km highway slated to be completed by April 2010 with a price tag of US$61 million.
Chang said that if Ret-Ser were to renege on the contracts by halting construction, all related bank deposits held as guarantees would be confiscated by Costa Rican government.

Under two cooperative contracts, covering the use of bank loans and funds that Taiwan promised to give to Costa Rica, signed by the Taiwan and Costa Rican governments in 2004, Ret-Ser began building the highway in October 2005, according to Chang.

As of last week, Chang said, the construction work was 28.5 percent completed, adding that the original scheduled date for completion had earlier been put off from Oct. 27, 2009 to April 12, 2010 due to weather factors.

Taiwan's Vice Foreign Minister Chang Siao-yue said June 7, one day after Costa Rica switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, that Taiwan will not at present consider establishing any other liaison office in Costa Rica and that it has decided to cease all cooperation projects between the two countries.

Responding to the vice foreign minister's announcement, Taiwanese expatriates in Costa Rica have since urged the government to open a representative office in Costa Rica's capital, San Jose, out of concerns that their interests might be affected because of the termination of the 63-year-old diplomatic partnership between the two countries.

The expatriates, including Taiwanese business people and students, urged the government to at least set up an economic and cultural office in San Jose to take charge of consular and document verification affairs.

Meanwhile, according to a report in the local weekly El Financiero on Sunday, Costa Rican Minister of Foreign Trade Marco Vinicio Ruiz said that bilateral trade between Costa Rica and Taiwan will not be affected by the severance of diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Costa Rica will continue to ship products to Taiwan, and all investors from Taiwan will be protected by Costa Rican laws, Luiz was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE SPOUSES NEED TO PRODUCE CLEAN BILLS OF HEALTH FROM SEPT. 1

TEXT.P: All Chinese spouses of Taiwan citizens who apply to make their first-ever "reunion visit" to Taiwan will have to produce a clean bill of health from Sept. 1, a National Immigration Agency (NIA) official said Monday.

According to the official, the Department of Health (DOH) has decided to impose the new requirement after a Chinese spouse who had come to Taiwan for a "reunion visit" was diagnosed as having tuberculosis (TB).

At present, Chinese spouses applying to make short-term "reunion visits" need not present a clean bill of health. The TB-infected Chinese spouse living in eastern Taiwan didn't develop symptoms until some time after her arrival in Taiwan, the official said.

Under current regulations, only Chinese citizens who apply to stay in Taiwan as a dependent of their local spouses are required to present a clean bill of health. Presently, Chinese spouses have to wait for two years to qualify for applying to stay in Taiwan as a dependent.

As Chinese spouses make an average of more than 13,000 "reunion visits" to Taiwan annually, the NIA official said, the government needs to formulate a new "health threshold" to plug any possible holes in the country's epidemic prevention network.

Starting Sept. 1, Chinese spouses intending to make their first "reunion visit" to Taiwan have to produce a clean bill of health issued by a state-run hospital, legally licensed private hospital or university-affiliated hospital and certified by an officially designated Chinese notary agency.

The clean bill of health must also be certified by Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation to prove the document's validity, the NIA official said, adding that the NIA will not begin to process Chinese spouses' entry applications until after all those health-related documents are available.
The health checkups must include screening for AIDS, rubella, TB, prevalent intestinal parasites and leprosy, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
CABINET FIRM ON REQUESTING RECONSIDERATION OF AMENDMENTS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Monday that the Executive Yuan stands on the side of farmers and fisherman in requesting that the opposition-controlled legislature reconsider amendments governing farmers' and fishermen's associations that it passed early last month.
The premier made the remarks one day before the Legislative Yuan is scheduled to vote again on the amendments to the Farmers' Association Law and Fisherman Assoiciation Law that it passed May 11.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, Chang said the country's farmers and fishermen are not a part of "black gold" politics, and instead are "the pride of Taiwan, " adding that the Executive Yuan decided to formally request the reconsideration May 30 in an effort to protect the rights and interests of farmers and fisherman.

The amendments would abolish the three-term limit for secretaries general of the associations and guarantee that any association staff standing trial would not be removed from their post until they are convicted in the final verdict in their case. Currently, indicted association staff members are discharged if they are convicted in a second trial.
According to the Constitution, the Executive Yuan has the right to request that the legislature reconsider a passed bill if it deems the passed bill too difficult to execute.
Meanwhile, over 1,000 farmers and fishermen from around the island gathered at the Legislative Yuan headquarters Monday to condemn the ruling DPP for treating them as "second-class" citizens.
They claimed that the request for reconsideration of the amendments was nothing more than "mudslinging" and political maneuvering ahead of the next presidential and legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC OPENS TRAVEL CLINIC TO PROVIDE HEALTH CARE CONSULTANCY

TEXT.P: A travel health center under the Center for Disease Control (CDC) was inaugurated Monday to provide health care counseling services for people preparing to travel to countries suffering from epidemics.

Deputy CDC Director-General Lin Ting explained that the new facility is transformed from the CDC's international inoculation stations, which were use to give vaccinations to people traveling to countries with epidemic diseases such as malaria, yellow fever and rabies.

Unlike the old inoculation stations, Lin said, the travel health center is manned by physicians who can give travelers health care advice, prescriptions and vaccinations or prophylactics, or examine travelers suffering from unidentified illness that they might have caught overseas.

People in Taiwan, including foreign travelers, are welcome to use the new facility, based at the CDC's Taipei headquarters, Lin said, noting that the CDC is also working with hospitals run by the Department of Health in Taichung, Hualien, and Kaohsiung to offer outpatient services to travelers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PRODUCTS WIN 15 GOLD MEDALS AT INVENTION SHOW
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 10 (CNA) 06/11/07 16:34:29 (By Lillian Lin and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese products won 15 gold medals at the Invention and New Product Exposition (INPEX) in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Taiwan Inventors Association Chairman Chen Chug-tai said Sunday.
Chen said Taiwanese products also won 18 silver medals, 10 bronzes and five special awards at the June 6-9 INPEX.
The exhibition, the largest invention trade fair in the United States, has entered its 23rd year and was attended this year by exhibitors from more than 20 countries occupying 275 booths.

Taiwan's delegation from enterprises, colleges, universities and research institutes operated 19 stalls at the show and registered a total of 144 competitions for its 27 original inventions, Chen said, adding that one product can be entered in many different categories.
Products that won gold medals included body-shaping underwear, a multifunctional folding chair, solar street lights and a fire extinguisher, Chen said.
Chen said Taiwanese inventors participate in the INPEX every year and have an excellent record for winning awards.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VOWS TO PUSH FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORT LINKS REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus vowed Monday to push for a nationwide referendum on the issue of opening direct cross-Taiwan Strait transportation links.
The legislators expressed the hope that a cross-strait direct transportation links referendum can be held in tandem with the presidential election slated to take place next year.

KMT legislative caucus whip Hsu Shao-ping claimed that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration has led Taiwan nowhere in terms of economic development and diplomatic achievement since it took power seven years ago.
Taiwan will fall even lower should the DPP be allowed to continue to rule the country based only on ideology, Hsu claimed.

Hsu added that the KMT believes opening direct cross-strait transport links is pragmatic and conducive to Taiwan's economic development, prompting the main opposition party to push for a national referendum on the issue.

KMT Legislator Ting Shou-chung said opening the links would undoubtedly benefit Taiwan's domestic economy, adding that the DPP is sticking its head in the sand by opposing the passage of an amendment to a statute to pave the way for direct links, while being unable to rev up the flagging domestic economy.

KMT Legislator Wu Yu-sheng said the KMT is not aiming at entering a "referendum race" with the DPP by putting forth the cross-strait links referendum plan to challenge a referendum plan on retrieving the KMT's ill-gotten assets proposed by the DPP.
Wu claimed that the Taiwan people are able enough to decide in referendums whether they prefer economic progress to "political word games."

KMT Legislator Lo Shih-hsiung noted that Kaohsiung Harbor's container handling capacity ranked third in the world when the KMT was running the country, but has fallen to sixth since Taiwan has been in the hands of the DPP.

He lamented that an amendment to a free trade harbor zone bill proposed by him to pave the way for China-originating semi-finished products to be processed in Taiwan's free trade harbor zones for re-export was boycotted by DPP lawmakers.

Also commenting on the KMT's intention to push for a cross-strait links referendum, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng -- formerly a KMT vice chairman -- said the KMT and the DPP have equal rights to push for the implementation of referendums on major issues concerning the people's rights and welfare, so long as they can muster enough signatures to pass the threshold of requirement for a referendum to take place.
Wang added, however, that a final decision on the opening of direct transport links would be a matter for the governments on the two sides of the strait and would require meetings and negotiations.
Meanwhile, Wang Hsin-nan, a whip of the ruling DPP legislative caucus, told the KMT not to "fool the Taiwan people" by playing with a referendum plan.

According to Wang, the DPP administration could announce in 24 hours Taiwan's opening of direct links with China without holding a nationwide referendum should the KMT and the Taiwan people accept the notion defined by Beijing that Taiwan-China air and shipping links are part of China's domestic routes and that Taiwan is part of the territory of the People's Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL LOSSES CAUSED BY HEAVY RAIN SURPASS US$3.2 MILLION

TEXT.P: Constant heavy rain that started last week around the country under the influence of a lingering monsoon frontal system has resulted in agricultural losses of over NT$106 million (US$3.2 million) , according to statistics released Monday by the Council of Agriculture (COA).

Miaoli County registered the heaviest losses at NT$43 million, followed by Changhua County at NT$32 million, with Hsinchu County losing NT$10 million and Yunlin County hit by losses worth more than NT$8 million, the tallies show.

The Central Disaster Emergency Operation Center (CDEOC) reported that from Sunday midnight to 7 a.m., Wanluan rural township of Pingtung County in southern Taiwan, received 59 mm of rainfall, the most recorded anywhere in the country for the seven-hour period. Taliao in Kaohsiung County, Nanchou in Pingtung County, Pingtung City and Tungshan in Yilan County had rainfall ranging between 53.5 mm and 22.5 mm during the period.

As the frontal system was still hovering over Taiwan, further heavy rain was expected Monday and the CDEOC warned people living in mountainous areas of sudden downpours and lightning strikes, as well as falling rocks and mudslides.
According to the National Police Agency, heavy rain had caused three deaths and six injuries since June 4, with 10 sections of provincial, county and city roads seriously damaged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PROVIDE ETHANOL GASOLINE AT ALL GAS STATIONS BY 2011

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. L. Chen said Monday that his ministry will push for government vehicles in Taipei to use E3 ethanol gasoline on a trial basis from September.

Chen said the ministry has asked the state-controlled oil company CPC to select several gas stations in Taipei to provide E3 ethanol gasoline -- gasoline to which 3 percent bioethanol has been added. It is expected that all gas stations will provide ethanol gasoline from 2011.

He also said that Taiwan has a large number of motorcycles, but noted that motorcycle engines are unfit for ethanol gasoline. The ministry is also studying incentives to encourage private motorists to use ethanol gasoline.

He said that since the Kyoto Protocol went into effect in February 2005, all nations have faced mounting pressure to cut greenhouse gas emissions. Although Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations, it will follow the international norm as a member of the global village, he added.
Chen said the government is planning to have renewable energy-power electricity generation capacity of around 5.13 billion watts by 2010 and 8 billion watts in the longer term.
The development of renewable energy in the short term will focus on wind power, solar power, geothermal power and bioenergy, and will focus on hydrogen energy and fuel cells in the long term.
He estimated that the production value of Taiwan's green energy industry will reach US$20 billion by 2015.
Chen made the remarks in a special report on Taiwan's industrial development and renewable energy resources at a monthly meeting at the Presidential Office
