DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS SUPPORT EXECUTIVE YUAN'S RECONSIDERATION REQUEST

TEXT.P: If corrupt staff members of farmers' and fishermen's associations are allowed to stay in their posts until they are convicted in a final verdict, the banking institutes run by those associations would be ruined by them and taxpayers would be forced to carry the can, Legislator Wang Tu-fa of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed Monday.

Flanked by his friends Charles Chiang and Wu Ming-ming, also DPP lawmakers, Wang told a news conference that more than 13 staff of the country's farmers' and fishermen's associations who are involved in criminal cases have been convicted, although final verdicts have not yet been delivered.

Noting that most of them are charged with cutting corners in extending association loans to their cronies, Wang said the longer these people remain in their posts, the more irreversible the damage they will cause to the associations.

Wang claimed that the ratio of bad loans of these associations' baking sections stood at 14.53 percent in 2000 when the DPP came to power. It was down to 7.6 percent as of last month after the DPP administration used NT$50 billion (US$1.51 billion) to bail out unliquidated banking sections of these associations over the last seven years.
The government's efforts to help these groups regain their health will be undermined unless corrupt personnel are fired when they are found guilty at their second trials, Wang claimed.

The three lawmakers urged the public to support the Executive Yuan's request for a legislative reconsideration of an amendment to the law governing the farmers' and fishermen's association, which was enacted in May to allow staff to stay in their posts unless convicted in the final trial.

The request was opposed by the opposition in the legislature and the leaders of the associations, who claimed that these organizations are private groups and that the restriction to be done away with by the amendment is tougher than a similar restriction imposed on government officials, as government officials cannot be removed before they are found guilty in their last trial.
The legislature is set to vote Tuesday on the Executive Yuan's request.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HAS FAITH IN CANDIDATE, NO PLAN TO REVISE PARTY CHARTER: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has every confidence in the integrity of its presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, and there is no plan to revise the party charter, DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung said Monday.

Lin was responding to reports that Hsieh's presidential candidacy might be in jeopardy if he is indicted over several high-profile corruption allegations during his 1998-2005 stint as Kaohsiung mayor.
The trio of cases -- in connection with the MRT system in Kaohsiung, political donations and his mayoral "special allowance fund" -- are being investigated by prosecutors.

Hsieh had said earlier that if he is indicted over the "special allowance fund" for his discretionary use, he will quit the presidential race, but he dismissed Sunday the idea of pulling out of the race if he is indicted over the political donation case.
Lin noted that Hsieh had explained his part in the cases at a meeting of the DPP's Central Standing Committee, and said the DPP members believe he is innocent.

The DPP charter states that if a member is indicted for alleged illicit gains or illicit profiteering, an integrity committee will suggest that a central advisory committee punish the indicted member by suspending his or her party rights at the minimum.
Lin said he believes in Hsieh's integrity and that the party will proceed "according to the its charter,"
He urged respect for the judicial procedure and the party system, adding that "the party has no question of discussing the revision now."

Meanwhile, DPP Legislator Wang Tuoh, a major whip of the legislative caucus, said the party's Central Advisory Committee will have the final say, noting that the committee has acted "consistently and rigorously in the past." First lady Wu Shu-jen and Ma Yung-cheng, former deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, had their membership rights suspended one-and-a-half years after their indictment late last year.
DPP Legislator Yeh Yi-jin also said the party will not revise the charter for a specific person, as that would "make it as decadent" as the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

The KMT recently revised its charter to bar only those who are found guilty in the third trial, instead of the original first trial, from representing the party in presidential elections, with the express purpose of allowing its presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou off the hook. Ma has been indicted in February over his alleged misuse of his "special allowance fund" during his mayoral term.

However, DPP Legislator Cheng Yun-peng said it would be better to revise the party charter before an indictment takes place, as he claimed that doing otherwise would "give the impression that the revision has been tailored for a specific person."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 38.17 points to close at 8,338.88.

The bourse opened at 8,351.03 and fluctuated between 8,328.61 and 8,359.75 during the day's trading. A total of 4.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$133.91 billion (US$4.05 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 1 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.5 percent, plastic and chemicals shares at 0.4 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.3 percent.
Textile stocks dropped 0.9 percent, while construction issues and banking and financial shares remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 674 to 463, with 208 shares remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: WILD DOGS IDENTIFIED AS GOAT KILLERS IN LINKUO

TEXT.P: Wild dogs were identified Monday as the killers of goats in Linkuo, a township in the northern county of Taipei, after a dog was caught in a trap cage early this morning, while two others fled when spotted mauling goats.

In the morning attack, 14 goats were killed and four others injured, calculated their owner, who lost eight goats Friday when his farm was first invaded by "some kind of large beast, " which was earlier thought to be a tiger.

The county government soon then launched efforts to hunt down the creature killing goats out of concerns for public safety, including the installation of three large trap cages at the Linkuo goat farm.

Tsai Chung-yi, a county official responsible for animal disease control, said it is almost certain that the mid-sized wild dogs were the culprits behind the attacks after catching one of them on the spot. But he added that a double check of the killers' tracks left at the scene is still needed to close the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: NIA TO ISSUE IC ALIEN RESIDENT CERTIFICATE STARTING JULY

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency (NIA) will replace paper alien resident certificates (ARCs) with electronic cards embedded with advanced anti-forgery microchips in two stages beginning July 1, NIA officials said Monday.
The officials said the move will be congruent with world trends, noting that it will contribute to the nation's anti-terrorist and anti-forgery efforts.

Officials also announced the format of the photos for the new cards, which will be the same as the newly replaced IDs for local citizens, with the face of the person covering between 70 percent and 80 percent of a photo taken within the last six months.

The officials said that during the first stage, from July 1 through Dec. 31, it will only issue new ARCs with integrated circuit (IC) chips to new applicants and those who apply to replace older, lost ARCs.

The approach is in line with international practices and will avoid having lost certificates forged or used by others, the officials said, adding that it is estimated that 120,000 new electronic alien resident cards will be issued during this stage.
In the second phase, from Jan. 1 to Dec. 31, 2008, the official went on, all existing ARC holders will be notified to exchange their old paper cards for the new electronic ones.

The official said the new ARC measures will also apply to the more than 330,000 international blue-collar workers employed by local manufacturing and construction companies and caregivers working for families with members in need of long-term care.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW GIO CHIEF ASSUMES OFFICE, VOWS TO INFUSE `NEW THINKING'

TEXT.P: New Government Information Office (GIO) Minister and Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Monday that he will perform his two new jobs according to different codes of conduct in order to fulfill his double duties successfully.

As the Executive Yuan spokesman, Shieh said, he will precisely convey the government's stances on various policy initiatives and issues of national concern; while in playing the role of GIO minister, Shieh went on, he will infuse the agency with new thinking and new idea, as the acronym GIO also stands for "Great Idea Office."

Shieh, who just ended a two-year stint as the country's representative to Germany, made the remarks at a changeover ceremony in which he took his new official seals from acting GIO Minister William J. Yih, who will continue to serve as GIO deputy minister.

A German literature professor-turned-official, Shieh has always been known for his quick wit and sense of humor. His 17-minute speech at the changeover ceremony was full of "pearls of wisdom and sparkling sayings, " drawing incessant laughter from those present at the ceremony.

Shieh said he will treat his new job as a challenge that can bring new opportunities and changes. As a novice to GIO work, Shieh said he will need the support and assistance of all GIO staff. "We need teamwork to fulfill our duties and I'll wholeheartedly appreciate your help," he said.
Noting the President Chen Shui-bian's administration is entering its final year, Shieh said that although there has been criticism of the administration, he still sees hope and sunshine ahead.
His two years of experience as Taiwan's representative to Germany also allowed him to see what role Taiwan can play on the world stage, Shieh said confidently.

"What I have been doing in Germany over the past two years is to introduce things-related to Taiwan to Germans. As the GIO head, I would have to sell Taiwan to all countries around the world. I need good ideas to accomplish my duties," he added.
For him, he said, the "ROC" of the Republic of China can also stand for "republic of confidence. "I hope all of our people will remain confident in our country's future," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved up 37 points to close at 8,313, with 23,889 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for July increased 35 points to finish at 8,264, with 1,265 contracts traded, while September futures gained 36 points to end at 8,121, on 204 contract transactions. December futures increased 32 points to close at 8,124, with five contracts traded. March futures decreased two points to close at 8,114, with four contracts changing hands.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 8,276 for June, 8,229 for July, 8,085 for September, 8.092 for December, and 8,116 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

June TE futures moved up 1.8 points to finish at 361, with 1,916 contracts traded, while July TE futures gained 2.7 points to close at 358.9, with 74 contract transactions. September TE futures increased 1.45 points to close at 352.6, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December or March.

June TF futures gained 0.4 points to end the day at 957.4, with 2,031 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures lost 0.8 points to close at 956.2, with 118 contracts traded. September TF futures moved down 1.2 points to finish at 951.6, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for December or March.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE EFFICIENT IN CRACKING DOWN ON HUMAN TRAFFICKING: MOI

TEXT.P: Anti-human trafficking police have done commendable jobs over the past few months in cracking down on human smuggling rings, Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang said Monday.

Following a China Times daily report earlier that day that Taiwan has been on a global human trafficking blacklist since the beginning of this year, Lee said law enforcement agencies, including the National Police Administration, have cracked down on 80 human trafficking cases involving 626 "snakeheads" or smugglers, ring operators and illegal brokers in the first five months of this year.
The figure represents a 16-fold increase over the figure posted for the same period of 2006, Lee said, describing the China Times report as "groundless."

In a written statement, Lee said the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has maintained coordination operations with local governments of the 24 cities and counties around the country with regard to anti-human trafficking efforts.
So far, 11 victims from outside Taiwan have been given temporary accommodation in shelters operated by private organizations with the assistance of local governments, Lee said.
Meanwhile, he added, a total of 1,585 foreign workers who have fallen victim to illegal labor brokers have been put up at 13 foreign laborers' halfway homes around the country.

Lee said the MOI has been overseeing the implementation of 52 measures to prevent human trafficking, track down traffickers and protect victims since Nov. 8, 2006, when the administration announced a supra-ministerial anti-human trafficking plan.

He added that in its 2007 global human trafficking report released in January, the U.S. State Department also confirmed that the Taiwan authorities have made some progress in efforts to crack down on human trafficking.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Fixing D.C.'s Schools Reform's Checkered History; Worn Down by Waves of Change; Bureaucracy, Politics Beat Back Succession of Superintendents and Plans.
When a board appointed by Congress seized control of the D.C. public schools in 1996, its members were eager to give the school system a clean break from its troubled past. They fired Superintendent Franklin L. Smith, replaced him with a war hero, retired Army Lt. Gen. Julius W. Becton Jr., and urged Becton not to bother debriefing Smith.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:U.S. Arming Sunnis in Iraq to Battle Old Qaeda Allies
With the four-month-old increase in American troops showing only modest success in curbing insurgent attacks, American commanders are turning to another strategy that they acknowledge is fraught with risk: arming Sunni Arab groups that have promised to fight militants linked with Al Qaeda who have been their allies in the past.
American commanders say they have successfully tested the strategy in Anbar Province west of Baghdad and have held talks with Sunni groups in at least four areas of central and north-central Iraq where the insurgency has been strong.
Wall Street Journal:Horseshoe Crabs In Political Pinch Over Bird's Future
On the high tides of spring, horseshoe crabs crawl out of the water to go about the business of making more horseshoe crabs. The crab has been at this for three or four hundred million years, a record of tenacity that accounts for its pet name: the cockroach of the sea.
From the crab perspective, the best beaches on earth ring Delaware Bay, where a bird called the red knot also takes a spring break during its world-record migration, a 9,300-mile tour to the arctic from the southern tip of South America. The crabs lay trillions of pebbly, fat-filled eggs. The birds peck a few billion out of the sand, then go on their way.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, rising NT$0.019 to close at NT$33.009.
A total of US$617 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.970 and fluctuated between NT$32.900 and NT$33.037.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY DELEGATION VISITING U.S.

TEXT.P: A delegation led by Kaohsiung City Councilor Speaker Chuang Chi-wang and Deputy Mayor Chiu Tai-san is visiting its sister city of Portland, Oregon for city-to- city exchanges, according to a press release issued by the city government Monday.
The statement added that a band and honor guard of Kaohsiung City's Shute Home Economics and Commercial High School is visiting along with the 30-member delegation that includes 16 city councilors.

The delegation attended the centennial celebration of Portland's Rose Festival Sunday in which Chuang, Lee Fu-peng, chairman of the school, and Chang Chi-wei, former chairman of the Portland-Kaohsiung Sister City Association, were honored as Rose Barons for their contributions in promoting exchanges between the two cities.
The school band and honor guard performed in the festival parade and will give another performance June 11.

According to the statement, the itinerary of the delegation also includes a visit to Portland Mayor Tom Potter and presiding over opening and closing ceremonies of the festival's dragon boat races, to be held on the Willamette River.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE OUTFIELDER LATEST IN LINE SIGNED BY U.S. MAJOR LEAGUE TEAMS

TEXT.P: The U.S. Major League baseball team, the Boston Red Sox, has signed 19 years-old Taiwanese outfielder Lin Che-hsuan to a minor league contract, the team announced at a press conference Monday.

"From now on it will be another new chapter in my life and a new level on the field, " said Lin, who graduated from Nan Ying Vocational High School of Business and Technology last week. Lin also said he hopes to make the major league in four years.

"We wish him well. We think he is a very special player, " Boston Red Sox's Coordinator of Pacific Rim Scouting Jon Deeble said, adding that Lin has "four pluses as a runner, a defender, a thrower and playing with great range."
Lin has all the tools to succeed, Deeble said, "but it's important not to push him too hard."

Taiwanese-born Lin will be the fourth Taiwanese player to play in the current Red Sox farm system, following in the footsteps of pitcher Lin Wang-yi and outfielders Huang Chih-hsiang and Chiang Chih-hsien.

The signing bonus was not disclosed but was estimated at around US$400,000, making it one of the highest signing bonuses for a Taiwanese baseball player in recent years, according to staff of Bros Sports, Lin's sports agency.

The highest signing bonus on record for a Taiwanese baseball player is pitcher Tsao Chin-huei's US$ 2.2 million, while the record bonus for a positional player is current La New Bears player Chen Chin-feng's US$680,000.
Lin is expected to depart for the U.S. on June 15 or 16 and begin his training with the Gulf Coast Red Sox rookie league team.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG COUNTY FORGES SISTER-CITY RELATIONS WITH DUZCE OF TURKEY

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsin and visiting Duzce Mayor Mehmet Keles from Turkey signed a memorandum of understanding Monday on the establishment of sister-city relations between the southern Taiwan county and Duzce City.

Addressing the signing ceremony, Mehmet said the sister-city ties will facilitate the efforts of two sides to boost mutual exchanges in the fields of municipal management, trade, technology, tourism, culture and education.
The memorandum makes Kaohsiung County the second Taiwanese municipality, following Tainan city, to forge sister-city ties with a Turkish city.

Duzce, located in northwest Turkey near the Black Sea, is the capital of the Duzce Province, and home to nearly 200,000 people. The city will become Kaohsiung county's eighth sister city as soon as the memorandum is passed at the county council and certified by the Minister of the Interior.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRMS URGED TO BUILD BRANDS AMID FALLING ICT EXPORTS

TEXT.P: The government should help local information and communications technology (ICT) companies develop their own brands as part of efforts to deal with declining exports of Taiwan's ICT products, local scholars said Monday.

The scholars made the appeal after the Ministry of Finance (MOF) recently released statistics showing that Taiwan's ICT exports have reported a negative growth for the 11th consecutive month as of May, despite an increase in overall exports.
Although the negative growth in ICT exports has become a long-term trend, the impact has been limited because ICT exports account for a very small proportion of Taiwan's total exports, they said.
This negative growth will not be a problem if total exports continue to rise, the experts said.
ICT exports in May decreased by 15.1 percent over the same period last year, generating a total value of US$707 million, according to statistics.
At the same time, total ICT exports during the first five months of this year also showed a year-on-year decrease of 15.1 percent, or US$4.058 billion in total value, statistics indicate.
Since last July, negative growth in Taiwan's ICT exports has become the norm due to the relocation of local ICT companies, MOF officials said.
Double-digit loses have been repeatedly reported in ICT exports during the past few months, the officials said, adding that last November showed a drop of 22 percent.
Kung Ming-hsin, deputy director of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said that this negative growth is not a short-term phenomenon as the problem began to emerge in 2004.
There were periods of positive growth since then, probably due to the strong exports of cell phone products, according to Kung, however, ICT exports started a regular slide in 2006.
Although the negative growth has become a long-term trend, Kung noted it has had a limited impact on total exports as ICT exports accounted for a small percentage -- 3.6 percent -- of May exports.
Electronic product export makes up a large part of Taiwan's total exports, Kung explained.

Hsu Song-ken, professor of industrial economics at Tamkang University, said that from a short-term perspective, the ups and downs in the exports of ICT products were due to business cycles and launches of new ICT products.
The relocation of local companies also contributed to the negative growth, Hsu went on.
Noting that the production of desktop computers has moved to China, Hsu urged the government to take proactive measures to deal with the economic fallout.
However, he also noted that if the government wants companies to develop stronger brands, it should think about how to achieve that goal as local production capabilities continue to move overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY WARNS AGAINST CATCHING TAIWAN BLUE MAGPIE

TEXT.P: The public should not catch Taiwan Blue Magpie, a bird native to Taiwan that has been listed as a protected species, or face possible prison terms or heavy fines, officials from the Taipei city government warned Monday.
The remarks came after the city's Department of Economic Development received reports of people hunting these birds.

Taiwan Blue Magpie has been voted as the leading contender in an online campaign aimed at selecting Taiwan's national bird, the officials said, who went on to describe the birds as "the official bird of the capital city."
The birds are not endangered, and can be spotted on several mountains in Taipei, but their numbers will decrease if their habitats are damaged, the officials went on.

Catching such birds violates the Wildlife Conservation Act, the officials said, and violators could face a sentence of six months to five years, or fines of between NT$200,000 (US$6,042) and NT$1 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT STUDENTS FAVOR SAME COMMERCIAL ADVOCATES

TEXT.P: A recent survey showed Taiwanese pop singers Jolin Tsai and Jay Chou are the most favorite commercial advocates for college students in both Taiwan and China, a spokesman for the Pilot Group said Monday.

The spokesman said that the survey, conducted by the Pilot Group, also showed that television and Internet advertisements, and television programs are the three top channels of commercial information for Taiwanese students, while television, Internet and magazine advertisements are the most common sources of commercial information for Chinese students.

The group issued questionnaires to about 1,900 students of 28 Taiwanese and 18 Chinese colleges to survey consumer cognition and behavior, soliciting 977 valid samples from Taiwanese students and 911 from Chinese students, the spokesman said.

The survey showed 30 percent of the recipients are willing to buy brand name products, however, Taiwanese students would spend only 17 percent of their living expenses, while Chinese students would spend 30 percent on buying brand name products.
In addition, 93.8 percent of Taiwanese students and 90.7 percent of Chinese students showed an inclination to travel.
Chinese students proved to be more enthusiastic about financial investments than Taiwanese students, by a margin of 14 to 8.4 percent.

Additionally, the survey showed that 22.4 percent of Taiwanese students said they would undergo plastic surgery to perfect their appearances, while 90 percent of Chinese students were opposed to the idea, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER VICE PREMIER RESPECTS CANDIDATE'S DECISION ON RUNNING MATE

TEXT.P: Former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan said Monday that she will respect the will of Frank Hsieh, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's presidential candidate, in choosing his running mate.

Yeh made the remarks one day after saying that if Hsieh taps her as the running mate, she would "embrace it gladly." Some have interpreted her statement, after having been tight-lipped for some time in response to reports she would join Hsieh on the ballot, as a sign that a Hsieh-Yeh ticket is now certain despite earlier reports that President Chen Shui-bian had wanted Hsieh to team up with former Premier Su Tseng-chang to boost the DPP's chances of winning the 2008 presidential election.

Yeh, who is a Hakka, explained Monday that her words came "in response to" the expectations of the Hakka, the second largest ethnic group in Taiwan after the Hoklo, as well as those of the nation's women.
She stressed that "all will have to respect the decision of Hsieh."
Meanwhile, DPP legislator, Wang Tuoh, said Monday that the tradition of the party is to respect the decision of the presidential candidate in choosing his running mate.
If Hsieh, who has said that there is no hurry to announce his running mate, chooses Yeh, the party will throw its weight behind the Hsieh-Yeh ticket, he said.
Another DPP legislator, Cheng Yun-peng, said that every potential running mate has the merits, and that the choice was best left to Hsieh himself.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST CLUSTER OF SAPOVIRUS INFECTION IN TAIWAN REPORTED

TEXT.P: The Center for Disease Control (CDC) reported the first cluster of Sapovirus infection in Taiwan, with 55 faculty members of a college in northern Taiwan being infected with the disease.

Sapoviruses are caliciviruses which, together with the noroviruses, are the leading causes of acute viral gastroenteritis in humans. The virus is named after Sapporo, Japan where the virus was first recognized during an outbreak at an orphanage. It generally causes only mild gastroenteritis in young children.

CDC officials said that the virus is hard to diagnose, and that the center only became capable of testing for the virus after cooperating last year with Japan's National Epidemiological Surveillance of Infectious Diseases to co-develop the means to do so.
The officials said that they are not ruling out the possibility that others might have been infected with the virus at an earlier date, but that such an outbreak went unrecognized.

Officials said they were notified by the Department of Health of the Taipei County Government in May that a cluster of 55 people had shown the symptoms of nausea, vomiting and diarrhea, and that the possibility of food poisoning had been initially ruled out.

Fecal specimens from eight infected people were sent to a laboratory for a series of tests that presented negative results to the initial battery of tests. The samples were then retested using the recently developed test for Sapovirus and seven of the eight showed a positive result.

Officials said that the virus is often transmitted through feces and oral contact, and that the cases often arise in nurseries and kindergartens in foreign countries, but it is rare in colleges and university.

Currently, there is little research on Sapovirus, and the prevalence rate is unclear, officials said, urging the public to wash their hands, and maintain a healthy diet and personal hygiene to stave off the virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL LOSSES FROM HEAVY RAINFALL HIT NT$160 MILLION

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses from days of heavy rainfall in most part of the country had reached NT$160 million (US$4.85 million) as of 4 p.m. Monday, according to statistics released by the Council of Agriculture (COA).

Miaoli County in northern Taiwan and the central county of Changhua took the brunt of the devastation, incurring NT$41 million and more than NT$20 million in agricultural losses, respectively, COA officials said.

They added that watermelon crops were the worst hit, while persimmons, Chufeng grapes, leafy vegetables, spring onions, fragrant melon, cabbage, winter melon and many other crops had also suffered water damage.

According to the officials, the situation is serious enough to merit compensation for Miaoli County's watermelon and fragrant melon farmers. Neighboring Hsinchu County also reported some NT$20 million in agricultural losses.
Other areas affected included Taoyuan County, Taichung County and Yulin County to a lesser degree.
Heavy downpours also disrupted transportation services around the country over the past week as flights and train service were canceled or delayed because of landslides and block roads.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE TO DEPART FOR JAPAN VISIT JUNE 19

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has named former Premier Frank Hsieh to head a delegation to attend the late Japanese lawmaker Motoo Shiina's funeral, a Presidential Office news release said Monday.

According to the press statement, Hsieh, who is also the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) candidate for the 2008 presidential election, will depart for Tokyo June 19 to attend Shiina's memorial service scheduled for June 20.

Shiina was a prominent member of the House of Councilors -- the upper house of Japan's Diet. He was very friendly toward Taiwan. Hsieh, who has doctoral degree in law from Kyoto University, will read an eulogy in remembrance of Shiina at his funeral on behalf of President Chen.

Hsieh told an international news conference earlier in the day that if he is elected Taiwan's next president, he will push Japan to legislate a law patterned after the United States' Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) to regulate its engagement with Taiwan.
"Through such a legislation, the substantive Taipei-Tokyo ties will be upgraded to a level based on the rule of law," Hsieh said.

Since Japan switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972, Taiwan and Japan have maintained unofficial ties. Without the support of a legal act, Hsieh said, bilateral exchanges have been restricted to a lower level.

As Taiwan and Japan share common strategic interests in maintaining regional security and stability, Hsieh said Japan needs to legislate a TRA-like law to allow for higher-level exchanges with Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Hsieh said he is scheduled to visit the U.S. in July as part of his campaign tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA DAYBOOK FOR JUNE 12, 2007

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE VISITS INDIA, SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou departed Taipei Monday for a five-day, two-leg visit that will take him to India and Singapore.

Ma said prior to his departure that the visit is aimed at promoting international exchanges. Noting that both India and Singapore are important players in the international community, Ma said if he wins the next presidency, he will not ignore them in his diplomatic agenda.

"While India boasts a large software talent pool and robust economic strength, Singapore also plays an important role in the global trade and regional politics. We cannot afford to overlook them in our diplomatic work, " Ma explained, adding that the Democratic Progressive Party administration has regrettably failed to do more in forging closer ties with the two Asian neighbors.

During his stay in India, Ma will visit India's information technology industry strongholds and meet with India's ruling Congress Party leader Dr. Karan Singh and Rajnath Singh, chairman of the largest opposition Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP).

Ma's Singapore itinerary will include inspection tour of the city state's harbor bureau and study of its casino management as well as meeting with Singaporean political heavyweights, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN RETURNS TO TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong returned to Taipei Tuesday after a weeks-long vacation trip to the United States.

Soong said at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport that the main purpose of his return is to get a better understanding of the current state of negotiations for closer cooperation between the PFP and its "pan-blue alliance" partner -- the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

According to Soong, the two parties will continue to cooperate in the coming legislative election and in screening of major bills in the Legislative Yuan. The two parties jointly hold a slim majority in the legislature.

As the next legislative election will adopt a new "single-member constituency, two ballots" electoral system and the number of legislative seats to be up for grabs will be halved to 113 seats, the two "pan-blue" parties have been working hard to mend differences in candidate nominations for certain constituencies.
Soong was greeted at airport by KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yi and senior PFP officials, including Legislative Yuan Vice President Chung Jung-chi.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 12, or the 27th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1809: Pope Pius VII, originally Barnaba Gregorio Chiaramonti, who was forced to crown Napoleon Bonaparte emperor in 1804, excommunicates him.
1924: George Bush, the 41st president of the United States, is born. Before becoming president, the Republican politician served as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations and China, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and vice president under Ronald Reagan.
1929: Anne Frank, the Dutch Jewish schoolgirl and wartime diarist, is born in Germany. In hiding from the Nazis, she wrote her famous diary before being taken to her death in a German concentration camp in March 1945 at the age of 16.
1938: China's Yellow River ruptures a dike, killing some 150,000 people.
1944: Chinese communist leader Mao Zedong announces that he will support Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1947: Chinese troops recapture Peitashan in Sinkiang Province from Mongolian troops which are aided by the Soviet Union in their invasion of the northwestern province of China.
1964: South Africa's Nelson Mandela and seven others are sentenced to life imprisonment.
1973: China Airlines inaugurates night flight services between the Taiwan cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
1976: Juan Maria Bordaberry, president of Uruguay, is overthrown and replaced by Alberto Demichelli.
1978: A strong earthquake rocks Miyagi prefecture in Japan, killing 38 people and injuring more than 1,000 others.
1978: Kuo Mojo, a Chinese communist writer, dies in Beijing at the age of 86.
1979: American Bryan Allen pedals his way across the English Channel in a human- powered aircraft to win a US$185,000 prize.
1979: Mohammed Ali Khoguir, charge d'affaires of the Saudi Arabian Embassy in the Republic of China, presents US$100,000 to National Chung Hsing University to establish a graduate school of Arabic.
1980: Tsiang Yen-si, secretary-general of the Kuomintang, cables condolences to Yasuhiro Nakasone, secretary-general of the Japanese Liberal Democratic Party, on the death of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira.
1982: The 16th Ministerial Conference on Economic Cooperation between the ROC and the Republic of Korea ends, with both countries pledging to cement closer cooperation in trade and technology.
1987: Britain's Conservative Party leader Margaret Thatcher, who in 1979 became the first woman ever to hold the office of British prime minister, is elected for the third time. She served in the post for over 11-and-a-half years, longer than any other British prime minister in the 20th century.
1987: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, former emperor of the Central African Republic, is sentenced to death for crimes committed during his 13-year rule.
1987: The ROC's Democratic Progressive Party leads its supporters in a demonstration outside the Legislative Yuan building in Taipei to protest against the National Security Law. In an ensuing clash with members of the Anti- Communist Patriotic Front, who support the National Security Law, several members from both sides are injured.
1991: In a referendum, the people of Leningrad vote by 55 percent to 43 percent to change the name of their city back to St. Petersburg.
1991: Boris Yeltsin beats five communist rivals in the country's first-ever democratic elections to become president of the Russian republic.
1998: The Japanese economy is in recession for the first time since the 1974-75 fiscal year.
2000: The 2000 World Congress of Information Technology kicks off its three-day session in Taipei with 1,500 experts and scholars from 80 countries around the world participating.
2001: The Republic of China opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan gives a speech at Oxford University in the United Kingdom in which he focuses on Taiwan's economic and political situations and the future of his party.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a thing is really hard, you may pound it and yet it will not crack; if a thing is really white, you may besmirch it, and yet it will not become black."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE ARRIVES IN NEW DELHI FOR VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, June 12 (CNA) 06/12/07 12:16:25 (By Paul Kuo, Chen I-wei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou arrived in New Delhi Tuesday for a whirlwind two-day visit at the invitation of the Indian government.
During his stay, Ma will visit major Indian information technology industry associations, including the powerful National Association of Software and Service Companies.

Ma, a former KMT chairman and a two-term mayor of Taipei from 1998 through 2006, will also meet with India's ruling Congress Party leader Dr. Karan Singh and Rajnath Singh, chairman of the main opposition Bharatiya Janata Party for wide- ranging talks.

Following his India visit, Ma will travel to Singapore for a brief visit. The itinerary will include visiting the city state's harbor bureau and getting first-hand information about its casino management as well as meeting with Singaporean political heavyweights, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew.
Ma said prior to his departure from Taipei late Monday evening that the five- day, two-leg visit is aimed at promoting international exchanges.
Noting that both India and Singapore are important players in the international community, Ma said that if he wins the next presidential election, he will not ignore them in his diplomatic agenda.

"While India boasts a large software talent pool and robust economic strength, Singapore also plays an important role in global trade and regional politics. We cannot afford to overlook them in our diplomatic work, " Ma explained, adding that the Democratic Progressive Party administration has regrettably failed to do more in forging closer ties with the two Asian neighbors.

Given India's excellence and prominence in computer software production, Ma said India can complement Taiwan, one of the world's top computer hardware suppliers, in information and communication technology industry development. Taiwan will benefit much from forging closer economic and political ties with India, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE VOTES TO UPHOLD AMENDMENTS ON GRASS-ROOTS ASSOCIATIONS

TEXT.P: The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan voted Tuesday not to overturn amendments to the law governing farmers' and fishermen's associations, delivering a blow to Premier Chang Chun-hsiung who assumed office May 21.
In Tuesday's vote, the legislature voted 115-96 to uphold the amendments, with one invalid ballots.

The amendments, passed by the opposition-controlled legislature on May 11, cancel the three-term limit on secretaries-general of the associations and lower the requirements of employment renewal. They also stipulate that indicted association staff are not to be relieved of their jobs until a final verdict has been delivered in their trial. Currently, indicted association staff members are discharged if they are convicted in the second stage of their trial.

Claiming that the amendments would hamper the government's efforts to clear the grass-roots farmers' and fishermen's groups of corrupt politicians, Chang's Cabinet decided May 30 to request that the legislature reconsider the amendments.

On Monday, Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker Wang Tu-fa claimed that many of these organizations, which tend to support the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party, have been dominated by corrupt local politicians who have been charged with criminal offenses and are currently standing trial.

Wang said that if these politicians are allowed to remain in their posts until they are convicted in the final stage of their trial, then the associations, along with the banking institutions run by these associations, will be ruined, and taxpayers will be forced to flip the bill.
He noted that more than 13 senior officials of the country's farmers' and fishermen's associations have been indicted and convicted, although verdicts have yet to be delivered in their final trial.

Noting that most of these officials have been indicted for cutting corners to extend association loans to their cronies, Wang said the longer these officials remain in their posts, the more irreversible the damage to the associations will be.

Wang claimed that the ratio of bad loans of these associations' banking sections stood at 14.53 percent in 2000 when the DPP came to power and that the figure had been reduced to 7.6 percent as of last month after the DPP administration used NT$50 billion (US$1.51 billion) to bail out unliquidated banking sections of these associations over the last seven years.

The Cabinet's request for reconsideration of the amendments was opposed by the "pan-blue" lawmakers and leaders of the associations, who claimed that these organizations are private groups and that the restrictions to be done away through the amendments are tougher than those imposed on government officials, as government officials cannot be removed from their posts before they are found guilty in their last trial.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
MOJ ORDERS CRACKDOWN ON DRUG TRAFFICKING VIA OUTLYING ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Law enforcement authorities should step up their crackdown on contraband smuggling via the Taiwan-held outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, both of which lie closer to China's Fujian Province than Taiwan proper, Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said Tuesday.
According to Shih, many Kinmen and Matsu fishermen have been illegally involved in small-scale trade in daily necessities, raw materials, contraband goods and firearms across the Taiwan Strait.
Smuggling via the two outlying island areas has become so rampant that locals tend to refer to their fishing vessels as part of the "North Sea Fleet," he added.

Over the past six years, Shih continued, only 82 cargo transshipment cases in the Kinmen-Matsu area have been reported for customs clearance, indicating that most of the area's cargo imports and exports have not been processed by customs authorities.
Shih said he has informed Minister of Finance Ho Chih-chin of this finding and asked him to probe into possible tax evasion related to this phenomenon.

In recent years, Shih said, contraband drugs smuggled from the Golden Triangle in northern Thailand via the Chinese provinces of Yunan, Guangxi, Guangdong and Fujian have been seized in Kinmen on many occasions.

Shih said he has ordered the Ministry of Justice's prosecutorial department to coordinate with the Coast Guard Administration and other relevant government agencies to take precautionary measures to prevent the two outlying islands from becoming "golden" drug trafficking channels.

Noting that 80 percent of the world's opium crop is produced in Afghanistan and that the opium trade is a major source of income for the notorious al-Qaida terrorist organization, Shih said Afghanistan-originating opium has been smuggled from China's Xinjiang and southeastern provinces to Southeast Asia.
Shih said he has asked law enforcement authorities to heighten their alert to prevent any such contraband drugs from being transshipped via Taiwan's outlying islands to other areas around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TAIEX Index futures for July rose 26 points to finish at 8,290, with 2,905 contracts traded, while September futures gained 25 points to close at 8,146, with 98 contract transactions. December futures moved up 20 points to finish at 8,144, with 21 contracts traded, while March futures rose 36 points to close at 8,150, with four contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 8,313 for June, 8,264 for July, 8,121 for September, 8,124 for December and 8,114 for March.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

June TE futures moved up 1.4 points to close at 362.4, with 2,620 contracts traded, while July TE futures gained 0.1 points to finish at 359, with 186 contract transactions. September TE futures rose 1.8 points to close at 354.4, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December and March.

June TF futures rose 4.6 points to close at 962, with 2,225 contracts traded, while July TF futures gained 4.2 points to finish at 960.4, with 360 contract transactions. DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange were higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 31.38 points to close at 8,370.26.

The bourse opened at 8,371.7 and fluctuated between 8,396.22 and 8,345.01 during the day's trading. A total of 4.77 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$143.2 billion (US$4.34 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.3 percent, construction issues at 0.6 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent, foodstuff issues and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.4 percent, banking and finnancial shares at 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSES CONCERNED ABOUT POSSIBLE ARRIVAL OF 'ZERO PROFITS' ERA

TEXT.P: Many businesses have expressed concern that their minimal profit margins could further dwindle over the next decade, with the possible arrival of an era of "zero profits, " according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.
The survey was conducted by 104 Job Bank, Global Views Monthly and 30 Monthly on 1,058 business representatives from May 21-25. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.21 percent.
Just over 80 percent of the respondents predicted that their businesses will face a crisis of "profitless operations" by 2015.
This sense of crisis is most evident among small- and medium-sized businesses with 20-100 employees, with 89 percent of representatives of these businesses sharing this view.
Asked to rate their confidence in the future development of the business environment on a 100-point scale, the respondents gave an average score of 57.8.
Among businesses with 100 or fewer employees, over 40 percent gave a failing mark of less than 60.

On the factors in Taiwan's overall environment that are critical to the continuation of their businesses, 58.1 percent of respondents mentioned government efficiency, 54.1 percent named the level of internationalization, and 51.6 percent pointed to the country's economic strength.

To cope with the possible arrival of a "zero profits" era, 54.5 percent of respondents said they will recruit and train talent, 42.5 percent will prepare to tap the international market, and 33 percent will adopt a creative business model.

The survey shows that technological development, cross-Taiwan Strait interaction and businesses' position in globalization are the top three choices among the respondents in seeking opportunities for business development.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT TAIWAN'S DIPLOMATIC ALLIES IN AFRICA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang will visit Taiwan's five diplomatic allies in Africa next month to extend invitations to the leaders of these countries to attend a summit to be held in Taipei in September, an official said Tuesday.

At a regular press conference held at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , Chang Yun-ping, director-general of the MOFA's Department of African Affairs, said Huang will serve as a special envoy of President Chen Shui-bian to invite the leaders to participate in the summit between the Republic of China and its African allies.
In Africa, Taiwan now only maintains diplomatic ties with Burkina Faso, Malawi, Swaziland, The Gambia, and Sao Tome and Principe.
During his stay in Africa, Huang will also attend activities to mark the national days of Malawi and Sao Tome and Principe, according to Chang.

In response to reports that China is discussing a cooperation project on oil exploitation with Sao Tome and Principe, Chang said it comes as no surprise to Taiwan as China has been working to establish relations with all the oil producing countries around the world.

Chang added that although the government expects that the matter will not have an impact on Taiwan's officials ties with the African country, the MOFA is trying to learn more about the details of the situation.

Huang announced in late April that the summit meeting between Taiwan's head of state and those of its African allies will focus on the measures Taiwan will adopt to help its allies on the continent to cope with globalization, including projects to promote renewable energy and ecotourism and strengthen environmental protection while developing their economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'DISPLAY TAIWAN' AND 'PHOTONICS FESTIVAL' TO LAUNCH JUNE 13

TEXT.P: The 9th International Flat Display Exposition, also known as Display Taiwan 2007, and the Photonics Festival will both be held at the Taipei World Trade Center beginning Wednesday, a representative of the optoelectronics industry said Tuesday.
Ma Sung-ya, chief executive officer of the Photonics Industry and Technology Development Association (PIDA) , said the two events will be attended by 464 firms, setting up a total of 1,105 booths.

Ma said Display Taiwan 2007, to be held from June 13-15, will be of a larger scale than before. It was jointly organized this year by the PIDA, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council, and the Taipei Computer Association.

The Photonics Festival in Taiwan 2007, scheduled for June 13-16, will include the International Optoelectronics Exposition, the International LED Lighting Exposition, and the International Solar Exposition, Ma said, adding that the festival will be attended by 304 firms, setting up 655 booths, and is expected to attract 25,000 visitors.

Ma said Taiwan's total output of flat panel displays in 2006 reached NT$823.3 billion (US$25.2 billion) , of which thin film transistor-liquid crystal displays (TFT-LCD) accounted for NT$762.8 billion (US$23.4 billion).
Taiwan's total output of flat panel displays in 2007 is expected to reach NT$977.8 billion (US$30 billion) , and will be over NT$1 trillion if output of components and parts are included, Ma added.
Ma also expressed hope that the two upcoming exhibitions will contribute to positive sales growth at participating firms.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCU DEVELOPS QUANTUM ENCRYPTION TECHNOLOGY FOR PHONE, INTERNET

TEXT.P: A local research team has made breakthroughs in the application of quantum encryption to telephone and the Internet data transmission, allowing greater privacy protection in daily communications, sources at National Central University (NCU) in Taoyuan County said Tuesday.

NCU Professor Li Pei-wen, the leader of the nanotechnology research and development team, said that quantum encrypted communications have been widely used in many areas to prevent phone tapping or computer hacking, and that the team has modified the equipment to allowing its use in daily life.

Li explained that messages sent in quantum communication are first coded and transmitted with a photon emitter, and then decoded by receiver with electron transistor -- if anyone "intercepts" the message, the sequence of photons will be altered and the sender and receiver can thus easily recognize a security breach has occurred.
With the quantum encryption techniques, everyday communications using phones or the Internet can be much safer, Li added.

According to NCU, the single-photon emitter and single-electron transistor developed by the team has already achieved high accuracy and efficiency, with 92 percent efficiency for single-mode light emission and 99 percent purity for single photons. Also, the size of the transistor has been reduced to less than three nanometers.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR BELIEVES STRAY DOGS CULPRITS BEHIND GOAT KILLING

TEXT.P: Professor Hsia Liang-chou, a specialist in veterinary medicine and animal husbandry, asserted Tuesday that stray dogs must be the culprits behind the recent goat killing in Linkuo, Taipei county, while a witness to the attack continued to insist that she saw a tiger, not dogs.

Hsia, director of the animal husbandry and veterinary medicine division of the National Pingtung University of Science and Technology (NPUST) in the southern county of Pingtung, also heads the NPUST-operated stray dogs home. He indicated that it's not unusual to see stray dogs attack other animals.

Some released or escaped dogs may become aggressive, but later generation strays are much more violent and wolfish than those which were once pets, Hsia said, citing a case that occurred in Pingtung years ago in which more than 10 mid- sized hogs and dozens of goats were killed by stray dogs in a single night.
Hsia explained how those strays mauled one of their victims, attacking its neck, and flinging it to the ground.

The most aggressive stray dogs are those of later generations, which are not all in large size, the professor noted. While attempting to attack farm animals, canines will usually rally others of their kind before striking, he added.

Hsia also indicated that it is easy to identify the attacker from the paw prints and bite wounds left on the scene. If dogs were responsible for attack on the goats in Linkuo Friday, there would be tooth marks left on the victim, whereas if it was a tiger, there should also be lacerations due to the creature's claws, Hsia noted.

Another dog was caught Tuesday morning in a trap cage at the Linkuo goat farm, owned by a man surnamed Hung, following the capture of a white stray nabbed the previous day at the farm, where eight goats were mauled to death by some kind of "unidentified large beast" Friday.
A foreign maid witnessed the killing and insisted that she saw a tiger launch the attack.
Fourteen goats at the farm were killed by animal bites Monday, but the owner saw wild dogs at the scene on that occasion.
Examining the two captured strays, neither was found to have paw prints matching the tracks left at the farm Friday, which appeared to be larger, Taipei county officials said.
The tracking operation will therefore continue until larger dogs, with paws matching the prints on the site, are captured, the officials said.

Meanwhile, U.S.-based ethnic Chinese forensic scientist Henry Lee suggested hair or bite wounds left on the mauled goats would provide evidence revealing the species of the animals responsible for the Linkuo attacks.
Lee made the suggestion in response to media inquiries during his visit to the central county of Changhua Tuesday, where he was invited to deliver a speech to local police.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST WORKERS EXPECT PAY HIKES OF LESS THAN 10% OVER NEXT DECADE

TEXT.P: Most workers expect only marginal increase and even no increase in their salaries over the next decade, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.
The survey was conducted by 104 Job Bank, Global Views Monthly and 30 Monthly on 1,966 workers from May 21-25, and has a margin of error of 2.21 percent.
While 18.5 percent of respondents predicted that their salaries will remain the same until 2015, 37.3 percent think their salaries will rise no more than 10 percent by 2015.
Although only 8.4 percent of respondents think their present jobs are promising, 19.9 percent believe that they will opt to stay on at their present positions.
Meanwhile, a survey conducted during the same period of 1,058 business representatives indicates that creative talents are in high demand by business.
When searching for business successors, the greatest number of the business representatives said that organization, management and policy-making are most important.

Over the next decade, key abilities cited include leadership, 49.8 percent; problem solving, 40.4 percent; the ability to make the best use of human resources, 31.7 percent; innovative entrepreneurship, 29.1 percent; and determination and decisiveness, 23.5 percent.
