DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE, CHINESE STUDENTS LOVE BRAND-NAME GOODS: POLL

TEXT.P: Both Taiwanese and Chinese university students enjoy purchasing brand-name luxury goods, and 90 percent of them favor enhancing their spiritual cultivation by means of travel, according to the results of a recent survey released Tuesday.

In view of the fact that a growing number of enterprises are simultaneously investing in consumer markets across the Taiwan Strait, the Pilot Group conducted the survey on Taiwanese and Chinese university students' consumption behavior to allow the companies to better know the consumption characteristics of students in the two markets.
The survey collected 977 valid samples from university students in Taiwan and 911 valid responses from Chinese students.

The most notable findings of the survey showed that students on both sides are in the habit of buying brand-name products, with Taiwanese students spending 17 percent of their living expenses on purchasing brand name products, while Chinese students spend 29 percent on such goods, according to Wu Yi-chen, a pollster in charge of the Taiwanese poll.
Nonetheless, up to 93.8 percent of Taiwanese students, and 90.7 percent of Chinese students responding to the survey indicated a desire to broaden their perspectives by means of travel.

Wu said, the survey showed that university students on both sides attach greater importance to promoting spiritual cultivation than buying brand names, then added that the survey should help alleviate public concerns that university students are unable to afford brand names purchases as they continue to indulge in puchasing their favorite goods.

In addition, as more and more high quality, low cost commodities have been introduced to the Taiwanese market, Taiwanese university students have become much more quality-oriented instead of solely focusing on brand names, Wu noted, adding that the reliance Taiwanese students place on brand name products is not as high as their Chinese counterparts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAX FILING WITH DIGITAL CERTIFICATE GROWS 50% OVER LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: More than 430,000 people filed their personal income tax using the Citizen Digital Certificate--an electronic identity for Taiwanese citizens--a 50 percent increase over last year's figure, according to a press release issued by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) Tuesday.
About 280,000 people filed their tax returns with the Citizen Digital Certificate last year, according to the statement.
The statement points out that the Citizen Digital Certificate system is crucial not only for e-government operations, but also an essential identification tool in the Internet era.

The MOI issued more than 110,000 Citizen Digital Certificates in May this year, up 85 percent over last May's issue of more than 60,000. More than 517,000 people downloaded tax filing data from governmental Websites using their Citizen Digital Certificates this year, according to the statement.

Taiwan's government organizations provide 1,106 online services that may be accessed using the Citizen Digital Certificate. The aggregate number of applications accessed online using the certificate exceeds 9 million, with applications to file personal income tax returns accounting for the largest share.
The statement said the MOI will continue promoting the Citizen Digital Certificate system to bring greater convenience to the provision of government services to Taiwanese citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RECORDS SECOND MEASLES CASE CONTRACTED OVERSEAS

TEXT.P: A resident in Taipei County has developed measles after a recent visit to Japan, the second overseas measles infection this year, health authorities reported Tuesday.
The patient, a 26-year-old woman living in the county's Panchiao City, is a Chinese citizen who has not been vaccinated against measles, according to officials of Taipei County Public Health Bureau.
The case was reported to the bureau last week, the officials said, adding that test results confirmed the diagnosis Monday.
Given the fact that the woman visited Japan with her Taiwanese husband May 17-24, she probably caught measles in Japan, which has been affected by a measles outbreak since May, the officials said.
While the patient is receiving treatment in an isolation ward in a local hospital, health authorities are tracing the other travelers who were part of the woman's tour group, the officials said.

Lin Ting, deputy director-general of the Department of Health's Center for Disease Control (CDC) , said a 28-year-old man who had contact with the patient has a rash and that further examination is required to determine if he is infected with measles.
Lin noted that in Taiwan, measles vaccination coverage averages more than 95 percent, with almost all people born after September 1976 having received inoculation.
While a measles outbreak is unlikely in Taiwan, people are advised to avoid taking infants who have not been vaccinated to measles-affected countries such as Japan, Lin said.
The incubation period for measles ranges from 10 to 14 days and symptoms include a runny nose, cough, fever, red eyes and a red blotchy rash.
Last Friday, the CDC confirmed the country's first overseas measles infection, which involved a woman in southern Taiwan who also traveled to Japan last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-FRANCE CULTURAL AWARD BESTOWED ON FRENCH PUPPETEER
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, June 11 (CNA) 06/12/07 20:09:25 (By P.C. Tang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official responsible for cultural affairs bestowed the 11th Taiwan- France Cultural Award on French puppeteer Jean-Luc Penso Monday at a ceremony held at the French Academy in Paris, France's most prestigious academic institute.

Wong Chin-chu, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council of Cultural Affairs (CCA) , said Penso will be awarded 25,000 euros for his contribution to the arts, combining both Oriental and Western features in his puppetry.

Penso, who learned puppet technique from Taiwanese puppet master Li Tien-lu, founder of Yi Wan Jan Puppet Theater, for five years, established his shadow puppet troupe "Theatre du Petit Miroir" in France in 1978.
After spending 30 years in puppetry, Penso's shows, featured both in Taiwanese and Western traditional stories, have been played in more than 100 countries.

Wong congratulated Penso for winning the award co-sponsored by the CCA and the French Academy, and extended gratitude to the academy and other foreign friends for their contribution to Taiwan-French cultural exchanges.
Wong said that cultural cooperation between Taiwan and France offers a good platform for Taiwanese and Europeans to better understand one another.

Michel Albert, an executive of the French Academy, who was also present at the ceremony, said the French Academy has been successfully assisting Europeans to better understand Taiwan's current situation through a series of cooperative projects staged with Taiwan's CCA over the last decade.

Albert said it was a wonderful experience to know that traditional puppetry, which was already being bypassed by the Taiwanese people, could be continued by a French young man and his show halfway around the world.

For his part, Penso stressed that he was content to perform Taiwanese puppet art in other parts of the world, adding that he planned to use the prize money to create a new drama featuring an episode from the noted Chinese historical novel "the Three Kingdoms" for ethnic Chinese in the French colony of Reunion to mark the 100th anniversary of a Gaundi Temple there next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG COUNTY TO SEEK SPECIAL MUNICIPALITY STATUS ALONE

TEXT.P: A Taichung county government proposal to seek upgrading the county's status to a special municipality without taking Taichung City into account was adopted Tuesday during a meeting attended by all township chiefs and representatives in the central county.

The county government will organize a status-upgrading promotion commission as soon as the proposal passes the county council's review and before it is delivered to the Executive Yuan for certification, county officials said.

Addressing the advantages of being a special municipality, Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng said a special municipality can receive more money from the central government for construction projects.

The county government's organic structure will also be expanded, Huang said, explaining that if the county is upgraded to a special municipality, the municipal government will be allowed to hire 4,230 additional employees to upgrade its services.

In December 2002, the Taichung County Council passed a resolution to bid for the special municipality status together with Taichung City. However, the county has been unable to get the resolution implemented because it would require re-zoning of the country's administrative districts.

According to the Act on Local Government Systems, an area with a population of over 1.25 million and with special political, economic, cultural and urban development may obtain special municipality status, the highest of three levels of local government organizations The county is now home to more than 1.5 million, according to the county government.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC URGED TO SUPPORT ANTI-PIRACY PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The Business Software Alliance (BSA)-Taiwan urged the public Tuesday to support an annual program promoted by the alliance against piracy, which the alliance said remains a serious problem in the country.
BSA-Taiwan officials said Taiwan's piracy rate stands at 41 percent, meaning that 41 in every 100 computers in the country contain pirated software.
The results of a BSA-Taiwan survey also indicate that 53 percent of businesses in the country use old hardware or pirated software in order to save costs, the officials said.

Since this year's anti-piracy program was launched May 1, the BSA-Taiwan has received more than 300 phone calls reporting the use of pirated software by local businesses, including some listed companies, they said, adding that the economic losses caused by piracy in the country has exceeded NT$6 billion.
They said the program will continue until June 15 and that BSA-Taiwan is offering up to NT$3 million for information concerning piracy activities during the period.
People with such information can call the alliance's anti-piracy hotline at 0800-051498, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Judges Say U.S. Cant Hold Man as Combatant
The federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., ruled yesterday that the president may not declare civilians in this country to be enemy combatants and have the military hold them indefinitely. The ruling was a stinging rejection of one of the Bush administrations central assertions about the scope of executive authority to combat terrorism.
The ruling came in the case of Ali al-Marri, a citizen of Qatar now in military custody in Charleston, S.C., who is the only person on the American mainland known to be held as an enemy combatant. The court said the administration may charge Mr. Marri with a crime, deport him or hold him as a material witness in connection with a grand jury investigation.
Wall Street Journal:For Troubled Firms, A Flood of Big Loans
Bally Total Fitness Holding Corp., a Chicago health-club operator, is deep in debt and has periodically been considered a candidate for bankruptcy.
That didn't prevent Bally from borrowing $284 million last October. A unit of J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. arranged the loan, with investment banks and a hedge fund participating.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES BEIJING TO NEGOTIATE ON TORCH RELAY ROUTE

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) expressed hope Tuesday that China will negotiate the Olympic torch relay route as soon as possible out of consideration for "the peace and freedom of the Olympic Games."
The nation's top China policy planning agency made clear its stance in a written statement.
"As long as China expresses sincerity in a substantive way and proposes a solution, we are willing to coordinate with China as soon as possible," it said.
"Although China has said openly that it is willing to negotiate with us, it has yet to put it into practice," the statement said.

The statement also said that the government "has always insisted that it will safeguard Taiwan's sovereignty. If there will be negotiation with China on the torch relay for the 2008 Olympic Games, the talks must be held under the principles of safeguarding the nation's sovereignty, dignity, and cross-strait parity."

MAC Chairman Chen Ming-tong, in an interview with Hong Kong media last week, also said that Taiwan is willing to re-negotiate the torch relay route with China so long as Taiwan's national status is not downgraded.

According to China's plan when it announced the torch relay route April 26, the Olympic torch would travel from Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City to Taipei and then continue on to Hong Kong, Macau and several other Chinese cities before arriving in the host city, Beijing.
Taiwan rejected the route planning at that time, saying it deliberately downgrades Taiwan's sovereign status.
Taiwan wants the torch to come to Taipei via a third country and travel on to another country before arriving in China.
The Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee would not comment on reports that negotiations might take place.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET REGRETS REJECTION OF RECONSIDERATION REQUEST

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan regrets the Legislative Yuan's decision to vote down its request to reconsider amendments to the law governing farmers' and fishermen's associations, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Tuesday.
Shieh made the remarks after the opposition-controlled legislature voted 115-96 to uphold the amendment, with one invalid ballot. The premier will have to comply with the legislature's decision.
Shieh said the Executive Yuan requested reconsideration of the amendments May 30 because it did not want to let corrupt association heads get off scot-free.
The Cabinet accepted the result of the legislature's decision "with regret," he said, adding that the "public will have their own judgment."

He claimed that the main opposition Kuomintang "has lost more than it has gained, " saying that the KMT's recent move to get its presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou off the hook has already raised public eyebrows and that "it is now allowing rogue elements to remain in grassroots organizations by upholding the amendments."

He was referring to the party's easing of its strict anti-corruption party charter to allow Ma to stay in the presidential race. Ma was indicted in February for allegedly embezzling from the "special allowance fund" for his discretionary use during his term as Taipei mayor 1998-2006.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed that the legislature's rejection of the reconsideration request shows that the opposition camp is trying to retain its connections with corrupt "black gold politics" with the aim of cementing grassroots support for Ma in the 2008 presidential election.

DPP Deputy Secretary Hsu Jen-tu said that during the five-decade rule of the KMT, it kept its grip on grassroots organizations, resulting in injustices in the election process of officials in such associations.
However, the KMT took the Executive Yuan to task for "wasting resources and time" by requesting reconsideration of the amendments.

Tseng Yung-chuan, KMT legislator and the party's Policy Committee executive director, said Premier Chang Chun-hsiung "should take political responsibility, " although he did not elaborate on what responsibility he was referring to.

The amendments, passed by the opposition-controlled legislature May 11, cancel the three-term limit on secretaries-general of the associations and lower the requirements for employment renewal. They also stipulate that indicted association staff are not to be relieved of their jobs until a final verdict has been delivered in their trials. Currently, indicted association staff members are discharged if they are convicted in the second stage of their trial.

The Executive Yuan requested a reconsideration from the legislature May 30. According to the Constitution, the Executive Yuan has the right to request that the legislature reconsider a passed bill if it deems the bill too difficult to execute.

The Cabinet said the amendments give strong backing to association officials mired in lawsuits or those who have criminal intentions, saying that if the Cabinet cannot forestall potential disputes resulting from the organization of the associations, they could expand into a systematic crisis, affect the sustainable development of the grassroots organizations and undermine the government's efforts to reform grassroots organizations.

The Executive Yuan estimated that 13 officials of farmers' and fishermen's associations have been indicted and convicted in the first trial, although verdicts have yet to be delivered in their final trials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE FOOD FESTIVAL KICKS OFF IN HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 12 (CNA) 06/12/07 21:22:54 (By Lo Kin-fai and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese Food Festival 2007 kicked off in Hong Kong Tuesday to promote healthy, high quality Taiwanese foods, according to Liu Shi-wei, chairman of the Taipei Trade Center in Hong Kong.
This year's festival, the biggest yet, will run through June 17 at the Jusco department store and supermarket, said Liu.
The Taipei Trade Center and Aeron Stores (Hong Kong) Co. organized this year's food festival with authorization from Taiwan's Bureau of Foreign Trade.
The festival includes the categories of vegetables and fruit, drinks, health food and snacks, Liu said, adding that all the foods displayed have passed strict examinations.

Liu said foodstuffs imported from Taiwan fave been increasing and the values import value to Hong Kong for the first six months of this year exceeded US$25.08 million, up 6.56 percent over last year's figure.
In order to better promote Taiwanese foods, Liu said Hong Kong people who buy Taiwanese food worth more than NT$250 (US$7.57) can win a trip to Taiwan's famous hot springs.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE TO VISIT U.S. IN JULY

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate for the 2008 presidential election, will start an 11-day visit to the United States July 20, one of his aides said Tuesday.

Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim, who serves as director of Hsieh's election campaign office in charge of international affairs, said his visit will be designed to strengthen what she described as "love and trust" between Taiwan and the U.S.
During his stay in the U.S., Hsieh will meet several "important Americans" who Hsiao did not identify and watch Taiwan-born pitcher Wang Chien-ming play for the New York Yankees.
It was reported that the U.S. is attaching much importance to Hsieh's visit, with The Nelson Report reporting that the Bush Administration is studying how to receive him.

According to Hsiao, Hsieh will visit New York, Washington, D.C., Detroit and Los Angeles. He will give a keynote speech at the National Press Club in Washington, attend a welcoming reception to be organized by the U.S. Congress and meet Taiwanese expatriates living in the United States.
In addition, he will visit a professor at the guide dog school "Leader Dogs" located in Detroit, who has expressed long-term concern over guide dog training in Taiwan.
Hsieh will return home July 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. BID AIMED AT WORLD RECOGNITION: DPP CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's bid to apply for United Nations membership under the name of Taiwan will help the world understand Taiwan's wish to be recognized as a normal country, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said Monday.
Hsieh made the remarks during a meeting with foreign journalists stationed in Taipei.
Hsieh said that this year, the DPP administration adopted a different strategy in launching its U.N. bid, using the name Taiwan instead of the official name "the Republic of China."
This strategy will let the international community know that Taiwan wishes to be recognized as a normal country, Hsieh said.
Describing the strategy as peaceful and legitimate, Hsieh said that if Taiwan wants to win the world's support, it should not cause any harm or "violate humane principles."
He predicted that the world will eventually change its stance on Taiwan and added that China is facing many challenges and that Taiwan should be patient and persevere.
China will not be completely satisfied with anything Taiwan does unless Taiwan surrenders, Hsieh claimed, adding that both sides of the Taiwan Strait need to negotiate and compromise.
China might care about Taiwan's new strategy but it will not be nervous because China has U.N. veto power and is more influential than Taiwan, Hsieh pointed out.
He explained that Taiwan's strategy is also aimed at underlining what he described as China "saying one thing while doing another."
China says that as long as Taiwan accepts Beijing's "one China policy, " Taiwan can have its own interpretation of the meaning of "one China," Hsieh said.

He noted that the structure of the Republic of China Constitution is based on "one China" -- the ROC. However, the People's Republic of China does not admit this Constitution and does not give any room for the ROC, he added.
In order to gain more room, Hsieh said Taiwan needs to change its strategy, which he described as "a passive act."

Hsieh also said there are many possibilities in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, describing himself as less conservative than the late President Chiang Ching- kuo, who insisted on a "three noes" policy -- no negotiating, no compromise and no contact with the Communist Party of China.

Now, many Taiwanese businessmen invest in China, Hsieh said, adding that in order to achieve a balance between the two sides, he agrees that Chinese people should be allowed to invest in or purchase property in Taiwan.

Responding to recent remarks made by his rival, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Ma Ying-jeou, Hsieh said it would be "contradictory" if Ma selects a DPP member to serve as premier should he win the election.
Meanwhile, Hsieh said there "might be a misunderstanding" because international media has reported that he is corrupt and under investigation.
Hsieh noted that not everyone who is investigated is corrupt or guilty of any wrongdoing.

Claiming that he did not do anything illegal, Hsieh said that he is under investigation simply because he is being sued by KMT members. He added he is confident that the public will have faith in him if he is not prosecuted.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOSPITAL DIETICIAN WARNS OF OVEREATING ZONGZI

TEXT.P: A dietician at the Tzu-Chi Buddhist General Hospital advised the public Tuesday to refrain from eating more than three per day of zongzi -- a pyramid-shaped dumpling made of glutinous rice and wrapped in bamboo leaves -- with the approach of the Dragon Boat Festival, the traditional time of year for serving the rice dumplings.

Lai Chu-ching, who works at the hospital's Taichung County branch warned that a single zongzi contains between 400 and 600 calories and that the traditional rice dumpling, usually stuffed with meat, peanuts, egg yolk and other fillings like dried mushrooms and fried soy bean products, is not good for people with digestion problems.
The dietician suggested making them at home with low-fat, healthy ingredients like brown rice, to ensure their quality and cleanliness.
The Dragon Boat Festival falls on June 19 this year and is celebrated by Chinese people around the world with rowing competitions using decorated canoes, as well as with eating zongzi.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEY SUSPECTS IN COUNCILMAN MURDER HAVE FLED TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Several key suspects in the killing of Taipei County Councilor Wu Shan-chiu have fled to China, Criminal Investigation Bureau Commissioner Hou Yu-ih confirmed Tuesday.
He said the gunman was not the only perpetrator in the murder of the opposition People First Party councilor and that a criminal ring pulled the strings and helped the killer escape.
"Police have kept track of suspects hiding in Taiwan, as well as those who have fled to China," Ho said.

He did not disclose the names or the number of suspects who have fled to China, saying only that the police are working through a cross-Taiwan Strait anti- crime mechanism to ask their Chinese counterparts to help track down the suspects.

Wu, who has spoken out against vested interest groups in the lucrative gravel and sand trade, was shot several times by a lone gunman at close range at his office in suburban Taipei May 23. He was pronounced dead on arrival at the hospital. The gangland execution-style killing has shocked society and police have vowed to nail the killer.

DOC.HEADLINE: 50% OF MANAGERS FAVOR ACTIVE JOB SEEKERS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: More than 50 percent of Taiwan's human resources managers favor job seekers with active attitudes, Wu Juei-ying, a spokesman for the Taiwan-based 1111 Manpower Bank, said Tuesday.

Wu said the results of a survey conducted by the manpower bank show that 49.64 of managers pay attention to job seekers' ability to handle stress and 31.02 percent focus on their ability to work independently.

The survey was conducted via telephone interviews and Internet questionnaires June 6-7 among firms that recruit personnel through the manpower bank's job matching Web site, with 274 valid samples returned.
Wu also said the results show that 36.13 percent of enterprises interview job seekers before giving them written tests, while 29.56 percent of them only give interviews.

DOC.HEADLINE: FATE OF AMNESTY BILL UNDECIDED

TEXT.P: The fate of a Cabinet-proposed amnesty bill remained undecided Tuesday as the ruling and opposition parties failed to reach consensus on key points.

President Chen Shui-bian announced April 24 that the government would implement a sentence commutation program to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident of 1947 and the 20th anniversary of the lifting of 38 years of martial law in 1987.

Although the Legislative Yuan's Judicial Committee passed the first reading of the amnesty bill presented by the Cabinet, the ruling and opposition parties remained divided over the threshold for sentence commutation and the reasons for the amnesty.

The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) disagreed with the inclusion of the 228 Incident commemoration as a reason for amnesty and demanded that the threshold for amnesty be expanded to include those who have been sentenced to one- and-a-half years.

The 228 Incident is a notorious dark chapter in Taiwan's history perpetrated by the KMT under the leadership of the late President Chiang Kai-shek, in which a popular uprising was brutally crushed by KMT troops.
According to the Cabinet-proposed bill, only those sentenced to a year or less would be eligible for commutation.
If the KMT's proposal is accepted, KMT Legislator Chiu Yi, who is serving a 16-month jail term for his role in a violent protest at Kaohsiung District Court in 2004, will benefit from the bill.

During a cross-party consultation session presided over by Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, both the KMT and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislative caucuses refused to compromise on their stances.
At the end of the day, the two camps came to a decision that a showdown vote will be held Friday -- the last day of the current legislative session -- to determine the amnesty bill's fate.
As the KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" partner -- the People First Party -- hold a slim majority in the legislature, the chances of the bill clearing the legislature are slim, analysts said.

According to Ministry of Justice data, if the Cabinet-proposed amnesty bill is passed, 10,287 inmates can be released immediately, while another 7,699 will have their sentences halved. If the KMT-proposed one-and-a-half-year threshold is adopted, 14,795 inmates can be released immediately and 10,140 will have their sentences cut by half.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE DELEGATION TO ATTEND FRAUD-FIGHTING SEMINAR IN SEOUL

TEXT.P: The National Police Agency (NPA) will send a delegation of experienced fraud busters to Seoul later this week to attend aseminar on strategies to fight various forms of fraud, an official said Tuesday.

The NPA delegation, to be headed by Liu Kuo, will share experience in fighting cross-border fraudulent operations with South Korean police personnel who the official said are having hard time fighting fraud conducted by cross-border criminal rings, particularly those based in China.

According to the official, several senior South Korean criminal investigators visited the NPA recently to study Taiwan's strategies and tactics in cracking down on fraudulent crimes committed by fraudsters hiding in China as cross- Taiwan Strait fraud rings have expanded their operations from Taiwan to South Korea.

"Cross-strait fraud rings have committed fraudulent crimes by phone or use Internet 'Trojan horse' program to steal personal information for swindling purposes, " the official said, adding that such operations require cross-strait cooperation to fight.

The NPA delegation is scheduled to depart for Seoul Friday, the official said, adding that the delegation will present three volumes on fraud-fighting techniques to their South Korean counterparts as gifts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 13, or the 28th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Rhode Island becomes the first American colony to ban the importation of slaves and to assure their freedom.
1865: Irish poet and playwright William Butler Yeats is born. The dramatist was the co-founder of the Abbey Theater in Dublin and won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1923.
1931: Dr. Shibasaburo Kitazato, noted Japanese bacteriologist, dies of a stroke at the age of 78.
1944: London comes under attack as Hitler lets loose a devastating new weapon on the city. The so-called V1 flying bomb, or "doodle bug," as it has been nicknamed, is a long-range device that can be launched safely from within enemy territory.
1951: United Nations troops capture Pyongyang, capital of North Korea.
1956: Communist China's Premier Zhou Enlai requests a meeting with the U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles. His request is rejected.
1956: The last British troops leave the Suez Canal Zone, ending 75 years of British rule in Egypt.
1971 Geraldine Brodrick gives birth to nine babies in Australia, one of the few recorded instances of nonuplets.
1973: Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, commander-in-chief of the U.S. Army in the Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo, in an interview with Edward W. Scripps II, director of the Scripps-Howard Newspaper in the United States, warns that the Chinese communists are trying to push the United States to the brink of war with the Soviet Union.
1978: Pu Chung-chiang, 10, labeled as the "fastest boy in the world" by the press, receives a silver medal from the ROC Ministry of Education in distance races in the United States.
1982: Saudi Arabian King Khalid ibn Abul-Aziz dies and is succeeded by his brother Prince Fahd.
1987: Republic of China Premier Yu Kuo-hua, in a statement made after returning from Singapore and learning of violent protests outside the Legislative Yuan, says the government's determination to implement constitutional democracy will never change, but unlawful acts will be dealt with in accordance with the law.
1989: Beijing orders the arrest of the leaders of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square.
1989: Russian President Mikhail Gorbachev and West Germany's Chancellor Helmut Kohl agree that East and West Germany should be reunited.
1994: The Foreign Ministry of North Korea announces it is withdrawing from the United Nations' International Atomic Energy Agency and will no longer permit U.N. nuclear inspectors into the country.
1996: Copper prices tumble around the world after Sumitomo Corp. says it has lost an estimated US$2.6 billion over 10 years due to unauthorized copper trade.
1998: Lucio Costa, Brazilian architect who planned the Brazilian capital Brasilia, dies at the age of 96.
1999: The fifth Taiwan-Poland Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Taipei with trade officials and business leaders from both countries taking part.
2000: The United States Senate passes a resolution in recognition of Stephen Chen, the Republic of China's representative to the United States, for his distinguished service.
2000: Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates praises Taiwan's companies as a key that "made things happen" in the growth of the global computer industry over the past 25 years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is austere in his look, but a weakling and a coward at heart -- is he not like one of your small, mean people? Is he not like a sneaking thief or a cowardly pickpocket?"
