DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REMOVED FROM U.S. WATCH LIST FOR HUMAN TRAFFICKING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 12 (CNA) 06/13/07 12:38:41 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States has removed Taiwan from a watch list for human trafficking in view of the country's "significant efforts" to tackle the problem over the past year, according to an annual report released Tuesday by the U.S. Department of State.

The Trafficking in Persons Report 2007 places Taiwan on a list of "Tier 2" countries, noting that Taiwan is primarily a destination for men, women and children trafficked for the purposes of forced labor and sexual exploitation.

"While the island's trafficking problems remain daunting, Taiwan authorities over the last year showed clear progress in addressing trafficking for both sexual and labor exploitation," the report says.

However, the report continues, much more remains to be done to bring Taiwan into compliance with the minimum standards, with Taiwan authorities needing to demonstrate greater political will in dealing with the trafficking problem.

The report urges Taiwan to grant victims of trafficking formal protection, including access to justice in order to obtain compensation from their traffickers or exploitative employers and the right to work while awaiting court cases.

It suggests that the Council on Labor Affairs stop addressing acts of involuntary servitude with administrative penalties and instead refer these serious crimes to the appropriate law enforcement authorities for criminal investigation and, if warranted, prosecution.
Also, Taiwan authorities should do more to eliminate the ability of labor brokers and employers to deport workers involuntarily, the report says.
The 2007 report rates 141 countries and regions and places them in three lists, based primarily on the extent of government action to combat trafficking.

While governments that fully comply with the minimum standards for the elimination of trafficking are placed in "Tier 1, " governments that are making significant efforts to meet the minimum standards are placed in "Tier 2."
Governments that do not fully comply with the minimum standards and are not making significant efforts to do so are placed in "Tier 3" and may be subject to certain sanctions.
Taiwan was ranked among the list of "Tier 1" countries in the 2003 and 2004 reports but was downgraded to "Tier 2" in the 2005 report.
In the 2006 report, Taiwan was placed on the "Tier 2 Watch List" for not fully complying with the minimum standards for the elimination of human trafficking.

Addressing a news conference on the release of the 2007 report Tuesday, U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said the Department of State has brought global attention to the problem of human trafficking by making an assessment of the problem annually since 2001.
"Millions more people know about human trafficking today than when the first report was issued in 2001, and we hope that this greater awareness translate into greater prevention," Rice said.
Mark P. Lagon, a senior advisor on trafficking in persons at the Department of States, called a raid in Taiwan last week a "real success story" that demonstrated a "welcome new attitude."

In the case, Taiwan worked closely with U.S. law enforcement authorities to break up a cross-border trafficking ring, arresting 12 people suspected of trafficking women to the United States and other countries where they were exploited in the sex and pornography industry.

Lagon said countries that have established credentials in good governance and rule of law, such as Taiwan, are more likely to move quickly in protecting victims of trafficking and bringing exploiters to justice.
In contrast, China, where there is a lack of rule of law, has resisted joining the international community in upholding universal anti-trafficking standards, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHIEF URGES OVERSEAS TAIWANESE TO VOTE IN PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 12 (CNA) 06/13/07 13:25:38 (By Jaw-pyng Hwang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged Taiwanese people living in New York or other cities and states in the United States to return to their home country to vote in the next presidential election in 2008.

Yu Shyi-kun made the call Tuesday in a speech to more than 400 DPP supporters in New York, the last leg of his eight-day visit to the United States aimed at seeking overseas Taiwanese people's support for Frank Hsieh, the DPP's presidential candidate.
Yu called for the DPP supporters to fly back to Taiwan to cast their ballots for Hsieh, describing him as a person who can help transform Taiwan into a "normal country."

According to the DPP's assessment, around 25,000 DPP supporters living overseas returned to Taiwan to cast their ballots in the 2004 presidential election. That year, President Chen Shui-bian was re-elected. Yu said it is hoped that the number of DPP supporters returning to Taiwan for the next presidential election will be even higher.
Yu arrived in San Francisco June 6 for his U.S. visit, which then took him to Los Angeles and Houston. He is scheduled to fly back to Taiwan from New York June 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH GREETS TAIWAN'S REPRESENTATIVE IN PUBLIC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 12 (CNA) 06/13/07 14:25:47 (By Jorge Liu, Chiehyu Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush shook hands and chatted with Joseph Wu, Taiwan's representative to the United States, Tuesday while attending the dedication of a memorial to those killed by communist regimes around the world.
Wu was among the roughly 1,000 guests invited to the dedication ceremony for the Victims of Communism (VOC) Memorial near a square in front of the U.S. Congress.
Bush was invited to deliver a speech on the occasion. He greeted other guests after his speech. When it was Wu's turn, Wu introduced himself to Bush by saying: "I'm Ambassador Joseph Wu from Taiwan."
Wu also took the opportunity to thank Bush for his support for Taiwan and said Taiwan firmly supports U.S. efforts to spread the ideals of freedom and democracy around the world.
Bush thanked Wu and said: "It's good to see you here, " while tapping Wu's chest with his fist. He then autographed a VOC Memorial manual and gave it to Wu.

Since the United States switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979, Taiwan's representative to the United States has had few opportunities to chat or shake hands in public with any sitting U.S. president. Tuesday's brief encounter marked the first face-to-face exchange between Bush and Wu.

The VOC Memorial was more than a decade in the making. The U.S. Congress passed an act in 2003 on the establishment of the Victims of Communism Memorial Foundation to raise funds from around the world to build the monument in memory of the more than 100 million people killed by communist regimes, from China and the now-defunct Soviet Union to Cambodia and North Korea.

The Republic of China has donated money to the foundation in the name of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy. When a groundbreaking ceremony was held in September 2006, then-ROC Representative to the U.S. David Ta-wei Lee was also invited to witness the ceremony.
The dedication ceremony was co-chaired by Lee Edwards, chairman of the VOC Memorial Foundation; Rep. Tom Lantos, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee; and Rep. Dana Rohrabacher.

Rohrabacher spoke on the 20th anniversary of one of President Ronald Reagan's most famous moments -- a speech at the Berlin Wall in which he challenged Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev to "tear down this wall." It was the ultimate challenge of the Cold War, and the wall fell in 1989 as communist rule collapsed in East Germany and Soviet-dominated Eastern Europe.

For his part, Bush said it was time to recall the lessons of the Cold War, namely "that freedom is precious and cannot be taken for granted, that evil is real and must be confronted, and that given the chance, men commanded by harsh and hateful ideologies will commit unspeakable crimes and take the lives of millions."
At the center of the memorial is the figure of a woman holding what Bush called a "lamp of liberty."
"She reminds us that when an ideology kills tens of millions of people and still ends up being vanquished, it is contending with a power greater than death," Bush said.

Noting that the United States is obligated to seek justice for victims of communism, Bush said the his administration will continue to promote freedom and democracy in the hope that there will be no more victims of communism.

Wu said he attended the monument dedication with empathy as Taiwan, like many other countries, has been a victim of communism and now still faces serious military, security and health threats from communist China.

Because of China's obstruction, Wu said, the health of Taiwan's 23 million people is denied the protection of the World Health Organization. Against this backdrop, Wu said, Taiwan is more than willing to contribute to activities honoring memories and educating current and future generations about communism's crimes against humanity.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange were lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 23.87 points to close at 8,346.39.

The bourse opened at the day's high of 8,388.49 and dipped to a low of 8,336.53 during trading. A total of 4.39 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$130.57 billion (US$3.95 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.8 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.7 percent, textile stocks at 0.6 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.3 percent.
Plastics and chemicals shares and paper and pulp issues both remained unchanged.
Meanwhile, machinery and electronics shares moved down 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 695 to 448, with 198 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU LAWMAKERS APPEAL FOR AMNESTY FOR 'RICE BOMBER'

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislators appealed to President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday to grant amnesty to "rice bomber" Yang Ju-men on the grounds that Yang's conscience led him to break the law and that he never meant to hurt his fellow compatriots.

TSU Legislator Lai Shin-yuan said the TSU came up with a proposal at Tuesday's cross-party consultations that President Chen grant a special pardon to Yang, which Lai claimed received the support of caucus whips of various parties.
The "bombs" Yang planted in protest of rice imports "were more like firecrackers" and that he turned himself in after planting the explosive devices, Lai said.
The legislature is scheduled to once again review the amnesty draft bill Friday.

Lai said Yang should not be considered a common criminal since Yang had no intention of hurting the people of Taiwan while expressing his displeasure with the World Trade Organization's "exploitation of the disadvantaged" and his concerns about the current uncertainties facing Taiwan's agriculture sector.
Yang always left a note or a letter at the scene, identifying himself as an opponent of the government's rice import policy, according to Lai.

Unfortunately, Lai said, a Taipei court still sentenced Yang to five years and ten months in jail and handed him a fine of NT$100,000 (US$3,030) for placing 17 explosive devices in public places in northern Taiwan during a one-year period from November 2003.

TSU Legislator Lin Chih-chia said Yang's motive was aimed at raising public awareness of the plight of Taiwan's farmers. Noting that Yang has already served more than three years of his term, Lin said the president can consider granting him a presidential pardon.

Meanwhile, the whip of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus said that because Yang would not be entitled to benefit from any articles of the Cabinet-drafted amnesty bill even if it were to be passed into a law, the KMT caucus would cooperate with other parties' caucuses to jointly push for a special amnesty granted by the president.

President Chen Shui-bian announced April 24 that the government would implement a sentence commutation program to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident of 1947 and the 20th anniversary of the lifting of 38 years of martial law in 1987.

Although the Legislative Yuan's Judicial Committee passed the first reading of the amnesty bill presented by the Cabinet, the ruling and opposition parties remained divided over the threshold for sentence commutation and the reasons for the amnesty.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY WORKING TO PROVIDE TOILET PAPER AT ALL PUBLIC RESTROOMS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin reiterated Wednesday the city government's resolve to provide toilet paper in all public restrooms around the city.

Noting that more than half of the 10,500 public restrooms in Taipei City currently do not provide toilet paper, Hau said it is tantamount to punishing law-abiding people for those who manage public restrooms not to provide toilet paper out of concerns that the supply will be stolen.

Toilet paper is now provided free of charge at almost all public hospitals and MRT stations around Taipei, but it is still not provided at most of the restrooms in markets, parks and other public facilities.

Hau said the city government will try harder to improve the situation by demanding that public restroom management make sure that every toilet in public restrooms is stocked with toilet paper while also coming up with measures to more effectively deal with the problem of theft of toilet paper from the restrooms.
Hau also appealed to the people of the city to display more public mindedness by refraining from taking toilet paper from public restrooms.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO STEP UP EFFORTS AGAINST HUMAN TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung pledged Wednesday that the government will step up its efforts to combat human trafficking, following the country's removal from a U.S. watch list for the trafficking problem.

Making the remarks during a weekly Cabinet meeting, Chang said the fact that the United States has removed Taiwan from the "Tier 2 Watch List" indicates that the United States has noticed the country's hard work in fighting human trafficking over the past year.
However, Taiwan must not be complacent about the achievement, Chang said, adding that it is the Cabinet's goal in the coming year to continue to work to have Taiwan's ranking upgraded to "Tier 1."

In the Trafficking in Persons Report 2007 released by the U.S. Department of State Tuesday, Taiwan has been reinstated on the list of "Tier 2" countries because while the island's trafficking problems remain daunting, Taiwan authorities showed clear progress in addressing trafficking for both sexual and labor exploitation over the past year.
Taiwan was placed on the list of "Tier 1" countries in the 2003 and 2004 reports but was downgraded to "Tier 2" in the 2005 report.
In the 2006 report, Taiwan was placed on the "Tier 2 Watch List" for not fully complying with the minimum standards for the elimination of human trafficking.
Chang instructed the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) to meet with concerned authorities to review and improve the government's measures against human trafficking.
Chang said the MOI should cooperate with the Ministry of Justice to work out a law on the prevention of human trafficking.

Also, to prevent the exploitation of foreign workers, the Council of Labor Affairs should review its policy toward foreign workers, such as the method in which foreign workers are imported into the country, the restrictions faced by foreign workers in changing employers and the penalties for law-breaking employers, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved down seven points to close at 8,331, with 27,311 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for July dropped eight points to finish at 8,282, with 4,663 contracts traded, while September futures lost one point to close at 8,145, with 71 contract transactions. December futures moved down four points to finish at 8,140, with nine contracts traded, while March futures dropped seven points to close at 8,141, with 11 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 8,338 for June, 8,290 for July, 8,146 for September, 8,144 for December and 8,148 for March.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

June TE futures moved down 1.55 points to close at 360.85, with 2,642 contracts traded, while July TE futures dropped 0.8 points to finish at 358.2, with 343 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

June TF futures rose six points to close at 968, with 2,951 contracts traded, while July TF futures gained 2.2 points to finish at 962.6, with 1,291 contract transactions. September TF futures moved up 2.8 points to close at 955.4, with 36 contracts traded, while December TF futures lost five points to close at 958, with nine contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR PRESENTS FLAG TO TAIPEI DELEGATION TO INT'L CHILDREN'S GAMES

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin presented a flag Wednesday to the city's delegation of athletes taking part in the 2007 International Children's Games (ICG) slated to be held in Reykjavik, Iceland June 20-24.
Wu Ching-chi, director of the city government's Department of Education, will lead the Taipei delegation to the event. The delegation is scheduled to depart July 19.
Athletes from a total of 66 cities around the world will compete in the games, which are aimed at strengthening friendship among schoolchildren around the world via sports.
Taipei City will send 17 athletes to vie for medals in four events -- swimming, badminton, judo and golf. Wu predicted that the Taipei team should be able to win more than five gold medals.
Hau encouraged the Taipei athletes to strive for victory while also trying to make friends during the event.

As an incident occurred at last year's ICG held in Bangkok in which Chinese officials forcefully seized two Republic of China flags being carried by Taiwanese athletes at a medal presentation ceremony, Hau asked the team members to inform city representatives immediately if a similar incident occurs at this year's games.

Stressing that sports should be kept separate from politics, Wu said the ICG organizers decided after last year's incident that they will set no restrictions on the displaying of national flags of any country at any venue of the games.
As Beijing will not send athletes to this year's games, with only a team from Macao set to participate in the event, Wu said he doesn't expect a repeat of last year's incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL ANALYST CALLS FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese financial analyst warned Tuesday that Taiwan might risk missing out on a global economic boom if its leader fails to negotiate with China to launch direct flights across the Taiwan Strait.
Hsieh Chin-ho, executive director of Wealth magazine, made the remarks while delivering a speech at a monthly luncheon hosted by the European Chamber of Commerce in Taipei.

Since 2000, most countries around the world have enjoyed unprecedented economic growth, according to Hsieh, who added that except for Thailand, Japan and Taiwan, other Asian countries have recorded brilliant performances, with the stock market index in many countries posting a whopping five-fold increase.
He said Taiwan's economic performance is undermined by the government's mismanagement of cross-strait relations.

The opening of cross-strait links is "unavoidable, " Hsieh claimed, saying that he has suggested that main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying- jeou and ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Frank Hsieh push for more open cross-strait policies.

The DPP candidate has a much more open attitude on relaxation of cross-strait restrictions than President Chen Shui-bian and many other DPP heavyweights, as he advocates cross-strait conciliation and co-existence, according to Hsieh.
However, he predicted that no matter who is elected president in 2008, there will be substantive improvement in cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAP SMEARS FAIL TO DETECT CERVICAL CANCER IN HUALIEN WOMAN

TEXT.P: A woman in eastern Hualien County has been diagnosed with cervical cancer six years after she contracted the disease, even though she has received pap smear screening annually for the past five years, doctors said Wednesday.
The 33-year-old patient, who is married with two children, displayed normal results for her pap smears for five consecutive years, the doctors said.
However, she was diagnosed with cervical cancer that she had had for six years only after receiving her sixth annual pap smear this year, they said.

Liao Chi-yuan, a gynecologist and obstetrician at Hualien's Mennonite Christian Hospital, noted that there is only a 60 percent-80 percent accuracy rate for conventional pap smear screening that uses a manual method to review samples.
Liao suggested that women make sure their pap smears are reviewed using computer-aided imaging, which is not covered by National Health Insurance.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE MAGPIE BEING HUNTED TO PROTECT TAIWAN'S ENDEMIC BIRDS

TEXT.P: Work to hunt down Chinese magpies in mountainous areas of central Taiwan in an effort to protect Taiwan's endemic species has begun to bear fruit, Taichung county government officials reported Wednesday.

So far this year, three adult Chinese magpies, four young and six eggs of the species have been found by "ecological police" authorized by the Endemic Species Research Institute (ESRI) under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).
The captured birds have been temporarily housed at the ESRI headquarters before being handed over to Taipei Zoo, the officials with the Taichung County Department of Agriculture said.
The sweeping action, sponsored by the ESRI, the COA Forestry Department and the Taichung County Department of Agriculture, has been focusing on the Wulin area in deep mountains of Taichung County.

The department began hunting down the Chinese magpies over the last year after receiving complaints by mountain climbers and wildlife conservationists that the birds have often been spotted in the Wulin area and out of concern that their growing numbers could pose a serious problem to the Formosan blue magpie, which is an endemic species.
Chinese magpies were reportedly spotted for the first time in 2002 in the area.
Since sightings have continued to be reported despite the capture of some birds, the officials said the hunt will continue.
Magpies, whose chattering is said to signify good news, is a symbol of happiness in Chinese culture.
Adult Formosan blue magpies have steel blue coloring on their wings and shining- black crests, while the Chinese magpies have white crests.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: A fresh row over phone tap erupted between Italian government entities Tuesday after newspapers published extracts of phone taps involving key figures in the ruling center-left coalition. Interior Minister Giuliano Amato described the publication as an "Italian madness" and expressed exasperation over the failure of the judiciary to keep phone tap stuffs under wraps.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTETRNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post: Fenty Criticized For Secrecy of Schools Choice; Rhee's Selection, a Shock To Many, Draws Scrutiny. District leaders stood beside Michelle A. Rhee on the steps of city hall yesterday as a show of public support for the newly nominated D.C. schools chancellor, but they complained behind the scenes about the secrecy with which Mayor Adrian M. Fenty made his surprise selection.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO SPEND NT$100 BILLION ON RURAL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved Wednesday a package of draft acts and bills and agreed to earmark NT$100 billion (US$3 billion) to reform rural areas in the coming 10 years.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced the passage of the draft acts and bills during a weekly Cabinet meeting and called on the Legislative Yuan to screen them and give its final approval as soon as possible to help the Executive Yuan step up its pace of improving the people's livelihoods.

As part of its efforts to live up to its promises to take care of the needs of the underprivileged and boost development in rural regions, Chang said, the government will do its utmost to improve infrastructure in the countryside and upgrade the living standards of rural residents.

If the Legislative Yuan approves the measures, the government estimated that public infrastructure in some 4,000 farming villages can be improved and more than 500,000 houses in such villages can be renovated, he said.

With the completion of the high-speed railway and more expressways, the increasingly comprehensive traffic network can more effectively connect city centers and rural areas around the country, he said.

The Executive Yuan will also allow more farmland to be rezoned for constructing high-end, low-population density residency communities as long as doing so will not hobble agricultural production and the rural environment, he went on.

Speaking after the weekly Executive Yuan meeting, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairwoman Ho Mei-yueh said that NT$50 billion is budgeted to subsidize reforms and build farmhouses, while another NT$50 billion will be used for improving or constructing infrastructure in rural areas.
According to Ho, at least 10,000 hectares of farmland across the country will be rezoned in a decade for residential communities of at least 25 hectares each.
In response to public concerns over profiteering from land speculation, Ho replied that the government will set strict thresholds for buyers wishing to purchase farmland plots.

If house developers fail to use land plots they have purchased within a certain time limit, the government will be entitled to rescind their land development rights and open fresh bids to search for new developers, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES BUDGET CARRIER OPENS TAIPEI-MANILA ROUTE

TEXT.P: Cebu Pacific Air, a budget carrier based in the Philippines, opened Wednesday a Taipei-Manila route for NT$588 (US$18) per single trip, its agent in Taiwan announced that day.
The special offer will be in place for three months and the single-trip price will cost over NT$1,388 after the three-month period ends, according to the local agent.
Cebu Pacific Air will use brand new 179-seat A320 airplanes to ply the two-hour daily route, it said, adding that seats already fully booked until the end of this month.

Cebu Pacific Air, established in 1996, operates low-cost flights from the Philippines to seven another destinations in Asia, including Hong Kong, Singapore, Bangkok, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Seoul and Busan.
It is the second low-cost foreign-based aviation company that has opened a route to Taiwan, after Singapore-based Jetstar Asia Airways.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, rising NT$0.019 to close at NT$33.039.
A total of US$619 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.990 and fluctuated between NT$32.923 and NT$33.045.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-HONG KONG RELATIONS ON WANE: EX-REPRESENTATIVE OF TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 13 (CNA) 06/13/07 19:07:53 (By Lo Kin-fai and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong have been on the wane since the former British colony was returned to Chinese rule in 1997, a former Taiwan representative to Hong Kong reportedly told a Hong Kong media outlet Wednesday.

Cheng An-kuo, former managing director of the Chung Hwa Travel Service -- the de facto Taiwan liaison office in Hong Kong in the absence of formal bilateral relations -- was quoted by the online Hong Kong Commercial Broadcasting Co. as saying that despite ever-closer private sector exchanges, overall ties have regressed over the past decade.

Cheng attributed the regression mainly to the facts that the Hong Kong authorities have been lukewarm about cementing ties with Taiwan and the lack of an efficient channel of contact between the two sides, according to the report.
Cheng added that after Hong Kong's transition, the number of Hong Kong students seeking education in Taiwan has also declined noticeably -- down from over 3,000 10 years ago to fewer than 900.

The report also quoted some Taiwan businessmen as telling the broadcasting company that after Hong Kong's transition, official ties between Taiwan and Hong Kong became cooler and cooler and many Taiwanese businessmen chose to invest in China as a result of "warmer and warmer" hospitality that they received from the Chinese authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE CALLS ON INDIAN MINISTERS
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, India, June 13 (CNA) 06/13/07 19:48:06 (By Chen Yi-wei, Paul Kuo and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou called on two Indian ministers Tuesday during a whirlwind two-day visit to the South Asian country to exchange views on economic and information technology industry cooperation.

Ma, a former KMT chairman and former Taipei mayor, arrived in India earlier that day and reached consensus during a meeting with Indian Minister of Communications and Information Technology Dayanidhi Maran and Minister of Commerce and Industry Kamal Nath on the need to enhance cooperation in the information technology field, for India's prominence in computer software production can complement Taiwan's excellent computer hardware production industry.

He also gave a speech titled "The Role of Taiwan's Economy in Regional and International Environment" at the Indian Council of World Affairs, which is the country's most authoritative unofficial think tank.
According to Ma's staff, he reiterated in the speech that Taiwan should ease cross-Taiwan Strait tension and reinforce international cooperation.
After finishing the first day of his visit, Ma told Taiwanese journalists who accompanied him on the trip that India's incumbent and former foreign affairs officials were present at his speech.
Chinese, American, Russian and Indian reporters also attended.

Ma also said Taiwan should consider operating flights serving the route between Taiwan and Chennai, which is India's technology stronghold and a stronghold for Taiwanese businessmen, to bring convenience for future cooperation.
He expressed hope that his two-day visit will contribute to bilateral relations.
Ma's second day itinerary included a visit to India's ruling Congress Party leader Dr. Karan Singh, and a meeting with Rajnath Singh, chairman of the largest opposition Bharatiya Janata Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: `NO NEED TO OVERSPECULATE' ON BRIBERY SCANDALS: DPP LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: There is "no need to overspeculate" that lawmakers took bribes from the Taiwan Dental Association (TDA) now that prosecutors are looking into the matter, a lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed Wednesday.

Ker Chien-ming, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, made the remarks after a special investigation unit under the Supreme Prosecutors Office raided a day earlier 21 dental associations around the country and questioned 27 people, including Nantou County Speaker Wu Chi-hsiang, a former executive director of the Taiwan Dental Association, and Chen Shih-chung, vice minister of the Department of Health (DOH) and a former president of the Taipei Dental Association.

The unit launched the raid after being tipped off that the TDA, fearing that the second-generation national health insurance program might not cover dental care, promoted an oral health bill that cleared the legislature in April 2003.

The TDA solicited funds from its members to lobby for the passage of the bill and investigators suspect that some funds might have been used as rewards for a legislator identified only as Lai and his colleagues, while some might have lined the pockets of TDA officials, the reports said.

Ker, a lawmaker with a dental background, claimed that the bill "was never controversial and had no interests involved. Now that the special investigation unit has begun to probe the matter, there is no need to overspeculate or make judgment."

He also said that after the passage of the political donation law in 2004, any groups can contribute as long as they comply with the regulations, adding that the DPP is more concerned about political parties' donations to candidates.

DPP Legislator Lin Chin-hsin, who is a practicing doctor, claimed that it is "only natural" that medical groups will chip in for legislators with medical backgrounds during elections because they hope that the legislators would push for bills relevant to their interests.
"But if some legislators receive money for the passage of a specific bill, then that is illegal," Lin added.
Meanwhile, DPP Legislator William Lai said he never received any illicit money to help the passage of a bill during his three terms as a legislator.

Lai said the oral health bill received the support of the DOH and that he reviewed the bill in a professional way at the time. "Since no other lawmakers had different views, its passage was only natural," he added.

He said that coming from a medical background, he has received donations from his friends in the medical sector for years, adding that he would have to check which medical groups offered support when the oral health bill was passed four years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OPTOELECTRONICS PRODUCTION TO ACCOUNT FOR 14% OF GLOBAL SHARE

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's optoelectronics industry is expected to reach NT$1.46 trillion (US$45 billion) this year, accounting for 14 percent of the global share, according to statistics released Wednesday by the organizers of the Photonics Festival Taiwan 2007.
The Photonics Festival Taiwan 2007, which comprises the International Optoelectronic Exposition, LED Lighting Taiwan and Solar Taiwan, began that same day at the Taipei World Trade Center.

Several government officials and industrial representatives attended the opening ceremony of the event, which is being organized by the Photonics Industry and Technology Development Association (PIDA), the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), and the Taipei Computer Association (TCA).

According to Chen Chao-yi, director-general of the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the production of Taiwan's optoelectronics industry totalled NT$1.27 trillion in 2006, with both the value of its production and global share surpassing that of South Korea, Taiwan's biggest competitor in this regard.

Tai Chien, vice chairman of National Science Council (NSC) expressed hope that the Photonics Festival can be combined with Computex Taipei, which was touted as the world's second largest information technology products exhibition, in a bid to further strengthen its competitiveness.

Noting that the optoelectronics industry is a key item that will help Taiwan reduce its unemployment rate and make the nation's scientific parks grow rapidly, Tai urged Taiwanese optoelectronics entrepreneurs to boost both production and research and investigation amid strong competition from South Korea.
A total of 304 companies from around the world are participating in the Photonics Festival, which will continue until June 16.

As a sideline of the festival, the organizers will present a number of seminars and conferences for the visitors, including a speech by Shuji Nakamura, the Japanese inventor of the blue light-emitting diode (LED), who is expected to talk about the newest blue LED and LD technology.
Seventeen LED experts from around the world, including Japan, the United States and China, will also be invited to deliver speeches on LED technological developments, market trends and patent issues.

The organizers will for the first time hold a forum on thin film photovoltaic (PV) products, in which foreign experts will be invited to share with participants Germany's experience in developing solar power and elevating the efficiency of solar cells.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AIRLINE PILOTS FREE TO WORK IN CHINA: AVIATION OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: In response to a report that more of Taiwan's civil airline pilots will choose to work for China-based carriers, a government official in charge said Wednesday that it is a personal matter and that the government respects their career development choices.

Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Billy K. C. Chang made the comments after the Taiwan Civil Aviation Pilots Association revealed that some 18 Taiwanese airline pilots are planning to work for China-based aviation companies in the near term, possibly including Sichuan Airlines, Shenzhen AirLines, Hainan Airlines and Xiamen Airlines.
Stressing that the CAA fully respects civil airplane pilots' personal career development plans, Chang said that they are free to choose to work for home- based or foreign-based aviation companies.

According to the association, salaries provided by China-based carriers are quite attractive to Taiwan pilots, taking into consideration the cheaper living costs in China and additional special monthly allowances provided by Chinese aviation companies.
It was understood that the 18 Taiwan pilots planning to work for Chinese airlines will be offered a monthly salary of 60,000 yuan.
Through the association's arrangement, eight pilots from several Taiwan-based aviation companies opted in 2005 to work for Sichuan Airlines.

Taiwan's civilian pilots have long been unhappy with the low monthly salaries provided by local carriers compared to those enjoyed by their foreign counterparts who receive an average monthly pay of at least US$10,000, in addition to other benefits, according to association officials.
The association has been pushing for the enactment of a "civil airplane pilot law" with an aim of redressing the imbalance and addressing local pilots' rights and interests, they explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORK FOR 8.1 YEARS WITHOUT ANY SPENDING TO BUY A TAIPEI HOUSE: CEPD

TEXT.P: If you were able to work for 8.1 years consecutively without spending any money, you might be able to purchase a house in Taipei, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Wednesday.
CEPD officials said that average house prices were 8.1 times greater than the average annual income in Taipei during the first quarter of this year, compared with 6.6 times nationwide.
Although the 8.1 times figure in Taipei may seem high, it is a decrease from 8.8 times the previous quarter, showing that house buyers have become more cautious in purchasing houses.
National Chengchi University professor Chang Chin-oh said that housing loans accounted, on average, for 29.9 percent of monthly income in the first quarter of this year in Taiwan.

Both house prices and loans in Taipei were the highest among all cities and counties in Taiwan, said Chang, noting that housing loans accounted for 37.1 percent of monthly incomes in the first quarter of this year in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOG OWNER SENTENCED TO 30 DAYS IN JAIL AFTER DOG INJURES PASSERBY

TEXT.P: A man living in Taipei County was sentenced to 30 days in detention for an injury his dog caused to a passerby, Taipei District Court officials said Wednesday.

The 57-year dog owner, surnamed Wu, did not have his door completely closed Jan. 17, when his dog, unleashed and unmuzzled, ran out onto the street and attacked a passing woman. The woman, who was injured on her left leg, filed a law suit with the court.

According to the ruling of Taipei District Court, Wu should have been aware that dogs are aggressive in certain situations, and that owners should therefore leash their dogs or muzzle them to prevent their animals from assaulting others.
The judge found that the owner was responsible for failing to attend to his dog's situation. However, the detention sentence can be commuted to a fine, at rate of NT$1,000 (US$30) per day.
According to the sentence, the case may be appealed to a higher court.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL LOSSES INCREASE TO US$6.92 MILLION

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses in 13 cities and counties have increased to NT$228.27 million (US$6.92 million) as of Wednesday after days of rains, the latest statistics released by the Council of Agriculture (COA) show.
COA officials said that the losses included damaged crops, agricultural lands being washed away or submerged, as well as forestry losses.

Of all agricultural products, watermelons losses were the most serious, with 1,132 hectares of watermelon fields being submerged under water, followed by persimmon losses, of which 823 hectares were affected.
Other crops affected include grapes, melon, scallions, and leafy vegetables.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Attacks Escalate as Palestinians Fight for Power
Gunmen of rival Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah sharply escalated their fight for supremacy on Tuesday, with Hamas taking over much of the northern Gaza Strip in what is beginning to look increasingly like a civil war.
Five days of revenge attacks on individuals X including executions, kneecappings and even tossing handcuffed prisoners off tall apartment towers X on Tuesday turned into something larger and more organized: attacks on symbols of power and the deployment of military units. About 25 Palestinians were killed and more than 100 wounded, Palestinian medics said.
Wall Street Journal:How Blackstone's Chief Became $7 Billion Man
Stephen Schwarzman, who stands 5-foot-6, describes himself as a scrappy "little man" who finds ways to win. When he pursues deals as the chief executive of Blackstone Group, he says, he wants to "inflict pain" on and "kill off" his rivals.
Later this month, the giant buyout firm intends to go public, offering many investors their first opportunity to share the kill. If there was ever a doubt about what investors will be buying, a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Monday cleared that up: Mr. Schwarzman utterly dominates the firm. He stands to pocket as much as $677.2 million, and will retain a 23% stake in Blackstone, likely to be worth more than $7.5 billion. enditem

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD ACT AS APEC MODEL IN MARKET OPENNESS: FORMER PREMIER

TEXT.P: Opening is the only way for Taiwan to have endless energy in promoting economic development, therefore Taiwan should try to open its market to all Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) members to display support for an APEC proposal for a free trade area of the Asia Pacific (FTAAP) , former Premier Vincent Siew said Wednesday.

Taiwan should try to act as a model in regional organization in the field of market openness, said Siew, who is chairman of the Taipei-based Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research (CIER) , in a speech to the Taipei International Economic and Trade Forum, held by the Importers and Exporters Association of Taipei (IEAT).

In the speech titled the "History and Future Prospects of Taiwan's Trade Development, " Siew said the government should be aggressive and active in opening doors to foreign investors and should make efforts to turn Taiwan into the largest free trade zone in the world.

Reviewing Taiwan's economic development over the past 300 years, Siew said Taiwan began its foreign trading practices in the 17th century, when the Dutch colonized the island. In those days, deerskins and sugar were exported in massive amounts.
Since then, Siew went on, foreign trade has been the water on which Taiwan depends for survival.

Taiwan created many economic miracles before China announced an opening and reform-oriented policy in 1978. "While it (China) slept, we (Taiwan) ran, " Siew said, adding that Taiwan had taken good advantage of development opportunities during the era of a closed China.

Addressing economic development in East Asia, Siew brought up the "flying-geese" model, that originated from a view of Japanese scholars upon technological development in Southeast Asia, looking at Japan as a leading power. He said countries in the region have built a highly professional industrial manufacturing network, with each of them making different contributions to the network.

The lead goose in this pattern is Japan, while the second-tier of nations consists of South Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong. After these two groups come the emerging countries including China, Indonesia, Thailand and Vietnam, Siew said.

Taiwan has to continue its opening to secure its position in the flying-geese line as the second important provider of key parts and components in Asia to the global manufacturing sector following Japan, in the face of strong competition from China, Siew said, advising Taiwan to secure key technologies by continuing to seek technological upgrading and innovation.
The economic forum was attended by representatives of the IEAT's sister organizations in Britain, the United States and South Korea, as well as those of Japanese and domestic business groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA'S POLITICAL DONATION CASE CLOSED: TAIPEI DISTRICT COURT

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou's political donation case has been closed by the Taipei District Prosecutors Office, according to a press release issued by the Taipei District Court Wednesday.

The statement said that the case was closed by prosecutor Chou Shih-yu Feb. 24, 2007, a move approved by the former Chief Prosecutor Yen Ta-ho. Therefore, the case will not be transferred for trial at the Taipei District Court.

The case stemmed from a complaint made by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator Hsu Chia-chin who claimed that Ma Ying-jeou last November had received illegal political funding during his run for the KMT chairmanship in 2005.

Although Ma spent more than NT$20 million (US$605, 345) on campaign advertising, Hsu claimed Ma's personal assets increased NT$4.4 million in that year. She accused Ma of accepting electoral donations, which is not allowed while running for party chairman because the position is not a part of the civil service.

The Taipei District Court's statement said the prosecutor closed the case on the ground that the allegations, even proved to be true, are punishable by administrative sanctions and do not constitute a criminal case.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUCHANG HIGHWAY CONNECTING HUALIEN, TAITUNG TO BE INAUGURATED FRIDAY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) decided Wednesday to open the long-awaited Yuchang Highway in the eastern region of Taiwan to traffic June 16.

The 16.2 km highway, also known as the Provincial Highway No. 30, runs between Yuli township of Hualien County, and Changpin township in Taichung county, passing through a tunnel over 2.6 km in length, according to the MOTC.

With the opening of the new road, the driving time between the two townships will be cut from two hours to less than 30 minutes. It is expected that as soon as it is inaugurated the highway will bring more tourists to the scenic but rugged area between the east coast and the East Rift Valley, MOTC officials said.
Construction of the two-track highway began in January 2004 and was not completed until May 2007, at a price of NT$2.55 billion (US$77 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT COSTA RICAN STUDENTS MAY CONTINUE STUDIES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Eight college students from Costa Rica may continue their studies in Taiwan on scholarships provided by the Republic of China government despite the recent termination of diplomatic ties between the two countries.

Lee Tian-shiang, vice president of Kung Shan University of Technology in Tainan County, said that the eight students from Costa Rica will be able to carry on with their studies at the university despite recent events.

According to Lee, officials with the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs expressed a willingness to continue providing university scholarships to the Costa Rican students during a recent meeting to discuss their status.
Before that meeting, the university was ready to offer its own scholarships to the Costa Rican students so as to help them complete their studies, Lee said.

Although Costa Rica and Taiwan last week severed their 63-year-old diplomatic partnership, ICDF officials said that the ROC government was poised to continue assisting these students and help them complete their academic pursuits in Taiwan as part of its efforts to maintain good links between the private sectors of the two countries.
According to ICDF officials, the scholarships are provided to help Taiwan's diplomatic partners educate their students and train them to acquire professional skills to better serve their homelands.

After learning the good news, the eight Costa Rican students held up banners and posters expressing their love for Taiwan, the ICDF and the university, vowing to do their best to help step up bilateral relations in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP ENCOURAGES WOMEN TO JOIN SOCIAL WELFARE ACTIVITIES

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu encouraged women in a speech delievered in Chiayi City, southern Taiwan, Tuesday to step out of the family sphere and participate in public welfare activities.
Lu spoke on the role of women in social welfare activities at Chiayi City Council at the invitation of Lions Club International 300D1.
Lu said that the working abilities of Taiwanese women have been increasing, with the number of Taiwanese women achieving college diplomas now 20 times greater than 30 years ago.
Also, Lu said that research shows some 87 percent of Taiwanese women are willing to work abroad, indicating that women have their own career ambitions.
As a woman, Lu said she was able to contribute to several issues related to social welfare during her term as Taiwan's vice president.
For example, she proposed a program to train and certify single mothers to care for the elderly and young. Currently, more than 68,000 women are enrolled in the training program.

Moreover, Lu spoke of introducing a program that invites college students and retired teachers to provide free homework counseling to kids from troubled families. About 3,000 kids in 128 classes are now receiving free counseling, Lu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT URGES TAIWAN TO DEAL BETTER WITH HUMAN TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's efforts to combat human trafficking have been recognized but it must demonstrate greater political will in dealing with the problem, the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said Wednesday in a statement after the release of the U.S. State Department's 2007 Trafficking in Persons (TIP) Report.

For 2007, Taiwan is classified as a "Tier 2" country and has been removed from a U.S. watch list because of its significant efforts to eliminate trafficking, the AIT said, adding that the most notable achievements are "the development of Taiwan's first comprehensive plan of action that covers all forms of human trafficking, plus the formation of an inter-ministerial committee to implement the plan in coordination with non-governmental organizations."

It pointed out, however, that trafficking victims should be granted formal protection, including access to justice, in order to obtain compensation from those who have exploited them, while victims should also have the right to work while awaiting the outcome of court cases.

It called for the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to stop addressing instances of involuntary servitude with administrative penalties. Instead, it should refer such cases for criminal investigation and possible prosecution. It also said the Taiwan authorities should do more to eliminate the ability of labor brokers and employers to deport workers against their will.

Taiwan was placed on the list of "Tier 1" countries in the 2003 and 2004 reports but was downgraded to "Tier 2" in the 2005 report. In 2006, Taiwan was placed on the "Tier 2 Watch List" for not fully complying with the minimum standards for the elimination of human trafficking.
AIT said it will continue to increase public awareness of the suffering caused by trafficking by working with Taiwan officials and non-government organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA TO MAKE SPLASH AT TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL FOOD SHOW

TEXT.P: More than 30 Canadian companies will participate in the 2007 Taipei International Food Show in the hope of boosting declining food-related Canadian exports to Taiwan, the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei (CTOT) said Wednesday.

The Canadian companies will present ginseng, Saskatoon berries, organic blueberries and high-protein nutrition supplements, as well as other products from Ontario, Alberta, British Columbia, Quebec and other provinces at the food show, which will take place at the Taipei World Trade Center June 21-24 with 589 exhibitors from all over the world displaying their wares in 1,600 booths.

Canadian agri-food, fish and seafood exports to Taiwan were valued at US$200.6 million in 2006, a significant decline of 17 percent from the 2005 value of US$249.2 million, according to the statistics of the "Agri-food: Past, Present and Future Report" released by the Canadian government in February 2007.

The decline was due to decreased shipments of many of Canada's most important agri-food exports such as cowhides, swine, canola oil and fish and crustacean exports, the report states, noting that goods such as cowhides, canola oil and colza oil make up the majority of exports to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG Arthritis drugs offer fresh hope at a price Tens of thousands of patients crippled by rheumatoid arthritis can expect dramatic improvements in their treatment with the arrival of a new class of smart drugs, scientists said today. A study of three medications has shown that they can reduce the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis, the debilitating joint disease, by about 50 per cent. Experts say the drugs will help liberate many sufferers with severe disease from pain and allow them to lead a near-normal life.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIR HOPES TO MEET PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES DURING TAIWAN VISIT

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt said Wednesday that he hopes to meet with the 2008 presidential candidates of two major parties in Taiwan.
Burghardt made the remarks shortly after arriving at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.
This is his second visit to Taiwan following his appointment as AIT chairman last February.

Describing his visit a regular one, Burghardt said that he has not visited Taiwan for a long while, without further commenting on whether he will meet President Chen Shui-bian or whether he brings any messages from the U.S. government.
Burghardt is expected to meet with Taipei-based American representatives from all sectors as well as local Taiwanese business people.
Burghardt served as the AIT Taipei Office director between 1999- 2001, as well as US ambassador to Vietnam and US consul-general in Shanghai.
He concurrently acts as director for the East and West Center in Honolulu, Hawaii.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN JOURNALISTS VISIT LOCAL UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: More than 30 Asian correspondents from foreign media organizations visited National Sun Yat-Sen University in southern port city of Kaohsiung Tuesday to discuss elections as well as social and economic issues in Taiwan.

Lin Wen-cheng, dean of the university's Graduate Institute of Social Sciences, Assistant Professor Liu Cheng-shan of the Graduate Institute of Political Science and the city's Bureau of Urban Development Director-General Lin Chin- rong exchanged their views with the representatives.

Speaking on last year's Kaohsiung mayoral election, Liu said that in order to improve the accuracy of opinion polls, the pollsters should ask those interviewed which local TV station rather than which candidate they like most.
During the mayoral election, many polls showed greater voter support for the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate, so the outcome came as a surprise, Liu said.
This indicates that the polls were very inaccurate, according to Liu, who claimed that polls conducted by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) were the most accurate.
Expressing his views on voter preference in southern Taiwan, Lin Chin-rong said that previous KMT national administrations focused their policies on the development of the capital, Taipei.

Frank Hsieh, DPP candidate for the 2008 presidential election, said that more government resources should be allocated to southern Taiwan, an issue expected to draw the attention of southern voters, Lin Chin-rong said.
Responding to the foreign media's concern with the military standoff between Taiwan and China, Lin Wen-cheng said that there is no denying that China has a greater military power than Taiwan.

However, as long as the people of Taiwan, across political spectrum, are united he does not think that China will attempt to take over Taiwan, Lin Wen- cheng noted, while adding that he believes no one in Taiwan will purposefully provoke China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 14, or the 29th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: The US Congress adopts the "Stars and Stripes" as the official flag of the United States.
1838: Yamagata Aritomo, Japanese soldier and twice prime minister, is born. He played a major role in turning Japan into a formidable military power.
1894: After displaying the first commercial motion-picture machine at the World's Colombian Exposition in 1893, Thomas Alva Edison's company presents the first sports-related movie on boxing.
1900: The first Grand Prix, or international car race, takes place in Paris.
1920: In China, war between the Chihli and Anhwei warlords breaks out. Tsao Kun of the Chihli faction and Chang Tso-lin of the Fengtien faction join forces to fight against Tuan Chi-jui of the Anhwei faction.
1936: Chang Tai-yen, a noted scholar of Chinese literature, dies in Soochow at the age of 67.
1940: German troops march into Paris, and the flag of Nazi Germany, bearing the swastika, is hoisted up the Eiffel Tower.
1941: President Franklin D. Roosevelt orders the freezing of all German and Italian assets in the United States.
1943: The Battle of West Hupeh ends with Japanese troops driven back to their previous positions.
1949: Bao Dai is installed as president of Vietnam.
1952: The Nautilus, the first nuclear-powered submarine, is put on public display in the United States.
1955: The Republic of China and the United States sign an agreement in Washington on the peaceful use of nuclear energy.
1964: In the ROC, the NT$3.2 billion multipurpose Shihmen Dam is dedicated.
1971: The Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Communications is inaugurated in Taipei.
1973: A 10-member Chinese national judo team headed by Mao Ming-chu leaves for Lausanne to take part in the 8th world championships.
1974: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung and Deputy Premier Cuthbert Edwy Talma of the Barbados sign a joint communique in Taipei announcing the extension of the Sino- Barbados agricultural technical cooperation agreement.
1975: More than 500 Chinese poets and Dr. Jeno Platthy, chairman of the Organizing Committee of the Third World Congress of Poets, gathered in Taipei to celebrate Chinese Poets Day and pay homage to poet Chu Yuan of the period of Spring and Autumn Annals.
1978: A technical cooperation agreement between Saudi Arabia and the Republic of China is signed.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Huang Shao-ku and Hung Shou-nan as president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan, respectively, following unanimous approval by the Control Yuan.
1982: Argentine troops surrender to the British commander of land forces in the Falklands, marking the end of a six-week conflict that cost 254 British and 750 Argentine lives.
1982: President Chiang Ching-kuo visits the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Taipei to extend his condolences over the passing of King Khalid ibn abdul Aziz.
1989: Former governor of California and US President Ronald Reagan is knighted by Queen Elizabeth II.
1992: Ronald Freeman, vice president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, visits the ROC to discuss Sino-European trade and financial relations.
2000: U.S. President Bill Clinton sends his greetings to the participants in the 24th annual Joint Business Conference of the U.S.-ROC (Taiwan) and ROC-U.S.A. Business Councils, which kicks off in Taipei.
2001: A 23-member mainland Chinese delegation arrives in Taipei to take part in an unprecedented cross-Taiwan Strait long-distance race as part of a campaign for mainland China's bid to win the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Your meek men of respectability, are they who unmercifully destroy all sense of moral sentiment in man."

DOC.HEADLINE: SWISS RETURN PART OF 'LAFAYETTE' KICKBACKS TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 13 (CNA) 06/14/07 11:35:36 (By Y.C. Jou and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Swiss authorities Wednesday returned to Taiwan US$34 million in frozen bank deposits believed to be illicit kickbacks connected to the purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates from France in 1991, Swiss officials said.
Officials at the Swiss Department of Justice said the returned funds belonged to two different holders but declined to identify them.

The officials noted that according to Switzerland's Federal Act on International Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters, frozen capital assets can be released to foreign authorities if the assets are evidently related to criminal activities.
The funds were handed over to Taiwanese authorities on the condition that the legal proceedings against the two concerned persons would comply with human rights principles, they said.

The sum is part of a total of US$520 million that Taiwan has sought to recover from a number of frozen Swiss bank accounts belonging to several Taiwanese holders involved in the scandal, including fugitive arms broker Andrew Wang and members of his family, as well as former naval officer Kuo Li-heng and his brother Kuo Wen-tien.
Proceedings for the retrieval of the remaining funds are still underway, the officials said.

Wang, the French arms supplier Thompson-CSF's agent in Taiwan, fled the country following the death of Navy Capt. Yin Ching-feng under suspicious circumstances in late 1993. Yin is believed to have been poised to blow the whistle on colleagues who had allegedly received kickbacks from the Lafayette deal. Wang has been wanted by Taiwan authorities on a murder charge since September 2000.

Concluding a second-phase investigation into the arms procurement scandal in September 2006, a special judicial panel in Taiwan indicted Wang and his wife, Yeh Hsiu-chen, as well as their four children and the Kuo brothers on charges of collecting illicit kickbacks from the Lafayette deal.
According to the indictment, the Wangs opened more than 60 bank accounts in Europe and Asia to launder US$520 million in illicit gains from the deal.
Taiwan began to seek legal assistance from the Swiss government in 2001 in an attempt to retrieve the funds frozen in several Swiss banks.

Through a judicial aid agreement with Switzerland, Taiwan prosecutors managed to acquire a collection of bank files from a Swiss federal judge in November 2005. After nearly 10 months of close examination of the files, Taiwan petitioned in September 2006 for the return of US$520 million from a total of US$730 million frozen in the Swiss banks.
