DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S MISSILE DEPLOYMENT CHANGING CROSS-STRAIT STATUS QUO: PENTAGON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 13 (CNA) 06/14/07 13:10:48 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: China's missile programs are posing challenges to the United States and are changing the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, a Pentagon official said Wednesday.

Richard Lawless, deputy undersecretary of defense for Asia and Pacific affairs, made the remarks while answering questions during a House Arms Services Committee hearing on China's recent security developments.

Citing an annual report on China's military power released last month, Lawless noted that there are at least 10 varieties of ballistic missiles deployed or in development in China, including over 900 short-range ballistic missiles in garrisons opposite Taiwan with a capability of threatening Taiwan's defense and disrupting the island's infrastructure.

"I think that these are challenges that are being presented to our ballistic missile programs, " Lawless said, adding that this year's military power report discusses the threat facing Taiwan and how the United States believes the threat is changing the cross-strait status quo and creating a new dynamic in the region.

Lawless said China has made substantial progress in fielding road-mobile, solid- propellant DF-31 intercontinental-range ballistic missiles (ICBMs) and continued modernization of its sea-based deterrent with the JL-2 submarine- launched ballistic missile (SLBM) program.

"These changes will bring greater range, mobility, accuracy and survivability to China's strategic forces capable of striking many areas of the world, including the continental United States, " Lawless said.

He said China's armed forces are rapidly developing capabilities designed to coerce or compel a settlement of the cross-strait dispute while simultaneously deterring, delaying or denying effective intervention from a third party, including the United States.
Long-term trends also suggest that Beijing is generating capabilities to employ military force for other regional contingencies, such as conflict over resources or territory, he said.

While China's nuclear force modernization is enhancing the People's Liberation Army's capabilities for strategic strikes beyond the Asia-Pacific theater, China's continued pursuit of anti-access and area denial strategies is expanding from traditional land, sea and air dimensions of the modern battlefield to include space and cyber space, Lawless said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LAUDS NATION'S NANOTECHNOLOGY PROJECT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that Taiwan's Nanotechnology Project has borne fruit, expressing the hope that the technology will help create another economic miracle for the island.
President Chen made the remarks while addressing the opening of the 2007 international nanotechnology week activities at National Taiwan University stadium.

Also attending the opening ceremony were Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. L. Chen, National Science Council Chairman Chen Chien-jen, Minister without Portfolio Lin Feng-ching and Nanotechnology Director Maw-kuen Wu.
Chen lauded the achievements of the project, which is entering its fifth year, in terms of research as well as innovative patents.

He said that as of the end of last year, Taiwan had published 3,745 papers in international academic journals and had formed more than a dozen top-notched international cross-field nanotechnology research teams.

On the application of nanotechnology, he noted that the nation has obtained 319 patents in other countries and 99 patents in Taiwan, adding that there have been 232 domestic technology transfers amounting to roughly NT$170 million (US$5.15 million).
Under the project, Taiwan has promoted 175 investment projects worth a total of about NT$3.96 billion, showing that Taiwan's importance in this field has been recognized, Chen said.

Noting that Taiwan has rich industrial resources and solid technology, the president said that these make the country very suited for developing nanotechnology, which focuses on cross-field research and innovation.
He expressed the hope that Taiwan will integrate resources to "create a green silicon island and another economic miracle."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange soared Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 104.33 points to close at 8,450.72.

The bourse opened at 8,421.21 and fluctuated between 8,476.13 and 8,409 during the day's trading. A total of 4.85 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$147.29 billion (US$4.45 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 1.8 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.6 percent, foodstuff issues and plastics and chemicals shares both at 0.5 percent, cement stocks at 0.2 percent, and construction issues at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 579 to 549, with 214 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC REMINDED OF NEW REQUIREMENT IN APPLYING FOR U.K. VISA

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials reminded members of the general public Thursday to be aware of the new anti-terrorist measures adopted by the British government when they apply for U.K. visas.

According to the British representative office in Taiwan, U.K. visa applicants of all nationalities will have to have their fingerprints and digital photos taken at their visa application offices starting from July 26 as part of the new anti-terrorist measures the British government has adopted worldwide.
British officials stationed in Taipei said they have also implemented this measure in 64 other countries.

Sung Wen-cheng, deputy director-general of the MOFA's Department of European Affairs, urged the public to respect the new visa policy adopted by the British government and apply for visas in advance to prevent any delays in their U.K. travel plans.

As to whether other European countries will follow suit, Sung said that Germany has been considering such a measure but that it has yet to impose the requirement after the MOFA notified German authorities that doing so would cause an inconvenience for Taiwan travelers.
Sung further said the United Kingdom is not the first country to adopt such a measure, noting that the United States implemented a similar measure several years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June rose 112 points to close at 8,443, with 37,951 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for July moved up 107 points to finish at 8,389, with 10,463 contracts traded, while September futures gained 95 points to close at 8,240, with 210 contract transactions. December futures rose 78 points to finish at 8,236, with eight contracts traded, while March futures moved up 97 points to close at 8,238, with 10 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 8,331 for June, 8,282 for July, 8,145 for September, 8,158 for December and 8,141 for March.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

June TE futures moved up 6.6 points to close at 367.45, with 4,624 contracts traded, while July TE futures rose 5.75 points to finish at 363.95, with 2,039 contract transactions. September TE futures gained 6.95 points to close at 359.8, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

June TF futures rose 13.8 points to close at 981.8, with 3,847 contracts traded, while July TF futures gained 14.4 points to finish at 977, with 2,488 contract transactions. September TF futures moved up 12.6 points to close at 968, with 41 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MUTUAL NON-DENIAL' IDEA NAIVE, FANCIFUL: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian derided as "naive, fanciful and ignorant nonsense" Thursday a "mutual non-denial" idea that opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou has put forward as a first step toward ending the cross- Taiwan Strait political impasse.

Commenting on Ma's proposal, made on the second day of a visit to India Wednesday to promote bilateral trade between Taiwan and the world's most populous democracy, Chen said he had "not the slightest idea" what Ma was talking about.

Speaking during a visit to grassroots representatives in the northern county of Taoyuan, Chen said he does not know what Ma was talking about, claiming that anything like "mutual non-denial" is simply a non-issue.

According to Chen, Ma is not in touch with reality if he expects China to let go of its sovereignty claims on Taiwan, adding that while Taiwan recognizes China as a nation, Beijing does not recognize Taiwan as a nation and mercilessly suppresses Taiwan in the international community.
Based on this backdrop, Chen said, there is no way the two sides could not deny each other.

Meanwhile, Chen appealed to the country to have faith in him and his administration. He said many people believed his government would be toppled when the anti-Chen "red-clad army" conducted a round-the-clock sit-in in front of the Presidential Office last year.
Nevertheless, Chen said, everything became "smooth and calm" after the protests, proving his belief that democratic politics respects differing voices from differing corners of society.

Ma said during his India trip that if mutual recognition is impossible, mutual non-denial may offer a way out, adding that the strategy might not be a solution, but rather could be a preparatory step to resolving the differences between China and Taiwan on the issue of the island's sovereignty.

Ma said the pragmatic approach to softening cross-strait tensions is to find a mutually agreeable middle ground and not keep fantasizing about de jure independence. He was referring to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's goal of establishing a "Taiwan Republic."

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL R&D CENTER ACCREDITED BY INTERNATIONAL CERTIFICATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Metal Industries Research and Development Centre (MIRDC) has established mutual recognition arrangements in certain product categories with certification authorities in Europe and the United States, MIRDC sources reported Thursday.

Since the center is recognized by its counterparts in other countries, MIRDC can then issue local manufacturers with certificates for mechanical and electrical products that are valid in respective markets, saving both the time and the cost of product accreditation, they noted.

Merchandise, including steel structure components, steel castings, steel bars, electric hand tools, metal brackets, electric fans, drinking fountains, dishwashers, electromotors, vacuum cleaners and electrical water heaters are all eligible for the "fast-track" accreditation process, according to the MIRDC.
Local companies in these areas can thus gain wider access to markets in the U.S. and European, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE ARRIVES IN SINGAPORE
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, June 14 (CNA) 06/14/07 17:09:08 (By Chen Yi-wei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou arrived in Singapore Thursday after wrapping up a whirlwind two-day visit to India.

Ma told Taiwanese reporters covering his two-leg overseas campaign tour that his visits to India, a South Asian major power, and Singapore, a major Southeast Asian economic powerhouse, reflect his broad vision in policy planning.
Shortly after his arrival in the city-state, Ma visited Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority, where he was briefed on the country's cargo transshipment management.

Noting that the port of Singapore tops all other Asian harbors in container handling volume, Ma said Taiwan has much to learn from Singapore in sharpening its competitiveness in cargo shipping services.

Ma, a former KMT chairman and two-term mayor of Taipei from 1998 through 2006, was also scheduled to look into Singapore's casino management and visit some major trade unions before concluding his visit Friday.

Media reports said Ma was to meet later Thursday with Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew. Ma refused to confirm the reports and instead said he would meet with "old friends" for exchanges of views on the general Asia-Pacific situation and the promotion of Taiwan-Singapore relations.

During his India visit, Ma met with Indian Minister of Communications and Information Technology Dayanidhi Maran and Minister of Commerce and Industry Kamal Nath to discuss the feasibility of enhancing bilateral cooperation in the information and communications technology (ITC) industry.

Ma also gave a speech titled "The Role of Taiwan's Economy in Regional and International Environment" at the Indian Council of World Affairs, India's most prestigious private think tank. His audience included India's incumbent and former foreign affairs officials, according to Ma's aides.
Ma's second day itinerary in India included a visit to Nationalist Congress Party leader Dr. Karan Singh and a meeting with Rajnath Singh, chairman of the largest opposition Bharatiya Janata Party.

At the conclusion of his India visit, Ma said Taiwan should consider operating flights serving the route between Taiwan and Chennai -- India's technology stronghold which also hosts a large number of Taiwanese businessmen -- to bring convenience for future cooperation. He expressed hope that his two-day visit will contribute to bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAGON BOAT FESTIVAL CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS BEGIN FRIDAY

TEXT.P: Direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights for the Dragon Boat Festival are scheduled to kick off Friday, with carriers from each side operating a total of 42 flights during the holiday period.
The flights, which will begin June 15, will last through June 22, according to officials from the Civil Aeronautic Administration (CAA).

This year, all six Taiwan carriers have applied to operate a total of 24 special charter flights from Taipei and Kaohsiung to and from China's Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou and Xiamen during the holiday period, CAA officials said.
Five Chinese carriers have applied to operate a total of 18 flights from the four Chinese cities to and from Taiwan's Taipei and Kaohsiung during the holiday period.
The Taipei-Shanghai route has proved to be the most popular this year, with Taiwan carriers applying to operate 16 flights, CAA officials said.
Taiwan citizens with valid entry permits issued by the governments on the two sides are eligible to take the flights.

This year marks the first year that direct cross-strait charter flight services have been offered during the Dragon Boat Festival holiday. This year's Dragon Boat Day falls on June 19, which is the fifth day of the fifth month, according to the lunar calendar.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASTOR ACCUSED OF SEXUAL ASSAULTS AGAIN

TEXT.P: A controversial pastor who has spent time in jail for sexual molestation was questioned by police Thursday after he was accused by several female followers of sexually assaulting them, according to police.
Police raided the church of Pastor Tang Tai-sheng, 60, in Chungli, Taoyuan County and arrested him a day earlier, but he refused to answer questions at the time.

During Thursday's questioning, Tang denied any wrongdoing. Faced with the media outside the police station, he said only that "it is God's will." Police have turned the case over to the Taoyuan Prosecutors Office.

Police also summoned eight female section chiefs in the church as witnesses. The eight are said to be in charge of recruiting senior high school students or college freshmen in front of bookstores to join the church.
Police even arranged for two female pastors to talk to the eight chiefs one by one, in the hope of learning more about the case.

The women said they had full confidence in Tang, with some saying they had followed Tang since they were senior high school students. They dismissed media reports that Tang, under the cover of "sex counseling, " had fondled his female followers or sexually assaulted them.
All eight women said they suspected that Tang's accusers have a "private vendetta" against him.
Chen Pi-er, Tang's wife, said she has every confidence in her husband, and claimed that all accusations against Tang have been "unfounded."
Quiet a few followers went to the church for classes Wednesday evening, saying that they believe Tang is innocent.
Tang was first accused of impropriety during "sexual counselling" in 1999. Prosecutors raided his home and church and found evidence that he had victimized at least 300 women.

After a long litigation process, the court gave its final verdict in 2004, sentencing him to a prison term of three years and two months and ordering that he undergo compulsory therapy for a maximum of three years. Tang was released in 2005, returned to his Taoyuan church and ceased the therapy.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, rising NT$0.046 to close at NT$33.085.
A total of US$734 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.989 and fluctuated between NT$32.970 and NT$33.090.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Middle East is again under fire. Bitter fighting between rival Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah in Gaza Strip killed some 80 people over the past days and a car bomb exploded in Beirut Wednesday, killing at least 10 people, including an anti-Syrian parliamentarian of Lebanon. 960614

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE ADOPTS NEW PENALTIES FOR POSSESSION OF CHILD PORNOGRAPHY

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Child and Youth Sexual Transaction Prevention Act Thursday in which new penalties are adopted for the possession of child pornography.
According to the amendment, anyone caught with child pornography without "proper reason" can be required to accept up to 10 hours of guidance lessons for a first offense.

Anyone caught committing the same offense more than once can be fined up to NT$200,000, the amendment stipulates, adding that the pornographic materials found will be seized regardless of whether they belong to the holder or not.
The "proper reasons" for possessing child pornography, as defined in the amended law, include scientific, educational and medical purposes.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Huang Shu-ying, a lead sponsor of the amendment, noted that child pornography is a serious form of sexual exploitation and is a permanent record of the abuse of the victims that can cause persistent harm to the victims.
Under these circumstances, penalization for the possession of child pornography has become an international trend, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC URGED TO BE ALERT FOR POSSIBLE ETA ATTACKS IN SPAIN

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials urged the public Thursday to be alert when visiting Spain in the face of warnings of renewed attacks by the Basque separatist group ETA.

Sung Wen-cheng, deputy director-general of the MOFA's Department of European Affairs, noted that the terrorist group announced June 6 that it will call off a 14-month cease-fire it had reached with Spanish government in an attempt to press it to make more concessions.

ETA, which has for nearly 40 years been seeking Basque independence, has killed more than 800 people since its first terrorist attack in 1968, Sung said, adding that its ending of the cease-fire shocked the Spanish government.
ETA is believed to be responsible for a powerful car bombing at Madrid's international airport last December.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTERS TO SERVE VETERANS TRAVELING VIA DIRECT LINKS

TEXT.P: Veterans Affairs Commission (VAC) Chairman Hu Cheng-pu said Thursday that the VAC will set up service centers on Kinmen and Matsu to assist veterans and their dependents traveling to and from China via the "mini three links."
Hu made the remarks while inspecting veteran operations on the outlying island of Kinmen.

He noted that the government has since March 31 eased the regulations to allow veterans born anywhere in China, instead of only Fujian Province, to travel directly from the two islands to and from China.
"The VAC attaches importance to the new policy and is considering how best to serve the veterans," he said.
He noted that there are still more than 500,000 veterans in the nation and said it is expected that more and more of them will travel to China through this "economical" and "convenient" channel.
"Where there are needs, there will be service, " Hu said, adding that the service centers will be set up at wharves on the two islands as soon as possible.

When the "mini three links" were inaugurated in January 2001, only people with household registration on Kinmen or Matsu were allowed to travel between Taiwan and China via the links, although those regulations have since been gradually eased.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY OF POLL RESPONDENTS ANGRY WITH CHINA'S DOUBLE-DEALING

TEXT.P: A majority of the respondents to a recent poll are angry with China's double- dealing toward Taiwan and contend that Beijing should be held responsible for the deterioration in bilateral ties, according to the results of the poll released Thursday by a private policy research group.
According to the poll results released at a news conference by the pro- independence Taiwan Thinktank, 78 percent of those surveyed think China has been deceitful in its dealings with Taiwan.

While 62 percent of the respondents said that they are angry with China's squeezing of Taiwan in the international community, 64 percent said that Beijing should be held accountable for worsening bilateral relations, the poll found.

Some 85 percent of the public polled believe China's efforts to exclude Taiwan from world bodies will affect two-way relations, and 60 percent agree that "it is better not to harbor any illusions with Beijing as China is unlikely to compromise over Taiwan's sovereignty."

As high as 72 percent said that they cannot accept Beijing's "one China principle" imposed on Taiwan as a condition for bilateral negotiations or taking part in international activities, according to the survey.
The telephone survey was conducted from June 9-11 and collected 1,067 valid questionnaires. It had a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIR HOPES TO MEET DPP, KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt said Thursday that he hopes to meet the presidential candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) during his stay in Taiwan.

Burghardt, who arrived in Taipei a day earlier, called on Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang and said later that he hopes to meet DPP candidate Frank Hsieh and KMT candidate Ma Ying-jeou to get a better understanding of their campaign platforms and policy initiatives for the 2008 presidential election.
He said that during the time he served as the AIT Taipei Office director between 1999 and 2001, he met with all three presidential candidates in the election of that time.
The U.S. policy is to meet with all candidates, understand their viewpoints and the policies they hope to adopt after being elected, he said.
The AIT is authorized by the U.S. government to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ATTACKS DPP LAWMAKER'S WITHDRAWAL OF NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) blasted Thursday a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker's withdrawal of a no-confidence vote against Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, calling it a "farce" and urging the DPP to "discipline its wayward lawmaker."

KMT lawmakers called a news conference in the Legislative Yuan to express their anger after DPP lawmaker Chen Chin-de put forward the no-confidence vote proposal but withdrew it two hours later during a legislative meeting earlier in the day.

Tseng Yung-chuan, a KMT lawmaker and director of the party's Policy Coordination Committee, said that the matter fully demonstrates the DPP's ineptitude. "As the ruling party, how could the DPP paralyze the parliament with such a farce?" he asked.

KMT legislative caucus whip Hsu Shao-ping accused the DPP of "foul play" by mounting such a trick a day before the Legislative Yuan is to screen the 2007 central government budget bill -- a bill that has been stonewalled by the KMT for over six months and that the DPP has been eager to push through the legislature.

According to KMT lawmaker Pan Wei-kang, Chen's proposal to topple the Cabinet fully reflects "the fact" that DPP lawmakers themselves are dissatisfied with Chang. She accused the DPP of seeking to paralyze the Legislative Yuan and pass the buck to the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP).

Chen proposed a no-confidence vote May 29 to topple the Cabinet given that the KMT and the PFP have deliberately boycotted the passage of several key bills, including the annual budget bill, in an attempt to exchange for the passage of a KMT-PFP proposed draft bill concerning the formation of the Central Election Commission (CEC) , which the DPP strongly opposes on the ground of "violating constitutional provisions."
To highlight the procrastinated partisan standoff in the Legislative Yuan, Chen said last week that he would initiate the no-confidence vote if the DPP's legislative caucus refuses to do so.

Chen's no-confidence proposal was endorsed by 74 lawmakers, most of them from the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), surpassing the legal threshold of one-third approval -- or 73 lawmakers -- to make it a motion for the lawmakers to vote on within five days.
Accompanied by DPP legislative caucus whips, Chen announced the withdrawal of the proposal after the 74 lawmakers who signed the petition pulled out their endorsement.

Chen decided to rescind the proposal after being fiercely attacked by his DPP peers earlier in the day, who accused him of "individualism" and "upsetting party unity" for failing to have discussed the issue with them and the party caucus before putting forward the proposal.

DPP legislative caucus whip Wang Sing-nan also criticized Chen's move, saying that launching a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet at this point will only create a constitutional crisis now that the "pan-blue alliance " has in recent days agreed to allow the budget bill to pass the legislature.
Wang asked Chen to withdraw the proposal 15 minutes after Chen submitted it upon learning that all DPP and TSU lawmakers who endorsed the petition had pulled out their signatures.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU PRESIDENT URGED TO HELP TAIWAN PARTICIPATE IN WHO
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, June 13 (CNA) 06/14/07 19:53:23 (By P. C. Tang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: European Parliament-Taiwan Friendship Group Chairman Georg Jarzembowski urged Germany, the European Union (EU)'s rotating president Wednesday to keep striving for Taiwan's "meaningful participation" in the World Health Organization (WHO).

Jarzembowski, a German member of the European Parliament, also urged the EU to make a request to WHO Director-General Margaret Chan to set up a center in Taiwan in order to help Taiwanese people prevent and fight epidemic diseases.

Taiwan's application for full WHO membership under the name "Taiwan" was refused by the World Health Assembly (WHA) this year because of China's obstruction, Jarzembowski said, adding that the EU president's stance of supporting Taiwan's "meaningful participation" was therefore turned down.

The "meaningful participation" of Taiwan in the WHO means taking part in technical-level meetings under the framework of the International Health Regulations, joining the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network and the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, and partaking in WHO-sponsored meetings on food sanitation, avian flu and tuberculosis.

Jarzembowski said the EU supported Taiwan's application by quoting a principle of the WHO Constitution that says "the enjoyment of the highest attainable standard of health is one of the fundamental rights of every human being."

The European Parliament has been very supportive of Taiwan's participation in the WHO and has voted many times to support Taiwan's WHA observer status, with the last vote being a resolution passed May 18, 2006, Jarzembowski said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO LICENSE REQUIRED FOR ELECTRIC BICYCLES

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed a law amendment Thursday to officially exempt riders of electric bicycles and electric-auxiliary bicycles from needing to obtain licenses, in a move aimed at boosting the development of the electric recreational vehicle industry.

The amendment to the Statute for Road Traffic Management and Penalties defines bicycles, electric bicycles and electric-auxiliary bicycles that move no faster than 25 km per hour and weigh no more than 40 kg as slow-moving vehicles for which no driver's license or license plates are required.
Such vehicles can be used on public roads as long as they have passed inspection by the relevant authorities and have been issued with a certification label, according to the amendment.

Meanwhile, the amended law stipulates that users of tricycles, hand-drawn carts and animal-drawn wagons for transporting passengers or cargo must register their vehicles before they can be allowed on the road, although violators will be subject to a fine of just NT$300.

DOC.HEADLINE: CURTAINS OF TAIWAN DEMOCRACY HALL NEED NOT BE REMOVED: MOE

TEXT.P: The curtains affixed to the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall need not be removed as they are not "illegal," an official of the Ministry of Education said Thursday.

The remarks came in response to local media reports that the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) believes that the curtains are advertisements and that MOE's hanging them on either side of the hall, which was formerly named as Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, violates the Waste Disposal Act.

Chu Nan-hsien, director-general of the ministry's Department of Social Education, produced an official document in which the EPA stated May 30 that the hanging of the curtains does not contravene any laws.

The ministry hung curtains bearing the name of the hall as it has been temporarily designated a historial site, and therefore no plaque may be affixed, Chu noted, stressing that the curtains are "not advertisements".

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE CULTURAL CREATORS TO EXHIBIT AT U.S. LICENSING FAIR

TEXT.P: Ten Taiwanese companies will exhibit at the New York Licensing 2007 International June 19 - 21, and set their eyes on bringing in record-breaking profits through licensing of cultural products and quality peripherals, the National Science Council (NSC) and National Digital Archive Program (NDAP), organizers of the Taiwan Pavilion said Thursday.

Through collaboration between government agencies and industry, it is hoped that the culture industry will become another "trillion-dollar industry" for Taiwan, NSC Deputy Minister Tai Chein said during a press conference introducing products from ten exhibiting companies.

This is the third straight year that Taiwanese companies have entered the annual fair, and there have been impressive results in the previous exhibitions, said Liu Tsui-jung, the NADP head who also serves as Vice President of Academia Sinica.
Taiwanese companies registered licensing authorization revenues of NT$250 million and NT$390 million at the global licensing fair in 2005 and 2006, respectively.

The ten exhibiting companies will appear in two major categories -- licensing of brand names and innovative brand names -- with five companies each category. Exhibitors created various artworks, animations, characters, figurines, cartoon images and merchandise, using either digital archives provided by the NADP or their own original creations.

Licensing International, which is approaching its 27th anniversary, is one of the largest annual events of its kind. Since 2002, more than 5,700 items from more than 500 exhibiting companies have been offered for licensing, realizing potential profits of more than US$170 billion.

During the fair, trading will be conducted in seven categories: art and publication authorization, brand name and trademark licensing, cartoon portraits, entertainment, internet and interactive multimedia, sports, and fashion.
The Taiwan Pavilion will be officially opened at 2 p.m. Eastern Time, June 20, after a press conference held at Booth 4135 in the Jacob Javits Convention Center in New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR TO SERVE AS ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO GERMANY

TEXT.P: Legislator You Ching of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has been tapped to serve as the country's representative to Germany, according to Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey.
Shieh, who just ended a two-year stint as the country's representative to Germany, took office as Executive Yuan spokesman and Government Information Office minister Monday.
You earned a doctoral degree in law from Germany's Heidelberg University, Shieh said, noting that his formation of a good social network during his study in Germany is sure to help him.
You has been a Control Yuan member, a two-term Taipei magistrate, a National Chengchi University associate professor, a Presidential Office national policy adviser and an ambassador-at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Madeleine officers prepare to dig after 'burial place' letter
Portuguese police may begin digging in search of the body of Madeleine McCann this morning after a letter apparently giving details of where she will be found was sent to a Dutch newspaper.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Efforts to Avert Sectarian Reprisals After Shrine Attack
Two explosions on Wednesday that appeared to have been set by Sunni extremists with links to Al Qaeda toppled the twin golden minarets that were most of what remained of one of Iraqs most revered Shiite shrines after a devastating bombing by Al Qaeda last year.
That bombing 16 months ago proved a watershed, engulfing the country in a wave of sectarian killing that pushed Sunnis and Shiites toward civil war. With American and Iraqi forces unable to restrain soaring levels of killing that saw as many as 3,000 Iraqi civilians dying every month by the end of 2006, President Bush ordered nearly 30,000 additional American troops deployed here, aimed at pulling the country back from the abyss.
Wall Street Journal:A Fight Over What You Can Do on a Cellphone
Wireless phone carriers and the makers of hand- held gadgets like the BlackBerry have long had a ymbiotic relationship. Carriers sell the BlackBerry to subscribers, putting it in the hands of millions. In turn, the carriers get to charge their subscribers not just for voice but for pricier data service as well.
Now, a turf war is looming between the two camps, as lucrative new services such as video, games, and maps move onto mobile devices. Each camp wants to control the new offerings, and the gusher of revenue they could produce.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN TO RECOGNIZE TAIWANESE DRIVER'S LICENSES

TEXT.P: Taiwanese driver's licenses are expected to be recognized in Japan soon after a formal announcement by the Japanese government, Taiwanese officials stationed in Japan said Thursday.

The officials made the remarks after the Japanese House of Representatives approved the same day an amendment to its traffic laws, which will allow those holding Taiwanese driver's licenses to drive on Japan's roads.
The details of the regulations will be announced formally after further discussions among officials of both countries, the officials added.
Koh Se-kai, the Republic of China representative to Japan, welcomed the policy.
This goodwill measure adopted by Japanese government follows its granting of 90-day visa-free treatment to Taiwan tourists announced in September 2005.
Koh added that as a gesture of reciprocity, Taiwan will adopt a similar policy allowing those holding Japanese driver's licenses to operate a vehicle on the roads of Taiwan.

The measure is expected to bring more flexibility to the visits of Taiwanese tourists to Japan. According to official statistics, Taiwanese tourists make more than 1.2 million visits to Japan annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: CUSTOMS OFFICERS SEIZE 130 KG OF KETAMINE IN MAY

TEXT.P: Taipei Customs officers reported Thursday that they seized a variety of smuggled goods in May, including 130 kg of ketamine.
According to the officers, other major amounts of smuggled goods included ivory, placenta extract, Viagra and undeclared Hong Kong dollars.
The officers said they will continue strengthening cooperation with law enforcement agencies at home and overseas to further protect the health of local people and improve the social order.
While claiming that they will strengthen anti-smuggling measures, the officers also urged the public to tip off the police about suspicious behavior by calling 0800-038-265 or 0800-311-006.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIVING BUDDHA POISED TO RECEIVE TAIWAN'S 1ST BUDDHISM DOCTORATE

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese man, who two years ago was recognized as a living, reincarnated Buddha and given the holy title of The Third Tulku Palme Khyentse, is expected to receive the first doctorate in Buddhism presented in Taiwan next month.

Huang Ying-chieh, or the Third Tulku Palme Khyentse from the Palme Monastery of China's Qinghai Province, has presented his doctoral thesis, an analysis and survey on Buddhism's middle way, and is scheduled to sit an oral defense for his doctorate, fielding questions from seven academics, at Huafan University on July 20.

If he passes the oral test, Huang will be awarded the first Buddhism doctorate from a Taiwanese institute, five years after the Ministry of Education permitted local colleges to open departments of religions.

Huang, 40, holds a bachelor of sociology from Fujen University. He has spent most of his time during the past 10 years studying Tibetan Buddhism, shuttling between Huafan University's Graduate Institute of Asian Studies and the International Buddhism Institute in Nepal.

In 1997, H.H. Sakya Trizin, the head of the Sakya Monastery in Qinghai, met Huang during his first-ever visit to Taiwan. The leader of the Sakya school of Tibetan Buddhism felt that Huang could be a reincarnated living Buddha, but he never said so at the time.
During Huang's every visit to Nepal, India and Singapore in the following years, Sakya Trizin met him "accidentally, " and grew further amazed by Huang.

Sakya Trizin submitted a proposal to H.H. Drikung Chetsang Rinpoche, the head of the Drikung school of the Tibetan Buddhism, in 2004, saying that Huang was likely to be the third reincarnated Palme Khyentse, the top man of the Palme school.

It took a year for Drikung Chetsang to recognize Huang. The verification process included dreams, special feelings and written records handed down from the Second Chetsang Drikung saying that the Third might be a "Han Chinese."
H.H. Drikung Chetsang Rinpoche traveled to Taiwan in person in 2005 to ratify Huang as the Third Tulku Palme Khyentse. The Tibetan word "tulku" means "a reincarnated one."
Huang has no idea why he has been involved in a Buddhist reincarnation system. All he knows is that he has found Buddhism to be as important as his life since he was first exposed to it.
Huang's grandfather was a renowned calligrapher who wrote with brush for most of the major Buddhism temples and monasteries around Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO EXPAND SCALE OF CULTIVATING TEXTILE DESIGN FORCE

TEXT.P: The Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) will enroll 350 students this year in an expanded training program to produce innovative, competent design talent to secure the future of Taiwan's textile industry, an IDB official said Thursday.

The official said these students will receive training in categories including chemical fibers, dyes, and design, because chemical fibers are expected to be a key feature of the textile industry, dyeing is a core procedure in textile production, and design is necessary to bring added value to finished products.

This program, dubbed the "textile design college program, " was organized by the Taiwan Textile Federation, the Taiwan Research Institute, and the Footware and Recreation Technology Research Institute. The program previously trained 20 people every year to become outstanding designers in textile and clothes industries, the official said.

The program was instituted under the government's "great investment" and "great warmth" policies, which aim to cultivate talents to benefit industries in need of highly professional skills in industries such as textiles, precision machinery, and module industry.

The program involves domestic and overseas training. Five students undergoing the overseas training are studying for their master degrees in England. Students who receive domestic training will have one-year intensive training in Taiwan and short-term overseas training for one month each year to gain an international perspective, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOMEN'S LABOR PARTICIPATION RATE WORLD'S 35TH: GOV'T REPORT

TEXT.P: The labor participation rate of Taiwanese women has grown in recent years and now ranks 35th in the world, a government report said Thursday.

According to analysis carried out by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), based on data compiled by the International Institute for Management Development, the labor participation rate of Taiwanese women increased to 42.45 percent last year, up from 40.45 percent in 2001.
During the same period, Taiwan's ranking rose to 35th from 38th place, lagging behind Thailand, Hong Kong, and Singapore, but outpacing Japan and South Korea, the report showed.

Relevant government agencies have been working on programs to help more women find employment or open their own business, so as to meet strong demand for manpower in many sectors, CEPD officials said.

Generally speaking, getting married and having children are the two major factors most affecting women's willingness to work, the officials said, adding that when sound social systems are in place, and society grants them equal rights, women will be better able to take care of their families and work at the same time.

Against such a background, the issue of how to take advantage of women's power to contribute to the workforce has been one of the focal points in the government's human resources policy, which aims to create more job opportunities for women and fully explore their workplace capabilities, the officials said.

Judging from changes during the 1980-2006 period, Taiwanese women's labor participation rates have steadily been rising, they said, pointing out that the employment rate for married women with children under six years old doubled, growing from 26 percent to 56 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE MANGO SALES TO JAPAN TO RESUME

TEXT.P: Taiwan's best mangos will again be allowed into Japan's markets next week following a short hiatus that began last year when Taiwanese grown-mangos were found to contain pesticide residues, government officials said Thursday.

At a press conference held in Jason's Supermarket in Taipei 101 to mark the reentry of Taiwan mangos to Japan, Su Huan-chih, magistrate of Tainan County, home to Taiwan's high-caliber Irwin mangos, said the exported fruits will each bear a production resume in addition to a certificate that they are free of pesticide residues.
Su said there are only 324 farmers in Taiwan who cultivate Irwin mangos, and among them three have received the European EUREPGAP certificate.

Yeh Ming-sui, deputy secretary-general of Taiwan External Trade Development Council, who was also present at the occasion, said mangos are Taiwan's second most popular fruit on world markets, following bananas.
In addition to Japan, Taiwanese-grown mangos are also popular in Australia, South East countries and South Korea, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU TO TERMINATE ANTI-DUMPING TAX ON TAIWANESE-MADE CD-ROMS

TEXT.P: The European Union will terminate its anti-dumping tax on Taiwanese-made CD- ROMs this month when a five-year EU anti-dumping tax program expires, officials from the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Thursday.

The European Commission, the top decision-making EU body, announced recently that a five-year anti-dumping tax on imports of CD-ROMS of Taiwanese origin, imposed on June 18, 2002, will not be extended when the program expires on June 18 this year, BOFT officials said.
Over the past five years, the European Commission has imposed anti-dumping taxes, ranging from 17.7 percent to 38.5 percent, on Taiwanese-made CD-ROMs.

The commission began a fresh investigation of CDs from Taiwan in March this year, but received no inquiries nor complaints from any EU companies about such imports, prompting the commission to decide to bring the retaliatory measure to an end, BOFT officials said.
According to BOFT officials, nearly all of Taiwan's CD-ROM makers and exporters have steered clear of the European market since June 2002 as a result of the anti-dumping tax.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS 2ND PHASE OF FINANCIAL REFORM NOT LINKED TO ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Thursday that the promotion of the second phase of financial reform has nothing to do with the two major elections next year.
President Chen made the remarks as he addressed the 60th anniversary of the Importers and Exporters Association of Taipei.
Chen stressed that the reform is necessary, saying that it is a major policy of the nation that aims at enhancing the international competitiveness of domestic financial institutions.

Faced with criticism by some who allege that his decision to revive talks on second phase of financial reform are a form of "election maneuvering, " he said that "this couldn't be further away from the truth and is a vicious smear campaign."

Critics have lashed out at the financial reform, saying that several influential family groups have benefited most from the merger of the financial institutes, and that the government is providing them with astronomical financial gains, from which it hopes to benefit in return during the elections.
The president urged related government agencies to "continue on the right path despite obstacles, " saying that "as long as they perform credibly, these smearing campaigns will not stand.'
He noted that a consensus on creating a sound financial environment, including the merger and the dissolution of financial institutions, had been reached at two major national economic conferences.

He said that the second phase of financial reforms will not only introduce foreign financial expertise and products to Taiwan, but will also encourage foreign enterprises to invest in domestic financial institutions or form strategic alliances with them, which he said will raise the service quality of domestic financial institutions to that of their international counterparts.
"This kind of effort has nothing to do with the legislative or presidential elections," the president stressed.

In the first phase of financial reform, the government was able to achieve the objectives of reducing the overdue loan ratios of domestic banks to below 5 percent and boosting their capital adequacy ratios to over 8 percent within two years.

The president announced in October 2004 the second phase of financial reforms, setting the targets of halving the number of publicly-owned banks, helping at least three financial institutions to grab a market share of at least 10 percent, halving the number of financial holding companies, and helping at least one financial institution to list their shares on overseas stock markets or be operated by a foreign owner.
Due to the controversy surrounding the second phase of financial reforms, then- Cabinet decided to make an overall review fo the reform before taking further steps last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA PRESENTS NEW DRUGS FOR CANCER IMMUNOTHERAPY

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica -- Taiwan's top research institution -- has developed a new immunotherapy for cancer, using newly-invented chemical compounds to enhance the "targeted attacks" of natural killer T-cells (NKT) on cancer cells, sources at the institution said Thursday.

Most anti-cancer drugs come with distinct side-effects and often lead to the development of drug resistance in patients, they noted, adding that by utilizing NKT cells -- inherent components of the human immune system, the new method can not only avoid the drawbacks of existing drugs but also avoid accidental damage to normal cells.

The compounds -- glycolipids with aromatic rings attached to the tail -- were developed and tested by Chi-huey Wong -- the institution's president, Yu Lin- tsing -- a member of the institution's Genomics Research Center, and Chang Ya-jen -- a postdoctoral researcher at Yu's lab.

The glycolipid drugs have proven effective in tests on rodents, prolonging the life expectancy of mice with lung cancer and inhibiting tumor growth rates by 75 percent in mice with breast cancer. The results were reported June 12 in the Online Early Edition of the U.S.-based Proceedings of National Academy of Sciences.

According to a press release from Academia Sinica, the inspiration behind the development of cancer-curing compounds came from alpha- GalactosylCeramide (alpha-GalCer), a material that exists in sponges, discovered by a Japanese beer brewer in 1995.

Alpha-GalCer was later found capable of boosting immune system and helpfully in curing cancers. However, the most distinct effects occurred only during experiments on rodents: in human tests, the effectiveness was limited because substances induced by alpha-GalCer suppress immune functions and offset the expected curing effects.

Leaping forward from the experience drawn through the failure, the team led by Chi-huey Wong first created 40 compounds based on the chemical characteristics of alpha-GalCer and then attached aromatic rings to them to enhance the effects.

After that, these compounds were sent to Yu Lin-tsing's laboratory for tests in vitro and in vivo to determine which ones have the best curative effects. Chang Ya-jen then examined the most promising compounds in the following tests and proved some of them being even more effective than alpha-GalCer in fighting lung and breast cancer cells on mice.
While the drugs made from these compounds will soon enter multiple stages of human testing, Academia Sinica has already filed patent applications for the drugs in various countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES U.S. TO REAFFIRM 6 ASSURANCES TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the United States Thursday to reaffirm at an opportune time the "Six Assurances" it made to Taiwan in 1982 so as to underscore that there has been no change in its stance on Taiwan's sovereign status and prevent China from downgrading Taiwan in the international community.

Chen made the appeal while meeting with Raymond Burghardt who, as the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) chairman, is the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Chen told Burghardt, who arrived in Taipei Wednesday to inspect AIT operations here, that the U.S. government's failure to insist on its support for Taiwan has allowed the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) to alter Taiwan's status in the body from a sovereign state to that of a non-sovereign regional member.

Under pressure from China, the OIE passed a resolution at its annual conference held in Paris last month which downgraded Taiwan's status to that of a non- sovereign regional member and changed Taiwan's moniker in the organization from "Taipei China" to "Chinese Taipei."
China originally pushed the OIE to change Taiwan's designation to "Taiwan, China, " a title that implies Taiwan is under China's jurisdiction.

Following expressions of grave concern from the Bush administration, Chen said, the OIE later agreed to refer to Taiwan as "Chinese Taipei, " a title that Taiwan now uses in the International Olympic Games and doesn't imply Taiwan's relations with the People's Republic of China (PRC).
"Although we are not satisfied with the 'Chinese Taipei' title, we still very much appreciate American assistance," Chen said.

Nevertheless, Chen said it was regrettable that the U.S. government failed to insist on its stance on Taiwan's sovereign status and eventually acquiesced in the OIE's change of Taiwan's membership status at the world body.

According to Chen, downgrading of Taiwan's status at the OIE violates the "Six Assurances" the U.S. made to Taiwan in 1982. Those assurances include a promise that the United States would not alter its position on the sovereignty of Taiwan, which was that the question was one to be decided peacefully by the Chinese themselves; that it would not pressure Taiwan to enter into negotiations with China; and that the United States would not formally recognize Chinese sovereignty over Taiwan.
Chen said he earnestly hopes that the U.S. government can reaffirm at an opportune time or in an opportune setting that its "Six Assurances" to Taiwan remain unchanged.

Meanwhile, Chen said Taiwan looks forward to join the U.N. Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. Regrettably, he said U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon rejected Taiwan's participation and even returned Taiwan's application instrument.

Even more outrageously, Chen said, Ban mentioned that the 1971 U.N. Resolution No. 2758 recognized Taiwan as part of the PRC. That's a lie, Chen said, insisting that Resolution 2758 didn't mention Taiwan's ties with the PRC. The resolution only allowed Beijing to take the "China" seat at the expense of Taipei.
To the best of his understanding, chen said the U.S. "one China" policy, including its Taiwan Relations Act of 1979, and the Six Assurances of 1982, never recognizes Taiwan as part of the PRC.
During his talks with the AIT chairman, Chen also said that he will never back off the "four noes" pledge he made in his 2000 and 2004 inaugural addresses to the U.S. government and the whole world.

Chen's now famous "four noes" pledge refers to a promise that so long as China has no intention to use force against Taiwan, he will not declare Taiwan independence, not change Taiwan's title or national flag, not enshrine in the Constitution the "two state" notion in addressing cross-Taiwan Strait relation and not hold a "unification versus independence" referendum to change the cross-strait status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHIEF REAFFIRMS U.S. DEFENSE COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Visiting American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt said Thursday that the U.S. government attaches great importance to its relations with Taiwan because it is committed to helping with Taiwan's defense.
Against this backdrop, Burghardt said it is very important for both sides to maintain constant dialogue and communications while dutifully keeping their communications transparent.

Burghardt, who as the AIT chief is the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, made the remarks after meeting with a number of Taiwanese political heavyweights, including President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng.

President Chen told Burghardt that he looks forward to seeing the U.S. government reaffirms its "Six Assurances" to Taiwan and thereby underscore that there has been no change in its stance on Taiwan's sovereign status.

The "Six Assurances" made by the Reagan administration to Taiwan in 1982 include that the United States would not set a date for termination of arms sales to Taiwan; not alter the terms of the Taiwan Relations Act; not consult with China in advance before making decisions about U.S. arms sales to Taiwan; not mediate between Taiwan and China; not alter its position about the sovereignty of Taiwan; and not pressure Taiwan to enter into negotiations with China.

Burghardt, who arrived in Taiwan Wednesday to inspect AIT operations and get first-hand information about Taiwan's latest developments, didn't make a direct response to Chen's request. Instead he said he expects the Taiwan government's long-stalled 2007 budget bill to clear the legislature soon.

The budget bill includes partial funding for the acquisition of U.S.-built submarine-hunting aircraft, the upgrading of the country's Patriot missiles and the financing of a feasibility study as a first step toward purchasing diesel- electric submarines.

Burghardt said the passage of the budget bill is very important for fulfilling U.S. commitment to aid Taiwan's defense. The United States is the only country in the world that maintains security commitment to Taiwan, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS RAID EMG OVER SUSPECTED FINANCIAL SCANDALS

TEXT.P: Law enforcement officers searched the headquarters of Eastern Multimedia Group (EMG) and other relevant premises Thursday as they probed the group's role in a spate of suspected financial irregularities.

Prosecutors led nearly 200 agents from the Bureau of Investigation's outposts in northern Taiwan cities and counties to search the EMG-related premises and EMG Chairman Gary Wang's home for evidence of suspected corruption and financial crimes.

Prosecutor Lin Chin-tsun of the Taipei Prosecutor's Office said the EMG is suspected of involvement in several scandals, including an alleged corruption scandal involving its acquisition of the rights to operate the Taipei Arena, a multi functional stadium built by the Taipei city government at a cost of NT$4.7 billion (US$142.42 million).

EMG secured a nine-year contract to operate the stadium at a price tag of NT$1.58 billion. Lin said prosecutors are probing whether the bidding process involved profiteering, bid-rigging or other irregularities.

The group was also suspected of involvement in corporate fund embezzlement related with some Rebar Asia Pacific Group subsidiaries, including Asia Pacific Broadband Telecom and Union Insurance Co., Lin said, adding that Gary Wang's sale of EMG stakes to U.S.-based Carlyle Group is also under investigation over suspected breach of financial laws.
More than 20 EMG executives, including Gary Wang, and several Taipei city government officials were questioned Thursday for their roles in those cases, Lin said.
Gary Wang is a son of Wang You-theng, the fugitive Rebar group founder who has been indicted together with 106 others for their implications in one of the country's largest financial scandals.
Gary Wang has repeatedly denied allegations that he embezzled Rebar group's money and then shifted it to Eastern Multimedia Group, which he founded.

Prosecutors have sought a 30-year prison term for the 82-year-old Wang You- theng, who has been detained in Los Angeles after his passport was revoked by Taiwan for violating securities, accounting and other financial laws.

The disgraced Rebar group founder also faces a fine of NT$1.7 billion dollars for masterminding a scandal in which he had allegedly siphoned off a record NT$73 billion in corporate funds into his personal or family accounts, according to the indictment.
Prosecutors have also demanded a 28-year jail term and a NT$700 million fine for Wang You-theng's wife Chin Shih-ying, a US citizen now living in Los Angeles.
Among others charged were at least 10 members of Wang's family, including his sons and daughters who had served as heads of different units in Rebar, one of the largest conglomerates in Taiwan.
The couple fled to China and later to the United States in December last year shortly before the group's financial troubles came to light.

The Rebar crisis became public in early January when two of its member companies filed for bankruptcy restructuring with the Taipei District Court. The move sparked a run on Chinese Bank, another Rebar subsidiary which has since been taken over by the state-run Central Deposit Insurance Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCER REMAINS NO.1 KILLER, DEATHS FROM CHRONIC DISEASES DROP: DOH

TEXT.P: Cancer remained Taiwan's top killer in 2006 for a 25th consecutive year, killing 37,998 people and accounting for 28.1 percent of total deaths, according to a statistical report released by the Department of Health (DOH) Thursday.
On average, cancer claimed a life in Taiwan every 13 minutes and 50 seconds, DOH officials said.

An encouraging sign was that the number of deaths caused by various types of cancer, including lung cancer, liver cancer, breast cancer and cervical cancer, declined 1.4 percent compared with 2005, the officials said.

The country's overall death rate also declined significantly last year, the officials said. A total of 135,071 people died in 2006, a decrease of 3,886 people from the previous year, the officials said, adding that the 6.5 percent drop was the steepest in the past 20 years.
The death rates of all of the top 10 causes of death dropped last year compared with 2005, with the exception of deaths caused by suicide which marked a 1.1 percent increase.

The top 10 causes of death in 2006 and their rankings remained the same as in the previous year, with cancer followed in order by stroke, heart disease, diabetes, accidents, pneumonia, chronic liver disease, kidney disease, suicide and hypertension-related diseases.

Wu Hsiu-ying, deputy director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion, attributed the decline in the total number of deaths mainly to an obvious drop in the number of deaths caused by chronic diseases, such as cirrhosis, diabetes and hepatitis.

The death rates of the three diseases slumped 12.8 percent, 11.4 percent and 10.1 percent respectively, Wu said, adding that successes in disease prevention programs that the bureau has promoted for the past few years should be credited for the declines in deaths caused by chronic diseases.

Although the number of suicide-caused deaths continued to rise in 2006, Wu said the 1.1 percent increase rate was a substantial fall from the increase rate registered in 2005, thanks to various suicide prevention projects launched by the public and private sectors over the past year.

The DOH tallies also showed that local people are living longer lives compared with a decade ago. The average lifespan of Taiwan people was 77.5 years in 2006. By gender, the average lifespan of a Taiwan man was 74.57 years, compared to 80.81 years for a local woman. Compared with 2005, the average lifespan of man and woman rose 0.73 year and 1.01 years, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 15, or the first day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1752: Benjamin Franklin, American founding father, diplomat, writer and scientist, flies a kite in a thunderstorm to prove his theory that lightning and electricity are the same phenomenon.
1775: George Washington is elected by Congress as general and commander-in-chief of the army of the United Colonies.
1849: James Knox Polk, the 11th president of the United States, dies at the age of 54. His term was marked by the establishment of the 49th parallel as the northern border west of the Great Lakes.
1860: Nursing pioneer Florence Nightingale opens the world's first school for nurses at St. Thomas' Hospital in London.
1911: The Computing-Tabulating Recording Company (CTR), an American firm that dominated the office equipment and information technology industries, changes its name to International Business Machines Corporation (IBM), becoming the world's largest manufacturer of information systems and equipment.
1919: Aviation history is made as English aviators Capt. John Alcock and Lt. Arthur Whitten Brown touch down in Clifden, Ireland, thus completing the world's first nonstop flight across the Atlantic.
1944: U.S. forces bomb and land on the Mariana Islands, inflicting a heavy defeat on Japanese troops in the west Pacific.
1945: Under the instruction of President Harry S. Truman, the U.S. envoy to China notifies the Chinese government of the Yalta Secret Agreement. Among other conclusions, the U.S., Great Britain and the USSR agreed at Yalta on Feb. 11 that the USSR shall enter the war against Japan on condition that its former rights (in China) plundered by Japan in 1909 shall be restored.
1948: The People's Daily, a Chinese Communist Party newspaper, publishes its first issue.
1957: The Kaohsiung plant of Formosa Plastics Corporation is inaugurated, becoming the first plastics raw material producing plant in Southeast Asia.
1964: The 11th Asian Film Festival opens in Taipei.
1975: Chang Pao-shu, secretary-general of the Kuomintang Central Committee, and four other members leave for Tokyo to attend the funeral of former Japanese Prime Minister Eikaku Sato.
1976: Maj. Gen. Kin Sang Tao, chief of the South Korean Air Force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: After seven years of negotiations, the United States and the Soviet Union sign the second phase of an arms-limitation treaty.
1981: Sun I-suan, chairman of the Taipei Bankers Association, announces an increase in the highest deposit interest rate to 15 percent and in the top loan rate to 18 percent.
1987: The ROC's Legislative Yuan committees pass the proposed National Security Law. The bill was scheduled for submission to the full legislature on June 19.
1987: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa says that the Republic of China is to buy ten commercial aircraft, including six Boeing 747-400 jetliners, from the United States, in an effort to narrow the trade imbalance between the two countries.
1993: The ROC's Legislative Yuan passes The "Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law."
1995: Premier Lien Chan launches a six-day visit to three European countries -- Austria, Hungary, and Czechoslovakia. He is the highest level ROC official to visit Europe since the ROC government moved to Taipei in 1949.
1999: South Korea sinks one North Korean gunboat and heavily damages others in the Yellow Sea.
2000: The three-day 2000 Taipei International Food Exhibition opens at the Taipei World Trade Center, with exhibitors from more than 10 countries participating.
2001: Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, says the information technology (IT) industry will remain be the top player among all industries in the next 10 years.
2004: The Non-Partisan Solidarity Union is inaugurated with former Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya as its founding chairwoman.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To preach in the public streets the commonplaces which you have picked up on the way is to throw away all your finer feelings."

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW AMENDED TO LEGALIZE PRIVATE OWNERSHIP OF AIRCRAFT

TEXT.P: The Civil Aviation Act was amended Friday to allow private ownership of aircraft and relax restrictions on foreign investment in the country's civil aviation industry.

According to the amendment adopted by the Legislative Yuan, individuals, corporations and civic groups can own locally-registered airplanes, although they are forbidden from using their aircraft for commercial operations or leasing.
The Civil Aeronautics Administration should send staff to inspect personnel, equipment and flight operations of privately-owned aircraft regularly, the amendment stipulates.

Also, the amended law provides a legal basis for private business groups and local governments to construct and operate airports, while allowing airline companies to operate executive charter services to overseas destinations using helicopters or aircraft with no more than 19 seats.
To provide Taiwan's civil aviation industry easier access to capital, the amendment relaxes the restrictions on foreign investment in the country's air passenger, air freight and ground services.

While the mandatory ratio of local shareholders was lowered from two-thirds of the total to 50 percent, a single foreign shareholder is allowed to own no more than 25 percent of a company's shares, according to the amendment.

Meanwhile, the revised law criminalizes the circulation of rumors that endanger aviation safety, with violators subject to imprisonment of up to three years or a maximum fine of NT$1 million (US$30,303).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
EMPLOYMENT PERIOD LIMIT FOR FOREIGN WORKERS EXTENDED TO 9 YEARS

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Employment and Services Act Thursday to extend the employment period limit for foreign workers from six years to nine years.
The change was adopted in response to complaints by local businesses that the short employment period lowers their productivity and increases their training costs.

Legislators sympathizing with the businesses had originally advocated lifting the employment period limit altogether but later compromised by agreeing to an extension, following strong opposition from the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).
CLA officials have claimed that removing the employment period limit for foreign workers would have a social and economic impact on Taiwan and increase the personnel costs of employers.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHO URGED TO TALK WITH TAIWAN ON IHR (2005) IMPLEMENTATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's health authorities once again called for the World Health Organization (WHO) Friday to talk with Taiwan regarding the fact that Taiwan is a sovereign state which has a strong intention of implementing the revised International Health Regulations, or IHR (2005).
The revised regulations, which were adopted by the World Health Assembly in May 2005, are set to be officially implemented Friday.

Lin Ting, a spokesman for the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH) , reiterated that China has no jurisdiction over Taiwan and does not have the right to handle Taiwan's public health and disease control affairs.

Noting that Taiwan has implemented the IHR (2005) ahead of schedule, Lin urged the WHO authorities to talk with the government of Taiwan about the matter and designate Taiwan's CDC as the country's national focal point for full implementation of the IHR.

Lin also appealed to the WHO authorities to repeal a memorandum of understanding (MOU) that the WHO signed in 2005 with Beijing under the one-China principle so that Taiwan can be allowed to take part in WHO activities more effectively and make more contributions to the world's health efforts.

The MOU sets limits on Taiwan's applications to attend WHO-related conferences, the rank of Taiwan officials to participate in such gatherings, and the use of the country's official designation, Lin said, adding that even if Taiwan files an application in advance, China usually delays its approval so that Taiwan's representatives cannot receive an invitation from the WHO in time.

Lin made the call after foreign wire services reported Thursday that David Heymann, a WHO assistant director-general in charge of communicable disease affairs, said in Malaysia earlier that day that the WHO will collaborate with China to ensure that Taiwan will be included after the IHR (2005) is fully implemented.

Lin stressed that China has no jurisdiction over Taiwan, including its territorial waters and airspace, adding that Beijing's claim that the IHR covers Taiwan as part of China's territory is unilateral and inconsistent with the facts.
Meanwhile, Shen Lu-hsun, Taiwan's representative in Geneva, said Thursday that the planned WHO-China cooperation in including Taiwan in the implementation of the IHR (2005) is "only empty rhetoric."

Noting that the IHR (2005) stipulates that all WHO member countries are responsible for discovering, reporting and handling public health emergencies, Shen said the issue of Taiwan implementing the revised regulations cannot be compared to the issue of allowing Taiwan experts to take part in WHO technical conferences, because only Taiwan has the right to handle its own internal affairs.

Shen also noted that some 80,000 ships from around the world call at Taiwan seaports each year and that all the vessels must be issued quarantine certificates by the Taiwan authority, asking whether Beijing has similar measures in place.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, RUSSIA TO FURTHER BOLSTER COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, June 15 (CNA) 06/15/07 13:49:23 (By Vlogya Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Russia signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) and an agreement to bolster bilateral exchanges Thursday upon the conclusion of a Taiwan-Russia cooperation forum.

The MOU was signed by Wu Rong-i, chairman of the Taiwan Futures Exchange (TFE) and his counterpart at the Russian Trading System (RTS) Stock Exchange, with Chen Jung-chieh, Taiwan's representative to Russia, witnessing the signing.
Under the MOU, the TFE and the RTS Stock Exchange agree to share stock market information and experience, as well as help each other bolster marketing efficiency under the principle of reciprocity.

The TFE's signing of the MOU with the RTS Stock Exchange marks the exchange's second giant step in efforts to globalize its business operations. It signed a similar MOU with the East European Stock Exchange in May.
Wu, who doubles as the chairman of the Taiwan-Russia Association, who is also chairman of the TFE, played an instrumental role in arranging for the signing of the MOU.

Meanwhile, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) also inked an agreement with the Moscow Federation of Business and Industry Thursday aimed at accelerating bilateral business and trade exchanges between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR KILLED, 14 INJURED IN YILAN COUNTY TRAIN ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: Four people died and 14 others were injured Friday in a train accident at the Tali Railway Station in the northeastern county of Yilan in which two tandem-connected locomotives ran into the ride of a train which was leaving the station.

The accident occurred at around 10: 30 a.m. The locomotives are suspected of having run a red signal onto the traffic railway before hitting the second carriage of the commuter train, according to the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA).

TRA officials said it is believed that the accident was the result of human error as the signal system at the scene operates well. However, they added that as the locomotives had just recently undergone maintenance and repair work, it also possible that mechanical problems may have been the cause of the accident.
The TRA has launched an investigation into the cause of the accident, the officials said, adding that it also checking the names of injured passengers.

The families of each of the four passengers who died in the accident will receive NT$5 million (US$150,850) in compensation, while the TRA will cover all the medical treatment costs for those who were injured, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS INVESTMENT LIMIT RELAXED FOR INSURANCE INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Insurance Law Thursday to allow insurance companies in the country to invest a larger portion of their capital in overseas financial markets.
According to the amendment, the overseas investment limit of insurance companies was raised from 35 percent of their total capital to 45 percent.
Officials at the Financial Supervisory Commission estimated that insurers will be able to channel an additional NT$700 billion (US$21.15 billion) to overseas investment under the amended law.
With excess capital in Taiwan amounting to more than NT$4 trillion, the capital outflow is not expected to seriously impact the country's economy, the officials said.
In fact, they noted, almost half of the capital of the insurance industry has been directed to the trading of foreign currencies even before the law's amendment.

Meanwhile, the amendment passed Thursday stipulates that insurance companies can purchase publicly issued shares, but the value of the shares purchased from a single issuing company must not exceed 5 percent of the insurers' total capital and 10 percent of the issuing company's paid-in capital.
However, insurance companies are forbidden from becoming or appointing proxies to act as a board director or supervisor of the companies they have invested in, according to the amendment.

In addition, insurance companies cannot vote to support their associates or their associates' board directors, supervisors or employees to become board directors or supervisors of the invested companies. And insurance companies cannot appoint any persons to serve as managers in the invested companies.

Meanwhile, the amended law allows property insurance companies to operate health insurance services and permits insurance companies to provide trust services to help secure insurance beneficiaries' compensation payment.

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June rose 152 points to close at 8,595, with 41,472 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for July moved up 169 points to finish at 8,558, with 21,203 contracts traded, while September futures gained 172 points to close at 8,412, with 313 contract transactions. Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
