DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA ADJUSTS UPWARD TAIWAN'S GDP GROWTH FOR 2007

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, raised its forecast Friday for the nation's 2007 economic growth to 4.46 percent thanks to an optimistic global economic outlook and rosier economic prospects in the United States.
The Institute of Economics at Academia Sinica originally forecast Taiwan's 2007 economic growth rate would be 4.21 percent.

Wu Chung-shu, a researcher with the institute, said at a news conference that his institute decided to adjust the 2007 gross domestic product (GDP) growth target upward by 0.25 percentage point to 4.46 percent on the grounds that global economy is gaining momentum, fueled by a recovering U.S. economy while Taiwan's export trade benefits from brisker global sales and a pick up in consumption in the country's private sector.
Wu said the 2007 consumption in the private sector is forecast to gain by 2.57 percent over the 1.45 percent posted in 2006, thanks to dynamic stock and real estate markets.

Growth in private investment, however, is forecast to shrink to 2.40 percent for 2007, down from 2006's 3.26 percent, mainly as a result of uncertainties surrounding the legislative and presidential elections to be held in early 2008, Wu noted.

In foreign trade, Wu said, Taiwan's export trade is expected to grow by 7.63 percent in 2007 mainly as a result of a stronger global economy, but the nation's import trade is forecast to advance by 4.81 percent, slightly lower than the 2006 level of 5.42 percent.

Inflation, he added, defined by the annual growth of the wholesale price index for 2007, is expected to climb to 6.31 percent, up 0.67 percentage point from the 2006 level of 5.64 percent, while growth of the consumer price index expecting to rise to 1.43 percent, up 0.60 percentage point from the year- earlier level.
Meanwhile, Wu forecast that the money supply M1B is expected to grow by 7.99 percent this year, compared to last year's 5.30 percent, largely fueled by a much brisker stock market.
Wu also forecast that the Taiwan's currency, New Taiwan dollar, will fluctuate around NT$33 to US$1 throughout the year.

All in all, he said, other uncertainties -- including international oil prices, whether the U.S. economy will continue to recover, money policies of the world's major economies, China's policy of constraining its over-heated domestic economy, cross-strait relations and Taiwan's domestic politics -- could also contribute to alter the trends governing how the Taiwanese economy unfolds in the second half of 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PRODUCE TRACEABILITY' LABELED TOMATOES ENTER MARKET

TEXT.P: The first batch of Taiwan-grown tomatoes labeled with "produce traceability" recently entered the market, Council of Agriculture (COA) officials said Friday.
The officials noted that the tomatoes were cultivated on a farm in Taichung County with the assistance of the COA's research center in central Taiwan.

With growing concerns among consumers about the hygiene standards of agricultural products, quality inspection labeling on the packaging of such products has become a global trend, the officials said, adding that this is why COA Chairman Su Jia-chyuan made implementing the "produce traceability" system his top priority when he assumed his post in January last year.
The COA's efforts in this regard have borne fruit, with more and more of Taiwan's agricultural products bearing "produce traceability" labels.
Meanwhile, the Legislative Yuan passed the Agricultural Products Production and Certificate Screening Management Law on Jan. 5 this year in a bid to further improve food safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE SUSPECT DETAINED OVER FIRE AT PRESIDENT'S HOUSE

TEXT.P: One suspect was arrested Friday for allegedly setting fire to President Chen Shui-bian's private residence on Ming Sheng East Road. No one was injured in the incident.

The suspect was detained by police shortly after he was seen tossing a five-kilo gas canister into Chen's private house -- on the ground floor of an apartment. No one has inhabited the house since Chen's daughter, Chen Hsin-yu, and her family moved out last year.
Although firemen men immediately rushed to the scene, the fire had already been extinguished by policemen who arrived earlier and detained the suspect.
No one was wounded in the fire, but a rain canopy in front of Chen's house was totally destroyed, police said.

Police have identified the suspect as a 32-year-old man, surnamed Hsu, who is employed as a chef in Hsinchu. Authorities said that the suspect's statements thus far have been contradictory and his motives remain unclear, adding that they suspect that he may be mentally disturbed.
In a statement issued later the same day, the Presidential Office thanked police for detaining the suspect and called for the case to be closed as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNET PROVIDERS REQUIRED TO REPORT INFO ON UNDERAGE PROSTITUTION

TEXT.P: Internet access providers and telecommunication companies are required to report to relevant authorities any information they may have about prostitution activities involving people under the age of 18, according to a law amendment that cleared the Legislative Yuan Friday.

Also required to report such information under the amended Child and Youth Sexual Transaction Prevention Act are chiefs of villages and boroughs, with those failing to comply being subject to a fine of up to NT$30,000 (US$906).

Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator David Huang, a lead sponsor of the amendment, noted that there are approximately 300 reported cases per year in Taiwan in which underage Internet users are sexually abused by friends whom they met online.

Of all teenage prostitution cases in which the Garden of Hope Foundation intervened between 2003 and 2005, 40 percent of the girls and 100 percent of the boys involved had organized sexual transactions over the Internet, Huang pointed out.
In addition, the popularity of mobile phones has increased children's and teenagers' access to pornographic information, Huang said.

With online chat rooms and mobile text messaging services having become convenient channels to the pornographic market, the loose management of the services and the lack of proper protection for users have had an unhealthy influence on children and teenagers, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES SOAR ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange soared Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 122.92 points to close at 8,573.64.

The bourse opened at 8,519.38 and fluctuated between 8,578.33 and 8,511.07 during the day's trading. A total of 5.28 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$151.73 billion (US$4.58 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 2.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 2.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 2.1 percent, textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares both at 1.2 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.7 percent, and construction issues at 0.4 percent.
Foodstuff issues remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 655 to 504, with 195 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARKET VALUE OF LISTED, OTC SHARES TOTALLING NT$22.33 TRILLION

TEXT.P: The market capitalization of Taiwan's listed and over-the-counter (OTC) stocks stood at NT$22.33 trillion (US$675.75 billion) as of the end of May, up 22.3 percent from the same period last year, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Friday.
DGBAS officials said that thanks to a booming stock market, the weighted index, the barometer of the stock market, increased to 8,144.95 as of the end of May, up 1,298 points year-on-year.

The market capitalization of the listed stocks totaled NT$20.16 trillion, up 20.4 percent year-on-year, while the stocks traded amounted to NT$10.52 trillion, down 3.6 percent from the same period last year.

The index measuring value of over-the-counter stocks rose to 181 in May, up 39 points from the same period last year. The number of over-the-counter shares also increased to 533 with a market capitalization totalling NT$2.17 trillion and the shares traded amounting to NT$3.11 trillion.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT ANNULS KAOHSIUNG MAYOR'S ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung District Court has annulled the election of Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu in a judgment handed down Friday.
Chen, who ran on the Democratic Progressive Party ticket, defeated Kuomintang candidate Huang Chun-ying in the Dec. 9 election with a margin of 0.14 percent, or 1,114 votes.
Huang brought forward a suit challenging the outcome and the election itself on Dec. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-RED CROSS SOCIETY SEC-GEN DENIES EMBEZZLEMENT ACCUSATION

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin, who once served as secretary-general of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, rebutted Friday an accusation that the organization has embezzled funds from its government-allotted budget for 20 years.

Hau, who served as Red Cross Society's secretary-general between April 2005 and February 2007, said he had seen to it during his stint that all income and expenses were audited by certified public accountants, making embezzlement impossible at that public-interest organization.
Hau termed it as "immoral" that certain people fabricated a wholly untrue story accusing Red Cross Society management of misusing funds allocated to the organization from government coffers.

He was referring to a report by the Taipei-based China Times daily Friday that quoted ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Wang Jung-chang as saying that Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang has told him recently that an investigation conducted by Ministry of the Interior officials had discovered that Red Cross Society has misused government subsidies over the past 20 years and that the ministry will work to retrieve the money.
Legislator Wang also submitted a proposal at the Legislative Yuan Friday demanding that the Red Cross Society be removed from a list of organizations entitled to special government subsidies.
Interiors Minister Lee said Friday that his ministry will openly state, once the relevant investigations are completed, whether the Red Cross Society management has misused subsidies.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAIL TERM ADOPTED FOR UNAUTHORIZED DOWNLOAD SERVICES

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Copyright Act Thursday to penalize Web site owners who profit by providing unauthorized download services to users.
Violators can be sentenced to imprisonment of up to two years, along with a maximum fine of up to NT$500,000 (US$15,106), according to the amendment.
Web site owners who do not stop these unlawful activities, even after being convicted, can be ordered to close down business, the law stipulates.

Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang, a lead sponsor of the amendment, noted that unlike Web site operators such as Yahoo! and KKBox that provide authorized point-to-point data transmission services, many other site owners are providing music or movie downloads for profit without the authorization of the producers.
Such activities have seriously infringe upon copyright, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CONFIDENT OF CRACKING DOWN ON THREATS AGAINST LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: The director-general of the National Police Agency Friday expressed confidence in ability of the police to solve, in the near term, a case involving threats targeting lawmakers.
Hou Yu-ih said police have identified a suspect, whom they are preparing to arrest in the near future.
Hou made the remarks in response to media inquiries after Legislator Huang Chao-shun of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) received a threatening letter attached to a bullet the previous day.

Earlier Friday, Legislator Lee Chen-nan of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) received a similar "bullet letter", mailed by a self-named "Heiho Association", which invited Lee to join the underworld as a branch chief of the group.

Lee said the bullet attached to the letter belongs to a rifle, a powerful weapon which can shoot through a normal bullet-prove vest. If the letter is not a joke, he believes it is a serious death threat, Lee said.

Besides Huang and Lee, four other lawmakers who received the similar letters, including Legislator Eva Hsieh of the DPP, independent Legislator Lee Ao, Legislator Lin Shu-fen of the DPP, and Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu of the KMT.

Lee pointed out that in addition to himself, six other lawmakers received similar letters at the same time Friday. Saying that the sender of the threatening mail is too bold to respect the law, Lee urged police to break the case as soon as possible.

According to the police, the threatening letters have been assessed as having been sent by a single individual -- likely a political fanatic dissatisfied with the current political situation in the country -- because the Chinese characters on the letters appear to have come from the same printer.

The threatening letters triggered safety concerns among lawmakers following the death of Taipei County Councilor Wu Shan-chiu of the opposition People First Party, who was shot several times by a lone gunman at close range at his office in suburban Taipei May 23. He was pronounced dead on arrival at the hospital.
Before the gangland execution-style killing, Wu had also received a threatening letter attached to a bullet.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMENDMENT TO MONEY LAUNDERING CONTROL ACT PASSED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's legislature has passed an amendment to the Money Laundering Control Act, introducing anti-terrorism regulations and lowering the threshold for offenses to be considered serious crimes.

The amendment stipulates that those who provide financial aid to terrorist organizations, or support terrorist activities, may be sentenced to a maximum of seven years or fined a maximum of NT$10 million.

The amendment also states that cases in which the value of funds laundered exceeds NT$5 million will be considered serious economic crimes, and perpetrators will face stricter punishment. The financial threshold was lowered from NT$20 million in order to better clamp down money-laundering crimes.

Taiwan joined the Egmont Group -- an international anti-money laundering organization -- under the name "Money Laundering Prevention Center (MLPC)." In May the group contacted its 20 members, including Taiwan, urging them to enact legal sanctions in cases involving financial aid to terrorists.
The Executive Yuan thus drafted the amendment based on an analysis of the Asia- Pacific Group on Money Laundering (APG), and 49 proposals from the Financial Action Task Force (FATF).
The amendment stipulates that both outbound and inbound travelers must declare their holdings in foreign currencies or bonds over a certain amount set by the government
Fraud and illegal, high-interest loans regulated under the criminal code are regarded as serious crimes under the money laundering amendment.

In addition, national agricultural banks and trust enterprises have been added to the list of designated financial institutions which must report suspected money laundering activities. Jewelry shops and other institutions likely to be caught up in such crimes are also included in the reporting system.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE SATISFIED WITH HIS 4-DAY ASIAN TRIP
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, June 15 (CNA) 06/15/07 18:51:39 (By Chen I-wei and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that he was satisfied with his four-day visit to India and Singapore.

Ma, a former KMT chairman and two-term mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006, said prior to his departure for home from Singapore that he had clearly conveyed his policy initiatives on relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to the governments of both India and Singapore, and that he had gained India's promise to strengthen scientific and economic cooperation with Taiwan.
During his two-day stay in India, Ma met several Indian ministers and heavyweights of its ruling and opposition parties.

While there, Ma, for the first time, put forward the idea of "mutual non-denial" between Taiwan and China which, considering that mutual recognition seems impossible, he hopes will be conducive to future cross-strait relations.
During his brief stay in Singapore, Ma visited several important political figures in the city state, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew.
Ma told Singaporean politicians that his cross-strait policy is to maintain the Republic of China's status quo without seeking Taiwan's independence or the unification with China.
If the KMT regains the power, it will ensure the dignity of Taiwan and the interests of its people while working to improve relations with China, Ma stressed.

Ma told reporters accompanying him during his trip that the rise of the BRIC countries -- Brasil, Russia, India and China -- and the planned free trade area between ASEAN countries, China, Japan and South Korea, speaks to Taiwan's need to adjust its economic, trade, and foreign policies.
He said his Asian trip was designed to expand Taiwan's economic and trade development space.
Noting that India, which has overlooked Taiwan in the past, took the initiative in inviting him to visit, Ma said this may also indicate India's intention to adjust its trade policy.
Ma stressed his hope that the trip might inaugurate a new way of thinking about Taiwan's foreign relations.

Asked about his "mutual non-denial" idea of cross-strait relations, Ma said that although he believes that China will not accept it completely, the concept at least provides a first step on the road to improving bilateral ties.

According to Ma, Beijing has seldom mentioned its "one country, two systems" formula in recent years, and has instead advocated the peaceful development of cross-strait ties, which Ma described as a change in China's policy.
Given such a change, Ma said his "mutual non-denial" overture, which aims at improving cross-strait relations, may present further opportunities.
Ma is scheduled to return to Taiwan at 7:30 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FARMERS PARTY ESTABLISHED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Farmers Party was established Friday in southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung, with the aim of better representing the rights and interests of local farmers and fishermen.

Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing witnessed the ceremony and congratulated Yang Cheng-chi, chief of the Kaohsiung Farmers' Association, who was chosen party chairman by representatives from local farmers' and fishermen's associations across the country.
Addressing the ceremony, Yang Chiu-hsing said he was happy to see such a party established -- the first of its kind dedicated to grassroots farmers and fishermen in Taiwan.

Yang Chiu-hsing expressed his hope that the new party could help the government work out sound policies to attend to the needs of farmers and fishermen, and contended that its establishment will push other political parties to more attentively heed voices from ranks and files.
For his part, Yang Cheng-chi said that the new party envisions itself as a representative of grassroots workers, and vowed that it will work hard to win public recognition.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE PASSENGERS DIE, OTHER 17 INJURED IN TALI TRAIN ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: The number of the passengers killed in a railway accident Friday at the Tali railway station in Yilan, eastern Taiwan, has increased to five, while the number of injured has risen to 17, according to the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA).

The second carriage of a commuter train was struck at the Tali station by two locomotives running in tandem as it was departing Friday morning, causing a serious blockage of the Eastern Railway Line. According to TRA officials, the accident will interfere with traffic on the Taipei-Hualien line until midnight Friday.
With this mind, TRA officials advised those planning to travel eastbound from Taipei by train later today to seek out other means of transportation, or reschedule the trip.

Yang Cheng-teh, head of the TRA department of transportation affairs, said passengers who have booked tickets on Friday evening east-bound trains will be able to get a refund within two weeks if they return their tickets.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND JUSTICES CONFIRM PRESIDENT'S RIGHT TO KEEP STATE SECRETES

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices confirmed Friday the president's Constitutional right to decide what is a state secret and his right to refuse to disclose it.

In an interpretation of the Constitution, the council said the president, within the authority conferred by the Constitution and the additional articles of the Constitution, has the privilege to keep secret classified information concerning national security, national defense and diplomacy if he determines that their disclosure would compromise national security and interests.
This privilege includes the right to refuse to give testimony and to produce evidence for that purpose in court.

Noting that this privilege should be governed by legislation which does not actually exist, the council said the president may claim it even before the legislation is in place by proclaiming that national security would be jeopardize if he were to be questioned, make a statement or produce evidence.

In the absence of law governing this privilege, the judiciary and prosecution should deal with the president's proclamation according to the Code of Criminal Procedure, and the president may challenge or appeal their decisions or rulings following the same code, said the council.

As to information already produced by the president to the court, the president may still declare it to be classified information according to the law and the court should follow the law related to classified information while using it during a trial.

The council also said the president's constitutional immunity to criminal trial for any crime other than offenses against the internal and external security of the state is designed for the presidency and cannot be forsaken by any individual serving as the president.

This immunity will shield the president from being investigated, prosecuted or tried on criminal charges other than offenses against state's internal and external security while he is in office. It does not means the president is inculpable, and he can be sued for offenses committed in office after he steps down, the council said.

Also, the council said, this privilege will not exempt the president from the obligation to serve as witness in the criminal trials of others, although he can be questioned only at places of his choosing.

The council's decision, agreed upon unanimously by 13 grand justices, was made at the request of President Chen Shui-bian, who refused to produce documents in the trial of his wife for alleged corruption at the Taipei District Court, claiming that doing so would undermine national security.
Chen welcomed the council's decision in a statement issued through his office Friday, and he urged the court to follow the ruling while trying his wife.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELATIONS WITH NICARAGUA SOLID: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Friday that diplomatic relations with Nicaragua are stable.
Huang made the remarks after presiding over a swearing-in ceremony at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of new officials and representatives of overseas offices.

Commenting on media reports that relations between Taiwan and Nicaragua could be on the rocks, Huang said that under the current difficult circumstances, he could not guarantee that relations with every ally will be problem free.
"Taiwan has limited resources and cannot compete with China's checkbook diplomacy," he said.
"What we can do is to be on guard and do everything possible to cement ties with our allies, " he said, adding that "Taiwan's relations with Nicaragua are solid at present."

The Associated Press recently reported that Nicaraguan Vice President Jaime Morales Carazo said that "we as a sovereign country choose who our friends are, " remarks seeming to indicate that Nicaragua is not ruling out possible diplomatic relations with China.
Huang said that he was present when Morales made the statement, adding that it was a "misunderstanding" and that Morales has always been supportive of Taiwan.

On reports that Nicaraguan officials have traveled to Beijing to discuss the establishment of diplomatic relations, Huang said Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega was visiting Africa, its foreign minister was at home and that there were no high-ranking officials in Beijing.
He noted that Nicaragua's new president and ruling party have been in the opposition for a long time and that their urgent task is to develop the economy and reduce poverty.
Taiwan, as the biggest investor in Nicaragua, has created 25,000 jobs there, which is a factor contributing to stable Taiwan-Nicaragua relations, Huang said.

Huang's remarks came against the background of Taiwan's severing of relations with Costa Rica earlier this month afer the Central American country switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, ending a 63-year diplomatic relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL CANDIDATE ELATED AFTER COURT RULING

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Huang Chun-ying said Friday that it is justice overdue after a court ruled to annul the election of Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu.

Huang made the remarks afer the Kaohsiung District Court handed down the ruling Friday to annul Chen's election on the grounds that she used election gambits that could have swayed the outcome of the election prior to the Dec. 9 mayoral election. However, the court rejected another suit against the election itself.

Huang, who lost to Chen of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party by a slim margin of 1,114 votes, filed lawsuits to challenge the outcome and the election itself with the Kaohsiung District Court Dec. 28 and asked that all ballots from 839 polling stations be impounded for a recount.
Huang said the significance of his victory is that it "indicates that democratic elections cannot go against justice."

He lauded the ruling as a "new milestone in Taiwan's democratic development, " adding that he hopes "future elections will take a lesson from this and that election gambits will not continue to hurt Taiwan's democracy."

Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chuang Chi-wan urged Chen to resign immediately to pave the way for by-election so that Huang can take over as mayor, but Chen's camp has said it will appeal the ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TO APPEAL AGAINST DISTRICT COURT RULING: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu will appeal a District Court ruling that nullifies last December's mayoral election result, a city government spokesman said Friday.

Hsiao Yu-cheng, director of the Kaohsiung city government's Department of Information, made the remarks after the Kaohsiung District Court annulled the election result earlier in the day on the grounds that the victor's camp unfairly accused her rival of vote-buying as an election gambit.

In the Dec. 9, 2006 election, Chen Chu of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) squeaked past Huang Chun-ying of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) by a slim margin of 0.14 percent, or 1,114 votes out of some 770,000 cast.

Huang filed a lawsuit late last December claiming that he lost the vote because Chen's camp smeared him by presented a video on the eve of the poll allegedly showing vote-buying on a bus returning from one of his campaign rallies.
The video was repeatedly aired by television stations on election day.
"The tactic... was enough to influence the election result, " the District Court ruled in its verdict.
But the court overruled another lawsuit by Huang aimed at annulling the election itself due to suspected vote rigging.

Commenting on the ruling, Hsiao said the judgment is absurd. "This is the darkest moment in Taiwan's judicial history, given that the candidate who bribed the voters with cash won the election lawsuit," he lamented.

As the city government has not yet received the court verdict, Hsiao said he cannot respond in detail. " At the moment, I can just say that the verdict violates Taiwan's basic values and is unacceptable," he added.
According to Hsiao, the court ruling will not in any way affect Chen's exercise of her mayoral power and performance of her official duties.
As a matter of fact, Hsiao said, the number of Chen's votes increased by 57 after several months of court scrutiny of the ballots.
He claimed that a court ruling giving a vote-buying suspect a lawsuit victory is unfair.
According to the law, an election lawsuit can only be closed by a high court ruling. If the High Court upholds the District Court ruling, a by-election will be held to choose a new mayor.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Palestinian Split Deepens; Government in Chaos
The Palestinian territories seemed headed Thursday to a turbulent political divide. Masked Hamas gunmen took control of the Gaza Strip and the Fatah president dissolved the 3-month-old unity government, declaring a state of emergency and plans for elections.
An aide to President Mahmoud Abbas announced the decrees, including the firing of Prime Minister Ismail Haniya of Hamas, at a West Bank news conference after Hamas militias overran Fatah strongholds in Gaza, dragging men into the street and shooting them.
Wall Street Journal:As Boomers Retire, Insurers Aim to Cash In
When baby boomers were in midcareer and eager to build nest eggs, the mutual- fund, banking and brokerage industries swooped in and took advantage. Now the insurance industry is eyeing that huge pile of money, hoping to build a global business soothing anxiety over whether those nest eggs will last as boomers retire and live long.
The result is a world-wide race to sell variable annuities, a product with risks for insurers and a checkered past for U.S. consumers, thanks to unscrupulous sales practices by some brokers and third-party agents. They typically offer regular payments for life -- no matter how long a customer lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIO-TECH PHARMACEUTICAL INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT STATUTE PASSED

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed Friday a biotechnology and pharmaceutical industry development statute that provides tax benefits to enterprises and individuals in order to encourage investment.
According to the statue, enterprises can have business income tax reductions on up to 35 percent of their investment in research, development and personnel training for five consecutive years.
Technology stocks held by professional personnel will not be included in personal income tax or business income tax. Such stocks will only be taxed after deducting the buying cost when they are sold.

Annual expenditure on personnel training, or research and development exceeding the average amount of the previous two years will get a business income tax reduction of 50 percent of the excess amount.
The regulations of tax benefits are scheduled to last till 2021, and will be examined and adjusted every two years.

The statute also states that with permission from the relevant authorities, researchers in government organizations can hold at least 10 percent of company stocks and can be company founders, directors, or technology consultants. They will not be restricted by the Civil Servant Work Act, which prohibits people in public service from working in private companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Takeover by Hamas Illustrates Failure of Bush's Mideast Vision.
Five years ago this month, President Bush stood in the Rose Garden and laid out a vision for the Middle East that included Israel and a state called Palestine living together in peace. "I call on the Palestinian people to elect new leaders, leaders not compromised by terror," the president declared.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHIEF CALLS FOR PRUDENCE FROM TAIWAN LEADER, CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: It is important for Taiwan's leader and presidential candidates to be careful what they say and do in the 11 months leading up to the 2008 presidential inauguration, American Institute in Taipei (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt said Friday.

The next president will have an opportunity to make progress in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, said Burghardt, who is in Taiwan for a regular visit during which he is scheduled to meet presidential candidates Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang.

"The inauguration of the new president in Taiwan in May 2008 will obviously be an important event. And regardless of who wins, it will present an opportunity for some improvement in cross-strait relations and hopefully for progress on some practical matters to the people of Taiwan, " he said in a roundtable meeting with local reporters.
He said the inauguration of the next president will offer a new start and expressed hope that the new leader will take advantage of it.

As Taiwan's media is notorious for its groundless speculation, the former AIT Taipei Office director urged the candidates to be careful with what they say and do and be ready to experience "scrutiny and over-analysis" from the media, adding that as the 2008 election has attracted international attention, "anyone could poison the atmosphere of cross-strait relations."
Regardless of who wins, he said, the U.S. is confident that "Taiwan-U.S. relations will be in good hands on the Taiwan side."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ACCEPTS RESIGNATION OF TRA HEAD

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung has accepted the resignation of Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) Director-General Chen Feng-nan, who offered to resign Friday to take responsibility for a railway accident that occurred earlier that day, according to Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey.

The accident happened at the Tali railway station in Yilan County, northeastern Taiwan. Five people were killed and 17 others injured. An investigation into the cause of the accident was still going on.
Chen offered his resignation to Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Tui after the accident, Shieh said, adding that Chang later accepted the resignation.
Chang also asked relevant government agencies to clarify the responsibility, pay proper compensation to the families of the dead and provide medical treatment for the injured, said Shieh.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS CALL FOR PASSAGE OF MORE BUDGET BILLS

TEXT.P: A group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers urged Ma Ying- jeou, presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), Friday to ask KMT lawmakers to allow the passage of more budget bills that will help boost economic growth.

The lawmakers issued the call in a Legislative Yuan news conference after the 2007 central government budget bill was eventually included for screening earlier that day, the last day of the Legislative Yuan's current session.
The KMT agreed to scrutinize the bill after Ma expressed willingness to compromise after his party had blocked it for over six months in the opposition "pan-blue alliance"-dominated legislature.

According to DPP lawmakers, the KMT should also approve several other budget bills that are needed to help boost Taiwan's economic expansion, such as a budget bill that would grant NT$77.3 billion for a new 10 major development plans program, as well as two other budget bills that would approve a total of some NT$80.7 billion for state-run enterprises and special funds to pay for 62 other projects.

The KMT and its "pan-blue" ally, the People First Party, must not further procrastinate over these budget bills, they said, arguing that the delay in the annual budget bill's passage has hobbled the economic growth rate by 0.64 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN MAGISTRATE HOPES MINI LINKS WILL SERVE TAIWAN TOURISTS

TEXT.P: As Kinmen is seeking to transform itself from a military bastion into a prime tourist destination, allowing Taiwan tourists to use the "mini three links" to travel to China will greatly help the island achieve its aim, Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng said Friday.
Lee made the remarks during a meeting with a group of 42 Kinmen migrants residing in Taichung County.

Pointing out that Kinmen County is eager to pursue economic progress after the number of military troops stationed there has declined due to a central government policy change, Lee urged the central government to include tourists from Taiwan proper into its scope of the "mini links" to help Kinmen better develop its economy.
"Such an opening will definitely help Kinmen boost its economic development, " Lee said, adding that he will continue reiterating the appeal to Taipei and calling for its quick approval.
By the end of this year, only around 2,000 troops will be left on Kinmen, and this is expected to further adversely impact Kinmen's dwindling economy, he said.

The "mini three links" refer to direct shipping and trade services maintained between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and China's Fujian Province ports of Xiamen and Mawei -- initiated in January 2001 by Taiwan to help offset the lack of direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait and bolster economic growth for the two outlying islands. Quanzhou in Fujian was also added to the links last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHIEF REAFFIRMS CONSISTENCY IN U.S. POLICY

TEXT.P: U.S. policy on Taiwan's participation in international organizations has been consistent over the last thirty years, and the U.S. continues to insist that Taiwan should be allowed to participate in various ways, American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt said Friday.

"Taiwan's being excluded from organizations that require the status of a sovereign state has been, from the beginning, the U.S. policy, " said Burghardt in a roundtable meeting with local press in the middle of his regular visit to Taiwan.
"The U.S. view on Taiwan's membership in the U.N. organizations has been consistent in 1979, 1982 and now, " he stressed.

However, the U.S. has also been the leading voice in supporting Taiwan's participation in organizations that do not require such status, he said, adding that "there are ways in which Taiwan can participate, in even the U.N. organization, in terms of expert participation and observership."
"We are strongly in favor of that. And we strongly oppose games that are played with a nomenclature in order to exclude Taiwan from participating is these organizations, " he said.

Responding to a question from the media on China's oppression of Taiwan in the participation of international organizations, Burghardt said the U.S. "has raised the issue with Beijing and will continue to do so."
As for China's response, "you can probably guess, " he said.

Burghardt has met President Chen Shui-bian, Legislative Speaker Wang Jyng-ping, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, and Foreign Minister James Huang during his visit, which he described as "the standard operating procedure" for the U.S. in countries all over the world in the run up to an election.
He is scheduled to meet Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou Saturday.

Burghardt was the director of the AIT's Taipei office from 1999 to 2001. He served as the U.S. ambassador to Vietnam, the U.S. consul general in Shanghai, and was a staff member at the National Security Council in Washington. Currently he also serves as the Director of East-West Seminars at the East-West Center in Honolulu, Hawaii.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO INVEST US$601 MILLION IN BIOTECH SECTOR

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan plans to appropriate NT$20 billion (US$601.7 million) from the National Development Fund for investment in the biotechnology industry in a drive to create another gigantic industrial sector like those in the fields of digital imaging and semiconductors, the chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday.

Ho Mei-yueh revealed the plan after the Legislative Yuan passed statutes governing the development of the biotech and pharmaceutical industries, which offer tax breaks and other relaxations in these sectors, including allowing government-hired researchers to work in the private sector, something that was previously forbidden.
The statutes also stipulate reinforced regulations on the protection and transfer of intellectual property rights, as well as improved regulations on pharmaceutical administration.
Because of the new statutes, Ho said, her council is confident of seeing a breakthrough in the development of the biotech and pharmaceutical sectors in the near future.
According to CEPD statistics, the National Development Fund has invested NT$7.8 billion in the biotech sector, with NT$3.69 billion of the money directly flowing into biotech enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMENDMENTS PRESCRIBE JAIL TERMS UP TO ONE YEAR FOR ANIMAL CRUELTY

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan Thursday passed amendments to the Animal Protection Law that would impose a jail term of up to one year for people convicted of animal abuse leading to death.

The amendments stipulate that perpetrators of various offensive acts against animals that result in severe injuries or the death of animals could be punished by up to a year in prison. These include pet owners who allow their pets to be harassed, abused, or harmed; pet owners who desert their pets; and any person convicted of harassing, abusing, harming or abandoning animals.

Other offenders subject to the jail sentence also include pet owners who fail to provide necessary health care for injured or ill animals, anyone caught slaughtering animals in public places without permission from relevant authorities, or anyone discovered slaughtering animals without following legal procedures.
Under the current law, animal abuse is only punishable by fines range from NT$10,000 to NT$50,000.
The amendments also prescribe that people who commit aforesaid acts twice in five years be subject to a prison sentence of up to one year.
Under the new law, offenders could be sentenced to a jail term up to one year plus a fine up to NT$10,000 if they commit specified offenses twice in five years.

These include violation of regulations regarding the transportation of animals; performing medical treatment or surgery for animals without taking into consideration their health condition; and slaughtering animals without the supervision of a vet.

While in view of the fact that as many as 70 percent of hogs in Taiwan are inhumanely slaughtered, the Legislative Yuan also approved a resolution requesting that the central government authority enact procedures to ensure more humane animal- slaughtering procedures.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR INFECTED WITH DENGUE FEVER AFTER TRIP TO VIETNAM

TEXT.P: Four out of a group of five people who traveled to Vietnam early this month to broker a marriage to a Vietnamese woman have been confirmed to have been infected with dengue fever, the Department of Health (DOH) said Friday.
Health officials said that the group was from Chiayi County and noted that a 50 -year-old was the first reported to have been infected June 12.

Health officials later found that a young man and his mother, both of whom are friends of the 50-year-old, and a Taiwanese man and his Vietnamese wife who was trying to introduce a Vietnamese woman to the young man, recently developed the symptoms of fever, aching bones and headaches that accompany dengue fever.
Further tests found that three of them had been infected, while the other was still being tested.

In addition, Nantou County also reported a case of hemorrhagic dengue fever a day earlier. The patient is a six-year girl who went with her mother to Vietnam May 10-June 7 and developed fever the day she returned to Taiwan, although she was not diagnosed at the time.
But her high fever persisted and she also developed rashes on her face and body, prompting the hospital to reported her as being infected with hemorrhagic dengue fever.

Lin Ting, deputy director of the DOH Center for Disease Control, said that there have been 36 imported dengue fever cases so far this year, 22 of which came from Indonesia, followed by nine cases from Vietnam and three cases from Thailand.
Lin noted that dengue fever infection is serious in Southeast Asia and that it is sometimes fatal. He urged the public to be on guard against mosquito bites when traveling to the region.

With the continuous rain in recent days, he also urged the public to remove standing water from their environments in the hope of reducing the breeding areas of the mosquitoes and preventing an outbreak of indigenous dengue fever.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS ASK FOR DETENTION OF EASTERN MULTIMEDIA HEAD

TEXT.P: Prosecutors demanded Friday the detention of Eastern Multimedia Group Chairman Gary Wang, a son of the fugitive Rebar Asia-Pacific Group founder Wang You- theng, after questioning him.
The prosecutors made the request one day after they led nearly 200 investigators and policemen on a raid of 29 offices of the subsidiaries of the Eastern Multimedia Group and Wang's residence.

Taipei prosecutors said Wang is involved in several major cases involving the securities transaction law, the banking law, breach of trust, conversion of property and the government purchase law. As he has the possibility of colluding with other accomplices, they asked the Taipei District Court to detain him.

Lin Ching-tsun, deputy chief prosecutor of the Taipei Prosecutors Office, noted that cases under investigation include Wang's group winning a project to operate the giant sports dome, the sale of land at the Nankang Software Park to an affiliated enterprise, diversion of funds from Asia Pacific Broadband and illicit loans from the Chinese Bank, an affiliate of Rebar Group.

Wang, who once served as a lawmaker and chairman of the ROC General Chamber of Commerce thanks to the political and financial clout of his father's powerful Rebar group, has until now avoided being caught since a major scandal triggered by his father earlier this year.

Rebar's financial woes came to light after two of its member companies -- China Rebar Co. and Chia Hsin Food and Synthetic Fiber Co. -- applied for bankruptcy protection Dec. 29. Their insolvency reorganization announcement prompted a run on the Chinese Bank, another Rebar subsidiary. The bank has since been taken over by the state-run Central Deposit Insurance Corp.

Judicial probes into the group's suspected financial crimes followed. Investigators have launched many rounds of large-scale searches at Rebar headquarters and the offices of several of its 120-odd member companies, as well as the homes of the Wang family and corporate executives.
Wang's brothers and more than 100 other family members and corporate executives were indicted in March on various charges.

Wang You-theng and his wife, Wang Chin Shi-ying fled to the United States in January. Wang has since been detained at an immigrant detention center in Los Angeles, although his wife is free because she is an American citizen.
The government has so far failed to extradite the couple back to Taiwan to face justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE FINALLY PASSES 2007 BUDGET BILL

TEXT.P: The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan finally passed the central government's 2007 budget bill Friday, which includes funds for certain arms procurement projects.
According to the newly passed bill, the government's annual revenues are projected at more than NT$1.48 trillion, while the expenditures are set at NT$1.63 trillion.

On the confidential budget section, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu- fang said an outlay of NT$200 million was approved to finance a feasibility study on Taiwan's efforts to purchase diesel-electric submarines from the United States while the remaining NT$4.3 billion for the submarine deal was deleted.

The funding for a submarine-hunting P3-C aircraft procurement plan, totaling more than NT$6.l billion, was approved, but an outlay of NT$11.3 billion for procuring Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries was killed, Lin said, adding that a NT$3.5 billion fund for upgrading the performance of Patriot PAC-2 anti- missile batteries was passed.

Meanwhile, the legislature froze one-third of the NT$16 billion outlay for an F-16 C/D jet fighter purchase plan, Lin said, adding that the freeze will be lifted if the Ministry of National Defense manages to obtain U.S. consent to the deal by the end of October.

At the opposition camp's insistence, President Chen Shui-bian's discretionary "special affairs funds" was cut from NT$50 million to NT$30 million, with the added proviso that the funds must all be reimbursed with receipts or sales invoices. In the past, only 50 percent of the fund needed proof of spending to be reimbursed.

The budget bill was stalled for more than six months because the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party, which controls a slim majority in the legislature, held the bill hostage to a bill to amend the Central Election Commission (CEC) Organic Law.
With more people getting angry with the opposition's boycott of the government budget bill, the KMT finally changed its mind and agreed to let go of the budget bill.

To vent its anger at the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's stonewalling of the CEC Organic Law amendment bill, the "pan-blue alliance" maneuvered to freeze a quarter of the CEC's 2007 budget and demand that the fronze fund cannot be used until after the CEC amendment bill is passed and a new commission is formed in terms of new rules.
According to a government estimate, the country's economic growth rate will will drop 0.25 percent to 0.3 percent if the budget bill fails to clear the legislature by the end of June.

The legislature will go into summer recess after the closure of Friday's session. Both ruling and opposition camps have unveiled plans to push for the holding an extra session in July or august to pass several other bills they respectively favored.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 16, or the second day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1890: American comedian Stan Laurel is born in England. With Oliver Hardy, he formed the first great comedy team of the talking film era. Their works include "The Music Box," "Hog Wild," "Way Out West," "The Flying Deuces" and "A Chump at Oxford."
1922: China's Chen Chiung-ming revolts against Dr. Sun Yat-sen, bombarding the presidential office on Kuanyingshan in Canton. Sun escapes from the office at night and reaches the naval headquarters at Chuhai aboard the warship "Chuyi."
1924: A school-opening ceremony is held at China's Whampoa Military Academy, presided over by superintendent Chiang Kai-shek.
1935: President Franklin D. Roosevelt's "New Deal" legislative package is passed by the House of Representatives. The Social Security Bill is aimed at tackling America's severe economic problems.
1941: Roosevelt orders the closure by July 10 of all German consulates in the United States.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Kaimaing in northern Burma.
1953: A total of 75 F-84 G Thunder jet fighters, the first batch of military equipment to be provided to the Republic of China by the United States, arrive at an ROC air force base in Tainan, southern Taiwan.
1961: Rudolf Nureyev, the 23-year-old Russian dancer who was the star of the Leningrad Ballet, asks for political asylum in France.
1963: Valentina Tereshkova of the Soviet Union blasts off in Vostok 6 to become the first woman in space.
1969: Earl Alexander of Tunis, a British field marshal during World War II, dies at the age of 78. He directed the British troop evacuation from Dunkirk, France, and led maneuvers in Burma, North Africa and Italy.

1977: Leonid Brezhnev, general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, is elected chairman of the Presidium (the Politburo), succeeding Nikolao Podgorny.
1977: Werner von Braun, a German-born American rocket pioneer, dies at the age of 65. He designed the German V1 and V2 rockets and later worked as director of the U.S. Army team that put the first American satellite, Explorer I, into space in 1958.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DPP CHAIRMAN RETURNS AFTER U.S. VISIT

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday he fully supports Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu's decision to appeal against a Kaohsiung District Court ruling that annuls her mayoral election victory.
Yu made the remarks upon his return from an 11-day visit to the United States that took him to several major U.S. cities, including San Francisco, Los Angeles and New York.

As the district court in the southern port city just handed down its election lawsuit ruling a day earlier, Yu was asked about his view on the issue right after his arrival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway.

Yu said he needs to get more information before making a detailed comment. But anyway, he added, the DPP and he himself will throw full support behind Chen in her quest for justice through due process of law.

During his just-concluded trip, Yu said he met with many DPP members, faithful supporters and Taiwanese expatriates in the United States to listen to their views on major Taiwan-related topics. Yu said he also took the opportunity to urge them to return to vote for DPP candidates in the next legislative and presidential elections to be held early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NON-PROFIT GROUPS IN D.C. TO PROMOTE NGO EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 15 (CNA) 06/16/07 12:58:06 (By Michelle Tsai and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A delegation of 15 representatives of Taiwan's non-profit organizations (NPOs) is on a visit in Washington, D.C. for exchanges with their U.S. counterparts regarding the operations of non-governmental organizations (NGOs), Taiwan officials posted in the United States said Friday.

Members of the delegation include Chiang Kuo-chiang, vice chairman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' NGO Affairs Committee, as well as representatives of the Taiwan NPO Self-Regulation Alliance, the officials said.

During their stay in the U.S. capital, the delegation members will call on major U.S. non-profit organizations to survey how these organizations assess their efficiency with financial and management criteria, the officials said.

Stanley Kao, Taiwan's deputy representative to the United States, noted that as various non-profit and non-governmental organizations are flourishing in Taiwan, NPOs are playing an increasingly important role in the process of Taiwan's development toward a mature civil society.

Kao said visits such as this one will enhance exchanges between Taiwan's NPOs and other similar organizations around the world, which he noted will help Taiwan's NPOs build up their trustworthiness and credibility.

The Taiwan NPO Self-Regulation Alliance was founded in 2005 with the goal of promoting financial transparency and accountability of NPOs to protect the rights of donors. It currently has a total of 80 member organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISTRICT COURT GRANTS NT$100 MILLION BAIL TO EMG CHAIR

TEXT.P: Eastern Multimedia Group (EMG) Chairman Gary Wang was granted NT$100 million (US$3.03 million) bail Saturday after being questioned about his alleged role in a spate of suspected bribery and other financial crimes.
Taipei prosecutors asked for Wang's detention after summoning him and several other EMG executives for questioning, but the Taipei District Court granted him bail.
As NT$100 million is a large sum, an EMG spokesman said, the company needs time to collect the money for Wang's release.

The bail amount is the second highest in Taiwan's judicial history. On Aug. 29, 2005, a Taipei district court judge granted NT$150 million bail to Hu Hung-jeou, a former finance chief of Pacific Electric Wire and Cable Co. in a corporate fund embezzlement case.
Prosecutors began questioning Wang and other company officials Thursday after a series of raids on EMG offices and Wang's properties.

Wang and his associates are being questioned about their roles in four suspected cases, including selling the group's stocks at an unreasonably low price; embezzling funds from Asia Pacific Broadband Telecom Co., an EMG-affiliated fixed-line operator; selling an EMG property to Union Insurance Co. and subsequently renting out the property in order to avoid paying taxes; and bribing Taipei City government officials to win a nine-year contract to operate the Taipei Arena, a multifunctional stadium in a bustling Taipei commercial district.
As of Saturday, 17 senior executives of EMG and its affiliate companies as well as two Taipei city government officials have been listed as crime suspects.

Gary Wang is a son of Wang You-theng, the fugitive Rebar Asia Pacific Group founder who has been indicted together with 106 others for their alleged involvement in one of the country's largest financial scandals.
Gary Wang has repeatedly denied allegations that he embezzled money from Rebar group and then shifted the funds to Eastern Multimedia Group, which he founded.

Prosecutors have sought a 30-year prison term for the 82-year-old Wang You- theng, who has been detained in Los Angeles after his passport was revoked by Taiwan for allegedly violating securities, accounting and other financial laws.

The Rebar group founder also faces a fine of NT$1.7 billion dollars for masterminding a scandal in which he had allegedly siphoned off a record NT$73 billion in corporate funds into his personal or family accounts, according to the indictment.
Prosecutors are also seeking a 28-year jail term and a NT$700 million fine for Wang You-theng's wife, Chin Shih-ying, a U.S. citizen now living in Los Angeles.

Among others charged were at least 10 members of Wang You-theng's family, including his sons and daughters who had served as heads of different units in Rebar, one of the largest conglomerates in Taiwan.
The couple fled to China and later to the United States in December last year shortly before the group's financial troubles came to light.

The Rebar crisis became public in early January when two of its member companies filed for bankruptcy restructuring with the Taipei District Court. The move sparked a run on Chinese Bank, another Rebar subsidiary which has since been taken over by the state-run Central Deposit Insurance Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REPS BACK TAIWAN'S OLYMPIC PARTICIPATION UNDER NATIONAL NAME
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 15 (CNA) 06/16/07 13:41:01 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Several members of the U.S. House of Representatives put forth Friday a piece of legislation urging the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to allow Taiwan to use its national name, flag and anthem in the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing.

Rep. Tom Tancredo (R-Colo.) , a lead sponsor of the legislation, said it is discriminatory and therefore against the Olympic Charter for the IOC to require that Taiwan use the name "Chinese Taipei, " instead of its official title "Republic of China, " to take part in Olympic games and for it to forbid the country from playing its national anthem and displaying its national flag.

According to the Olympic Charter, any form of discrimination with regard to a country or a person on the grounds of race, religion, politics, gender or otherwise is incompatible with belonging to the Olympic Movement.
The Olympic Charter also directs the IOC to "oppose any political or commercial abuse of sport and athletes," Tancredo noted.
"It's disappointing that the IOC seems to be more interested in acting as a foreign policy handmaiden for Beijing than it does in promoting sportsmanship and fair play," he said.
Pointing to the example of Puerto Rico, Tancredo noted that despite the territory's status as a U.S. commonwealth, it is not required to use the name "American San Juan" to compete in Olympic games.
Co-sponsors of the legislation include Steve Chabot (R-Ohio), Dan Burton (R-Ind.) and Thaddeus McCotter (R-Mich.).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO VISIT KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TO SHOW SUPPORT FOR APPEAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to call on Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu Sunday to show his support for the mayor's decision to appeal a court ruling that annuls her election victory, Presidential Office sources said Saturday.

The president is supportive of Chen Chu's decision to appeal and has full confidence that the ruling will be overturned by a higher court, the sources said, adding that the president will also make a major statement during his Sunday meeting with Chen Chu.

The president will be accompanied by Chen Chi-mai, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, and Lee Nan-Yang, director of the Department of Public Affairs, when he calls on Chen Chu at her mayoral residence, the sources said.
The mayor was released from hospital earlier this week after suffering a minor stroke April 26.

The Kaohsiung District Court handed down the ruling on Friday, annulling Chen's election victory on the grounds that she used election gambits, referring her spreading words of "bribery" by the camp of Huang Chun-ying, the main opposition Kuomintang's candidate, after the campaign activities had officially ended on the eve of the Dec. 9 mayoral election, that the court claimed could have swayed the outcome of the election.

Huang filed lawsuits to challenge the outcome of the election and the election itself after losing by a razor-thin margin of 1,140 votes to Chen Chu. The court rejected the second suit against the election itself Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMENDMENT BANNING SMOKING IN ALL INDOOR PUBLIC PLACES PASSED

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment Friday to the Tobacco Hazards Prevention and Control Act (THPCA) to prohibit smoking in all indoor public spaces.

Under the amendment, no smoking will be allowed in any common indoor work space that can accommodate at least three people or public indoor spaces such as educational, medical treatment, government, financial, transportation or entertainment facilities
However, smoking will still be allowed in smoking rooms that have their own air conditioners, as well as at cigar stores, KTVs and pubs open after 9:00 p.m., and outdoor spaces at dining facilities.
The amendment also raises the fine for violators to between NT$2,000 (US$60) and NT$10,000 from between NT$1,000 and NT$3,000.

Also under the amendment, people aged under 18 and those who are pregnant will be prohibited from smoking. Youth who violate the law will have to attend a quit-smoking educational program, and their parents or guardians will be obliged to be present. Parents or guardians who fail to attend will be fined between NT$2,000-NT$10,000 for each absence.

The amendment also doubles the tobacco tax, with the tax on cigarettes rising NT$500 per 1,000 cigarettes, that on cigars increasing NT$500 per kilogram and that on shredded tobacco rising NT$500 per kilogram.

Furthermore, the manufacturing of candy, desserts, toys or any other objects in the form of any kind of tobacco product will be prohibited, and no tobacco advertisements will be allowed on any electronic devices, the Internet or magazines.

Tobacco-relevant businesses will also be prohibited from offering discounts or awards in promoting their products and from organizing promotional activities, such as sampling and presentation. Violators will be subject to a fine of between NT$5 million and NT$24 million.
The amended THPCA is expected to take effect about 18 months after being announced.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES RICE TO KENYA FOR FAMINE RELIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 15 (CNA) 06/16/07 15:54:38 (By Chiehyu Lin and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has donated 5,000 metric tons of rice to Kenya, in collaboration with the international charity organization Feed the Children (FTC), as relief for the East African country which has been struck by famine caused by drought, Taiwan's representative to the United States, Joseph Wu said Friday.

Wu said that the donated rice has been shipped to Kenya and that it will be delivered to Kenyan children by the FTC through local social welfare organizations, such as orphanages and hospitals in Kenya's capital Nairobi.

The donation is part of Taiwan's participation in the FTC's program to feed millions of children suffering in areas struck by famine, Wu said, adding that another 5,000 metric tons of rice donated by Taiwan has been delivered to its diplomatic ally Malawi in southeastern Africa through the FTC.

Taiwan worked with the FTC in 2005 to deliver a donation of 10,000 metric tons of rice to Indonesian victims of the tsunami disaster of December 2004, and it also donated 52 containers of new clothing worth a total of US$17.6 million to over 160,000 children in need of clothes in 11 countries last year.

The FTC and its long-term partner, the United States' National Basketball Association (NBA) , held a news conference in Cleveland City, Ohio, Wednesday to announce Taiwan's donation, which was reported by major newspapers in the United States Thursday, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC TO OPERATE WITH CURRENT REGULATIONS AS AMENDMENT FAILS

TEXT.P: A Central Election Commission (CEC) official said Saturday that the CEC will operate with its current regulations as an amendment bill to the CEC Organic Law failed to be passed in the Legislative Yuan Friday.

CEC Spokesman Teng Tien-yiou noted that the tenure of the 19 members of the CEC was set to expire Saturday, and the premier will ask the president to designate new CEC members in accordance with the current law.
According to the current CEC regulations, the CEC will have 11 to 19 members with a tenure of three years.

The CEC amendment bill failed to be passed in the just-concluded session due to major differences between ruling and opposition parties over the composition of the CEC, with the opposition parties demanding that members be chosen in proportion to the number of seats each party maintains in the legislature, and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) insisting that the current system be used.

Unhappy with the CEC amendment bill's failure in the legislature, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" maneuvered to freeze a quarter of the CEC's budget for 2007, saying that the frozen funds will only be allowed to be used after the CEC amendment bill is passed and a new commission is formed.
Teng noted that it is the Legislative Yuan's right under the Constitution to freeze the CEC's budget, adding that he had no further comment on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR PASSAGE OF BUDGET FOR STATE-OWNED ENTERPRISES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged legislators Saturday to hold a special session to review a list of important budget bills, including the budget for state-owned enterprises.

Raising the issue during a visit to Changhua County, Chen expressed his gratitude for the legislature's passage of the central government's 2007 budget bill Friday after it was delayed for more than six months.

However, several other budget bills, such as one concerning the operations of state-owned enterprises and another one for 10 major development projects, have yet to clear the legislature, Chen noted, calling on legislators to speed up their passage by holding an extra session to deal with them.

Responding to the president's proposal, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary- General Wu Den-yih said that whether the opposition will agree to include the budget bills on the agenda of the special session will depend on whether the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is ready to compromise on a bill to amend the Central Election Commission (CEC) organic law.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party as well as the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union are promoting a motion to hold a special legislative session to review the KMT-initiated CEC bill concerning the formation of the 17-member CEC.

Owing to strong opposition from the DPP, the "pan-blue alliance" -- which holds a slim majority in the legislature -- failed in its bid to steamroll the CEC bill through the legislature, despite its attempt to hold the CEC bill hostage with the 2007 budget bill during the last legislative session ended Friday and the previous session ended in January.

The 2007 budget bill only passed the legislature on the final day of the last session after the "pan-blue alliance" finally agreed to let go of it in view of growing public displeasure with their move.

The KMT has insisted that the 17 members of the CEC be recommended by political parties in proportion to the number of seats they each hold in the legislature, with no single party allowed to control more than two-fifths of the total seats.
However, the DPP opposes any party-based proportional principle for the CEC's formation on the ground that such a practice violates the "division of power" provision set forth in the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU HOSPITAL CELEBRATES 112TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The National Taiwan University Hospital celebrated its 112th anniversary Saturday, inviting cancer patients to strut the catwalk to show their confidence in fighting to conquer the disease and start a new life, an NTU spokesman said.
The NTU Hospital arranged the show on its 112th anniversary in order to make the celebration more meaningful, the spokesman said.

Lin Yun-ying, a leukemia patient, and Hung Wei-ling, a breast cancer patient, both had suffered from despair and pain during medical treatment and had even written their wills in the expectation that they would soon die. However, they conquered their fear and hopelessness and became volunteer workers at the hospital to share their experiences with patients in order to console them and ease their suffering.
Lin and Hung joined Saturday's catwalk show to encourage more patients, the spokesman said.

Other activities held to celebrate the hospital's anniversary included a singing performance by senior Taiwanese singers Chang Chi and Hsieh Lei, and a wheelchair ballroom dance sponsored by the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE ELABORATES ON CROSS-STRAIT POLICY TO AIT HEAD

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that he explained the party's cross-strait policy during a meeting with Raymond Burghardt, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), earlier the same day.
Ma made the remarks when he attended a Hami melon festival in Yilan, northeastern Taiwan.

Ma said that he spoke about the KMT's present situation, Taiwan-U.S. relations and future cross-strait policy during the meeting with Burghardt, stressing that if he is elected, he will bring peace to both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The KMT does not want volatile cross-strait relations, although it will insist on its stance and will never capitulate to China, he said.
He also told Burghardt that "Beijing must first remove its missiles targeting Taiwan before the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can engage in peace negotiations."

Burghardt, who arrived Wednesday for his second visit to Taiwan following his appointment as AIT chairman in February 2006, has said that he wants to meet the 2008 presidential candidates of the two major parties in Taiwan.
The AIT is authorized by the United States to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.
Meanwhile, Ma said a court ruling Friday to annul Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu's election victory shows that "one should adopt legitimate methods to win an election."
"The practice of candidates making unsubstantiated accusations on the day of the election should be checked, otherwise, it will be difficult to ensure fair elections in the future," he said.

Ma claimed that if the court did not hand down the ruling on annulling the election, then there would probably be other election "gambits" by candidates on election day in the future, which he said would be "detrimental to the development of Taiwan's democracy."

He was referring to the bribery allegations by Chen Chu's camp, including President Chen Shui-bian himself, against Huang Chun-ying, the KMT's Kaohsiung mayoral candidate, on the day of the Dec. 9 mayoral election.

The Kaohsiung District Court handed down the ruling on the grounds that Chen Chu used election gambits that could have swayed the outcome of the election. Huang filed lawsuits to challenge the outcome of the election and the election itself after losing by a razor-thin margin of 1,140 votes to Chen Chu. The court rejected the second suit challenging the election itself Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TALI RAILWAY ACCIDENT CAUSED BY HUMAN ERROR: PRELIMINARY PROBE

TEXT.P: Friday's railway accident leading to five deaths at the Tail Railway Station in Yilan, northeastern Taiwan was caused by human error, a high-ranking Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) official cited a preliminary investigation report as saying Saturday.

TRA Secretary-General Chang Ying-huei said that the driver of the train, identified as Lin Chung-liang, failed to follow the pre-warning signals until it was too late to stop the locomotive ahead of the last red signal light that indicated the approach of a passenger train.

Lin was driving a locomotive joined with another locomotive on a test run when the accident occurred. Chang pointed out that Lin turned off the Automatic Train Protection (ATP) system after its malfunction. However, he added, Lin failed to stay alert after switching off the system installed in the train to help prevent collisions through a driver's failure to observe a signal or speed restriction.
A preliminary probe showed that the locomotives ran into the side of the commuter train at a speed of 49 kilometers per hour.
Lin was severely disciplined and was transferred to a different job within the TRA, while his supervisors were also disciplined, Chang announced.

As for TRA Director General Chen Feng-nan's resignation after the largest railway tragedy in Taiwan in 15 years, Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Ho Nuan-hsuan said that the ministry will deal with the matter after the probe into the accident is completed.

On Nov. 15, 1991, two trains collided with each other on the Chaochiao section of the West Rail Line in the northern county of Miaoli. Thirty people died and more than 100 others were injured in the accident which was later determined to have been caused by human error.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW AMENDED TO ALLOW TRADE GROUPS TO ISSUE CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed a set of amendments to the Trade Law Friday that will allow trade and industrial groups to issue certificates of origin for Taiwan's exports.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Wang Hsien-nan, who initiated the amendments, explained that he proposed the amendments due to an error in the Trade Law amendments approved last December in which trade and industrial groups were unintentionally omitted from the list of agencies qualified to issue certificates of origin for the country's exports.
"The error has seriously affected the interests of local trade and industrial groups and caused disputes," Wang added.
Friday's amendments also allow agricultural and fishing associations, provincial-level agricultural cooperatives, and marketing associations of agricultural products to issue such certificates.

The amendments stipulate that the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs is the agency responsible for issuing certificates of origin for exports and that the bureau can entrust the mentioned organizations to issue such certificates if necessary.

The amendments also stipulate that any of the mentioned organizations that violate the regulations will face a fine of between NT$30,000 and NT$300,000 or have their right to issue such certificates suspended for up to a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATION ON PROFESSIONAL SPORTS COACH EMPLOYMENT PASSED

TEXT.P: Legislation concerning the employment of professional sports coaches was finally passed during the current session of the Legislative Yuan after having been shelved for the past two decades.

The Legislative Yuan passed the amendment to the National Sports Act Friday night, designating the Ministry of Education (MOE) as being in charge of issues concerning the employment of professional sports instructors, including wages, welfare, and definition of duties.

The amendment also stipulates that management of issues concerning the retirement, resignation and laying off of professional sports coaches be conducted based on regulations applied to educational personnel.

Sports Affairs Council officials described the passage of the legislation as one of the most significant events in the domestic sports sector this year, predicting that the amendment will have a profound and positive effect on the development of Taiwan's sports programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: THIS YEAR'S GRADUATES MORE ACTIVE IN JOB SEARCH: JOB BANK

TEXT.P: Recent graduates are more actively engaging in job search this year than last year, an official of an online employment service provider said Saturday.

According to Chiu Wen-jen, marketing director of 104 Job Bank, 151,113 fresh graduates had looked for jobs through the job bank as of early June, compared with 131,978 recorded during the same time last year.
Chiu said the job market is more competitive this year because the number of job openings for fresh graduates is 7 percent lower this year as compared with last year.
The fact that more people have begun their job search even before graduation also intensifies the competition, Chiu said.
Of the positions open to fresh graduates this year, those in the electronics and information technology sectors account for the largest portion, at 26.9 percent, she said.
While positions in the general manufacturing industry account for 13.7 percent, those in the financial, investment consultancy and insurance industries account for 13.1 percent, she added.
