Police are to examine the findings of a long-awaited report into allegations of illegal payments, or bungs, in football which for the first time identifies deals involving Chelsea, Britains highest-spending club.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUCHANG HIGHWAY INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung presided over an inauguration ceremony to kick off the operations of the newly completed Yuchang Highway in eastern Taiwan Saturday.
The highway, at 16.2 kilometers long and nine meters wide, runs through the coastal mountain range, linking Yuli Township in Hualien County and Changbin Township in Taitung County.
The highway, which took nine years to build at a cost of NT$2.5 billion (US$75.43 million), also features 12 bridges and the Yuchang Tunnel, which is 2.6 kilometers long.

Many residents of the counties of Hualien and Taitung gathered to celebrate the inauguration, with aboriginal singing and dancing groups putting on performances and aboriginal elders performing rituals to bless the new highway.

Chang expressed his gratitude for the efforts of the Directorate General of Highways and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications in working to complete the highway's construction a half year ahead of schedule.

The opening of the highway will be beneficial to the tourist industry of Taitung and Hualien, Chang said, adding that the government will help promote the two counties' tourism around the world and establish a joint administrative center ineastern Taiwan to improve the efficiency of civil services to local residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-CHIANG SKIT STAGED AT DEMOCRACY MEMORIAL HALL

TEXT.P: A group of young people staged a skit at the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, formerly known as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, Saturday to highlight the reasons why they had been opposed to the memorial hall's old name.

The young men and women were invited by the Hand-in-Hand To Safeguard Taiwan Alliance and the Memorial Foundation of 228 to launch the short theatrical performance designed to remind the public of the "absurdity" of having a memorial hall dedicated to the late President Chiang Kai-shek who the group denounced as a dictator and culprit of the tragic 228 Incident.
The performers named 10 reasons for opposing a memorial hall for Chiang, not the least of which the fact that Chiang was a dictator who suppressed the people's rights.
They reminded the general public to ponder the issue thoroughly and help Taiwan come out of the shadows of its past authoritarian rule.

Chiang is considered by many to be the mastermind behind the 228 Incident, which refers to an an uprising against the corrupt Kuomintang (KMT) administration that began Feb. 28, 1947 and which led to the murder of thousands of civilians. The incident consequently led to four decades of martial law rule by the Kuomintang.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUSEUM DEPUTY CURATOR HELD INCOMMUNICADO OVER SUSPECTED SCANDAL

TEXT.P: National Palace Museum Deputy Curator Lin Po-ting was held incommunicado by prosecution authorities Saturday in connection with a suspected profiteering scandal involving the museum's facelift project.

Prosecutors asked for court permission to detain Lin, former National Palace Museum Curator Shih Shou-chien, screening member Chang Chin-chuan and clerk Sun Chao-feng, for further probes after questioning the four and five others.
The court granted the request to detain Lin but released Shih and Chang on bail of NT$1 million (US$30,300) and NT$400,000 bail, respectively. Sun was also released.

Chou Ching-lin, a former general affairs department director of the museum, was released on NT$500,000 bail. Duan Yung-ting, vice president of an engineering consultant company; Liu Chang-hsin, a former secretary-general of the National Palace Museum; Wang Wen-lu, a former general affairs department head; and technician Chang Chao-hua were all released.

At issue was a NT$385 million museum renovation project that got underway in July 2004 and was not fully completed until late last year. The project is said to have been conceived and drafted during the stint of then-curator Tu Cheng- sheng, who is now the education minister.

Suspecting possible irregularities in the bidding process after repeated cost overruns, the prosecutors launched massive raids on the offices and residences of architect Luo Hsing-hua and other contractors late last month, collecting a large number of files and documents in their searches.
They have also begun questioning relevant staff of the National Palace Museum, which houses one of the most precious art treasures in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUDGE QUESTIONS LEGITIMACY OF RULING ON ANNULING ELECTION RESULT

TEXT.P: The legitimacy of the Kaohsiung District Court ruling that annuls the result of last December's Kaohsiung mayoral election is questionable and unjustifiable, according to a judge handling the case.

Ku Chen-hui, a member of the three-person panel of judges handling the election lawsuit filed by main opposition Kuomintang candidate Huang Chun-ying after he narrowly lost to Chen Chu of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the Dec. 9, 2006 election, has expressed his doubts about the ruling's legality in a six-page footnote.

Led by presiding judge Huang Hung-chin, the panel ruled in favor of Huang who accused Chen of violating campaign regulations by presenting a video on the eve of the poll allegedly showing vote-buying by Huang on a tour bus returning from one of his campaign rallies.

The video was repeatedly aired by television stations on election day. "The tactic...was enough to influence the election result, " the district court ruled in its verdict. Based on this point, the court invalidated Chen's election victory and demanded that a new election be held to select a new mayor.
However, Ku, who as the reporting judge on the panel was actually in charge of most of the investigative work, didn't see eye-to-eye with his colleagues on the judgment.

Ku outlined three questions to challenge the ruling. First of all, Ku said if Huang could not prove that Chen's claim of discovering "Huang paying 'walking fees' to those who attended his campaign rally as shown in the video" was ill- motivated, the court should not have judged it as a slanderous move or illegal campaign gambit.

Second, Ku said that since the Chen camp's negative campaign tactic at most violated the regulations related to the period for campaigning, voters' voting rights were by no means affected by such an infraction. Consequently, he said, Chen had not broken any election-related fundamental principles to justify the "annulment" ruling.

Third, Ku said that in the conducting of election campaigns, exposing political rivals supposedly illegal campaign gambits, such as vote-buying on a tour bus, is part of freedom of speech which is protected by the Constitution. A complete ban on such moves could infringe upon personal freedom of speech, he added.

In his view, Ku said, the court's hyperboling a candidate's negative campaigning gambit as a criminal act and employing it as a reason to invalidate the candidate's election vitory would hobble protection of the candidate's freedom of speech and ordinary voters' exercise of their voting rights.

Moreover, Ku said that in this case, there has not been sufficient evidence to prove that Chen herself was involved in the conduct of the "walking fee" campaign gambit. Therefore, he said it's inappropriate to hold Chen herself equally responsible for violations of the Election and Recall Law by her campaign aides who unveiled the controversial video at an election eve news conference after the legal campaign period had expired.
Chen announced at a Friday night press conference that she will appeal the case because "the ruling was unreasonable."
"I want to let everyone know that I am the legal mayor and that I will strive for justice," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Iran Strategy Stirs Debate at White House
A year after President Bush and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice announced a new strategy toward Iran, a behind-the-scenes debate has broken out within the administration over whether the approach has any hope of reining in Irans nuclear program, according to senior administration officials.
The debate has pitted Ms. Rice and her deputies, who appear to be winning so far, against the few remaining hawks inside the administration, especially those in Vice President Dick Cheneys office who, according to some people familiar with the discussions, are pressing for greater consideration of military strikes against Iranian nuclear facilities.
Wall Street Journal:Tax Plan Adds To the Pressures On Buyout Firms
Wall Street's new masters of the universe, hedge funds and private-equity partnerships, are suddenly finding the universe a less-hospitable place.
The latest pressure arose this week when the Senate Finance Committee decided to introduce a bill to tax financial-services partnerships that are publicly traded, as giant Blackstone Group soon will be, at the same higher rate paid by corporations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOV'T PUBLISHES CULTURAL MANUAL TO ATTRACT TOURISTS

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government has published a new cultural manual introducing Taiwan's traditional festivals to attract both local visitors and foreign tourists, especially Japanese.

This will be the first year that the manual will contain a bar code that can be scanned by cell phone for instant translation into Japanese, according to Lee Yung-ping, director of Taipei City government's Department of Cultural Affairs (DCA).
He added that the Department of Cultural Affairs may expand the bar code translation service to include English and several European languages in the future.
The manual will also include information on 36 tourist attractions and 193 spots of cultural interest in the northern cities and counties of Taiwan, Lee said.

The manual will be available for free at Taipei's tourist spots, MRT stations, DCA offices, hotels and various bookstores, Lee said, adding those interested can visit the Taipei city government's Web site at http://www.tcp2007.tw. for more information.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TALKS WITH DOCTOR REPRESENTATIVES ON VISIT TO HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Chui-bian held talks with representatives of doctors associations in the central Taiwan region Saturday during his visit to the Changhua Christian Hospital.

During the closed-door meeting, Chen and the doctors' representatives talked about the National Health Insurance system, with some participants complaining about the medical expenses reimbursement system, according to hospital sources.

Lin Yung-nung, a representative of the national federation of Chinese medical associations in Taiwan, criticized the existing "Global Budget" payment system, which was adopted in 2002 to control medical service costs, claiming that it has seriously threatened the survival of grassroots clinics and restricted the medical sector's development, according to the sources.
In response, Chen only said there is dilemma of carrying out the system or taking care the medical sector's development, according to the hospital sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL AFRICAN COUNTRIES WELCOME TO JOIN TAIWAN-AFRICA SUMMIT: MOFA

TEXT.P: All African countries are welcome to attend a Taiwan-Africa summit meeting scheduled to be held in Taipei in September, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said Saturday.

Wang said that the summit meeting will focus on Taiwan's five diplomatic allies on the continent -- namely Burkina Faso, Malawi, Swaziland, The Gambia, and Sao Tome and Principe -- but that other countries are welcome to join the meeting.

Wang made the remarks amid reports that President Chen Shui-bian has asked that this year's summit be of the same scale as that of a forum on China-Africa Cooperation held late last year in Beijing by inviting as many African countries as possible to attend the meeting.
In addition to inviting the leaders of Taiwan's five allies in Africa, at least one representative from each of the 53 countries on the continent will be invited to the meeting, the reports said.
Presidential Office officials declined to comment on the reports.
Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang is scheduled to visit the five African allies next month to deliver the invitations on behalf of President Chen.

Huang said in late April that the theme of the summit meeting will be how Taiwan can assist its African allies to cope with the challenges of globalization. Issues to be discussed at the summit meeting will include environmental protection, biotourism, solar energy, medical care and public health, and agriculture.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS JOIN WORLD CAMPAIGN TO FREE MYANMAR DEMOCRACY LEADER

TEXT.P: Forty-four Taiwanese female lawmakers have signed a petition urging Myanmar's junta head to immediately and unconditionally free the country's pro-democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi who has been under house arrest for most of the past 17 years, legislative sources said Saturday.

Legislator Huang Shu-ying of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party took the initiative to launch a signature drive earlier this week to enlist female lawmakers' support for a global campaign for Aung San Suu Kyi's early release, the sources said.

Huang managed to collect signatures from 44 female lawmakers of different political stripes in a very short period of time, the sources said, adding that nine female councilors from various cities and counties as well as Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and his wife Shaw Hsiao-ling have also signed their names in support of the drive. Aung San Suu Kyi was Hu's classmate at Oxford University.

Aung San Suu Kyi, winner of the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize, has promoted non-violent campaign for democratic reform in her homeland since her return to Myanmar in 1988. Her campaign is widely seen symbolizing the struggle of Myanmar people to be free.

Over the past 17 years, she has been under house arrest for most of the time. The latest round of her house arrest began in May 2003 and should have expired in May this year. But the Myanmar military government recently announced that her imprisonment will be extended for another one year.

Major world organizations, including the United Nations, the European Union, the ASEAN, the Amnesty International and human rights groups around the world have appealed for her immediate and unconditional release. Many Nobel Peace Prize winners and parliaments in many countries have issued statements condemning the Myanmar junta leaders' suppression of their country's pro-democracy Nobel laureate.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA DAYBOOK FOR JUNE 17, 2007

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CLARIFIES REPORT ABOUT TAIWAN-AFRICA SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan has no intention of rivaling China in holding gala meetings to woo African countries, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said Saturday.

Wang was responding to a United Evening News report that President Chen Shui- bian has asked the MOFA to organize a Taiwan-African summit that measures up to the China-Africa Cooperation Forum held in Beijing late last year.

Besides inviting heads of state of the country's five African allies, the report claimed that Chen has directed the MOFA to see to it that all of the continent's 53 countries be represented in the meeting.

Wang said the report deviates from truth, stressing that Taiwan's engagements with African countries focus on assisting them in national development through official or non-governmental channels, not in the least for China's sake.

Rebutting the newspaper report, the MOFA further issued a press statement late Saturday saying that the Taiwan-African Allies Summit to be held in Taipei in September will bring together the top leaders of Taiwan's five African allies to meet with President Chen on charting sustainable development strategies and coping with the challenges of globalization.

Following on the heels of the Taiwan-African Allies Summit, the statement said a Taiwan-African partnership forum will be held with the participation of representatives from all African countries regardless of whether their countries maintain or do not maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

The partnership forum will discuss conclusions reached at the Taiwan-African Allies Summit as well as feasible measures to narrow the digital divide, promote public health and protect natural environment, the statement added.

According to MOFA sources, Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang is scheduled to visit the country's five African allies -- Burkina Faso, The Gambia, Malawi, Sao Tome and Principe, and Swaziland -- next month to deliver the invitations to the summit on behalf of President Chen.

The theme of the summit meeting will focus on how Taiwan can assist its African allies in coping with the challenges of globalization, the sources said, adding that issues to be discussed will include environmental protection, biotourism, solar energy, public health, and agricultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHIEF MEETS WITH DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Visiting American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt met with ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh Saturday for wide-ranging talks.

Lee Ying-yuan, a Hsieh campaign strategist, said Burghardt, who as the AIT chief is the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties, was accompanied by Stephen Young, head of the AIT Taipei Office, during his one- hour meeting with Hsieh at the latter's campaign office in Taipei.

According to Lee, the meeting proceeded in a cordial atmosphere, with topics focusing on major international issues, relations across the Taiwan Strait as well as Taiwan-U.S. ties and Taiwan's general political and economic development.
Out of respect for Burghardt, Lee said he could not reveal the content of the talks in detail.

Lee said Burghardt and Hsieh are old friends. Their first encounter took place 15 years ago when they attended an international forum at the City University of New York. At the time, Lee said, Hsieh delivered a speech advocating Taiwan applying for U.N. membership in the name of "Taiwan" rather than its official title of "Republic of China."

During Saturday's meeting, Lee said Burghardt and Hsieh also talked about their love for baseball. When seeing a big-size picture featuring Hsieh shaking hands with Taiwan-born New York Yankees on a wall of Hsieh's campaign office, Burghardt said that like Hsieh, he himself is a Yankees fan. But Young said he likes Boston Red Sox more than any other Major League baseball team.

On Saturday, Burghardt also met with main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou. During their meeting, Ma was quoted as having elaborated on his campaign platform, particularly his visions on cross-strait relations and Taiwan-U.S. ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO REVIEW REQUEST FOR 'RICE BOMBER'S' SPECIAL PARDON

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will consider the Legislative Yuan's suggestion for him to grant a special pardon to an imprisoned "rice bomber" in a reasonable, fair- minded way, a Presidential Office spokesman said Sunday.

The spokesman made the remarks after the legislature unanimously passed a non- binding resolution Friday requesting a presidential amnesty for Yang Ju-men, better known locally as "rice bomber" as he sprinkled with small amounts of rice in his homemade explosives for a bombing campaign during a one-year period starting November 2003.

Yang is serving a five-and-a-half-year prison term for planting at least 17 explosive devices around Taipei until he turned himself in to police in the company of his brother in November 2004. Nobody was injured in Yang's bombing campaign.

Yang said during his trial that he had resorted to the bombing campaign to attract the government's attention to the plight of local farmers after the country's accession to the World Trade Organization in 2002.
The legislature's non-binding request for a special pardon to Yang was passed along with a commutation statute granting amnesty to prison inmates serving sentences of 18 months or less.

The Presidential Office spokesman said President Chen will make a thorough review of Yang's case in terms of expert views collected in his extensive consultations with specialists as well as the principles and spirit of the newly passed commutation statute.

According to the spokesman, the president believes that those who offend the law unwittingly or occasionally should not be denied an opportunity to correct their own errors or deficiencies and get a fresh start in their career life.
On April 24, President Chen proposed an amnesty plan in commemoration of the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident of 1947 and the 20th anniversary of the lifting of 38 years of martial law in 1987.
Acting on Chen's directive, the Cabinet drafted a commutation bill and referred it to the legislature for approval.

Although the ruling Democratic Progressive Party supported the Cabinet-drafted bill, the version proposed by the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) was passed by the legislature after a cross- party consensus was reached.
The Cabinet-drafted version would grant commutation to only those who receive one-year sentences or less, compared to the opposition-proposed one-and-a -half-year sentences or less.
Some DPP lawmakers accused the "pan-blue alliance" of tailoring the statute to benefit KMT Legislator Chiu Yi.

Chiu was sentenced to 14 months in prison for his violent conduct during a protest at the Kaohsiung District Court following the 2004 presidential election. Chiu began serving time behind bar in April.
According to Ministry of Justice estimate, 14,795 inmates can be released immediately now that the KMT-proposed version has been passed, while another 10,140 will have their sentences cut by half.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 17, or the third day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1703: British religious leader John Wesley is born. He founded Methodism in 1738, while his brother, Charles, wrote thousands of hymns, including "Hark, the Herald Angels Sing."
1775: The second battle of the American Revolution commences at Bunker Hill and Breed's Hill, just north of Boston, Massachusetts. The Americans lost around 400 men, the British 1,000.
1925: A total of 29 countries sign the Geneva Protocol prohibiting the use of poisonous gases in war.
1940: Red Army forces occupy Latvia and Estonia and pro-Soviet administrations are installed.
1950: The first kidney transplant is performed by Dr. Richard Lawler in Chicago.
1960: The Chinese communists launch 85,965 shells toward the island of Kinmen on the eve of US President Dwight D. Eisenhower's visit to the Republic of China.
1967: Communist China detonates its first hydrogen bomb.
1971: The United States and Japan sign an agreement for the return of Okinawa to Japan in 1972.
1972: Five men are caught snooping around the Washington apartment-hotel complex known as The Watergate, currently being used by the Democratic Party as their headquarters during the US election campaign.
1974: ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Y.S. Sun leaves for Seoul to attend the 9th Sino-Korean Ministerial Level Economic Cooperation Conference.
1976: Hsu Li-teh is appointed vice minister of finance by the ROC Executive Yuan.
1978: More than 4.5 million eligible ROC voters go to the polls to elect 3,786 representatives of townships and villages as well as 6,417 urban and rural district chiefs.
1979: Charles Cross, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1982: Raymond Perodin, Haiti's new ambassador to the ROC, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1982: Fourteen generals meet at an army base in Buenos Aires and vote unanimously to fire Leopoldo Galtieri, the president who led Argentina into the Falklands War against Britain.
1982: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chu Fu-sung, as President Chiang Ching- kuo's special envoy, leaves for Saudi Arabia to offer Taiwan's condolences for the passing of King Fahd ibn Abdul Aziz.
1986: Nineteen mainland Chinese youths defect across the Yellow Sea aboard a small wooden boat to South Korea to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: Some 400,000 Parisians and tourists from all over the world celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Eiffel Tower.
1990: President Andres Rodriguez of Paraguay arrives in Taipei to sign a joint communique calling for closer bilateral relations with the ROC.
1992: Lin Yang-kang, president of the Judicial Yuan of the ROC, leaves for the United States for a three-week visit.
1996: The United States and mainland China reach a deal to stamp out rampant Chinese copyright piracy.
1999: The International Labor Organization adopts a treaty banning the worst forms of child labor, including slavery and forced military recruitment.
2000: Kuomintang heavyweights at an extraordinary session of the party's 15th National Congress call for party unity while protesters outside the session's venue call for the expulsion of former party chairman Lee Teng-hui.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I hate the way scarlet dims the perception of vermilion. I hate the way the modern popular airs are liable to spoil the taste for good music. Finally, I hate the way smartness of speech in men is liable to destroy kingdoms and ruin families."

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: U.S. restricts high-tech exports to China
The United States late Friday slapped new restrictions on high-technology exports to China and moved to create a pool of so-called trusted customers within the Chinses business community who will be rewared for compliance with U.S. guidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Battle in Gaza is Now Political.
After four days of brutal street battles, Palestinians on Friday found themselves facing the prospect of two competing governments when Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas named a political independent respected by the U.S. and Israel as prime minister but the victorious Hamas movement refused to step aside. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
KMT CANDIDATE WILL ANNOUNCE RUNNING MATE BY JUNE 24

TEXT.P: The presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Sunday that he will announce his running mate by June 24, when the party is to hold its national congress.
Ma Ying-jeou, a former KMT chairman who stepped down from the post in mid- February, made the remarks to reporters in response to questions on the issue.
Ma said he will make the announcement before next Sunday, thereby ensuring that KMT delegates have an opportunity to give the presidential ticket their stamp of approval during the party congress.
Ma originally sought to pair up with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, but late last month Wang turned down Ma's offer to serve as his running mate in the 2008 presidential election.
According to Ma's aides, as part of his efforts to rebuild Taiwan's traditional values, Ma will team up with a running mate who is honest and diligent and has a down-to-earth work style.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUP URGES MYANMAR JUNTA TO FREE NOBEL PEACE LAUREATE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Labor Front (TLF) , a private affiliation, urged Myanmar's military- run government junta Sunday to free Nobel peace laureate Aung San Suu Kyi and other freedom fighters who have been incarcerated or oppressed in Myanmar.

TLF members said that in defiance to pressure from the international community, the Myanmar junta extended recently Aung San Suu Kyi's house arrest for another year, triggering condemnation from United Nations' Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon and human rights groups around the world.

The TLF said that they have worked with other Taiwan NGO groups since June 19, 2005 -- Suu Kyi's 60th birthday -- to collect signatures in support of "Free Aung San Suu Kyi" campaigns launched by many NGO groups abroad.

TLF is also collaborating with other Taiwanese NGOs in sponsoring a "Free Aung San Suu Kyi" concert in Taipei Sunday evening, hoping that more people in Taiwan will become aware of the lack of democracy in the Indochinese country, Myanmar, and extend their support to Suu Kyi, who has spent most of the last 17 years under house arrest, TLF members said.
Myanmar has been ruled by the military since 1962.
Suu Kyi led the opposition National League for Democracy (NLD) party to a landslide victory at the polls in 1990, but her party was never allowed to take power.

The NLD has decided to boycott again the closed-door National Convention being sponsored by the military junta for charter talks, saying that unless the authorities free her, it will not alter its stance on a political boycott.
The National Convention is the first of seven steps that the junta claims will lead the isolated and impoverished Southeast Asian nation back to democracy after 45 years of military rule.
The NLD walked out on talks in 1995, after which discussions were suspended for nearly 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE FAVORS COURT RULING REGARDING KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL RACE

TEXT.P: The presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Sunday that he hopes the Taiwan High Court will uphold the ruling issued June 15 by the Kaohsiung District Court annulling the Dec. 9 election victory of the incumbent Mayor Chen Chun of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Ma Ying-jeou, formerly a KMT chairman who stepped down from the post in mid- February, made the comments while answering questions from reporters on the issue, which has stirred up debate following the district court's verdict last Friday.
Although the court's rule provoked mixed responses, Ma said, he believes that the verdict will be helpful in wiping out "dirty tricks" in future elections.

Kaohsiung District Court judges annulled Chen's victory in the Dec. 9 Kaohsiung mayoral election on the grounds that the airing of a videotape by Chen's camp late on the eve of the election -- when all campaigning activities are supposed to stop -- accusing Huang Chun-ying, Chen's KMT rival, of vote-buying, violated election laws and cost Huang the race.
Huang filed two suits against Chen's camp after losing the election by 1,114 votes, asking that the court annul Chen's victory and invalidate the election.

Chen was extremely dissatisfied with the ruling and vowed to appeal the case. According to the Central Election Commission, Chen may remain in the mayor's office until the outcome of the second trial.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Gay Pride 2007 demonstration held in Rome.
The demonstration Gay Pride 2007 was held Saturday in Rome with the participation of gay,lesbian, bisexual and transgender associations and their sympathy groups, appealing for legal civil rights. Some one million people joined the anual event, according to organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMG CHAIRMAN LIKELY TO BE DETAINED AGAIN

TEXT.P: Eastern Multimedia Group (EMG) Chairman Gary Wang is likely to be detained once again as Taipei prosecutors succeeded Sunday in annulling a Taipei District Court ruling which freed Wang the day before on NT$100 million (US$3.03 million) bail.
Taipei prosecutors lodged an appeal Sunday with the Taiwan High Court, asking that it to throw away the bail decision.
The high court accepted the appeal and ordered the Taipei District Court to rehear the case.

As a result, Wang, who has been questioned by prosecutors over his involvement in at least four fraud and embezzlement cases connected with the Rebar Asia Pacific Group, was ordered to return to the court for a new hearing Sunday afternoon -- one day after he was freed on near-record bail of NT$100 million.

Taipei prosecutors appealed to the Taipei District Court to detain Wang on Friday night, but after a hearing, the court decided that it was unnecessary and released him Saturday on NT$100 million bail, the second-highest bail set in Taiwan's judicial history.
Wang left the court Saturday afternoon after his company spent nine hours collecting the bail money. He was prohibited from leaving the country.
Wang may be detained or face record-high bail for his release.
Prosecutors began questioning Wang and Tung Chia-ching, an EMG vice president in charge of finance, Thursday after a series of raids on EMG offices and properties belong to Wang.

Wang and his close associates were questioned over allegations that Wang might have won the contract to operate the Taipei Arena for nine years by bid-rigging, that Wang illegally sold the group's stocks at an abnormally low price, that he stole NT$27.2 billion from Asia Pacific Broadband Telecom Co., a local fixed- line operator and a subsidiary of EMG, and that he tried to avoid paying taxes by selling one of the group's properties to Union Insurance Co. and subsequently renting out the property.
Wang is the son of Wang You-theng, the fugitive Rebar founder who has been indicted together with 106 others for their alleged involvement in one of the country's biggest financial scandals.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE SPEAKER TO VISIT JAPAN

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng is scheduled to leave for Japan Tuesday for a three-day visit, mainly to attend a memorial service for the late Japanese lawmaker Motoo Shiina, an aide of Wang's said Sunday.

Wang will attend the memorial service slated for June 20 in Tokyo before paying a visit to Takeo Hiranuma, chairman of the Japan-Republic of China Dietmen's Council, on June 21, before returning to Taiwan that same day, according to Wang's aide.

Wang, who has close ties with members of the Japanese political scene, last visited Japan in July 2006, at which time he met with the then Chief Cabinet Secretary Shinzo Abe, who is now Japan's prime minister.
Motoo Shiina and his father -- the late Etsusburo Shiina, who had been an influential politician and a vice president of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party -- were both good friends of Taiwan.

Motoo Shiina, a former dietman and leading authority on Japan-U.S. relations, died of pneumonia at a Tokyo hospital on March 16. Over the course of his career, Shiina played an important role in Taiwan-Japan-U.S. security issues, and frequently spoke for Taiwan's cause in the international community.

Meanwhile, President Chen Shui-bian has instructed former Premier Frank Hsieh, the presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, to attend Shiina's memorial service on his behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE FEMALE LAWMAKERS URGE MYANMAR JUNTA TO FREE SUU KYI

TEXT.P: Forty-four female legislators from across Taiwan's political spectrum urged Myanmar's military-run government junta Sunday to free, without conditions, Nobel peace laureate Aung San Suu Kyi.

The 44 women lawmakers were joined by nine other female city and county councilors from around the island in a signature-collection campaign aimed at condemning the Myanmar junta for having recently extended Aung San Suu Kyi's house arrest for another year.

Other people, including Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen, Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu and his wife, and several Taiwanese classmates from Suu Kyi's time at Oxford University, also signed the appeal demanding total freedom for the Nobel peace laureate.

A copy of the signed petition will be sent to the United Nations' Secretariat and the European Commission, the top executive body of the European Union, said ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Huang Shu-ying.
The signature collecting campaign was launched on the eve of Suu Kyi's 62nd birthday, on June 19.

On the sidelines of the campaign, several NGO organizations from around Taiwan are also sponsoring a "Free Aung San Suu Kyi" concert in Taipei Sunday evening, hoping that more people in Taiwan will become aware of the lack of democracy in the Indochinese country, Myanmar, and extend their support to Suu Kyi, who has spent most of the last 17 years under house arrest.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE KICKS OFF CUISINE FINAL COMPETITION

TEXT.P: Ma Yin-jeou, presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , Sunday kicked off the final competition of the "Taipei Cooking Championship" organized by the municipal Bureau of Labor Affairs.

At the invitation of bureau director Su Yin-quei, Ma presided over the last stage of the competition at the Taipei World Trade Center by serving up a "supremacy" tsongzi -- a traditional pyramid-shaped dumpling made of glutinous rice wrapped in bamboo leaves and eaten during the annual Dragon Boat Festival, which is only two days away.
The "supremacy" tsongzi is 12 cm high, contains eatable gold powder worth NT$2,500, and top caliber abalone and pork valued about NT$5,000.
Ma publicly auctioned off a 167-kg tuna donated by the Suao Fishermen's Association, netted by a Japanese restaurant owner surnamed Lee with a winning bid of NT$417,500 (US$12,651).
Ma, who recently returned from a trip to Singapore and India, hailed Chinese cuisine as the "world's best, " and encouraged food specialists and chefs attending the contest to present it with flare.
According to Su, fine food is the most useful means of integrating different cultures and ethnic groups, and is helpful in boosting cultural exchanges and creating social harmony.

Group and individual winners from a pool of 56 teams of finalists in the first "Taipei Cooking Championship" will be awarded cash prices of NT$100,000 and NT$30,000, respectively, by Mayor Hau Long-bin.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMICS RECOMMEND LOW CARBON ECONOMY TO TACKLE CLIMATE CHANGE

TEXT.P: Local and foreign academics suggested at a seminar Sunday that the government consider building a low carbon economy to help mitigate global climate change due to global warming.

Lin Tzu-lun, a professor at Shih Hsin University, issued the call at the forum, which was also attended by officials from the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration and experts from Japan.

Suggesting that the government come up with bolder measures and a clear-cut policy in response to global warming, Lin opined that the government should follow in the footsteps of British authorities in proclaiming to shift to a low carbon economy instead of just focusing on how, when or how much to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

Moving to a low carbon economy not only addresses an environmental imperative, it make business sense, some British experts were quoted as saying and adding that the transition to a low carbon economy will have a negligible impact on long term GDP growth and will present tremendous opportunities for those who develop and deliver low carbon products and services.

According to Lin, the British government published its first white paper on energy policy calling for a low carbon and cost-effective economy in 2003, thereby encouraging the European Union, Canada and New Zealand to follow suit.

In addition to reducing emissions of carbon dioxide by 60 percent by 2050 using a mixture of energy efficiency, Lin said, the British white paper also announced the government's goal of fully engaging in the development of renewable and environmentally-friendly sources of electricity, replacing coal and oil with lower carbon fuels.

He urged the government to resist efforts to misrepresent or otherwise underestimate the impact of greenhouse gas emissions and warned that the failure to tackle the fundamentals of climate change will carry serious economic and social costs.
A Japanese expert attending the forum stressed that civil society groups are responsible for raising public awareness that "using nuclear power is not helpful in reducing global warming.

According to the Japanese specialist, although nuclear power plants do not emit greenhouse gases, other carbon-emitting power plants must be maintained as they remain indispensable in case nuclear plants are rendered inoperative during an emergency.

Additionally, the Japanese expert warned of the risks posed by nuke waste and the major incidents that might arise at nuclear power plants, and encouraged local private groups to do their best to clearly relay that message to the general public.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE PROMISES ACCESS TO MAINLAND VIA KINMEN, MATSU

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou promised Sunday to give all people in Taiwan access to mainland China via Kinmen and Matsu, if he is elected president next year.
During a whirlwind visit to Kinmen, Ma pledged to announce this measures the day when he is inaugurated as president.

Noting that direct air and shipping links across the strait may not be launched overnight given the complicated political and security issues involved, Ma said to give all Taiwan people the access to mainland via Kinmen and Matsu, the two Taiwan-controlled islands which link the mainland by ferry service, is something Taiwan could do by itself.

As the ferry service linking the two islands with southern Chinese ports of Xiamen and Mawei have proved very successfully since it was opened in 2001, Taiwan could make good use of it before the direct transportation links with China is in place, Ma said.
This access is only available to residents on the two islands and Taiwan businessmen working on the mainland thus far.
The KMT former chairman also promised to allow Kinmen's schools to accept students from China in hopes it will help boost the island's economy.
Ma was accompanied by KMT Vice Chairman Chan Chun-poh on the trip during which he visited county officials and met with local people to exchange views with them on local development.

New York Times:F.D.A. Tracked Tainted Drugs, but Trail Went Cold in China
After a drug ingredient from China killed dozens of Haitian children a decade ago, a senior American health official sent a cable to her investigators: find out who made the poisonous ingredient and why a state-owned company in China exported it as safe, pharmaceutical-grade glycerin.
The Chinese were of little help. Requests to find the manufacturer were ignored. Business records were withheld or destroyed.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT APPROVES PROSECUTORS' REQUEST TO DETAIN BUSINESS TYCOON

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court approved the prosecution's request Sunday to detain business tycoon Gary Wang, reversing its own ruling issued the previous day, which set Wang free on NT$100 million (US$3.03 million) bail.

Prosecutors convinced the court that Wang, under investigation in connection with several high-profile economic criminal cases, might coach witnesses to give false testimony if allowed to remain at large.
Wang who was present at the court hearing was whisked away by sheriffs to the Taipei Detention Center after the ruling.
The prosecution had sought Wang's detention on Friday but failed after the court let Wang go after posting the second-highest bail in Taiwanese judicial history.
In that ruling, the judges said there is no reason to believe Wang, the chairman of Eastern Multimedia Group, with billion's worth of assets, could collude with witnesses to provide false testimony.
The prosecutors lodged an appeal Sunday with the Taiwan High Court, asking it to throw away the bail decision.
The high court accepted the appeal and ordered the Taipei District Court to rehear the case, and Wang was called back for Sunday's hearing.
Wang was probed over allegations that he won the contract to operate the Taipei Arena for nine years by bid-rigging, and lining his pocket with his group's money.
Wang is the son of Wang You-theng, the fugitive Rebar founder who has been indicted together with 106 others for their alleged involvement in one of the country's biggest financial scandals.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT BLASTS JUDGE FOR ANNULLING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR'S ELECTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said here Sunday that much as he respects the judiciary he can't accept the court's decision to annul Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu's election.

Condemning the decision contained in a judgment handed down by the Kaohsiung District Court on Friday as ridiculous, the president said he is confident that Chen who won the Dec. 9 election by a margin of 0.9 percent or 1,114 votes will serve out her four-year term.

Without mentioning the name of Huang Chun-ying, Chen Chu's rival in the election who were accused by Chen Chu on the eve of the ballot-casting day of buying votes, the president said the cityhall will never be led by "a man who bought votes."

"The absurdity of the judgment is born out by the fact that one of the three judges in charge of the trial of the case disagreed with the presiding judge's decision by attaching a dissenting opinion to the judgment." the president said.

The Kaohsiung District Court declared in its judgment in a lawsuit brought by Huang that Chen Chu's election is null and void in light of the fact she spread the news of her rival's alleged vote buying hours before the ballot-casting day when all electioneering are supposed to stop.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT BLASTS JUDGE FOR ANNULLING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR'S ELECTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said here Sunday that as much as he respects the judiciary he can't accept the court's decision to annul Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu's election.

Condemning the decision contained in a judgment handed down by the Kaohsiung District Court on Friday as ridiculous, the president said he is confident that Chen, who won the Dec. 9 election by a margin of 0.14 percent or 1,114 votes, will serve out her four-year term.

Without mentioning the name of Huang Chun-ying, Chen Chu's rival in the mayoral race and who was accused by Chen on the eve of the election of buying votes, the president said the city will never be led by "a man who bought votes."

"The absurdity of the judgment is born out by the fact that one of the three judges in charge of the case disagreed with the presiding judge's decision and attached a dissenting opinion to the judgment," the president said.

The Kaohsiung District Court declared in its judgment of a lawsuit brought by Huang that Chen Chu's election is null and void in light of the fact she spread the news of her rival's alleged vote buying hours before the ballot-casting day when all electioneering was supposed to have stopped.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 18, or the fourth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1155: Frederick I "Barbarossa" is crowned Holy Roman Emperor by Pope Adrian IV.
1812: The U.S. Congress approves a declaration of war on Great Britain over trade restrictions.
1815: British and Prussian forces under the command of the Duke of Wellington and Field Marshall Gerhard von Blucher finally defeat France's Napoleon Bonaparte in a bloody battle at Waterloo, in Belgium. The total number of casualties on both sides is estimated to be 62,000.
1900: With the anti-foreign Boxer Rebellion already under way in China, the Empress Dowager Tzuhsi of the Ching court orders all foreigners executed.
1927: Chang Tso-lin, head of the separatist Fengtien Army in China's northeast (Manchuria), sets up a military government in Beijing and declares himself marshal.
1928: Amelia Earhart, a 30-year-old American aviator, becomes the first woman to fly across the Atlantic when the tri-engine plane "Friendship," in which she is a passenger, lands at Burny Port.
1940: Charles de Gaulle, founder of the Free French, makes a radio appeal from London urging his fellow countrymen to continue to resist the Germans.
1942: The United States formally begins its Manhattan Project, the manufacturing of the first atomic bomb.
1944: Changsha, capital of China's Hunan Province, falls to invading Japanese troops who violate the Geneva Protocol by using poison gas in battle.
1944: US Vice President Henry Wallace visits China.
1950: Chen Yi, former top administrator of Taiwan province, is executed for sedition.
1960: US President Dwight D. Eisenhower arrives in Taipei for a state visit.
1965: Typhoon Dinah hits eastern Taiwan, killing more than 100 people and injuring over 200.
1965: Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky vows to militarily defeat the Viet Cong after assuming office as premier of South Vietnam.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Dr. Robert M. Lumiamsky, president, and Dr. Gordon B. Turner, vice president, of the American Council of Learned Societies.
1979: US President Jimmy Carter and Soviet President Leonid Brezhnev sign the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) documents in Vienna.
1980: General Jose Dolores Herrera, El Salvador's ambassador to the ROC, presents his government's Gold Medal of Great Achievements to General Kao Huei- yuan, defense minister, Admiral Soong Chang-chih, chief of the general staff, General Wang Sheng, director of the General Political Warfare Department, and General Wang Yung-shu, director of the National Security Bureau.
1981: The Executive Yuan appoints Dr. Yen Chen-hsing, president of National Taiwan University, as chairman of the Atomic Energy Council.
1982: Republic of China Premier Sun Yun-suan instructs government agencies to study the feasibility of setting up a free trade zone in Taiwan.
1986: Chang Tung-sheng, a noted ROC wrestler known as the "Master of Wrestling," dies of cancer at the age of 76.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Admiral Soong Chang-chih (Sung Chang-chih) as the new ambassador to Panama.
1993: Japanese Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa loses a crucial no-confidence vote and dissolves parliament to trigger snap elections in July.
1997: Pol Pot, the fugitive Cambodian Khmer Rouge leader, surrenders to his former comrades.
1999: Florencio Marin, Belize minister of the sugar industry and local government and Latin American affairs, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
2000: The opposition Kuomintang passes a party reform package that includes provisions for the popular election of its party chairman following a nationwide party membership verification and registration process.
2001: The ROC breaks off diplomatic relations with Macedonia after the Balkan state made its intention clear that it would establish formal ties with China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is really a bad situation when a man simply eats his meals without applying his mind to anything at all during the whole day. Are there no such things as gambling and games of skill? To do even one of those things is better than to do nothing at all."

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT APPROVES PROSECUTORS' REQUEST TO DETAIN BUSINESS TYCOON

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court approved prosecutors' request Sunday to detain business tycoon Gary Wang, reversing its own ruling issued the previous day, which set Wang free on NT$100 million (US$3.03 million) bail.

Prosecutors convinced the court that Wang, under investigation in connection with several high-profile economic criminal cases, might coach witnesses to give false testimony if allowed to remain at large.
Wang, who was present at the court hearing, was whisked away by sheriffs to the Taipei Detention Center after the ruling.
The prosecution had sought Wang's detention on Friday, but failed when the court let Wang go after posting the second-highest bail in Taiwanese judicial history.

In that ruling, the judges said there is no reason to believe that Wang, the chairman of Eastern Multimedia Group with billions of dollars worth of assets, would collude with witnesses to provide false testimony.
The prosecutors lodged an appeal Sunday with the Taiwan High Court, asking it to throw out the decision on bail.
The high court accepted the appeal and ordered the Taipei District Court to rehear the case, and Wang was called back for Sunday's hearing.
Wang is being investigated over allegations that he won the contract to operate the Taipei Arena for nine years by bid-rigging, and also allegations of embezzlement from his business group.
Wang is the son of Wang You-theng, the fugitive Rebar founder who has been indicted together with 106 others for their alleged involvement in one of the country's biggest financial scandals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
TRADE WORKSHOP FOR 2ND GENERATION O'SEAS TAIWANESE OPENING

TEXT.P: A training workshop for second-generation overseas Taiwanese to learn skills in international trade, particularly how to promote Taiwan products, is scheduled to open in Taipei June 21, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (Taitra) reported Monday.

Forty young men and women, who are Taiwanese offspring from around the world, are expected to attend the six-week business workshop, which is being organized by Taitra at the request of the Cabinet-level Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission (OCAC) , Taitra officials said.

Taitra and OCAC officials hope that these young Taiwanese descendants from the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Brazil, Paraguay and Southeast Asia will pick up skills in international trade, including marketing, international business norms and business communications, after receiving intensive training at the 38-day workshop.

Meanwhile, Taitra officials said, it is also expected that these workshop attendees will learn about Taiwan products and the skills to promote them on their graduation from the workshop, which is titled: "A Training Program for Young Pioneers in Promoting Taiwanese Products."

The training workshop will be followed by field trips to several renowned Taiwan enterprises and travel to a number of tourist attractions around the island to allow the students to gain a better understanding of Taiwan, Taitra officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONGOLIAN BUSINESS GROUP TO GO ON SHOPPING SPREE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A business group from Erdenet, Mongolia's largest industrial city, which is preparing to transform itself into a "silicon valley," is expected to visit Taiwan later this month on a shopping spree to purchase manufacturing machinery, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (Taitra) reported Monday.
Erdenet, located about 300 kilometers northwest of the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator, is the site of Asia's largest, and the world's 10th largest copper/molybdenum mine.

Due to the fact that the copper/molybdenum reserves in the Erdenet area are extensive enough to support extraction for only about 20 years more, the Mongolian government has decided to develop Erdenet into a science-based industrial park housing machinery manufacturing, wood and building-materials processing, food processing and leather garment processing zones, Taitra officials said.
The Mongolian government has allotted US$15 million this year to develop infrastructure in the park and provide soft loans to attract new companies, Taitra officials said.
Owners and operators of 16 companies to be housed in the Erdenet industrial park are expected to be in Taiwan June 20-26, mainly for talks with Taiwanese machinery suppliers.

The Mongolian businessmen are interested in machines to process jewelry, stone, ceramic tile, leather shoes, and wood, as well as commercial washing machines and dryers, saws, beverage bottling machines, weaving and knitting machines, Taitra officials said.
Taiwan suppliers are welcome to contact Taitra regarding related business opportunities, Taitra officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WANTS REFERENDUM TO BE HELD ALONGSIDE PRESIDENTIAL POLL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Monday called for a referendum to be held on the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name "Taiwan" alongside the 2008 presidential election.

Chen issued the call during a meeting with Heritage Foundation President Edwin J. Feulner Jr. at the Presidential Office. It was the first time that Chen has made a clear statement concerning the country's aspiration to seek a seat in the U.N.

Stating that holding a referendum will make the world aware of the Taiwanese people's desire to enter the United Nation, Chen said that "Taiwan" is the most "appropriate, " "powerful, " and "familiar" designation for the country to take part in international activities.

Chen argued that pushing the country to join world bodies under the name of "Taiwan" has nothing to do with a change in its national title, neither will it go against his previous "four noes" pledge, because the country has long participated in international organizations using different designations.

According to Chen, he assured visiting American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond Burghardt, during a recent meeting in Taipei, that he will never deviate from his "four noes" pledge, made to President George W. Bush and the rest of the world.

But Chen said he also told Burghardt that during his last year in office he will not cease building the Taiwan-centric notion of national character among the people of Taiwan and cementing the country's democratization.

Although the country failed in its bid last month to join the World Health Organization as a full member under the name "Taiwan, " Chen expressed to Feulner his appreciation of American support for Taiwan's efforts to become an WHO observer and meaningfully participate in its activities.
Chen also thanked Feulner for his foundation's long-term and firm support of Taiwan's democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI RELEASES INNOVATIVE NANO PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The products -- a "nano plastic soap" and "nano anti-moisture agent" -- were presented at "Taiwan Nano 2007", held June 14-16 at National Taiwan University in Taipei City.

The nano plastic soap is made of nano-scale particles that minimize attrition during cleaning or polishing process, said ITRI Researcher Wei Yu-kun. This means that product can be used both in daily life cleaning, and also in high- tech production processes, such as silicon wafer polishing or grinding.

Additionally, Wei continued, the nano anti-condensation agent offers a better water-proof effect, which lasts up to seven days: all the user has to do is add the agent to water, dip a napkin into the water, and polish the items with the napkin to create an anti-condensation layer on the surface, Wei added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALAN PRESIDENT DUE TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Guatemalan President Oscar Berger Perdomo is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Tuesday for a five-day state visit at the invitation of President Chen Shui- bian, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Monday.

Berger, whose term is slated to end in January 2008, is paying an official visit to Taiwan to demonstrate Guatemala's firm stance on maintaining good relations with Taiwan, Foreign Ministry officials said.

Berger recently said in an interview with a Guatemalan daily newspaper that Guatemala will not follow in Costa Rica's footsteps by switching diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, describing Guatemala-Taiwan ties as being in their best shape ever.

The Guatemalan president also said in the interview that he will stick to his original schedule and visit Taiwan June 19-23, during which he will sign three agreements with President Chen to further boost bilateral cooperation in various fields.

Meanwhile, Foreign Ministry officials said Vice President Annette Lu is scheduled to travel to Latin America and the Caribbean in early July in an effort to secure Taiwan's diplomatic ties with its allies in the wake of the severance of formal relations between Taiwan and Costa Rica -- a development political observers feared might trigger a "domino effect" unfavorable to Taiwan.

Officials also said that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will host a Taiwan- Africa summit meeting in Taipei in September, which will bring together leaders from Taiwan and its five African allies to discuss measures to boost cooperation.

Following the summit, a Taiwan-African forum will be held in which all African countries, including those maintaining no formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan, are welcome to participate, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO ORGANIZE GRAND PARADE TO PROMOTE U.N. BID REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has decided to organize a large- scale parade in September prior to the annual opening of the U.N. General Assembly to voice Taiwan's longstanding wish to join the United Nations, said the DPP deputy chief executive officer of policy affairs Monday.

Chang Yi-chan made the announcement after President Chen Shui-bien expressed his hope that a referendum would be held together with the 2008 presidential election, asking voters whether or not they to support the idea of bidding to join the United Nations under the name "Taiwan".
Chang said the DPP will do its utmost to collect enough endorsements for the proposed referendum to be carried out.

The Referendum Supervisory Committee is scheduled to review the proposal June 29. Since most members of the committee are members of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, Chang said the DPP has prepared a backup plan to launch an endorsement campaign to gather support should the committee reject the referendum proposal.

The DPP will campaign for the cause during the parade in early September in a drive to seek a consensus among Taiwan's 23 million people over the referendum issue, which aims to declare the country's strong desire to join the United Nations under the name "Taiwan".
The DPP expects that the planned parade will see more than 1 million people participate, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTORS WELCOME TO APPLY FOR OUTLYING ISLET CONSTRUCTION FUND

TEXT.P: The government invites investors to join in efforts to develop Taiwanese- controlled outlying islets, such as Matsu and Kinmen, by taking advantage of the state-run Outlying Islet Construction Fund, officials of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Monday.

The fund has a budget of NT$350 million (US$10.56 million) for proposed investments on the outlying islets this year, with local operators of holiday villas and hotels being welcomed to bid for the money, according to the CEPD.
Investors are also entitled to the government's preferential low-interest loans for outlying islet investment.
The fund began operations in 2006, offering investment and low-interest loans to local enterprises, as part of the government's efforts to accelerate the development of outlying islets.
