DOC.HEADLINE: TSU FAVORS HOLDING PRESIDENTIAL POLL WITH REFERENDUM ON U.N. SEAT

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) is backing a proposal by President Chen Shui-bian that calls for a referendum on Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations to be held along with the 2008 presidential poll, TSU lawmakers and officials said Monday.
Legislator Lin Chih-chia, who concurrently serves as the TSU's legislative caucus office director, made the comments while answering questions from reporters on Chen's call.

As the TSU has always supported pursuing a U.N. seat for the country under the name of Taiwan, the party will definitely back Chen's call to have the U.N. bid referendum held at the same time as the next presidential election, Lin said, adding that all TSU lawmakers have taken part in an endorsement drive initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to meet the legal threshold to put the issue to a referendum.

However, Lin went on, the TSU objects to holding the presidential and legislative elections at the same time. Both putting off the legislative election from January to March or holding the presidential poll in January instead of March would be unconstitutional, he claimed.
Chou Mei-li, executive director of the TSU's public relations department, said that her party supports Chen's idea of holding a U.N. referendum simultaneously with the next presidential election.

The DPP is slated to organize a mass march in early September to demonstrate the eagerness of the Taiwanese people to enter the U.N., and according to Chou, TSU lawmakers will also add their names to endorse that campaign.

Chen told visiting Heritage Foundation President Edwin J. Feulner Jr. earlier the same day during a meeting at the Presidential Office that he believes a referendum on the country's U.N. bid under the name of "Taiwan" could be held simultaneously with the 2008 presidential poll.

It was the first time that Chen has spoken out clearly on the DPP administration's plan to hold a referendum simultaneously with the 2008 presidential election on the country's pursuit of U.N. membership under the name of "Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: 70% OF ENTERPRISES OFFER DRAGON BOAT FESTIVAL BONUS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Around 13 percent of local enterprises have offered their employees both a bonus and a gift to celebrate the Dragon Boat Festival, a key festival in Taiwan that is considered the formal beginning of summer, according to the results of a survey released Monday.

The survey on Dragon Boat Festival bonuses was conducted by the Taipei-based 1111 Job Bank June 12-15 among business owners and human resources managers via telephone. A total of 341 effective samples were obtained.

The results show that 58.9 percent of the respondents awarded their employees with a bonus only prior to the June 19 Dragon Boat Festival, while some 13 percent offered only gifts and 15.54 percent gave nothing.
Most respondents (27.35 percent) offered bonuses ranging between NT$1,000 and NT$2,000, while 25.32 percent gave a bonus of NT$500-NT$1,000 and 13.06 percent gave NT$2,000-NT$3,000.
As for enterprises that did not award their employees, the survey shows that 78.9 percent said they have never given Dragon Boat Festival bonuses.

DOC.HEADLINE: FACTORIES TO BE FINED FOR EXCESSIVE NOISE

TEXT.P: Factories in Taipei whose machines produce low frequency noise that exceeds allowed levels and creates disturbance for nearby residents will be fined from next year, officials of the city's Department of Environmental Protection said Monday.
Violators could face fines of between NT$6,000 (US$180) and NT$60,000 or could be closed down, according to the officials.
The department has established a team of experts who can provide advice to factory operators on how to reduce noise, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO PUSH FOR REFERENDUM ON NATION'S BID TO JOIN U.N. AS `TAIWAN'

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will step up efforts to organize a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name "Taiwan" alongside the next presidential election, a DPP legislative caucus whip said Monday.

Ker Chien-ming made the remarks after President Chen Shui-bian called for the referendum to tell the world the people of Taiwan want to join the United Nations during a meeting with Heritage Foundation President Edwin J. Feulner, Jr. at the Presidential Office earlier in the day.

Ker said the first stage of a signature collection for a referendum on the proposal has been completed and the party will soon begin the second stage of collecting more signatures for the proposal to be put to a national referendum alongside the next presidential election.
"The time for collecting more signatures in the second stage will be limited, and the party will have to step up its efforts," he said.

Ker said he did not know whether the legislative elections will be held in tandem with the presidential election. The Central Election Commission has set Jan. 12 for the legislative elections, while the presidential election will be held in March according to past practice.

If the two elections are combined, the referendum on joining the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan, " as well as another referendum on a proposal to ask the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to return its ill-gotten assets, can be held simultaneously, Ker said.
If the two elections are held separately, whether to put the referendum on one proposal in each election or have two proposals in one election will have to be discussed further, he continued.

He said the party has yet to decide on whether the legislative and presidential elections should be combined and that the party will hear the views of the DPP caucus as well as take into consideration of DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh's views.
Meanwhile, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party (PFP) called for the DPP to "consider international reality" in proposing such a referendum.

KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yi said the KMT is taking a pragmatic and flexible approach. Whether it is "the Republic of China, " or "Taiwan, " or another name that takes into consideration Taiwan's dignity will be acceptable, although the premise will be international recognition.
He suggested that Chen not take a rigid stance on the matter.
KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin said there is a high level of consensus among the Taiwan people on joining the United Nations and that there is no need for a referendum.

He expressed hope that the DPP will not attempt to make an "election gambit" out of the issue by using the diplomatic setback to galvanize the public into throwing its support behind the ruling party.
Daniel Huang, executive director of the PFP's Policy Committee, echoed Su's words.

He pointed out that joining the United Nations as "Taiwan" will be "next to impossible, " noting that the United States will not support such a proposal and claiming that the president's suggestion is "only for the sake of election maneuvering."

DOC.HEADLINE: VP'S LATIN AMERICA TRIP TO CEMENT TIES: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office said Monday that an upcoming visit by Vice President Annette Lu to Central and South America and Caribbean is aimed at cementing diplomatic ties with allies in the region.
The Presidential Office's Department of Public Affairs denied reports in the China Times newspaper that Lu's visit is to engage in dollar diplomacy, dismissing them as untrue.
The reports said that Lu will embark on the visit in early July in a bid to forestall a domino effect caused by Costa Rica's switch of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing early this month.

The reports said Lu will depart for Paraguay via Panama and will return to Taiwan via the Dominican Republic. She is expected to announce two cooperation projects worth US$60 million while she is in Panama, as well as other forms of economic assistance to the Dominican Republic.
The press release asked the media to refrain from what it described as "random speculation" and to keep the national interests in mind.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT HONORS DEAD SONGWRITER

TEXT.P: Council for Hakka Affairs Chairman Lee Yung-teh awarded a medal to a grandson of the late Taiwanese songwriter Teng Yu-hsien Sunday to honor Teng's contribution to the country.

The award came at the concluding ceremony of a Broadway-style musical featuring the late songwriter's life story. In the musical, many of Teng's popular Taiwanese songs, as well as new pieces composed by contemporary songwriters, were presented.
Teng was a Hakka, but used the Taiwanese dialect in his songs, Lee said, adding that they became popular among different ethnic groups in the years that followed.
Describing Teng as a "national treasure, " Lee said his life and work "best reflect abundant and harmonious ethnic cultures."
Kuo Hsiao-ling, president of the Yungling Educational Foundation, which sponsored the three-day event, said 20 percent of the box-office revenues will be used to preserve documents related to Teng.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE TO RELEASE CAMPAIGN WHITE PAPERS FROM JULY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou is expected to release campaign white papers from July to keep the country abreast of his ideas on running the nation if elected, his campaign aides said Monday.

The aides said Ma, who has served as Taipei mayor and KMT chairman, has exchanged ideas intensively with members of a KMT think tank over the compilation of the campaign white papers and that he favors "short and concise" white papers to "long and traditional" ones so that voters can be allowed to grasp his ideas clearly and snappily.

The KMT think tank researchers have suggested that Ma avert ethnic rows and ideological issues, which they claimed the ruling Democratic Progressive Party is "good at manipulating, " and instead focus on real policies concerning the people's interests and welfare.
According to the aides, Ma's campaign white papers -- on differing major issues -- will mainly reflect "dignity" and "opening" as his main governance concepts.

His white paper on cross-Taiwan Strait relations and diplomatic policy will advocate that Taiwan seeks a "mutual non-denial" approach with China based on the principle that both sides interpret the "one China" policy separately.

It states that based on the premise of maintaining the cross-strait status quo, Taiwan will promote economic and trade exchanges with China and the rest of the Asia-Pacific region, or improving cross-strait relations while expanding substantive diplomatic ties.

His white paper on industrial development will suggest that while developing Taiwan into a regional business and industrial operational center, the Ma administration will seek to open Taiwan to Chinese tourists and develop tourism- related businesses so as to spur development in various industrial sectors.
On internal affairs, Ma will propose a "co-exist and prosper" idea, with streamlining social order being one of the top options, according to the aides.

On defense, he will propose "reasonable weapon purchases" and "appropriate military build-up" to allow Taiwan to maintain its defensive capability while refraining from entering an arms race with China. His white paper on defense will also oppose Taiwan's pursuit of the development of assault weapon systems, including nuclear weapons, the aides said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA AGREES TO IMPORT MANGOES FROM TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Sydney, June 18 (CNA) 06/18/07 21:07:46 (By Derek Chen and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: The Australian government has agreed to import mangoes from Taiwan, a major breakthrough in bilateral trade relations, officials of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Australia announced Monday.
The breakthrough is the result of a three-year effort to persuade the Australian government to import the Taiwanese fruit, the officials noted.
The announcement came after Australian quarantine officials came to Taiwan to inspect mango farms and other related facilities at the end of May, according to the officials.

Mango is a tropical fruit in season during the summer. Therefore, when Australia's mangoes are out of season in its southern hemisphere winter, Australian consumers can enjoy imported northern hemisphere Taiwanese mangoes, the officials said.
The office will continue to push for the export of other Taiwanese fruit to Australia, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE KEEN TO OBTAIN PROFESSIONAL CERTIFICATES

TEXT.P: There has been an increasing trend of seeking professional certificates over the past two years, according to data compiled by the School of Continuing Education of Taipei-based Chinese Culture University (SCECCU) , which shows that members of the public want to spend more money on private courses in preparation for professional certification examinations.

The SCECCU unveiled the data Monday of revenues generated from professional certification classes held 2000-2006. The data shows that the average cost of getting a professional certificate, such as state-level technician certification in the field of interior decoration, was NT$11,203 (US$337) in 2004.
In 2005 and 2006, the cost rose to NT$15,000-NT$16,000, according to the data. SCECCU executives concluded that people are willing to spend more money to obtain proof of their proficiency.
Notably, the data also shows that yoga instructor certification is the most- purchased professional certificate in Taiwan over the past six years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VALUES CANNOT BE ERODED OVER CHINA LINKS: DPP CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's values must not be compromised even if direct transport, trade and postal services are opened with China, Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said Monday on the offshore county of Penghu.

According to Hsieh, who was in Penghu for a two-day tour, the establishment of the so-called "three direct links" between Taiwan and China must be based on the values that Taiwan has long pursued, although such opening would be mutually beneficial.

Stating that Taiwan has to insist on its own principles and must not give its way to China's conditions when it comes to the issue of building direct cross- strait links, Hsieh said that "happiness and the future are in our hands" and that "Taiwan must lead the way in bilateral talks."

In response to talks made a day earlier on the island of Kinmen by Ma Ying-jeou -- the main opposition Kuomintang's candidate in the 2008 presidential election -- that he will allow all Taiwanese people to use the "mini three links" if he is elected president, Hsieh claimed that such rhetoric would impair two-way talks concerning the opening of direct transport links between Taiwan proper and China.
"It is very inappropriate for Ma to come up with this card for the time being and it shows that he lacks experience, " according to Hsieh.
The "mini links" refer to direct shipping services maintained between Taiwan- held Kinmen and Matsu islands with three ports in China's Fujian Province -- Xiamen, Mawei and Quanzgou.
For his part, Ma said that same day while giving a speech at National Chung Hsing University in Taichung City that direct Taiwan-China transport links should be designated as cross-strait routes.
Pointing out that China represents both threats and opportunities for Taiwan, Ma said he will ask Beijing to pull back its missiles pointing at Taiwan before holding bilateral negotiations.

If he is elected head of state and conducts negotiations with China, Ma reiterated, he will be resolved to mitigating China's threats by seeking to brandish the opportunities China could bring to Taiwan.
He also rebutted President Chen Shui-bian's criticism that he was too naive when broaching the idea of "mutual non denial" between Taiwan and China.

According to Ma, it would be more "practical" and "flexible" if both could shift from the current state of "mutual non recognition" to "mutual non denial" so as to allow for the creation of space for the two sides to engage.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES PRESIDENT'S REVELATION LED TO ARREST OF TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Monday reports that President Chen Shui-bian's revelation of secret information resulted in the arrest of Taiwan businessmen in China are "not true."
Officials of the MND's Bureau of Military Intelligence made the statement in a press release in response to reports by the China Times, a local newspaper.

The reports accused Chen, in a bid to promote a national referendum on the purchase of missiles alongside the 2004 presidential election, of revealing Nov. 30, 2003 the locations and number of 496 missiles deployed along the southeastern coast of China.

According to the reports, the president described the information as having come from intelligence sources. China then arrested more than 30 Taiwan spies between mid-December 2003 and January 2004 in revenge, the reports said, adding that most of the spies are businessmen who have become scapegoats in the cross-Taiwan Strait intelligence war.

The bureau said it is well known that China has deployed a large number of missiles along its southeastern coast and pointed out that satellite photos are all that are required to substantiate the existence of the missiles.

The reports that Chen, in a bid to seek re-election, noted the deployment of the Chinese missiles, which led to the arrest of the Taiwan businessmen "do not conform to the truth, " according to the press release.
It described the reports as "digging out an old case that the bureau had handled properly."

On personnel who had access to China's secret information against Taiwan but had dedicated themselves to safeguarding peace in the Taiwan Strait, the public should "be positive of them," the press release said.
The bureau has done its best to take care of the family members of arrested intelligence personnel serving time in Chinese prisons, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT `INCAPABLE' OF INTIMIDATING JUSTICE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu said Monday that President Chen Shui-bian is "incapable of intimidating justice," noting that this is no longer an authoritarian era.

Chen Chu was responding to misgivings that the president is trying to intimidate judges one day after he lashed out at a ruling of the Kaohsiung District Court that annulled Chen Chu's election victory in the Dec. 9 Kaohsiung mayoral election on the grounds that her camp spread "unsubstantiated" accusations of her rival's vote buying that could have swayed the outcome of the election.

Huang Chun-ying of the main opposition Kuomintang's Kaohsiung mayoral candidate filed lawsuits challenging the outcome of the election and the election itself after losing to Chen Chu by a slim-margin of 1,114 votes. The court rejected his lawsuit against the election itself.
According to Chen Chu, "the ruling is difficult for the public or legal sector to accept" and that she would appeal the case.
Huang for his part said that as a national leader, the president's stern criticism of the judicial ruling was "inappropriate, " "incredible" and a "negative model of democratic education."
Huang said Chen Chu's camp had spread unsubstantiated words of "vote-buying" after the official campaign activities ended, prompting the court to hand out the annulment rule.

Meanwhile, ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators from seven DPP-held cities and counties will travel to Kaohsiung Thursday to lend support to Chen Chu, according to a DPP legislative caucus whip.

Ker Chien-ming said the court ruling shows that "there will be no more peace after every election, " pointing out that Chen Chu had caught her rival vote- buying but ended up being annulled of her election victory.
Hsu Shao-ping, a KMT legislative caucus whip, said that the KMT will convene a meeting Wednesday to decide how to lend support to Huang.

KMT Legislator Lo Shih-hsiung said that five legislative candidates nominated by the KMT Kaohsiung city chapter and KMT caucus member of Kaohsiung City Council will accompany Huang to another news conference Wednesday.
They will announce that KMT city councilors will use a boycott or another "rational" way to show that Chen Chu's clinging onto her post has "no legitimacy."
Because Chen Chu's election victory has been annulled, her administrative team will only be a caretaker one and should not make any major policy decisions, according to Lo.

The councilors will boycott plans and budgets for the lantern festival next year until the court hands out a second trial ruling, although they will not obstruct the follow-up funds for construction projects for the 2009 World Games and the repair work for a cave-in on the mass rapid transit system construction, Lo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: `DISSENTING OPINION' DISCLOSURE DECIDED BY PANEL OF JUDGES: COURT

TEXT.P: A three-person panel of judges charged with trying the Kaohsiung mayoral election lawsuit chose to reveal a dissenting opinion expressed by one of its members by attaching it to the court verdict, a Kaohsiung District Court administrator said Monday.

The court official made the remarks after main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Kuo Su-chung, who is also a KMT legislative caucus whip, said the disclosure of the panel's reporting judge's dissenting opinion before the final ruling is handed down is illegal.
Quoting Article 103 of the Court Organic Law, which was revised last December, Kuo said judges' comments should not be made public until all court proceedings are finalized.
Under the current law, an election lawsuit cannot be closed until after the second instance is finalized.

The KMT's candidate in last December's Kaohsiung mayoral election, Huang Chun- ying, filed a lawsuit demanding that the result of the election be annulled after he narrowly lost to Chen Chu, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's candidate.

Led by presiding judge Huang hung-chin, the panel ruled last Friday in favor of Huang, who accused Chen of violating campaign regulations by presenting a video on the eve of polling day allegedly showing vote-buying by him on a tour bus returning from one of his campaign rallies.
The video was repeatedly aired by television stations on election day.

"The tactic... was enough to influence the election result, " the District Court ruled in its verdict. Based on this point, the court invalidated Chen's election victory and demanded that a new election be held to select a new mayor.
However, Ku Chen-hui, who as the reporting judge on the panel was actually in charge of most of the investigative work, did not see eye-to-eye with his colleagues on the judgment.

Ku outlined three questions to challenge the ruling. First, Ku said, if Huang cannot prove that Chen's claim of discovering "Huang paying `walking fees' to those who attended his campaign rally as shown in the video" was ill-motivated, the court should not have judged it as a slanderous move or illegal campaign gambit.

Second, Ku said, since the Chen camp's negative campaign tactic at most violated the regulations related to the period for campaigning, voters' rights "were not affected" by the infraction. Consequently, he went on, Chen did not break any election-related "fundamental principles" to justify the annulment.

Third, Ku said, in the conducting of election campaigns, exposing political rival's supposedly illegal campaign gambits, such as vote-buying, is part of freedom of speech and therefore protected by the Constitution. A complete ban on such moves could infringe upon personal freedom of speech, he added.

In his view, Ku said, the court's description of a candidate's negative campaigning gambit as a criminal act and employing it as a reason to invalidate the candidate's election victory would hobble protection of the candidate's freedom of speech and ordinary voters' exercise of their voting rights.

Moreover, Ku said that in this case, there has not been sufficient evidence to prove that Chen herself was involved in the conduct of the "walking fee" campaign gambit. Therefore, he said it is inappropriate to hold Chen responsible for violations of the Election and Recall Law by her campaign aides, who unveiled the controversial video at an election-eve news conference after the legal campaign period had expired.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FAMRERS PARTY TO HOLD DEVELOPMENT MEETING JUNE 28

TEXT.P: The newly established Taiwan Farmers Paty will hold a commissioners meeting June 28 to hammer out strategies to boost the party's development and recruit more members, party sources said Monday.
The party, headquartered in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan, formed a 23-member Development Commission at its inaugural meeting June 15.

The commission will hold its first meeting June 28, during which a liaison officer will be selected to represent the party in engagements with other political parties and government authorities, the sources said.

The party, which vows to fight for grassroots farmers and fishermen's rights and interests, will work out effective tactics and strategies to win at least 5 percent of ballots in the next legislative elections in order to secure two to three at-large legislative seats, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 19, or the fifth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1566: King James I of England and VI of Scotland is born in the Scottish capital of Edinburgh. The son of Mary Queen of Scots, he succeeded Elizabeth I as the first Stuart king of England. His belief in the divine rights of kings and his attempts to keep the peace with Spain led to the English Civil War.
1623: Blaise Pascal, French philosopher and mathematician, is born. Among his achievements are the invention of an adding machine and the development of the modern theory of probability.
1885: The Statue of Liberty arrives in New York as a gift from France.
1924: The "Red Army" of the Chinese communists takes Lungyen and other towns in an attempt to establish a military base in western Fukien province in southern China.
1935: The British government overrides the Treaty of Versailles signed at the Paris Peace Conference in 1919 by agreeing to allow Germany a massive increase in its naval strength.
1944: The Japanese fleet attacks US ships protecting a landing at Saipan, resulting in considerable air and sea losses for Japan.
1953: Julius Rosenberg, 35, and his wife Ethel, 37, having been convicted by the United States of passing atom bomb secrets to the Russians, are sent to the electric chair at Sing Sing prison.
1956: American industrialist Thomas John Watson dies of a heart attack in New York at the age of 82. He became president of the company that later became International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) in 1924. Under Watson's leadership, it became one of the world's most successful corporations.
1960: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek and U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower issue a joint communique pledging that their governments will "continue to stand solidly behind the Sino-US Mutual Defense Treaty in meeting the challenge posed by the Chinese communists in this area."
1960: Prior to U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower's departure from the ROC, mainland China attacks Kinmen with 88,978 shells. Ordered to retaliate, ROC artillery units destroy eight coastal guns, seven fortifications, and four ammunition depots on the mainland.
1961: An 1899 agreement by which Britain is responsible for overseeing Kuwaiti foreign policy is terminated, making Kuwait a fully independent nation.
1964: Chiang Meng-lin, chairman of the ROC Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, dies of liver cancer in Taipei at the age of 79.
1974: Korean National Assembly Speaker Chung Il Kwon and a party of 15 arrive in Taipei for a four-day visit at the invitation of Premier Chiang Ching-kuo.
1975: The Republic of China and Saudi Arabia sign an agreement to strengthen economic and technical cooperation.
1975: The Chinese Pacific Economic and Cultural Center and the Philippines Far East Trade Promotion Center sign an agreement to exchange offices to promote bilateral trade, tourism and other relations.
1976: The US Manufacturers' Hanover Asia Consortium loans US$80 million to the China Steel Corporation.
1983: Li Xiannian becomes mainland China's first president since 1969.
1989: The Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Task Force of the ROC announces the government's plan to simplify procedures for the relocation of Hong Kong and Macau citizens in Taiwan and to provide assistance for their emigration to a third country.
1992: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with Niger.
1992: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the Law on Foreign Futures Contracts, to take effect in January 1993.
1994: Wu Lihung, Hu Zehan and Yu Aiquin, who were found guilty and sentenced to death by a court in mainland China's Hangchow for killing 24 tourists from Taiwan at Qiantaohu in Chekiang province, are executed by firing squad.
1997: William Hague is chosen as the youngest-ever leader of Britain's Conservative Party.
1999: Prince Edward of Britain marries Sophie Rhys-Jones, a public relations executive, in a ceremony at Windsor Castle.
2000: Fifty-eight mainland Chinese were found suffocated in a truck container at an English port. They died during the trip from Belgium to Britain.
2001: Formosa Platics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching says that Taiwan should accept mainland China's "one China" principle out of consideration for its mutual benefits at this critical moment of development for the entire Chinese race.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman esteems what is right as of the highest importance. A gentleman who has valor, but is without a knowledge and love of what is right, is likely to commit a crime. A common man who has courage, but is without the knowledge and love of what is right, is likely to become a robber."

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER DEPARTS FOR JAPAN

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng flew to Japan Tuesday for a three-day visit, his assistants said.
Wang will attend the memorial service for Motoo Shiina, a member of the Japanese House of Councilors who was very friendly toward Taiwan. The funeral is scheduled for June 20.
President Chen Shui-bian named former Premier Frank Hsieh -- the candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the 2008 presidential election -- to take part in the funeral on his behalf.
Wang's assistants said they expect that Wang will meet with Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe during his visit.
Wang will also visit Takeo Hiranuma, chairman of the Dietmen's Alliance for Japan-ROC Friendship, before flying home June 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE VISITS PENGHU, VOWS OPENING OF CHINA LINKS

TEXT.P: Ma Yin-jeou, presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , reiterated Tuesday his promise on the offshore county of Penghu to open direct cross-Taiwan Strait links if elected president.
Ma flew into the Penghu Islands earlier the same day -- during the annual Dragon Boat Festival -- to drum up public support for his presidential bid.

Echoing remarks he made Sunday on the outlying Kinmen Island, Ma asserted that he will hold cross-strait talks on opening direct transport, trade and postal services between Taiwan proper and China -- the so-called "three links, " allow all Taiwan people to use the "mini links" to travel to China and implement direct cross- strait charter flight service on weekends and holidays as soon as he is elected president.

Ma pledged to wrap up bilateral talks on the "three links" within one year following his election while working to make the "mini links" -- direct shipping services between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and Fujian ports of Xiamen, Mawei and Quanzhou in China -- as well as direct cross-strait holiday and weekend charter flights, available to all Taiwanese people.
Although Penghu residents have been permitted to travel to China via Kinmen and Matsu on the "mini links" routes since April this year, Ma said that such a detour does not much benefit Penghu.

Recognizing the possibility that the opening of the "three links" could have a great impact on Penghu, the outlying island should consider transforming itself into a prime tourist destination, Ma opined, suggesting that its Makung Airport would perfectly serve international flights should some of its shortcomings be overcome.

Turning to a policy under consideration that would allow the establishment of gambling casinos on Penghu, Ma said that he and the KMT's legislative caucus members all are supportive of the idea and expressed his belief that it will materialize when conditions are ripe.

Ma also refuted criticism against him made a day earlier by Frank Hsieh, his rival from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the 2008 presidential poll, by challenging Hsieh to come up with a clear and concrete China policy.

According to Hsieh, Ma has demonstrated a lack of experience in cross-strait affairs on the grounds the he has revealed his "three links" policy too soon, which Hsieh said will simply invite China to frustrate the policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAO TRIBESMEN ON LANYU ROW TRADITIONAL BOAT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Twelve tribesmen of Tao aborigines on Lanyu, also known as Orchid Island, off the coast of eastern Taiwan, began a journey early Tuesday to Taiwan on a traditional Tao wooden boat.
Lin Chien-heng, an organizer of the project said in Taipei Tuesday that the boat, christened Ipanga Na 1001, left Langdao on Lanyu at 4:30 a.m. braving a downpour and thunderstorm.

The first leg of their journey will take them to Taitung, which is 49 nautical miles away as the crow flies although the rowing route would be much longer as the boat has to cross the Kuroshio current flowing northward off the coast of eastern Taiwan at a pace of four to five nautical miles per hour.
Lin said the boat, made of 60 planks of wood and measuring 10 meters in length, 1.7 meters in width, 2.7 meters in height, is the biggest traditional Tao boat to be made in living memory.

Construction of the boat by five Tao fishing clans began last November and finished in May, said Lin who came up with the project to prove that it was possible for the Tao's ancestors to journey from island to island throughout the south Pacific in their small boats.

Capable of carrying 12 to 14 rowers, the boat set out at a speed of nine to 12 kilometers per hour and entered into the Kuroshio current at 9 a.m. Tuesday, Lin said, predicting that it will arrive off of Taitung's beach at 9 p.m.
After that, Lin said, four teams of Tao crew members will take turns rowing the boat along the coastline of Taiwan to Taipei.
The Tao, numbering about 4,000 throughout the country, lived on Lanyu and no other place. Their ancestors are believed to have immigrated to that island from Batan, the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIAL URGES PRESIDENT CHEN TO REJECT REFERENDUM PROPOSAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 18 (CNA) 06/19/07 16:53:50 (By Chiehyu Lin & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: An official of the U.S. Department of State urged Taiwan's President Chen Shui- bian Monday to drop the proposal to hold a referendum on joining the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan."

The official with the department's Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, speaking on the condition of anonymity, made the call while responding to Chinese-language media requests for comment on an earlier announcement by Chen that he will push for a referendum on whether to apply for the U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan, to be held alongside the next presidential election in 2008.

The official first reiterated that the United States supports "Taiwan's inclusion in appropriate international organizations that do not require statehood for membership, " adding that such practice is consistent with his country's "One China" policy.

However, he went on, that policy does not include supporting Taiwan's quest to gain membership in international organizations that require statehood, including the United Nations. Moreover, the official said the United States opposes any initiatives that appear to be designed to change unilaterally Taiwan's status, including a referendum on "Whether apply to the U.N. under the name of Taiwan."

"While such a referendum will have no practical impact on U.S.-Taiwan status, it would increase tensions in the Taiwan Strait," he explained, urging President Chen to exercise leadership by rejecting the proposed referendum.
The official further said that maintaining peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait is vital to the interests of the people of Taiwan, and serves U.S. security and interest as well.

President Chen formally expressed his wish for holding a referendum on Taiwan's drive to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan alongside the next presidential election for the first time during his meeting with Heritage Foundation President Edwin J. Feulner, Jr. in Taipei Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 TAIPEI BIOTECH AWARDS KICK OFF: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taipei Biotech Awards are now open to applications from some 400 biotech and biomedical companies located in Taipei City and the awards ceremony scheduled for mid-October, after the review board selects winners in four categories, city government officials said Tuesday.
The awards were launched in 2004, and prizes presented annually since then, they said, adding that the objective of the awards is to establish Taipei as Taiwan's "biotech capital."

Reward monies of NT$5 million (approximately US$152,000) will be distributed among winners in categories including "Technology Commercialization, " "R&D Innovation, " "Technology Transfer, " and "Academia-Industry Cooperation," they said.
The winners of the gold prizes in "Technology Commercialization" and "Technology Transfer" will be given NT$800,000 each -- the largest single monetary rewards of the four categories, they said.

According to the city government, the deadline for applications is August 4. After that, a board of 28 specialists in areas of technology, finance and operations, and intellectual property rights will review the applications to select the finalists.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO GRANT SPECIAL PARDON TO 'RICE BOMBER'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian announced Tuesday his decision to grant a special pardon to imprisoned "rice bomber" Yang Ju-men.

Making the announcement during an inspection of a naval fleet in the northern port of Keelung, Chen said he had consulted with Vice President Annette Lu and relevant authorities concerning Yang's case and determined that special commiseration is appropriate given the situation.

In addition, Yang has performed well in prison and should be in no danger of re- offending, Chen said, adding that he has ordered authorities concerned to process the special pardon for Yang according to the relevant laws.

The move was made in response to a non-binding resolution adopted by the Legislative Yuan last Friday in which the president was asked to pardon Yang. The resolution was adopted along with the passage of a commutation statute that grants amnesty to prison inmates serving sentences of no more than 18 months.

Yang, who is serving a five-and-a-half-year prison term for planting at least 17 explosive devices around Taipei over a one-year period until he turned himself in November 2004, is not eligible for commutation under the statute.

Identifying himself as an opponent of the government's rice import policy, Yang always included small amounts of rice in his homemade, non-lethal explosives, and claimed his actions were intended to call the government's attention to the plight of local farmers.

Also during Tuesday's inspection tour, Chen again urged legislators to hold a special session to review a list of important budget bills, including one dealing with state-owned enterprises and another one addressing a series of major development projects, in which the government is expected to invest NT$500 billion over a five-year period.

Chen expressed his gratitude to legislators for approving part of the budget for an arms procurement package from the United States on the final day of the legislative session last Friday, after the procurement had been stalled for three years.

Noting that there have been more than six years since the package was approved by U.S. President George W. Bush in 2001, Chen said debates over the arms procurement over these past years have helped people in this country realize that strong defense capabilities are their only protection in the realm of national security, and that peace is not to be had for nothing, or at a discount.

"Taiwan has no intention of engaging in an arms race with China, but only if we are ready for combat and are capable of combating can we stop and prevent a war to ensure true, long-lasting peace, " Chen said.

He said politicians across party lines in Taiwan agree that the country urgently needs to modernize its military forces, a situation which he said demonstrates the will of Taiwan's 23 million people to safeguard the country's security and sovereignty.

Included in the government's 2007 budget, which cleared the legislature last Friday, were NT$200 million to finance a feasibility study on the purchase of diesel-electric submarines from the United States, NT$6.1 billion to procure submarine-hunting P3-C aircraft, and NT$3.5 billion to upgrade the performance of Patriot PAC-2 anti-missile batteries.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. STUDENTS LEARN CRAFTS AT LOCAL UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: A total of 11 college students from Auburn University in the United States are learning crafts at Shu-Te University in the southern county of Kaohsiung as part of an annual bilateral exchange program, a spokesman for Shu-Te University said Tuesday.

American students of the Industrial Design Department, who arrived in Taiwan May 12, will put on a presentation showcasing their works on the last day of their stay -- July 3, according to the spokesman.

The students are learning how to create western-style furniture with a Taiwanese touch under the instruction of teachers and students at the local university's Department of Product Design, the spokesman noted.
The students hope to use their made in Taiwan works to participate in a furniture design contest to be held in the U.S. in 2008, the spokesman said.

Shu-Te University has selected eight students from the Department of Product Design to provide assistance and instruction to their U.S. peers, the spokesman said, adding that the experience will enhance the Taiwanese students' organizing ability and their understanding of the U.S. culture.

The university also chose another 44 students to help the U.S. students deal with issues arising in their daily lives in Taiwan as part of efforts to improve students' English abilities, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE DEPARTS FOR JAPAN

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh, who is the 2008 presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , departed for Tokyo Tuesday to attend a memorial service for the late Japanese lawmaker Motoo Shiina on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

Shiina was a prominent member of the House of Councilors -- the upper house of Japan's Diet. Known for his friendliness toward Taiwan, Shiina was granted the Order of Brilliant Star with Violet Grand Cordon by Chen in 2003.
Hsieh, who has a doctoral degree in law from Kyoto University, will read a eulogy in remembrance of Shiina at the memorial service scheduled for Wednesday.
Responding to press inquiries about his policy toward China, Hsieh said he is consistent on the issue in both theoretical and practical dimensions.

During his one-year stint as premier from 2005 through early 2006, Hsieh said he advocated early opening of measures that would benefit Taiwan's economic development, such as opening to Chinese tourists and Chinese capital. "I remain unchanged on these stances, " he added.
As to cross-Taiwan Strait transportation links, Hsieh said he favors gradual opening, beginning with charter flights.
Hsieh further said Taiwan's national identity and dignity should never be compromised when addressing issues that require cross-strait negotiation.

DOC.HEADLINE: BNHI WARNS OF FRAUD SCHEMES

TEXT.P: Officials of the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) Taichung branch warned the public Tuesday of fraud schemes aimed at stealing money from gullible people's bank accounts.
The warning came after the branch received inquiries from several members of the public about their insurance premiums or health insurance cards.

Some of them reported having received telephone calls claiming to be from BNHI staff asking them to pay overdue insurance premiums or telling them they were eligible for a refund, while others were told that someone else was using their National Health Insurance cards, the officials said.
The fraudsters attempt to obtain personal information and ask their victims to transfer money to a specific bank account, according to the officials.
Urging the public to be on high alert for such suspicious phone calls, the officials said the public can call the bureau or the branch to verify the requests.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACHINERY MANUFACTURING OUTPUT TO HIT NT$1 TRILLION BY 2009: MOEA

TEXT.P: The machinery sector is expected to become the third manufacturing industry in Taiwan to generate an annual production value of at least NT$1 trillion (US$30.09 billion) , following the semiconductor and flat-screen monitor production sectors, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said Tuesday.
The MOEA plans to assist 10 local enterprises in the sector in efforts to develop them into flagship enterprises whose turnover reaches NT$10 billion or more per year, the officials said.

According to MOEA statistics, the machinery sector generated output valued at NT$800 billion in 2006, representing an increase of 10.8 percent over the previous year. The output accounted for 6.5 percent of the accumulated production value of all the domestic manufacturing sectors in 2006, but the carbon dioxide emission amount accounted only for 0.7 percent of the total.

The figures suggest that the government should make efforts to help the energy- saving sector's development, the officials said, noting that the efforts should include the establishment of more conglomerates of precision machinery-related manufacturers following one set up in the Central Taiwan Science Park in Taichung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Burglars and drug offenders to be freed
Two thousand criminals are to be released early from jail to ease the prison overcrowding crisis, under plans being prepared by the Justice Secretary.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL GIFT BAGS OVER-PACKAGED: TAIPEI BUREAU

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Bureau of the Taipei city government is urging business and the public to cooperate in a drive that will kick off July 1 to wipe out over-packaging and reduce waste.
According to bureau officials, during a random inspection of food gift bags last month, the bureau found that four out of 10 gift bags were over-packaged. Most of these were chicken essence products.

The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration has since July 2006 been implementing increasingly strict regulations targeting the over-packaging of gift bags containing cakes, cosmetics, liquor, computer software and video games, bureau officials said. They added that over the past year, the bureau lodged complaints with producers of 11 items, out of a total of 9,000 products examined.
A second phase in the bureau's campaign to raise public awareness of over- packaging will be launched July 1 to deal with processed food gift bags, officials said.

As offenders face fines of between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000, bureau officials called on companies concerned about the rules to have their products packaging examined by licensed certification agencies before releasing them on to the market, and thereby avoid punishment.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Finance minister warns of pension reform cost.
The finance ministry said that a proposed pension reform plan, which will be discussed in a meeting between the government and trade unions, will cost 10 billion euros for the government in the next 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERIMENTAL FILM TO PREMIERE AT TAIPEI FILM FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: A 50-minute experimental film that will premiere at the Taipei Film Festival will try to create "poetry in motion, " the film's producer said Tuesday at a test screening.

The film, produced by the Public Television Service (PTS), is a collaboration of five established Taiwanese directors each of whom presents a 10-minute film inspired by famous poems and poets, said Sylvia Feng, producer of the PTS program Viewpoint and chief coordinator of the project.
The short films, directed by Tseng Wen-chen, Wu Mi-sen, Hou Chi-jan, Chu Hsien- jer and Mickey Chen will premiere June 24 at the annual Taipei Film Festival and will be played on Viewpoint June 29.
"You can find a lot of similarities between poetry and documentaries. However, it is extremely difficult to transform words into images, " according to Wu.

Other than Wu's, whose idea for his short animated film titled "Yearning" came from an assignment he gave his students years ago, all the films have been inspired by works of well-known Taiwanese poets, including Hsia Yu, Ling Yu and Sun Tse-ping.
The films include Tseng's "Keep Dancing, " Chu's "Genesis, Rehearsal, " Hou's "Shopping Cart Boy " and Chen's "Seeking Friends Along the Coast."

This is the second time PTS has produced experimental "poetry in motion" filmmaking, following huge success in 2003, Feng said, adding that the production of documentary films has seen a cross-over trend in recent years that combines the elements of animation, musical and image effects.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGER REACTS WITH MIXED FEELINGS TO DAUGHTER'S MAHJONG SUCCESS

TEXT.P: Veteran singer Yu Tien, whose daughter recently came third in a major mahjong competition in Macau, said Tuesday that he is proud of her, but added jokingly that he is also concerned he might have difficulty inviting friends to play the traditional Chinese game at home.
"With a gambling diva at home, most of my friends will be scared away," Yu quipped.
Yu, who admits to being a mahjong enthusiast himself, said his daughter Yu Hsiao-ping learned the game as a baby when her grandma would hold her with one hand while playing with the other.
"It is not an exaggeration to say that she mastered her mahjong skill before she learned to speak and walk," Yu said.
As a girl growing up, Yu said she often briefly substituted for her father when he would play mahjong with friends at home and would have to leave the table to attend to other business.
The proud father said his daughter usually ended up winning while playing on his behalf and that he often lost what his daughter had won after taking over the game again.

Although mahjong is frowned on by some Chinese as a form of gambling and its playing was forbidden in public places in Taiwan for a long time, Yu spoke out for it, claiming that the game improves harmony at home when played among family members and that it is a better form of entertainment than wining and dining.
Furthermore, Yu claimed that by having children play the game at home prevents them from roaming about outside, which could lead to trouble.
Yu said both he and his singer wife Lee Ya-ping like playing mahjong and own more than 30 sets of high quality mahjong tiles.
Yu Hsiao-ping, who ended up in third place in the 2007 World Series of Mahjong in Macau last Sunday, won US$50,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELATIONSHIP COURSES MAY BE INCLUDED IN SENIOR HIGH SCHOOL CURRICULA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) is collecting public opinion on a draft curriculum outline that proposes including relationship courses in the senior high school program, an education official said Tuesday.

Huang Kun-lung, deputy director-general of the MOE's Department of Secondary Education, said the ministry has organized a series of public hearings in which experts and academics have been invited to contribute their views on the proposed outline, which is intended for implementation in the 2009-2010 academic year.

The relationship courses have been included in the draft as part of civic and social education, which, according to the draft, is aimed at "nurturing care and virtue" in the country's citizens and will cover a wide range of issues such as life education, gender equality, the environment and cultural diversity.
To facilitate teenagers' healthy transition to adulthood, the courses will help teenagers understand the meaning of love and how to handle breakups with their lovers, according to the draft.

Commenting on the draft Tuesday, some opposition lawmakers said the relationship courses should be optional, not compulsory, because senior high school students might differ in terms of their relationship maturity.

Legislator Kuo Shu-chun of the Kuomintang said the availability of qualified teachers is another aspect that should be taken into consideration if the MOE is to include the courses in the senior high school curriculum, pointing out that "students nowadays are probably more experienced than their teachers" in dealing with relationships.
Lu Shiow-yen, another KMT legislator, said the MOE should not further increase students' workloads when the load is already very heavy.
Lu suggested that knowledge about relationships be included in the existing life courses.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED TO PRIORITIZE PUBLIC'S INTERESTS ON TOURISM ISSUE

TEXT.P: China should adopt a positive mindset based on the best interests of the people when dealing with the issue of cross-Taiwan Strait tourism, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Tuesday.

Chen noted that technical problems concerning the government's plan to open Taiwan to Chinese tourists are almost solved through several rounds of talks with the Beijing authorities and that the main bottleneck of the plan lies in political issues.

"We hope the Beijing authorities will consider the matter from a positive point of view. Hasn't Chinese President Hu Jintao said that `anything in the people's interests should be done'? This is a matter in the people's interests that Beijing should deal with from the perspective of the people's interests, " Chen told CNA.
Chen blamed China for impeding progress of the cross-strait talks on the tourism issue by imposing political rhetoric in the talks.
For example, China has referred to Taiwan as "Taiwan, China" and insisted that cross-strait visits are not ones "between two countries," according to Chen.

Chen is scheduled to attend a seminar with a group of China-based Taiwanese businessmen organized by the Straits Exchange Foundation June 20-22 in Hualien, during which he will brief the participants on the progress of talks on cross- strait tourism and cross-strait charter cargo and passenger flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE CLIMBERS REACH TOP OF NORTH AMERICA

TEXT.P: A team of Taiwanese climbers have conquered the highest mountain in North America--the 6,914-meter Mt. Mckinley, also known as Mt. Denali, according to a report from Alaska.

The report said the expedition, organized by the Taiwan Mountaineering Education Development Association, was made up of six members including Captain Chiang Kuo-hua, Vice Captain Ku Ming-kaung, Hsieh Chiang-sung, Chin Ko-chien, Ko Chin-yuan and Yu Kaun-chou.

The climbers left Taiwan May 24 and arrived at a glacier base camp May 26 to spend three weeks on final training for the climb and for glacier travel. They set up four camps at altitudes ranging from 2,400 meters to 5,200 meters.
The summiteers were Ku, who is a Taiwanese aboriginal, followed by Chiang, with the rest of the team in auxiliary roles.

They will return to Taiwan June 26 and start a six-month training program for an attempt next year on Mt. Everest, the highest mountain in the world, following in the footsteps of Makalu Gau, the Taiwanese climber who summitted in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU HOPES DPP CAN ASSUAGE U.S. MISGIVINGS ABOUT REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progress Party (DPP) "should be able" to relieve U.S. misgivings about its plan to hold a referendum on Taiwan's bid for U.N. membership in the name of "Taiwan, " an opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) spokeswoman said Tuesday.

Chou Mei-li, chief executive of the TSU's information department, made the remarks after an unidentified U.S. State Department Official reiterated that the United States opposes any initiatives that appear to be designed to unilaterally change Taiwan's status, which includes a referendum on whether to apply for U.N. membership as "Taiwan."

"While such a referendum would have no practical impact on U.S.-Taiwan status, it would increase tension in the Taiwan Strait," the American official explained, urging Chen to exercise leadership and reject the proposed referendum.

Responding to the remarks, Chou said Taiwan is an independent country that is entitled to decide its own future or destiny. The international community should not "misunderstand" the purpose of its push for a referendum on its U.N. membership bid, she added.
"We believe that the DPP administration should be capable of quenching U.S. misgivings about our country's U.N. membership bid, " Chou said.

The TSU, which controls 12 seats in the legislature, supports simultaneous holding of a referendum on the country's U.N. membership application under the name of Taiwan along with the 2008 presidential election, Chou said.

Nevertheless, she added, the party opposes the "two-in-one" merger of the next presidential and legislative elections or the "three-in-one" merger of the next presidential and legislative elections and the U.N. bid referendum.
The TSU and the DPP are "pan-green" camp partners who share similar pro- independence convictions but are otherwise divided on a variety of policy issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: `PAN GREEN CAMP' WANTS EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION FOR FARMER'S BILL

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) vowed Tuesday to push for an extra legislative session and demand that a bill on a monthly stipend for farmers, along with other key bills, be dealt with in the session.

Ker Chien-ming's remarks echoed a call made earlier in the day by President Chen Shui-bian, who asked the Legislative Yuan to hold an extra session to deal with several important bills still being blocked after the latest session adjourned last Friday.
According to Ker, the DPP will definitely ask the legislature to hold an extra session "out of concern over the people's livelihoods."

Apart from the 2007 central government budget bill that was approved last week, Ker said the DPP will also demand a bill regarding a five-year NT$500 billion expansion program of public construction projects, as well as a bill aimed at granting a monthly stipend of NT$6,000 for elderly farmers and an annual budget bill for state-run companies, be addressed in the proposed extra session.

Ker predicted that the farmers' monthly stipend bill will quickly be approved during the extra session, on the grounds that both the ruling and opposition parties have reached initial agreement on it.

Hsu Shao-ping, a legislative caucus whip of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said she agreed that an extra session should be called to deal with the key bills, but questioned why the DPP excluded a draft law regarding the formation of the Central Election Commission (CEC) from the legislative agenda.
As far as the KMT is concerned, the party hopes to approve all major bills in the proposed extra session, including the draft CEC Organic Law, Hsu said.
Tseng Yung-chuan, a lawmaker and director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Commission, accused the DPP of double-dealing with the farmers' stipend bill.

The KMT was willing to allow the bill to clear the Legislative Yuan last Friday -- the last day of the session, but it was the DPP that came up with a motion asking to put off a final approval for the bill in order to further discuss the issue with the opposition.
"This two-faced tactic was deliberately designed by the DPP to deceive elderly farmers," he claimed.

The several annual budget bills and the draft CEC Organic Law have been stonewalled in the legislature over the past few months due to the divergent positions of the "pan-green camp" led by the DPP and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP).

The "pan-blues" had insisted on passing their version of the CEC draft law in exchange for the passage of the 2007 central government budget bill. But "pan- blue" lawmakers agreed to approve it late last week after Ma Ying-jeou, the KMT's presidential candidate, asked for the approval of the 2007 central government budget bill amid public outrage over the KMT's antics.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS TO LOBBY U.S. PEOPLE ON TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: A former senior adviser to the president, Wu Li-pei, said Tuesday that he is planning to make a public call in the United States for U.S. recognition of Taiwan and establishing diplomatic relations with the country.

Wu, who is the founder of the U.S.-based Formosa Foundation and a steadfast pro- Taiwan independence advocate, made the statement prior to his departure slated for Wednesday for the U.S. along with Peng Ming-min, also a prominent pro- independence activist and a former senior presidential advisor.

Wu said he and Peng are scheduled to hold a press conference in Los Angeles Thursday to promote the call. They will then kick off efforts to make Taiwan's independence an issue for policy debate between the Republicans and the Democrats amid the approach of the U.S. presidential and congressional elections in 2008.

Wu said they hope to expand the issue into a "grassroots movement" in the United States by launching a lobbying campaign there in hope of winning support from the U.S. people. He stressed that that their gambit has nothing to do with the Taiwan government and that they will be acting in a private capacity.

He said surveys show that more than half of the American people are unaware that their country maintains no diplomatic ties with Taiwan and claimed that now is the best time to lobby U.S. grassroots voters for their support, as the U.S. is entering a major election year. He did not elaborate further.

Wu suggested that Taiwan first seek support from workers' unions, Christian organizations, Republican conservatives, "free" Democrats, human rights groups and environmental protection associations. Taiwan should also organize "Taiwan's Friends" associations in every U.S. state and try to make the "Taiwan issue" a big issue for American voters during election campaigns and major debates, he added.

Admitting that seeking U.S. diplomatic recognition will be difficult to complete "soon, " Wu said, however, that their movement is expected to raise U.S. people's attention toward the Taiwan issue. He also said it might even force the U.S. government to review its "one China" policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP ATTENDS CHARITY CONCERT TO ECHO U.N. WORLD REFUGEE DAY

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan should join hands with people around the world to respect human life and human rights, Vice President Annette Lu said at a charity concert and ceremony on the eve of the U.N. World Refugee Day Tuesday.

Hopefully, the idea of the World Refugee Day will spark more participation in humanitarian work in Taiwan and extend blessings to those who are suffering so there will be no more refugees in the world in the future, Lu said in her opening remarks at the charity concert organized by the Chinese Association for Human Rights (CAHR).

The concert included performances by local groups the Physicians Chamber Orchestra and the Center Choir, and a rummage sale with all proceeds going to charity projects organized by CAHR's Taipei Overseas Peace Service (TOPS).
TOPS has been participating in international humanitarian relief and projects related to post-war rebuilding for 27 years, said CAHR President and TOPS Director Lee Yung-ran.
2007 marks the seventh year of World Refugee Day, which was established by the U.N. Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER VISITS WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 18 (CNA) 06/19/07 21:59:40 (By Chiehyu Lin and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng arrived in Washington, D.C. Monday to exchange views with members of the North America Taiwanese Professors' Association on how to build Taiwan's identity through education.
The participating professors urged the Ministry of Education to strengthen cultivation of Taiwanese consciousness among young students and gave many suggestions on how this might be achieved.

Tu pointed out that the preservation and education of mother tongues is a very important link to enhancing identity education, because learning mother tongues will contribute to understanding different cultures. Tu also said the government is working on making language laws that "gives every language equal status."

Hakka and aboriginal languages already have formal learning and preservation measures, Tu said, adding that Taiwanese has not had a preservation mechanism and that more efforts need to be made to protect this language.

Tu also mentioned that identity education has to shed light on the cultivation of an international perspective so that people can acquire a better understanding of Taiwan's status in the international arena.

Tu also attended an international conference in Vancouver June 13, where he met with education officials from British Columbia to discuss cooperation on language teaching. He also went to Chicago June 15 to discuss cooperation projects such as the training of Chinese teachers and establishing Taiwanese studies seminars at local colleges.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Military Strikes Insurgents Base East of Baghdad
The American military began a major attack against Sunni insurgent positions here in the capital of Diyala Province overnight, part of a larger operation aimed at blunting the persistent car and suicide bombings that have terrorized Iraqis and thwarted political reconciliation.
The assault by more than 2,000 American troops is unusual in its scope and ambition, representing a more aggressive strategy of attacking several insurgent strongholds simultaneously to tamp down violence throughout the country.
Wall Street Journal:For UAW Chief, a Bid To Forestall 'Waterloo'
As Detroit's struggling auto giants enter an epic battle with their unionized workers to reduce costs, they contend they either must win a profound restructuring or face catastrophe. Ron Gettelfinger's plan is to allow neither.
The head of the United Auto Workers union is trying to avoid becoming the union leader who ends seven decades of nearly unbroken advances in workers' wages and benefits. He is under unprecedented pressure to give back as much as $10 billion a year to help U.S. car companies stop losing to their lower-cost Asian counterparts -- or see the U.S. companies build more and more of their cars overseas. Former UAW president Doug Fraser calls this "the most difficult time in the history of our union. Period."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA ISSUES 4-POINT RESPONSE TO U.S. OPPOSITION TO U.N. REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The majority of Taiwan people support the government's plan to apply for U.N. membership in the name of Taiwan, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said Tuesday.

Moreover, Wang said, the government's push for a national referendum on the U.N. membership bid does not break President Chen Shui-bian's now-famous "four noes" pledge nor has it anything to do with changing the status quo.

Chen's four noes pledge, made in his 2000 inaugural speech, refers to his promise that so long as China has no intention of using force against Taiwan, he will not declare independence, will not change the national title or flag, will not enshrine a "two states theory" in the Constitution to define cross-Taiwan Strait relations and will not hold an "independence versus unification" referendum to change the cross-strait status quo.
Since Taiwan is a democratic country, Wang went on, the government must respect the grassroots call for joining the U.N. in the name of Taiwan.

Wang made the remarks after an unidentified U.S. State Department Official reiterated Monday that the United States opposes any initiatives that appear to be designed to unilaterally change the Taiwan Strait status quo, which the U.S. believes includes a referendum on whether to apply for U.N. membership as "Taiwan."

Noting that the quest for U.N. representation under the name of Taiwan is backed by the majority, Wang said the government's plan to hold a national referendum on the issue is a response to public expectations.
Stressing that the government attaches great importance to relations with the United States, Wang said MOFA will continue to communicate with the U.S. on the issue.

President Chen formally expressed for the first time during his meeting with Heritage Foundation President Edwin J. Feulner, Jr. in Taipei Monday his wish for holding a referendum on Taiwan's drive to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan alongside the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALA PRESIDENT ARRIVES FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Guatemala President Oscar Berger Perdomo arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a five- day state visit.

Berger's visit symbolizes his firm stance on siding with Taiwan despite another Central American country Costa Rica's switching of diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing earlier this month, diplomatic officials said.
During his June 19-23 visit, Berger will sign three agreements with President Chen Shui-bian to further boost bilateral cooperation in various yields, the officials said.
Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang greeted Berger at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.

In related news, Foreign Ministry officials said Vice President Annette Lu will visit Latin America and the Caribbean early next month in an effort to secure Taiwan's diplomatic ties with its allies in those regions in the wake of the severance of formal relations between Taiwan and Costa Rica -- a development political observers feared might trigger a "domino effect" against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA DAYBOOK FOR JUNE 20, 2007

TEXT.P: 2.
