DOC.HEADLINE: 'RICE BOMBER' TO BE FREED SOON: MOJ

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) is preparing paperwork for a presidential pardon of "rice bomber" Yang Ju-men, Vice Justice Minister Lee Chin-yung said Wednesday.

Lee's remarks came after President Chen shui-bian announced Tuesday that he will grant a special pardon to Yang who is serving time at an open prison in Hualien county in eastern Taiwan for offending the Firearms Control Act.

Noting that the ministry has received the president's instruction to prepare for Yang's release, Lee said the ministry will soon send a proposal of that effect to Chen for formal approval in the coming days.
If all goes well, Lee said Yang can be released by the end of this week. "Yang can leave prison within 24 hours after Chen formally signs the proposal," he added.

Yang was sentenced in 2005 to seven-and-a-half years in prison plus a fine of NT$100,000 (US$3,030.3) for planting 17 explosive devices in public places around Taipei over a one-year period until he turned himself in November 2004.

Identifying himself as an opponent of the government's rice import policy, Yang always sprinkled small amounts of rice in his homemade explosives, which is where Yang's nickname came from. Nobody was injured in his year-long bombing campaign.

During his trial, Yang said he had mounted the bombing campaign to attract the government's attention to the plight of local farmers after the country's accession to the World Trade Organization in 2002.
In January 2006, the Taiwan High Court reduced Yang's sentence to five years and 10 months, saying his motive was not malicious.

While announcing his decision to grant a special pardon to Yang in his speech delivered at a luncheon with members of the Navy's 131 Fleet in Keelung Tuesday to celebrate the Dragon Boat Festival, Chen said Yang deserves compassion and is not expected to break the law again as he has behaved well during his time behind bar.
Yang's pardon marks the second presidential pardon since Chen assumed office in May 2000. He first granted special pardon to 21 special prison inmates in 2000.
Yang first served at a prison in Taipei and was transferred to an open prison in Hualien early this year because of his good behavior. He works on a farm in the Hualien open prison.
According to Hualien prison sources, Yang remained calm after learning of President Chen's decision to grant him special pardon.
A spokesman for a pro-Yang advocacy group said the special pardon is "belated justice."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA ISSUES 4-POINT RESPONSE TO U.S. OPPOSITION TO U.N. REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The majority of Taiwan people support the government's plan to apply for U.N. membership in the name of Taiwan, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said Tuesday.

Moreover, Wang said, the government's push for a national referendum on the U.N. membership bid does not break President Chen Shui-bian's now-famous "four noes" pledge nor has it anything to do with changing the status quo.

Chen's four noes pledge, made in his 2000 inaugural speech, refers to his promise that so long as China has no intention of using force against Taiwan, he will not declare independence, will not change the national title or flag, will not enshrine a "two states theory" in the Constitution to define cross-Taiwan Strait relations and will not hold an "independence versus unification" referendum to change the cross-strait status quo.
Since Taiwan is a democratic country, Wang went on, the government must respect the grassroots call for joining the U.N. in the name of Taiwan.

Wang made the remarks after an unidentified U.S. State Department Official reiterated Monday that the United States opposes any initiatives that appear to be designed to unilaterally change the Taiwan Strait status quo, which the U.S. believes includes a referendum on whether to apply for U.N. membership as "Taiwan."

Noting that the quest for U.N. representation under the name of Taiwan is backed by the majority, Wang said the government's plan to hold a national referendum on the issue is a response to public expectations.
Stressing that the government attaches great importance to relations with the United States, Wang said MOFA will continue to communicate with the U.S. on the issue.

President Chen formally expressed for the first time during his meeting with Heritage Foundation President Edwin J. Feulner, Jr. in Taipei Monday his wish for holding a referendum on Taiwan's drive to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan alongside the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER VISITS WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 18 (CNA) 06/20/07 10:29:44 (By Chiehyu Lin and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng arrived in Washington, D.C. Monday to exchange views with members of the North America Taiwanese Professors' Association on how to build Taiwan's identity through education.
The participating professors urged the Ministry of Education to strengthen cultivation of Taiwanese consciousness among young students and gave many suggestions on how this might be achieved.

Tu pointed out that the preservation and education of mother tongues is a very important link to enhancing identity education, because learning mother tongues will contribute to understanding different cultures. Tu also said the government is working on making language laws that "gives every language equal status."

Hakka and aboriginal languages already have formal learning and preservation measures, Tu said, adding that Taiwanese has not had a preservation mechanism and that more efforts need to be made to protect this language.

Tu also mentioned that identity education has to shed light on the cultivation of an international perspective so that people can acquire a better understanding of Taiwan's status in the international arena.

Tu also attended an international conference in Vancouver June 13, where he met with education officials from British Columbia to discuss cooperation on language teaching. He also went to Chicago June 15 to discuss cooperation projects such as the training of Chinese teachers and establishing Taiwanese studies seminars at local colleges.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALA PRESIDENT ARRIVES FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Guatemala President Oscar Berger Perdomo arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a five- day state visit.

Berger's visit symbolizes his firm stance on siding with Taiwan despite another Central American country Costa Rica's switching of diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing earlier this month, diplomatic officials said.
During his June 19-23 visit, Berger will sign three agreements with President Chen Shui-bian to further boost bilateral cooperation in various yields, the officials said.
Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang greeted Berger at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.

In related news, Foreign Ministry officials said Vice President Annette Lu will visit Latin America and the Caribbean early next month in an effort to secure Taiwan's diplomatic ties with its allies in those regions in the wake of the severance of formal relations between Taiwan and Costa Rica -- a development political observers feared might trigger a "domino effect" against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REITERATES OPPOSITION TO TAIWAN'S PLAN TO HOLD U.N. REFERENDUM
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 19 (CNA) 06/20/07 12:16:19 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A U.S. State Department official reiterated Tuesday Washington's opposition to Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations, warning that such a move would intensify tensions across the Taiwan Strait.

"The United States opposes any initiative that appears designed to change Taiwan's status unilaterally. This would include a referendum on whether to apply to the United Nations under the name of 'Taiwan, '" said State Department Spokesman Sean McCormack when asked to comment on the issue during a daily press briefing. He was repeating a similar statement released by the department a day earlier.
"While such a referendum would have no practical impact on Taiwan's U.N. status, it would increase tensions in the Taiwan Strait," McCormack added.
McCormack stressed in line with its "one China" policy, the United States does not support Taiwan's membership in international organizations that require statehood, including the United Nations.

He urged President Chen Shui-bian to exercise leadership by scrapping the planned referendum, saying the plan would appear to run counter to Chen's repeated commitments to U.S. President George W. Bush and the international community.
"Maintenance of peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait is of vital interest to the people of Taiwan, and serves U.S. security interests as well," he said.

Taiwan, which failed in its first attempt to gain membership to the World Health Organization under the name of "Taiwan" in May, is planning to use a similar model to apply for U.N. membership in September despite the prospect of failure.

On Monday, President Chen unveiled his plan to push for a referendum on the U.N. bid alongside the 2008 presidential election to "make the world aware of Taiwan's 23 million people's desire to join the United Nations."

Calling "Taiwan" the most "appropriate, " "powerful, " and "familiar" name for the country to take part in international organizations, Chen said applying to enter the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan" will not mean any changes of its national title, the Republic of China, or violate its "four noes" commitments to the United States.

Chen pledged during his 2000 and 2004 inaugural addresses that if China has no intention of using force against Taiwan, he will not declare Taiwan independence, not change the official name of the country, not include the "state-to-state" concept on cross-strait relations in the Constitution, and not promote a referendum to change the cross-strait status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 20, or the sixth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1863: West Virginia becomes the 35th state of the United States.
1887: The longest railway bridge in Britain and the second over the River Tay in Scotland is opened.
1895: The Japanese government in Taiwan founds the "Taiwan Hospital" in Taipei, which later became the National Taiwan University Hospital.
1902: Prior to the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War in 1904, the Japanese supreme wartime office establishes the "General Headquarters of Military Service in Manchuria" and appoints Gon Oyama, former joint chief of staff, as its commander-in-chief.
1909: Errol Flynn, the American actor who specialized in swashbuckling and war hero roles, is born in Tasmania. He appeared in such films as "The Adventures of Robin Hood," "Captain Blood," and "The Sea Hawk."
1940: At the request of Japan, France closes the railway between Yunnan Province and Vietnam, cutting transportation links between Vietnam and China.
1960: American Floyd Patterson knocks out Sweden's Ingmar Johansson to become the first boxer to regain the world heavyweight title.
1960: Mali gains independence from France.
1963: The United States and Russia agree to establish a hotline telephone link.
1964: A China Air Transport (CAT) passenger plane crashes near Fengyuan in Central Taiwan on its way from Makung to Taipei, killing more than 50 aboard, including movie industry tycoon Loh Yun-tao, who is visiting Taiwan to attend the 11th Asian Film Festival.
1967: Muhammad Ali, originally Cassius Marcellus Clay, the American boxer who won the world heavyweight title in 1964, is sentenced to five years in prison and fined US$10,000 for refusing to be conscripted into the armed forces.
1974: Dr. Amade M. Yuzon, president of the United Poets Laureate International, arrives in Taipei to attend a meeting celebrating Chinese Poets' Day.
1976: A six-man delegation led by artist-poet Wang Lan leaves for Seoul to attend the Asian Artist Conference and a plenary meeting of the Asian Arts Center.
1978: The Republic of China is listed the 25th-largest trading country in the world by the International Monetary Fund.
1979: American TV reporter Bill Stewart is gunned down by Nicaraguan National Guardsmen as he walks toward a roadblock with a white flag in one hand and his official yellow press card in the other.
1982: The Directorate General of Telecommunications (DGT) opens the first public data switching service in the Republic of China.
1984: Some 70 miners are killed in the Haishan coal mine disaster in northern Taiwan.
1990: South Africa's Nelson Mandela gets a ticker-tape welcome in New York.
1992: Czech and Slovak leaders decide to split Czechoslovakia into two nations, one for Czechs and one for Slovaks. The Czech Republic and Slovakia formally came into existence on Jan. 1, 1993.
1997: Russia pledges to stop targeting Japan with nuclear missiles.
1999: Boris Yeltsin presents U.S. President Bill Clinton with recently declassified Russian reports relating to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
2000: Hans Muench, a German doctor in the Nazis' Auschwitz death camp is given immunity from trial at a French court because of his senility.
2001: The 46th World Conference of the International Council for Small Businesses (ICSB) concludes in Taipei after some 500 participants from 55 countries spent three days to discuss how to cope with the challenges posed by the new era.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Of all people in the world, young women and servants are the most difficult to keep in the house. If you are familiar with them, they forget their position, but if you keep them at a distance, they are discontented."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
WORKS TO EXPORT TAINAN-GROWN MANGOES TO JAPAN ACTIVATED

TEXT.P: Works to export mangoes produced in the southern county of Tainan have been activated recently since Japan, a major Taiwanese mango importer, gradually removed import restrictions on Taiwan's Irwin mangoes in recent months.

The Tainan County government expected an increase in Irwin mango exports to Japan this year, with the price to move up, too, Wu Wei-ta, chief of the marketing for the county's Bureau of Agriculture, said Wednesday.
Japan gave an order in 2006 to detain Taiwan mango exports at customs for inspection after pesticide residue was found on the fresh fruit. Following that, the numbers of shipments fell significantly.

Since then, the county government has built a tracking system for local mango production and has tightened quality control and certification operations in hopes of ensuring the quality and safety of the county's mango products, Wu said. In doing so, local farmers and traders have won back Japan's trust in buying Tainan County mangoes, Wu said.
It is estimated that the county may be allowed to export around 1,500 tons of mangoes to Japan this year, with a price better than the NT$70 (US$2) per kilogram posted last year, Wu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS CRITICIZE U.S. FOR OPPOSING PLAN TO HOLD U.N. REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday criticized the United States for being "overbearing" in its opposition to Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations.

They made the remarks one day after a U.S. State Department official said that "the United States opposes any initiative that appears designed to change Taiwan's status unilaterally. This would include a referendum on whether to apply to the United Nations under the name of 'Taiwan.'"
Wang Tuoh, a major DPP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, said that Taiwan has followed democratic procedures to plan the referendum for the people to express their views.
"The United States has no reason to object to it," Wang said, criticizing the United States for being "overbearing.'
Noting that U.S. spokesman Sean McCormack said that such a referendum "would increase tensions in the Taiwan Strait," Wang said that cross-strait tensions have existed for a long time.

"China has deployed around one thousand missiles against Taiwan," Wang said, asking if this is not creating cross-strait tensions. "The United States is silent on the deployment, but is stern toward Taiwan," he said.

DPP Legislator Wang Shu-huei also said that "the United States cannot force Taiwan to deny its sovereignty. Whether the United States supports it or not, the DPP caucus will support a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations in the name of Taiwan." (By Lilian Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI PUBLICITY OFFICER LEAVES FOR BEIJING TO PROMOTE TAIWAN TOURISM

TEXT.P: Taipei city government's top publicity official, Yang Hsiao-tung, left for Beijing Wednesday mainly to promote Taiwan tourism at the 2007 Beijing International Tourism Expo slated for June 21-23.
Yang is expected to officiate at the opening of the Taiwan Pavilion at the expo, which will be showcasing tourism attractions in Taiwan.
Yang is the first Taipei city official to visit Beijing since Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin assumed office early this year.

In a brief interview with CNA at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport before his departure, Yang said he will join other private operators to promote Taiwan's tourism attractions, including travel to hotspring resorts, at the expo and will promote "city exchanges" between Taipei and Beijing, and other Chinese cities and countries from around the world.

Yang, who also serves as a spokesman for Taipei City Hall, said the Taiwan Pavilion will be positioned independently at the expo -- not in the domestic area nor in the international area -- to avoid Taiwan from being "dwarfed."
The 2007 Beijing International Tourism Expo is expected to attract exhibitors from over 80 countries and areas around the world to show off their tourism specialties.
At the Taiwan Pavilion, according to Yang, Taiwan's signature sweet -- tapioca or "pearl tea" -- will be offered free of charge during the three-day run, as well as instant "fun photo" stickers.

Yang, meanwhile, declined to confirm speculation that he will meet officials from Beijing's National Tourism Administration for talks on a wide range of topics, including Taipei's continuing efforts to have the 2008 Olympic torch come to Taiwan.

Officials from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council have said recently that Taiwan is willing to re-negotiate the torch relay route with China so long as Taiwan's national status is not downgraded.

According to China's plan when it announced the torch relay route April 26, the Olympic torch would travel from Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City to Taipei and then continue on to Hong Kong, Macau and several other Chinese cities before arriving in the host city, Beijing.

Taiwan rejected the route planning at that time, saying it deliberately downgrades Taiwan's sovereign status. Taiwan wants the torch to come to Taipei via a third country and travel on to another country before arriving in China.

Yang is also scheduled to travel to Shanghai after the Beijing tourism expo to meet officials and leaders from the private sector there for talks on city and cultural exchanges between Taipei and Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN WELCOMES GUATEMALAN COUNTERPART FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over a ceremony at the Presidential Office Wednesday to welcome the arrival of Guatemala President Oscar Berger Perdomo, who was accorded full military honors complete with a 21-gun salute.

Addressing the red-carpet welcome ceremony for Berger, Chen described the visit by Berger and his wife as that of old friends paying a visit to one's home in a stormy weather -- and that Guatemala is demonstrating true friendship towards Taiwan at a time when Taiwan is facing a grim and grave situation in the international community.

Berger's visit is symbolic of his resolution to stand with Taiwan despite another Central American country, Costa Rica, switching diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing earlier this month, Chen said during the welcoming ceremony.
The Guatemalan president and first lady arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a five-day state visit at the invitation of Chen.

President Chen will accompany Berger and his wife on a ride aboard a Taiwan High-Speed Rail train Thursday to the southern port city of Kaohsiung, the first time that Chen will travel aboard the high-speed train with one of his foreign counterparts.
Chen will play host to a state banquet in honor of Berger and his entourage in Kaohsiung Thursday, which will also be the Bergers' 40th wedding anniversary.
During his visit, Berger is expected to sign three agreements with Chen to boost further bilateral cooperation in various fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PROPOSES HOLDING EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION JULY 9

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) proposed Wednesday that a special legislative session be held July 9 to review a controversial bill concerning the organization of the Central Election Commission (CEC).
Hsu Shao-ping, the KMT's legislative caucus whip, insisted that the Legislative Yuan must deal with the CEC bill "now that the central government's 2007 budget bill has been passed."
Hsu said the KMT will leave the door open for negotiations with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on the bill before its passage.
Responding to the proposal, DPP legislative caucus convener Ker Chien-ming said the date of the special session will be decided upon through inter-party consultations.
As to the agenda of the extra session, Ker said the DPP will not accept any bills that violate the Constitution or any conditions attached to the passage of the government's budget bills.
Both the DPP and KMT favor holding an extra session, but differ on its agenda.

Unlike the KMT, which aims to pass the CEC bill, the DPP expects the legislature to pass a list of budget bills, including one concerning the operations of state-owned enterprises and another one addressing a series of major development projects.

Owing to strong opposition from the DPP, the KMT-led "pan-blue alliance" -- which controls a slim majority in the legislature -- failed in its bid to steamroll the CEC bill through the legislature during the legislative session that ended last week and the previous session ended in January, despite the alliance's strategy of holding the CEC bill hostage along with the 2007 budget bill.

The 2007 budget bill only passed the legislature on the final day of the last session after the "pan-blue alliance" finally agreed to pass it in view of growing public displeasure with their legislative tactics.

The KMT has insisted that the 17 members of the CEC be recommended by political parties in proportion to the number of seats they each hold in the legislature, with no single party allowed to control more than two-fifths of the total seats.
However, the DPP opposes any party-based proportional principle for the CEC's formation on the ground that such a practice violates the "division of power" provision set forth in the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE ENDORSES GOV'T EFFORTS TO JOIN WORLD BODIES

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, the presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , Wednesday gave his backing to the government's efforts to join world bodies, but called on the government to employ feasible means to achieve that aim.

Ma made the comments while answering questions from reporters on the issue after President Chen Shui-bian Monday proposed holding a referendum on the country's bid to enter the United Nations as "Taiwan" along with the 2008 presidential election.

Stressing that the KMT supports all possible means that the government might pursue to help the country play a role in international organizations, including the United Nations, Ma said that it is critical to apply the most feasible and least risky means based on the "Taiwan-centric" notion so as to safeguard the nation's dignity.
Ma argued that "any precipitous moves will damage Taiwan" and "the government must never use public referendums as a tool to score political points."

Commenting on the question of which designation the country should adopt to enter world bodies or take part in international activities, Ma urged the government to be flexible in this regard to help create greater room for it to play a role on the world stage.
Chen's referendum plan has met with objections from the United States, which called on Chen to show leadership by dropping the idea so as not to fuel cross- Taiwan Strait tensions.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW VACCINE AGAINST ACUTE FEVER IN CATTLE PUBLICIZED

TEXT.P: A yearly vaccination may decrease the risk to cattle of contracting bovine ephemeral fever (BEF), a viral cattle disease characterized by a short-term, acute fever, which leads to its being named the "three day sickness, " according to researchers of Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University (NCKU).

NCKU President Lai Ming-chao, National Science Council Vice Chairman Tai Chien, and Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih jointly hosted a press conference Wednesday to announce the release of a new vaccine against mutant BEF virus, developed by NCKU with the Tainan county government cooperation.

BEF was first reported in South Africa in 1906. Taiwan was unaffected by outbreaks of the acute fever in cattle until 1967. However, since then there have been five major outbreaks, in 1967, 1983-1984, 1989-1990, 1996, and 1999, with an average mortality rate of 5 percent.

This viral disease usually spreads in summer and early autumn, with young cows aged between six months and 2 years old most easily affected. Flying insect vectors, including mosquitoes, are responsible for the BEF transmission.
Infected cattle develop symptoms including fever and dyspnea, while dairy cows suffer a drop in production of approximately 50 percent.

Taiwan began performing BEF vaccination in 1985, with each animal being given two or three doses of vaccine each year. However, given viral mutations the traditional vaccine is no longer effective in guarding against outbreaks, NCKU researchers said.

Noting that the new vaccine was developed to protect against the mutant BEF virus in Taiwan, Tai revealed that if a similar virus was to appear in China, Taiwan would be delighted to assist the relevant Chinese authorities in combating an outbreak.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO IMPORT CRUDE FROM RUSSIA: ECONOMIST
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, June 20 (CNA) 06/20/07 16:48:31 (By Vlogya Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan would like to import crude oil from Russia to help diversify the country's sources of oil imports, a visiting Taiwan economist said in Moscow Wednesday.

Wu Rong-i, chairman of the Taiwan Futures Exchange and head of the private Taiwan-Russia Association, said in an interview with a Moscow media outlet that 99.8 percent of the crude oil consumed in Taiwan is imported, thus securing stable oil supplies is a top concern of the country.
Taiwan hopes that it can import crude oil from Russia so as to lower reliance on imports from the Middle East, an area rife with social instability and military disturbances, Wu added.

Importing crude oil from Russia, however, is not an easy task for Taiwan, Wu said, adding that in the past, some importers have faced variable quality in the shipments, and recently experienced complications in securing supplies, including difficulties involving transporting crude oil from the Ural Mountains area and Russian Far East.
Wu urged the Russian government to seriously consider cooperating with Taiwan over these issues to benefit both sides.

Meanwhile, Wu, a former vice premier of Taiwan, said that Taiwan sits in a strategically important location in terms of regional security and crude oil imports, pointing out that all oil tankers transporting imported crude oil for Japan and South Korea pass through the Taiwan Strait.

Against this backdrop, he said, Beijing's constant threats to use force against Taiwan to solve cross-strait differences could also be threats to security and stability of other countries in East Asia and the Asia-Pacific area as well.
Wu continued that since Russia has maintained close connections with China, Moscow could play an important role in influencing the development of cross- Taiwan Strait relations.

Wu and a Taiwanese delegation arrived in Moscow last week on a business trip. Over the past several days, they have participated in a Taiwan-Russia cooperation forum and have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) and an agreement with public and private Russian organizations to bolster bilateral exchanges between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.161 to close at NT$32.981.
A total of US$1.356 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened lower at NT$33.045 and fluctuated between NT$32.981 and NT$33.150.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI RELEASES '3D MOUSE' FOR COMPUTER GAMERS

TEXT.P: A unit under the Hsinchu-based Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) has developed a new "3D mouse" for computer games, with the aim of increasing the entertainment value of games by offering omni-directional, full-movement control over virtual characters, ITRI researchers reported Wednesday.

ITRI's Microsystems Technology Center (MTC) -- located outside the institute's main base in Southern Taiwan Science Park in Tainan County -- has been pursuing research and development of the mouse for about one year, and recently achieved satisfactory results, they said, adding that the institute is now working on transferring the related technologies to a local computer accessory manufacturer.

The 3D mouse has been developed based on micro-inertial sensing technology, human movement calculation and simulation mechanisms to bring three-dimensional sensing capabilities to the conventional mouse, MTC Associate Research Fellow Lu Ying-ke explained.
The mouse, Lu said, can detect user's body movements and transmit the signals back to the computer via wireless communications to command the virtual character to act according to user movements.

The video game console-like mouse can then be used as a bat in baseball games, a racket in tennis or badminton games, or even a handgun in shooting games to create a "more-than-real" gaming experience, said Lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP VOWS TO CONTINUE TO PUSH FOR U.N. REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will continue to push for a referendum on Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and disregard opposition from the U.S. government, party chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday.

Noting that 80 percent of the people in Taiwan support the country's plan to apply for U.N. membership under the name of "Taiwan, " Yu said holding a referendum on the issue will make the voices of the Taiwanese people heard by the world.
Yu said he believes the United States, as a democratic country, will not obstruct the Taiwanese people from practising democracy.

"No matter what the U.S. State Department says about the matter, I believe the American people will definitely support the implementation of democracy in Taiwan and the Taiwanese people's move to demonstrate their desire to enter the United Nations through a referendum," he said.
Yu said the DPP has completed the first phase of signature drive for an initiative to hold the referendum and that the Central Election Commission is expected to review the initiative Friday.
On Monday, President Chen Shui-bian expressed hope that the referendum might be held alongside the 2008 presidential election.

However, U.S. State Department Spokesman Sean McCormack reiterated Tuesday that the United States opposes any initiative that appears designed to unilaterally change Taiwan's status, including a referendum on whether to apply to the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: RUNNING RED LIGHT TOPS TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Running a red light was the most frequently committed traffic violation in the southern port city of Kaohsiung during the January-May period of 2007, according to statistics released Wednesday by the city Bureau of Transportation.

Illegal parking was the second most often recorded traffic violation in the country second largest city, followed by speeding. There were 482,000 traffic violation cases reported by police in the five-month period, tallies show.

It is the first time that the red-light running has been recorded as most frequent traffic violation in Kaohsiung during the past three years. Illegal parking and speeding were the most frequent violations in 2005 and 2006, city officials said. They urged drivers and motorbike riders to exercise self- restraint while on the roads.

Under the Statute for Road Traffic Management and Punishment, a motorcycle rider caught running a red light faces a fine of NT$1,800 (US$54) ; the fine rises to NT$2,700 for motor vehicle drivers. Those who do not pay the fines as scheduled face a fine double the original amount.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S U.N. BID NEEDS CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS: KMT

TEXT.P: Amendments to the Constitution or a new constitution altogether would be needed to allow President Chen Shui-bian's bid to purse U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers said Wednesday.

Hsu Shao-ping, a KMT legislative caucus whip, made the comments at a Legislative Yuan news conference after Chen called Monday for a U.N. bid referendum to be held alongside the 2008 presidential election.

Questioning how the country could enter the United Nations as "Taiwan" as the country's official designation is Republic of China, Hsu said that Chen' s bid to pursue U.N. membership would need constitutional amendments or a new constitution written for a country named Taiwan.
KMT Legislator John Chiang attacked Chen's referendum proposal as a meaningless "fake issue," because whatever the outcome, it would have no leverage on gaining U.N. membership for the country.

Chiang predicted that the United States will step up its pressure on Chen if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party insists on holding the referendum, as Washington has expressed its opposition to the issue.

U.S. State Department Spokesman Sean McCormack told a Tuesday news briefing that Washington objects to any move designed to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, which includes holding a public referendum on Taiwan's U.N. bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Offensive Targets Al-Qaeda In Iraq; Blast Near Mosque Kills 60 in Baghdad.
BAGHDAD, June 19 -- Thousands of U.S. troops waged a new offensive against al- Qaeda in Iraq north of the capital Tuesday, focusing in particular on the extremist group's bombmaking facilities, while at least 60 people were killed and more than 85 wounded in a massive suicide truck blast at a Baghdad mosque, U.S. and Iraqi officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM LAST MEANS TO SAFEGUARD DEMOCRACY: CABINET SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan will be the last means to safeguard its democracy and human rights, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Wednesday.

"Taiwan people will not give it up, nor will they allow President Chen Shui-bian to give it up," Shieh said, referring to the president's announcement Monday that he hopes to hold such a referendum alongside the presidential election next year.
"Chen is not an authoritarian president, and he can't give up when another country asks Taiwan to do things that run counter to democracy and human rights," he added.

Shieh made the remarks one day after a U.S. State Department official said that "the United States opposes any initiative that appears designed to change Taiwan's status unilaterally. This would include a referendum on whether to apply to the United Nations under the name of 'Taiwan.'"

He said that Taiwan has wanted to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization in the name of Taiwan based on the idea that Taiwan has lifted its martial rule for 20 years and that the people will play a decisive role in determining its status and future.

He noted that the desire of Taiwan people to join the international community accords with human rights and democratic principles, and that no country that champions human rights or democracy "should say no to Taiwan, or intimidate Taiwan."

As the president represents the people, and a referendum will highlight democracy and human rights, the president cannot but hold such a referendum to solicit the maneuvering space for the nation, he said.
"Taiwan's stance is legitimate in every way," he added.

He noted that since Taiwan withdrew from the United Nations in 1971, its diplomatic allies have been repeatedly lured away by China, and its bid to join international organizations has suffered repeated setback due to China's obstruction.

"That there have been changes in the status quo is no mistake, and one must see what is being changed," he noted, saying that Taiwan has changed to safeguard democracy and human rights, while China moves to mount an ever greater military threat focused on Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD VISION PROMOTES `30 HOUR FAST' CAMPAIGN IN CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The central regional office of World Vision Taiwan urged the public Wednesday to support the charity's annual "30 Hour Fast" campaign to help hunger-stricken people trying to survive in every corner of the world.

Hu Wan-wen, head of the office, urged people to take part in the "30 Hour Fast" drives that are set to be launched around the country Wednesday -- World Refugee Day -- to help raise money for the world's refugees and raise awareness of helping people.
Hu said that of the 20 million-odd refugees worldwide, 9 million are children, adding that all adults in the world should be concerned about efforts to safeguard these children's basic human rights.
She added that despite World Vision Taiwan's strenuous efforts to send aid to young refugees, there are still many who have yet to receive help.

DOC.HEADLINE: TKU ROBOTS WIN 2007 ROBO GAMES CHAMPIONSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 18 (CNA) 06/20/07 18:48:17 (By Josie Chou and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Robots designed by students of Tamkang University (TKU)'s Electoral Engineering Department, won the championship at this year's international Robo Games, or ROBOlympics, held in San Francisco June 14-17, taking two gold medals.
TKU's robots won a gold medal by gaining four first place prizes in categories including an obstacle run, penalty kick, dash, and weight lifting in the "Humanoid Challenges" competition.
TKU won another gold medal in the "RoboSot" competition in which three TKU's robots competed as team against teams from China and South Korea.

Wung Ching-chang, chairman of TKU's Electoral Engineering Department, said the victory was the result of teamwork among 17 students participating in the Robo Games in San Francisco and another 17 who remained in Taiwan to provide technical aid. Wung added that "robotic designs emerged from collective creativity and technological integration."
In addition to NKU's awards, Chang Gung University won a silver medal in the basketball competition, while National Cheng Kung University took bronze in the penalty kick.

TKU's robotic design team began participating in international robot competitions in 2003. This year's team leader Yang Yu-ting, a graduate student and the only woman on the team, said designing robots fills her with a sense of fulfillment. Yang added that exchanges with other teams that join such competitions is precious.

David Calkins, the president of the Robotics Society of America and lecturer in robotics and computer engineering at San Francisco State University, said international robotic games encourage scientific education and allows participants to share their passion and knowledge with others.

This year's Robo Games was the largest open game in the event's history, with nearly 800 robots from more than 30 countries assembled to do battle, demonstrating the youngsters' creativity and entertaining the audience of all ages.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Britain puts player in role of sadistic killer
A video game that puts players in control of a psychopath who must sneak up on people and bludgeon them to death with axes and sledgehammers has been banned in Britain. Manhunt 2 has become the only prohibited game in the country after the British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) condemned its unremitting bleakness and encouragement of casual sadism.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIENNIAL CHILDREN'S FILM FESTIVAL PROMOTED

TEXT.P: A biennial international children's television and film festival that will be held next April officially launched its promotion drive and began receiving film submissions from all over the world, festival organizers said Wednesday at a press conference.

The third Taiwan International Children's TV & Film Festival will be held April 4-8, 2008 in Taipei, said Hu Yuan-huei, president of Public Television Service (PTS) , the main organizer. Submissions will be accepted until Oct. 31.

So far, Hu said, there have been submissions from Taiwan, India, Sweden, Germany, France, the U.S. and the Philippines vying for six awards -- best dramatic feature, best animation, best documentary, best TV program, Taiwan award and special jury prize.
This event has been trying to find a balance between "adults' perspective and children's height, " said Wang Gun-yu, curator of the festival.
The festival was previously held in 2004 and 2006 and received more than 230 entries each time, Hu said, adding that the organizers expect a record-breaking number of entries for the next one.
The five-day event features screenings, side events and exhibitions, and "Kids as Directors" workshops for teachers and students to learn about filmmaking, in addition to awards with cash prizes.

Ma Chih-hsiang, a young actor making his first attempt at filmmaking, became the first local entry in the category of best dramatic feature with a film titled "Wish of the 10-year-old Dina, " the story of a young Bunun girl in Hualien.
"I tried to reveal the social status and problems of the indigenous people, and at the same time reverse local people's bias against indigenous people, " said Ma, who is also an aborigine.

PTS also announced 10 nominees for the "Kids as Directors" workshop in the press conference. The nominees were selected out of more than 40 project entries, said Lin Leh-chyun, director of the PTS International Department.
All the winning projects will be assisted with production resources from PTS when the filmmaking begins and will be screened during the festival, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRISTIAN CHARITY URGES PUBLIC TO SHOW CARE FOR CHILDREN REFUGEES

TEXT.P: The World Vision Taiwan (WVT), a Christian charity, urged all of Taiwan's people Wednesday to demonstrate their care for child refugees around the world, according to a charity executive.
The Christian group made the call to mark the June 20 U.N. World Refugee Day, a WVT executive said.

Currently, there are a total of 20.8 million refugees in the world, 9 million of whom are children, the executive said, adding that most of the refugee children are at risk of violence, kidnapping or cruel physical abuse.
The charity, the executive said, is slated to organize a "30-hour fast" later this year to raise funds for children refugees in war-torn countries in Africa.
It is hoped that at least 100,000 people will take part in the annual event so that the target of NT$150 million (US$4.53 million) can be collected.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET SETS JULY 15 TO MARK LIFTING OF MARTIAL LAW

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has designated July 15 as the day to mark the lifting of martial law in Taiwan, Cabinet spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Wednesday.

Shieh said this year marks the 20th anniversary of the ending of martial law and that the government has planned a series of activities, including concerts of songs that were forbidden during the martial law era, exhibitions and the issuance of memorial postage stamps.

"Designating July 15 as a memorial day and the 60th anniversary activities of the 228 Incident are an integral part of memorial activities in the hope of understanding Taiwan's historic truth, " he said.

The 228 Incident refers to a Feb. 28, 1947 uprising against the corrupt Kuomintang (KMT) government of the time. Rooted in this incident, the ensuing "White Terror" period describes the brutal suppression of political dissents and public discussion of the incident under martial law that lasted from May 19, 1949 to July 15, 1987.
"Almost every family in Taiwan was directly or indirectly affected by martial law," Shieh said.
But 20 years after martial law, Taiwan now enjoys a democratic system and human rights values that it can be proud of, he continued.

Asked if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) had the coming elections in mind when it designated a day to mark the end of martial law seven years into its rule, Shieh claimed that "the two things are irrelevant."
"The government is worried that history will be left behind, truth will be forgotten and reconciliation will be hard to achieve," Shieh said.

He questioned why the KMT did not stage any memorial activities during the 13 years between 1987 and 2000 when it was swept from power by the DPP. To this day, the KMT is still trying to evade its responsibility for the harm and suffering it brought to the people of Taiwan during the 38 years of martial law, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INBOUND INVESTMENT TOTAL US$3.48 BILLION IN FIRST FIVE MONTHS

TEXT.P: There were 830 overseas and foreign investment projects worth a total of US$3.48 billion approved between January and May this year, down 47.57 percent year-on- year, the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Wednesday.

Commission officials said the inbound investment decrease was mainly because electronics giant Philips lowered its holdings in the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. last year. If that factor is not counted in, inbound investment in the first five months increased by 20.23 percent when compared with the same period of last year.
Meanwhile, there were 217 applications for outbound investment outside China worth a total of US$1.26 billion in the first five months of this year, down 10.97 percent year-on-year.
The commission approved 420 projects worth a total of US$3.16 billion for investment in China during the first five months, up 8.02 percent from the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER ATTENDS MEMORIAL SERVICE FOR LATE JAPANESE LAWMAKER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 20 (CNA) 06/20/07 20:26:57 (By Mike Chang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, a former Taiwan premier who is now the candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for the 2008 presidential election, attended a memorial service for the late Japanese lawmaker Motoo Shiina Wednesday on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
Shiina, a member of Japan's House of Councilors and a leading player in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party in promoting U.S.-Japan relations, died March 16 at the age of 73.
The memorial service was attended by nearly 500 people, including guests from South Korea, the United States, Britain and Taiwan.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jyn-pyng, National Security Council Secretary- General Tan Sun Chen, Chairman of the East Asia Relations Association Lo Fu- cheng, as well as Taiwan's Representative to Japan Koh Se-kai, and Peng Ren-tzu, president of the Taiwan Transportation Machinery Corp., also attended the service.

Hsieh gave a speech on behalf of Chen to express condolences over Shiina's death and praised his contributions to mitigating the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis and promoting Japan's friendliness toward Taiwan. He added that continuous development of bilateral relations is the best way to remember Shiina.

Koh read a eulogy written by Chen and noted that Shiina was awarded the Order of Brilliant Star with Violet Grand Gordon by Chen in 2003 for his efforts in promoting a U.S.-Japanese defense alliance to help form a solid foundation for peace in the Asia-Pacific region.
Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Foreign Minister Taro Aso both also gave speeches in praise of Shiina's contribution to regional peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Truck Bomb Hits Baghdad Mosque, and 61 Are Killed
A suicide bomber barreled a truck filled with cooking gas and explosives into a square bordered by a large Shiite mosque in the heart of Baghdad on Tuesday, just as worshipers were finishing midday prayers. The Interior Ministry said at least 61 people were killed and 130 wounded.
The attack took place as American forces continued a large-scale assault on strongholds of Al Qaeda outside the capital where, they say, many of the vehicle bombs are manufactured. The timing seemed intended to demonstrate that the insurgents could still strike with near impunity, blindsiding the American security crackdown in Baghdad.
Wall Street Journal:Toyota's New U.S. Plan: Stop Building Factories
Five years ago, Toyota Motor Corp. launched a factory-building blitz in the U.S. that helped make it the world's largest auto maker. Now the architect of that push and a senior member of the company's founding family are both urging a new strategy for the U.S. -- hit the brakes.
Top Toyota executives are concerned that the car maker may have built too many U.S. factories, in part to build political support by providing new jobs in lots of places. And although Toyota's U.S. sales continue to grow, these executives worry about an uncertain outlook.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO INVESTIGATE TOXIC TOYS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Consumers Protection Commission (CPC) should investigate whether Chinese-made "Thomas and Friends Wooden Railway" toys pose a threat to local children's health, a lawmaker said Wednesday.

Legislator Lin Chih-chia of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) made the appeal at a press conference after 1.5 million of the toys were recalled in the United States due to concern that the paint on the toys contains lead, which is hazardous to the health.
Lin said the toy trains are available at local supermarkets and department stores, and called on the CPC to investigate.
TSU spokeswoman Chou Mei-li, who was also present at the press conference, said harmful products made in China are sold all over the world and that Taiwan is no exception.

Noting that Taiwan reported cases of Chinese towels containing cancer-causing substances and Chinese medicines containing heavy metals, Chou said the commission should fulfill its duty to safeguard the health of Taiwanese consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTORS GIVEN ACCESS TO SECURITIES FINANCE COMPANIES

TEXT.P: The government has opened local securities finance companies to foreign investors as another source of stock loans in an effort to further liberalize and internationalize Taiwan's stock market trading, an official of the Securities and Futures Bureau said Wednesday.

The bureau, under the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission, announced before Tuesday's Dragon Boat Festival that overseas Taiwanese and foreigners are allowed to borrow stocks from securities finance companies to invest in Taiwan's stock market.
Ahead of the announcement, foreign investors could borrow stocks from the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp. (TSEC) or securities brokers to short sell.
The new measure will provide more flexibility for foreign investors to trade in the stock market, said Chen Wei-lung, the bureau's deputy director-general.
Currently, there are four securities finance firms in Taiwan -- Fuhwa Securities Finance Co., Fubon Securities Finance Co., EnTie Securities Finance Co. and Global Securities Finance Corp.
In addition, the bureau has raised the maximum limit on the total amount of finance or stock loan for individual clients, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA DAY TO BE CELEBRATED IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The Canadian Trade Office in Taipei (CTOT) will host a series of events in Kaohsiung for the first time to celebrate Canada's 140th birthday, a Canadian official said Wednesday.

Ron MacIntosh, Executive Director of CTOT, said the Canada Day celebration will be a great opportunity for Taiwanese living in southern Taiwan to enjoy a taste of Canada's excellence and creativity in education, food, drink and culture and to experience Canada's dynamic spirit.

CTOT has been hosted the celebration in different cities in Taiwan each year to celebrate Canada Day, which falls on July 1. From 2004 to 2006, the celebration has been held in Tainan, Taichung and Taipei, respectively.
The celebration will begin June 26 at the Kaohsiung Film Archive, where the CTOT will host the First Canadian Animation Festival in Kaohsiung until July 12.

To further promote the animation industry in southern Taiwan, the office is working with the Kaohsiung Film Archive to organize a half-day animation seminar to connect Canada's experience with Kaohsiung's animators. The seminar will feature the presence of David Baas, a Canadian animation director who won an Oscar in 2006 for his excellence in animation, and Alex Liao, a digital artist of well-known animation software company Softimage.

From June 20 until the end of July, a Kaohsiung restaurant will offer Canadian seafood. As Kaohsiung is also home to thousands of young Canadians, the office will hold a "Canadian-style party" at a Canadian-run local pub June 27.

The last and the biggest event of the celebration will be a "Canada Village" to be held in front of the Film Archive June 30, offering Canadian food and drink, building products, education counseling and tourism information.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIORITIES SHOULD BE LISTED ON TAIWAN'S U.N. BID: KMT CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Taiwan should try to set priorities in efforts to seek Taiwan's return to the United Nations after the United States expressed opposition to President Chen Shui-bian's intention to push for a referendum on its U.N. bid under the name of Taiwan, the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) presidential candidate suggested Wednesday.

In response to media inquiries, Ma Ying-jeou, a former KMT chairman, said he believes the reason Washington opposed Taiwan's referendum plan is that it understands the plan being formed to be not purely for the goal of returning to the U.N. but for a "certain political purpose."

The KMT raised the bid for resumption of Taiwan's membership in the U.N. every year when it ran the country until 2000. In those days, the U.S. government never voiced opinions against the bid, Ma said.
The Republic of China was a founding member of the U.N. before it walked out of the organization in 1971 after its rival, the People's Republic of China, succeed in gaining admission to the U.N.

Ma said it will be difficult to get Taiwan back into the United Nations and pointed out that the task involves not just the matter of Taiwan's designation. Taiwan needs to figure out why it can join the World Trade Organization but not the U.N., and why it can attend the Olympic Games but is not allowed to enter some other international organizations such as the WHO, he said, suggesting that Taiwan learn from its setbacks.
Taiwan needs to work out practical and possible strategies in bids for its space in the international community, Ma added, citing the recent setback in seeking the WHO membership

Member states of the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the WHO's decision-making arm -- rejected a proposal on Taiwan's membership application by a vote of 148-17 in mid-May. It was the first time Taiwan had sought full WHO membership, instead of WHA observer status, in the name of Taiwan.

Over the years, Ma claimed, many influential WHA member states like Japan, the U.S. and some European countries appeared to prefer Taiwan to seek observer status in the WHA before seeking full membership. These countries all opposed Taiwan's membership bid this year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPANISH TOURISM DELEGATION ARRIVES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Spanish delegation has arrived in Taipei to promote Spain's tourism industry, Spanish Chamber of Commerce in Taiwan Director Jose Luis Lamas announced Wednesday.
According to Lamas, the delegation was organized by Spain's Institute of Tourism under the Ministry of Industry, Tourism and Commerce. Its other stops in Asia included Seoul and Tokyo.
Quoting statistics complied by the institute, Lamas said Spain gets over 48 million visitors every year, higher than its population of about 40 million.
More than 58.5 million people visited Spain in 2006, up 4.5 percent over 2005, Lamas said, adding that Spain is the second-largest tourist destination in terms of visitor numbers and income revenues.
The statistics also show that about 12,000 Taiwanese visitors travel to Spain directly every year, and another 25,000 local people go there from other European countries.
Lamas said Spain attracts visitors with its beautiful scenery, cuisine and avant-garde architecture, as well as its natural and cultural heritage sites included on the U.N.'s World Heritage list.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL EDITION EASYCARDS OF TAIWANESE MLB PITCHERS TO BE ISSUED

TEXT.P: The Taipei Smart Card Corp. (TSCC) is slated to issue two special sets of Easycards featuring two Taiwan-born pitchers in the U.S. Major League Baseball (MLB) -- New York Yankees Chien-ming Wang and Los Angeles Dodgers Kuo Hong-chih -- by the end of August to commemorate the duo's career achievements during the ongoing MLB season, TSCC General Manager Lin Chih-ying said Wednesday.
Lin said the most difficult part of the publishing process was to gather continuous images of a home run hit by Kuo.
In addition to Wang and Kuo, the TSCC has also signed an Easycard agreement with another Taiwanese pitcher, Tsao Chin-hui, who also plays in the MLB.

Lin added that the TSCC's decision to issue the new Easycard sets came after Kuo won his first victory of the season with a solo home run for the Los Angeles Dodgers to overcome the New York Mets last week, as well as because of Wang's work with the Yankees.
He noted that Kuo's home run, the first ever by a Taiwanese player in the U.S. Major League history, is a rare feat for a pitcher.
The two sets of limited edition Easycards are expected to go on the market by the end of August. ENDITEM/J

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO BOOST ANTLER VELVET YIELDS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday the birth of the first Formosan sambar deer developed from a frozen embryo will help boost local deer farmers and increase the production of fresh deer antler velvet, an important ingredient in some Chinese medicines.
The COA reported that the deer was born April 16 and has grown to a weight of 10 kg.

Kang Hsien-jen, an assistant researcher at the COA's Kaohsiung Animal Propagation Station of the Livestock Research Institute, noted that researchers collected the embryo Nov. 24, 2005, seven days after it was inseminated, froze it and later implanted it into the uterus of a surrogate mother Aug. 9, 2006. The calf was born 257 days later.
Kang said the station staff were elated, believing it to be another breakthrough in their breeding technology after their first deer born through artificial insemination July 28, 2005.
He noted that the frozen embryo technology will help improve the quality of the species and that the breeding technology will also help favor deer that can yield higher quantities of antler velvet.
Statistics showed that Taiwan has around 21,000 deer, with the Formosan sambar deer accounting for around 85 percent of the total.

Noting that deer antler velvet can fetch good prices in Taiwan, at between NT$1,000-NT$1,200 (US$30.3-US$36.36) per tael (around 38 g), he said the development of the breeding technology will be profitable.
Kang said the deer antler velvet each male deer can produce varies dramatically from between 20 taels and 326 taels per year.
"The number of male deer that have high velvet yields is small, " Kang said, adding that a good stud deer can sell for between NT$100,000 and NT$1 million.

Kang added that Taiwan needs around 80 tons of deer antler velvet a year, although it can only produce between 20 tons and 25 tons. Taiwan imports around five tons from New Zealand and relies on "parallel imports" for its remaining needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN GUATEMALAN PEOPLE'S COMMON WILL: BERGER

TEXT.P: Visiting Guatemalan President Oscar Rafael Berger Perdomo said Wednesday that maintaining friendly diplomatic relations with Taiwan is not just his personal decision but also "the common will of all Guatemalan people."
Berger, who arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a five-day visit, made the remarks during a meeting with President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
This is Berger's third visit to Taiwan. He came despite another Central American country Costa Rica's recent switching of diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing.
Chen said Berger's arrival shortly after Taiwan suffered a fresh diplomatic setback manifests his firm and genuine friendship toward Taiwan.
Berger made his first trip to Taiwan in 1998. At that time, he was mayor of Guatemala City, Guatemala's capital, and he visited Chen, who was mayor of Taipei at the time.

Berger recalled that he received a letter from Chen after he lost his first presidential bid in 1999. In that letter, Berger said, Chen gave him enormous encouragement while showing no trace of despair over his own loss in his Taipei mayoral re-election bid.

"That letter has profound meaning for me and my family. It gave me strength at a low point in my career and has become one of my most treasured collector's items, " Berger was quoted as having told Chen during their Wednesday meeting.
Berger further said he looks forward to seeing the cordial Taiwan-Guatemala relations become a model for mutual interaction among countries around the world.

During his visit, Berger will sign three agreements with Chen to boost bilateral cooperation in various fields. Since Guatemala and Taiwan signed a free trade agreement, Berger said, bilateral trade and commercial cooperation have further expanded and Guatemala's exports registered a whopping 125 percent year-on-year growth in 2006.
Berger said he hopes more Taiwan companies will invest in Guatemala to further enhance bilateral economic cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RE-APPOINTS EX-CENTRAL ELECTION COMMISSIONERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has decided to re-appoint all 16 previous Central Election Commission (CEC) commissioners for another three-year term, political sources said Wednesday.
According to the sources, former CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung will continue to head the commission.

The tenure of previous CEC commissioners expired June 16. Now that the president has decided to re-appoint all 16 former commissioners, the sources said, the Executive Yuan will unveil the full namelist Thursday.
Under the existing regulations, the CEC should install 11 to 19 commissioners for a three-year tenure. Except for the CEC chairmanship, all other commissioners are not paid.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA DAYBOOK FOR JUNE 21, 2007

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 21, or the seventh day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1788: The US Constitution comes into effect.
1900: Battles rage in both Beijing and Tientsin after Empress Dowager Tzuhsi of the Ching court declares war on Great Britain, Germany, Russia, France, the United States, Japan, Italy and Austria.
1905: Jean-Paul Sartre, the French philosopher, novelist, dramatist and critic who propounded the philosophy of existentialism, is born.
1908: Russian composer Nikolai Rimski-Korsakov dies at home in St. Petersburg at the age of 64. He was best known for his orchestral piece "Scheherazade" and the opera "The Golden Cockerel."
1919: Twenty-seven vessels of the German fleet interned at Scapa Flow in Scotland's Orkney Islands are scuttled by their crews.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek leaves for Nanchang, Kiangsi province, to assume command of a campaign to suppress communists.
1942: Troops of Germany's General Rommel take 25,000 Allied prisoners at Tobruk on the Libyan coast.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek extends a 15-day cease-fire order to June 30. He had accepted on June 6 General Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks, and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1970: Sukarno, founder and former president of the Republic of Indonesia, dies at the age of 69.
1976: A 36-member Republic of China delegation to the 22nd Asian Film Festival returns to Taipei from South Korea after winning nine awards.
1979: Premier Sun Yun-suan calls on free nations to assume moral responsibility for Indo-Chinese and mainland Chinese refugees and to take effective action immediately.
1981: Francois Mitterrand's socialists gain a landslide victory in the second ballot in general elections in France.
1982: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo calls on the nation's agricultural experts to work out concrete measures to expand agricultural development in the country.
1984: ROC Premier Yu Kuo-hwa orders an investigation into the cause of the Haishan coal mine disaster.
1990: A strong earthquake rocks northwestern Iran, killing some 25,000 people and injuring tens of thousands of others.
1990: The ROC Council of Grand Justices announces that senior parliamentarians should terminate their responsibilities by Dec. 31, 1991.
1992: Li Xiennien, former president of mainland China, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 83.
1993: An ROC-US agreement for technical cooperation in the field of environmental protection is signed in Washington, D.C.
1996: Leaders of the European Union reach a deal to end the mad cow crisis with Britain.
1997: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC Straits Exchange Foundation, is invited by the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait to attend the ceremony marking the transfer of Hong Kong's sovereignty to mainland China at midnight on June 30.
1999: The ROC formally joins the International Council for Small Business (ICSB), becoming the 11th chapter of the world trade body.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui describes US$300 million-worth of aid pledged to Kosovar refugees as "the chance of a thousand years," and urges the public to have empathy as well as a broader mindset.
2000: US Representative Benjamin A. Gilman (R-NY), chairman of the House International Relations Committee, submits Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inaugural address for insertion in the congressional record.
2001: New Republic of China representatives to Russia and Germany, Charles King and Hu Wei-chen, respectively, are sworn in Taipei and both men promise to further strengthen the nation's ties with the two countries.
2004: SpaceShipOne safely lands in the Mojave Desert in California after completing the first-ever space flight by a privately built spacecraft.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man after 40 is an object of dislike to men, he will continue to be so to the end of his days."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RE-APPOINTS EX-CENTRAL ELECTION COMMISSIONERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has decided to re-appoint all 16 previous Central Election Commission (CEC) commissioners for another three-year term, political sources said Wednesday.
According to the sources, former CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung will continue to head the commission.

The tenure of previous CEC commissioners expired June 16. Now that the president has decided to re-appoint all 16 former commissioners, the sources said, the Executive Yuan will unveil the full namelist Thursday.
Under the existing regulations, the CEC should install 11 to 19 commissioners for a three-year tenure. Except for the CEC chairmanship, all other commissioners are not paid.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN GUATEMALAN PEOPLE'S COMMON WILL: BERGER

TEXT.P: Visiting Guatemalan President Oscar Rafael Berger Perdomo said Wednesday that maintaining friendly diplomatic relations with Taiwan is not just his personal decision but also "the common will of all Guatemalan people."
Berger, who arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a five-day visit, made the remarks during a meeting with President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
This is Berger's third visit to Taiwan. He came despite another Central American country Costa Rica's recent switching of diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing.
Chen said Berger's arrival shortly after Taiwan suffered a fresh diplomatic setback manifests his firm and genuine friendship toward Taiwan.
Berger made his first trip to Taiwan in 1998. At that time, he was mayor of Guatemala City, Guatemala's capital, and he visited Chen, who was mayor of Taipei at the time.

Berger recalled that he received a letter from Chen after he lost his first presidential bid in 1999. In that letter, Berger said, Chen gave him enormous encouragement while showing no trace of despair over his own loss in his Taipei mayoral re-election bid.

"That letter has profound meaning for me and my family. It gave me strength at a low point in my career and has become one of my most treasured collector's items, " Berger was quoted as having told Chen during their Wednesday meeting.
Berger further said he looks forward to seeing the cordial Taiwan-Guatemala relations become a model for mutual interaction among countries around the world.

During his visit, Berger will sign three agreements with Chen to boost bilateral cooperation in various fields. Since Guatemala and Taiwan signed a free trade agreement, Berger said, bilateral trade and commercial cooperation have further expanded and Guatemala's exports registered a whopping 125 percent year-on-year growth in 2006.
Berger said he hopes more Taiwan companies will invest in Guatemala to further enhance bilateral economic cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO BOOST ANTLER VELVET YIELDS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday the birth of the first Formosan sambar deer developed from a frozen embryo will help boost local deer farmers and increase the production of fresh deer antler velvet, an important ingredient in some Chinese medicines.
The COA reported that the deer was born April 16 and has grown to a weight of 10 kg.

Kang Hsien-jen, an assistant researcher at the COA's Kaohsiung Animal Propagation Station of the Livestock Research Institute, noted that researchers collected the embryo Nov. 24, 2005, seven days after it was inseminated, froze it and later implanted it into the uterus of a surrogate mother Aug. 9, 2006. The calf was born 257 days later.
Kang said the station staff were elated, believing it to be another breakthrough in their breeding technology after their first deer born through artificial insemination July 28, 2005.
He noted that the frozen embryo technology will help improve the quality of the species and that the breeding technology will also help favor deer that can yield higher quantities of antler velvet.
Statistics showed that Taiwan has around 21,000 deer, with the Formosan sambar deer accounting for around 85 percent of the total.

Noting that deer antler velvet can fetch good prices in Taiwan, at between NT$1,000-NT$1,200 (US$30.3-US$36.36) per tael (around 38 g), he said the development of the breeding technology will be profitable.
Kang said the deer antler velvet each male deer can produce varies dramatically from between 20 taels and 326 taels per year.
"The number of male deer that have high velvet yields is small, " Kang said, adding that a good stud deer can sell for between NT$100,000 and NT$1 million.

Kang added that Taiwan needs around 80 tons of deer antler velvet a year, although it can only produce between 20 tons and 25 tons. Taiwan imports around five tons from New Zealand and relies on "parallel imports" for its remaining needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIA FORUM BRINGS TOGETHER NGO EXECUTIVES TO DISCUSS AID WORK

TEXT.P: An international forum sponsored by Taiwan Overseas Aid (TOAID) opened in Taipei Thursday for non-government organizations (NGOs) executives to exchange expertise and experiences in post-disaster relief and long-term humanitarian aid work.

"The fourth East Asia Forum brings together about 120 international aid project managers from more than 10 countries to discuss aid operation strategies and methods with an aim to upgrade international aid service quality," said a TOAID spokesman.
Keynote speakers at the two-day forum will include French and Japanese emergency relief and long-term aid experts as well as executives of the five TOAID member organizations, the spokesman said.

The five NGOs that form TOAID are Compassion International Taiwan, the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, the Field Relief Agency of Taiwan, the Noordhoff Craniofacial Foundation and the Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps.

Topics listed on the agenda include emergency relief and long-term aid for landmine victims, key policy formulation for emergency medical aid, interaction between NGOs and government organizations (GOs) , review of major aid projects as well as philanthropy, ethics and obstacles to international aid, the spokesman said.

Noting that Taiwanese NGOs have become increasingly active in international disaster relief operations in recent years, the spokesman said that many local NGOs organized volunteer teams to take part in aid work in the wake of a tsunami disaster in South Asia in 2004, a devastating earthquake in Pakistan in 2005 and a similar deadly temblor in Indonesia in May 2006.

While Taiwanese NGOs are developing rapidly and have contributed much to international humanitarian relief campaigns, the spokesman said Taiwan has yet to mature in international aid work. It is hoped that the ongoing seminar will help enhance public awareness of international aid work and assist local NGOs in upgrading their relief expertise and techniques, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES CHINA TO SPEED UP CROSS-STRAIT TOURISM TALKS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming-tong urged China Thursday to speed up negotiations with Taiwan on issues concerning visits to Taiwan by Chinese tourists and the operations of cross-Taiwan Strait charter passenger and cargo flights.

Chen made the remarks during a seminar with a group of China-based Taiwanese business people held in eastern Hualien County, in response to a recent proposal by Beijing authorities that cross-strait weekend charter flights be launched at the same time as the opening of visits by Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

Chen said Beijing authorities need to accelerate the progress of talks on these issues and resolve the remaining problems involved before both sides can decide on the date for the launch of these two programs.
While the technical problems regarding the operations of cross-strait passenger charter flights have been settled, political problems are what both sides need to overcome now, Chen said.

In what has been considered by the MAC as the main obstacles impeding the progress of cross-strait talks, China has referred to Taiwan as a tourist destination within China, and insisted that cross-strait visits are not ones "between two countries."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT'S U.S. TRANSIT PLAN EXPECTED TO BE FINALIZED NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu's plan to stop over in the United States on the way to her scheduled visit to Latin America is expected to be finalized next week, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Thursday.

According to MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh, Lu will visit Paraguay in early July to take part in activities marking the 50th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Paraguay, and is also planning to visit two other Central American countries with diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
The ministry is targeting the Dominican Republic and Panama as the possible destinations, but details of Lu's itinerary have yet to be finalized, MOFA officials said.

Hsueh Mei-yu, deputy director-general of the ministry's Department of North American Affairs, said Taiwan filed an application with Washington two weeks ago for Lu's plan to make transit stops in the United States for the Latin American trip.
The U.S. government is expected to reply to the application within next week, Hsueh said.

Asked if Taiwan's plan to push for a referendum on the country's bid for U.N. membership despite U.S. opposition will affect Lu's transit plan, Hsueh said she cannot speculate how the United States is going to deal with the matter.

Noting that there is an established procedure for the arrangement of U.S. transit plans for Taiwan leaders, Hsueh said she believes the U.S. government will process Taiwan's application based on the principles of comfort, convenience, security and dignity for the traveler.
President Chen Shui-bian has unveiled a plan to push for a referendum alongside the 2008 presidential election on Taiwan's effort to apply to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan."

Although the U.S. government has expressed its opposition to the plan and warned that the move would escalate tensions across the Taiwan Strait, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has insisted on going ahead with it.
