DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 96.11 points to close at 8,851.99.

The bourse opened at 8,789.09 and fluctuated between 8,871.72 and 8,722.15 during the day's trading. A total of 5.58 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$184.76 billion (US$5.6 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 4.7 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.3 percent, and textile stocks at 1.2 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues and banking and financial shares and foodstuff issues all moving down 0.3 percent and paper and pulp issues decreasing 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 690 to 487, with 196 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALAN PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS FRIENDSHIP FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Visiting Guatemalan President Oscar Berger reaffirmed Thursday his country's friendship with Taiwan.
Berger said that diplomatic relations between Guatemala and Taiwan are stable and stressed that he has a deep affection for Taiwan, which he called a very wonderful country.

Berger made the remarks in response to questions from reporters during a visit to a naphtha cracking plant operated by the Formosa Plastic Corp. in Mailiao, Yunlin County. Berger was accompanied by President Chen Shui-bian during the visit.

This is Berger's third visit to Taiwan. Nevertheless, the visit has drawn widespread attention in Taiwan given the fact that Berger has come in the wake of the severance of diplomatic ties between Taiwan and another Central American country, Costa Rica.
Chen said Wednesday that Berger's visit demonstrates his firm and genuine friendship toward Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said Thursday that Taiwan-Guatemala relations remain strong and that leaders of the two countries are maintaining close interaction.
On a local media report suggesting it is "unusual" that Guatemalan Minister of Foreign Affairs Gert Rosenthal has not come with Berger, Wang said the media should not speculate unnecessarily.
According to Wang, Rosenthal is not visiting Taiwan this time because he needs to stay in Guatemala to receive several visiting foreign ministers from European and South American countries.
After maintaining formal ties with Taiwan for decades, Costa Rica secretly established diplomatic relations with China early this month and cut off ties with Taiwan.
The development sparked concerns in Taipei about a possible domino effect impacting Taiwan's diplomatic relations with other Central American nations.
Taiwan now has 24 diplomatic allies around the world, 12 of which are in Latin America and the Caribbean region.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS TO LAUNCH 'LIGHTS OUT' CAMPAIGN FRIDAY

TEXT.P: Several environmental groups will launch a "Lights Out" campaign Friday night, calling on the general public to turn off their lights for between 10 minutes and one hour as a gesture to save energy and reduce global warming.
The campaign, which will enter its third year, is organized jointly by the Society of Wilderness (SOW) and the Delta Electronics Foundation at the summer solstice of each year.

According to the SOW, some 650,000 people around the country will join the campaign, with more than 100 public buildings of local governments, high-tech companies at Hsinchu-based Science Park, high-speed railway stations, Taipei 101 building, Kaohsiung's Love River and museums in Tamsui planning to turn off unnecessary lighting on their outside walls.
Several countries from around the world will also held similar lights out activities on the night of June 21, including the United Kingdom, Japan and South Korea.

A Delta Electronics Foundation executive said the campaign is aimed at arousing the public's awareness of energy saving, and expressive of the hope that everybody can offer their creative ideas to protect the Earth.
On Thursday, officials of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office were invited by the SOW to share with Taiwan's people Sydney's lights out experience.

On Friday night, several electrical-free concerts will be held both around the global and around the island, with the organizers inviting the public to not just turn off the lights, but also to embrace nature by going mountain climbing and fishing without lighting.
More information will be available at the SOW's Web site at: www.sow.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOO EARLY TO SPECULATE ON 'GREATER NUMBER OF TYPHOONS' THIS YEAR: CWB

TEXT.P: Central Weather Bureau (CWB) meteorologists disagreed Thursday with speculation that Taiwan is bound to experience a greater than usual number of typhoons this year under the influence of La Nina, saying that it is still too early to tell.

CWB forecasters said they do not agree with the speculations of the academic in question based on an analysis conducted by the Japan Meteorological Agency that the number of typhoons likely to directly hit Taiwan this year would be greater than the usual three or four due to the influence of La Nina.

According to CWB tallies, an average of 27 typhoons occurred in the western Pacific and South China Sea areas each year over the past several decades, and of the total, three or four directly affected Taiwan each year.

The forecasters said that La Nina is characterized by unusually cold ocean temperatures in the Equatorial Pacific, compared to El Nino, which is characterized by unusually warm ocean temperatures in the Equatorial Pacific.
They said currently, ocean temperatures in the Equatorial Pacific are at normal levels, although these temperatures could turn colder than usual in months to come.

Arguing that it is still uncertain whether there will be a La Nina this year, and that even if there is a La Nina, it would take months to tell, by which time typhoon season would be over in the Taiwan area, the forecasters said it is still too early to speculate that Taiwan should expect unusually greater number of typhoons this year due to La Nina.
Noting that July and August are usually the high season for typhoons in the Taiwan area, the CWB forecasters said they will publicize their typhoon forecasts for 2007 at the end of June.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TOURISTS IN SIGHT: MAC CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Bilateral talks on opening to Chinese tourists and the inception of direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight service have made progress, meaning that the entry of Chinese tourists is foreseeable, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Thursday.
Chen made the remarks during a gathering with reporters after attending a Dragon Boat Festival seminar with China-based Taiwan businessmen earlier the same day.
According to Chen, the opening to Chinese tourists and the establishment of direct cross-strait passenger and cargo charter flights are high on the agenda of the government's negotiations with China.

"Now that the two sides have achieved major breakthroughs in bilateral technical talks concerning the three issues, the Chinese side should accelerate its pace in resolving the remaining details and wrap up the ongoing talks in the shortest possible period, " Chen said, adding that "our side has been doing its best to complete the negotiations as quickly as possible under the directive issued by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung."

DOC.HEADLINE: PATIENTS MAY HAVE TO WAIT FOR UP TO 33 YEARS FOR KIDNEY TRANSPLANTS

TEXT.P: Patients in Taiwan may have to wait for up to 33 years before a kidney is available for transplant, a surgical doctor at the National Cheng Kung University Hospital in Tainan, southern Taiwan said Thursday.

Lee Po-chang, director of the hospital's Department of Surgery, said he has based his estimate on the fact that there are around 6,000 patients in Taiwan awaiting kidney transplants, but only 180 patients who actually receive the transplant surgery each year.

He said the concept of organ donation is popular in foreign countries, so foreign patients may only have to wait for three or five years for transplants. In Taiwan, the waiting period may be 10 times longer.

Lee cited his hospital as an example, saying that around 700 patients in the hospital are awaiting kidney transplants, but only around 30 kidney transplant surgeries are conducted every year. This means that those who are waiting for an available kidney must wait at least 23 years, he added.
In addition to the unpopularity of the idea of organ donation in Taiwan, there are other problems, Lee said.

He noted that a kidney transplant surgery can only receive a reimbursement of NT$19,800 (US$600) from the National Health Insurance program, which he described as a meager amount compared to the large sum of time and money the hospital must spend on training the surgical team.
He also said that Taiwanese transplant medicine needs to undergo reform in several aspects.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONCERT IN CELEBRATION OF TUNNEL INAUGURATION ANNIVERSARY TO BE HELD

TEXT.P: A concert will be held in Yilan Sunday in celebration of the first inauguration anniversary of the Hsuehshan Tunnel, Yilan County Deputy Magistrate Lin Hsin-hua said Thursday.
The Hsuehshan Tunnel, centerpiece of the 55 km Peiyi Freeway linking the northern county of Taipei and the northeastern county of Yilan, was inaugurated last June 16, Lin said.

The 12.9 km tunnel -- the longest highway tunnel in Southeast Asia and the fifth-longest in the world -- took 14 years to complete at a cost of more than NT$100 billion (US$3.11 billion) , Lin said, noting that it has been dubbed the "tunnel beneath troubled waters" because of the engineering difficulties encountered during its construction.

The Yilan County government and the National Expressway Engineering Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications have recently decided to invite several noted choirs to perform at the Yilan County government-run performance center to mark the tunnel's inaugural anniversary.
Those interested in attending the concert may request some of the 630 free tickets available at either the center or the county's Cultural Affairs Bureau beginning Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT GRANTS SPECIAL PARDON TO IMPRISONED 'RICE BOMBER'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian granted a special pardon to imprisoned "rice bomber" Yang Ju-men Thursday in accordance with the Constitution and an amnesty law, a Presidential Office spokesman said.

Chen signed the special pardon Thursday in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, where he played host to a state banquet in honor of visiting Guatemalan President Oscar Berger Perdomo and his entourage, according to Lee Nan-yang, director-general of the Department of Public Affairs under the Presidential Office.

Yang, who is serving time at an open prison in Hualien County in eastern Taiwan for offending the Firearms Control Act, is expected to be freed by nightfall after the pardon order signed by the president reaches the Ministry of Justice in Taipei, Lee said.

Chen announced Tuesday his decision to grant a special pardon to Yang on the grounds that he had behaved well in prison over the past three years and should be in no danger of re-offending. Chen said he had consulted with Vice President Annette Lu and relevant authorities concerning Yang's case and determined that the terrorist should be given special consideration given the situation.
Chen's special pardon announcement was made in response to a non-binding resolution adopted by the legislature June 15 in which the president was asked to pardon Yang.

Yang was sentenced in 2005 to seven-and-a-half years in prison plus a fine of NT$100,000 (US$3,030.3) for planting 17 explosive devices in public places around Taipei over a one-year period until he surrendered in November 2004.

Claiming to be an opponent of the government's rice import policy, Yang always included small amounts of rice in his homemade, "non-lethal" explosives, which is where Yang's nickname came from. Nobody was injured in his year-long bombing campaign.

During his trial, Yang said he had mounted the bombing campaign to attract the government's attention to the plight of local farmers after the country's accession to the World Trade Organization in 2002.
In January 2006, the Taiwan High Court reduced Yang's sentence to five years and 10 months, describing his motive as "not malicious."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO CONTINUE TO COMMUNICATE WITH U.S. ON U.N. BID: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to communicate with the United States on its plan to hold a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.
Hsueh Mei-yu, deputy director of the ministry's Department of North American Affairs, made the remarks after a U.S. State Department official reiterated Washington's opposition to the proposal.

"The United States opposes any initiative that appears designed to change Taiwan's status unilaterally. This would include a referendum on whether to apply to the United Nations under the name of 'Taiwan, '" State Department spokesman Sean McCormack said.

McCormack stressed that in line with its "one China" policy, the United States does not support Taiwan's membership in international organizations that require statehood, including the United Nations.
Hsueh said that Taiwan and the United States have communicated on the issue for more than one year, and that they know each other's stance through various channels.

She noted that President Chen Shui-bian declared several months ago that he would promote the bid to join the United Nations in the name of Taiwan, and that he conveyed this to several U.S. delegations during visits they made to Taiwan.
"Taiwan has continued to communicate with the United States on the issue, and both sides are aware of the respective policies and stances," she added.

However, she also claimed that the U.S. State Department official's remarks "may only be reiterating its firm stance," and she further claimed that the U.S. official use of the word "oppose" "might only be a tone to stress its firm stance."
She said Taiwan and the United States are well aware that they have different viewpoints and predicted that "heated discussion will not affect the overall relations between the two sides."

She also said Chen's plan to hold a referendum on the nation's U.N. bid is not an attempt to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, and does not run counter to his "four noes" pledge made in his 2000, and again in 2004 inaugural address.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY IN TAINAN COUNTY WINS HONORS AT PITTSBURGH TRADE FAIR

TEXT.P: Far East University in the southern county of Tainan has won 12 medals with four invention entries at America's largest invention trade show held earlier this month in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, a university professor said Thursday.

Chen Yu-kang, director of the university's Creativity Center, told reporters that the four new inventions submitted by students and faculty members of the university won three golds, three silvers, three bronzes and three special awards at the 2007 Invention and New Product Exposition (INPEX).
INPEX is a unique exposition showcasing numerous inventions and new products available to license, manufacture or market.

One of the four entries submitted by Far East University was a multimode bicycle built for two that can allow the riders to ride face-to-face or back-to-back. It won five honors, including two gold medals.

The other inventions were a preservative-free facial mask that can separate dryness from moisture, a biodegradable material for mobile phone cases that can block electomagnetism, and a construction material made of recycled wood powder compressed with polystyrene.

Far East University was just one of the teams from Taiwan to win honors at the 23rd INPEX. Altogether, Taiwan submitted 27 original inventions and won 15 gold medals, 18 silvers, 10 bronzes and five special awards at the June 6-9 trade fair.
More than 700 entries were submitted from 20 countries to the exhibition's 50 categories.
Taiwan's delegation, comprising teams from enterprises, universities and research institutes, had 19 stalls at the show.
Other inventions that won gold medals included body-shaping underwear, a multifunctional folding chair, solar street lights and a fire extinguisher.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: British hostages held by Iran-backed killers
A group funded, trained and armed by Iran was responsible for kidnapping five British civilians in Baghdad last month, according to the commander of US forces in Iraq. General David Petraeus told The Times yesterday that he believed that the men, four security guards and a consultant, were alive and added that there had been repeated attempts to free them. No demands have been made for their release.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING ASKED TO CALL TAIWAN 'CHINESE TAIPEI' IN 2008 OLYMPICS: MAC

TEXT.P: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has requested that China abide by a 1989 agreement with Taiwan under which Taiwan is to compete in Olympic games under the name "Chinese Taipei, " Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming- tong said Thursday.

Speaking during an informal gathering with the media in Hualien County, Chen said the IOC has decided that the agreement should apply to the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing and has written Taiwan about its decision.

In what Taiwan considered intentional moves to downgrade the country's status, China offered to include Taiwan as the first stop of a "domestic" torch-relay route for the 2008 Olympic Games and referred to Taiwan as "Taipei, China", implying that Taiwan is part of China. That offer was rejected by Taiwan.

Owing to Beijing's opposition, Taiwan has been barred from most international activities, and where Taiwan is allowed to participate, it is forbidden from using its official name -- the Republic of China.

Last Friday, several pro-Taiwan members of the U.S. Congress put forth legislation urging the IOC to allow Taiwan to compete in the 2008 Olympic Games using the national name, flag and anthem of choice.

Congressional members said it is discriminatory, and therefore against the Olympic Charter, for the IOC to require that Taiwan use the name "Chinese Taipei" to take part in Olympic games, and for it to forbid the country from playing its national anthem and displaying its national flag.

DOC.HEADLINE: `BUDGET FREEZE' BY-PRODUCT OF PARTISAN STRIFE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Thursday that feels heartache over the Legislative Yuan's freezing of a large chunk of the government's 2007 budget and hopes a special legislative session can be held to pass certain urgent budget bills.
Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Chang said he was grateful for the legislature's approval of the government's annual budget plan last Friday before going into summer recess.

Nevertheless, he went on, the 197-day delay in the budget bill's passage has adversely impacted the economy, particularly hindering the launch of NT$70.6 billion-worth of new public investment or infrastructure construction projects. The delay could result in a slowdown of the country's economic growth by an estimated 0.25 to 0.3 percentage points, he lamented.

Worse still, Chang said, as much as NT$62 billion of the government's 2007 budget remains frozen on the orders of the opposition-controlled legislature. The frozen amount cannot be used pending further review by the legislature on a case-by-case basis.

Noting that the Budget Act doesn't offer any basis to justify the so-called "partial budget freeze, " Chang, who was a seven-term legislator before assuming the premiership, said the legislature only cut off the administration's budget proposals or passed them before the "rotation of the political party in power" or the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) grip of power.
Describing the legislative-engineered "budget freeze" as a by-product of partisan strife, Chang said the move has threatened the well-being of the public.

Chang called for the holding of an extra legislative session as soon as possible to lift the "budget freeze" and screen a number of other critical budget bills, including one concerning the expansion of public infrastructure construction projects worth NT$77.4 billion, which form part of an ambitious five-year NT$500 billion development plan.
Another budget bill that needs to be addressed urgently concerns the operations of state-owned enterprises and several government-run development funds totaling NT$4.2 trillion, Chang said.
Noting that the accumulated amount of these long-stalled budget bills far exceeds the government's 2007 budget, Chang said their early passage is critical to the country's overall development.

During the Cabinet meeting, Chang directed Vice Premier Chiou I-jen to form a supraministerial task force to deal with issues related to the NT$62 billion in frozen budget so as to ensure smooth government operations and realize a 4.6 percent economic growth target.
According to the Legislative Yuan-approved budget bill, the government's revenues for 2007 are set at NT$1.48 trillion, while the expenditure is projected at NT$1.62 trillion.
Meanwhile, DPP legislative caucus whip Ker Chien-ming said the party caucus will come up with a motion urging the legislature to open a special legislative session July 1.
"We hope the special legislative session can start July 1 and last for 10 to 14 days to address a large number of critical bills, " Ker said.

In addition to the budget bills mentioned by Chang, Ker said the DPP caucus also expects the special session to deliberate certain other long-shelved key bills, including amendments to the Income Tax Law aimed at canceling decades-old income tax exemption privileges for military personnel and elementary and junior high school teachers, as well as amendments to the farmers stipend statute to raise the monthly allowances for elderly farmers to NT$6,000 from the current NT$5,000.

As the main opposition Kuomintang already proposed that the legislature hold a special session July 9 to address an amendment package to the Central Election Commission organic statute, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng is expected to call a cross-party consultative meeting to hammer out the timing and the agenda for the proposed special session, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL BAND TO VOICE SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN'S U.N. BID ON WORLD TOUR

TEXT.P: Chthonic -- a Taiwanese black metal band -- will voice support for Taiwan's full participation in the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan" during a concert tour of America and Canada in July and September, bandleader Freddy Lin said Thursday.
Chthonic will perform in the 2007 Ozzfest tour, which is an annual tour of the United States featuring heavy metal, hard rock and black metal groups, in more than 30 American cities.

The government asked Chthonic to voice support for Taiwan's U.N. bid during the tour, in association with a series of activities to be held to promote Taiwan's full participation in the U.N. in New York in September.

Many Taiwanese entertainers avoid political questions and occasions to prevent their Chinese market being compromised, Lin said, adding that Chthonic is willing to cooperate with the government's promotion and feels obliged to contribute to Taiwan's future.

Lin said the band has named its concert "UNlimited Taiwan," which signifies the unlimited potential of Taiwan and also shows how the U.N. has limited Taiwan's full participation as a sovereign nation.

Lin said he hopes the band's endeavors and musical power in the concerts will help arouse international awareness of Taiwan's difficulties in joining international organizations, and will prompt more friends to support Taiwan's U.N. bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS WANT VIGOROUS CONTROL ON WiMAX BASE STATIONS

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers from the ruling and opposition camps urged the government Thursday to impose strict controls on the erection of WiMAX base stations, which they said pose a great risk to the health of those living nearby.

Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Wang Yu-ting and her ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) counterpart Tien Chiu-chin issued the call at a news conference after government authorities recently revealed a plan to allow for the establishment of WiMAX (worldwide interoperability for microwave access) base stations.

Wang and Tien asked the National Communications Commission (NCC) to review its planned opening of WiMAX base stations and demanded that it not issue licenses for base stations before WiMAX safety has been fully assured.
According to the two legislators, WiMAX base stations will be more powerful than cell phone base stations in transmitting electromagnetic radiation, posing an even greater health threat.

Meanwhile, representatives from the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union also suspect that some 20 residents in Tainan City diagnosed with cancer are victims of electromagnetic radiation released by cell phone base stations.

However, officials from the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) and the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs were reserved about their concerns over the negative health effects of WiMAX.

Wu Ming-chi, an IDB section chief, said that it is "too early" to talk about the dangers of WiMAX, as no WiMAX base stations, whose power transmission efficiency and electromagnetic radiation is lower, have been erected in Taiwan.

According to an EPA official, the government will adjust its regulations on the establishment of WiMAX base stations in compliance with the rules of the World Health Organization, which is expected to release a new report on electromagnetic radiation next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISM BUREAU INVITES CELEBRITIES TO PROMOTE TOURISM

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau has invited Jolin Tsai, a pop singer, and Wu Nien-chen, a writer and cinematographic director, to serve as its spokespersons to lure tourists from Southeast Asian countries.
Tourism Bureau officials said Thursday the project aims to increase the number of tourists coming from Southeast Asian countries by 7 percent this year.

Janice Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau, noted that tourists from Japan and South Korea account for nearly 39 percent of the total number of foreign tourists arriving in Taiwan, followed by those from Southeast Asian countries, which account for 21 percent.
According to Lai, the number of tourists from Hong Kong, Macao, Singapore and Malaysia totalled 760,000 last year.
The bureau's move follows its recent project inviting pop group F4 to serve as tourist spokesmen targeting visitors from Japan and South Korea.
Tsai and Wu will visit Southeast Asia in July to promote tourism in Taiwan, while the bureau officials will invite journalists from the region to tour the island in September.
Tsai, who was just chosen best female singing artist at the Golden Melody Awards in Taiwan, will also give several concerts around the island as a part of the bureau's efforts to promote Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOOD SHOW EXHIBITORS OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TAIWAN-CENTRAL AMERICAN TRADE

TEXT.P: The free trade agreements (FTAs) Taiwan has signed with Central American countries will help boost trade between Taiwan and those nations, Central American exhibitors said Thursday in an international food show.

The Taiwan-El Salvador-Honduras FTA was signed May 7 and became the third FTA established between Central American nations and Taiwan, which has inked separate FTAs with Panama, Guatemala and Nicaragua.

With more products from both sides enjoying tariff-free incentives, El Salvador is looking to export more sugar, coffee and seafood to Taiwan, said Mauricio Chavarria, Marketing Manager of EXPORTA -- a Salvadoran government agency in charge of export promotion, which is the equivalent of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

El Salvador was among several nations, including Panama, Guatemala, Nicaragua and Honduras, that jointly set up an FTA Nations Hall at the 2007 Taipei International Food Show, which is being held from June 21-24. The Latin American nations are showcasing products such as coffee, seafood, sauces, juices and meat.
"Taiwan manufactures high-quality machinery, which is what El Salvador needs. Once the FTA kicks in, Salvadoran industries will benefit from the lower prices of Taiwanese products, " Chavarria said.

"Without the FTA, you would not see many products displayed here, " said Rodrigo Coba, general manager of a Panamanian company that sells products made from the noni fruit. Coba's company has secured its first distributor in Taiwan.
In 2003, Panama became the first Central American country to sign an FTA with Taiwan.

"El Salvador intends to keep doing business with Taiwan, although we import a lot of products from China, " Chavarria said, adding that El Salvador's limited manufacturing capability is not capable of handling a large market like China yet.

"And we would like to trade with Taiwan because of your democracy and your assistance in fishery, agriculture and infrastructure in El Salvador. I do not see China buying a large amount of products from El Salvador at the moment, " he said.
After the FTA goes into effect, he said, El Salvador can trade coffee with Taiwan directly instead of through Japan, so that consumers in Taiwan will get Salvadoran coffee at a cheaper price.
According to Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), bilateral trade between Taiwan and El Salvador was valued at US$80.48 million for 2006, with Taiwan enjoying a trade surplus of US$62.5 million.

Central American countries can be Taiwan's gateway to the North American market, as Taiwanese manufacturers can also take advantage of the Central America- Dominican Republic-United States Free Trade Agreement (CAFTA-DR).

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WANTS TO MAINTAIN ROC STATUS QUO

TEXT.P: Maintaining the status quo of the Republic of China is the position of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), the party's presidential nominee Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday.
Ma told reporters that seeking Taiwan independence is not one of the KMT's options and that now is not an appropriate time to talk about unification with China.
"The KMT's position is that we should maintain the status quo of the ROC," Ma said.

He made the remarks after Mao Kao-wen, chairman of the presidium of the KMT Central Advisory Committee, told a meeting of the presidium that he will propose to Ma that the current relationship across the Taiwan Strait is one between "two Chinas," with the ROC based in Taiwan and the People's Republic of China based in China.

The two sides should move toward "one China" in the future, Mao said, adding that maintaining the status quo of "two Chinas" at present should be the KMT's answer to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's favoring of Taiwan independence.
Asked to comment on Mao's remarks, Ma said he respects Mao's view but added that the KMT's official position is to maintain the status quo of the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONCERNED OVER DPP CANDIDATE'S STANCE ON REFERENDUM
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 21 (CNA) 06/21/07 20:19:26 (By Chiehyu Lin and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Bush Administration is now more concerned about the stance of Frank Hsieh, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate, toward President Chen Shui-bian's plan to hold a referendum on Taiwan's U.N. bid, a political observer in Washington said Wednesday.

With less than one year left of Chen's tenure, the U.S. government is now showing more interest in Hsieh's attitude toward the issue, as Ma Ying-jeou, the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) presidential candidate for 2008 election, has made known his stance in this regard recently, added the observer, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Chen unveiled Monday his plan to promote a referendum on Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan" to be held alongside the 2008 presidential election.
Chen's plan immediately encountered strong opposition from the U.S. government, which declared that it opposes any initiative that appears designed to change Taiwan's status unilaterally.
A U.S. State Department official pointed out that such a referendum will have no practical impact on Taiwan's U.N. status but will increase tension in the Taiwan Strait.

According to the source, some people believe that the harsh attitude from the U.S. government is due largely to the fact that the United States is conducting high-level talks with China and that the State Department's disapproving words were spoken to mitigate pressure from Beijing.
The observer noted that the Bush Administration was obliged to expressed its stance strongly and openly after failing to convince Chen through private channels not to make the move.
The Bush Administration now is hopeful that Hsieh's attitude will differ from Chen's, the observer said, adding that Chen is seen as pandering to local voters at the expense of Taiwan-U.S. relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST DRUG, ALCOHOL-EXPOSED CHILDREN FACE SURVIVAL CRISES: FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: There are at least 3,000 infants and children in Taiwan who are victims of drug or alcohol abuse and are facing survival crises, the Child Welfare League Foundation reported Thursday.

Most of these children who are exposed to drugs or alcohol are facing crisis of survival, crisis of delayed development and crisis of suicidal tendency as a result of long-term mental and psychological trauma, foundation experts said.
The experts said 239 children from cases that the foundation has helped or intervened in are victims of drug or alcohol exposure.
Of them, 48.6 percent have alcoholic or drug abusing adults who are their only caregivers.

Of these adults, 79.1 percent are also jobless, 56 percent are debt-ridden, 36.8 percent are mentally challenged and 39.7 percent are child-abusers who sometimes even feed drugs and booze to their children to calm them down, foundation experts said.
Wang Yu-min, executive director of the foundation, said that islandwide, a total of 1,212 infants and children were found to be victims of drug or alcohol exposure in 2006.

Wang quoted statistics compiled by the Children's Bureau under the Ministry of the Interior as indicating that the number of children from high-risk families who have received expert intervention had surpassed 15,000 as of early this year.
Of these 15,000 children, about 10 percent were victims of drug or alcohol exposure, Wang said.

Wang quoted a U.S. study as reporting that children who are victims of drug or alcohol abuse are three times more likely to be physically abused than their counterparts from non-drug or non-alcoholic families.
These children are also four times more likely to suffer neglect, Wang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC SHOULD NOT `REACT POLITICALLY' TO RE-APPOINTMENT OF CEC MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chung-hsiung said Thursday that the public should refrain from responding in an "intuitive and political" way to the re-appointment of all 16 Central Election Commission (CEC) commissioners.

Chang made the remarks one day after he submitted the list of the original 16 commissioners to President Chen Shui-bian for approval. All of them were re- appointed and former Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung also continued to head the commission.

"In view of the sensitivity of the opposition camp on the matter, as well as taking into consideration the national interests and the practical needs of the law, " Chang said, he submitted the old list after the tenure of the previous CEC commissioners expired June 16.

He claimed that the operations of the CEC cannot be disrupted, noting that the previous CEC set Jan. 12 for the next legislative elections, which will adopt the new "single-member constituency, two vote" electoral system. The new legislature will also see its seats cut by half to 113 from the current 225.
"Whether at the central or local levels, there are many new measures awaiting decisions from the CEC," he said.
Under the regulations, the CEC should install 11 to 19 commissioners for a three-year tenure. Apart from the CEC chairman, none of the commissioners are paid.
The regulations state that commissioners should include those with no party affiliation and that commissioners of a single party should not exceed two- fifths of the total seats.

The KMT has wanted the formation of the CEC to be recommended by political parties in proportion to the number of seats they each hold in the legislature, with no single party allowed to control more than two-fifths of the total seats.
The version of a KMT bill regarding the CEC formation failed to pass the last opposition-controlled legislative session due to serious clashes between the ruling and opposition parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP CALLS FOR YOUTH TO TAKE PART IN POLITICS

TEXT.P: Thanks to strong dissatisfaction with the poor performance of incumbent lawmakers, a youth group urged young men and women Thursday to devote themselves to politics and take part in the next legislative election to demonstrate their discontent.

Members of the group named "Youth Rebellion Base," mostly college students, issued the call at a Legislative Yuan news conference. They also staged a skit to lash out at lawmakers for what they claimed are their attempts to "deceive voters" by approving several controversial bills, including one that grants a monthly stipend of NT$6,000 for elderly farmers.

"Such wily old foxes should bow off the stage, " they argued, adding that the national coffers will be hollowed out if "unworthy politicians" continue "deceiving voters" with fake election promises and pursuing avenues such as ethnic differences and independence versus unification with China.

"Issues concerning environmental protection, as well as wealth and education gaps, are issues that present-day young people are really concerned about, " they pointed out, encouraging young people to take part in politics and outlining their programs to sponsor courses at local colleges and universities with the aim of training qualified young "elite" to run in the next legislative elections slated for January 2008.

They also urged young men and women to support their efforts to call for the legislation of a "veto ballot" that would empower voters to "deny all the candidates listed on the ballot" in future elections, asking young voters to put pressure on lawmakers who boycott the passage of such a bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:U.S. Is Urging Blair to Be Lead Mideast Envoy
The United States is pressing Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to become a special envoy to the Middle East, representing the diplomatic "quartet of world powers, administration officials said Wednesday.
The appointment would be the most visible attempt at laying the groundwork for a Palestinian state since President Clinton wrangled with Yasir Arafat and Ehud Barak during the waning hours of his administration in 2001.
Wall Street Journal:Saving Rotterdam From the Varmints
Cees Noorlander, undisputed master of this port's vast open spaces, shoots intruders on sight. And he shoots to kill.
The official gamekeeper for Europe's busiest trading hub, Mr. Noorlander patrols the docklands in a tireless hunt for the varmints that could undermine global trade by tunneling under the pipelines, rail tracks and levees that keep Europe's economy operating smoothly. As a container of Chinese goods rumbled by on a train early one morning recently, the 57-year-old Mr. Noorlander quickly shouldered his weapon and cut down his first rabbit of the day. "That's a small one," he said. "I'll feed it to my ferrets."

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSTAYING HONG KONGER NABBED

TEXT.P: A Hong Kong citizen who has overstayed his visa to Taiwan for over 13 years without being caught, was nabbed Wednesday for using a counterfeit Hong Kong ID, immigration sources said Thursday.

The 42-year-old Hong Konger, surnamed Chiu, was caught using a fake Hong Kong ID at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Wednesday when he was preparing to board a Cathay Pacific flight for Hong Kong, officials from the National Immigration Agency said.
During interrogation at the airport, Chiu claimed that he lost his real ID in 2004 and managed to obtain a new one from the Hong Kong authorities.

However, Taoyuan aviation police discovered that not only was Chiu's new ID counterfeit, he actually landed in Taiwan off a ship that arrived in Kaohsiung April 28, 1993 from Hong Kong with a visa that expired Aug. 31 of the same year.
Chiu, who has overstayed for more than 13 years, was handed over to the Taoyuan District Prosecutors Office for further questioning, the police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRICTER FOOD LABELING REQUIRED FROM NEXT YEAR: DOH

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced Thursday that from Jan. 1 next year, all packaged food should provide consumers with information such as the place of origin and the content of trans fatty acids and saturated fats.
Cheng Huei-wen, director of the DOH Bureau of Food Safety, said the labeling of the place of origin is targeting multinational enterprises whose products may be produced in various countries.
Also, if there is a food safety problem, the labeling will facilitate the authorities in tracking down the source of the production and taking the necessary measures.
Trans fatty acid and saturated fat are also considered to be detrimental to the health, which is why the DOH will demand that their content be labeled on food, he said.

Producers of packaged beverages, cans, milk powder and instant noodles will be fined between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000 (US$909-US$4,545) if they fail to observe the new regulations and will also be required to make improvements.
Goods sold loose will not be subject to the new regulations, according to Cheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTER RECALLS TOXIC TOY TRAINS: CPC

TEXT.P: The Pro and Pacific Co., a Taiwan-based toy importer, has announced a voluntary recall of various "Thomas and Friends Wooden Railway" toys due to concern that the paint on the toys might contain lead, an official of the Consumer Protection Commission (CPC) under the Executive Yuan said Thursday.
The CPC was urged by legislators Wednesday to investigate the toys after the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) recalled 1.5 million of the toxic toys from retailers and consumers.

The official said the Taiwanese importer announced a recall of 15 kinds of the Chinese-made toys produced from January, 2005 to June this year after receiving notice about the toxic paint from the CPSC June 14.
A total of 1,000 units of the toys had already been sold in Taiwan, the spokesman said, adding that consumers can contact the importer on 02-2999-5700 to return the goods and get a refund.
The spokesman said the CPC will notify consumer ombudsman officers at local governments to supervise retailers' cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE SUPPORTS U.N. BID UNDER NAME OF `TAIWAN'

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh supports a plan to hold a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan, " a spokesman for Hsieh's campaign office said Thursday.

Chao Tien-lin said Hsieh promoted a bid to join the United Nations in the name of "Taiwan" 16 years ago and added that Hsieh debated the issue at the time with John Chiang, then-minister of foreign affairs and now a legislator of the opposition Kuomintang.
The plan is not only being advocated by President Chen Shui-bian, who expressed the wish to hold such a referendum earlier this week, according to Chao.
Noting that a U.S. State Department official has reiterated Washington's opposition to the referendum proposal, Hsieh said that it is only natural that the two countries "have different stances."

"The United States opposes any initiative that appears designed to change Taiwan's status unilaterally. This would include a referendum on whether to apply to the United Nations under the name of 'Taiwan, '" State Department spokesman Sean McCormack said.

McCormack stressed that in line with its "one China" policy, the United States does not support Taiwan's membership in international organizations that require statehood, including the United Nations.
Despite the U.S. opposition, "Taiwan can still create a win-win situation after a full and comprehensive communication with the United States," Chao quoted Hsieh as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR UPSET WITH CUTTING OF EDUCATION SUBSIDIES

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu expressed strong dissatisfaction Thursday over a Ministry of Education (MOE) decision to cut this year's subsidies for the city's two English learning programs for adult residents and parents with their children.
Hu vowed that he will appeal the ministry's decision to the Cabinet and failing that, will pursue the case through administrative litigation.

The two English language programs cost NT$2.74 million per year, but the Taichung city government has been informed that because it "failed to cooperate with a major ministry policy" on screening and identifying talented students last year, the subsidies will no longer be forthcoming this year.

Hu pointed out that Taichung's performance in carrying out the two language programs ranked fourth nationwide last year and said the MOE should not have cut its subsidies for the city using a "totally irrelevant reason."

"The city of Taichung submits NT$300 billion (US$9.08 billion) in tax revenues a year to the national coffers. How could the central government withhold the subsidies from us in this way?" he asked, adding that "the subsidies come from the tax money paid by us."

Hu said that although he can easily find NT$2.74 million to meet the shortfall from elsewhere, he cannot comply with the "ill will" of the central government but will seek redress for the unfair treatment of Taichung's citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE TAIWAN CITIES JOIN `SWITCH OFF, UNPLUG' CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: A campaign to heighten awareness of the seriousness of global warming has been set in motion, with three cities -- Kaohsiung, Taichung and Taipei -- joining hands to ask their residents to switch off and unplug all electrical appliances for 10 minutes on Friday.

The campaign, titled "Let the Earth Cool Off a Little: Unplug Your Appliances to Fight Global Warning," was initiated by the Taiwan Broadcasting System (TBS) , a public broadcasting service group consisting of four television stations, to coincide with the summer solstice. It is supported by the three city governments.
The organizers have urged all residents in the three cities to turn off or unplug their electrical appliances for at least 10 minutes from 7:40 p.m. to 7:50 p.m. June 22.

A concert will be held from 7:30 p.m. Friday at a plaza beside Kaohsiung's Love river to call public attention to the global warming issue, with all the lighting provided by solar energy, according to the organizers.
Another concert will be held at Taichung's Wenhsin Forest Park that same evening to increase the awareness among Taichung residents about the need to help slow down global warming.

DOC.HEADLINE: COED MURDERESS NOT ELIGIBLE FOR PAROLE UNTIL SEPTEMBER: MOJ

TEXT.P: A woman convicted of murdering her classmate at National Tsinghua University more than nine years ago will be eligible for parole this September, a Ministry of Justice (MOJ) official said Thursday.

The official was responding to a United Daily News report that the Kaohsiung Women's Prison in the southern port city of Kaohsiung had applied for parole for Hung Hsiao-huei, who is serving an 18-year prison term for murdering her classmate Hsu Chia-chen and mutilating her corpse in March 1998 in an auditorium of the prestigious university in Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan.

"The newspaper report is false, " the MOJ official said, adding that the Kaohsiung prison authorities have not filed a parole application for Hung because she will not be eligible for parole until this fall.

Hung was sentenced to 15 years in prison for killing Hsu and three-and-a-half- years for mutilating the body. Her murder sentence is not eligible for commutation under an amnesty statute passed by the legislature earlier this month, but she is qualified to have her mutilation sentence halved.
Following the commutation, the MOJ official said, Hung's prison term will end April 2, 2014.

According to the official, Hung served her time behind bars at Taipei Prison and Taoyuan Prison from January 1999 through March 2001. She was transferred to Kaohsiung Women's Prison March 21, 2001 and has been there since.
The official said Hung has behaved well since her incarceration and has converted to Christianity.

As the best educated inmate at the Kaohsiung Women's Prison, Hung teaches other inmates English and other subjects, prison sources said, adding that she has received citations for quitting smoking and writing Bible and other religious scriptures, as well as winning championships in calligraphy and essay writing.
Prison sources said Hung is unwilling to give any media interviews and looks forward to continuing her graduate studies after regaining her freedom.

In addition to serving a long prison term, Hung has to compensate Hsu's parents with NT$24.17 million. Prison sources said Hung hopes society can forgive her, allowing her to stand on her own feet and save money to repay Hsu's parents.
Hung and Hsu were rivals in a love triangle, but the Taiwan High Court verdict ruled that it was Hung's unauthorized use of Hsu's credit card that led to the murder.

Regarding Hung's intent to murder, the verdict said it was based on the fact that the victim was brutally beaten before Hung poured a powerful corrosive chemical on her that disfigured her body and led to her death. Hung later dragged Hsu's body to the rear of the auditorium to keep it from being found.
The cold-blooded campus murder shocked society at the time. Both Hung and Hsu were second-year graduate students at Tsinghua University's radiobiology institute at the time of the murder.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREED `RICE BOMBER' CALLS FOR MORE CONCERN FOR CHILDREN, FARMERS

TEXT.P: Newly released "rice bomber" Yang Ju-men shunned the media limelight Thursday but called for more public concern for the well-being of the country's children and farmers.
Yang arrived in Taipei late that day from an open prison in Hualien County in eastern Taiwan after President Chen Shui-bian formally granted him a special pardon earlier in the day.

Responding to press inquiries about his feelings after regaining freedom, Yang, who planted bombs around Taipei City as a way to air his grievances, claimed that he is "only an ordinary person" unworthy of media attention. He said he hopes to see the media and the public turn their attention to welfare services for children and farmers.
Yang then traveled back to his old home in Changhua in central Taiwan in the company of his brother.

Yang's father who is residing in the northern port city of Keelung expressed his gratitude for President Chen's granting of a special pardon to his son. "I hope Ju-men can find a job in Changhua and will never offend law in the rest of his life," his father said.

Wu Yin-ning, a Changhua-based freelancer who has maintained regular correspondence with Yang during Yang's incarceration, said she plans to publish a book in July on the "rice bomber" incident and the plight of local farmers based on Yang's more than 100 letters to her over the past few years. The proceeds from book sales will be donated for school lunch for children from impoverished families, Wu said.

Yang was sentenced in 2005 to seven-and-a-half years in prison plus a fine of NT$100,000 (US$3,030.3) for planting 17 explosive devices in public places around Taipei over a one-year period until he turned himself in November 2004.

Identifying himself as an opponent of the government's rice import policy, Yang always sprinkled small amounts of rice in his homemade explosives, which is where Yang's nickname came from. Nobody was injured in his year-long bombing campaign.

During his trial, Yang said he had mounted the bombing campaign to attract the government's attention to the plight of local farmers after the country's accession to the World Trade Organization in 2002.
In January 2006, the Taiwan High Court reduced Yang's sentence to five years and 10 months, saying his motive was not malicious.

While announcing his decision to grant a special pardon to Yang in his speech delivered at a luncheon with members of the Navy's 131 Fleet in Keelung Tuesday to celebrate the Dragon Boat Festival, Chen said Yang deserves compassion and is not expected to break the law again as he has behaved well during his time behind bar.
Yang's pardon marks the second presidential pardon since Chen assumed office in May 2000. He first granted special pardon to 21 special prison inmates in 2000.
Yang first served at a prison in Taipei and was transferred to an open prison in Hualien early this year because of his good behavior. He works on a farm in the Hualien open prison.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 22, or the eighth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1757: George Vancouver, the British explorer after whom Canada's Vancouver Island and Vancouver are named, is born.
1893: Thomas Francis Bayard presents his credentials as U.S. ambassador extraordinary and plenipotentiary to Great Britain, becoming the first actual American ambassador after more than a century of ministers carrying out diplomatic representation.
1906: U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt sues John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Company for operating a monopoly.
1910: Paul Ehrlich, the German bacteriologist and immunologist who won the 1908 Nobel Prize for physiology with Elie Metchnikov, announces he has discovered the definitive cure for syphilis.
1933: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler outlaws both the Communist Party and the National Peoples Party, permitting only one political party -- the National Socialist German Workers Party or Nazi Party -- thus beginning a Nazi dictatorship.
1937: Joe Louis becomes the heavyweight boxing champion of the world. He holds the title for nearly 12 years until his retirement in March 1943. The powerful American fighter successfully defended the title for a record 25 fights.
1940: The French formally surrender to Germany when Gen. Charles Huntziger of France signs terms of surrender with Germany at Compiegne, in the same railroad car in which Gen. Foch had received the German surrender in 1918.
1941: Germany invades the Soviet Union, commencing Adolf Hitler's "Operation Barbarossa."
1941: Italy and Romania declare war on the Soviet Union.
1947: Outer Mongolian troops, aided by planes bearing Soviet insignia, renew attacks on Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang Province.
1956: Republic of China Air Force jet fighters shoot down four Chinese communist MiG-17s and damage two others over Matsu, an ROC-controlled island in the Taiwan Strait.
1965: Japan and South Korea sign a treaty in Tokyo establishing diplomatic relations.
1977: Gen. Hu Lien, former deputy commander-in-chief of the ROC Army and ROC ambassador to South Vietnam, dies of a heart attack at the age of 71.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs into law the "Taiwan Relations Act" in order to resume arms sales to the ROC following the break of diplomatic ties.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Prime Minister Ezekiel Alebua of the Solomon Islands.
1987: Fred Astaire, one of America' best-loved entertainers, dies at the age of 88. He co-starred with Ginger Rogers, Judy Garland, Lesley Caron and Audrey Hepburn in musicals including "Top Hat" and "Shall We Dance?"
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revision of the Law on Negotiable Instruments, retroactively abolishing criminal penalties for over 30,000 people convicted of issuing bad checks before January 1987.
1989: Seven students involved in the Tiananmen Square protests in Beijing are executed after televised "show trials."
1991: The ROC gains admission to the Central American Development Bank.
1995: British Prime Minister John Major resigns as head of the ruling Conservative Party in order to conduct a party leadership election.
1999: The second Asia-Pacific technology conference opens in Taipei with over 100 fund managers from around the world gathering to discuss developments in the region's high-tech industry with the heads of high-tech companies from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, South Korea and Thailand.
1999: The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission releases a draft of the ROC's first white paper on maritime policy to stress ROC sovereignty over the disputed Spratly and Tiaoyutai islands.
2000: Taiwan's computer giant Acer Group has recently begun participating in the "Oxygen Alliance" project led by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in the U.S. The alliance is a five-year project aimed at making computers more widespread and less physically intrusive.
2001: Oscar Alvarez, Costa Rican ambassador to the Republic of China, hosts a "Latin Night" to mark 60 years of diplomatic relations between Taipei and San Jose.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is not right to refuse to enter public service. For if it is wrong to ignore the duties arising out of the relations between the members of a man's family, how is it right for a man to ignore the duties he owes to his sovereign and country?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
THREE TAIWAN CITIES JOIN `SWITCH OFF, UNPLUG' CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: A campaign to heighten awareness of the seriousness of global warming has been set in motion, with three cities -- Kaohsiung, Taichung and Taipei -- joining hands to ask their residents to switch off and unplug all electrical appliances for 10 minutes on Friday.

The campaign, titled "Let the Earth Cool Off a Little: Unplug Your Appliances to Fight Global Warning," was initiated by the Taiwan Broadcasting System (TBS) , a public broadcasting service group consisting of four television stations, to coincide with the summer solstice. It is supported by the three city governments.
The organizers have urged all residents in the three cities to turn off or unplug their electrical appliances for at least 10 minutes from 7:40 p.m. to 7:50 p.m. June 22.

A concert will be held from 7:30 p.m. Friday at a plaza beside Kaohsiung's Love river to call public attention to the global warming issue, with all the lighting provided by solar energy, according to the organizers.
Another concert will be held at Taichung's Wenhsin Forest Park that same evening to increase the awareness among Taichung residents about the need to help slow down global warming.

DOC.HEADLINE: COED MURDERESS NOT ELIGIBLE FOR PAROLE UNTIL SEPTEMBER: MOJ

TEXT.P: A woman convicted of murdering her classmate at National Tsinghua University more than nine years ago will be eligible for parole this September, a Ministry of Justice (MOJ) official said Thursday.

The official was responding to a United Daily News report that the Kaohsiung Women's Prison in the southern port city of Kaohsiung had applied for parole for Hung Hsiao-huei, who is serving an 18-year prison term for murdering her classmate Hsu Chia-chen and mutilating her corpse in March 1998 in an auditorium of the prestigious university in Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan.

"The newspaper report is false, " the MOJ official said, adding that the Kaohsiung prison authorities have not filed a parole application for Hung because she will not be eligible for parole until this fall.

Hung was sentenced to 15 years in prison for killing Hsu and three-and-a-half- years for mutilating the body. Her murder sentence is not eligible for commutation under an amnesty statute passed by the legislature earlier this month, but she is qualified to have her mutilation sentence halved.
Following the commutation, the MOJ official said, Hung's prison term will end April 2, 2014.

According to the official, Hung served her time behind bars at Taipei Prison and Taoyuan Prison from January 1999 through March 2001. She was transferred to Kaohsiung Women's Prison March 21, 2001 and has been there since.
The official said Hung has behaved well since her incarceration and has converted to Christianity.

As the best educated inmate at the Kaohsiung Women's Prison, Hung teaches other inmates English and other subjects, prison sources said, adding that she has received citations for quitting smoking and writing Bible and other religious scriptures, as well as winning championships in calligraphy and essay writing.
Prison sources said Hung is unwilling to give any media interviews and looks forward to continuing her graduate studies after regaining her freedom.

In addition to serving a long prison term, Hung has to compensate Hsu's parents with NT$24.17 million. Prison sources said Hung hopes society can forgive her, allowing her to stand on her own feet and save money to repay Hsu's parents.
Hung and Hsu were rivals in a love triangle, but the Taiwan High Court verdict ruled that it was Hung's unauthorized use of Hsu's credit card that led to the murder.

The cold-blooded campus murder shocked society at the time. Both Hung and Hsu were second-year graduate students at Tsinghua University's radiobiology institute at the time of the murder.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
KEY INTEREST RATES RISE BY 0.25 BASIS POINTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central bank raised key interest rates Friday by 0.25 basis points, marking the 12th hike since October 2004.

Following the hike, the discount rate stands at 3.12 percent, the rate on accommodations with collateral at 3.5 percent, and the rate on accommodations without collateral at 5.375 percent, all hitting the highest levels since September 2001.
Also raised Friday is the required reserve ratio on foreign currency deposits, which is up significantly from 0.125 percent to 5 percent.

Central bank officials said the adjustment is aimed at narrowing the wide gap existing between the required reserve ratio on foreign currency deposits and that for Taiwan dollar deposits, which averages 5.3 percent at present.
The move is expected to prompt banks to cut interest rates for foreign currency deposits, slowing down capital outflow and stimulating an appreciation of the Taiwan dollar, market analysts said.

Meanwhile, central bank officials said the hike of key interest rates is warranted give the rise in market rates and the projected increase in inflationary pressure and economic growth in the second half of this year.

Citing forecasts by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the officials said the country's inflation rate is likely to increase from 0.99 percent in the first half of this year to 1.93 percent in the second half, as the rise in wholesale prices gradually feed into consumer prices and unit labor costs return to positive growth.

In addition, with the steady economic expansion in Asia and Europe expected to boost Taiwan's exports, Taiwan's economic growth is projected to rise from 4.27 percent in the first half of this year to 4.48 percent in the second half, the officials said.
Members of the financial sector predicted that the central bank will further adjust the key interest rates upward in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange were lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 5.6 points to close at 8,846.39.
The bourse opened at 8,879.99 and fluctuated between 8,884.03 and 8,799.29 during trading. A total of 5.97 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$179.49 billion (US$5.48 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up most at 3.5 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.5 percent, construction issues at 1 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down most at 2.4 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 883 to 328, with 159 stocks remaining unchanged.

He said that the expenditure is increasing worse than expected and that if he were to re-estimate the 2.5 billion euros of extra tax revenue which would be allocated to welfare measures, the figure would have to be revised downward.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CANDIDATE SUPPORTS TAIWAN'S U.N. CAUSE

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, the presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , confirmed Friday his support of the country's efforts to join the United Nations as "Taiwan."

Hsieh made the remarks while answering questions from reporters after President Chen Shui-bian called Monday for the holding of a referendum along with the 2008 presidential election on Taiwan's U.N. bid, which prompted opposition from the United States.
Asserting that it is by no means his election gambit, Hsieh said rather that it is his long-standing position and that he is also obliged to abide by the party's resolution as a loyal DPP member.

"Taiwan highly treasures the strategic partnership with the United States based upon mutual benefits and interests, and the government, as well as I myself, should better explain the country's U.N. cause to the U. S. side, " Hsieh said, expressing hope that "a national consensus regarding the issue could be forged as soon as possible."
"And this is the reason why a public referendum should be held to set a direction even if the Kuomintang (KMT) or the People First Party (PFP) comes to power in 2008," he argued.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. URGED TO ESTABLISH DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 21 (CNA) 06/22/07 16:03:27 (By Lawrence Chu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Two former advisers to Taiwan's President Chen Shui-bian urged the United States to recognize Taiwan as a sovereign country and establish diplomatic ties.
Peng Ming-min and Wu Li-pei, who is also founder of the Formosa Foundation, made the appeal at a press conference held in Los Angeles.

Wu noted that the main goal of the establishment of the Formosa Foundation five years ago was to challenge the "one China" policy of the United States, and that now the appeal is still more imperative.
Noting that the United States should recognize both China and Taiwan, Wu said it is necessary to tell the American public about the unfair treatment the Taiwanese people is enduring.

According to Wu, more than half of Americans do not even know that there are no diplomatic relations between the United States and Taiwan. Wu noted that it's important to make the American people understand that the establishment of U.S.-Taiwan official ties are crucial to the economic, political and military futures of both countries.

Wu added that 29 Taiwanese young people participating in a series of training courses organized by his foundation will begin visiting U.S. congressmen next week in a bid to lobby for "recognizing and establishing diplomatic ties with Taiwan."

Peng, who teaches some of the training courses, noted that the policy of the United States toward Taiwan is contradictory in that it hails Taiwan's democracy and freedom while refusing to recognize Taiwan diplomatically.

Being that the major U.S. presidential hopefuls are now bringing forward their campaign policies, Peng said it's the proper time for Taiwan to present an appeal to the American people in a bid to change the "one China" policy of the U.S. government.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMAN KILLED AFTER JUMPING IN FRONT OF RUNNING MRT TRAIN

TEXT.P: A woman was killed by a Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) train in Taipei Friday after she jumped off the platform while the train was entering the Longshan Temple Station of the MRT Bannan Line.
According to the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp., the woman showed no signs of life after being pulled out from under the train.

In a preliminary probe, MRT police said they suspected the woman, believed to be named Fang Chun-ying, 48, committed suicide by suddenly jumping in front of a running train so that the vehicle had no time to brake. However, no suicide note was found in her purse, police said, noting the investigation is still ongoing to learn why the woman acted as she did.
The accident affected transportation operations on the Kungyang-Yongning MRT line. At this point, only one track is opened to back-and-forth traffic.
