DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL THINK TANK WARNS ON TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC FUTURE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's electronics industry is facing fierce competition from South Korea, while the local financial services industry is less competitive than that in Hong Kong and Singapore, the head of a private think tank said Friday, suggesting that Taiwan might rank last among the four Asian Dragons.
The four Asian Dragons refer to South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore.
Liang Kuo-yuan, president of the Polaris Research Institute, made the remarks while offering the institute's forecast on Taiwan's economic prospects this year at a press conference.
Liang predicted that Taiwan's economic growth is likely to reach 4.31 percent this year, adding that the manufacturing industry is expected to grow further to 4.82 percent.

However, amidst slowed growth in the construction industry and other industries, the industrial production growth rate will drop to 4.37 percent, while the service industry is expected to register a 4.36 percent rise this year, Liang went on.

Liang noted that the total output of Taiwan's service industry, which accounts for about 72 percent of the total GDP, has not grown as fast as expected in recent years. Moreover, Liang said that Taiwan's economy relies too heavily on the electronics industry, which is encountering strong competition from South Korea,
In addition, the Korean won has been appreciating against the New Taiwan dollar over the years, but Taiwan's export performance is not as good as South Korea's, Liang noted.
"If Taiwan cannot compete with South Korea when it has an advantage in price, what should Taiwan do when it does not have a price advantage?"Liang said.

Giving the institute's forecast on the price of goods, Liang said that the increased price of imported goods has resulted in an increase in the Wholesale Price Index (WPI) and exported goods prices, but not in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and the core CPI.
This year's CPI growth rate is predicted to grow by 1.5 percent, and the inflation pressure is not evident, according to Liang.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDC RECEIVES MORE PURCHASE ORDERS IN PARIS

TEXT.P: The government-owned Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) has received another purchase order for 50 airplane rudders from Dassault Aviation at the Paris Air Show, an AIDC spokesman said Friday.

The order came after the French firm awarded a Certificate of Compliance to AIDC June 18 for the 600th rudder for Falcon series aircraft, which is part of a cooperation project between the two companies.

AIDC has been given more orders thanks to its ability to meet the client's needs for quality and meet the delivery date, the spokesman said, adding that Dassault Aviation is studying the feasibility of outsourcing the manufacturing of other airplane parts to AIDC.
AIDC began the production of rudders for Falcon 50/ 900/ 2000 series passenger aircraft after the two companies signed an agreement in April of 1995, the spokesman said.
AIDC received a Certificate of Quality from Dassault Aviation in June in the following year and delivered the first rudder to the French firm October in that year, he went on.

The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) is also involved in the quality certification and audit of the project, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4TH ASIA REGION CIVIL ENGINEERING CONFAB TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 4th Civil Engineering Conference in Asia Region will be opened at the Taipei International Convention Center next Monday, Chern Jenn-chuan, chairman of the Asian Civil Engineering Coordinating Council which organizes the conference, said Friday.

The conference, which is one of the world's biggest civil engineering conferences, will bring together more than 1,000 representatives from 22 countries, including the United States, Japan, South Korea, Australia, Vietnam, the Philippines, Mongolia, Turkey and Nigeria, Chern said.
The main theme of the conference is "Working toward Asian Sustainability," according to Chern.

During the four-day conference, Chern said, the organizer will confer an award on builders of the Hsuehshan Tunnel, the centerpiece of the 55 km Peiyi Freeway linking the northern county of Taipei and the northeastern county of Yilan, in recognition of their joint efforts in building the 12.9 km tunnel -- the longest highway tunnel in Southeast Asia and the fifth-longest in the world.

The tunnel took 14 years to complete at a cost of more than NT$100 billion (US$3.11 billion), Chern said, noting that it has been dubbed the "tunnel beneath troubled waters" because of the engineering difficulties encountered during its construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE COSTUME DESIGN CONTEST LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese costume design competition aimed at selecting a symbolic costume that best represents Taiwan's unique cultural characteristics is calling for entries, an event organizer said Friday.
The first prize winner will be granted a cash award of NT$300,000 (US$9,090) , according to a spokesman for the Taiwanese Costumes and Etiquette Association which is sponsoring the contest.
In addition, the organizer will arrange to have the winning work made into uniforms for Taiwanese athletes in the 2008 Olympic Games, the spokesman said.

Almost every country around the world has its own clothing style with distinct ethnic characteristics, such as the kimono -- the traditional clothing of Japan -- or the traditional Korean Hanbok and Vietnamese ao dai, the spokesman noted, adding that Taiwan also needs to have a costume in its own style.

Under the auspices of the Ministry of Interior, since 2002, the association has launched a number of activities around the cities of Taipei, Taichung, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Hsinchu to publicize the necessity and significance of creating a symbolic costume of its own.
The spokesman said that the deadline for competition entries is Sept. 30, and all nationals of the country are encouraged to participate regardless of their age and sex.

DOC.HEADLINE: CCA HEAD TO BRING NEW THINKING TO TAIWAN'S CULTURAL POLICY

TEXT.P: The Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) Chairwoman, Wong Chin-chu, who had just returned from a tour of Europe, said Thursday that her travel experience would help her shape Taiwan's future cultural policy.
Wong held a news conference Thursday to discuss her 11-day tour of Europe earlier this month, and to introduce the CCA's future policy on Taiwan's cultural development.

During her trip, Wong bestowed the 11th Taiwan-France Cultural Award on French puppeteer Jean-Luc Penso, who learned puppetry technique from the late Taiwanese puppet master Lee Tien-lu, founder of "Yi Wan Jan Puppet Theater", and established his shadow puppet troupe "Theatre du Petit Miroir" in France in 1978.
The "Yi Wan Jan Puppet Theater" gave a performance featuring anecdotes of Penson's experiences learning puppetry techniques from Lee.

Wong also participated in the 7th OISTAT Theatre Architecture Competition in the Czech Republic, and visited the Documenta 12--the third largest art exhibition in the world--at Kassel city in Germany during her trip.
Discussing future CCA policies, Wong said the CCA will provide integrated services at a single business window to make the services it offers citizens more user-friendly and convenient.

Moreover, Wong said the CCA has set many objectives for Taiwan's cultural development, including reinforcing international exchanges, striving to find performance opportunities for Taiwanese artists, and concentrating its efforts on specific foreign cultural institutes to better promote cultural interchanges.

The CCA will also make the most of domestic culture spaces, protect cultural resources, renovate cultural facilities, and nurture art troupes in central and southern Taiwan to invigorate Taiwan's cultural development, Wong added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOSPITAL SUCCEEDS IN TREATING ALLERGIC DISEASES WITH HERBAL PATCHES

TEXT.P: A traditional Chinese medicine hospital in southern Taiwan claimed Friday that it has achieved good results in treating more than 500 asthma and allergic rhinitis patients with herbal patches.

The Kaohsiung Municipal Chinese Medicine Hospital began to treat patients with bronchial asthma or allergic rhinitis last summer by sticking patches with specially prepared herbal blends to selected acupuncture points on the back on the three hottest days of the year.

The treatment program was launched based on Chinese medicine literature that using this method to treat asthma and allergic rhinitis for three consecutive years can achieve an over 80 percent success rate.
According to Chen Chien-chih, a doctor in charge of the treatment program, the three hottest days of a year come after the summer solstice.

He added that according to the Chinese calendar, the three hottest days of 2007 will fall on July 16, July 25 and Aug. 14, and that these days are believed to be the best opportunities to boost the patients' "yang" energy and strengthen their immune systems.

Chen said the method involves the use of a herbal paste made from a variety of herbs that can help strengthen vital "yang" energy and eliminate pathogens when applied to relevant acupoints, and that a gravely ill patient may receive three extra treatments in addition to the treatments on the three supposedly hottest days.
He said the hospital will continue to use the therapy on patients with asthma and allergic rhinitis this summer, and that interested patients can make reservations for treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAOKONG CABLE CAR TO BE INAUGURATED JULY 4: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: The long-expected Maokong cable car system is scheduled to be inaugurated for commercial operations July 4, if the system passes a battery of tests and checks, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Friday.
Hau made the announcement at a meeting of the city's Bureau of Transportation, held to review the progress of the cable car project.

According to the operator, the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC), the cable car will run from 9:00 a.m. to 22: 00 p.m. on weekdays, and will begin operations a half hour earlier on weekend and holidays, in accordance with the opening hours of the Taipei Zoo, one of the cable car terminals.

In a report on operational drills of the cable car system, which runs from the popular Taipei Zoo to Muzha's Maokong tea-production area, TRTC officials said at the meeting that thunder storms in Muzha were the greatest challenge facing the new transportation system.

When thunder strikes, all 144 cabins of the cable car system must stop running and all passengers be evacuated as soon as possible. This is particularly troublesome as it is difficult to accurately predict thunder storms, the officials said.

To address this problem, the TRTC has consulted with the Taiwan Power Company on how to detect the occurrence of lightning strikes and how long thunder storms, while planning to purchase a lightning detection system, the officials said.

In an attempt to assuage public concerns over the cable car safety, Yang Hsi-an, deputy secretary-general of the city government, said passengers in the cabin will not be affected by thunder storms because the cable care system is equipped with lightning conductors.

According to the city officials, ticket prices for the Maokong cable car line, which will have four stations, have been set at NT$30, NT$40 and NT$50. There is also a "One-Day" ticket available for NT$250 which may be used multiple times in a 24 hour period.
Ticket prices will be reviewed and adjusted 18 months after the cable car system's inauguration, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S U.N. BID AIMED AT PROTECTING STATUS QUO: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Friday the country's plans to apply for U.N. membership under the name of "Taiwan" and to push for a referendum on the bid, in spite of opposition by the United States.

Addressing the issue during an informal gathering with the media at Yilan County's Fushan Research Station under the Taiwan Forestry Research Institute, Chen claimed that the U.N. bid does not violate his commitment to the United States but is aimed at protecting the status quo of Taiwan and the basic human rights of the Taiwanese people.

According to Chen, Taiwan has been barred from the World Health Organization (WHO) mainly because it is not a member of the United Nations, and the situation is becoming "increasingly unfavorable to Taiwan" in light of China's on-going attempts to downgrade Taiwan's status internationally.
As a sovereign state, Taiwan is entitled to appropriate representation in the United Nations, according to Chen.
"We must let the whole world hear the desire and determination of the country's people to safeguard Taiwan's status as a sovereign state," Chen said.
"We must use the name of `Taiwan' to apply to enter the United Nations to protect the status quo from being changed or damaged, " he added.

The fact that opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou has expressed his support for Taiwan's inclusion in the world body indicates that there is a national and cross-partisan consensus on the issue, Chen said.

"As to the areas where consensus is lacking, such as under what name the country should apply to the United Nations, they should be put to a public referendum to allow for the establishment of a common ground acceptable to the majority of people through debate and discussion," Chen said.

Calling the introduction of a referendum system in Taiwan an important step to consolidate and deepen the country's democratic development, Chen said democracy should not only provide people with franchise but also with the right to decide on major public issues.

He said the proposal to hold a referendum on whether the country should apply to the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan" was initiated directly by the people, and that as president, he has an obligation to comply.

Chen said he respects the different opinions that the United States have expressed over Taiwan's U.N. bid and referendum plan, adding that his administration will continue to communicate with Washington to try to sort out the differences.

Chen noted that the first referendum that was held alongside the 2004 presidential election against China's missile threat against Taiwan had likewise sparked great concern in the United States and that he nevertheless resisted the U.S. pressure to make the referendum possible.

Insisting that the government should "walk the right path and do the right thing" despite international pressure, Chen said he will use the final year of his presidential term to blaze a viable trail for the future president so that the new government "will not be afraid of China or the United States."

Taiwan, which failed in its first attempt to gain membership in the WHO under the name of "Taiwan" in May, is planning to use a similar model to apply for U.N. membership in September despite the almost certain prospect of failure.

In response to the move, officials at the U.S. State Department have reiterated that the United States does not support Taiwan's membership in international organizations that require statehood and that Washington "opposes any initiative that appears designed to change Taiwan's status unilaterally, " including a referendum on whether to apply to the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan."
The officials urged Chen to "exercise leadership" by scrapping the planned referendum, which they said would appear to run counter to Chen's repeated commitments to U.S. President George W. Bush.

They were referring to pledges that Chen made during his 2000 and 2004 inaugural addresses that if China has no intention of using force against Taiwan, he will not declare Taiwan independence, will not change the official name of the country, will not include the "state-to-state" concept on cross-Taiwan Strait relations in the Constitution and will not promote a referendum to change the cross-strait status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: PATIENTS WITH MULTIPLE DRUG-RESISTANT TB URGED TO SEEK TREATMENT

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) Friday urged patients infected with multiple drug-resistant tuberculosis (TB) to seek treatment immediately.

Yang Shih-yang, section chief of the DOH Center for Disease Control (CDC), made the appeal as he reported on an HIV-positive man who has been infected with multiple drug-resistant TB, the first such case since the center launched a medical care network for multiple drug-resistant TB patients May 1.
Yang noted that the man is registered with the health authorities as HIV- positive and that he usually resides in central Taiwan. He has never been infected with TB before.
Yang said HIV-positive patients are at high risk of tuberculosis, adding that their risk of being infected with TB is 10 times greater than non-HIV people.
The CD4 T-cells per cubic millimeter of the blood sample of the man was lower than 50, although patients receiving drug cocktail treatment for AIDS usually have cell counts of over 200, Yang said.

CD4 T-cells are a type of lymphocyte that co-ordinate the immune system's response to certain micro-organisms such as viruses. HIV can infect and kill CD4 T-cells, as well as some other types of cell.
Yang said the low CD4 T-cells show that the man's immune system is diminished.
The CDC has quarantined the man and is keeping tabs on those with whom he has had contact, Yang said.
The number of HIV-positive patients had reached 13,742 as of the end of April, according to CDC statistics.
Taiwan has an additional 15,000 TB patients every year, with a mortality rate of about 10 percent. There are currently between 600 and 800 of them who are multiple drug-resistant.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE DETAIN 12 ABSCONDED INDONESIAN WORKERS

TEXT.P: Police detained 12 migrant workers from Indonesia Thursday who illegally ran away from their work and hid out in an apartment in Tucheng City, Taipei County.
According to a spokesman for the police authorities, the 12 laborers -- 11 men and one woman -- were caught together in a small apartment in an industrial park.

An initial investigation showed that all 11 men are fishermen who worked for fishing boats registered in Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties in southern Taiwan before running away to the north. The eldest of them is 37 years old, while the youngest is 25.

The sole 28-year-old female told police in fluent Chinese that she decided to abscond due to the poor salary she was paid. Working as a domestic maid, she said she got only NT$4,000 per month, far lower than the legal minimum of NT$15,000 (US$455).

The woman said that she and her husband, who entered Taiwan a few months later than she did, went into hiding in the Tucheng apartment. The other Indonesian workers who lived with them are friends of the husband who had also absconded due to the poor treatment they received, she added.
Police claimed that someone might be acting behind the scenes, inducing them to run away and helping them hide out in Tucheng.
Policemen from Juifang township in Taipei County raided the Tucheng apartment late Thursday, acting on a tipoff that unknown foreign workers frequented the place.
Police sent 11 of them to a detention center operated by the Immigration Agency in Taipei County, while the remaining one will face the same fate after his identity has been clarified.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS HE NEEDS NO APPLAUSE FOR GRANTING SPECIAL PARDON

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that granting special pardon to the "rice bomber" Yang Ju-men is what he has been wanting to do for the last few years and that he needs no applause from others while doing the "right thing."

Chen made the remarks at a meeting with journalists in Yilan County, northeastern Taiwan, one day after he granted Yang a special pardon after he served less than three years in prison for planting 17 home-made explosive devices around Taipei City during 2003-2004, striking terror into the hearts of city residents.

Yang was dubbed the "rice bomber" as he put a note on each of his bombs expressing his opposition to the government's rice import policy and urging the government to take good care of farmers. Yang said his movement was to arouse the government's awareness of farmers' plight.
Chen said that although Yang's terrorist acts were to be "blamed," his motives were "worthy of sympathy."

Thanking Yang for continuing to remind the government to pay attention to the problems of farmers, Chen said his administration has been doing so, although he admitted that the results "may not be satisfactory to all."

In response to the reports saying that Yang seemed not appreciative of Chen's pardon, as he was expected to be released on parole in October due to good behavior in any case, Chen said he just did what he should do in releasing the bomber.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Im more likely to be assassinated here than in Baghdad, says Blair
Tony Blair believes that he has been in greater danger of assassination on the streets of Britain than in Iraq. In a surprise insight during a series of lengthy interviews with The Times Mr Blair, when asked why he had not worn body armour during a recent visit to Baghdad, said: Its far more likely Ill shake hands with a group of kids today and somebody does something crazy than on a day in Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC REPORTS THIRD IMPORTED CASE OF MEASLES

TEXT.P: The Center for Disease Control (CDC) announced Friday the third imported case of measles this year.
CDC officials said the patient is a 25-year-old man living in southern Taiwan who has been inoculated with the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine twice.
The man has shown no classical symptoms of the measles, which is why his case was only confirmed after two blood tests.

CDC Deputy Director Lin Ting said the man and his girlfriend visited Japan May 19-25. He developed high fever June 4 and a rash on his face June 5. He was discharged from hospital June 11 after treatment.
Lin said that after two MMR shots, the protection effect is about 95 percent, although some people still get measles with milder symptoms.
Lin said that more than 40 family members and friends with whom the man has had contact have not shown symptoms of measles and the CDC estimates that there is no reason to suspect a measles outbreak.
Lin said Taiwan has a high ratio of measles vaccination and that the public have nothing to worry out.

But he suggested that those who plan to travel to Japan make sure they have been inoculated. Children under one year old who have not had the first MMR shot are advised not to travel to Japan, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN LAWMAKER URGES WHO TO INCLUDE TAIWAN IN IHR
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, June 21 (CNA) 06/22/07 19:59:51 (By P.C. Tang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: A member of the European Parliament urged World Health Organization (WHO) Director-General Margaret Chan Thursday to include Taiwan in the International Health Regulations (IHR) , the WHO's global legal framework for infectious disease control.

Miroslav Ouzky, chairman of the Committee for Environment, Public Health and Food Safety of the European Parliament, made the appeal in a statement issued June 20 while attending June plenary session of the parliament in Strasbourg, France.
As the parliament is discussing the IHR, which was passed in 2005, Ouzky said that allowing Taiwan to join the WHO is a very practical issue.
Ouzky made his first appeal to Chan May 3 to express his support for Taiwan's WHO membership.
In the latest statement, Ouzky said the new IHR will be meaningless and will not produce effective results if it fails to include Taiwan.

Ouzky further said in the statement that he asked Chan to take immediate action to establish a focal point in Taiwan to help the world health body make better preparations for preventing and fighting against the threats of epidemic diseases.
Ouzky said a large majority of the members of the European Parliament share his view and have expressed the stance on many occasions.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-BORDER HUMAN TRAFFICKING RING SMASHED, 9 SUSPECTS NABBED

TEXT.P: A cross-border human trafficking ring specializing in smuggling Vietnamese and Chinese citizens into Taiwan for labor exploitation has been smashed through joint operations of police and coast guard personnel, police sources said Friday.

Officers from the Taichung Harbor Police Bureau in central Taiwan, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) and Coast Guard Administration's (CGA's) third and eighth patrol fleets stationed in offshore Penghu County busted the criminals earlier this week after more than two months of intensive probes, the sources said.

Nine ring members and 16 Vietnamese illegal immigrants were rounded up in a series of raids in Taipei County's Chungho City, Taipei City's Songshan District and Penghu County's Hsiyu islet and Chibei waters that began Wednesday, the sources said.

According to the sources, Taichung Harbor police discovered a group of Vietnamese illegals trying to destroy a wooden boat in waters off the Formosa Plastics Group's petrochemical complex in Mailiao, Yunlin County in April.

Their unusual action prompted police into believing that their arrival in the region could not be accidental and could just be the tip of the iceberg of a well-organized criminal operation, the sources said.
Criminal investigation and coastal guard authorities then formed a joint task force to investigate suspected human trafficking operations under the leadership of the Yunlin Prosecutors Office.

After extensive probes, the task force discovered that underworld figures in Vietnam, China and Taiwan had colluded in smuggling Vietnamese people to Taiwan for labor exploitation via Shantou, Guangdong Province in southern China, the sources said.

Chinese snakeheads tended to purchase wooden boats to transport their Vietnamese clients to Taiwan, making the ships mingle with Chinese fishing boats to avoid detection. Once the ships arrived in Taiwan waters, their Taiwanese accomplices would transship the illegals to Taiwan and send them to strictly guarded hideouts.

Taiwanese ring members would then produce bogus identities or marriage certificates for the illegal Vietnamese immigrants and arrange laboring jobs for them. Ring members in Vietnam, China and Taiwan would draw lucrative commissions from brokering the smuggled immigrants into jobs, the sources said.
The ring also smuggled Chinese immigrants to Taiwan through similar routes, the sources said.
Among the apprehended ring members were a Taipei-based Vietnamese nicknamed A-chuan who was responsible for contact with snakeheads in Vietnam and arranging work for the illegals.
Two Taiwanese ring members, nicknamed A-Cheng and A-mei, were accused of specializing in document forgery so that the illegals could find jobs or partners in marriages of convenience.

In Wednesday's raid, coast guard officers stationed in Penghu first spotted four Vietnamese illegals -- two men and two women -- on a road in Hsiyu -- a small islet of the Penghu island group, the sources said, adding that 12 others -- two women and 10 men -- were intercepted Thursday aboard an unnamed Chinese fishing boat off Mutouyu, another Penghu islet.
The discovery led to subsequent raids on the ring's hideouts and the arrest of the key figures, the sources said, adding that no other illegals smuggled in the latest operation remained at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Investors Suits Face Higher Bar, Justices Rule
The Supreme Court on Thursday dealt a blow to investors who want to sue companies and executives because of suspected fraud, setting a higher standard for class-action lawsuits to go forward.
The decision was the second one this week by the court that was a defeat for shareholders and a victory for the defendant companies. On Monday, the justices ruled that securities underwriters on Wall Street are generally immune from civil antitrust lawsuits.
Wall Street Journal:U.S. Labor Leader Aided China's Wal-Mart Coup
As China imprisoned dozens of dissident labor activists after massive worker demonstrations in 2002, an American labor leader decided it was time to embrace China's government-backed unions.
Andy Stern, head of the second-largest U.S. union, began working behind the scenes with the All-China Federation of Trade Unions, which has long been criticized by labor leaders around the world for being more aligned with Beijing's Communist government than with China's workers. His Service Employees International Union helped the Chinese federation successfully organize Wal- Mart Stores Inc., the world's largest retailer, which unions have failed to do in the U.S. enditem

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG RAPID TRANSIT SYSTEM TO BE PARTIALLY OPEN BY YEAR-END

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system's Red Line will open by the end of this year after successful test runs, a spokesman for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) said Friday.

Queried about the progress on construction of the MRT project, the spokesman said the 118-km rail system comprising the Red Line and the Orange Line is almost complete except for three sections totaling six kilometers on the Orange Line.
The spokesman admitted that construction on the Orange LIne is behind schedule because of a collapsed tunnel near Station 7 and water seeping from an underground wall in Station 1.
He predicted that the three unfinished sections will be completed by the end of this year and that passenger services on the line will begin in late 2008.
The Kaohsiung rapid transit system has 66 shield tunnels, 28 underground stations, eight elevated stations and one ground-level station. All the hardware is already in place.
The KRTC has also taken delivery of all the rolling stock and will use 42 carriages on the Red Line later this year, while keeping the remaining 78 for the Orange Line, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE IN FIRST FIVE MONTHS HITS SIX-YEAR LOW: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The average unemployment rate in the first five months of the year hit a new low of 3.84 percent compared with the same period during the last six years, government officials said Friday.

According to officials of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), the May unemployment rate stood at 3.87 percent, an increase of 0.04 percentage points over April, with the number of unemployed registering 413,000.

The average jobless rate in the first five months hit a six-year low compared with the unemployment rate of 5.08 percent in the first five months of 2002, 5.04 percent in 2003, 4.47 percent in 2004, 4.13 percent in 2005 and 3.84 percent in 2006.
The number of employed totalled 10.26 million in May, up 15,000 from April, or 196,000 over the same month of last year.

In terms of sectors, the number of employed during the first five months in the service and industrial sectors increased by 122,000 and 96,000, respectively, over the same period of last year, while that of those employed in the agricultural sector dropped by 20,000.

According to DGBAS statistics, the non-labor force totaled 7.68 million in May, with those studying or preparing for exams reaching 2.24 million, housekeepers totalling 2.38 million and elderly and physical or mentally challenged people totalling 2.13 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRADE, ECONOMIC EXCHANGES COME TO BOTTLENECK: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Trade and economic exchanges between Taiwan and China have come to a political bottleneck that is hindering further progress of exchanges, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tung said Friday.

In an interview with the CNA, Chen said that when Taiwan attempts to open its doors to Chinese tourists, establish direct cross-Taiwan Strait flights, or establish a mutual currency settlement mechanism, it gets trapped in a "political framework" every time it is about to sign an agreement with the relevant Chinese authorities.

He said he expects that Beijing will bring up the question of how to define the nature of planned direct cross-strait flight routes when the two sides begin talks on the issue. "That is a political framework, " Chen noted, referring to China's insistence upon its claim that Taiwan is part of China.

The same challenge also hits talks on the establishment of a currency settlement mechanism, Chen went on, pointing out that since the issue involves the exercise of sovereignty, there is no way for Taiwan and China to reach agreement on the issue unless they resolve their political disputes.

Asked whether the existing restrictions on local investment in China can be relaxed, Chen replied that there has to be a balance between domestic investment and investment in China. Under the current regulations, a local enterprise is only allowed to invest a maximum of 40 percent of the company's total capital in China.

If the situation in which Taiwanese capital flows to China but is not remitted back to Taiwan changes, so that profits made in China are brought back to Taiwan, there will be possibility for the government to consider raising the investment ceiling, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE TO ANNOUNCE RUNNING MATE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou will announce his running mate for 2008 presidential election at a Saturday news conference, a high-ranking KMT member said Friday.

Ma's choice of running mate has caused great speculation after Legislative Speaker Wang Jyn-pyng, who ran for the KMT chairmanship against Ma in 2005, turned down Ma's invitation to be his partner in next year's presidential election.

Rumor has it that Uni-President Group Chief Executive Officer Jason Lin, former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen, former Minister of the Department of Health Chan Chi- shean, National Chi Nan University former President R.C.T. Lee, former presidents of National Cheng Chi University Cheng Jei-cheng and Cheng Ting-wong, and National Taiwan University former President Chen Wei-jao, are all Ma's final choice.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S 1997 PROMISE TO HONG KONG `SHEER LIE': PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the promise Beijing made in 1997 to Hong Kong that it could maintain its lifestyle for 50 years under the "one country, two systems" unification scheme was "a sheer lie."
Chen made the remarks at the Fushan Research Station, a botanic research facility in Yilan County, during a meeting with reporters.
According to Chen, time proves that the promise Beijing made to Hong Kong upon its reversion to Chinese rule 10 years ago was a lie.

Hong Kong people have long been keen to enjoy democracy and direct popular elections, and this is exactly the major key difference between Taiwan and the former British colony, according to Chen. He also blamed Ma Ying-jeou, presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , for harboring unrealistic illusions of China.

Accusing Ma of being totally wrong to insist on promoting Taiwan's dealings with China based on the so-called "1992 consensus," Chen quoted C.F. Koo, ex-Chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, as admitting that it was a term created by former Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi in April 2000.

No high ranking Beijing officials, including former President Jiang Zemin and incumbent President Hu Jintao, or official Chinese documents have acknowledged that the "1992 consensus" refers to "one China, respective interpretations" -- something Ma appears to believe, Chen said.
Accepting the "1992 consensus" means that Taiwan has to yield to Beijing's "one China" principle that would downgrade the country to a province or region of the People's Republic of China, he said.

The president urged Ma and his party to "get to the bottom" of the "1992 consensus" and warned him not try to sell his rhetoric to Taiwan's people in his efforts to push Taiwan to forswear its national sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO OFFER TAIWANESE TOURISTS FREE ETA SERVICE

TEXT.P: Australia will offer Taiwanese tourists free Electronic Travel Authority (ETA) services from July 1, the Australian Commerce and Industry Office (ACIO) announced Friday.
Taiwanese tourists who apply for ETAs -- the equivalent of visas -- will no longer be charged the NT$1,000 application fee, ACIO Visa Services Director Catherine Genn said.
An ETA is issued electronically by a computer system and there is no stamp or label in the passport. Applications for ETAs can be submitted through travel agencies or airlines.

"This is good news following Australia's approval of the import of Taiwanese mangoes last week. And the timing of the announcement is wonderful because of the summer vacation, " said Yu Teh-sheng, deputy director of the Department of East Asia and Pacific Affairs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
According to an ACIO tally, Genn said, 77,000 of the 80,000 visas the office authorized to Taiwanese tourists in 2006 were ETAs. The free ETA service is expected to boost tourist numbers.
However, tourists who apply for ETAs online instead of through ACIO's visa service will still be charged the transaction fee of A$20, she noted.

Taiwan is among a limited number of countries in the Asia Pacific region, which include Japan, Korea, Singapore and Malaysia, that are eligible for ETA services as "low-risk countries" as defined by the Australian government, Genn said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALE FRESHMEN ACCOUNT FOR MOST COLLEGE STUDENT TRAFFIC DEATHS

TEXT.P: Male freshmen account for the majority of traffic deaths among college students, according to the results of a survey released Friday.

The survey was conducted by National Chiao Tung University Professor Wu Tsung- hsiu at the commission of the Ministry of Education (MOE) . The ministry is concerned that accidents have been the major cause of death among college students in recent years, and that traffic accidents accounted for around 60 percent of the deaths.
Wu said random checks on college students who died in traffic accidents show that out of 108 cases, 90 were men and 18 were women.
Forty-one were freshmen, followed by 29 sophomores, 15 juniors and 17 seniors and six post-graduates.
Wu said the higher number of deaths among male freshmen is because freshmen are usually just 18, have just started driving and tend to go out joyriding.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN NOBEL PRIZE WINNER TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Barry Marshall, Australia's most recent Nobel Prize for Medicine winner, will visit Taiwan and seek to inspire Taiwanese students' engagement in science, organizers said Friday in a press conference.

Marshall, 56, and his longtime collaborator Robin Warren were awarded the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 2005 for their discovery of the helicobacter pyroli bacterium and its role in gastritis and peptic ulcer disease. He is scheduled to visit Taiwan June 26-29 and deliver speeches to medical school students and high school students, National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) and Australian Education Center (AEC) announced.

The discovery identified the great majority of gastritis and peptic ulcer cases, which were previously thought to be chronic infections caused by stress and dietary factors, as being caused by the helicobacter pyroli and found that they were curable with just a short regimen of antibiotics.
"The real story about Marshall's visit is about the type of person he is, " said Dean Woodgate, Director of the AEC's education, science and training section.

Marshall was dismissed as "a crazy guy saying crazy things" about his hypothesis at first. To prove his theory, he experimented on himself, ingesting a turbid, foul-tasting solution of helicobacter pyroli.
The story of Marshall is one of a scientist who will do anything to prove his point, said NTUH physician and professor Lin Jaw-town.
"The achievement and story of Marshall represent two distinct characteristics of Australians: we like to give things a go and encourage friendship, " Woodgate said.
Marshall will also meet with President Chen Shui-bian, officials and scholars from the Ministry of Health, the National Science Council and Academia Sinica during his visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAFER TO WALK ON LEFT SIDE OF ROAD: POLICE

TEXT.P: Pedestrians on a road that has no sidewalks should walk on the left side of the road facing oncoming traffic, a spokesman for the Taipei County Police Bureau said Friday.
Citing bureau statistics, the spokesman said the period between January and May saw 934 traffic accidents involving pedestrians in Taipei County, resulting in 17 deaths and 919 injuries.
He noted that many of the accidents occurred when pedestrians were hit from behind by cars and motorcycles traveling in the same direction.
"We would strongly urge pedestrians going down a road with no sidewalks to walk on the left, so that they can see oncoming cars and avoid injuries," the spokesman said.
Another advantage of doing so is that pedestrians, especially women, can avoid falling victim to bag-snatching robbers on motorcycles, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO LAUNCH PACKAGE TOUR AIMED AT JAPANESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: The Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is to launch a package tour to attract more Japanese tourists to Taiwan as part of the government's efforts to promote local tourism and boost "creative life industries," a bureau spokesman said Friday.

The bureau has chosen 11 tourist attractions to feature on the tour said Chang Chin-chung, an official of the bureau's Knowledge Service Division, who added that the bureau hopes to use the tour to introduce Taiwanese culture and nature to Japanese visitors.
The tour is also expected to increase the business turnover of local "creative industries" by 4 percent and to attract investment of NT$25 million (US$756,887) in these industries, Chang noted.

Taiwan has an abundance of natural resources due to its tropical and subtropical climates, as well as cultural assets and traditional arts, Chang said, adding that all of these are of great interest to older Japanese tourists.

Citing statistics compiled by the Tourism Bureau, Chang said Japan was the largest source of visitors to Taiwan in 2005 with 1,163,835 visitors, which accounted for 33.07 percent of the total number of foreign visitors.

Among these Japanese visitors, 70.53 percent named food as Taiwan's leading attration, comparing to 37.94 percent naming the scenery and 30.53 percent naming the historical relics, according to Chang.

However, Chang citred a Japanese survey as pointing out that 83.7 percent of the senior wealthy Japanese tourists liked the natural scenery, followed by 74.4 percent who preferred historical sites and 60.5 percent who wanted to see natural ecosystems or environmental protection-related tours.
Japanese tourists spend an average of US$270 each day in Taiwan, which is much higher than the US$180 spent daily by Hong Kong and Macao visitors, Chang said.

Middle-aged and senior Japanese visitors are generally rich, have leisure time and are more willing to understand Taiwan's culture, Chang said, adding that the bureau will also launch a package tour targeting young Japanese tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP VISITS KINMEN, WARNS OF CHINA'S MILITARY THREAT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu inspected the outlying island of Kinmen Friday, where she warned of the military threat from China.

Lu issued the call during a seminar with local residents and businessmen using direct ferry services from Kinmen to several ports in China's Fujian Province -- part of the popularly known "mini links" that also exist between Taiwan's Matsu island and the Fujian port of Mawei.

In response to Kinmen residents' call for a full opening of the mini links to all Taiwan people rather than just Kinmen residents and select others, Lu urged local people not to ignore the possibility of attacks from China, on the grounds that Beijing has never slowed its military buildup aimed at Taiwan.
Currently, only Kinmen and Matsu residents, as well retired veterans and Chinese spouses of Taiwan citizens, are allowed to travel to China via the "mini links."

Beijing had 50 missiles pointing at Taiwan in 1996 and the number has increased to more than 1,000 at present, Lu said, adding that Taiwan and Kinmen are on the same boat and will share the same fate should China invade.
She urged the Kinmen people to "face up to this reality" and join the central government efforts in creating a "mutually beneficial situation" for Kinmen, Taiwan and China.
However, Lu also promised to relay Kinmen residents' opinions to President Chen Shui-bian, as this was the major purpose of her inspection trip to the island.

Kinmen's hope of transforming into a modern hub in the Taiwan Strait, if successful, will not only help the island catch up with new trends but will also help China dilute its hostility toward Taiwan, paving the way for the three sides to explore new horizons, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI FILM FESTIVAL OPENS

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taipei Film Festival opened Friday, with Lee Yong-ping, director of the Taipei City Cultural Affairs Department saying at the opening ceremony that the festival, the ninth of its kind, has attracted 191 submissions from around the world which is 25 more than last year.
Lee added that this year's festival features more award-winning films than ever before.
Of the entries, 30 have been nominated by a panel of festival judges and will be screened during the 18-day festival at five cinemas in Taipei City and in Panchiao City, Taipei County.
The film screened on the opening night was The Most Distant Course by Lin Jing- jie.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER VINCENT SIEW TO BE MA YING-JEOU'S RUNNING MATE

TEXT.P: Former Premier Vincent Siew will be named by Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou as his running mate, KMT sources said Friday.
Ma is expected to announce his choice Saturday, said the sources.
Siew who had served as the running mate of KMT presidential candidate Lien Chan in 2000 is the chairman of the Chung -Hua Institute for Economic Research now.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY

Today is Saturday, June 23, or the ninth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1537: Spanish explorer Pedro de Mendoza dies at sea on his way
back to Spain from Argentina. He headed an expedition to explore South America, during which he reached the Rio de la Plata area of Argentina and founded Buenos Aires.
1683: William Penn, the English Quaker and advocate of civil and
religious liberty, signs a treaty with chiefs of the Lenni Lenape tribe under an elm tree at Shakamaxon, Philadelphia to guarantee peace for his colony.
1757: British troops under Robert Clive defeat the Nawab of
Bengal, Siraj-ud Dawlah, at the Battle of Plassey, thereby making possible the British annexation of Bengal.
1848: Adolphe Sax, French instrument maker, is granted a patent
for the saxophone, a wind instrument in various sizes with a single-reed mouthpiece and a curved conical metal tube.
1894: British monarch Edward VIII is born. He abdicated in order to marry the divorcee Mrs. Simpson and took the title Duke of Windsor.
1894: Alfred Kinsey, the American zoologist and sociologist best
known for his studies of human sexuality and his books "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male" and "Sexual Behavior in the Human Female," is born.
1912: Alan Mathison Turing, British mathematician and computer
expert, is born. He pioneered the Turing machine, which greatly advanced computer development.
1914: The Kuomintang is reorganized as the Chinese Revolutionary
Party in Tokyo, with Dr. Sun Yat-sen elected
director-general.
1922: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Wu Ting-fang,
who is concurrently governor of Kwantung province, dies of illness in Canton at the age of 81.
1952: The four characters "Wu Wang Tsai Chu," an ancient saying
that translates as "Do Not Forget National Humiliation in Times of Peace and Security" are inscribed on a huge stone at Taiwushan on ROC-controlled Kinmen. The inscription is based on the handwriting of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1956: Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, a man who stands as a symbol of Arab nationalism from the Atlantic Ocean to the Persian Gulf, is elected president of Egypt.
1969: President Chiang Kai-shek nominates Gen. Chen Ta-ching as governor of Taiwan.
1975: The First Television Conference of the Cultural and Social
Center for the Asian and Pacific region opens in Taipei with more than 47 delegates from South Korea, Hong Kong, the United States, the Philippines, Thailand, Kuwait, Australia and the ROC attending.
1975: The Chinese delegation to the 21st Asian Film Festival
returns from Jakarta with seven awards.
1980: Sanjay Gandhi, son of Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi
and next in line for political power, is killed in an airplane crash.
1983: The U.S. Supreme Court rules that Congress cannot veto presidential decisions.
1985: An Air India Boeing 747 jet en route from Canada explodes
off the Irish coast, killing all 329 people on board.
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the National Security Law
during the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion. After the law becomes effective, the Emergency Decree in Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu) is lifted.
1991: The International Monetary Fund agrees to offer associate
membership to the Soviet Union.
1995: American microbiologist Jonas Edward Salk dies in
California at the age of 80. The medical pioneer developed the first effective killed-virus vaccine against polio in 1954.
1999: The ROC and the Republic of Panama sign a press cooperation
agreement in Taipei to step up bilateral relations.
2000: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao meets with
Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, agreeing to strengthen exchanges of ranking officials as a way to further enhance substantive ties between the two countries. a lawyer to protect its legitimate rights in a kickback scandal involving its purchase of six French-made Lafayette-class frigates 10 years ago

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC EXPERTISE OF KMT VP CANDIDATE WINS CROSS-PARTISAN RECOGNITION

TEXT.P: Vincent Siew, who has been named by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou as his running mate, is among a small minority of politicians who has won recognition from across Taiwan's political spectrum because of his strong economic background.

An expert in economic and cross-Taiwan Strait affairs, the 68-year-old Siew served as premier under the former KMT government for three years until the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) came to power in 2000.
In 2002, he was appointed by the DPP government as chairman of the state-funded Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, a position he still holds.
In recent years, Siew has been promoting the establishment of a cross-strait common market to take advantage of the rise of China as an economic giant.
According to Siew, the formation of a cross-strait common market will facilitate Taiwan's entry to the greater China market, which will benefit both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Siew proposes that Taiwan and China normalize their economic and trade relations to pave the way for the removal of unnecessary trade barriers, the provision of preferential treatment for each other and the eventual establishment of a customs union.
To cope with the possible marginalization of Taiwan in the wake of the economic integration of East Asia, Siew advocates developing Taiwan into the world's largest free trade region.
He believes that foreign trade is the lifeline of Taiwan's economy and that only if Taiwan opens itself to the world will it be able to sustain its economic momentum.

Siew suggests that Taiwan should set a good example in the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum by opening its market to other APEC members and welcoming them to invest, manufacture and set up research and development centers in Taiwan, which he believes will help lessen the sensitivity of cross- strait economic and trade activities.

Starting his civil service career as a diplomat in the 1960s, Siew later took up important economic positions in the KMT government, including minister of economic affairs from 1990 to 1993 and chairman of the Council of Economic Planning and Development from 1993 to 1994.
Siew was chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council from 1994 to 1995 and in 1996 he was elected a legislator representing his birthplace, Chiayi City.
During the National Development Conference hosted by then-President Lee Teng-hui at the end of 1996, Siew was the then-ruling KMT's main negotiator with the then-opposition DPP.
He was appointed premier by Lee in 1997 and in 1999, he was named by Lien Chan, then-vice president and the KMT's candidate for the 2000 presidential election, as his running mate.
After the KMT's defeat in that election, Siew was appointed a vice chairman of the party, a position he held until 2005.
Siew's economic expertise has also won the recognition of President Chen Shui- bian, who named Siew as a vice chairman of the Economic Development Advisory Council in 2001.

Chen planned to designate Siew as his special envoy to the informal APEC leadership summit in 2000 but was forced to drop the plan following the DPP government's decision to scrap the fourth nuclear power plant project that year, a move that enraged the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL TICKET `BEST MIRROR' FOR DPP CANDIDATE: VP

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou's selection of former Premier Vincent Siew as his running mate could be the "best mirror" for the ruling party's presidential candidate in picking his running mate, Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday.

Lu, who was on an inspection tour of the outlying island of Kinmen, made the remarks after Ma formally announced his decision to team up with Siew for the 2008 presidential election at a Taipei news conference earlier in the day.

"Siew is one of my 'old colleagues' as we ran for the vice presidency simultaneously in 2000. I congratulate him for his being chosen again to run for the post, " Lu said, adding that she believes that in the KMT ranks, Siew is the best candidate for the post.

As for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's vice presidential candidate, Lu said she is not in a position to address the issue. "Our presidential candidate, Frank Hsieh, should have full freedom to pick his running mate," she added.
Nevertheless, Lu said she feels Hsieh could draw inspiration from Ma's selection of Siew, an experienced economic policy architect, for his ruling expertise.
"In choosing a running mate, one must consider public expectations," Lu said, adding that forming a ticket that lives up to social expectations could be a test of Hsieh's political wisdom.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS ASK FOR INTERPRETATION OF POST COMPANY'S NAME

TEXT.P: Several opposition lawmakers requested Saturday a constitutional interpretation of the re-naming of the nation's state-owned post company earlier this year.
Legislators Lee Fu-tien and Liu Wen-hsiung of the People First Party and Justin Chou of the Kuomintang requested the Council of Grand Justices for the interpretation.

Lee noted that the board of Chunghwa Post Co. approved a proposal to rename the company Taiwan Post Co. and that President Chen Shui-bian and former Premier Su Tseng-chang attended a new plaque unveiling ceremony Feb. 12.

Lee said the Executive Yuan exercised an administrative order to change the name of the post company, and then proposed a bill to ask the Legislative Yuan to revise the law to accommodate the new name.
"This is an infringement of the legislative authority and a clear violation of the principles of division of power enshrined in the Constitution," according to Lee.

Lee said the post company is a state-owned enterprise and the legislature has the right to screen its budget. The Executive Yuan's instruction to change the name will "lead to doubts" in the legislative Yuan's screening of its budget, he said.

The re-naming of the post company is part of the government's campaign to shed the names of state-owned enterprises that contain references to China, in a bid to underscore Taiwan's distinct national identity. "Chunghwa" means "Chinese" or "China" in mandarin Chinese.

Two other state-owned enterprises have had similar name-changes. The China Petroleum Corp. has been changed to "CPC., Taiwan, " while the China Shipbuilding Corp. has been changed to "CSBC Corp., Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: QUESTIONS OVER DPP VICE PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh's choice of running mate is now generating intense speculation now that the ticket of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the 2008 presidential election has been set, DPP sources said Saturday.
KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou announced earlier in the day that former Premier Vincent Siew will be his running mate.

Hsieh's camp said he has no timetable for announcing his running mate, that he is not in a hurry to settle the matter and that he will probably not announce his choice before a party congress in August or September.
"This also shows respect toward the potential running mate," they said.
DPP sources said Hsieh's choice could be former Premier Su Tsang-chang or former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan.

Although Hsieh is widely believed to be tilting toward Yeh, given that Yeh's political career is closely intertwined with his own and that she is a woman and a Hakka -- the second-largest ethnic group next to Hoklo in Taiwan -- the party's calls for Hsieh to team up with Su have not subsided.
Yeh served as vice premier (2004-2005) and as acting mayor of Kaohsiung (2005-2006) , the post in which Hsieh served between 1998 and 2005. Hsieh later served as premier 2005-2006.

DPP sources claimed that only a Hsieh-Su ticket will help mend fences in the wake of the rifts caused by the bitterly contested party presidential and legislative primaries. Such a ticket would be also beneficial to the upcoming legislative and presidential elections, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA REGRETS SINGAPORE'S CRITICISM ON TAIWAN'S U.N. BID REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has expressed deep regret and dissatisfaction Saturday over the Singapore government's opposition to President Chen Shui-bian's proposal to seek a referendum on Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan."

Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement a day earlier that Taiwan's proposal is "provocative and irresponsible" and pointed out that the referendum will only give the people of Taiwan false hope, raise tension between Taiwan and China and reduce Taiwan's international space.

MOFA spokesman David Wang said Singapore's statement is utterly unacceptable, because Taiwan is a sovereign democratic country, the right to referendum is a basic right of the people and other countries have no right to intervene.

In a press released Saturday, the MOFA said that Taiwan, as a sovereign state, is qualified to apply for participation in the U.N. and that the international community should support the country's U.N. bid.

According to the statement, Taiwan's admission into the U.N. under the name "Taiwan" would not mean a change of the nation's official name, as Taiwan participates in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum under the name "Chinese Taipei" and is a member of the World Trade Organization under the name "Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu," with no official name-change.

Wang said that China, instead of Taiwan, should be considered the biggest threat to the status quo and regional peace because it deploys thousands of missiles against Taiwan and its national defense budget continues to grow in double digits.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange were lower Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 33.48 points to close at 8,812.91.
The bourse opened at 8,817.4 and fluctuated between 8,833.63 and 8,790.76 during trading. A total of 4.6 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$118.19 billion (US$3.61 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 0.5 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.4 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.3 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by banking and financial shares and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.5 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 588 to 563, with 205 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE EXPECTS RUNNING MATE TO ENGINEER ECONOMIC REVIVAL

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou expressed the expectation Saturday that his running mate, Vincent Siew, will play the role of "chief engineer" of the country's economic revival if the ticket wins the 2008 election.

Making the remarks while announcing the former premier as his running mate, Ma said he is honored to be able to win Siew's consent to team up with him, in light of Siew's extensive administrative experience and remarkable contributions to Taiwan's economic development.
Ma said he hopes Siew will use his experience to seek a way out of Taiwan's economic impasse rather than serving simply as a deputy with only limited formal power.

Siew, a technocrat who served as a diplomat for 10 years and an economic official for 30 years, sailed the country through the Asian financial crisis under his premiership in the late 1990s, Ma noted.

Other achievements that Siew attained during his premiership included applying for Taiwan's entry to the World Trade Organization, building the country's fifth naphtha cracking plant and kicking off the high-speed railway project.
"After seven years under the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , people are starting to miss `smiling Siew' -- a composed helmsman who led Taiwan through a crisis," Ma said.

According to Ma, owing to his concern for Taiwan's economy, Siew did not turn down the DPP's offer for him to serve as an advisor to the national economic development conference and as the country's representative at an informal leadership summit of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.
However, Ma blamed the DPP for not accepting the advice put forth by Siew, a situation Ma said is responsible for the economic problems faced by the country today.

On criticism that the running mate choice lacks "novelty" -- given the fact that Siew also served as the running mate of then-KMT presidential candidate Lien Chan in 2000, Ma said he does not care whether his partner is a new face or an old face because experience and talent are what he values.
Meanwhile, Siew said Ma met with him several times over the past few weeks to invite him to serve as running mate and that he was deeply moved by Ma's sincerity.

Siew said that although he has left the civil service, his concern for Taiwan's economic development continues, adding that he shares Ma's ideas of giving priority to economics and the people's livelihoods.
Siew pledged he will work hard for a KMT victory in the 2008 presidential election for the well-being of the people.

According to Ma's close aides, Siew's economic background and his credentials as a native Taiwanese from Chiayi complement Ma's image as a mainlander descendant and can help expand Ma's support base in southern Taiwan.

As Siew has put forth the idea of "Republic of China equals Taiwan, " upholds the Taiwanese identity and has taken part in various international economic and trade conferences as chairman of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, it will be more convincing to the voters if Siew promotes Ma's cross- strait and economic policies, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Saturday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved down 55 points to close at 8,770, with 19,549 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for August dropped 48 points to finish at 8,739, with 284 contracts traded, while September futures lost 42 points to close at 8,690, with 74 contract transactions. December futures moved down 38 points to close at 8,697, with 16 contracts traded, while March futures dropped 24 points to finish at 8,688, with eight contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Saturday at 8,825 for July, 8,787 for August, 8,732 for September, 8,735 for December and 8,712 for March.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

July TE futures moved down 1.9 points to close at 378.65, with 1,796 contracts traded, while August TE futures lost 1.55 points to finish at 376.7, with 11 contract transactions. September TE futures increased 0.45 points to close at 377, with two contract transactions, while March TE futures moved up 3.35 points to finish at 372, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for December.

July TF futures dropped 4.8 points to close at 1,032.6, with 2,855 contracts traded, while August TF futures lost 2.4 points to finish at 1,032.6, with 26 contract transactions. September TF futures moved down 11 points to close at 1,027, with eight contracts traded, December TF futures decreased 33 points to end at 1,010.2, with one contract transaction. March TF futures moved down 23.8 points to close at 1,010.2, with one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMY SHOULD BE THEME OF NEXT GOVERNMENT: ASSOCIATION HEAD

TEXT.P: Whoever wins the 2008 presidential election, the development of the economy should be the theme of the next government, the chairman of the powerful Taiwan Electrical and Electronics Manufacturers' Association said Saturday.

Arthur Chiao made the remarks after main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou named former Premier Vincent Siew as his running mate earlier that day, saying that he hopes to make use of Siew's economic and financial expertise to revitalize the economy.
Chiao expressed the hope that Siew will help upgrade Taiwan industry's competitiveness amid ever-fiercer global competition.

He noted that Siew was previously deeply involved in Taiwan's economic development and said that although he has not been active in politics recently, he is concerned about industrial development in Taiwan and has put emphasis on an open economic environment.

Chiao recalled some of the things Siew has done that impressed him most, including the promotion of the build-operate-transfer model for the nation's first high speed railway, which was officially launched this January.
Siew also helped Taiwan emerge relatively unscathed from the Asian financial crisis of the late 1990s, he said.

Siew advocated the Asia-Pacific operations hub project and promoted the low energy consumption, capital-intensive and technology-intensive concepts that are followed by many countries today, Chiao said.

He also said relations with China are closely intertwined with Taiwan's economic development and that the future leader of Taiwan must see to it that Taiwan's economy is not subject to restrictions in cross-strait exchanges.
"The government needs to work in tune with the changing times, "he said.
He noted that a lot of policies might be correct at the time of their formulation but need to be adjusted with time.

He cited the example of a cap of 40 percent for local investment in China, saying that the restriction might have been reasonable five years ago, but might no longer be suitable for the present situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 71% POLL RESPONDENTS SUPPORT U.N. BID UNDER NAME OF `TAIWAN'

TEXT.P: Seventy-one percent of the people who answered a recent survey said they support a proposal to put forward a bid for Taiwan's membership in the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan" in September when the U.N. General Assembly is held in New York.

The issue has triggered public concern over Taiwan's diplomatic situation since the United States expressed its opposition Monday to President Chen Shui-bian's resolve to push for a referendum on the U.N. bid under the "Taiwan" designation.

The private Institute for National Policy Research (INPR) , a think tank, conducted the poll on Taiwan's diplomatic prospects June 15-16 in which 1,070 effective questionnaires were collected, with a margin of error of three percentage points.

According to the survey results, 48 percent of the respondents said they agree with the idea that China's diplomatic suppression of Taiwan will increase and that the suppression will continue no matter which political party wins the 2008 presidential election.

Sixty-eight percent of the respondents said they know Beijing spent NT$14 billion (US$427 million) to buy diplomatic recognition from Costa Rica, attributing this to the severance of the 63-year-old diplomatic partnership between Taiwan and the Central American country June 6.

Seventy percent said China has never stopped trying to damage Taiwan's friendships with foreign countries, lock Taiwan out of influential international organizations, suppress Taiwan in every different field and hurt Taiwan people's feelings.

Meanwhile, 87 percent said Taiwan, as a sovereign country, does not need to seek China's consent before seeking membership in major international organizations, and 77 percent of the respondents expressed disagreement with the notion that Taiwan is part of the People's Republic of China.

Asked what Taiwan should do to expand its diplomatic relations, 57 percent of the respondents said it should boost civic exchanges with foreign countries and international groups, 48 percent said it should join international organizations, 43 percent said it should make efforts to maintain relations with the United States, Japan and Europe, and 23 percent said it should try to get more diplomatic allies.

Analyzing the poll results, Cheng Duan-yiao, director of National Chengchi University's Institute of International Relations, said that the results show not many people see "increasing diplomatic allies" as an important diplomatic task.

Quoting the survey results, Cheng said many people now think that it is more important for Taiwan to engage in pragmatic international exchanges than to seek diplomatic allies, which suggests that people want the government to take practical diplomatic approaches.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VISITS LOCAL LAWNMOWER COMPANY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian visited a local lawnmower factory in Taichung County Saturday to learn about traditional metal manufacturing operations as part of a grassroots community outreach tour program.
Chen paid a visit to Fu Shin Metal Co. in the county's Waipu township and was warmly welcomed by the company's staff and Chairman Chen Min-tuo.
Executive director of the Central Taiwan Joint Services Center under the Executive Yuan, Lin Feng-shi, and Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai accompanied Chen on his tour.

The company was established in 1976 to produce bicycle parts and underwent a business transformation in 1991 when that industry relocated, manufacturing lawnmowers, portable sprayers, drilling machines and suction pumps, with its products sold in both the domestic and foreign markets.
The firm's factory director, Chen Teng-tien, who won the 1998 Tour of Taiwan -- an annual international cycling race -- gave detailed explanations to Chen about the company's operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC CHECKING FOR HARMFUL INGREDIENTS IN `CRYSTAL BABIES'

TEXT.P: The Consumer Protection Commission (CPC) said Saturday it has requested the relevant authorities to test a popular chemical product called "crystal babies" that is popular among local school children, in the wake of reports that the product has caused allergic reactions in some children.
According to Liu Ching-fang, a section chief at the commission, the results of the tests are expected to be out within three days.
If any harmful ingredients are discovered in the product, the CPC will order a recall of the product and the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will also punish the manufacturers, Liu said.
Liu said the so-called "crystal babies" are a kind of acrylic polymer originally designed to be used in aquariums as a soil substitute.

However, owing to the strong absorbent properties of the product, the tiny, colorful balls split after absorbing a certain amount of water. This phenomenon, which to children apparently appears similar to reproduction, has made them popular as "pets," Liu said.
Noting that the MOEA's Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection does not classify the product as a toy, Liu urged consumers not to let their children play with it.

DOC.HEADLINE: VEGETABLE PRICES EXPECTED TO STABILIZE BY END OF JUNE

TEXT.P: Leafy vegetable crops have completely recovered in central and southern Taiwan after vegetable fields there were inundated two weeks ago by flooding caused by heavy rain, Council of Agriculture (COA) officials said Saturday.
The new crops are expected to reach market by the end of the month, the officials said, noting that by then, the fluctuating vegetable prices will have stabilized.
In early June, Changhua and Yunlin counties, two of the country's major vegetable production areas, sustained heavy losses of leafy vegetables due to the flooding, resulting in a supply shortage.

With assistance from the COA Agriculture and Food Agency, farmers in the flood- affected areas began work to restore cultivation as soon as the water receded and are expected to harvest by the end of June thanks to sunny weather over the past few weeks, the COA officials said.

To ensure non-stop vegetable supplies to the domestic market, the agency has been assisting local vegetable farmers since 2005 in building protection facilities on their fields, including plastic net houses.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Saturday, falling NT$0.018 to close at NT$32.736.
A total of US$413 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.655 and fluctuated between NT$32.645 and NT$33.765.

DOC.HEADLINE: RIVAL'S CHOICE FALLS OUTSIDE EXPECTATION: DPP CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said Saturday his counterpart's choice of running mate "falls outside his expectation."
Hsieh was commenting in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, on opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou's announcement of his running mate, former Premier Vincent Siew.

Hsieh said that public opinion polls conducted by himself show that every one of Ma's running mates mentioned previously, including Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, former Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen, former National Taiwan University President Chen Wei-chao and Uni-President Enterprise CEO Lin Chang-sheng, would be a big boost to Ma.
"But Wang definitely comes out on top, although the KMT has turned him away," Hsieh claimed.
Hsieh said Siew, a Hoklo, will be a plus for Ma, who was born in Hong Kong, in terms of winning ballots from the Hoklo, the largest ethnic group in Taiwan.

He also claimed that Siew contributed to Taiwan's economy during what he described as the "early years, " when Taiwan played the role of the world's factory and used fast-track development to stimulate rapid economic growth.

But Taiwan "has long passed that period. At the present stage, political stability, social justice, clean environment and the upgrading of mutual trust between people are equally important, " he said.
"The emphasis now should be on a high-quality nation and an economy that will make people happy," he added.

Noting that Ma has touted Siew's advocacy of the formation of a cross-strait common market to facilitate Taiwan's entry into the greater China market, Hsieh claimed that this means the introduction of laborers from China, to which he is opposed.
"What Taiwan needs to introduce is capital and more investment so that the value of the laborers will be upgraded," he said.
Asked whether he will announce his running mate any time soon, he said that after seeing Siew's name, "we are not in a hurry."

Meanwhile, a major caucus whip of the DPP in the legislature claimed that the "Ma-Siew" ticket is a game of the "high-class society, " which he described as deviating from the "mainstream views of society."
Ker Chien-ming said he was surprised to see that the KMT is suffering "a dearth of talent" and is "putting old wine in new bottles."

Ker noted that Siew served as the running mate of former Vice President Lien Chan in the 2000 presidential election and finished a distant third that time, and said Ma is now trying to "copy the defeat experience."
Lee Ying-yuan, manager of Hsieh's campaign office, also lashed out at Ma for trying to use "smiles to cover up his own corruption, " referring to the nickname of his partner -- " Smiling Siew."

Lee said that Ma, after playing up the issue of his running mate for months, hastily announced his partner on the eve of a party congress, which is set to approve a revised party charter tailored to allow Ma to continue running for president even if he is convicted of corruption.

Ma, who served as Taipei mayor for two terms between 1998 and 2006, was indicted earlier this year for alleged misuse of the mayoral "special allowance fund" for his discretionary use. The KMT is revising the party charter, which bars KMT members found guilty in the first trial from representing the party in elections.

DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Britain hails EU deal
European leaders struck an outline deal on the future of the EU at midnight last night after Britain won a legal exemption from a new rights charter and Gordon Brown intervened directly to thwart French efforts to weaken competition laws.
