La Repubblica: EU leaders agree on outline of new treaty.
European Union leaders reached accord on an outline of new rules for the 27-member bloc after two days of talks in Brussels.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD VICE CHAIRMAN INSPECTS CHIAYI CITY TO ASSIST IN URBAN RENEWAL

TEXT.P: The vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) inspected the area surrounding the railway station of Chiayi City, southern Taiwan, Saturday, as the land is listed in the city's urban renewal program.

Chang Jing-sen made the inspection accompanied by Chiayi Deputy Mayor Lee Hsi- chin, as well as officials of the Taiwan Railway Administration, the Taiwan Forestry Bureau's Chiayi district office, and other relevant government representatives, after the city requested central government assistance with urban renewal.

The mission took Chang to an Alishan railway repair workshop, a fish market, a vegetable and fruit market, a park and a preserved area housing old governmental forestry institutions. During the tour, Chang praised the city as one of the few cities in Taiwan that have such forestry conglomerates.

The city, which is the door to the scenic Alishan mountain resort area, still has a huge lumber storage center built during the Japanese colonial era, Chang said. He suggested that the local government preserve and restore the city's forestry-related historic architecture, which he described as valuable cultural and tourism resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: NIA TO ISSUE ELECTRONIC ALIEN RESIDENT CARDS FROM JULY 1

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency (NIA) will begin issuing electronic alien resident certificates (ARCs) embedded with advanced anti-forgery microchips to replace the existing paper cards from July 1, an immigration official said Saturday.

Noting that the move is congruent with general world trends, the official said it will not only bring new convenience to foreigners but will also contribute to the government's anti-forgery and anti-terrorism drives.

In the initial stage from July 1 through Dec. 31, the official said, the NIA will only issue new ARCs with integrated circuit (IC) chips to new applicants and those who apply to replace older or lost ARCs.
The fees for the new ARCs will remain unchanged at NT$1,000 (US$30.30) per year.

Responding to calls by foreign expatriates for lower prices for ARCs, the official said the fees are reasonable and much cheaper than those exacted in many other countries, including the United States, Canada, New Zealand, Australia and Japan.
In the second phase from Jan. 1 to Dec. 31, 2008, the official went on, all existing ARC holders will be required to exchange their old paper cards for the electronic ones.

The official said the new ARC measures will also apply to the more than 330,000 foreign blue-collar workers employed by manufacturing and construction companies as well as caregivers hired by families with patients in need of long- term care.

According to the official, the new IC ARCs are designed in line with the electronic international ID cards (eID cards) adopted in advanced countries to help speed up customs clearance and prevent forgery as well as help stave off possible terrorist activities.

NIA data shows that Belgium, Sweden, Italy, Finland, Estonia, Hong Kong, Mexico, Saudi Arabia and United Arab Emirates have issued eID cards while the United States, Germany, Norway and Denmark have issued e-passports to prevent forgery and fight terrorism, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY TO CELEBRATE PHILIPPINE CULTURE

TEXT.P: A Philippine Cultural Festival that includes a parade, song and dance performances and a Miss Talent contest will be held in downtown Taipei Sunday to celebrate Philippine culture, the Taipei city government's Department of Labor announced Saturday.

The celebration, which is a part of the 2007 Southeast Asian Cultural Activities series organized by the Migrant Workers' Cultural Center (MWCC) , is held to ease the homesickness of the more-than 8,000 Filipino workers in Taipei City and to foster bilateral understanding between Taiwanese and Filipinos, said Department of Labor Commissioner Su Yin-kuei.

The first event will be a cultural parade that starts from St. Christopher's Church going to the Taipei Art Park, where the remaining activities will take place. To highlight the diversity of Philippine culture, there will be song and dance performances by various indigenous tribes, as well as a choir from St. Christopher's Church and foreign groups.
A Miss Talent contest will also take place, with the final winner getting a Taipei-Manila round-trip ticket and cash.
The Taiwan government has been very supportive of foreign workers, according to Reynaldo Gopez, labor representative of the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO).

Father Romeo Velos from St. Christopher's Church, where thousands of Filipino Catholics gather every Sunday for Mass, said the international community is no loner homogeneous and that foreign workers are not only laborers and strangers.
"They are, at the same time, residents and our brothers and sisters, " Velos said.

June 24 is Manila Day in the Philippines, Department of Labor official Victoria Huang said. In addition to the Philippines, the department also organizes similar cultural events for workers from Indonesia, Vietnam and Thailand every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA HOPES TO CONVINCE U.S. OF TAIWAN'S U.N. BID REFERENDUM: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 22 (CNA) 06/23/07 19:53:14 (By Jorge Liu and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will continue to attempt to persuade the United States to understand the need for President Chen Shui-bian to seek a referendum on Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan, "a MOFA official said Saturday.

Taiwan's Deputy Representative to the United States Huang Wei-feng made the remarks to reporters after attending a seminar at George Washington University, in response to the U.S. State Department's opposition to Chen's referendum proposal.
U.S. State Department Spokesman Sean McCormack said Tuesday that such a referendum would raise tension between Taiwan and China.

Huang explained at the seminar that Taiwan government decided to strive for entry to the U.N. and the World Health Organization under the name of "Taiwan" this year after having sufferd many setbacks in its bids to join various world bodies in the past decade.

Responding to questions about the necessity of holding a referendum -- since poll results already show public support for Taiwan's U.N. bid -- Huang said that a referendum can "truly show the people's will" because it is active involvement compared with passively answering poll questions via telephone.

Huang said it is understandable that the U.S. does not agree to Taiwan's referendum proposal but said the MOFA will keep communicating with the U.S. to let it know the referendum proposal is "the will of the people of Taiwan" and that the government has to "respect the people's decision."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE'S CHOICE DRAWS MIXED REACTIONS WITHIN OWN CAMP

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou's choice of former Premier Vincent Siew as his running mate has drawn mixed reactions from within the party but has won support from its ally, the People First Party (PFP), and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU).

KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng were optimistic about the Ma-Siew ticket, saying that Siew's financial and economic expertise, as well as his ability in handling crises will boost the party's chance in winning the 2008 presidential election.
Liu Wen-hsiung, a caucus whip of the PFP, said the ticket represents the combination of integrity and financial expertise, which he described as "worthy of expectations."

NPSU Chairman Lin Ping-kun noted that Siew comes from an impoverished family in Chiayi, giving him a background close to the grassroots, and said that even if it is not a plus, it is at least not a minus.

But some KMT members expressed worry, saying that while Siew definitely will complement Ma in terms of his financial expertise and his being a Hoklo -- the largest ethnic group in Taiwan -- "the biggest problem of this ticket is that it is not fresh enough, given the current volatile Taiwan society and the preferences of the electorate."
Some even said that "they are bracing for a drop in approval ratings for the KMT ticket in the next couple of days."
KMT legislators Su Chi and Lin Yu-fang were positive about the team's strength, saying that it will be a boost to the party and Taiwan's economy.

Su said that a "new" running mate is not necessarily the best choice, while Lin said that Siew's solid economic and political background and his coming from Chiayi, as well as his less distinctive political and party stripes, make him a suitable choice.

But several other KMT legislators, including Chu Chun-hsiao, Hsu Hsu-po and Hsu Chung-hsiung, expressed worry that the ticket will not be strong enough to get out the vote other than in Chiayi in southern Taiwan, traditionally a stronghold of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REOPENS DOORS TO CANADIAN BEEF WITH STRICT CONDITIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan reopened its doors to Canadian boneless beef from cattle under 30 months of age Saturday, ending a three-and-a-half-year import ban on Canadian beef out of concern over mad cow disease.

Hsieh Ting-hung, deputy director of the Bureau of Food Safety under the Department of Health (DOH) , said Canadian beef entering Taiwan must bear health and hygiene certification issued by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CIFA) and must be handled and packed by DOH-approved slaughterhouses and packaging facilities in Canada.
Moreover, Hsieh said, the beef should be free of all bone and other animal parts regarded as high-risk in terms of the deadly disease. These parts include principally brains and spinal cords.

Taiwan issued an import ban on beef from Canada, the United States, Japan, Britain and several other European Union countries Dec. 31, 2003 amid fears over the threat of Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE), also known as mad cow disease.

The Canadian government applied to the DOH in March 2004 for lifting the import ban, Hsieh said, adding that the DOH agreed to reopen the doors to Canadian beef with stringent restrictions only after holding 11 rounds of consultative meetings with health experts in terms of BSE prevention measures unveiled by the World Health Organization and the World Organization for Animal Health.
Moreover, Hsieh said, the DOH had sent personnel to Canada for field study and comprehensive assessment before deciding to lift the ban.

Besides demanding the Canadian government produce regular reports on its enforcement of BSE prevention and control measures, Hsieh said the DOH has also asked relevant government agencies, including the Ministry of Economic Affairs, to step up beef safety inspection and crack down on smuggling.

City and county health bureaus have also been ordered to intensify inspection of supermarket chains and hypermarts to check whether Canadian beef imports meet relevant DOH regulations or requirements.
As of Saturday, Hsieh added that only beef from the United States, New Zealand, Australia and Canada is allowed to enter Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN `GREEN ENERGY' INDUSTRY HAS BRIGHT FUTURE IN DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's "green energy" industry's annual output value is expected to reach NT$152.4 billion (US$4.65 billion) by 2009 as Taiwanese enterprises have been continuing to expand their investments in the sector with the government's encouragement, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials said Saturday.

Environmental protection has become an important issue worldwide after signs that the global warming is worsening as the greenhouse effect expands. Out of environmental protection concerns, more and more people around the world are turning to non-polluting, recycled green products, the officials said.

The green-purchasing trend has changed enterprises' passive attitude toward environmental protection to an active and aggressive attitude and they have begun injecting money into research and production of so-called green products such as renewable energy and technology to cut down carbon dioxide emissions, the officials said.

In the green trend over the past few years, the world's investment in the green energy industry has risen from the level of US$28 billion in 2004 to US$71 billion in 2006, representing a 1.5-fold increase, the CEPD said, touting the sector as a rising star in global investment.

In Taiwan, the annual production value of the green energy sector amounted to NT$92.96 billion in 2006, posting a growth of 40 percent over the previous year, while that of the environmental protection services sector grew from NT$39.63 billion in 2004 to NT$57.39 billion in 2005, the officials said.

In the government's planned efforts to push for the emerging industries' development, the green output is expected to increase to NT$152.4 billion in green energy production and NT$70.9 billion in environmental protection services by 2009, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Militants Said to Flee Before U.S. Offensive
The operational commander of troops battling to drive fighters with Al Qaeda from Baquba said Friday that 80 percent of the top Qaeda leaders in the city fled before the American-led offensive began earlier this week. He compared their flight with the escape of Qaeda leaders from Falluja ahead of an American offensive that recaptured that city in 2004.
In an otherwise upbeat assessment, Lt. Gen. Raymond T. Odierno, the second- ranking American commander in Iraq, told reporters that leaders of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia had been alerted to the Baquba offensive by widespread public discussion of the American plan to clear the city before the attack began.
Wall Street Journal:Bear Stearns Bails Out Fund With Big Loan
Bear Stearns Cos.'s dramatic decision to lend as much as $3.2 billion to one of its two troubled hedge funds staves off the risk of a fund collapse that could have damaged its position as a major Wall Street bond player -- and had the potential to ripple through a jittery subprime-mortgage market.
The loan on Friday came only after days of high -stakes brinksmanship with some of Wall Street's biggest players. All wanted to protect their stakes in the hedge funds, but they worried as well that a liquidation of the funds -- which invested heavily in subprime-mortgage assets -- risked igniting a broader panic in the mortgage- bond market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA, PRESS REVIEW HONG KONG'S RETURN TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's "democracy and press freedom" have been continuously regressing since its return to China and there is no sign of possible improvement at this moment, scholars and journalists from Hong Kong and Taiwan said Saturday in asymposium.

As Hong Kong was the model city in Asia for its cultural diversity and economic development in the 1980s and 1990s, now it looks like Taiwan in the 1950s and 1960s, political wise, said Tung Li-wen, a professor and the vice president of Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, in a syposium one week before the 10th anniversary of Hong Kong's handover to China.
The United Kingdom returned control of Hong Kong to China on June 30, 1997, signifying the end of British ruling for over 100 years.

July 1, 2003, when half a million Hong Kong residents marched on streets to protest against the Basic Law that had stripped away the basic civilian freedom, was an important date in Hong Kong history, Tung said.
"Before that day, Chinese government didn't think the governence of Hong Kong is a big problem. After that, it knew Hong Kong would be abig problem, " he said.

"The past 10 years of Hong Kong can be summed up with three characteristics: inconsistent economy, regressed democracy, and diverted media, " said Paul Lin, a political commentator who fled from China to Hong Kong and now lives in Taiwan.

China's failed experience in Hong Kong was the main reason why it had never mentioned that Hong Kong's "One country, two systems" framework would serve as a good example for Taiwan after 2003, Tung noted.
"It is also interesting that 'chief executive' has become a term of insult and "SAR" (special administrative region) basically means puppet regime in Taiwan, " he added.

Donald Tsang, chief executive of the Hong Kong Special Administration Region, is smart to direct people's attention to economy instead of politics, Lin said. However, Hong Kong's economy was not as optimistic as it seemed since it had relied heavily on China since 1997, he stressed.

A number of Hong Kong press members lamented about self-censorship and self-restraint of Hong Kong media. Because of China's tighter control and interference, Hong Kong's press freedom has dropped to 66th in the world in 2006 in the independent Freedom House survey, said Woo Lai Wan, chairperson of Hong Kong Journalists Association.
Woo called for a "never retreat" mentality against the oppression from China for Hong Kong and Taiwan media alike.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES U.S. HOUSE APPROVAL OF EASING CURBS ON TAIWAN CONTACTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) welcomes a proposal passed by the U.S. House of Representatives Thursday that would eliminate a long list of U.S.-imposed restrictions on contacts with Taiwan, MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said Saturday.
The House acted by adding an amendment to a bill funding the U.S. State Department and other diplomatic operations for next year.

The amendment, introduced by Republican Representative Tom Tancredo, demands removal of the guidelines drafted by the U.S. State Department that have restricted official contacts with Taiwan since the United States switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979.

The guidelines bar the top Taiwan leader from visiting the United States (only transit stops are permissible) , prohibit Taiwan's foreign minister from visiting Washington, D.C., ban Taiwanese diplomatic personnel and legislators from entering the White House and the State Department, and forbid U.S. executive branch officials from attending functions sponsored by Taiwan's representative office in Washington, D.C.
In response, Wang said the Republic of China government welcomes and appreciates the House passage of the amendment proposal.

"We keenly hope that the U.S. ruling and opposition camps can reach consensus on the issue soon so that the various diplomatic curbs can be lifted to facilitate bilateral communications and engagements," Wang said.
The funding bill will now be referred to the Senate for deliberation and approval. The House passed a similar proposal last year, but the proposal failed to make the Senate's agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN COUNTY CHIEF TO VISIT JAPAN FOR EXPORT PROMOTION

TEXT.P: Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih will depart for Japan Sunday for a visit aimed at promoting exports of the southern Taiwan county's farm produce, mangoes in particular, local officials said Saturday.

It will be the fourth consecutive year that Su has visited Japan to boost sales of his county's specialty farm products, including Irwin mangoes, mulberry juice, Tungshan coffee, mango pudding, mango preserves and other fine-quality farm produce, the officials said.

Thanks to concerted efforts of the Council of Agriculture, the county government, fruit farmers and traders, Su said Tainan-grown mangoes have met the excessively stringent Japanese quality requirements, including no pesticide residues.

"A produce traceability system has been implemented this year to ensure good quality of our mangoes. We are confident that our produce can pass strict Japanese pesticide residue tests, " Su said, adding that each mango to be exported to Japan carries a label on which the place of origin, the name of producer, product number and Web site are clearly stated.
Moreover, Su said, major Tainan mango farmers associations will cooperate with Japanese importers in launching home delivery services to boost sales.

Su will be traveling along with a delegation of county government officials and representatives of local farmers associations. During the June 24-30 visit, Su said the delegation will organize mango culture festival activities to introduce the county's special farming culture and customs to Japanese consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PALACE MUSEUM TREASURES FEATURED IN NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC DOCUMENTARY

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum (NPM) in suburban Taipei has collaborated with National Geographic in producing a documentary on its vast trove of art treasures to be introduced to international audience, museum curators said Sunday.

It marks the first time that the museum-- home to the best of the 1,000-year-old art collection of China's emperors -- has cooperated with an international media outlet to film its magnificent holdings for presentation to TV audience around the world, NPM Director Lin Mun-lee said.
Noting that the NPM houses the world's most famous collection of Chinese art, Lin said the hour-long documentary will provide a fascinating glimpse into the finest of Chinese cultural heritage.

The film features three spheres of focus -- the history of the museum's huge and versatile art collection, the epic-like story of the museum's emigration from China to Taiwan and how the museum has harnessed modern technology to display its invaluable art objects in fresh, dynamic ways to the public, Lin said.

National Geographic has sent a seasoned crew to produce the film, including Mike Barrett, writer and producer of the project; Jamie Hamill, director of photography; Christopher Slaughter, managing director; and Jonathan Schutz, director.

According to NPM curators, the National Geographic feature has not only catalogued the museum's priceless art treasures but also spun out their subtext, including maintenance, security and delicate logistics such as temperature and humidity. The filming started June 14 and wrapped up Saturday.

The museum houses several items that are the pride of their collection and famous worldwide, including the "Jade Cabbage", a piece of jade carved into the shape of a head of cabbage, with an insect attached; the "meat-shaped stone", a piece of agate, the strata of which are cleverly used to create a likeness of a piece of pork cooked in soy sauce; a boat carved from an olive pit; and the "Painting of One Hundred Horses"; as well as four paintings from the Northern and Southern Song Dynasties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 24, or the 10th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1314: Led by Robert the Bruce, the Scots defeat the English army at the Battle of Bannockburn.
1340: The British fleet destroys the French at Sluys in the Hundred Years' War.
1497: John Cabot, originally Giovanni Caboto, an Italian-born navigator and explorer in the service of the English crown, discovers the North American mainland just 35 days after leaving Bristol in his ship, the Matthew.
1812: Napoleon Bonaparte, leading his Grand Armee, begins his invasion of Russia.
1821: Simon Bolivar, known as "the Liberator," leads 8,000 South American patriots to victory against 4,000 Spanish Royalists at the Battle of Carabobo in Venezuela, virtually freeing Venezuela from Spanish control.
1940: Japan formally asks Britain to close the Burma Road.
1948: The Berlin airlift begins as the Allies delivery food and essential supplies by air to Berliners after the Soviets blockade the city.
1953: Jacqueline Bouvier announces her engagement to Senator John F. Kennedy.
1964: Fu Jen Catholic University, founded in Beijing in 1926 and taken over by the Chinese communists in 1950 after the ROC government moved to Taiwan, is reopened in Hsinchuang, Taipei County.
1973: Eamon de Valera resigns as president of Ireland at the age of 90.
1974: Robert E. Page, and Frank W. Beatty, vice presidents of United Press International, arrive in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes revisions to the banking law.
1975: The China External Trade Development Council and the Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, sign an agreement to promote trade and other economic relations.
1976: A 1,000,000-ton dry dock at Kaohsiung shipyard is christened.
1976: The Executive Yuan appoints Fan Kwei-shu as political vice minister of the Ministry of Justice and Chen Min-ching as commissioner of the Department of Reconstruction, Taiwan Province.
1978: Lieutenant-Colonel Ahmed Hussein al-Ghashni, president of the Yemen Arab Republic, is killed by a bomb carried by a South Yemen special envoy, who also dies in the explosion.
1981: The opening ceremony of the 30th Council Meeting of the Asian Pacific Parliamentarians' Union is held at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.
1983: President Assad of Syria orders Yasser Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to leave Damascus.
1983: Sally Ride becomes the first American woman in space when she blasts off in Challenger with four male astronauts.
1987: Kim Dae-jung and 300 other dissidents are released after two weeks of unrest in South Korea.
1989: Zhao Ziyang, who expressed sympathy with pro-democracy students in mainland China, is replaced by Jiang Zemin as general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party.
1993: A Xiamen Airlines passenger plane is hijacked and diverted to Taiwan by Chang Wenlung, a mainland Chinese youth.
1994: Russia and the European Union sign a friendship accord in Corfu, Greece, designed to help stabilize Russia and bring it closer to its former rivals.
1998: The UNSC agrees to maintain sanctions against Iraq for 60 more days.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the conduct of government there are five good principles to be kept in mind and respected. First, to benefit the people without wasting the resources of the country; secondly, to encourage labor without giving cause for complaint; thirdly, to desire for the enjoyments of life without being covetous; fourthly, to be dignified without being supercilious; fifthly, to inspire awe without being severe."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: EU leaders finally clinch deal to reform bloc
European Union leaders clinched agreement Satruday on a mandate to overhaul the 27-nation bloc after persuading Poland to end a standoff that nearly torpedoed a marathon summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN COUNTY CHIEF TO VISIT JAPAN FOR EXPORT PROMOTION

TEXT.P: Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih will depart for Japan Sunday for a visit aimed at promoting exports of the southern Taiwan county's farm produce, mangoes in particular, local officials said Saturday.

It will be the fourth consecutive year that Su has visited Japan to boost sales of his county's specialty farm products, including Irwin mangoes, mulberry juice, Tungshan coffee, mango pudding, mango preserves and other fine-quality farm produce, the officials said.

Thanks to concerted efforts of the Council of Agriculture, the county government, fruit farmers and traders, Su said Tainan-grown mangoes have met the excessively stringent Japanese quality requirements, including no pesticide residues.

"A produce traceability system has been implemented this year to ensure good quality of our mangoes. We are confident that our produce can pass strict Japanese pesticide residue tests, " Su said, adding that each mango to be exported to Japan carries a label on which the place of origin, the name of producer, product number and Web site are clearly stated.
Moreover, Su said, major Tainan mango farmers associations will cooperate with Japanese importers in launching home delivery services to boost sales.

Su will be traveling along with a delegation of county government officials and representatives of local farmers associations. During the June 24-30 visit, Su said the delegation will organize mango culture festival activities to introduce the county's special farming culture and customs to Japanese consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES U.S. HOUSE APPROVAL OF EASING CURBS ON TAIWAN CONTACTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) welcomes a proposal passed by the U.S. House of Representatives Thursday that would eliminate a long list of U.S.-imposed restrictions on contacts with Taiwan, MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said Saturday.
The House acted by adding an amendment to a bill funding the U.S. State Department and other diplomatic operations for next year.

The amendment, introduced by Republican Representative Tom Tancredo, demands removal of the guidelines drafted by the U.S. State Department that have restricted official contacts with Taiwan since the United States switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979.

The guidelines bar the top Taiwan leader from visiting the United States (only transit stops are permissible) , prohibit Taiwan's foreign minister from visiting Washington, D.C., ban Taiwanese diplomatic personnel and legislators from entering the White House and the State Department, and forbid U.S. executive branch officials from attending functions sponsored by Taiwan's representative office in Washington, D.C.
In response, Wang said the Republic of China government welcomes and appreciates the House passage of the amendment proposal.

"We keenly hope that the U.S. ruling and opposition camps can reach consensus on the issue soon so that the various diplomatic curbs can be lifted to facilitate bilateral communications and engagements," Wang said.
The funding bill will now be referred to the Senate for deliberation and approval. The House passed a similar proposal last year, but the proposal failed to make the Senate's agenda.

SINGAPORE (DPA) X Political and business leaders from Asia started arriving in Singapore yesterday for the 16th World Economic Forum (WEF) on East Asia to examine the regions growth and effect on the global power equation.

Los Angeles TimesG Plans to Close Hospital Weighed.
A major of Los Angeles County supervisors said Friday that they are ready to vote next week to begin the process of closing Martin Luther King Jr.-Harbor Hospital. Face with a threat from California regulators to pull the hospital's license, Supervisors Zev Yaroslavsky, Gloria Molina and Mike Antonovich indicated that they wanted to act before the county's hand was forced. ]By Lu- sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HOPEFUL PROMISES TO HAVE PREMIER FROM MAJORITY PARTY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou promised the country Sunday that if elected in the 2008 race, and if the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -led "pan-green" lawmakers outnumber KMT-led "pan-blue" legislators at that time, he will allow the DPP to organize the Cabinet.

Making the vow at a KMT congress, Ma, who named former premier Vincent Siew his running mate the day before, said that if elected, he will put forth an appropriate plan for political reforms but will not seek to change or rewrite the nation's constitution arbitrarily.
Ma said if elected, he will push for judicial reforms and will remain stringently neutral and let Cabinet operate independently.

The former Taipei city mayor and KMT chairman spelled out four major goals that he vowed to achieve if elected president of the Republic of China in 2008. Those goals are: Revive Taiwan's core values, rev up Taiwan's economy, secure Taiwan's dignity, and create a promising future for Taiwan.

On the economic fronts, Ma said Siew, his running mate, will play the role of "chief engineer" of the country's economic revival if the ticket wins the 2008 election, adding that he will see to it that all of Taiwan becomes a free trade zone, which will win back funds and shipments to Taiwan from around the world, help lower the unemployment rate to below 3 percent and allow Taiwan's per capita income to top US$20,000 by 2011.

Ma said if elected, he will return long-lost "dignity" to the people of Taiwan and make sure that the ruling KMT discard unhealthy unification/independence issues and instead shift to issues that are directly related to the people's welfare and interest.

On Taiwan's international status, Ma said if elected, he will seek to allow Taiwan to take part in global activities more often while securing Taiwan's sovereignty and avoiding hostile confrontations with China. He urged the people of Taiwan not to look on Taiwan's status and situation in the world as hopeless just because unfair treatment that the island has encountered.
On the educational front, Ma said if elected, he will seek to develop Taiwan into the world's Mandarin-learning hub and raise Taiwan's profile via cultural means.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC NATIONAL ARRESTED IN KINMEN AFTER SWIMMING TO ISLET

TEXT.P: A Kinmen detachment of the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) referred a Chinese mainland national to the Kinmen Public Prosecutors' Office Sunday after he swam from a beach in Xiamen, Fujian province, to Dadan Islet a day earlier, where he was immediately arrested by garrison troops.
Hu Xianping, 50, a resident of Nanjing, claimed that he was trying to escape from 20 years of political persecution in China.
Admitting that he had bought a map to plan his escape route, Hu said he wanted to go to Taiwan to meet with his uncle, whom he claimed is a military general.
Hu was arrested shortly before noon Saturday after swimming about three and a half hours across a narrow strait to reach Dadan -- one of the islets in the outlying island group of Kinmen.

The CGA's Kinmen detachment declined to comment on whether Hu was really suffering from political persecution in China. A spokesman for the detachment said Hu was referred to the public prosecutors' office for breaching the National Security Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-KMT CHIEF VOWS TO WIN PRESIDENTIAL, LEGISLATIVE POLLS

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, former chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the party's presidential candidate, vowed to go all out Sunday for the party's victory in the coming legislative and presidential elections.

Ma issued the call while leaving the KMT's 17th national congress, during which party delegates gave their approval to the presidential ticket of Ma and former Premier Vincent Siew. Ma announced that he had selected Siew as his running mate a day earlier.
While pledging his resolve to win back power in 2008, Ma also encouraged the KMT's legislative candidates to do their best to win more than half of the seats in the Legislative Yuan.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT heavyweight previously favored to serve as Ma's running mate, said that he is more than confident that the Ma-Siew ticket will win the next presidential poll.

In response to reporters' questions on whether or not he has been invited to serve as the Ma-Siew camp's election campaign manager, Wang replied that he has not been contacted by anyone regarding this issue and argued that it is "too early" to discuss at the moment.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIAL GROUPS MAY SEEK TO HAVE OWN LEGISLATORS ELECTED

TEXT.P: Representatives of nearly 30 social activists groups said Sunday that they have not ruled out the possibility of fielding their own candidates in the next legislative election to fight for greater rights for the people.
Twenty-eight social groups, which represent over 700 sub-groups islandwide, formed a single confederation Sunday to better present the views of popular groups, particularly disadvantaged groups.

Bai Hsiu-hsiung, formerly a deputy Taipei mayor, said during a ceremony marking the establishment of the Taiwan Social Welfare Confederation that the confederation has not excluded the possibility of seeking group members to run for legislative seats so that the voices of private social groups would no longer fall on the deaf ears of the major ruling and opposition political parties. Bai spoke in his capacity as chairman of a preparatory committee of the confederation.

Meanwhile, Chen Ming-li, chief secretary of the preparatory committee, said his confederation firmly opposes the practice of Democratic Progressive Party and Kuomintang candidates bidding for the votes of farmers, fishermen, and senior citizens by promising ever greater subsidies or annuities.
This kind of contest is nothing more than political ploy to win votes in general elections, Chen added.
Chen noted, however, that it is still too early to tell whether the confederation will field its own candidate in the next legislative election.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Parisi: It is enough massacre of civilians in Afghanistan.
Italian Defense Minister Arturo Parisi was angry about casualties of civilians in raids launched by allied forces against insurgents in Afghanistan. He asked for stricter restrictions on operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALISHAN FOREST RAILWAY DISRUPTED BY LANDSLIDE

TEXT.P: The Alishan forest railway was disrupted Sunday when a landslide caused by heavy rains damaged a section of the line near the end of a tunnel.
According to the Chiayi office of the Council of Agriculture's Forestry Bureau, which manages the rail line, it will take at least 50 days to repair the damaged section of the railway.

A spokesman for the office pointed out that successive afternoon thunderstorms during the past few days caused a landslide near No. 42 Tunnel, located 59 kilometers from Chiayi Station, and damaged the railway.

The Alishan railway is said to be one of the world's three remaining alpine railways. The other two are located in northern India, connecting Himalayan mountains, and in the Andean mountain range of South America.

Opened in 1912 while Taiwan was under Japanese rule, the narrow-gauge railway was designed to haul timber down the mountain, but is now mainly used to transport the more than 200,000 tourists who annually visit Alishan to see the area's beauty at an altitude of more than 2,200 meters in Taiwan's Central Mountain Range.

The scenic rail line winds its way up from the subtropical plains to mountainous pine forests in just 72 kilometers, crossing more than 80 bridges and passing through about 50 tunnels. Its route includes a series of dangerous switchbacks.

Although the government has been operating the train at an annual loss of about NT$110 million (US$3.35 million) , it has decided to preserve the line not only for its historic value but as a means to boost local tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT REVISES CHARTER FOR PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) approved Sunday a revision to the party charter during its 17th national congress, clearing the way for its presidential candidate to run in the 2008 presidential election.
More than 1,000 party delegates endorsed the revision, giving it their unanimously approval during the meeting chaired by KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang at the stadium in Taoyuan County.

The party charter amendment, which allows party members standing trials to run for public offices on party tickets before they are "convicted" in the third trial, will replace a regulation that prohibited those convicted in the first trial from vying for the party's nomination in elections.

The change will permit Ma Ying-jeou, who had been indicted on embezzlement charges before being named as KMT presidential candidate, to run in the coming presidential election until he is convicted in the third trial.
KMT delegates also enthusiastically approved the party's presidential ticket of Ma and former Premier Vincent Siew.

In addition, KMT delegates added a clause underscoring the party's "Taiwan- centric" beliefs in its charter, promising to prioritize to bring benefits to Taiwan's people, while replacing the word "unification" with "peaceful development" in another clause to underscore its stand concerning Taiwan's relations with China.

Ma was indicted by Taipei prosecutors in mid-February for allegedly misusing funds from a special monthly municipal allowance designated for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006. He stepped down from the party's top post shortly after the indictment.
Despite the corruption charges, the KMT nonetheless nominated Ma in May as its presidential candidate, stirring up strong social criticism.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TECH TREK 2007 INTERNSHIP PROGRAM KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Tech Trek 2007 internship program is scheduled to kick off in Tainan City, southern Taiwan Sunday evening, co-sponsored by the National Science Council (NSC) and National Cheng Kung University (NCKU).

A total of 271 second-generation, overseas Taiwanese from 23 countries around the world will start eight-week internships at some 50 institutes and companies in southern Taiwan Monday to enable them to gain a deeper understanding and greater recognition of Taiwan.

NSC officials said that the Taiwan Teck Trek internship program has expanded since its inception in 2005, from 183 participants to this year's 271 participants, and from six-week internships to this year's eight-week internships.

They said the Taiwan Tech Trek -- held for the first time in 2005 -- is designed to offer internships to young overseas Taiwanese students in the hope that their visits to Taiwan will provide incentives for them to work in Taiwan after graduation.
More than 800 young Taiwanese descendants have applied for 271 internship openings this year, the official said, adding that 24 of the 271 selected had taken part in the 2005 or 2006 programs.
The NSC will finance each "trekkie" with NT$50,000 (US$1,515) for the internship courses, although they will have to pay for their airline tickets, room and board, and insurance, NSC officials said.

Before starting their internships at various institutes and companies July 1, the "trekkies" will travel in a group to Tainan City to visit historic sites, explore their cultural legacy, view the famous local yacht industry, salt- processing industry, and a biotech industrial park in Tainan County, between June 25-30.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER APPROVES NEW ENVOY TO ST. LUCIA

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung has approved Tom Chou, secretary-general of the Coordination Council for North American Affairs, to serve as Taiwan's ambassador to St. Lucia, and Chou has promised to assume his new post as soon as he receives notification of approval from the Caribbean country government, a foreign affairs official said Sunday.

Chou made the remarks Saturday in an interview after his appointment to the new post was approved by the Executive Yuan, following the government's announcement of the resumption of diplomatic ties with St. Lucia May 1, according to the official.
Chou has served at Taiwanese representative offices in South Africa, St. Vincent and the Grenadines and New York.
St. Lucia first established diplomatic relations with Taiwan in 1984, before switching diplomatic recognition to China in 1997. However, the two countries restored diplomatic ties in May.
St Lucia, an island nation in the eastern Caribbean, has a total area of 616 square kilometers and a population of about 170,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY CRACKING DOWN ON ILLEGAL WASTE DISPOSAL

TEXT.P: In an effort to prevent illegal waste dumping, the Taipei City government has decided to grant cash rewards to citizens who provide information leading to the arrest of offenders, with the rewards of up to 30 percent of fines collected by the agency, a city official said Sunday.

The city's Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) has stepped up its crack down on wanton waste dumping and littering since June 2000 when it implemented the "fee per bag" measure, which required residents to purchase specially designated trash bags for the disposal of garbage, and a "No Drop" policy which prohibited leaving garbage on the streets.

The DEP, based on information supplied by local residents, has uncovered a total of 8,000 cases of illegal waste dumping over the past five months, and investigated 14,243 cases altogether during the last year, according to the official.
Under the Waste Disposal Act, those convicted of illegally dumping waste face fines ranging from NT1,200 (US$36.36) to NT$6,000, the official said.

The DEP is now poised to adopt measures to further crack down on improper dumping and encourage the public to provide information on offenders, the spokesman noted, stating that beginning July 1, violators will be subject to heavy fines if they commit offenses more than twice within a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER VISITS CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 23 (CNA) 06/24/07 18:33:09 (By Lillian Lin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng paid a visit Saturday to William P. Kelly, president of the Graduate Center of the City University of New York (CUNY) , to discuss faculty and student exchanges between Taiwanese and U.S. universities.

During the meeting, Tu specifically introduced Taiwan's Chinese language education and sinology centers, while recommending that CUNY students interested in pursuing advanced education in Taiwan take epidemiology and sinology related courses.
As for Taiwanese university students wishing to enroll in overseas study programs at the New York university, he encouraged them to take CNYU's English language and literature courses.

The CUNY Graduate Center was established in 1961 and offers more than 30 doctoral programs in international affairs, environmental protection, urban planning, women and society, music, education, media, as well as language and literature.
There are 60-plus Taiwanese graduate students currently studying at the center, including two government-supported students.
The CUNY houses 29 graduate and undergraduate research centers. Several executive chiefs from the school's various sections attended Saturday's meeting with Tu.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOOL CHILDREN TURN USED COOKING OIL INTO BIODIESEL FUEL

TEXT.P: Students from an elementary school in Taiwan's southernmost county, Pingtung, are collecting used cooking oil at the school and having it turned into biodiesel fuel, which has thus far powered a teacher's car for over 30,000 kilometers.

Tung An Elementary School in Pingtung County's Nanchou Rural Township began to process used household cooking oil into biodiesel fuel three years ago to help keep the environment clean and to improve environmental efficiency in the county, which is an agricultural area with many orchards, Tung An Principal Tsai Ching-wen said.
"We experienced a bumpy start during which there was little action, but then more and more students started to bring in waste oil after repeated public campaigns," Tsai said.

Hsieh Cheng-wen, the teacher responsible for instructing students how to process used household cooking oil into biodiesel, contributed his own diesel engine van to serve as a "lab mouse" and use biodiesel fuel processed in a makeshift factory at the school.
His van has traveled nearly 30,000 kilometers over the past two years using school-produced biodiesel.
A student's grandmother has been one of the most steadfast supporters, not only contributing used cooking oil, but also expired, clean cooking oil.

Biodiesel is simple to use, biodegradable, nontoxic and essentially free of sulfur and aromatics. Most importantly, biodiesel provides a way for the county's households and eateries to dispose of their used cooking oil in an environmentally friendly manner, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SENT TO PROTECT JUDGES HANDLING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR CASE

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City Police Bureau (KCPB) has sent three officers to safeguard three Kaohsiung District Court judges in charge of Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu's case after their ruling to annul Chen Chu's election victory, police sources said Sunday.

At the request of the district court, the KCPB dispatched three police officers to serve as bodyguards for the three-person panel of judges: presiding judge Huang Hung-chin, and associates Ku Chen-hui and Huang Hsuan-fu, said sources.

The trio handled the election lawsuit filed by main opposition Kuomintang candidate Huang Chun-ying after he narrowly lost to Chen Chu of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the December 9, 2006 election and announced on June 15 the invalidation of Chen Chu's electoral victory.

The court ruling has provoked intense debate between "pan-blue alliance" and "pan-green camp" over whether or not the decision is just, the sources said, adding that in an effort to prevent the three judges from facing a potential life-threatening situation due to passions stirred up by the mounting controversy, the district court asked the police for protection services. That request was approved by the KCPB after conducting an assessment.
The KC PB selected three police officers to safeguard the operation and instructed police local precincts and police stations to step up patrols around the residences of the trio judges.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLEAN MOUNT HOHUAN OPERATION SET FOR JULY 1

TEXT.P: A clean-up operation will take place July 1 on scenic Mount Hohuan in Nantou County to remove trash left behind by tourists, the Taipei-based Good Neighbor Foundation indicated Sunday.
The foundation, established by the 7-Eleven convenient store chain in 1999, has been engaged in "Clean Up the World" operations since 2001.

A spokesman for the foundation said volunteers and members of the foundation will join servicemen from the Army's Airborne Command and retired paratroopers July 1 to clean up all of the trash left by tourists on Mount Hohuan and in the adjacent Taroko Gorge National Park.
Mount Hohuan is a scenic spot favored by people in Taiwan during winter because it is a rare, accessible place where they can see snow.
The mountain has an elevation of 3,416 meters, meaning its summit is above the tree line. When there is enough snowfall in January and February, the hills around the resort serve as ski slopes.
Unfortunately, the beautiful scenery is often marred by tons of trash left behind by visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: JANUARY-APRIL REGULAR WAGE HITS 5 YEAR HIGH: STATISTICAL OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Regular salaries of local wage earners registered year-on-year growth of 1.42 percent during the first four months of this year, which, while not a big increase, set a five-year high, officials of the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Sunday.
The annual growth rate for regular wages rose over one percent during the past 11-month period, indicating that the regular wage is steadily on the increase, according to DGBAS officials.
The average salaries was NT$39,942 (US$1,215) in April, down 0.32 percent from last month, but increased by 0.25 percent over the same period last year, the officials said.
The average salary during January-April was NT$51,634, which represents a 1.44 percent increase year-on-year, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIKA DEER ECOLOGICAL PARK OPENS ON GREEN ISLAND

TEXT.P: An ecological park featuring Formosan sika deer opened Sunday on the outlying Green Island, attracting thousands of visitors who happened to be visiting the island over the weekend.
The 23-hectare park was built by the local township administration and is being collectively run by several local tourism operators as part of efforts to boost the island's tourism.

Huang Ching-an, a spokesman for Hoya Hot Springs Resort and Spa, a major shareholder of the park, said that the annual number of visitors to Green Island has reached 400,000, but most of them come to the island during the summer.
In order to make the island an ideal tourist destination in all seasons, the locals decided to build the park, according to Huang.

The establishment of the park is also an attempt to boost the island's deer industry, Green Island Township Chief Chen Chia-wen said, adding that the industry made a major contribution to the island's economy in earlier days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CUSTOMS OFFICE CONFISCATES 400 PIRATED WII DISCS

TEXT.P: The 400 Wii discs seized by customs officials at Taiwan's ports of entry in late May have all been certified as counterfeits, the Taipei Customs Office announced Sunday.
A spokesman for the office said that a representative from Nintendo, the copyright holder of the game console, had examined the 400 discs and found that they were all pirated replicas.
The spokesman added that the office will now pursue the piracy cases as they would have affected the rights of lawful businesses in Taiwan selling the Nintendo video games.
He said the pirated Wii discs, worth about NT$600,000, would have seriously disrupt the market prices of the games.
The latest Nintendo game console is becoming increasingly popular in Taiwan, with the number of owners estimated at more than 20,000, although the product is yet to be formally marketed in Taiwan.

According to the National Communications Commission, Taiwan's highest media regulator, Nintendo has obtained certification in Taiwan for the Wii. Passengers entering Taiwan are allowed to import two Wii's duty-free if they are certified to be genuine Nintendo products.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUS CRASHES INTO RAVINE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A tour bus carrying 38 passengers went off road and rolled down the side of a 50-meter deep ravine on Yangminshan, north of Taipei city, killing at least five and injuring many others, according to Taipei fire fighters.
The accident took place at 6:30 p.m. during the weekend rush hour while many tourists were returning to Taipei on the road winding through Yangminshan National Park.

The ill-fated bus, owned by a transportation company located in Chutung, Hsinchu County, was traveling from Yangminshan to Taipei when it went off road and into the ravine. Witnesses said the driver did not seem to have applied the vehicle's brakes during the crash.
The tour bus was reportedly rented by an American-owned direct sales company Shaklee which is headquatered in Taipei to take employees in Hsinchu to a meeting in the scenic national park.

The accident caused a traffic jam on the already busy road, hampering rescue operations. Fire fighters were forced to rappel down to the ravine to reach victims, and to bring the injured up to the road before rushing them to nearby hospitals.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CANDIDATE CRITICIZES KMT CHARTER CHANGE, IGNORES POLL RESULTS

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, the presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Sunday dismissed poll results showing the opposition ticket in the lead, saying that he cares more about doing the right thing and does not mind temporary changes in opinion poll results.

Hsieh made the remarks in Pingtung County while answering reporters' questions after local newspapers reported that public approval ratings for the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) presidential ticket, formed by former chairman Ma Ying-jeou and former premier Vincent Siew, are higher than those of the DPP, regardless of whether former Premier Su Tseng-chang or former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan is chosen to complete the ticket.

Ma announced that Siew would be his running mate a day earlier and KMT delegates gave the pairing their stamp of approval during Sunday's 17th national congress after agreeing to amend a clause of the party's charter that would have barred Ma, who has been indicted on embezzlement charges, from taking part in the presidential election if he is found quilty in the first trial.

Commenting on the poll results showing that he is trailing the opposition, Hsieh said that he will not be mindful of temporary ups- and -down in public approval ratings, but rather focus on doing the right thing.

According to Hsieh, the KMT's charter revision, aimed at allowing Ma to run in the coming presidential election, was improper, and the higher approval rating Ma currently enjoys is meaningless. Hsieh went on to warn Ma that he might be cast aside by voters upset with the KMT's wrongdoing.

Lee Ying-yuan, executive director of Hsieh's election campaign office, told a news conference later the same day that the KMT's decision to revise its charter to smooth the way for Ma was solely motivated by partisan gain and will seriously hobble the development of party politics in Taiwan.

Speaking on the same occasion, DPP lawmaker Hsu Kuo-yung accused the KMT of "back pedaling" on Taiwan's political development with the charter amendment. He blamed the KMT for a lack of self-reflection and asked Ma to come up with a clear explanation regarding the issue.

In response to Ma's pledge that if elected president, he would allow the DPP to form a Cabinet should that party gain a majority of seats in the Legislative Yuan, DPP legislative caucus whip Ker Chien-ming called Ma's promise an "electoral gambit" to deceive voters, and a political maneuver by the KMT to gloss over his corruption charges.
"Ma's pledge is merely 'empty talk' because he knows very well that the DPP can hardly win more than half of the seats in the legislature," Ker claimed.

"If Ma is sincere in his vow that he will do his best to improve Taiwan's economy," Ker asked, "why do 'pan-blue' lawmakers of the KMT and the People First Party still refuse to approve some key bills devoted to the country's economic development, such as the annual budget bills for state-run enterprises and several special funds?"

Regarding a United Daily newspaper report that the Ma-Siew ticket will lure votes from supporters of the "pan-green" camp and median voters, DPP lawmaker Wang Shu-hui called it a KMT trick, saying that the KMT was blowing its own trumpet.

According to the report, some 51 percent of the respondents to its survey favor the Ma-Siew ticket and opined that Ma's pairing up with Siew will help lure an additional 4 percent in support from "pan-green" and moderate voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUS CRASHES INTO RAVINE IN TAIPEI (UPDATE-1)

TEXT.P: A tour bus carrying 38 passengers went off road and rolled down the side of a 50-meter deep ravine on Yangminshan, north of Taipei city, Sunday killing at least seven and injuring 23 others, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said.

Hao who arrived at the scene about two hours after the accident told journalists that although the bus company said there were 38 passengers on board in addition to the driver but only 30 of them were accounted for.
The mayor said rescuers were trying to lift the wreckage of the bus to see if any one is buried under it.
The accident took place at 6:30 p.m. during the weekend rush hour while many tourists were returning to Taipei on the road winding through Yangminshan National Park.

The ill-fated bus from Chutung, Hsinchu County, was traveling from Yangminshan to Taipei when it hit a car in front of it before went off road and into the ravine. Witnesses said the driver did not seem to have applied the vehicle's brakes during the crash.
The tour bus was reportedly rented by an American-owned direct sales company Shaklee which is headquartered in Taipei to take its salespeople to a meeting in the scenic national park.

The accident caused a traffic jam on the already busy road, hampering rescue operations. Fire fighters were forced to rappel down to the ravine to reach victims, and to bring the injured up to the road before rushing them to nearby hospitals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI ZOO CHALLENGES COUNCIL OF AGRICULTURE'S PANDA DECISION

TEXT.P: Taipei City Zoo filed an administrative suit against the Council of Agriculture (COA) after repeated COA rejections of the zoo's applications to import pandas from China, a spokesman for the zoo said Sunday.

Rebutting the council's arguments that the zoo lacks well-trained personnel and adequate facilities to house pandas, Spokesman Chiao Ming-chie said that the zoo had sent staff to many countries to learn about the care of pandas.

The zoo also sent a veterinarian and two staff members to China last month to receive training, Chiao said, stressing that zoos in many countries send staff overseas to undergo training one to three months before importing animals.

Noting that the zoo has the expertise, facilities, and capability to care for pandas, Chiao pointed out that the key problem lies in how to overcome the limits that the Washington Accord imposes on the import and export of endangered animals.

To solve that problem, governments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait need to show sincerity and jointly work towards a solution, Chiao said, asserting that now is the time for a breakthrough in the exchange of wild animals between Taiwan and China.

Chiao also said that the zoo is dealing with the issue from a professional viewpoint, adding that the zoo has consulted experts and public for opinions on the issue in three meetings and one public hearing.

The COA has consistently denied the zoo's applications reasoning that the international conservation community favors in situ conservation over ex situ conservation. However, according to Chiao, both approaches are equally important.
"You cannot just promote in situ conservation and totally reject ex situ conservation," he went on.

At present, the zoo has received total donations of NT$250 million (US$7.6 million) from local enterprises to sponsor the construction of an exhibition hall for pandas, Chiao said, while admitting that progress is behind the schedule, and stressing that construction will be completed by the end of this year.

Virtually every aspect of global migration can be seen in this tiny West African nation, where the number of people who have left approaches the number who remain and almost everyone has a close relative in Europe or America.
Migrant money buoys the economy. Migrant votes sway politics. Migrant departures split parents from children, and the most famous song by the most famous Cape Verdean venerates the national emotion, "Sodade," or longing. Lofty talk of opportunity abroad mixes at cafe tables here with accounts of false documents and sham marriages.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 25, or the 11th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1788: Virginia becomes the 10th U.S. state.
1843: Commercial production of cigarettes begins in France when the French National Tobacco Co. turns out its first batch of 20,000 cigarettes.
1900: Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma, British naval commander and colonial administrator, is born. He was the supreme Allied commander in Southeast Asia during World War II, the last viceroy of India, then the commander in chief of Britain's Mediterranean fleet.
1903: Marie Curie, the Polish-born French chemist and scientist, announces the discovery of radium, a radioactive metallic element found in pitchblende, remarkable for its spontaneous disintegration, and other elements.
1942: Maj. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is appointed commander of U.S. forces in Europe and sets up his headquarters in London.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Magaung in northern Burma.
1945: Representatives of 50 nations, including the Republic of China, attend a United Nations meeting in San Francisco to pass the U.N. Charter. The ROC, the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain are made members of the U.N. Security Council.
1947: The ROC Foreign Ministry reveals repeated Soviet Union attempts to block Chinese troops from entering Dairen and Port Arthur.
1950: North Korea invades South Korea, marking the beginning of the Korean War.
1953: Heavy rain hits Kyushu, an island of Japan, killing 1,013 people.
1968: The ROC Cabinet is partially reshuffled, with Defense Minister Chiang Ching-kuo becoming vice premier.
1969: Pancho Gonzalez and Charlie Paserell play the longest-ever singles match at Wimbledon, which lasts five hours and 12 minutes.
1973: Mathieu Vangha Ekra, Ivory Coast state minister in charge of tourism, accompanied by his wife and a party of five, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1975: The 22-member Chinese track and field team returns from the Philippine national invitational track and field championships with 27 medals and a second- place finish.
1975: Mozambique gains independence, with Samora Machel, a Marxist, as its president, after four centuries of Portuguese rule.
1975: More than 4,000 refugees from Cambodia, Laos and South Vietnam are resettled in Taiwan.
1982: Alexander Haig resigns as U.S. secretary of state and is succeeded by George Schultz.
1989: The British government refuses to allow residency rights in Britain to ethnic Hong Kong Chinese.
1990: Under international pressure, Beijing allows Fang Lichih, a noted Chinese physicist and democracy activist, to leave mainland China and study at Cambridge University in England.
1990: Reporters from mainland China are permitted to visit Taiwan for news- gathering purposes, and government employees from Taiwan are allowed to visit sick relatives or attend funerals across the Taiwan Strait.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata resigns along with his minority government.
1996: A terrorist bomb blast tears through a Saudi Arabian military complex housing foreigners, killing more than 60 people and injuring nearly 400 others.
1997: Jacques Yves Cousteau, French underwater explorer and film producer, dies in Paris at the age of 87. The veteran oceanographer helped develop the aqua- lung in 1943, and popularized underwater exploration with his prize-winning films.
2000: Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh is elected as chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
2001: The Council for Economic Planning and Development announces that the government will encourage the formation of 50 private venture capital funds, totaling NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion), to boost the development of the local bio-tech industry.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To benefit the people without wasting the resources of the country is to encourage the people to undertake such profitable labor as will best benefit them, without it being necessary to give them any assistance out of the public revenue."

DOC.HEADLINE: MURDER SUSPECT KILLS SELF AFTER GUN BATTLE WITH POLICE

TEXT.P: A man suspected by police in the shooting death of a Taipei County councilor killed himself after engaging in a gun battle with police in Taipei late Sunday.
The man, who was cornered by police at a private parking lot, fired at least three or four shots at police before turning the gun to his own head.

Police identified the man through a driver's license found on his body as Lan Chia-wei, with Lan's identity later verified through fingerprinting. Lan had been wanted by police in connection with the killing of Wu Shan-jeou, a Taipei County councilor from Hsintien City , who was shot four times by a gunman in his office on May 23, and died on spot.
Lan was stopped by police at a roadblock in downtown Taipei Sunday night for a routine check, but he suddenly dropped a bag he was carrying and tried to flee the scene.

Police officers gave chase on foot and called for reinforcements via radio. The man drew a gun and shot at police officers, but he was finally cornered by police at a private parking lot and continued the gun battle in an attempt to escape.
During the shoot-out, police fired some 20 shots before the man committed suicide by turning the gun to his temple and pulling the trigger.
He was sent to Mackay Memorial Hospital, but was declared dead on arrival according to police.

Lan's picture was published by police on June 18 as the main suspect in the assassination of councilor Wu, as his image was caught on a surveillance camera outside Wu's office minutes before the murder even though the suspect's face was partially covered with sunglasses and a helmet.
The police believe Lan was hired to kill Wu and they are working to track down the masterminds behind the death, whom they believed have fled to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE MAKES ECONOMY AS MAIN THEME OF ELECTION CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said Monday that he will make "economy" the main theme of his election campaign.
Ma made the remarks during a meeting with KMT representatives from overseas at the party's headquarters.
Asked why he picked former Premier Vincent Siew as his running mate, Ma pointed out that what Taiwan most needs now is a good economy.

"Don't talk to me about the independence versus unification issue now, because it is a false issue unrelated to Taiwan's economic development, " he said, adding, "It is a must to have another transfer of power in 2008, to reverse Taiwan's languishing performance over the past seven years."
Siew, a veteran technocrat who served as premier from 1997-2000 and as economic affairs minister 1990-1993, is popular for his familiarity with economic affairs.

According to several public opinion surveys carried out by local media outlets, the Ma-Siew ticket is backed by some 50 percent of the public, well ahead of a 20 percent public approval rating enjoyed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party ticket, regardless of whom joins its presidential candidate, Frank Hsieh, on the ballot.

Hsieh, who served as premier from 2005-2006, has yet to announce his running mate. Su Tseng-chang, Hsieh's predecessor in the premiership from 2006-2007, and Yeh Chu-lan, vice premier during the 2004-2005 period, are widely favored.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and ended higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 126.28 points to close at 8,939.19.

The bourse opened at the day's low of 8,882.3 and hit a high of 8,985.93 during the day's trading. A total of 6.5 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$184.32 billion (US$5.63 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical shares moving up the most at 4.0 percent, followed by cement stocks at 2.5 percent, textile issues at 2.0 percent, banking and financial stocks at 1.6 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.2 percent, machinery and electronics issues, as well as construction stocks both at 0.9 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 781 to 432, with 179 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG TURNS BACK TAIWAN HUMAN RIGHTS LAWYER
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 25 (CNA) 06/25/07 16:36:44 (By Mandy Wong and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese human rights lawyer was turned away from Hong Kong airport Monday after arriving from Taiwan the previous night.

Chu Wan-chi told CNA that she arrived from Taiwan Sunday night but was refused entry at the airport after immigration officials found that she had been blacklisted by Hong Kong authorities for bringing a suit in 2003 against Hong Kong authorities over their refusal of entry to a group of Taiwanese Falung Gong practitioners.

In that case, which is still pending in a local court, Chu has been acting on behalf of three Taiwanese Falung Gong practitioners suing the Hong Kong authorities for refusing 80-odd Taiwan Falung Gong practitioners entry to attend an international gathering of Falung Gong followers in February, 2003.

Chu, who entered Hong Kong June 19 and left June 20, told CNA that an immigration official took her to a room Sunday for questioning over the purpose of her visit to Hong Kong, and whom she is intended to meet during her stay.
Chu said she replied that she had come to witness the July 1 celebrations of 10th anniversary of Hong Kong's hand over to China.

However, Chu said that immigration official would not let her enter despite the willingness of local Falung Gong practitioners to vouch for her good behavior during her stay, claiming that her stay would not serve the public interest.

Chu said that the official took away her travel documents and ordered officers with the riot squad to remove her shoes in preparation to forcefully carry her onboard a Taiwan-bound Dragonair flight Sunday night.
Asking that she be treated with due respect, Chu promised to board by herself, but the plane took off before she arrived at the boarding gate, Chu said.
She was therefore kept in an office waiting expulsion on the next flight.

Condemning the Hong Kong government's illegal treatment of Taiwanese Falung Gong practitioners, Chu said about 100 Taiwanese Falung Gong practitioners are trying to travel to Hong Kong to take part in a march on July 1 to protest the crack down by Chinese authorities, but none of their visa requests were granted.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE TO START NATIONWIDE TOURS SEEKING GRASSROOTS SUPPORT

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou will begin touring Taiwan in July to drum up grassroots support, a staff member with Ma's campaign office said Monday.
Ma and his running mate, Vincent Siew, will start intensive nationwide tours in six areas of Taiwan to explain and promote the KMT's national policy to local people, and solicit their support.

They will stay in each of the regions for 10-15 days, beginning with the Taichung, Changhua, and Nantou area, followed by the Yunlin, Chiayi, and Tainan area, the Kaohsiung and Pingtung area, the eastern Taiwan and offshore islands area, the Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli area, and the Taipei, Keelung, and Yilan area.

According to staff, the arrangement reveals that Ma takes central Taiwan as the area crucial to winning the election, and that he hopes to narrow the gap in votes with the ruling Democratic Progressive party in southern Taiwan, and consolidate support in northern and eastern Taiwan.

The staff member said that Ma's campaign office will start integrating with local KMT campaign resources to expand the scale of the campaign team and launch the first presidential campaign advertisement Monday.
