DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY BEGINS COMPREHENSIVE SAFETY CHECK OF TOUR BUSES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin Monday decreed that all passenger buses operating in the city immediately undergo a thorough safety check following Sunday's accident, in which a coach plunged into a ravine on scenic Yangmingshan in surburban Taipei, killing eight people and injuring 25 others.

According to statistics of the city Bureau of Transportation, there are currently 265 passenger bus operators in Taipei, with more than 3,000 buses on the road. Bureau Director Luo Hsiao-hsien said the bus companies that have been recently ticketed for traffic violations will be the first subjected to safety checks.
Police will also crack down on violators of traffic regulations on Yangde Boulevard, the main road running through National Yangmingshan Park, which is a popular tourist attraction in Taipei City.

The Sunday accident, which occurred on Yangde Boulevard, saw the tour bus, carrying a driver and 29 passengers, collide with the car in front of it before going off road and into the ravine. According to the driver, who was injured in the accident, faulty brakes were at fault.
Hau said that a probe into the accident is still ongoing, and it is too soon to determine what caused the tragedy.

Meanwhile, Luo said the bureau has found that the driver of the ill-fated vehicle is well qualified to drive the large double-decker touring bus as he holds the highest-degree license for driving trailer trucks. Additionally, the bus, which was built in 2001, passed its regular check Jan. 20, and had been scheduled to undergo another regular maintenance check on July 20.

Asked why such a "good vehicle" sustained a brake failure, Luo speculated that it might have resulted from an "improper" driving habit -- remaining in top gear on a downhill road. In such a situation the driver must constantly apply the vehicle's brakes to control its speed. As a result, the brakes are more likely to overheat and break down, Luo said.
Stressing these possible causes were wholly speculative, Luo noted that relevant authorities are investigating whether the Sunday accident was caused by mechanical failure or human error.

Meanwhile, Hsieh Jung-lin, a prosecutor of the Shilin District Prosecutors Office, indicated after his examination of the debris of the bus lying in the ravine that the ill-fated vehicle had not only been remodeled, but was running with retread tires,
After being remodeled, the bus could no longer provide sufficient protection to its passengers, Hsieh said.
The bus owner, the Taipei-based Taiwan Tour Bus Company, has denied the accusations.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE UNVEILS 1ST TV CAMPAIGN AD

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou has unveiled his first TV campaign ad, featuring a call to rediscover Taiwan's core values to enable the nation to march forward.
The campaign ad contains a simple image of Ma slowly stepping forward against a blank background, and speaking in a firm voice.
Ma says in the ad that Taiwan has been plunged into deep anxiety and grievance over the past eights years, and that the dynamism of its economy has disappeared.

"Society is divided and restive because of the disappearance of Taiwanese values, " he said, adding, "We were brought up believing in diligence, integrity, perseverance and kindness, and these values have been behind Taiwan's progress."
Ma also said, "For the hope and well-being of our offspring, we have to rediscover Taiwan's values. Taiwan cannot remain stalled, but must march forward."
KMT spokesman Su Jun-ping said the ad sets the tone for ads to be unveiled later.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARSHALL ISLANDS PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Marshall Islands President Kessai Note will arrive in Taiwan Tuesday with his wife for a five-day visit, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official said Monday.
Note's visit to Taiwan is a private one, save that he will call on President Chen Shui-bian during his stay, the official said.

This is the sixth visit Note has made to Taiwan since his state visit in May 2002. He led delegations to Taiwan in May and December in 2004, and visited Taiwan again at the invitation of Chen in April 2005. His last visit, a private one, was made in November 2006.

The official said the frequent exchanges between high-level officials of Taiwan and the western Pacific island nation of the Marshall Islands underline the cordial friendship enjoyed by the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATION PREPARATIONS ON TRACK: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday that preparations for the Double Ten National Day celebrations are following procedure.

Wang, who concurrently serves as the chairman of the Oct. 10 National Day Organizing Committee, made the remarks after listening to reports by Vice Interior Minister Lin Chung-sheng on the preparations.

Noting that President Chen Shui-bian suggested during a National Day rally last year that the rally be scrapped in 2007, given that the public views on holding the rally were so divergent and that some were reluctant to take part, Wang said "all preparations are following set procedures."

He said the committee has tentatively decided that the National Day celebration party be held at Zuoying, Kaohsiung, while a National Day fireworks display will be held at Pingtung in southern Taiwan.
Since there will be National Day celebration party and fireworks, the National Day rally in the daytime "should also be held, although its scale can be left open for discussion."

"The committee will also respect President Chen's decision on whether he wishes to attend the rally, " he said, but added that the committee will have the final say on whether to hold National Day celebrations.

When the National Day rally was held last year, it was at the height of a "depose President Chen" campaign launched by a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) over a series of alleged corruption scandals surrounding his family members and close aides.

During the National Day rally, red-clad opposition legislators were sitting on both sides of the grandstand, separated completely by a white curtain from the main section where the president, Vice President Annette Lu, and the heads of the executive, legislative, judicial and examination yuans, as well as foreign dignitaries, were seated.
The curtain was set up by the National Day Organizing Committee in the hope of avoiding embarrassment for the president during the event.

However, brief scuffles broke out nevertheless. During Chen's address, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) legislators continued to chant "step down" slogans, unfurled "depose Chen" banners, and flashed the "thumbs down" sign for several minutes to lend support to the anti-Chen protesters.
The actions triggered angry responses from DPP legislators sitting next to them.
PFP Chairman James Soong led party legislators in an abrupt walkout from the grandstand during Chen's address, which caused nervousness among security personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECTED ASSASSIN KILLS HIMSELF AFTER SHOOTOUT WITH POLICE

TEXT.P: The suspected gunman in the May 23 assassination of Taipei County Councilor Wu Shan-chiu shot himself shortly before midnight Sunday in a parking lot in Taipei after engaging in a shootout with police, a police spokesman announced Monday.

Wang Yu-kang, spokesman for the police task force investigating the assassination case, said Lan Chia-wei, 35, shot himself in the head after he was encircled by a special police unit, and that he was pronounced dead on arrival at a hospital.
The spokesman said Lan's mother had confirmed her son's identity.
Lan was believed to be the killer who went into Wu's service office in suburban Taipei May 23 and pumped five bullets into him at close range, killing him instantly.
Police acting on information from CCTV footage traced Lan through two thieves who provided him with a stolen motorcycle to carry out the murder.

The police task force is still trying to track down the suspected mastermind identified by the surname Wu, who police said has fled to China, and another chief suspect, Wang Yao-kai, who, according to the two motorcycle thieves, abetted them in stealing the motorcycle at an agreed price.
Police have indicated that they are working through a cross-Taiwan Strait anti-crime mechanism to ask police in China to catch the mastermind and repatriate him to Taiwan.

The motivation for the murder is unclear, but the task force spokesman said police believe the criminals wanted to get rid of the opposition People First Party councilor because he had spoken out against vested interest groups in the lucrative gravel and sand trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUS PASSENGERS MAY HAVE TO BUCKLE UP IN PROPOSED ROAD SAFETY MEASURE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) is considering the introduction of mandatory seat belts for passengers in coaches that are used on mountain roads, the director of the MOTC department of railways and highways revealed Monday.

Yin Cheng-peng explained that the proposal was brought up to decrease the number of people killed or injured in traffic accidents after a tour bus ran off the road and crashed into a ravine on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei City Sunday, causing eight deaths and 25 injuries.
Under the regulations governing road traffic safety, all seats on coaches have had to be equipped with seat belts since Feb. 1.
However, Yin said, the law only demands for the installation of seat belts, but does not stipulate that passengers must use them.

Meanwhile, according to a statement from the Shaklee (Asia) Inc., the American- owned direct sales company that lost eight employees in Sunday's accident, the family of each of the dead is entitled to insurance compensation of at least NT$4 million.
The tour bus, carrying 29 passengers, was rented by the company's Taiwan branch to take its sales people from around the island to a meeting in the scenic Yangmingshan National Park.

The bus was traveling from Yangmingshan to Taipei when it hit a car in front of it and went off the road and into the ravine. Those who were injured during the accident include the bus driver, other Shaklee employees and several car passengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RECEIVES US$27.53 BILLION-WORTH OF EXPORT ORDERS IN MAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan received export orders totaling US$27.53 billion in May, representing a year-on-year growth of 11.92 percent, according to statistics released Monday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
The tallies also show that Taiwan received export orders totaling US$130.87 billion in the first five months of this year, up 12.25 percent from the same period of last year.

In terms of export items, information and telecommunications products made the biggest contribution, increasing by US$1.23 billion, or up 27.62 percent from the same month of last year, mainly because demand for notebook computers was strong and international companies continued to subcontract orders to Taiwan.
In May, Taiwan received orders from Hong Kong and China totaling US$7.45 billion in May, ahead of those valued at US$6.8 billion from the United States.

Among the companies surveyed by the MOEA, 22.67 percent anticipated that their orders will increase in June, while 24.77 percent expected dropping contract numbers and 52.56 percent expected the value of their foreign orders in June will be at the same level as for May.
MOEA Director-General of Statistics Huang Chi-shi estimated that foreign orders will continue to increase thanks to steady growth of global trading and the strong demand from emerging economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN INJURED IN CHEMICAL FACTORY FIRE

TEXT.P: Seven workers were injured Monday when a Taoyuan County factory producing high- purity chemicals for electronics manufacturing was destroyed by fire.
The injured workers were hospitalized with burns and respiratory problems caused by inhaling toxic fumes.
The fire occurred during a chemical dispensing process and spread to a storage tank at the Luchu township-based factory owned by E Kay Technology Co.
The fierce blaze soared as high as a 20-story building and produced a huge black pall of smoke that could be seen from five kilometers away.
Fire departments in the area dispatched 27 fire trucks to the fire scene and it took nearly six hours for firemen to bring the conflagration under control.
Officials from the Council of Labor Affairs said they will go back to the fire scene with fire experts to establish the cause of the fire.

E Kay Technology Coa. is a subsidiary of Yee Fong Chemical and Industrial Co. It was established in August 2000 to produce propylene oxide-based glycol ethers (POGEs) , which are in increasing demand because their high purity and low metal content make the materials ideal for the manufacturing of sensitive electronics components.

POGEs are used for the etching or depositing of conductive lines, as well as the removal of contaminant deposits and final cleaning of components. High purity of the materials is required because the slightest impurity could cause a short circuit on these highly sophisticated components.
E Kay Technology supplies around 100,000 tons per year of specialist chemicals to the Taiwanese electronics industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: FSC JOINS GOVERNMENT EFFORTS TO CRACK DOWN ON VOTE-BUYING

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC), the country's highest financial watchdog institution, will join the government's efforts to crack down on vote- buying with the approach of two key elections slated for 2008, Minister of Justice hih Mao-lin said Monday.

Shih made the announcement at a press conference he hosted with Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang and Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Shieh Jhy- wey at the GIO to publicize the Cabinet's anti-vote-buying strategies.
All relevant Cabinet units have been mobilized in the battle in a drive to carry out Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's pledge of holding clean elections in 2008.
It marked the first time the FSC has been summoned to assist in the task.

Shih also said that those who offer tips that lead to the uncovering of a vote- buying offense in the presidential election will be awarded with NT$15 million, while those who help crack down on vote-buying in the Legislative Yuan election will be awarded NT$10 million.
An anti-vote-buying hot line is available at 0800-024-099, Shih said, calling for the people to join the national campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCUMENTARY TO GIVE TAIWANESE INSIDE VIEW OF EU NEGOTIATION PROCESS

TEXT.P: A documentary focusing on European Commission President Jose Manuel Durao Barroso will be aired to give people of Taiwan an inside view of European Union (EU) negotiation processes, a Taiwan-based EU official said Monday.

The 52-minute documentary titled "At the Heart of Europe, " which will be aired at 10 p.m. July 5 on Public Television Service (PTS) channel, follows Barroso for six months and seeks to discover how much scope national governments, European members of parliament, pressure groups and journalists give the president of the commission.

"Taiwanese people can see what it is like working in a big international organization and see the daily negotiation process of the EU, " said Frederic Laplanche, deputy head of the European Economic and Trade Office (EETO) , the EU's representative office in Taiwan.

Viewers will be able to see and feel how difficult the negotiation process is and what the negotiation tactics are in Brussels, where an average of 50 meetings are held daily between 27 EU member states, he said.
"The documentary probably says something about Taiwan... One of the big lessons for Taiwan, in my opinion, is how the EU works and moves forward to face every crisis and find the solution, " he said.
The documentary was produced by the public television channel ARTE, which is a collaboration of Germany and France.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION INDEX IN MAY UP 6.35% OVER LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production index for May increased by 6.35 percent from the year-earlier figure to reach 152.83, a Ministry of Economic Affairs official said Monday.
The number was 7.55 percent higher than the April figure, the official added.

The manufacturing production index was 156.7 in May, up 6.71 percent over the year-earlier level. Meanwhile, the official said, the industrial production index for the first five months of this year was 139.05, an increase of 2.6 percent over the same period of last year.
The manufacturing production index from January to May was 143.03, up 2.84 percent year-on-year, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEASON'S 1ST CASE OF INDIGENOUS DENGUE FEVER REPORTED

TEXT.P: The first indigenous dengue fever case this summer has been reported in the Annan district of Tainan City, southern Taiwan, the Department of Health (DOH) said Monday.
Lin Ting, deputy director of DOH's Center for Disease Control, said the patient, a 21-year-old man, is now fully recovered. His parents, sisters and neighbors were not infected.

The DOH has sent extra personnel to carry out disinfection spraying around the man's house in the hope of eliminating the breeding sites of the mosquitoes that carry the disease. However, the mosquito density in the area was still high, leading health officials to suspect that there may be other potential patients who have yet to be detected.
The health officials will conduct a more thorough examination of the area.
Before this case, there were already 16 indigenous dengue fever cases, although all the cases were reported before the summer, showing them to be the tail end of last year's illnesses.
Forty imported dengue fever cases have been reported this year, with 24 cases imported from Indonesia, followed by 10 cases from Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES FORMER CHINA STEEL HEAD TO RETURN TO OLD POST

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Monday that the Cabinet has approved former China Steel Corp. Chairman Lin Wen-yuan to return to his old post in the state-controlled enterprise.
Lin has served as chairman of the Taiwan Cogeneration Corp. since leaving China Steel in October 2005.
Vice Economics Minister Shih Yen-hsiang said the ministry has notified China Steel of the Cabinet's decision. China Steel is set to convene a board meeting Friday to handle the new appointment.
A new post for current China Steel Chairman Chiang Yao-tsung has yet to be decided, he added.

Reports about Lin taking over the China Steel have been in circulation for some time, with some of them saying that the appointment of Lin -- a protege of President Chen Shui-bian and said to be an able hand in soliciting campaign funds -- is eyeing the presidential election next year.
Lin was forced out of China Steel partly because of his involvement in disputes concerning his receiving generous stock bonuses valued at NT$44 million (US$1.32 million) from the company.
Legislators of the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union demanded at the time that Lin return his bonus stock to the national coffers.

The lawmakers said Lin was leading China Steel as a representative of the government, which owns 23.5 percent of the company, and that he should voluntarily return the bonus stock, totaling 1.5 million shares, to the national treasury.
Lin worked as chairman of China Steel between December 2002 and October 2005, and received an annual salary of about NT$8 million.
Lin later donated the money to charity.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC TRACKING PATIENTS WITH SUPER-DRUG-RESISTANT FORM OF TB

TEXT.P: Taiwan might have 17 patients with super drug-resistant forms of tuberculosis (TB) remaining unaccounted for, an official with the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health said Monday.

Yang Shih-yang, a CDC division chief, made the remarks after U.S. health officials quarantined a man in late May over concern that he might have exposed passengers on two trans-Atlantic flights to a dangerous form of TB that the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention identified as "extensively drug- resistant TB."
Quoting CDC tallies, Yang said an average of 15,000 new TB cases are reported in Taiwan annually, about 6,000 of which are contagious.

Among local TB patients, Yang went on, an estimated 300 to 400 have multiple drug-resistant forms of TB. "And a further assessment shows that about 20 have even more dangerous super drug-resistant forms of TB," he added.
Noting that the CDC has so far only tracked down three patients with super drug- resistant forms of TB, Yang said 17 others suspected to have similar illness remain unaccounted for.
"We are worried that they might expose other people to the disease, " Yang said, adding that those with super drug-resistant forms of TB should immediately come forward to receive special treatment.
Those with contagious or dangerous forms of TB should also refrain from taking long-distance flights to prevent spread of the disease, Yang said.

Tuberculosis is a major communicable disease that the government has spent much money and energy fighting. Although the mortality rate has dropped by nearly 20 percent since the government launched a new treatment project, Yang said, TB remained the 13th highest cause of death in Taiwan last year.
Moreover, Yang added, the number of TB deaths outnumbered that of all other communicable diseases.

Tuberculosis is a bacterial infection that usually attacks the lungs. It is spread through the air and can lead to symptoms such as chest pain and coughing up blood. There were an estimated 1.6 million deaths from TB in 2005, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).

In late May, the U.S. government quarantined a patient with a super drug- resistant form of TB after he violated rules on taking long-distance flights. It marked the first U.S. federal quarantine order in 44 years.

To ensure public health and hygiene and protect airborne passengers from being infected with TB, Yang said the DOH has decided to forbid those with multi-drug- resistant forms of TB from taking any flights from July 1 and those with contagious TB from taking international flights that last eight hours or longer. Violators will be slapped with fines ranging between NT$10,000 (about US$303) and NT$150,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Election set for 2008 Gordon Brown put Britain and the Labour Party on the alert for a general election next year as he was crowned as Tony Blairs successor yesterday.
In his first speech as party leader, he promised to heed and lead the call for change. He also used his coronation speech to announce the appointment of an election co-ordinator in a clear signal that he would like to go to the country next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Hussein Cousin Sentenced to Die for Kurd Attacks
As the judge pronounced five death sentences on the man Iraqis know as Chemical Ali, the defendant seemed on Sunday to be a shadow of the merciless enforcer who oversaw poison gas attacks that killed thousands of Kurdish villagers in Iraqs northern uplands nearly 20 years ago.
At the age of 61, severely weakened by diabetes, the defendant, Ali Hassan al- Majid, leaned heavily on a walking stick for the 18 minutes it took the judge to read guilty verdicts on counts of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity. Unlike his cousin Saddam Hussein, whose shouted defiance nearly drowned out the judge who sent him to the gallows last year, Mr. Majid offered no protest until the judge ordered bailiffs to lead him from the iron-ribbed cage that serves as a dock.
Wall Street Journal:'Mainstreaming' Trend Tests Classroom Goals
When school started last August, veteran first -grade teacher Patricia McDermott made sure to place one student, 8-year-old Andrea Gavern, in a seat beside her own desk.
Andrea suffers from a rare genetic condition called Williams Syndrome, which causes learning disabilities and medical ailments such as heart problems and difficulty eating. Knowing that Andrea had disrupted her kindergarten classes a year earlier, Ms. McDermott wanted to keep her new pupil under close watch.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VOWS TO PUSH THROUGH CEC DRAFT LAW IN EXTRA SESSION

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) vowed Monday to push through a draft organic law concerning the formation of the Central Election Commission (CEC) in a proposed legislative extra session.

Hsu Shao-ping, the KMT's legislative caucus whip, told reporters that the party is poised to have the draft CEC organic law approved during the planned extra session now that the KMT has allowed the passage of the 2007 central government budget bill June 15 -- the last day of the previous session.

Hsu's remarks came after Ker Chien-ming, the legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), called earlier that same day for an extra legislative session to be held as soon as possible to handle 13 bills that it submitted, and urged the KMT not to continue insisting on first screening the draft CEC organic law as a way to block other bills.

Since the annual budget bill has cleared the Legislative Yuan, Hsu argued that the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) should in turn permit the draft CEC organic law crafted by the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) to pass.

Commenting on the 13 bills that the DPP hopes to deal with in the extra session, Hsu said the KMT will support the passage of those pertaining to Taiwan's economic development but will not back bill that aims to get back for the national coffers the KMT's ill-gotten assets.
According to Hsu, the KMT will come up with a decision next week on when to hold the legislative session, with the date tentatively set for July 9.

Speaking in a Legislative Yuan news conference earlier in the day, Ker said the DPP legislative caucus has gained sufficient endorsements from lawmakers to call an extra session to address the 13 important bills -- including sunshine bills on political donations and the KMT's ill-gotten assets, a five-year NT$500 billion public work expansion bill and a budget bill for state-run companies, as well as bills aimed at the underprivileged and a tax reform bill.

Now that Ma Ying-jeou, the KMT's presidential candidate, has vowed to devote his energy to helping reinvigorate what he has called Taiwan's dwindling economy, Ker said, Ma should ask the KMT lawmakers not to block the sunshine and economic stimulus bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: INFECTIOUS TB PATIENTS TO BE BARRED FROM TAKING LONG-HAUL FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: From July 1, those who are infected with infectious tuberculosis (TB) will be barred from taking long-haul international flights of over eight hours, the Department of Health (DOH) said Monday.

Yang Shih-yang, a section chief of the DOH Center for Disease Control, said that those infected with infectious TB should wait for tests to show negative after taking medicine for two weeks before boarding a long-haul flight.

Those infected with multiple drug-resistant TB will not be allowed to fly at all until they are fully recovered, with violators facing fines of between NT$10,000 and NT$150,000 (US$303-US$4,545) , he said.
As domestic flights are all less than an hour in duration, the DOH has yet to set restrictions on these flights for TB patients, Yang said.
But he said infectious TB patients should wear a surgical mask throughout the flight, while multiple drug-resistant TB patients should refrain from taking domestic flights.
Yang also said the DOH is planning to provide a list of the two kinds of TB patients to immigration authorities in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: RHINO HORN SEIZED AT TAOYUAN AIRPORT

TEXT.P: A man returning from a trip to South Africa was prosecuted by the Taoyuan Public Prosecutors Office Monday for trying to smuggle a rhino horn in his golf bag.
Taipei Customs Office Deputy Director Li Mao said the man, identified by the surname Hsu, had a 61-cm-long rhino horn weighing 4.8 kg in his checked-in luggage -- a golf bag.

According to Li, Hsu claimed he was not aware there was a rhino horn in the golf bag because he was merely bringing in the bag at the request of a "mandarin- speaking oriental man" he met in South Africa.

In addition to having the rhino horn confiscated, Hsu could face up to five years in prison, plus a fine of between NT$300,000 and NT$1.5 million (US$45,640), for breaching the nation's Wildlife Conservation Law.

Possession and trade of rhino horn is prohibited worldwide under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora in an attempt to protect the 11,000 rhinos left in the world today.

However, a thriving black market in rhino horn has continued, mainly because in some East Asian countries, rhino horn is seen as a treasured medicine, while in the Arab country of Yemen, rich young men use rhino horn to make elaborately- carved dagger handles as a symbol of their wealth and status.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE ENVISIONS MAKING TAIWAN `FREE TRADE ZONE'

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, the presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang, pledged Monday to make Taiwan a "free trade zone" so as to more competitively open the country to the rest of the world.
Ma made the pledge while giving a keynote speech in Taipei titled: "Taiwan's Turn" in English during a forum sponsored by UBS AG, Taipei Branch.

Stressing his determination to promote trade and economic policies based on "Taiwan-centric" beliefs to benefit Taiwan's people if he wins the 2008 presidential poll, Ma promised that he will do his best to build Taiwan into a "free trade zone" that would allow the country to further reach out.

The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government's refusal to set up direct transport links with China and its restrictions on China-bound investment by local companies have negatively impacted Taiwan's economy, Ma claimed.

The KMT candidate said he is confident that Taiwan's economy will be given a boost if he is elected president, adding that his pairing up with Vincent Siew -- a veteran economic technocrat who served as premier from 1997-2000 -- has also helped ease concern in the business community.
According to Ma, foreign investors and companies believe that the election of the KMT ticket will help revive Taiwan's economy.
The main theme of his election campaign will be the economy, he said, adding that the DPP government has had five premiers serving six terms of premiership over the past seven years.
With such frequent changes of premier, the government has been unable to hammer out comprehensive policies to fit Taiwan's economic needs, according to Ma.

Recounting recent trip he made to Singapore and India, Ma said Taiwan's economic development and its relations with China are the two issues about which most "foreign friends" are concerned with regard to Taiwan.
He also touted the importance of a "non mutual denial" concept broached by himself to promote peace and development in cross-Taiwan Strait.

Like most of Taiwan's people who favor maintaining the status quo across the strait, Ma said, he will make it clear to the international community upon his election that the Republic of China does not intend to alter the current cross- strait situation.
Ma also expressed his belief that a new TV ad showing him striding ahead against a blank background will help relay his message to the public that Taiwan needs to continue moving forward.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4 APPLICATIONS FOR CHINA-BOUND INVESTMENT PASS INITIAL SCREENING

TEXT.P: Applications submitted by four Taiwanese technology firms seeking to invest in low-end semiconductor packaging and testing factories in China have passed "strategic screening" by a supraministerial task force, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Monday.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang identified the four companies as the Siliconware Precision Industries Co., Walton Advanced Engineering Inc., Greatek Electronics and Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Group.

The government announced the lifting of a ban on Taiwanese firms investing in packaging and testing factories in China in April last year. Many Taiwanese companies submitted applications, but only four passed the first phase of screening, Shih said.

The supraministerial task force started examining the applications in early June and decided that these four companies' applications fitted in with the government's regulations on cross-strait division of labor and investment.

The MOEA's Investment Commission has begun the second stage of acreening or substantial screening, Shih said, adding that the commission will finalize its examination and deliberation as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES THE PUBLIC TO DONATE BLOOD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the public Monday to donate blood during the summer when local schools, a regular source of blood donations, are in recess.
Chen made the remarks while receiving long-term blood donors at the Presidential Office.
Noting that this year marks the 33rd year in which Taiwan has promoted blood donation, Chen said that many locals have become regular blood donors.
Taiwan now has a high percentage of blood donors, on a level on par with advanced countries, according to Chen.
With summer approaching, blood reserves will be in short supply, Chen said, urging the public to lend a helping hand to those in need.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WINS BIG AT INTERNATIONAL CHILDREN'S GAMES

TEXT.P: Young athletes from Taipei won a total of six gold, four silver and four bronze medals at the just-concluded 41st International Children's Games (ICG) held in Reykjavik, Iceland, Taipei city government officials said Monday.
The 17-member team took park in four events -- judo, badminton, golf and swimming, the officials said, adding that the number of medals won by the team was five more than last year's figure.
A total of 964 young athletes, mostly junior and senior high school students, from 64 cities in 33 countries took part in the 2007 ICG.
According to city officials, China tried unsuccessfully to bar the Taipei students from wearing the Republic of China national flag to receive their trophies during the medal-presentation ceremonies.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO HOLD ROUNDTABLE ON LABOR POLICY CONCERNS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will hold a roundtable Tuesday to discuss major labor policy concerns, including the much-anticipated overhaul of foreign labor policy, government sources said Monday.

The roundtable will bring together representatives of labor unions and employer associations as well as labor affairs administrators and academics to exchange views on major labor policy concerns, the sources said.

It meeting will be the first of its kind since the minimum wage was hiked and new CLA Chairman Lu Tine-lin assumed office. The last roundtable took place in April, with basic wage adjustment as main theme.

Officials from the CLA and the Ministry of Economic Affairs as well as senior executives of six leading industry and commerce associations and the national federation of labor unions are expected to take part in Tuesday's roundtable discussion which is likely to focus on foreign labor policy issues.
According to CLA officials, foreign labor policy may be adjusted in terms of domestic labor market situation, economic development, public sentiments and management responses.

CLA Chairman Lu Tien-lin said earlier this month that a dynamic management mechanism will replace the current quota system with regard to labor import policy. Under the new system, Lu said local enterprises will be allowed to import more migrant workers if the domestic unemployment rate drops to a certain level and local people's job opportunities will not be affected and vice versa.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO HOLD ROUNDTABLE ON LABOR POLICY CONCERNS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will hold a roundtable Tuesday to discuss major labor policy concerns, including the much-anticipated overhaul of foreign labor policy, government sources said Monday.

The roundtable will bring together representatives of labor unions and employer associations as well as labor affairs administrators and academics to exchange views on major labor policy concerns, the sources said.

It meeting will be the first of its kind since the minimum wage was hiked and new CLA Chairman Lu Tine-lin assumed office. The last roundtable took place in April, with basic wage adjustment as main theme.

Officials from the CLA and the Ministry of Economic Affairs as well as senior executives of six leading industry and commerce associations and the national federation of labor unions are expected to take part in Tuesday's roundtable discussion which is likely to focus on foreign labor policy issues.
According to CLA officials, foreign labor policy may be adjusted in terms of domestic labor market situation, economic development, public sentiments and management responses.

CLA Chairman Lu Tien-lin said earlier this month that a dynamic management mechanism will replace the current quota system with regard to labor import policy. Under the new system, Lu said local enterprises will be allowed to import more migrant workers if the domestic unemployment rate drops to a certain level and local people's job opportunities will not be affected and vice versa.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 26, or the 12th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
363: Roman emperor Julian the Apostate, the first non-Christian emperor since Constantine, dies of spear wounds inflicted during a battle with the Persians. He was 32.
1541: Francisco Pizarro, the Spanish conqueror of Peru who played a major part in crushing the Inca Empire, is attacked and killed in his house in Lima. He was 66.
1843: Hong Kong is proclaimed a British colony, with Sir Henry Pottinger as its first governor.
1844: John Tyler, the 10th president of the United States, who succeeded to office after the death of President William Henry Harrison, secretly marries Julia Gardiner in New York. His administration was marked by the annexation of Texas in 1845.
1858: The Treaty of Tientsin is signed, ending hostilities between China's Ching court and Britain and granting British trade rights.
1892: Pearl S. Buck, the American writer who won the 1938 Nobel Prize for literature, is born. Her life as a missionary in China lent a vivid immediacy to her novels, including "The Good Earth."
1907: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, receives an honorary doctorate from Oxford University. He drew on his childhood experiences along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1908: The U.S. Congress votes to return the so-called "Boxer Indemnity" in the amount of US$14.8 million. The money was used three years later to found Tsinghua School and to help finance Chinese students' studies in the United States.
1930: Joseph Stalin announces that his murderous purges are "purifying" the Soviet Union.
1945: Representatives from 50 nations including the Republic of China, one of the U.N. founding members, sign the United Nations Charter in San Francisco. The charter would become effective Oct. 24.
1956: The Tainan College of Technology in Taiwan is formally transformed into National Cheng Kung University.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1962: The United States declares it will not support any attempt by the ROC on Taiwan to land forces on the Chinese mainland.
1963: A million and a quarter West Berliners turn out to give a tumultuous welcome to U.S. President John F. Kennedy who addresses the 120,000-strong crowd in Rathaus Square near the Berlin Wall.
1975: Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declares a state of emergency and arrests hundreds of political opponents.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Irian Jaya province in Indonesia, killing more than 400 people.
1986: The ROC Executive Yuan announces that, due to opposition by Lukang residents, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has ordered a hold on the Du Pont Corporation's plan to construct a titanium dioxide plant in Lukang and the carrying out of an environmental impact study on the project.
1989: Student leaders who have escaped from the Chinese mainland after the Tiananmen Square massacre leave Hong Kong for exile to Western countries.
1991: Approval is given to 15 of 19 applications to set up private commercial banks in the Republic of China.
1992: A peoples' court in mainland China's Tsingtao sentences Li Hsienpin, an air force pilot who defected to Taiwan and later returned to the mainland, to 15 years in prison for "surrender to the enemy and mutiny."
1993: U.S. forces hit targets in Iraq following a failed assassination attempt on former U.S. President George Bush while he was visiting Kuwait in April.
1998: President Bill Clinton begins a state visit to mainland China in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, where a protest movement was brutally suppressed nine years earlier.
1999: ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang leaves for Auckland, New Zealand, to attend an annual trade ministers meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
1999: The Ever Power IPP, Taiwan's first private power plant to use natural gas to generate power, is inaugurated at Luchu, Taoyuan County, in northern Taiwan.
2001: ROC Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi signs an agreement with his Guatemalan counterpart, Marco A. Ventura, to help train youth from the Central American nation.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the employment of people in forced labor on works for the public good, if you select those who are most able to bear it, who will have any cause for complaint?"

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S SON-IN-LAW GETS HEAVIER SENTENCE IN SECOND TRIAL

TEXT.P: Chao Chien-ming, president Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law, was given a seven-year sentence Tuesday following his appeal to the Taiwan High Court for his role in insider trading of stock of the Taiwan Development Corporation (TDC).
He had been sentenced to six years in jail in the original trial heard in the Taipei District Court on December 27, 2006.
His father, Chao Yu-chu, was sentenced to nine and a half years in jail in the same case Tuesday, compared to a sentence of eight years and four months handed down in the first trial.
A fine of NT$30 million (US$915,383)in addition to the jail terms, which was imposed in the original trial on both Chao Chien-ming and Chao Yu-chu, remained unchanged.
Two other defendants in the case, Yu Shi-yi and former TDC Chairman Su Teh- chien, were also handed fine and heavier prison time.
Yu received a sentence of seven years in prison in addition to a fine of NT$60 million (US$1.83 million).
Su was given a jail term of seven years and six months and a fine of NT$30 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
SUSPECTED 'INTERLOCUTOR' IN COUNCILOR ASSASSINATION NABBED

TEXT.P: A man suspected of playing an intermediary role in the murder of a Taipei County councilor last month was nabbed Tuesday, just a day after the alleged killer in the case committed suicide following a gun battle with police.

Wang Yueh-kai, 24, was staying with six other men and a woman in an apartment on Changshun Street in Taipei's Wanhua district close by a police station and a police dormitory when he was arrested by detectives in the early hours of Tuesday morning.

According to the police investigation team, Wang served as a liaison in the assassination of Councilor Wu Shan-jeou in May. He was believed to have abetted Wu Chu-hsien and Hu Ting-yueh in stealing two motorcycles, which were later modified into one vehicle for the use of the alleged gunman, Lan Chia-wei, in the Mafia-style killing of the outspoken councilor.

Wu Chu-hsien and Hu Ting-yueh are already in police custody after they were apprehended in a raid earlier this month, but the suspected mastermind of the cold-blooded murder, identified as Wu Hsin-chung, fled to China a couple of days after the assassination.
Police said Wang's arrest is expected to help verify Wu Hsin-chung's role in the premeditated killing, particularly his motives, and determine whether there are other suspects remaining at large.

Councilor Wu Shan-jeou, an opposition People First Party member and councilor from Taipei County's Hsintien City, was gunned down in his office May 23 and died on the spot after being shot four times.

After a month of intensive investigations, police said they believed that both suspects Lan and Wang had not yet received any money from the suspected mastermind after the councilor's murder, and that the fugitives had joined together to avoid capture.
The investigative team had mounted more than 10 raids in Panchiao, Taipei City, Yilan, Chiayi, Changhua and Taichung in attempts to nab the two, but all those operations failed.
Late on Sunday night, Lan, 36, who had arrived by bus from Chiayi City in southern Taiwan stumbled onto a police roadblock while walking near the intersection of Civic Boulevard and Chengde Road.
When he was stopped by police officers for a routine check, he dropped the bag he was carrying and fled. The officers gave chase and called for reinforcements.

Hemmed in by police, Lan exchanged gunfire with police officers in a parking lot for more than 20 minutes, before turning the gun on himself. He was declared dead on arrival after being rushed to nearby Mackay Memorial Hospital.

Following Lan's death, police stepped up efforts to track down the alleged intermediary, Wang, by closely monitoring the behavior of his family members as well as analyzing Lan's cellphone records. Police finally traced Wang to the apartment in Wanhua, which is adjacent to a police dormitory and a riot police station.

Now that the key contact or "middleman" in the murder has been rounded up, police said they will use cross-Taiwan Strait communication channels to request that their Chinese counterparts speed up efforts to track down the suspected mastermind Wu Hsin-chung.

According to police, Wu Hsin-chung and some friends were involved in environmental cleanup businesses and the murder is possibly connected to those deals. Councilor Wu Shan-jeou often raised environmental issues at Taipei County Council sessions before his death.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO VISIT 3 ALLIES IN LATIN AMERICA, CARIBBEAN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu will visit three diplomatic allies of the Republic of China in Latin America and the Caribbean next month to cement ties with them, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Simon Ko, director of MOFA's Department of Central and South American Affairs, said Lu, at the head of a delegation, will depart Taiwan July 2 for Paraguay, Guatemala and the Dominican Republic for a 10-day visit. Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Ho Ching-shan will accompany her for the visit.
But Ko said that Lu's itinerary has yet to be finalized, and the ministry will have further discussion with officials at the Presidential Office Wednesday.

MOFA officials also said that the United States, based on the principles of "dignity, safety, comfort and convenience, " has initially arranged for Lu to make a transit stop on the U.S. West Coast en route to Central America, although a stopover via the United States on her return trip to Taiwan has yet to be finalized.

Lu's visit will come against the background of Taiwan's severing of relations with Costa Rica earlier this month afer the Central American country switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, ending a 63-year diplomatic relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ASSESS NICARAGUA'S REQUEST TO WRITE OFF DEBTS: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that the ministry will study the request of its Central America ally Nicaragua to write off its debts.

Simon Ko, director of MOFA's Department of Central and Southern American Affairs, made the remarks in the wake of media reports that Nicaragua Foreign Minister Samuel Santos has requested that Taiwan write off the debts as a precondition for maintaining diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Ko said that Nicaragua, an impoverished country with a high level of debt, may have asked its other creditor countries to write off the debts.

He said that debt elimination is probably a world trend, but since Taiwan is not a member of "The Paris Club, " and has no similar debt relief mechanism, it will have to take stock of the experience of the club.

The Paris Club is an informal group of financial officials from 19 of the world's richest countries, which provides financial services, including debt restructuring, debt relief, and debt cancellation to indebted countries and their creditors. Debtor countries which have failed to reach agreement with credit countries on rescheduling their debts are often recommended to the Paris Club for assistance by the International Monetary Fund.
"Taiwan will have to gauge it's own financial capacity and discuss the matter before conducting an assessment and making a decision," Ko said.
The ministry is currently collecting relevant information for related government agencies to study, he added.

The Nicaraguan request comes against the background of Taiwan's severing of relations with Costa Rica earlier this month afer the Central American country switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, ending a 63-year diplomatic relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COMPUTER BUSINESS DELEGATION TO VISIT VIETNAM IN JULY

TEXT.P: A delegation of Taiwanese computer businesses, organized by the Taipei Computer Association (TCA) , is scheduled to make a five-day visit to Vietnam July 1-5 to explore the market there in an effort to seek new trade opportunities.

According to the TCA, the business delegation will be headed by a TCA board member, Wang Chao-chun, chairman of the Taipei-based LEO Systems, Inc. Members of the group include high-ranking executives of more than 10 companies in the information technology sector, such as Chunghwa Telecom Co., Tatung Co. and Syscom Computer Engineering Co.

The visit is a part of the executive programs of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Digital Opportunity Center, which is run by the Board of Foreign Trade under Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs, to pursue an APEC- initiated goal to narrow the digital gap between developed and developing countries in the region.
During the delegation's stay in Ho Chih Minh City, it will attend a trade fair and a business presentation, and visit local IT-relevant associations and companies.

Ho Chih Minh city, the largest Vietnamese city, has obtained government support to develop itself as a computer software, electronic parts and components, and IT services supplying center in Southeast Asia by the year of 2010. With that goal in mind, it will invest US$2.5 billion in the IT market in the next years, according to the TCA.

The fund will be used to establish Internet accessing networks in middle schools, popularize information technology, upgrade public services of the local government, and cultivate 1,000 IT marketing talents and 30,000 IT experts, TCA executives said.

Ho Chi Minh City is now the largest IT products trading center in Vietnam, with a sale's volume accounting for 55 percent of the total in the country. It is also the home of over 300 electronic information enterprises.

According to the Vietnamese Ministry of Trade's assessment, total sales of personnel computers in the country are expected to surge to 1.5 million units this year, representing a nearly 30 percent in year-on-year growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL HOTLINE FOR TEENAGE PREGNANCY COUNSELING LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) announced Tuesday the launch of the national toll-free 0800-257085 hotline providing teenage pregnancy counseling.
Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang noted that the ministry has since 2004 subsidized the operation of various teenage pregnancy counseling hotlines in 15 counties and cities.

In an effort to expand those services to the entire country, the ministry integrated the hotlines under a single number and set up the www.257085.org.tw Web site to provide one-stop service to pregnant teenagers who need help, Lee said.

Chi Hui-jung, CEO of the non-profit Garden of Hope Foundation that is in charge of operating the hotline, estimated that the number of underage abortions in Taiwan number approximately 24,300 cases per year, based on National Youth Commission tallies which show there were 12,300 surgical abortions, and 12,000 non-surgical abortions involving girls under 20 years of age in 2002.
With MOI tallies indicating that 5,000 babies were born to teenage mothers in 2006, the number of teenage pregnancies likely totals at least 30,000 per year, Chi said.

According to Chi, many pregnant teenagers find themselves helpless to deal with pregnancy, which involves common problems such as whether to tell their parents, how to tell their parents, whether to have an abortion or give birth to the baby, whether to get married, and whether to give up their babies for adoption by others.

In addition to counseling pregnant teenagers in need of assistance, hotline workers can also help transfer their cases to social workers for medical, legal, financial and adoption services and help negotiate with their families, Chi said.
Meanwhile, the teenage pregnancy Web site provides various information on pregnancy, parenting, medical care, schooling and employment, along with an online counseling mailbox, Chi said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD APPROVAL NEEDED FOR BASE STATION: MAYOR

TEXT.P: Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair instructed city government officials Tuesday to draw up regulations which will require the approval of neighborhood residents before wireless network base stations are established within the city.

Although there is no evidence proving that electromagnetic waves pose a hazard to human health, most people choose, if possible, to remain at a distance from cell phone base stations and other types of transmission stations.

As there are increasing protests among local people against the erection of wireless network base stations in their neighborhoods, some entrepreneurs are disguising their base stations, causing greater panic among citizens concerned about their health.

In view of recent strong protest among villagers against a cell phone base station in Tainan City, and a wireless networking system to be set up in the city that has been a cause of great concern among environmentalists, Hsu proposed the autonomous regulations, applicable only in Tainan City, and called for an efficient means of managing the establishment of base stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA ESTABLISHES 'GENE TRANSFER & CLONING RANCH'

TEXT.P: A new laboratory to study animals after they undergo gene transfer and cloning operations has been established by the staff of the Livestock Research Institute (LRI) under the cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, government sources announced Tuesday.

The new lab in the southern county of Tainan -- officially named the "Molecular Research Ranch for Gene-modified Animals" -- serves as an "intensive care unit" for livestock or poultry that has been genetically modified in other labs, LRI researchers explained.

Animals undergoing genetic modification require intensive care to preserve the intended genetic expressions, as well as to protect them from disease, mutation, or contamination, they noted, adding that most livestock research labs in Taiwan lack such facilities, meaning that an ICU-type lab has been urgently needed for a long time.

They pointed out that the "ranch" is currently equipped with animal surgeries, an assisted reproductive technology center, a genetic engineering lab, and a farm for gene-modified animals. LRI will continue expanding the lab's equipment and refining its standard operating procedures to earn accreditation from the International Organization for Standardization.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange were lower Tuesday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 73.44 points to close at 8,865.75.
The bourse opened at 8,695.82 and fluctuated between 8,983.96 and 8,856.29 during trading. A total of 5.7 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$160.48 billion (US$4.9 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issue moving down the most at 2.02 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.31 percent, construction issues at 1.09 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.32 percent, and cement stocks at 0.22 percent.

The three other major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 0.6 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.33 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 971 to 284, with 134 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL UNIVERSITY DISCOVERS 10 NEW SPECIES OF SEA SLUG

TEXT.P: National Sun Yat-sen University in the southern port city of Kaohsiung has discovered 10 new species of sea slug, drawing international attention to its remarkable research results, an university spokesman announced Tuesday.
The announcement came at a press conference that the university held to unveil the results of its recent research on sea slugs in waters off Taiwan.

Sun Yat-sen University was one of the few local universities granted subsidies from the Ministry of Education in 2005 as part of the ministry's five-year subsidy plan of NT$50 billion (US$1.5 billion) aimed at enhancing the quality of academic research.

The university's research team has identified 150 species of the marine creatures in waters off Taiwan, as well as the outlying islets of Penghu, Hsiaoliuchiu, Green Island, and Orchid Island, Michael Hin-Kiu Mok, a professor at the university's Institute of Marine Biology, said.

Nearly 120 of the sea slugs are newly collected in Taiwan, and 10 of may have been discovered for the first time, Mok pointed out, adding that few of the animals found were previously recorded in Taiwan's scientific literature.
At present, 2,700-3,000 species of sea slug have been identified around the world, according to Mok.

Compared with only four or five species of such animals found off the coast of Australia, Taiwan's discovery of 150 species in its waters has received a significant amount of attention from the international community, Mok said, adding that 61 of these species are found in the Wai-an sea area off of Penghu Island.
Mok urged the government to designate the area as a protected one, which he claimed will become a new environmental asset.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BAN WHALE SHARK SALES STARTING JUNE 27

TEXT.P: Sales of whale sharks, the largest living fish species, fillets of the same will be banned in Taiwan starting Wednesday, an executive of the fishermen's association of Suao township in Yilan county, northeastern Taiwan, said Tuesday.

The Council of Agriculture (COA) , the highest fishery authority of the country, stipulated a catch quota of 30 whale sharks for this year. When that quota was reached in March, the COA declared March 27 that no further fishing would be allowed to target the giant fish -- locally called "Tofu shark" for its tender and white meat. The COA also demanded that the catches be sold out within three months.
The sale deadline is due on June 27, Lin Yueh-ying said.

Whale shark is not listed as an endangered species in Taiwan, but is listed in the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) signed in 1973 in Washington to slowdown species extinction.

Out of respect for the international convention, Taiwan has set catch quotas to control the take of whale sharks. In 2006, the quota was set at 60, and that was cut into half this year, Lin said, noting a full ban on targeting the filter feeding shark will be imposed for next year.

Under the ban, fishermen are obliged to return whale shark bi-catch to the ocean, whether it is dead or alive. Violators face up to a maximum three years' imprisonment or fine of up to NT$150,000 (US$4,575), according to the COA.
