DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES ARMED FORCES TO SHED `OLD MINDSET'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the military Tuesday to sever ties with the "old era" and shed what he called is its "old mindset" and step up democratic education in the military.

The president made the remarks while presiding over a commissioning ceremony for senior military officers at the Ministry of National Defense. A total of 45 military personnel were promoted to the ranks of major general or lieutenant general.
The president noted that from July 1, the "five tenets" of the nation's armed forces that have been observed for decades will be shortened to "three tenets."
He was referring to the deletion of "doctrine" and "leader" and the keeping of "nation, responsibility and honor."

He said that in the past, the line between the then-ruling Kuomintang and the nation was thin so that the military put "doctrine and leader" ahead of "nation" to facilitate the championing of a specific ideology and the promotion of the personality cult of the late President Chiang Kai-shek and later his son, the late President Chiang Ching-kuo.
"In this way, the armed forces served a specific party and individuals, " Chen said, which he said posed the greatest hindrance and damage to Taiwan's pursuit of democracy and freedom.

He noted that since he first assumed the presidency in 2000, he immediately embarked on the task of promoting the neutrality of the armed forces and readjusting the function of the political warfare system from a tool serving a specific party to spy on the armed forces to one that really cares about the welfare of military personnel.
He also ordered the removal of all statues of Chiang Kai-shek from military barracks.
These, coupled with the shortening of the tenets for the armed forces, have paved the way for the military to "sever ties with the old era and shed its old mindset thoroughly," Chen said.
He expressed the hope that "political turbulence will not affect the right tenets and management of the military."

He noted that there will be two national elections in the coming months -- the legislative and the presidential elections, during which several proposals might be put to national referendum -- which he said will be a major litmus test of Taiwan's deepening of democracy.
He urged the armed forces to "step up the education of democracy and rule of law so that the armed forces will not be disrupted by the election activities."

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH FIRM TO INVITE PUBLIC TO BREAK BIKING RECORD

TEXT.P: The France-based mineral water firm Volvic has invited the public to take part in a bike ride July 21 aimed at breaking a Guinness world record.

In a bid to arouse the importance of protecting the Earth and taking exercise, the company has invited the people to take part in an attempt to break the previous world record of 641 bicycles riding at the same time for 3.5 km in the Netherlands last year.

The activity will start from and end at the Tachia Riverside Park along the Keelung River and will be a 16-km ride, with each participant awarded a T-shirt. Some lucky participants will win free gifts offered by the organizer, including a visit to France.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP STARTS FUND-RAISING DRIVE TO HELP FORMER ORPHANAGE RESIDENTS

TEXT.P: The Chinese Childrenhome and Shelter Association started a fund-raising campaign Tuesday aimed at helping former orphanage residents live independently.
The campaign is being held through Sept. 24 in cooperation with the convenience store chain FamilyMart, with the goal of raising NT$1.5 million to help at least 1,800 former orphanage residents.

During the period, the public are welcome to donate cash using donation boxes available in FamilyMart stores nationwide, make donations online through the association's Web site at www.childrenhome.org.tw, or remit their donations to the association's postal account, according to the association's secretary-general, Hung Chin-fang.

The funds will be used to finance various programs preparing orphans for independent living after leaving orphanages, including psychological counseling and guidance, vocational training, subsidies for senior high school, college and university tuition fees, as well as allowances for housing rental, National Health Insurance premiums and living costs, Hung said.

She noted that most orphanage residents have to face the pressure of schooling and employment immediately after leaving orphanages and that only a small number of them are able to live in their relatives' homes.

Because of their limited educational backgrounds and financial difficulties, most former orphanage residents are unable to further their studies and thus have problems finding stable employment, she said.

According to the results of a survey conducted by the association in February on 42 orphanages around the country, 60 percent of the respondents said financial assistance is what orphanage residents need the most after leaving orphanages, while 56 percent mentioned assistance in schooling and employment.
The survey found that 69 percent of orphanage residents leave the institutions before the age of 15, with only 48 percent continuing schooling after that.

Meanwhile, former residents at 44 percent of the surveyed orphanages have full- time jobs and stable work, while those from 32 percent of the orphanages have only part-time jobs and 50 percent have unstable employment.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST CHIKUNGUNYA FEVER CASE THIS YEAR REPORTED

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) reported Tuesday this year's first imported case of chikungunya fever, a viral illness that is spread by the bite of infected mosquitoes.
Lin Ting, deputy director of the DOH Center for Disease Control, said the patient is a five-year old boy whose mother is an Indonesian woman married to a Taiwanese national.

The boy returned to Indonesia with his mother recently and developed a high fever and rash upon his return June 20. He was confirmed to have been infected with chikungunya fever five days later, Lin said.
Lin said it was still not certain if the boy's mother has also been infected.

Lin noted that chikungunya fever is an infectious disease often seen in Southeast Asia, South Africa and South America. The symptoms are similar to dengue fever, although the incubation period is shorter and the symptoms are more obvious.

The disease is characterized by severe, sometimes persistent, joint pain, as well as fever and rash. It is rarely life-threatening. Nevertheless widespread occurrence of the disease causes substantial morbidity and economic loss.

Lin said the first imported chikungunya fever case occurred seven months ago. The patient was a student studying in Singapore, which, together with Japan, later detected imported cases, although both countries had had no such cases before.

Lin noted that to prevent the disease from making inroads into Taiwan, the priority will be to stop it from entering Taiwan. On this point, the fever monitoring stations set up at the nation's airports have worked to good result.
The other important task will be to remove standing water in the environment to prevent the mosquitoes from breeding.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER TO LEAVE FOR AFRICA JULY 4

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang is scheduled to depart July 4 for a 10-day visit to the country's five diplomatic allies in Africa, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Tuesday.
Huang's destinations will cover Malawi, Swaziland, Burkina Faso, Gambia and Sao Tome and Principe, the officials said.
He will extend invitations on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian to the heads of state of the African nations to take part in a leadership summit slated for Sept. 9 in Taiwan, they added.
Also during the visit, Huang will attend celebrations to mark the National Days of Malawi and Sao Tome, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORDER GIVEN TO ELIMINATE BROWN ANOLES IN CHIAYI COUNTY

TEXT.P: Agriculture authorities in Chiayi County issued an order Tuesday to eliminate all brown anoles -- a lizard species native to Cuba and the Bahamas -- because they have been propagating so rapidly that they now pose a threat to indigenous lizard species.
Tseng Yung-hua, head of the Agriculture Bureau under the Chiayi county government, urged residents to report sightings of the lizards to the authorities so that action can be taken to catch them.

Tseng said the results of an initial study show that the brown anole probably carries parasites and that their presence could impact the local ecology, environment and the "quality of life of people in the county."

The brown anole, or anolis sagrei, was first discovered in Chiayi County seven years ago. But recently, large numbers of the lizards have been sighted in orchards, betel palm plantations and rural neighborhoods in Chiayi County.

An estimate by agriculture experts puts the number of brown anoles in Chiayi County at more than 10,000. It is not known how the foreign lizard got into Taiwan, but the experts believe they were brought in from the United States.
Agriculture officials said that if their propagation is not stemmed in time, they could spread rapidly to other areas of Taiwan.
In July last year, a resident of Hualien City spotted four brown anoles in his backyard and took photos of them.
The brown anole originates from Cuba and the Bahamas and spread to Florida, Louisiana, Georgia, Texas and Mexico.

A major characteristic of these lizards is that they extend an orange dewlap -- a fold of loose skin hanging from the neck -- when they feel threatened. The lizards feed on ants, spiders, grasshoppers and many other insects and defend their territory very fiercely.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CAUTIONS PUBLIC NOT TO FALL VICTIM TO KOREAN FRAUD RINGS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) urged the public Tuesday not to seek employment with unknown companies or individuals seeking frontmen for unlawful activities in South Korea.

According to MOFA officials, since September 2006 more than 100 people from Taiwan have been arrested by South Korean police for allegedly opening dummy bank accounts, receiving suspicious funds from banks, or using fake credit cards for purchases made in that country.

Some of the Taiwanese arrested have been given prison terms ranging from one to three years by South Korean judges, while others remain in custody at detention centers awaiting trial or appealing their cases, MOFA officials said.

The MOFA has issued several press releases since the beginning of the year urging the public to remain alert and guard against the possibility of being unwittingly set up as the front for an illegally operating company, group or individual based in South Korea, the officials said.

The number of Taiwanese people swept up by South Korean police in such cases has risen in recent months, they said, adding that it seems that more and more fraud rings have shifted operations to that country.
The MOFA has cooperated closely with the National Police Administration under the Ministry of the Interior and South Korean police authorities to shut down such rackets, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PLANNING 'LONG STAY' FOR PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is planning a "long stay" program for its presidential candidate, Ma Ying-jeou, in central Taiwan, in a bid to establish closer links with local people, KMT lawmaker Lu Shiow-yen said Tuesday.

Speaking at a Legislative Yuan news conference, Lu said that the party central is in charge of the program, which aims to help Ma, former KMT chairman, understand in depth local grassroots' needs and development.

As the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration has overlooked development in cities and counties in central Taiwan, Ma's "long stay" to start with the region will be helpful in boosting mutual communications and understanding between Ma and local residents prior to the 2008 presidential election, Lu said.

The two-week project, the first of the KMT's "long stay" program, is expected to kick off within two weeks at the earliest, with Ma staying in each city and county for three to five days, Lu said, adding that a meeting will be held in the Taichung area Wednesday to discuss the project's relevant details.
Commenting on the kinds of places that might accommodate Ma, Lu said, temples, private houses and budget hotels are under consideration by the KMT as Ma himself is a simple person.

Ma released his first TV advertisement Monday and announced former Premier Vincent Siew as his running mate Saturday. The Ma-Siew ticket currently enjoys a public approval rating of some 50 percent, according to surveys conducted by local media outlets.
Siew was born in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan and his pairing with Ma has been viewed by some political observers as giving a boost to Ma's chances in the coming presidential poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Blair set to clinch job as worlds man in the Middle East
Tony Blairs nomination for the post of international envoy in the Middle East is likely to be confirmed as early as today despite grumbles from Europe and last- minute wrangles over his job description.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA TO CONTINUE DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH TAIWAN: PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 26 (CNA) 06/26/07 19:05:22 (By Mike Chang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Panama President Martin Torrijos was quoted by a Japanese newspaper as having reiterated that his country will maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan while promoting trade ties with China.

According to a dispatch carried in the Tuesday edition of the Mainichi Shimbun, Torrijos told a visiting Japanese press group Monday that he will pay attention to the relations his country has developed with Taiwan, as well as to relations with China, the second-largest user of the Panama Canal after the United States.

After Costa Rica switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing June 6, there is concern in Taiwan about a possible domino effect on the country's official relations with other Central American countries. Among these nations, Panama, which maintains close trade relations with China, is expected to attract "world attention" with its movements in relation to Taiwan and China, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD APPROVES MOEA'S OFFSHORE WIND POWER PLANT PROJECT

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has approved a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) proposal to build offshore wind power plants, a CEPD spokesman said Tuesday.

Taiwan theoretically has about 9 million kilowatts of potential wind power in costal areas, but only 1.2 million kilowatts of offshore wind power are exploitable after various restrictions are excluded, the spokesman said.

The spokesman explained that the restrictions include national defense areas, transportation routes, approved exploitable areas, ecological and coastal preservation areas, coastal protection zones, potential geological hazards, undersea cable routes, fault lines, and possible areas for shallow earthquakes greater than a magnitude of three on the Richter scale.

According to the spokesman, Taiwan has no practical experience in building offshore wind power plants and is still in the beginning stages of manufacturing key wind turbine parts. In order to ensure steady development, the government decided to implement the project in several phases, with the maximum wind power projected for the first phase set at 300,000 kilowatts.
The CEPD also asked the MOEA to help domestic wind turbine parts manufacturers improve production ability, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AID MEASURES FOR DOMESTIC FLIGHT SERVICE PROVIDERS TO BE PROLONGED

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) has decided to extend for another year the current measures aimed at assisting domestic flight service operators in overcoming the impact of high-speed railway competition, CAA officials said Tuesday.

The CCA has found that since the Taiwan High-Speed Rail system began operations Jan. 5, passenger loads on flights between Taipei in northern Taiwan and Kaohsiung in the south have been dropping significantly.
According to CCA statistics, the operational volume on west coast flight routes fell 50 percent in May compared with the same month of the previous year, the officials said.

There are currently 31 single-trip high-speed rail trains per day, with the number set to be increased to 61 by September. The CAA predicts that passenger flights in western Taiwan will be even harder-hit by then.

The CAA began to implement the aid measures July 1, which include suspending landing fees at the Pingtung and Hengchun aviation terminals, cutting landing fees by 50 percent at other domestic aviation terminals, reducing land and real estate leasing fees for the Pingtung and Hengchun terminals by 30 percent, and reducing the leasing fees of this kind for other terminals by 10 percent.
The aid program is estimated to save a combined NT$230 million per year for all the affected carriers, the CAA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUNLIN MAGISTRATE TO PROMOTE TAPI SOUR MUSTARD EXPORTS TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen said Tuesday the county government plans to commission food research institutions to flesh out a special project to help export the county's popular pickled sour mustard to Japan.

Su made the remarks while presiding over a seminar at a farmers association in the county's Tapi township to gain a better understanding of farmers' needs. Also on hand were farmers association executives and several Yunlin County officials.
Tapi is known for its delicious pickled sour mustard which Su said should have good market potential in Japan.

As Japan is a country dedicated to strictly regulating produce imports, Su suggested the food research institutions do more to eliminate chemical residues from the savory vegetable to meet the standards set by Japanese food authorities.

During the seminar, Su also reaffirmed the county government's willingness to draw up other projects to assist farmers associations around the county in developing high-quality produce to tap overseas markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISSIONARY DOCTOR MEETS TAITUNG STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Frank Dennis, an American doctor and missionary who has offered medical care to Taitung residents for 33 years, made a splash Monday during a visit to an elementary school in Taitung County, eastern Taiwan.

"It's amazing, I don't believe I shook hands with him" said a student at National Taitung University Laboratory Elementary School when he met Dennis, as his devotion to Taitung has been documented in a Taiwanese elementary school textbook, making him a well-known figure.
During his visit to the school, Dennis delivered a speech and spoke with students, telling them stories and sharing his wisdom with them.

He recalled that the most difficult part of helping people in need is communication, as there are a wide variety of languages and dialects used in Taitung -- Hoklo, Hakka, Mandarin and six aboriginal languages. Dennis first came to Taiwan in 1964 and began operating a mobile medical program in remote mountain areas of the county. He established the Taitung Christian Hospital later in the year.
Dennis devoted himself to the people of Taitung until his return to the United States when he retired in 1994.

For his selfless contributions, the government has awarded him with the third Medical Devotion Award, and former President Lee Tung-hui conferred on him the Order of Brilliant Star with Violet Grand Cordon, making Dennis the first private citizen to receive the honor during Lee's administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY DONATES COMPUTERS TO MALAWI

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government's Department of Labor donated 162 old computers to Malawi Tuesday in an effort to help the poor and children in the African ally.

The department held a donation ceremony at City Hall that was attended by Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, Malawi Ambassador to Taiwan Thengo Maloya, Department Director Su Ying-kuei, and the Pu-Hsien Educational Foundation's Buddhist Master Hui Li.
Hau said at the ceremony that the old computers might be virtually worthless, but are priceless to those who need them.
He noted that the donation, to be made through the Buddhist foundation, will contribute to the sisterhood ties between Taipei City and the Malawi capital of Lilongwe.
He also promised Maloya that the city government will offer more assistance in the future.
Expressing his appreciation, Maloya said the Taipei city government has also donated ambulances to Lilongwe and provided aid in many city construction projects.

Su, for his part, said that the people of Malawi do not have sufficient access to computers and added that Malawi can use the donated computers as educational tools and to improve the quality of its public services.

Master Hui Li said the volunteer workers of the Buddhist foundation, which has built clinics, primary schools and orphanages in the African country, will also teach the people of Malawi how to use the computers.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. VICE PRESIDENT MAY NOT COME TO TAIWAN: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday that a public relations company that arranges schedules for former U.S. Vice President Al Gore has notified that Gore has canceled all his appointments for the latter half of the year.

DPP Legislator Tien Chiu-chin noted that civic environmental protection groups in Taiwan had wanted to invite Gore to visit after the Oscar-winning documentary "An Inconvenient Truth" presented by Gore on the Earth's climate crisis was aired.

The civic groups, noting that Gore has been active in environmental protection issues in recent years, hope to use his international stature to invoke in Taiwan an attachment to the importance of the problem of global warming.
Tien, who is coordinating Gore's trip, said Gore agreed last month to come to Taiwan to deliver three speeches between Sept. 13-20.
But Tien said the PR company notified her that Gore is seriously considering whether to run for the next U.S. presidency and has canceled all his scheduled trips in the latter half of the year.

Since reports were aired about Gore's plan to visit Taiwan, more local heed has been paid to the issue of cutting carbon dioxide emissions to help address the problem of global warming, according to Tien.
Although Gore will not be coming, the civic groups will continue to work toward upgrading the country's consciousness of environmental protection, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S SON-IN-LAW GETS HEAVIER SENTENCE IN 2ND TRIAL (UPDATE-1)

TEXT.P: Chao Chien-ming, president Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law, was given a seven-year sentence Tuesday following his appeal to the Taiwan High Court, for his role in insider trading in stock of the Taiwan Development Corporation (TDC).
He had been sentenced to six years in jail in the original trial heard in the Taipei District Court Dec. 27 last year.
His father, Chao Yu-chu, was sentenced to nine-and-a-half years in jail in the same case Tuesday, compared to a sentence of eight years and four months handed down in the first trial.
A fine of NT$30 million (US$915,383) in addition to the jail terms, which was imposed in the original trial on both Chao Chien-ming and Chao Yu-chu, remained unchanged.
Two other defendants in the case, Yu Shi-yi and former TDC Chairman Su Teh- chien, were also handed fines and heavier prison terms.
Yu received a sentence of seven years and two months in prison in addition to a fine of NT$60 million (US$1.83 million) , while Su was given seven years and six months and a fine of NT$30 million.
Both Yu and Su were handed terms of four years and three months in the previous trial.

A spokesman for the Taiwan High Court said the court meted out heavier jail terms to the four defendants because their combined profits from their offenses were over NT$100 million -- which made them subject to jail terms of seven years or above rather than terms of between three years and 10 years as prescribed by law for ordinary insider trading offenses.

The court determined in its judgment that the four defendants had raked in NT$100.83 million (US$3.07 million) in illegal profits, while the Taipei District Court said in the case's first trial that their illegal gains were just NT$4.27 million.

The difference lies in the two court's different methods of calculating the defendants' illegal gains from their offenses, although both courts believed there is no question of the defendants' involvement in insider trading.
The high court worked out their combined illegal profits according to the stock prices at which they bought and the prices at which each defendant sold their stocks.

The Taiwan High Court said the Chaos was awarded the minimum jail term stipulated in law for the crime of insider trading, while the senior Chao was also guilty of embezzling NT$4.5 million, for which he was given a sentence of three years and six months.
The senior Chao's two separate sentences was incorporated into a term of eight years and four months by the Taiwan High Court.

The case stemmed from a dinner party between the younger Chao and then-TDC Chairman Su Teh-chien July 14, 2005, during which Chao learned that the loss- making TDC was to be bailed out by a syndicated loan from several banks.
He relayed the information to his father, who bid for 5,000,000 shares on July 25, 2005 and sold them after banks approved the loan to TDC.
Su did not engage in insider trading but was found guilty of tipping off the Chaos.
The fourth defendant, Yu Shi-yi, is a friend of the Chaos who was present at the dinner party and bought TDC stocks along with them.

The two other people involved in the case -- Chen Chin-jao and Hung Min-sen -- were given a suspended sentence of one year and ten months and one year and four months, respectively in a separate trial by the Taipei High Court on April 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA URGED TO BAN TAICHUNG CIRCUS SHOWS

TEXT.P: Two ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators urged the Council of Agriculture (COA) Tuesday to ban circus shows set to take place in a recreational park in Taichung this summer, based on an amended law that forbids the import and export of wild animal for circus performances.

According to Tien Chiu-chin and Wang Tu-fa, although the Encore Garden had obtained a permit for the shows before the Wildlife Conservation Act was amended, the COA should order the planned shows to be scrapped now that the law has been changed.
Echoing the call of the legislators, animal conservationists from the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union and the Life Conservationist Association called on the public to boycott the shows.
In response, Lee Tao-sheng, deputy chief of the COA's Forestry Bureau, said the shows, to be performed by a Vietnamese circus, are being organized by a local entertainment company.

While the company has so far only obtained the Taichung city government's permit for the circus to perform at the Encore Garden, the bureau is still processing the company's application to import seven rhesus monkeys for the shows, Lee said.

On the company's plan to import three Asiatic black bears, the company has not obtained the Vietnam government's export permit and therefore has not applied with the bureau to for the animals' import into the country, Lee said.

He said the bureau is handling the case according to the old law, noting that although the amendment to the Wildlife Conservation Act was passed by the legislature June 14, it is still pending promulgation by President Chen Shui- bian before it becomes effective.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST ENGLISH VILLAGE INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The Taoyuan County International English Village -- Chungli Village -- billed as the "first all-English environment in Taiwan," was inaugurated Tuesday.

The village was constructed by adopting the model of a successful English camp in South Korea, housing facilities that simulate various settings, including airport customs, a restaurant and a hotel. All the students in the village are obliged to speak only English.
A ceremony was held by the Taoyuan County Bureau of Education, which founded the village along with several domestic enterprises, to mark its opening.
County Director of Education Chang Ming-wen said the village will provide immersion teaching to allow children to learn and practice real-life English in situational settings.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Justices Loosen Ad Restrictions in Campaign Law
The Supreme Court on Monday took a sharp turn away from campaign finance regulation, opening a wide exception to the advertising restrictions that it upheld when the McCain-Feingold law first came before it four years ago.
In a splintered 5-to-4 decision, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. said that as interpreted broadly by federal regulators and the laws supporters, the restrictions on television advertisements paid for from corporate or union treasuries in the weeks before an election amounted to censorship of core political speech unless those advertisements explicitly urge a vote for or against a particular candidate.
Wall Street Journal:Fleeing Chavez,Oil Workers Flock To Frigid Alberta
Before he left Venezuela in April for this petroleum outpost in northern Alberta, Freddy Mendez heard tales about bone-chilling winter cold and lumbering moose. Since he's come to town, he's seen two black bears in his neighborhood. Still, the toughest adjustment is the late-night sun.
"You get a lot of work done when the sun doesn't set until 11," he says, stifling a yawn. "But it's so hard getting the kids to bed." The 45-year-old engineer is part of a swelling colony of Venezuelan expats who say they were driven into exile by a hostile government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAVELERS REMINDED OF EU'S NEW CASH DECLARATION RULES

TEXT.P: Customs officials reminded local travelers Tuesday to be aware of new cash declaration rules of European Union countries as the peak tourist season is approaching.

According to the new rules, people entering or leaving EU countries will have to declare cash totaling 10,000 euros or more from June 15. EU customs officers will be authorized to check travelers' luggage and seize cash exceeding 10,000 euros unless a valid reason is given by the travelers for having the cash.
EU customs officers were quoted as saying that the new regulations are aimed at cracking down on money laundering,

In the United Kingdom, which adopted the same rules as other EU countries, travelers failing to declare cash in excess of 10,000 euros or who have false declarations of cash will face fines of up to 5,000 pounds.

Meanwhile, Taipei customs officers also reminded local travelers that people entering or leaving Saudi Arabia are required to declare cash or precious metals worth 60,000 riyals (US$16,000) or more, a rule that went into effect June 2.

As for Taiwan's cash declaration rules, the customs officers said travelers leaving the country should declare local currency exceeding NT$60,000 (US$1,834) and are required to declare foreign currency worth more than US$10,000 before they leave, or risk have their cash confiscated, the officers added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAIN DRIVER GETS CITATION FOR SAVING PASSENGERS' LIVES

TEXT.P: A train driver with the Alishan forest railway received a citation from the government Tuesday in recognition of his vigilance that saved more than 100 passengers from imminent disaster two days ago.
With 27 years of experience operating the train, Lin Chi-cheng, 52, quickly sensed something was wrong when the four-carriage train went into the No. 42 tunnel on the 72-km rail line.
"The echo was extremely loud and there was no light at the end of the tunnel," Lin recalled, adding that he immediately activated the brakes.
Some of the passengers in the first carriage said that as the train ground to a halt, they found that only a meter away, a huge pile of rocks from a landslide had blocked the railway.

Realizing that they had just cheated death, the passengers applauded and thanked Lin for saving their lives. Maintaining his usual composure, Lin laid no claim to the merit and pointed out that he was only doing his job.

Su Chia-chuan, chief commissioner of the Council of Agriculture, presented the citation to Lin at the Forestry Bureau's Chiayi Forest District Office. The local office also presented Lin with a cash award.
Three other staff members operating the train were also cited for helping avert a major disaster.

The Alishan forest railway was disrupted June 24 by a landslide caused by successive thunderstorms. Hundreds of tons of rocks damaged part of No. 42 tunnel and a 100-meter section of the railway near the exit of the tunnel. The tunnel is located 59 km from Chiayi Station.
According to the Forestry Bureau, which manages the railway, it will take about 40 days to repair the damaged section of the railway and eight months to reconstruct the tunnel.
The Alishan railway is said to be one of the world's three remaining alpine railways. The other two are located in the Himalaya in northern India and in the Andes of South America.

Opened in 1912 while Taiwan was under Japanese rule, the narrow-gauge railway was designed to haul timber down the mountain, but is now mainly used to transport the more than 200,000 tourists who visit Alishan each year to see the area's beauty at an altitude of more than 2,200 meters in Taiwan's Central Mountain Range.

The scenic railway winds its way up from the subtropical plains to mountainous pine forests in just 72 km, crossing more than 80 bridges and passing through about 50 tunnels. Its route includes a series of dangerous switchbacks.

Although the government has been operating the train at an annual loss of about NT$110 million (US$3.35 million) , it has decided to preserve the line not only for its historic value but as a means to boost local tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEFENDS DRIVE ON RETRIEVING ILL-GOTTEN KMT ASSETS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung defended Tuesday a government planned exhibition to ask that the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) ill-gotten party assets be returned to the national coffers and denied allegations that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is seeking only to serve its own interests.
Chang made the remarks to reporters while answering questions on the issue before he gave a speech at a meeting of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce.

Asked whether the plan by the Cabinet-level Research, Development, and Evaluation Commission to spend NT$9.5 million to sponsor the exhibition is aimed at the KMT, Chang argued those who illegally posses national assets must return them to the national coffers.

"The KMT's party assets targeted by the DPP administration were ruled by the courts as illegally seized and the government efforts to get them back is by no means a way to serve its own interests with national resources, " he said.
"If it were the DPP that had taken the assets in the first place, the government authorities also would have to demand their return to the state," he pointed out.
Later, in his speech, Chang said the government deeply appreciates the contribution made by Taiwan's small- and medium-sized enterprises to the country's economic development.

According to the premier, there are 1.23 million small companies in Taiwan, accounting for 97.8 percent of the business community. They have created 7.6 million jobs and generate combined business revenue of NT$10 trillion per year, he said.
The DPP administration remains committed to its promise to take care of the underprivileged and the small businesses, as well as boosting development in central and southern regions, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S SON-IN-LAW URGED NOT TO APPEAL INSIDER TRADING CASE

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) Tuesday urged Chao Chien-ming, President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law, not to appeal to the Supreme Court and to immediately start serving his jail term after he was sentenced to seven years in jail in a second trial earlier in the day.

Liu Wen-hsiung, a PFP lawmaker and one of the party's legislative caucus whips, issued the call in a news conference, claiming that members of the first family "have the responsibility" to set a good example for society" and should do their best not to further waste national and judicial resources.

The Taiwan High Court handed down a prison term of seven years to Chao Chien- ming, and one of nine years and six months to his father, Chao Yu-chu, for their roles in insider trading of Taiwan Development Corp. shares. Each of them was also fined NT$30 million.
The Chaos and their conspirators were proved by the Taiwan High Court to have illegally made more than NT$100 million (US$3 million) in the insider trading.

The verdicts of the High Court were heavier than the punishment handed down in the first trial by the District Court, which gave a six-year jail term to Chao Chien-ming and eight years and four months for his father.

Predicting that Chao Chien-ming may still face a severe penalty even if he appeals his case to the supreme court, Liu said that first lady Wu Shu-jen and first daughter Chen Hsing-yu should ask him to drop his appeal, acknowledge his wrongdoing and begin serving the jail term as soon as possible "for the sake of the national interest."

"It will be extremely deplorable if polarized confrontation is sparked in society as the legislative and presidential elections approach, " Liu said, adding that "disputes arising from the case should be put to an end as quickly as possible."

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST 6-MONTH IPI PREDICTED TO INCREASE 3% OVER LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: The industrial production index (IPI) is expected to register a 3 percent year- on-year increase for the first half of the year thanks to steady growth of manufacturing industrial production in June, an official said Tuesday.

Huang Chi-shih, director-general of the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Department of Statistics, said Taiwan's industrial production index for May reached 152.83, an increase of 6.35 percent year-on-year.

The manufacturing production index was 156.7 in May, up 6.71 percent over the year-earlier level. Of this, the electricity, gas and water industries increased by a combined 3.59 percent and the building construction industry was up 2.83 percent.

The information and electronics industry gained 13.21 percent, the metals and machinery industry was up 2.32 percent, the food, textiles and other industries increased by 0.82 percent, and the chemical industry was up 0.80 percent, while the mining and quarrying industry decreased by 18.17 percent, Huang said.

The industrial production index for the first five months of this year was 139.05, an increase of 2.6 percent over the same period of last year, and the manufacturing production index from January to May was 143.03, up 2.84 percent year-on-year, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELEMENTARY SCHOOL PRINCIPAL COMMITS SUICIDE

TEXT.P: An elementary school principal in Taichung County was found dead -- an apparent suicide -- on a bamboo farm Tuesday.

Wang Cheng-duei, 50, head of the Shihcheng Elementary School in Tungshih township, Taichung County, left home early Monday and never returned. Farmers discovered his body next to a bottle containing pesticide residue and a suicide note.
The note says Wang had been having trouble sleeping.

Wang's family said he had a history of depression. He was transferred to Shihcheng Elementary School a year ago after serving as principal of both Pingteng Elementary School and Lishan Elementary School in Hoping township.
A coroner from the local public prosecutors office will perform an autopsy to ascertain the cause of death.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE OUTLINES ECONOMIC VISION

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that if elected in 2008, he will strive to develop a "well-being economy" in which promoting a systematic upgrading of Taiwan's quality of life and environment will be the main themes.

Hsieh, a former premier, also criticized the economic agenda advocated by his election rival -- the main opposition Kuomintang's standard bearer Ma Ying-jeou -- as "wrong diagnosis and wrong prescriptions."

Ma said recently that if he wins the 2008 presidency, he will boost Taiwan's per capita gross domestic product (GDP), a measure of wealth, to US$20,000 in 2011 from the current level of about NT$16,000 and lift the stock index to over 10,000 points. Ma also mocked the DPP administration's inexperience in running economic and financial affairs.
Claiming that Ma has misread Taiwan's current situation, Hsieh said Taiwan's predicament does not lie with its economic or GDP growth.
According to Hsieh, Taiwan's woes are primarily the result of protracted political fighting in the legislature and the uneven distribution of wealth spurred by the widening wealth gap.

Against this backdrop, Hsieh said, Taiwan's greatest need is not quantitative growth but an all-inclusive upgrading of quality of life, which comprises social justice, ethnic harmony, political stability, environmental protection and sustainable economic growth.
Dismissing Ma's economic platform as promoting a "commodity economy, " Hsieh said what he wants to pursue is a "well-being economy" that aims to bring economic well-being to all citizens.

On Ma's overture of rediscovering Taiwan's core values, Hsieh asked what forms Taiwan core values. "For me, democracy, happiness and dignity form our core values, " Hsieh said, adding that Ma's advocacy of diligence and tenacity as Taiwan's core values are irrelevant. "Diligence and perseverance have been integral parts of our character that do not need advocated by a president," he noted.

Hsieh was also critical of Ma's cross-Taiwan Strait policy overtures, claiming that Ma's advocacy of forming a cross-strait common market and making entire Taiwan a free trade area is risky as such a development could eventually make Taiwan an "offshore island of China."

Stressing that he backs opening to Chinese tourists and capital, Hsieh said he is nevertheless reserved about Ma's advocacy of unlimited openness toward china by making Taiwan a free trade zone and forming a common market with China.
"We must always strike a balance in safeguarding our separate national identity while liberalizing cross-strait trade and economic exchanges," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELEMENTARY SCHOOL PRINCIPAL COMMITS SUICIDE

TEXT.P: An elementary school principal in Taichung County was found dead -- an apparent suicide -- on a bamboo farm Tuesday.

Wang Cheng-duei, 50, head of the Shihcheng Elementary School in Tungshih township, Taichung County, left home early Monday and never returned. Farmers discovered his body next to a bottle containing pesticide residue and a suicide note.
The note says Wang had been having trouble sleeping.

Wang's family said he had a history of depression. He was transferred to Shihcheng Elementary School a year ago after serving as principal of both Pingteng Elementary School and Lishan Elementary School in Hoping township.
A coroner from the local public prosecutors office will perform an autopsy to ascertain the cause of death.

Hsieh, a former premier, also criticized the economic agenda advocated by his election rival -- the main opposition Kuomintang's standard bearer Ma Ying-jeou -- as "wrong diagnosis and wrong prescriptions."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 27, or the 13th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1801: British troops defeat a French militia force and take control of Cairo, Egypt.
1829: James Smithson, British chemist, mineralogist and philanthropist, dies in Genoa, Italy, at the age of 64. He helped establish the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.
1880: Helen Keller, American teacher, social worker, and writer, who was deaf and blind from birth, is born.
1893: A major stock market plunge begins in the United States, leading to a depression. By the end of 1893, 600 banks and 74 railroads had gone out of business.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek, who became commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces on June 5, launches the Northern Expedition from Canton.
1939: Pan American Airways operates the first scheduled transatlantic air service by the Dixie Clipper, a 19-seat flying boat, leaving Port Washington, New York, for Marseilles in France.
1945: Premier and Foreign Minister T. V. Soong, accompanied by Deputy Foreign Minister Hu Shih-tse, Shen Hung-lieh and Chiang Ching-kuo, leave for Moscow to discuss matters concerning the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders US forces into battle to aid South Korea following an invasion across the 38th parallel by North Korean troops.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders the US 7th Fleet to prevent a communist attack on Taiwan and asks the ROC government to cease air and sea operations against the mainland.
1953: Some 30,000 ROC government troops stranded on Dao Fhu Quoc (Fukuo Island) off the coast of South Vietnam begin returning to Taiwan.
1954: The world's first nuclear power station is opened at Obninsk in the Soviet Union, about 55 miles from Moscow.
1973: Dr. Chester W. Clark, new American commissioner of the Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction, arrives in Taipei.
1975: Some 1,000 ROC military leaders conclude a five-day conference on modernizing Taiwan's military equipment and strategy.
1976: Six Palestinians hijack an Air France Airbus from Athens, Greece with 246 passengers and 12 crew onboard and force it to fly to Entebbe, Uganda, where Israeli commandos storm it on July 4.
1977: The Kaohsiung steel mill of China Steel Corp. begins production. The construction of the integrated steel mill was financed by a US$200 million loan from the Continental Illinois National Bank and the Trust Company of Chicago.
1979: The Republic of China's first "buy American" mission of the year, led by H.K. Shao, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, departs with a shopping list for goods worth US$850 million.
1982: Broad gauge trains begin to operate on the widened railroad on the east coast area between Hualien and Taitung.
1986: The 1986 National Administration Conference opens in Taipei. More than 260 government officials and specialists attend the meeting.
1988: Intrepid British mountain climbers Dave Hurst and Alan Matthews become the first blind climbers to reach the summit of Mont Blanc in Switzerland, Europe's highest mountain at 4,810 meters.
1989: Another wave of refugee boats from Vietnam hits Hong Kong, where closed refugee camps are already bulging with 45,000 "boat people."
1991: Government spokesman Shaw Yu-ming announces that mainland Chinese journalists will no longer have to renounce their membership in the Chinese Communist Party when applying to visit Taiwan.
1998: US President Bill Clinton and Chinese President Jiang Zemin hold a press conference in Beijing. The two leaders clash over dissidents, the Dalai Lama, and the Tiananmen Square massacre.
1999: George Papadopoulos, Greek military officer and politician who became premier after a 1967 coup, dies at the age of 80. He was overthrown in 1973.
1999: A Republic of China congressional delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng leaves for a visit to Macedonia.
2000: The Legislative Yuan adopts a special resolution requiring the government to reduce the number of foreign laborers in Taiwan starting next year.
2001: A total of 175 illegal mainland Chinese immigrats are repatrated from Fu Su Port on the frontline island of Matsu through arrangement by the Red Cross Societies of Taiwan and mainland China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Make it your aim to wish for moral well-being and you will never be accused of being covetous."

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH ADMINISTRATION URGED TO OPEN U.S. VISITS BY TAIWAN OFFICIALS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 26 (CNA) 06/27/07 12:16:38 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A U.S. congressional committee adopted a non-binding resolution Tuesday urging the administrative branch to lift restrictions on visits to the United States by high-level elected and appointed officials of Taiwan, including the president.

The resolution asked the administrative branch to abide by section 221 of the Immigration and National Technical Corrections Act of 1994, which provides for the president or other high-level officials of Taiwan to visit the United States, including Washington, D.C., at any time to discuss a variety of important issues.

The resolution, passed unanimously by the House of Representative's Committee on Foreign Affairs, said the United States should allow direct high- level exchanges at the Cabinet level with the government of Taiwan to strengthen a policy dialogue with Taiwan.

It said it is in the interest of the United States to strengthen links between the United States and the democratically-elected officials of Taiwan and demonstrate stronger support for democracy in the Asia-Pacific region.
"Since the Taiwan Strait is one of the flashpoints in the world, it is essential that United States policymakers directly communicate with the leaders of Taiwan," the resolution said.

It said the U.S. policy that bars the president, vice president, premier, foreign minister and defense minister of Taiwan from visiting Washington D.C. deprives the U.S. president, Congress and the American public of the opportunity to engage in a direct dialogue with Taiwan.
Lifting these restrictions will help bring a U.S. friend and ally out of its isolation, which will be beneficial to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, it said.

The resolution was initiated by Rep. Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) , a co-chair of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus. It was co-sponsored by 33 other representatives including Tom Lantos (D-Calif.), chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs.

Delighted at the passage of the resolution, Chabot said it is undesirable that democratically-elected officials from Taiwan are not allowed to visit the U.S. capital while leaders from communist China are received with state courtesies.
Chabot said this policy is humiliating to Taiwan and sends the wrong signal to the rest of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO ORGANIZE REGULAR FOREIGN LABOR POLICY CONSULTANT MEETINGS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will hold a consultant meeting every three months with representatives of both management and workers, experts and scholars, and officials of economic affairs to discuss issues relating to foreign-labor policies, according to CLA officials.

The initiative was formed at a round-table meeting for social dialogue hosted Tuesday by Minister of Labor Affairs Lu Tien-lin, in which officials responsible for economic planning and development, representatives of enterprise management and workers, as well as scholars in relevant fields took part.

The social dialogue meeting was initiated by former CLA chief Lee Ying-yuan to serve as a platform for management-worker dialogue. The Tuesday event was the first of its kind since Lu took office May 21.

Commenting on the planned consultant meetings, Lu said that in the preliminary formulation, the participants will comprise six representatives of management, six representatives of workers, four officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, two CLA officials, as well as three experts and scholars from relevant fields, with the CLA minister to serve as the meeting convener.
Topics for discussions will include the total number of foreign laborers, and restrictions on working permits for foreign laborers.

Basically, Lu stated his council will adopt a process of "dynamic management" on foreign-labor policy, meaning enterprises will be allowed to import more foreign workers once the unemployment rate falls below a certain figure, and the import will not affect the employment of local workers. If unemployment is found to be rising, the CLA will consider cutting the number of foreign workers allowed, he added.
On Tuesday, the participants also agreed that the management-worker dialogue process should be further expanded to cover issues concerning most professional sectors in the country.
Therefore, Lu said the CLA plans to organize 20 separate meetings for dialogue between the management and workers from 20 different professional sectors before the end of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP 1,000 'TAISHANG' MAY OUTSHINE TAIWAN COUNTERPARTS SOON: CCIS

TEXT.P: The accumulated turnover of the top 1,000 Taiwan-funded companies in China, commonly known as "Taishang, " could outpace that of the top 1,000 corporations in Taiwan in five years, according to a newly released market research report.

The report, prepared by the Taipei-based China Credit Information Service Ltd. (CCIS), said the top 1,000 "Taishang" posted an average 45.88 percent year-on- year growth in business turnover in 2006, far exceeding the average 16.03 percent increase registered by their Taiwan-based counterparts.
If the trend continues, the report said, the top 1,000 "Taishang" will outshine their Taiwan parents in terms of revenues by 2012.

In its latest annual survey, the CCIS evaluated the growth potential of the top 1,000 "Taishang" and the top 1,000 Taiwan-based corporations in terms of their growth rates of turnover, pre-tax profits, work force and net profits.
The study showed that the top 1,000 "Taishang" outperformed their Taiwan counterparts in terms of the first three indexes while only lagging behind in their net profit ratio.
According to the CCIS analysis, it's harder for "Taishang," most of which operate labor-intensive lines of business, to make profits than their Taiwan- based counterparts.

Nevertheless, the report said "Taishang" still enjoy many advantages from China's vast market scale and fast economic growth rates. As a result, CCIS researchers said large Taiwan enterprises must rely on investment in China to sustain their growth.

The CCIS survey also found that 70 percent of Taiwan's top 500 private manufacturing companies have invested in China. Moreover, survey results showed that each of them tends to have six or more offshoots in China.

Another noteworthy finding was that large Taiwan companies are more fervent than their smaller counterparts in launching investment projects in China. According to the survey, only 40 percent of Taiwan's top 5,000 companies have invested in China, but the ratio reached 52 percent among the top 1,000 conglomerates.

The survey further found that not only many manufacturing corporations have set up production facilities in China, nearly 36 percent of Taiwan's top 500 service firms have also opened shop there to tap its immense domestic market.
In the past three years, the report said, the business turnover of the top 1,000 "Taishang" posted 81 percent growth, compared to about a 24 percent increase registered by their Taiwan counterparts.

Meanwhile, the pre-tax profits of Taiwan's top 1,000 companies dropped from 7.75 percent in 2004 to 6.13 percent in 2005 and rebounded to 6.43 percent in 2006. In comparison, the pre-tax earnings of the top 1,000 "Taishang" surged to 4.53 percent in 2006 from a mere 3.3 percent in 2005.
The CCIS report also urged the government to take precautions against a possible "hollowing out" of Taiwan's manufacturing sector following an "exodus" of large enterprises to China.

Noting that China-based offshoots may cut ties with their Taiwan parents to facilitate their listing on foreign stock exchanges, the report said more and more "Taishang" are also forming new industry supply chains in China instead of relying on their Taiwan parents in materials and parts procurement.

The survey further found that the top 300 foreign-funded companies in Taiwan saw a slower pace in their turnover and pre-tax profits, and some of them even registered negative growth on both fronts. About 14 percent of foreign-owned companies said they treat Taiwan as a launch pad for their ventures into the vast Chinese market.

According to the survey, securities companies were the most lucrative foreign enterprises in Taiwan last year, with the pre-tax profit rate reaching an average of 32.76 percent, far higher than semiconductor firms' average 7.79 percent earning rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
'UNREPENTANT' DRUG PUSHER GIVEN 5-YEAR SENTENCE

TEXT.P: A young drug pusher, who was nabbed for possession of more than 360 grams of the illicit drug Ketamine in January this year, was given a sentence of five years and two months by Taipei judges Tuesday.

According to judges from the Taipei District Court, Chen Liang-hsu, 20, was nabbed by Coast Guard Administration (CGA) agents on Taipei's bustling Changchun Road on the night of Jan. 18 and was found to have three small bags of Ketamine, or 69.8 grams in total, on him, possibly ready to meet his customers there.
With a warrant from the district court, CGA agents then accompanied Chen to his home in Sanchung City, where they found six more small bags of Ketamine, weighing 297 grams in total, and a scale.
Chen admitted that he bought the Ketamine at a cost of NT$30,000 (US$915) per 50 grams from two drug "mules" known only as "A-Ru" and "Sis" in Taipei County in August and September of last year.
Chen then told the judges that he was suffering an unspecified mental-health illness, and that police had tortured a confession from him.

The judges checked with doctors from the Far Eastern Memorial Hospital where Chen had been ordered to undergo psychological examination, only to be told that Chen had fabricated the reports of mental-health illness.

In addition, the judges said Chen seemed not to be remorseful and could not show any evidence to prove that he was tortured by police, prompting them to hand down a five-year, two-month sentence for violation of the statute on illicit drug prevention.
Ketamine -- a third-grade illicit drug -- is a white crystalline powder used as a general anaesthetic mainly in veterinary medicine.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT PLANNING FRIENDLY TREATMENT OF FOREIGN PROFESSIONALS

TEXT.P: The government is working on measures aimed at attracting foreign professionals to work in Taiwan, and stay longer for their work, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials said Wednesday.

Those friendly measures include a proposal to exclude the expenses of traveling, relocation, telephone fees and even house cleaning from the paychecks of foreign professionals, meaning that these costs will be tax-free, the officials said.
The CEPD-proposed measures were brought forward for discussions at the Executive Yuan meeting Wednesday.

Foreign professionals are defined as those who are invited to work in Taiwan under Ministry of Economic Affairs-operated special programs for hiring overseas talents in technology and science, and the high-tech talents employment policy of the National Science Council, as well as those who are invited to assist in the government's national economic development plans, according to the CEPD.
It's expected that the foreign professional friendly treatment plan will be implemented as soon as it is approved by the Executive Yuan.

The CEPD began to review existing regulations governing the employment of foreign professionals after the European Chamber of Commerce in Taipei expressed in March that high taxation levels have affected the willingness of professionals to live and work in Taiwan.
Taiwan employs a progressive individual income tax rate of up to 40 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCENTIVES IMPERATIVE TO WOO FOREIGN PROFESSIONALS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Wednesday welcomed the Executive Yuan's passage of a program to woo foreign professionals to work in Taiwan's high-technology industrial sectors.

Describing the passage of the incentive program as "important" and "imperative, " Chang said that foreign professionals, when working in Taiwan, bring with them new knowledge and innovative technologies that are important elements in the country's economic development.

The government is offering a two-pronged incentive program of tax- and non- taxation-based incentives to attract foreign professionals in the hope that they will contribute to the sustainable development of Taiwan's economy over the long term, Chang said.

He added that there will be some 34,000 openings in the following three years in Taiwan's six major high-tech sectors: semiconductor, video and image, telecommunications, digital content, biotechnology and information technological services. The government believes that there will not be enough locally-trained professionals to fill those openings.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES RESOLUTION ON U.S. VISITS BY TAIWAN OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official expressed approval Wednesday for a resolution adopted by a U.S. congressional committee calling for the removal of U.S. restrictions on visits by high-level Taiwan officials.
Noting that the restrictions have been in place for years, MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said lifting the restrictions will be favorable to the development of Taiwan-U.S. relations.

The resolution, adopted by the House of Representatives' Committee on Foreign Affairs, urged the administration of President George W. Bush to lift restrictions on visits to the United States by high-level elected and appointed officials of Taiwan, including the country's president.

The resolution asked the administrative branch to abide by Section 221 of the Immigration and National Technical Corrections Act of 1994, which provides for the president or other high-level officials of Taiwan to visit the United States, including Washington, D.C., at any time to discuss a variety of important issues.
The resolution said the United States should allow direct high-level exchanges at the Cabinet level with the government of Taiwan to strengthen policy discussions between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR PENSION FUND SUPERVISORY COMMITTEE INAUGURATED JULY 2

TEXT.P: The Labor Pension Fund Supervisory Committee (LPFSC) is scheduled to be inaugurated July 2, Minister of Labor Affairs Lu Tien-lin said Wednesday.

In his report on the new institution and the implementation of the new labor pension system, which was enacted July 1, 2005, at a meeting at the Executive Yuan, Lu said that the state-operated labor pension fund has amounted to NT$600 billion (US$18.25 billion).

The report showed that as of the end of May, the number of persons with a retirement pension account under the new system has exceeded 5.8 million. Those account holders have contributed more than NT$172.2 billion to the pension fund.

It is estimated that the fund will increase to NT$1.13 trillion a decade after the enactment of the new portable labor pension system, according to Lu. He also mentioned that up to 40 percent of the pension fund will be devoted to investments in the domestic stock market in an effort to generate more profits for pension account holders.

The Council of Labor Affairs is still working to find the proper person to serve as LPFSC chairman, and another to serve as vice chairman, having now completed task of selecting 19 LPFSC members, Lu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISITING CZECH STUDENT HELPS CLEAN UP TAIWAN'S ENVIRONMENT

TEXT.P: A student from the Czech Republic is helping to clean up Taiwan's environment by picking up litter and inspiring his Taiwanese peers to follow suit.

Twenty-two year old Daniel Hradsky, an exchange student studying Chinese at Wenzao Ursuline College of Languages in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, rode a motorcycle around the island soon after he arrived in Taiwan in February this year, picking up garbage littering the beaches and valleys along the way.

Daniel said he fell in love with the island's scenic areas soon after he first set foot in Taiwan. He rode to beaches and mountains to enjoy the natural beauty of Taiwan, which has been known to people in the West as "Isla Formosa" in Portuguese meaning "the beautiful island.

Many sites, however, are littered by tourists' drink bottles, cans, glass and garbage, Daniel said, adding that sometimes the volume of trash was so great that "it would take an army" to finish cleaning the litter up.

Daniel recalled that his girlfriend back in the Czech Republic was a conscientious "garbage collector" who would stoop to pick up litter on the street whenever she saw it. At the time, he recalled, he considered her actions "boring" and "meaningless."
To his surprise, Daniel said, he started picking up litter on the streets, in the mountains and on the beaches after he came to Taiwan.

Over the past five months, Daniel has been to Taipei City in the north, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Kenting in the south, as well as Taitung and Hualien in the east, all the while picking up garbage as he went.

According to Daniel's observation, the Taiwanese people are very kind and friendly to foreigners, but they are "litter bugs" who are also heavily dependent on cars, motorcycles and air conditioners -- all conveniences that are implicated in environment hazards and climate change.
Daniel's actions have inspired his Taiwanese classmates and friends, who have, in turn, joined him in collecting garbage. Some of his classmates have even stop using their air-conditioners.
