DOC.HEADLINE: THREE LOCAL INSTITUTES ACCREDITED BY INT'L LAB ANIMAL ASSOCIATION

TEXT.P: Three local research institutes have earned accreditation from the Association for Assessment and Accreditation of Laboratory Animal Care (AAALAC) for their laboratory animal management, paving the way for international cooperation in biomedical studies, academic sources reported Wednesday.

The three institutes -- National Laboratory Animal Center (NLAC), National Defense Medical Center (NDMC) , and BioLASCO Taiwan Co. -- passed AAALAC's accreditation and assessment reviews in March, they said, adding that they were informed of the final results only last week.

AAALAC is a U.S.-based nonprofit organization that promotes the humane treatment of animals in scientific research. Currently, 730 companies, universities, hospitals, government agencies and other research institutions in 30 countries have earned AAALAC accreditation, demonstrating their commitment to responsible animal care and use, according to the association's website.

Taiwan's Development Center for Biotechnology was accredited by AAALAC in 2000 -- the first to receive accreditation among all research institutes around the island, they said, adding that they have since been joined by NLAC, NDMC, and BioLASCO, bringing the number of accredited institutes in Taiwan to four, second only to China's six and South Korea's five among Asian countries.

"Being recognized by the AAALAC means that both the lab animal management and the research quality control in these institutes have achieved a higher standard, " NLAC Researcher Chang Wei-cheng explained. "Taiwan's efforts in biomedical research and development can thus be more easily accepted in other countries, facilitating international collaboration and helping made-in-Taiwan medicines gain wider market access."

In the future, NLAC and BioLASCO will be able to provide lab animals in compliance with international standards; meanwhile, NDMC will be in charge of providing qualified facilities for animal experiments, according to the institutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TOUTS TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC ACHIEVEMENTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that increasing investment in Taiwan by foreign investors is a proof of the country's thriving economy, rejecting criticisms from the opposition that the country's development has been at a standstill under his leadership.
According to Chen, such criticism appears whenever there is an election.
Chen stressed it is not Taiwan that has made no progress over the past seven years, but rather the political groups and individuals who are making such criticisms.

Chen pointed out that boosted by the semiconductor and flat panel display industries, the science parks located in Hsinchu, southern Taiwan and central Taiwan are flourishing, and have induced many foreign investors to expand their operations in Taiwan
In addition, Chen continued, the financial reforms promoted by his administration have helped domestic banks write off bad debts amounting to NT$1.5 trillion.
Chen pledged that the government will continue its policy of boosting development in central and southern Taiwan, and of small- and medium-sized businesses.

Chen made the remarks while addressing a ceremony marking the inauguration of a 12-inch wafer recycling plant operated by Applied Materials Taiwan in the Tainan section of the Southern Taiwan Science Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR TO BE APPOINTED SEF CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung confirmed Wednesday that ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Hung Chi-chang will be appointed chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
Chang told reporters that Hung is the only candidate for the position and that the Cabinet is processing paper work related to the appointment.
The position has been left vacant since Chang, who previously held the post, assumed the premiership a month ago.
The SEF is an intermediary body in charge of handling cross-Taiwan Strait affairs in the absence of formal relations between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY PUBLISHES STORIES OF BRAVE YOUNGSTERS

TEXT.P: The Taipei County government has published a book titled "Flying with Dreams" depicting the life stories of 10 youngsters who have shown courage and stamina in overcoming difficulties, a local government official said Wednesday.
The county government held a book launch Tuesday at which those 10 youngsters were invited to share their experiences with other people.

The brave youngsters are Liu Chi-yi, Chou Chih-chen, Wung Wei-ming, Wang Tien- yiou, Lu Chun-yi, Liao Wei-hsiao, Luo Yi-chu, Chung Yiou-chu, Chen Pei-ying, and Lin Ching-lan. These youngsters have all experienced difficulties overcoming life challenges or physical limitations. Moreover, each has proactively faced those difficulties with a positive attitude.

Lin Ching-lan, who was diagnosed as a child with nystagmus--an eye disease causing involuntary eye movement--shed tears while speaking about her experiences growing up. She said she knew that her eyes were different from those of other people, and that she had to make greater efforts to achieve goals easily realized by others.

Lin is now a student of the Taipei First Girls High School, the first choice of most Taiwanese female junior high school students. She expressed gratitude to all those who had helped her, and said she hoped to pass on the same level of care and love to others in need in the future.

The county government will distribute 10,000 copies of the book to the county's elementary schools, junior and senior high schools with the aim of encouraging students to care for others and resist the temptation to give in to life's frustrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COUNTY INAUGURATES TOURIST BUS SERVICE

TEXT.P: Kinmen County inaugurated a tourist bus service Wednesday, with four routes linking various scenic spots around Kinmen Island in an attempt to boost local tourism.
The bus service will be managed by the Kinmen county government and the Kinmen National Park Administration.

County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng, park Director Huang Wen-chin and two leaders of the local tourism industry cut a ribbon at an inauguration ceremony in the Shuangli Wetlands Nature Center to open the new bus service.

Speaking at the ceremony, Lee pointed out that the outlying island, which used to be a military no-go zone for tourists, has been attracting an increasing number of visitors each year since the authorities opened its doors to tourists 15 years ago.
He said the new bus routes are intended to provide more convenience to visitors.
According to the Kinmen County Transportation and Tourism Bureau, bus rides will be free June 28-30, with commercial operations beginning formally July 1.
Bureau officials said a day pass will cost NT$200, while the price of a two-day pass is set at NT$350.
However, they added that from July 1 to Sept. 30, a 20 percent discount will be offered for all one-day and two-day passes.

The four bus routes will take tourists to nearly all the major scenic spots on Kinmen, including the Guningtou Battle Museum, the Aug. 23 Artillery Battle Museum, Shuangli Lake, the Kinmen Ceramic Factory and the Banyan Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO HEAD PANS H.K. FOR BARRING FALUN GONG FOLLOWERS FROM ENTERING

TEXT.P: A government spokesman reviled Hong Kong authorities Wednesday for barring Taiwanese Falun Gong followers from entering Hong Kong even though they held valid travel documents.

Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey lambasted Hong Kong immigration authorities as "absolutely wrong" for denying 12 Taiwanese Falun Gong adherents entry Monday in the run-up to the 10th anniversary of Hong Kong's return to Chinese rule.
The 12 Taiwanese citizens were repatriated after being denied entry to Hong Kong because their visits were "not conducive to the public good."
Shieh said Taiwan -- a democratic country whose people fully enjoy freedom of religion and freedom of speech -- feels it is a pity that Hong Kong denied entry to the 12 Taiwan citizens.

He said the entry denial reflects the fact that Hong Kong's human rights and democracy have regressed to a level much lower than that enjoyed by Hong Kongers 10 years before under British colonial rule.
This latest incident should also remind the Taiwanese people that Beijing has been manipulating democracy and human rights in Hong Kong under the guise of the so-called "one country, two systems."
China outlawed Falun Gong, which combines meditation with Buddhist-inspired teachings, as an "evil cult" in mid-1999 and practitioners have subsequently faced often brutal repression.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG How Brown led his latest recruit across the floor Gordon Brown did not leave the delicate negotiations that brought Quentin Davies into the Labour fold to colleagues or aides. He did it himself.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG TO STAGE STREET PERFORMANCES FOR THREE WEEKENDS

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government's Bureau of Cultural Affairs has signed up music groups to stage street performances for the next three weekends, a spokesman for the bureau announced Wednesday.
The spokesman said Kaohsiung residents are invited to enjoy the afternoon live music performances at Pier-2 Art Center, a former warehouse in Kaohsiung harbor.
First to appear on the stage on June 30-July 1 will be the Kaohsiung Philharmonic Brass Ensemble.
The numbers to be played by the group will include Bach's Minuet, Casablanca, Quandoquando, Yesterday on Cemore and the theme song of the movie C'est la Vie, Mon Cheri.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC ORDERED TO UPGRADE SAFETY OF BUSES

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung ordered the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Wednesday to work out measures to upgrade the safety of tour buses following the latest fatal bus crash.

Chang addressed the issue during a weekly Cabinet meeting, in the wake of repeated accidents involving buses over the past year. In the latest case, a tour bus plunged into a ravine Sunday on scenic Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei, killing eight people and injuring 25 others.

Chang instructed the MOTC to strengthen the disclosure of information concerning tour bus rentals, to review regularly the existing measures that regulate tour buses, drivers, operators and routes, and to step up its inspection and crackdown on law-breaking vehicles.

To improve the structural safety and fire-proof properties of the vehicles, the government has established new requirements in these areas and will require passenger buses to undergo tests on their ability to resist overturning starting at the end of next year, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN READY TO TALK WITH CHINA ON BANKING, FINANCIAL EXCHANGES: MAC

TEXT.P: A Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) vice chairman said Wednesday that although Taiwan has tried to liberalize banking and financial exchanges with China as best it can, Beijing has been tremendously uncooperative.

MAC Vice Chairman Tung Chen-yuan said during a cross-Taiwan Strait forum that Taiwan is willing to open negotiations with China to help normalize economic and trade relations across the strait so long as Beijing stops resisting.

Tung said the administration allowed Taiwan's banking institutes to open liaison offices in China in June 2001, followed by allowing Taiwan insurance operators to establish subdivisions in China in August 2002, allowing insurance operators to invest in their Chinese counterparts in April 2004 and allowing Taiwan stocks and securities firms to establish branch offices in China in February 2005.

Despite Taiwan's liberalization, the Chinese authorities have refused to talk with the Taiwan authorities in this regard and have refused to allow Taiwan stocks and securities firms to establish branch offices or subsidiaries in China, letting them only set up representative offices, Tung added.

In July 2004, Tung noted, the administration put forth 18 proposals to enhance cross-strait economic and trade exchanges, including currency exchanges, investment guarantees, financial supervision, judicial reciprocity, commercial arbitration, cargo and passenger charter flight services, allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan and direct air and sea links, in the hope that the Chinese authorities would at least meet Taiwanese officials for talks.
However, Tung said, Beijing has set numerous "political barriers" to official talks on those proposals.

In June 2005, he added, the administration authorized the quasi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council to talk with its Chinese counterpart on cross-strait trade relations. However, the Chinese authorities refuse to talk with the officials, and only agreed to increase business and trade exchanges with Taiwan via a mechanism arranged by Taiwan's opposition parties.
Tung claimed that instead of helping, the mechanism created more problems in terms of boosting cross-strait trade.
For example, he said, in August 2005, China opened 15 categories of Taiwan fruits to be exported to China, but the exports of Taiwan fruits to China declined by 9 percent that year.

Last December, he continued, China announced that it would import 2,000 tons of bananas from Taiwan "in an effort to help Taiwan banana farmers digest stocks." But in the end, China purchased only 118 tons -- less than 6 percent of the promised volume.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 1,000 FOREIGN PROFESSIONALS TO BENEFIT FROM NEW INCENTIVES

TEXT.P: More than 1,000 foreign professionals living and working in Taiwan will immediately benefit from a series of government incentives that aim to lure greater numbers of high-end white-collar workers to remain in the country, a government official said Wednesday.

According to Thomas M. F. Yeh, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , 1,032 foreign managers and high-tech workers will immediately become beneficiaries of the new measures, which were approved by the Executive Yuan in its weekly meeting earlier the same day.

Although the national coffers will suffer a loss in tax revenues of about NT$1 billion per year after the measures are implemented, Yeh said that incomes derived from increases in related economic activities will definitely exceed the decline in tax revenues.

The new measures offer a wide range of tax reductions, lowered thresholds on residency permits, and relaxed employment conditions for high-class foreign professionals together with benefits targeting those professionals' spouses and children.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI HELPS LOCAL GOVERNMENTS HIRE MORE CHILD-PROTECTION SOCIAL WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Children's Bureau under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has launched a program to recruit 320 social workers to help local governments deal with child protection issues, Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang said Wednesday.
The recruitment will bring the total number of local governments' child- protection social workers from 185 to 505, Lee said.
Lee said the program, initiated at the end of May, will give 40 percent personnel subsidies to local governments and will loosen restrictions on hiring contract staff.

Lee said that more social workers will reduce the workload on staff so that they will have more time and energy to work on each case. The quality of local governments' child protection will also be improved, he added.

The MOI has also recruited 89 social workers to help disadvantaged families in the last two years and has enlisted 190 to deal with domestic violence and sexual assault cases. Some of the newly recruited social workers also provide assistance to the MOI's services in the form of a counseling hot line for teen pregnancy.
Lee said the MOI has enrolled more than 600 social workers in the last two years, but added that the number is not enough to handle the large number of cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INSTRUCTS PREPARATIONS TO BE MADE FOR MASSIVE INMATE RELEASE

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung instructed relevant authorities Wednesday to be prepared for a massive release of prison inmates who are eligible for commutation in an amnesty program, to reduce the possible social impact to the lowest degree.

In a Ministry of Justice (MOJ) report on measures to deal with the enforcement of President Chen Shui-bian's commutation act, statistics show that 25,670 inmates will benefit from the amnesty, initiated as a way to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident of 1947 and the 20th anniversary of the lifting of 38 years of martial law in 1987.
The act will be enacted July 16 and on that day, 10,523 inmates will be released, while others will have their sentences halved, the report said.

Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin released the report at a meeting at the Executive Yuan, in which he cited MOJ statistics as saying that more than 31,000 prisoners were released in a 1988 amnesty and another 27,706 in 1991.

The ratio of recidivism among pardoned prisoners within 10 years of their release were 19.7 percent and 16.2 percent, respectively in those two amnesties, both lagging far behind the recidivism rate of 46.9 percent among those released after 1997.
The figures prove that the 2007 amnesty program does not contradict the government's determination to maintain social order and crack down on crime, according to Shih.

After hearing the report, the premier said reinforced measures should be implemented to monitor drug abusers and thieves, since the tallies show that drug abusers comprised the largest portion of prisoners to be released July 16.

Chang also instructed the Council of Labor Affairs to make efforts to assist the released prisoners with vocational training and employment opportunities, while requesting the Ministry of the Interior to help the socially disadvantaged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WELCOMES BEIJING USING `CHINESE TAIPEI' IN OLYMPICS

TEXT.P: Taiwan welcomes Beijing's move to address it with the official title that it uses in the International Olympic Committee (IOC), Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey said Wednesday.

Shieh made the remarks after China's Taiwan Affairs Office spokesman Yang Yi referred to Taiwan as "Chinese Taipei" while talking about the 2008 Beijing Olympic torch relay issues at a routine news conference earlier in the day.

It marked a major change in Beijing's references to Taiwan on Olympic affairs. For years, Beijing has addressed Taiwan as "Taipei, China" instead of the IOC- sanctioned designation "Chinese Taipei." Beijing has deliberately used its moniker as a means of showing its claim of sovereignty over Taiwan.

On April 26, Taiwan rejected a China-proposed torch relay route that would have had the flame arriving in Taiwan from Vietnam April 30, 2008, and going on to China-controlled Hong Kong and Macau. The moniker dispute was one of the reasons cited by Taiwan for its snubbing of the Beijing-proposed route.

"Given Taiwan's status as a formal IOC member, Beijing should at the very least address us by our official title in the organization, " Shieh said, adding that Beijing's change has vindicated some of the injustice Taiwan has endured over the years.

Shieh further said that so long as China refrains from efforts to "downgrade Taiwan or localize Taiwan" and instead deals with Taiwan on an equal footing, relations across the Taiwan Strait will definitely be on friendly terms and could even be "as cordial as brotherhood."
Lee Kao-hsiang, deputy minister of the Sports Affairs Council, echoed Shieh's view, saying that Taiwan is satisfied with Beijing's change in its attitude toward the name issue.
As for the Olympic torch relay, Lee said Taiwan remains firm on its position that the flame must enter and exit Taiwan via a third country.

"We cannot afford to compromise on this fundamental stance, "Lee said, adding that Taiwan cannot accept any arrangement of the relay route that would make Taiwan appear as a stop on a Chinese domestic route.
Lee said Taiwan looks forward to a new round of cross-strait talks on adjustments of the original Olympic torch relay route.

While announcing the 137,000-km relay route in Beijing April 26, Chinese officials claimed that Taiwan would be the starting point of China's domestic relay route, prompting Taiwan to reject the offer.

As with all Olympics, next year's relay will begin in Greece March 25. After circling Greece, it will arrive in Beijing March 31. It will then wend its way across Asia, Europe, the Americas, Africa and back to Asia and China before being used to ignite the cauldron at the opening ceremony Aug. 8 in Beijing's 91,000-seat National Stadium.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANGHUA COUNTY TO HOST 2011 NATIONAL ATHLETIC MEET

TEXT.P: Changhua County has obtained the right to host the 2011 National Athletic Meet after its magistrate signed an agreement Wednesday with the nation's top sports official.
Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan inked the pact at a ceremony with Yang Chung-ho, head of the Cabinet-level National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports.

Speaking at the ceremony, Cho said the Changhua county government will call on the public to provide "100 creative ideas" to make the 2011 athletic meet a memorable event, as the year is the Republic of China's 100th anniversary.
He promised that the county government will do its best in the next four years to make preparations and make the meet a success.
The event will be the first major athletic meet to be held in Changhua County in 26 years. The county last held a Taiwan Area Athletic Meet in 1985.
The National Athletic Meet has been held every two years since 1999, when it replaced the Taiwan Area Athletic Meet, which had taken place annually since 1974.
The 2007 National Athletic Meet will be held in Tainan City, while the 2009 event will take place in Taichung City.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:New Poll Finds That Young Americans Are Leaning Left
Young Americans are more likely than the general public to favor a government- run universal health care insurance system, an open- door policy on immigration and the legalization of gay marriage, according to a New York Times/CBS News/MTV poll. The poll also found that they are more likely to say the war in Iraq is heading to a successful conclusion.
The poll offers a snapshot of a group whose energy and idealism have always been as alluring to politicians as its scattered focus and shifting interests have been frustrating. It found that substantially more Americans ages 17 to 29 than four years ago are paying attention to the presidential race. But they appeared to be really familiar with only two of the candidates, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton, both Democrats.
Wall Street Journal:How Wall Street Stoked The Mortgage Meltdown
Twelve years ago, Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. sent a vice president to California to check out First Alliance Mortgage Co. Lehman was thinking about tapping into First Alliance's lucrative business of making "subprime" home loans to consumers with sketchy credit.
The vice president, Eric Hibbert, wrote a memo describing First Alliance as a financial "sweat shop" specializing in "high pressure sales for people who are in a weak state." At First Alliance, he said, employees leave their "ethics at the door."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENT CANDIDATE CONFIDENT IN BULLISH STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said Wednesday that the domestic stock market would rebound to over 10,000 points if the KMT regains power in 2008.

Ma made the remarks while answering reporters' questions after having attended a news conference called by human rights groups to lend support to three suspects involved in a high-profile homicide case that occurred in 1991 in Hsichih, Taipei County.

In response to criticisms made by Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Ma clarified that he has never called for an opening to Chinese laborers or Chinese farm products. "Hsieh must not make such false accusations against me," Ma said.
According to Ma, the KMT backs a liberal economic policy that would allow Taiwan to open to the whole world, including China, and Chinese tourists.
Ma vowed to establish direct transport links between Taiwan and China, and spoke of making Taiwan a free trade zone during a forum sponsored by UBS AG, Taipei branch Monday.
Ma announced Vincent Siew, a former premier from 1997-2000, as his running mate Saturday. Siew is known for his familiarity with economic affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW RADAR SYSTEM INAUGURATED AT THREE AIR FORCE BASES

TEXT.P: The air force held an inauguration ceremony Wednesday at the Pingtung air force base, marking the joint start of operations of new digitized radar systems at its bases in Pingtung, Taitung and Penghu counties.
Air Force Commanding General Shen Kuo-jen presided over the
ceremony at the air base in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, with more than 300 officers and retired veterans taking part.

According to the Air Force Command Headquarters, the installation of the digitized AN/MPN-14K (SS) radar system will replace the aging GCA (TH-CSF) radar system at the three bases -- marking the final stage of a NT$85 million program launched in 1999 to revamp the radar systems at air force bases nationwide.

The air force's overhaul of the radar systems will greatly help improve repair and maintenance of its aircraft, step up flight safety and boost overall combat ability, officers at the headquarters said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT SEMINAR ON POLITICAL, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT HELD

TEXT.P: Scholars from Taiwan and China discussed a wide range of topics related to political, social and economic development on both sides of the Taiwan Strait in a seminar held Wednesday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Tung Chen-yuan briefed the participants on the status of cross-strait exchanges and the Taiwan government's policy regarding cross-strait exchanges in his opening remarks at the one-day seminar, which took place at National Taiwan University (NTU).

The government has been trying to protect national interests instead of blocking cross-strait economic exchanges because the increasingly active cross-strait economy is determined by a market mechanism that should not be obstructed by government, Tung summed up.

However, Shen Jiuyuan, secretary-general of Pudong Taiwan Economic Research Center, and Liu Xiangping, a professor at Nanjing University, said Taiwan should be more open in its economic relationship with China to prevent itself from being marginalized.

The cross-strait political interaction of the last 20 years has not helped the Taiwanese people to erase their fear and distrust of China, said Georg Gesk, an assistant professor at Taiwan's Hsuan Chuang University. China's oppression of Taiwan's diplomatic and international space and its deployment of close to 1,000 missiles pointing at Taiwan led to a collective feeling of China's "animosity and unfriendliness," he added.

Gesk said the governments of Taiwan and China should make efforts to eliminate the animosity, citing the evolution of relations between France and Germany in explaining how former enemies make peace with each other.

A thesis by NTU professor Chou Chi-hsiang focused on the analysis of the second phase of constitutional reform in Taiwan and claimed that President Chen Shui- bian's road of constitutional reform has hit the wall and that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party will have to initiate negotiations with China to build up a healthy environment for presidential candidate Frank Hsieh.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN'S GROUP CALLS FOR JAPANESE COMPENSATION FOR COMFORT WOMEN

TEXT.P: A women's rights advocacy group protested in front of Japan's representative office in Taiwan Wednesday on the
heels of passage of a U.S. House committee resolution on the Japanese military's wartime sexual enslavement of women in Asia, demanding a formal apology and compensation from the Japanese government.

"This can be seen as a huge victory in our 15-year effort to get compensation for comfort women, " said Fran Gau, Executive Director of the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation (TWRF) , on the overwhelming 39-2 vote in the U.S. House of Representatives Foreign Affairs Committee passed that day, which called on the government of Japan to "formally acknowledge, apologize and accept historical responsibility" for its coercion of young women into sexual slavery during World War II.

The foundation and two former comfort women, Cheng Chen-tao and Chen Yang, staged a 30-minute protest in front of the Interchange Association, Japan's official representative office in Taiwan, under the watchful eyes of dozens of policemen. They were not received by Japanese officials.

"At 86 years old, I can no longer work and make a living. For many years the Japanese government has refused to recognize the existence of comfort women or offer a formal apology and compensation. With the passage of the resolution, I hope for Japan's apology and compensation, " said Cheng.

Chen Yang also questioned why the Taiwan government and legislature failed to initiate a practical solution in pressuring Japan now that the U.S. has shown support for the compensation claim movement.

"The governments of South Korea and China have been very active and supportive of the compensation claim. The Taiwan government and legislature should step up their efforts as well, as the resolution has now received support from Canada, Australia, Germany, South Korea, China and the Philippines, " said Gau.
"We are not requesting Japan's apology forever. We want the truth to be recognized, " said Legislator Joanna Lei, who also attended the protest.

"The government of Japan has never taken the responsibility it should have taken. On the contrary, it has spent a lot of money lobbying in the U.S. for the resolution not to pass, " Gau said, adding that the TWRF also condemned 44 Japanese lawmakers' denial of the existence comfort women in a full-page advertisement in the Washington Post earlier this month.
The non-binding Resolution 121, which was introduced by Representative Michael Honda last January, will now be voted on in a full House.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Leaving No Tracks.
Sue Ellen Wooldridge, the 19th-ranking Interior Department official, arrived at her desk in Room 6140 a few months after Inauguration Day 2001. A phone message awaited her.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH ENGINES OF MAY 19 CAL FLIGHT STOPPED: CAA

TEXT.P: An investigation into why both engines of a China Airlines plane on a May 19 flight to Hong Kong shut down before descending from 22,000 feet has concluded that the engines probably accumulated too much ice.

The CAL aircraft -- an Airbus A330-300 -- was equipped with two CF6-80E1 type engines manufactured by General Electric Co. of the United States, according to a report by the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

The report said that although the plane was able to continue its flight and landed in Hong Kong after its captain restarted both engines in less than a minute, the fact that both engines stopped was an "unusual incident."

Chang Hsiang-ti, deputy director of the CAA's Flight Standards Division, noted that the GE-produced engine had eight similar incidents worldwide previously and that the Airbus company had issued instructions on precautionary steps to prevent the engines from shutting down in the event of ice accumulation.
However, both engines stopped even though the captain followed standard procedure, Chang said, adding that the incident shows that "the CF6-80E1 engine does have a problem."
He said the CAA has asked Taiwan's two largest air carriers -- China Airlines and EVA Airways -- to upgrade the control systems on their planes equipped with the same type of engines.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO FORM ASIA PACIFIC UNIVERSITY ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that she will invite 35 university presidents from home and abroad to form an Asian Pacific university alliance later this year.
Lu made the remarks while receiving the first group of students to be awarded scholarships from the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) to conduct research in Taiwan.
She said the alliance will be inaugurated at the second assembly of the DPU, which is slated to be held in Taipei Aug. 14.

Lu noted that in the age of globalization, important universities in the DPU member countries should serve as a platform for the promotion of academic exchanges and give young students an opportunity to pursue knowledge in foreign countries.

Expressing their appreciation to Lu and the DPU for the support and assistance in helping them come to Taiwan, the students from Canada, Guatemala, El Salvador and Japan said they will share their Taiwan experience when they return home to let more people know about the beauty of Taiwan.
Lu said that following its establishment in 2005, the DPU began to offer scholarships to students of its member countries to engage in academic exchanges in Taiwan.
The number of applicants is rising every year, which indicates that what Lu describes as Taiwan's "soft power" has received widespread recognition from Pacific Rim countries, she said.
A total of 100 foreign guests -- congressmen, university presidents and representatives from non-profit organizations -- from 33 countries will attend the assembly in Taiwan, according to Lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH DEFENDS CONDITIONAL LIFTING OF BAN ON CANADIAN BEEF

TEXT.P: A Department of Health (DOH) official defended Wednesday the department's recent decision to reopen Taiwan to imports of Canadian boneless beef from cattle under 30 months of age, saying that the move was decided upon only after prudent and scientific evaluation.

Cheng Hui-wen, director of the DOH Bureau of Food Sanitation, made the remarks after opposition People First Party Legislator Tsai Sheng-chia accused the government of pandering to political pressure by allowing Canadian beef to enter Taiwan again.
Claiming that Canada remains a mad cow disease-affected area, Tsai said he is afraid that reopening Taiwan to Canadian beef will expose local people to health risks.

In response, Cheng said the legislator's worries are unwarrented and unnecessary, adding that the DOH dare not take any risk in exposing local people to deadly diseases nor would it pander to political pressure at the expense of local people's health.

According to Cheng, the DOH has conducted a comprehensive review of official documents furnished by Canadian authorities as well as done a scientific analysis based on the findings of field inspections.

"We have twice sent expert teams to Canada to inspect its cattle ranches, slaughterhouses and other relevant facilities and then commissioned the National Health Research Institute to conduct a professional assessment before coming to a decision, " Cheng said, adding that the DOH has not faced any political pressure in its decision-making process.

Under DOH regulations, Canadian beef entering Taiwan must bear health and hygiene certification issued by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CIFA) and must be handled and packed by DOH-approved slaughterhouses and packaging facilities in Canada.
Moreover, the beef should be free of all bone and other animal parts regarded as high-risk in terms of the deadly disease. These parts include principally brains, spinal cords and cattle bone marrow.

Taiwan issued an import ban on beef from Canada, the United States, Japan, Britain and several other European Union countries Dec. 31, 2003 amid fears over the threat of Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE), also known as mad cow disease.

The Canadian government applied to the DOH in March 2004 for lifting the import ban, and the DOH agreed to reopen Taiwan to Canadian beef imports with stringent restrictions last Saturday after holding 11 rounds of consultative meetings with health experts in terms of BSE prevention measures unveiled by the World Health Organization and the World Organization for Animal Health.

Besides demanding the Canadian government produce regular reports on its enforcement of BSE prevention and control measures, the DOH has also asked relevant government agencies, including the Ministry of Economic Affairs, to step up beef safety inspection and crack down on smuggling.

City and county health bureaus have also been ordered to intensify inspection of supermarket chains and hypermarts to check whether Canadian beef imports meet relevant DOH regulations or requirements.
At present, Taiwan only allows beef imports from the United States, New Zealand, Australia and Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SEEKS MARSHALL ISLANDS SUPPORT FOR U.N. BID

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said he looks forward to seeing Marshall Islands President Kessai Note travel to New York in September to attend the U.N. General Assembly and speak for Taiwan's membership bid.
Chen made the remarks while receiving Note and his wife at the Presidential Office for wide-ranging talks. The Marshall Islands first couple arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a five-day visit.

Although the Marshall Islands' representative stationed in Geneva failed to side with Taiwan in its quest for World Health Organization (WHO) membership under the name of Taiwan at the annual World Health Assembly -- the WHO's decision- making arm -- held in May because of various reasons, Chen said he is convinced that the South Pacific island nation will continue to support Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and the WHO in the future.

The Marshall Islands foreign minister already gave detailed explanations and apologized to the Republic of China government for his country's WHO ambassador's failure to give positive support for Taiwan's WHO bid this year, Chen said.

Noting that Note's current visit manifests the Marshall Islands' friendship and firm support for Taiwan, Chen said he appreciates the Pacific ally's support for Taiwan's cause in the world arenas over the past years.

Chen said he is scheduled to visit the Marshall Islands in mid-October to attend the second Taiwan-Pacific Allies Summit Meeting to be held in that country's capital, adding that he has high expectations of the planned meeting with top leaders of Taiwan's allies in the region.
For his part, Note said he will definitely attend this year's U.N. General Assembly to throw his weight behind Taiwan's bid to join
the body as "Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH ENGINES OF MAY 19 CAL FLIGHT STOPPED: CAA

TEXT.P: An investigation into why both engines of a China Airlines plane on a May 19 flight to Hong Kong shut down before descending from 22,000 feet has concluded that the engines probably accumulated too much ice.

The CAL aircraft -- an Airbus A330-300 -- was equipped with two CF6-80E1 type engines manufactured by General Electric Co. of the United States, according to a report by the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

The report said that although the plane was able to continue its flight and landed in Hong Kong after its captain restarted both engines in less than a minute, the fact that both engines stopped was an "unusual incident."

Chang Hsiang-ti, deputy director of the CAA's Flight Standards Division, noted that the GE-produced engine had eight similar incidents worldwide previously and that the Airbus company had issued instructions on precautionary steps to prevent the engines from shutting down in the event of ice accumulation.
However, both engines stopped even though the captain followed standard procedure, Chang said, adding that the incident shows that "the CF6-80E1 engine does have a problem."
He said the CAA has asked Taiwan's two largest air carriers -- China Airlines and EVA Airways -- to upgrade the control systems on their planes equipped with the same type of engines.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO FORM ASIA PACIFIC UNIVERSITY ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that she will invite 35 university presidents from home and abroad to form an Asian Pacific university alliance later this year.
Lu made the remarks while receiving the first group of students to be awarded scholarships from the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) to conduct research in Taiwan.
She said the alliance will be inaugurated at the second assembly of the DPU, which is slated to be held in Taipei Aug. 14.

Lu noted that in the age of globalization, important universities in the DPU member countries should serve as a platform for the promotion of academic exchanges and give young students an opportunity to pursue knowledge in foreign countries.

Expressing their appreciation to Lu and the DPU for the support and assistance in helping them come to Taiwan, the students from Canada, Guatemala, El Salvador and Japan said they will share their Taiwan experience when they return home to let more people know about the beauty of Taiwan.
Lu said that following its establishment in 2005, the DPU began to offer scholarships to students of its member countries to engage in academic exchanges in Taiwan.
The number of applicants is rising every year, which indicates that what Lu describes as Taiwan's "soft power" has received widespread recognition from Pacific Rim countries, she said.
A total of 100 foreign guests -- congressmen, university presidents and representatives from non-profit organizations -- from 33 countries will attend the assembly in Taiwan, according to Lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH DEFENDS CONDITIONAL LIFTING OF BAN ON CANADIAN BEEF

TEXT.P: A Department of Health (DOH) official defended Wednesday the department's recent decision to reopen Taiwan to imports of Canadian boneless beef from cattle under 30 months of age, saying that the move was decided upon only after prudent and scientific evaluation.

Cheng Hui-wen, director of the DOH Bureau of Food Sanitation, made the remarks after opposition People First Party Legislator Tsai Sheng-chia accused the government of pandering to political pressure by allowing Canadian beef to enter Taiwan again.
Claiming that Canada remains a mad cow disease-affected area, Tsai said he is afraid that reopening Taiwan to Canadian beef will expose local people to health risks.

In response, Cheng said the legislator's worries are unwarrented and unnecessary, adding that the DOH dare not take any risk in exposing local people to deadly diseases nor would it pander to political pressure at the expense of local people's health.

According to Cheng, the DOH has conducted a comprehensive review of official documents furnished by Canadian authorities as well as done a scientific analysis based on the findings of field inspections.

"We have twice sent expert teams to Canada to inspect its cattle ranches, slaughterhouses and other relevant facilities and then commissioned the National Health Research Institute to conduct a professional assessment before coming to a decision, " Cheng said, adding that the DOH has not faced any political pressure in its decision-making process.

Under DOH regulations, Canadian beef entering Taiwan must bear health and hygiene certification issued by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CIFA) and must be handled and packed by DOH-approved slaughterhouses and packaging facilities in Canada.
Moreover, the beef should be free of all bone and other animal parts regarded as high-risk in terms of the deadly disease. These parts include principally brains, spinal cords and cattle bone marrow.

Taiwan issued an import ban on beef from Canada, the United States, Japan, Britain and several other European Union countries Dec. 31, 2003 amid fears over the threat of Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE), also known as mad cow disease.

The Canadian government applied to the DOH in March 2004 for lifting the import ban, and the DOH agreed to reopen Taiwan to Canadian beef imports with stringent restrictions last Saturday after holding 11 rounds of consultative meetings with health experts in terms of BSE prevention measures unveiled by the World Health Organization and the World Organization for Animal Health.

Besides demanding the Canadian government produce regular reports on its enforcement of BSE prevention and control measures, the DOH has also asked relevant government agencies, including the Ministry of Economic Affairs, to step up beef safety inspection and crack down on smuggling.

City and county health bureaus have also been ordered to intensify inspection of supermarket chains and hypermarts to check whether Canadian beef imports meet relevant DOH regulations or requirements.
At present, Taiwan only allows beef imports from the United States, New Zealand, Australia and Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SEEKS MARSHALL ISLANDS SUPPORT FOR U.N. BID

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said he looks forward to seeing Marshall Islands President Kessai Note travel to New York in September to attend the U.N. General Assembly and speak for Taiwan's membership bid.
Chen made the remarks while receiving Note and his wife at the Presidential Office for wide-ranging talks. The Marshall Islands first couple arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a five-day visit.

Although the Marshall Islands' representative stationed in Geneva failed to side with Taiwan in its quest for World Health Organization (WHO) membership under the name of Taiwan at the annual World Health Assembly -- the WHO's decision- making arm -- held in May because of various reasons, Chen said he is convinced that the South Pacific island nation will continue to support Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and the WHO in the future.

The Marshall Islands foreign minister already gave detailed explanations and apologized to the Republic of China government for his country's WHO ambassador's failure to give positive support for Taiwan's WHO bid this year, Chen said.

Noting that Note's current visit manifests the Marshall Islands' friendship and firm support for Taiwan, Chen said he appreciates the Pacific ally's support for Taiwan's cause in the world arenas over the past years.

Chen said he is scheduled to visit the Marshall Islands in mid-October to attend the second Taiwan-Pacific Allies Summit Meeting to be held in that country's capital, adding that he has high expectations of the planned meeting with top leaders of Taiwan's allies in the region.
For his part, Note said he will definitely attend this year's U.N. General Assembly to throw his weight behind Taiwan's bid to join
the body as "Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 28, or the 14th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1776: British forces are defeated at the first Battle of Charleston during the American Revolution.
1836: James Madison, fourth president of the United States, is born. His influence at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia in 1787, which drew up the constitution, gained him the name "Father of the American Constitution."
1838: The coronation of Queen Victoria, 19, is held in Westminster Abbey. Her sense of duty and strict moral code greatly influenced 19th-century British society.
1902: The United States authorizes the construction of the Panama Canal.
1919: A peace treaty officially ending four years of devastating war is finally signed by a humiliated Germany and the victorious allies at Versailles, France.
1919: The Republic of China refuses to sign the Treat of Versailles because German rights in Shantung are given to Japan.
1932: Chiang Kai-shek, who became chairman of the National Military Council on March 18, arrives in Hankow from Lushan to direct the campaign against the Chinese communists.
1940: Japan declares a blockade against Hong Kong, cutting off land and sea traffic between Hong Kong and the Chinese mainland. Air transportation is excluded from the blockade.
1948: A strong earthquake rocks Fukui prefecture in Japan, killing more than 5,000 people.
1948: The Yugoslav Communist Party is expelled from Cominform at a meeting in Bucharest, marking the formal breach in relations between Yugoslavia and the rest of the communist bloc.
1950: Foreign Minister K.C. Yeh (Yeh Kung-chao) declares the Republic of China has in principle accepted the U.S. government's proposal to cease military operations against mainland China and that the necessary orders have been given to the ROC Navy and Air Force.
1950: Gen. Douglas McArthur, commander of the Allied forces in the South Pacific, flies to South Korea soon after North Korean troops capture Seoul.
1958: Brazil wins the World Cup in Stockholm thanks to the outstanding performance of the 17-year-old soccer player Pele, whose real name is Edson Arantes do Nascimento.
1970: U.S. troops begin their pullout from Cambodia.
1976: Fifty-one American scholars, researchers, teachers and students arrive in Taipei for a five-week Seminar on China Studies.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives H.A.E. Scheels, permanent honorary vice president of the International Badminton Federation.
1977: Ma Chi-chuang, board chairman of the China Steel Corp., puts a torch to the blast furnace of the company's new Kaohsiung steel plant to signify the start of steel making at the plant.
1979: The ROC government approves two new appointments proposed by the Kuomintang's Central Committee, naming H.K. Yang, political vice foreign minister, as ambassador to South Africa, and Ding Mou-shih, administrative vice foreign minister, as ambassador to South Korea.
1981: To promote cultural communication and economic relations, the Sino- Nigerian Cultural and Economic Association is established in Taipei.
1986: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1987: The 70th Annual Lions Clubs International Convention is held in Taipei. The convention lasts seven days, with 40,000 members and their families joining the gathering.
1996: The ROC exchanges economic and trade representative offices with the Republic of Belarus. Belarus becomes the second (Russia being the first) member of the Commonwealth of Independent States to establish such relations with the ROC.
1999: The 1999 International Seminar on the Protection of Clean Coasts opens in Kaohsiung with more than 100 experts from home and abroad attending.
2000: Just as scientists from around the world have finished the first big step toward mapping the human genome, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh announces that Taiwan will establish its own genetic research center within one year.
2001: The National Policy Foundation, an opposition Kuomintang think tank, unveils new policy guidelines featuring a "confederation" with Beijing and a "double economic triangle" covering Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, whether dealing with a few people or many, with great matters or with small, is never presumptuous and never regards anything as beneath his notice or as unworthy of serious and careful attention -- that is what is meant by being dignified without being supercilious."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO LEAVE FOR LATIN AMERICA JULY 2

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu is scheduled to leave July 2 for a visit to three of the country's diplomatic allies in Latin America via the United States, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Thursday.
Lu's destinations will cover the Dominican Republic, Paraguay and Guatemala, MOFA officials said.
Lu will stop over in the U.S. city of San Francisco en route to the first leg of her trip, the Dominican Republic, where she will stay for three nights, the officials said.
Lu will then head to Paraguay to take part in an event marking the 50th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Paraguay, the officials said.
After staying for three nights in the South America nation, Lu will leave for Guatemala via Panama, where Lu's flight will stop briefly for refueling, they said.

Lu is scheduled to stay in Guatemala for another three nights, after which she will wrap up the trip and head back to Taiwan via Los Angeles, they said, adding that Lu is expected to arrive home July 14.
Members of Lu's delegation will include Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Javier Ching-shan Hou and ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators Hsu Jung-shu and Lan Mei-chin, MOFA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
PUBLIC WARNED ON STINGRAY DANGER

TEXT.P: The public should be on guard if they are stung by a stingray, as the spine contains a potentially deadly venom, a doctor from a central Taiwan hospital warned Thursday.

Lu Li-hua, director of the Emergency Department of Tung's Taichung Metro Harbor Hospital, said the hospital recently handled three such cases including a 39 -year-old local and a 28-year-old foreign national, who were stung by the fish as they were collecting fishing nets, and a 28-year-old chef, who was stung while preparing a dish featuring the fish.
Lu noted that clinical experience has shown that most patients were inadvertently stung while fishing or preparing the fish for cooking.
He said the classic symptoms after being stung are severe pain, chest pain or chest tightness, palpitations, night sweats and dizziness, and in the most serious cases, death.

He said that after being stung, the patients should immerse the affected area in hot water at a temperature of between 41 and 45 Celsius, and seek urgent medical treatment. They should remain under observation in hospital for at least six hours to be safe.
The most famous stingray-related injury resulted in the death of Stephen Irwin, nicknamed "the Crocodile Hunter."

Irwin, an Australian wildlife expert and television personality, achieved world- wide fame from the television program "The Crocodile Hunter, " which was an internationally broadcast wildlife documentary series co-hosted with his wife Terri Irwin.
On September 4, 2006, Irwin was fatally stung in the chest by a stingray whilst snorkeling at Batt Reef off the coast of Port Douglas, Queensland, on Australia's Great Barrier Reef.
Irwin was in the area filming a documentary entitled "Ocean's Deadliest."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ TO FLESH OUT DETAILS FOR RELEASE OF PARDONED PRISONERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) will hold a meeting next Monday to flesh out technical details for the smooth release of prison inmates eligible for pardon under a sentence commutation statute that will take effect July 16, an official said Thursday.

According to MOJ tallies, 25,670 prisoners will benefit from the statute passed by the legislature June 15, with more than 10,000 eligible for release immediately and the remaining having their sentences cut by half.
As soon as the statute comes into force, 10,523 inmates, including 170 people serving time in military prisons, will be eligible for release.

To ensure the smooth operation of relevant formalities, the official said, staff members from the MOJ's prosecutorial, correction, and rehabilitation and protection affairs departments as well as chief prosecutors and prison heads from across the country will meet July 2 to hammer out technical details and various corresponding measures.

MOJ statistics show that more than 40 percent of prisoners to be released July 16 are offenders against the narcotics control act. To prevent recidivism among newly released drug offenders, the official said, the MOJ will keep close tabs on their behavior and offer them necessary assistance, including helping them join treatment programs and find jobs.

Among drug offenders to be released on the first day that the pardons take effect, 635 are HIV-carriers, the official said, adding that the MOJ will take special measures to prevent further spread of AIDS and assist the released HIV- carrier drug offenders in rehabilitation.

On that day, the official said, the Taiwan Aftercare Association will send staff to prisons around the country to present a package of pamphlets to each of the freed HIV-carrier drug offenders, which will contain information about AIDS prevention, drug rehabilitation and Methadone substitute programs.

The second largest group of inmates to be released on the first day of the pardons are offenders convicted of burglary and theft, while those convicted of fraud will form the third largest group of pardoned prisoners, the official said.

On April 24, President Chen Shui-bian proposed a sentence commutation plan in commemoration of the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident of 1947 and the 20th anniversary of the lifting of 38 years of martial law in 1987.
Acting on Chen's directive, the Cabinet drafted a commutation bill and referred it to the legislature for approval.

Although the ruling Democratic Progressive Party supported the Cabinet-drafted bill, the version proposed by the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) was passed by the legislature after a cross- party consensus was reached.
The Cabinet-drafted version would grant commutation to only those who receive one-year sentences or less, compared to the opposition-proposed one-and-a -half-year sentences or less.
Some DPP lawmakers accused the "pan-blue alliance" of tailoring the statute to benefit KMT Legislator Chiu Yi.

Chiu was sentenced to 14 months in prison for his violent conduct during a protest at the Kaohsiung District Court following the 2004 presidential election. Chiu began serving time behind bar in April.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY PRODS CHINA TO MAKE CHANGES: MOFA

TEXT.P: China is addressing Taiwan with the official title that it uses in the International Olympic Committee (IOC) thanks to the influence of the international community, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

David Y. L. Lin, director of MOFA's Department of International Organizations, made the remarks a day after China's Taiwan Affairs Office spokesman Yang Yi refereed to Taiwan as "Chinese Taipei" while talking about the 2008 Beijing Olympic torch relay issues.

That marks a major change in Beijing's references to Taiwan on Olympic affairs. For years, Beijing has addressed Taiwan as "Taipei, China" instead of the IOC- sanctioned designation "Chinese Taipei." Beijing has deliberately distorted the name as a means of restating its claim to sovereignty over Taiwan.
Lin said that this shows that if the international community speaks out for Taiwan, it will prod China to rethink its past practices and make changes.

He also said that a recent move by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) to downgrade Taiwan's membership to the level of a "non-sovereign regional member" under pressure from China is indicative of China's relentless obstruction of Taiwan's efforts to seek maneuvering space in the international community.
China would even force members of international organizations in which Taiwan is already a member to accept its "one China principle," which Taiwan can never accept, Lin said.

Lin said the recent drive to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan" is aimed at making the international community "recognize Taiwan's separate identity and that the island is by no means a part of the People's Republic of China."
He said the drive is still ongoing, and priority must be given to soliciting support from allies as well as communicating with other major countries.

Asked whether the ministry will send delegations to the European Union, Japan and the United States to lobby for their support, Lin said Taiwan's overseas embassies and representative offices are communicating with the officials of their stationed countries.

The ministry will not necessarily send delegations, but will ask experts and scholars to visit major countries to explain the reasons why the nation wishes to apply to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: YULONG GETS NATION'S 1ST CERTIFICATE FOR VEHICLE ANTI-THEFT SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Yulong Nissan Motor Co., a joint venture between Yulong Group of Taiwan and Nissan Motor of Japan, has received the nation's first certificate from the Ministry of the Interior on its newly developed vehicle anti-theft system called "Anti Theft Vehicle Identification Number (VIN)."
Yulong Nissan General Manager Wu Hsin-fa and Interior Minister Lee Yi-Yang announced the achievement at a news conference Wednesday.

According to Wu, the system protects a vehicle by having vehicle identification numbers tagged on important parts and components. These security lables are invisible and very difficult to remove. Even if they are scratched off, ultraviolet marks will be left on the vehicle for tracing, Wu said.
Lee said vehicle anti-theft system will help reduce vehicle theft by increasing risk of theft and raising difficulties for selling stolen cars and components.

All of the cars produced by Nissan will be fitted with the system from July 1 and the company will absorb the added production cost until the end of October, Wu said. It will also be available for sale for retro-fitting to older cars, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR TAIWANESE COMPANIES GET GREEN LIGHT FOR CHINA-BOUND INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Four Taiwanese high-technology companies have gotten the green light from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Thursday to invest in low-end semiconductor testing and packaging plants in China.

Executives of the Advanced Semiconductor Engineering (ASE) Group, Siliconware Precision Industries Co., Greatek Electronic and Walton Advanced Engineering Inc. all welcomed the "final approval" granted by the MOEA's Investment Commission.

The four companies' China-bound investment plans involve ASE Group's joint venture with Philips' NXP Semiconductor to establish a semiconductor testing and packaging plant in Suzhou; Siliconware's investment of US$30 million in Suzhou; Greatek's investment of US$30 million in a Chinese city yet to be decided; and Walton's investment of US$18 million, also in Suzhou, according to Investment Commission officials.

The administration announced the lifting of a ban on Taiwanese firms investing in semiconductor testing and packaging plants in China in April last year. Many Taiwanese companies had submitted applications, but only these four have passed the Investment Commission's screening process as their applications fit with the MOEA's regulations on cross-strait division of labor and investment, the officials said.

In order to accelerate the approval of their applications, these four companies have also promised to first increase investments in Taiwan. Of them, Siliconware plans to spend some NT$30 billion (US$915 million) to build a new semiconductor testing and packaging plant, which is expected to create some 6,000 jobs, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
