Rome Mayor Walter Veltroni announced to run for the post of secretary of the center-left democratic party in formation. He will face a primary election Oct. 14 for leading the future new party which will be formed by main allied parties of the ruling center-left coalition led by Premier Romano Prodi.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OPEN TO ALL POSSIBILITIES ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 27 (CNA) 06/28/07 16:19:47 (By Michelle Tsai and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not rule out any possibilities in the development of the country's relations with China, so long as they are approved by the people through a democratic process, Taiwan's representative to the United States said Wednesday.

Making the remarks during a luncheon with members of major U.S. think tanks in Washington D.C., Joseph Wu said Taiwan's cross-Taiwan Strait policy has remained unchanged despite the suspension of the National Unification Guidelines last year.

According to Wu, President Chen Shui-bian will try to improve Taiwan's relations with China during the remaining 11 months of his term by seeking a breakthrough on cross-strait talks on issues concerning the operations of cross-strait charter flights and visits to Taiwan by Chinese tourists.

However, Wu said the government of Taiwan will never accept Beijing's "one China" principle or the so-called "1992 consensus, " which Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang claims allows Taiwan and China to interpret the meaning of "one China" separately.
Pointing to results of opinion surveys, Wu said the majority of people in Taiwan wish to maintain the status quo and are not ready to go for the option of establishing a "Republic of Taiwan."
Wu said although it is unlikely that China will accept this option at present, the minds of intellectuals in China are expected to become more open as China becomes more prosperous.

On Taiwan's plan to push for a referendum on the country's bid to apply to the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan, " Wu said Taiwan and the United States should step up their communications to sort out their differences on the matter.

Wu said Taiwan understands that some moves it is planning to make are likely to draw strong reaction from the other side of the Taiwan Strait. But if the United States is to try to restrict Taiwan from doing things that are common in other democratic countries, it will be hard to convince the people of Taiwan, he said.

Wu noted that the United States was supportive of referendums held by Eastern European countries to withdraw from the former Soviet Union and that many other countries are also holding referendums as part of the process to amend their constitutions.

However, the United States is always nervous whenever Taiwan is planning to push for a referendum, especially on issues concerning Taiwan's participation in the international community and other sovereignty-related issues, Wu said.

He said Taiwan has no intention of causing a cross-strait crisis and hopes the United States will allow its key policy-makers to visit Taiwan to conduct direct communication with their Taiwanese counterparts.

According to Wu, although Taiwan maintains no diplomatic relations with member nations of the European Union, many of these countries have sent vice ministerial-level officials and foreign affairs officials to Taiwan.
Taiwan hopes there will be similar exchanges between Taipei and Washington, he said.

Expressing approval for a non-binding resolution adopted Tuesday by the U.S. House of Representatives' Committee on Foreign Affairs urging the administrative branch to lift restrictions on visits to the United States by high-level elected and appointed officials of Taiwan, Wu said the resolution reflected the U.S. Congress' recognition of Taiwan's democratic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE FALUN GONG MEMBERS REMAIN DETAINED IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: More than 20 Falung Gong members from Taiwan remain in detention in Hong Kong Thursday after staging a sit-in the previous night at the airport in protest against having been denied entry.

One of the Falung Gong members, surnamed Yang, spoke to the CNA by telephone from detention in Hong Kong, saying that the group began their sit-in at the airport after being barred from entering the former British colony upon arrival at 7: 30 p.m. Wednesday.

The group of Taiwanese Falun Gong members were slated to take part in a demonstration July 1 in Hong Kong to protest China's human rights abuses on the occasion of the 10th anniversary of the special administrative region's return to Chinese rule.
According to Yang, they asked Hong Kong authorities to give an explanation as to why they were denied entry and decided to stage the sit-in after getting no response from Hong Kong officials.
They continued the protest until 4 a.m., when Hong Kong policemen took them away by force and placed them in the detention center. All of the demonstrators were detained in isolation, she added.

The Hong Kong police were extremely unfriendly to them during the sit-in, refusing to allow them to drink water, or go to the toilet with company, she said, adding that those who went to the toilet alone were taken away one by one.
Yang accused Hong Kong authorities of treating them in a brutal manner without justifiable reason and stated that they were determined to reveal the episode to the whole world.
Meanwhile, the Hong Kong government spokesman declined to comment on the incident on the grounds that it was an isolated case.

In a written statement, the U. S. State Department also called on the Hong Kong government to maintain a high level of personal and policial freedom, saying that it had learned that at least one Falun Gong member from Taiwan had been denied entry to Hong Kong.
Theresa Chu, a human rights lawyer and Taiwanese Falun Gong practitioner, was deported the day after arriving on the evening June 24 in Hong Kong.
According to a spokesman for the Falun Gong movement in Hong Kong, a further 100 Taiwanese Falun Gong members were also barred from entering the former British colony.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 48.61 points to close at 8,892.83.

The bourse opened at the day's high of 8,914.69 and dipped to 8,841.96 during the day's trading. A total of 5.69 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$151.16 billion (US$4.61 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up most at 1.9 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 1.3 percent, cement stocks at 0.9 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.6 percent, and construction issues at 0.3 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving down 0.9 percent and textile stocks decreasing 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 722 to 504, with 199 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED NOT TO POLITICIZE TAIWAN'S REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian blasted China's ceaseless efforts to squeeze Taiwan out of the international community Thursday, calling on Beijing not to politicize his recent proposal to hold a referendum on Taiwan's U.N. bid.
Chen made the remarks at the opening ceremony of a training course on national development and women leadership sponsored by the Executive Yuan.

In addition to hailing Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's leadership, Chen spent nearly 30 minutes talking about Beijing's malicious repression of Taiwan's efforts to participate in international activities over the last seven years.
Noting that Beijing deployed some 200 missiles targeting Taiwan in 2000 when he assumed post as Taiwan's president, Chen said the number of the missiles recently jumped to 988.

In addition, China's military spending is growing by double digits every year, with the U.S. government warning that Taiwan should stay alert as China's military expansion has exceeded its defense needs.
According to Chen, China is oppressing Taiwan from top to bottom, regardless of political affiliations, including both people and animals, and central and local governments.

For example, Chen added, recently Beijing lured away Taiwan's diplomatic ally -- Costa Rica -- as it did with Saudi Arabia, South Korea, and South Africa during the previous Kuomintang (KMT) government.

Chen went on that Beijing's suppression of Taiwan will not loosen even if Taiwan adopts policies advocating unification with China, citing the example of China's blocking Taipei's participation in the World Capital Forum and the meeting of the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC21) , when former opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou was mayor of Taipei.
Ma, the KMT's presidential candidate for the 2008 election, is considered by some as favoring unification with China.

Furthermore, Chen said, China told a visiting Taiwanese delegation of opposition leaders in 2005 that it would help Taiwan join the World Health Organization (WHO) , however, Beijing later signed a secret memorandum of understanding with the WHO secretariat, downgrading Taiwan's sovereignty and requiring that the island's technical exchanges with the WHO be contingent on China's approval.

In regard to his recent plan to promote a referendum on Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan", to be held alongside the 2008 presidential election, Chen stressed that the proposal does not violate his former commitment to U.S. government and has nothing to do with changing Taiwan's official designation.
As Taiwan has failed in its U.N. bid for the last decade under the name of Republic of China, Chen asked what other options the country has other than pursuing membership under the name of "Taiwan."
Chen's plan immediately encountered strong opposition from the U.S. government, which declared that it opposes any initiative that appears designed to change Taiwan's status unilaterally.

Concerning opposition from some people to his referendum proposal, Chen said he did not quite understand whether these people are opposing the holding of a referendum, the use of the name of "Taiwan", or Taiwan's entry into the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOVEREIGNTY KEY TO DEMOCRACY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that Hong Kong's regressive democratic development over the past 10 years of Chinese rule, which strikes a sharp contrast with Taiwan's improving democratization during the same period, proves that "without sovereignty, there is no democracy."

Making the comment in the latest issue of his online newsletter ahead of the 10th anniversary of Hong Kong's transition to Chinese rule, Chen likened Hong Kong to a bird confined in "a cage that is becoming smaller and smaller."

According to Chen, Beijing's promise to grant a high-degree of autonomy to the Hong Kong people under the "one country, two systems" formula is nothing but a lie -- one which prompted 500,000 Hong Kong residents to take to the streets on July 1, 2003.

"Today's Hong Kong can only choose between staying in a bigger cage and a smaller one, but is unable to change its fate in a bird cage or enjoy the right to be its own master. Taiwan's 23 million people should count themselves lucky about this," Chen said.

Noting that this year also marks the 20th anniversary of the lifting of martial law in Taiwan, Chen said Taiwan's history over the past five decades testifies that the wave of democracy is irresistible and that the party-state system and authoritarianism cannot last long.

While democratization is the path that China is bound to take in the future, the experiences of Taiwan and Hong Kong will be the best references for China in its process to achieve freedom, democracy, human rights and the rule of law, Chen said, expressing the hope that democracy and freedom will become common in China, Hong Kong and Taiwan, and across all of the ethnic Chinese community.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE FOOTWEAR DUMPING HAS DAMAGED TAIWAN INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Imported footwear from China has indeed substantially damaged Taiwan's industry, the International Trade Commission (ITC) of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) ruled Thursday after months of investigation.

The MOEA will notify the Ministry of Finance of its final ruling and the latter will decide on whether to impose anti-dumping taxes on Chinese footwear by July 13 at the latest, economics officials said.

The Ministry of Finance imposed a provisional anti-dumping tax of up to 43.46 percent on footwear imported from China March 13 after Taiwanese footwear manufacturers filed a complaint with the ITC last August and the ITC ruled last November that imported cheap Chinese footwear had inflicted substantial damages on Taiwan shoemakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 9TH ASIAN TEXTILE CONFERENCE KICKS OFF IN TAICHUNG CITY

TEXT.P: The 9th Asian Textile Conference (Atexcon) --the biggest textile conference in the Asia-Pacific region-- kicked off its three-day meeting Thursday at Feng Chia University (FCU) in the central city of Taichung.
The biennial international conference brings together more than 400 participants, including nearly 180 scholars and experts from more than 10 countries, an FCU spokesman said.

According to the spokesman, "wisdom, security and environmental protection " are the subjects of this year's Atexcon, which the FCU organized together with Taiwan's Chinese Institute of Textile Engineers.
Textile specialists from Iran, Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea, India, and Australia will give six keynote speeches, and a total of 210 research papers will be presented during the three-day meeting.

The Atexcon conference, first held in 1991, is hosted in turns by members of the Federation of Asian Professional Textile Association (FAPTA) , the spokesman said, adding that Taiwan, one of the association's six founding members, strove to hold this year's conference during the last meeting, held in Iran.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved up 62 points to close at 8,838, with 41,295 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for August gained 28 points to finish at 8,766, with 397 contracts traded, while September futures increased 41 points to close at 8,734, with 106 contract transactions. December futures rose 36 points to close at 8,769, with 11 contracts traded, while March futures moved up 62 points to finish at 8,769, with 15 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 8,776 for July, 8,738 for August, 8,693 for September, 8,733 for December and 8,707 for March.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

July TE futures rose 2.25 points to close at 378.85, with 2,576 contracts traded, while August TE futures gained 1.4 point to finish at 376.7, with 21 contract transactions. September TE futures moved up 4.15 points to close at 376.7, with seven contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

July TF futures moved up 10 points to close at 1,045, with 3,494 contracts traded, while August TF futures gained 6.6 points to finish at 1,040, with 110 contract transactions. September TF futures rose 8.8 points to close at 1,041.6, with 12 contracts traded, while December TF futures increased 15 points to finish at 1,044, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.051 to close at NT$32.836.
A total of US$810 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.735 and hit a high of NT$32.843.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP OPPOSES LIMIT ON NUMBER OF CHINESE SPOUSES

TEXT.P: Members of a private cross-Taiwan Strait relations group, accompanying some 60 Chinese spouses of Taiwan nationals, lodged a protest at the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) Thursday, opposing the administration's plans to further restrict the number of Chinese spouses settling in Taiwan.

Tang Shu, secretary-general of the private Chunghua Cross-Strait Marriage Consultation Association, said this was the second time since mid-June that the association and the Chinese spouses have filed an appeal with the MOI to scrap articles in a draft population policy white paper that would be tremendously discriminatory to Chinese spouses of Taiwan citizens.

The protesters expressed opposition to the parts of the population policy white paper stipulating that the number of Chinese spouses of Taiwan citizens would be further restricted and that Chinese spouses and foreign spouses of Taiwan citizens should produce a financial certificate effective for one year before obtaining their Republic of China IDs. The financial certificate would require the applicants to have at least NT$350,000 (US$10,671) of their own.

The protesters also demanded that the government immediately amend articles 17 and 21 of the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area so that Chinese spouses can be treated equally as foreign spouses to obtain ROC IDs after four years of continuous residence in Taiwan, instead of eight years.

Tang said his association and the protesting Chinese spouses hope that the discriminatory lines in the white paper will be scrapped before it is submitted to the Executive Yuan for approval in mid-July. If not, he said, association members and the Chinese spouses will take their protest to the streets in September.

Zhou Yuhui, a woman from Hunan Province and the wife of Taichung resident Yang Chiang-yao, who were among Thursday's protesters, said that according to the draft population policy white paper, she would be unable to obtain her ROC ID until 30 years after she came to Taiwan in April 2006 after marrying Yang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPRESSES CONCERN TO H.K. OVER ENTRY DENIAL CASE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 27 (CNA) 06/28/07 18:49:12 (By Lin Yu-kuo and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative office in Hong Kong expressed concern Wednesday to the Hong Kong authorities over their denial of a Taiwanese Falun Gong practitioner's entry into Hong Kong.

Theresa Chu, who is also the Asian executive director of the United States-based Human Rights Law Foundation, was barred from entering Hong Kong Wednesday, making it her second denial of entry in three days.

Chu said that prior to the 10th anniversary of Hong Kong's handover to China July 1, the Hong Kong authorities have been repatriating dozens of Taiwanese Falun Gong practitioners to Taiwan recently in an effort to prevent them from staging a protest in front of Chinese President Hu Jintao during his visit to Hong Kong.

Chu and three other Taiwanese members of Falun Gong filed a lawsuit against the Hong Kong authorities in 2003 over the authorities' refusal to allow 80 Taiwanese Falun Gong members to enter Hong Kong. The case has not been settled.
Beijing outlawed Falun Gong in 1999, followed with a national crackdown on what it considers to be an evil cult.
A spokesman for the Hong Kong authorities declined to comment on the issue, describing it as "an individual case."
Following the denial, a spokesman for the U.S. State Department urged Hong Kong to "continue to uphold its high standards of personal and political freedom."
"We believe all individuals, regardless of their beliefs or affiliation, should enjoy the right to legitimate travel and peaceful assembly," the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PEOPLE MISUSE REFRIGERATORS: POLL

TEXT.P: Nearly 70 percent of people in Taiwan have wrongly stored food in their refrigerators, which raises serious health concerns, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.

Yuan's General Hospital in the southern port city of Kaohsiung conducted the telephone survey of local citizens aged 15-70 in Taipei, Taichung, and Kaohsiung May 16-29, collecting a total of 400 valid samples.

The survey shows that 70 percent of the respondents do not properly care for their food before placing it in the refrigerator, while 60 percent often leave rotten food in the refrigerator, accelerating the growth of bacteria.
In Kaohsiung, the survey indicates, around 55 percent of the people surveyed said that their refrigerators have an odd odor and are dirtied with spilled soup, blood, or other liquids.

In Taichung, every one in five person often stuffs their refrigerators with food, eats it over seven days after purchase, and finds spoiled food in the refrigerator almost every month, the survey states.
Nearly 50 percent of respondents in Taipei mistakenly believe that the freshness of food can be maintained so long as it is kept in a refrigerator, the survey points out.

Hsu Chong-ming, a medical doctor at the hospital, urged the public to pay greater attention to the preservation of food, adding that few people realize that eating unclean food at home may lead to diarrhea or food poisoning.

DOC.HEADLINE: HALF NATION'S COACH DRIVERS ARE OVERWORKED: CONSUMER'S FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: An investigation by the Consumer's foundation has found that half of the long- distance coach drivers plying Taiwan's highways are overworked in apparent violation of the nation's Labor Standards Law.

Foundation Chairman Cheng Jen-hung told a press conference Thursday that the foundation sampled six coach drivers working for the Kuo-Kuang Motor Transport Co. and the Aloha Bus Co. and monitored their work patterns June 13-22, to find that half of them worked more than 12 hours per day.

Cheng pointed out that the current working conditions of coach drivers show no improvement compared with four years ago when a report by the Institute of Occupational Safety and Health said that coach drivers in Taiwan worked an average 58.9 hours per week, or 11.8 hours per day in a five-day work week.

According to the Labor Standards Law, the normal hours of work should not exceed eight per day, but can be extended by four hours to 12. The Ministry of the Interior has made it clear that for professional drivers, the time spent on standby duty should be included as part of their working hours.
Cheng said that although the two coach service companies allowed two to three hours of rest periods during a work day, there are no comfortable environments for them to rest properly.
"During their rest times, a coach driver needs to eat, clean the interior of the vehicle and have the fuel tank filled. Some drivers even have to wash their vehicles," he said.

Cheng said fines of between NT$6,000 and NT$60,000 for breaching the Labor Standards Law have failed to provide a deterrent to coach service operators who demand that their drivers work more than 12 hours a day.
He urged the government to examine the accident-causing practice of coach companies paying low basic salaries to drivers but offering them handsome bonuses for longer than normal working hours.
Taiwan has no strict laws governing the working hours of long-distance drivers.

In Europe, coach drivers must take a 45 minute break after four-and-a-half hours of continuous driving. That break can be split into two -- the first of 15 minutes and the second of 30 minutes. The maximum amount of driving per day is nine hours but this can be extended to 10 hours twice a week. Total weekly driving is limited to 56 hours per week or 90 hours per fortnight.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PETITION TO RETRIEVE KMT'S ILL-GOTTEN ASSETS PASSES THRESHOLD

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun delivered to the Central Election Commission (CEC) Thursday a petition signed by 1.4 million people endorsing a referendum proposal initiated by the party and several civic groups on forcing the opposition Kuomintang to return its ill-gotten assets to the national coffers.

Before delivering the petitions, Yu, who concurrently serves as the convener of an alliance seeking the retrieval of the ill-gotten assets, DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, DPP Legislator Trong Chai and World United Formosans for Independence Chairman Ng Chiau-tong attended a news conference during which they predicted that they will succeed in retrieving the assets improperly or illegally amassed by the KMT during its 55 years in power.
Yu said that despite some having had misgivings about collecting enough signatures to put the proposal to a national referendum, it has proved to be a success.

He claimed that this is the first referendum proposal launched by "the citizens, " instead of a top-down one. The proposal "has demonstrated the Taiwan people's resolve and will to retrieve the assets that belong to the nation," Yu added.
Hsieh said that in the past, the line between the ruling party and the nation was often blurred so that what should have been national assets actually lined the pockets of the KMT.
"Retrieving the KMT's ill-gotten assets is the wish of the Taiwan people and their common language," he claimed.
He also said that some opposition party members have suggested that the KMT return all its party assets, but said the party cannot follow through on this.
Yu, Hsieh and various supporters later chanted slogans and symbolically moved a carton of signatures to a container truck that went to the Executive Yuan to deliver them to the CEC.

Chang Yi-chan, deputy executive director of the DPP's Policy Committee, said that after the CEC receives the 1.4 million signatures, it will deliver them to local election commissions for verification. As long as there are more than 840,000 valid signatures, the CEC will have to promulgate the holding of a referendum on the proposal in between one and six months.
Taiwan held its first nationwide referendum alongside the presidential election in March 20, 2004 to vote on two questions proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.

A total of 45.17 percent of eligible voters cast their ballots in the first question in the referendum -- whether the country should strengthen its anti- missile defense ability -- and 45.12 percent voted on the second question -- whether the country should negotiate a peace framework with China. Both failed to reach the threshold of 50 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PETITION ON REFERENDUM ON GRAFT TO BE SENT TO CEC

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has countered a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) referendum proposal to retrieve the KMT's ill-gotten assets by proposing a referendum on corruption.

Huang Chung-hsien, director of the KMT's Organization and Operation Department, said Thursday that the party has been promoting its anti-graft referendum since last year. The second-stage name-collecting drive has obtained 1.1 million signatures so far, surpassing the threshold of 820,000 names for it to be put to a national vote.
Huang said the KMT will send the petition to the Central Election Commission for screening next Monday.

Under the Referendum Law, a valid referendum proposal must be put to a vote within six months, and Huang estimated that the vote on the anti-graft proposal can be held alongside the legislative elections slated for Jan. 12 next year.

KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung has said that faced with a series of corruption scandals surrounding the DPP administration, the KMT will mobilize the party to launch a referendum vote against corruption so as to retrieve the national assets it claims have been embezzled by the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUNE CONSUMER CONFIDENCE PICKS UP

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer confidence index (CCI) for June stood at 66.23, up 0.71 points from May's 65.52, which was the lowest of its kind since December 2001, indicating that consumers' confidence has regained a little from the previous month, according to the results of a survey released Thursday.

According to the survey, conducted by National Central University's Research Center for Taiwan Economic Development, three out of the six indicators used in the survey rose in June, with the "timing for investing in the stock market over the next six months" indicator registering the greatest increase, rising 4.30 points from May to stand at 82.70.

The "next six months' family financial status" indicator rose by 0.05 points to 51.55 from the May level, while the "next six months' employment opportunities" indicator also rose by 0.05 points to 72.30.

The "next six months' domestic consumer price" indicator remained unchanged for June at 32.60, while the "next six months' domestic economic outlook" indicator fell by 0.05 points to 45.80 and the "timing for buying durable goods over the next six months" indicator also dipped 0.05 points from the May level to 112.45.
According to the pollsters, only a CCI of between 100 and 200 would indicate that consumers are confident and optimistic about their economic and financial situations.
The survey, conducted via telephone June 20-22 among 2,270 adults around Taiwan, had a margin of error of 2.1 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS OF HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK HITS YEAR'S HIGH

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science Park reported Thursday that exports from the park totaled NT$54.15 billion (US$1.65 billion) in May, up 9.33 percent from the previous month and marking a single-month high so far this year.
The May figure also marked an increase of 14.41 percent over the year-earlier level, according to park administration.
Of the park's six major manufacturing sectors, the optoelectronics sector posted NT$20.71 billion-worth of exports, up a whopping 124.12 percent year-on- year.

Exports from the optoelectronics sector in May constituted 38.2 percent of the total exports from the park for that month, a record high and representing only 10.2 percentage points less than that posted by the semiconductor sector, which is the largest sector in the park, administration officials said.

Meanwhile, the semiconductor sector registered NT$26.22 billion-worth of exports in May, down 10.2 percent from the same month of the previous year. The sector's exports made up 48.4 percent of the total exports from the park in May.

Other sectors, including computer peripherals, communications and biotech, recorded declines in exports in May, down 23.36 percent, 7 percent and 63 percent, respectively, from the year-earlier levels.
Exports of the precision machinery sector in May, meanwhile, posted a year-on- year increase of 1.4 percent.
The park's exports stood at NT$239.64 billion in the first five months of this year, marking an increase of 5.91 percent from the corresponding period of 2006, park administration officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO CANOEISTS MISSING IN SEA CROSSING ATTEMPT

TEXT.P: Two canoeists in a nine-member team trying to cross the sea between the outlying island of Penghu and Chiayi County in Taiwan were still missing Thursday despite a full day's search by boats and helicopters.

Team leader Chang Tien-ming, 52, and Wu Chao-chang, 39, together with seven other team mates, were seen off early Thursday from Huhsi township by Penghu County Magistrate Wang Chien-fa and local villagers.
The canoeists, all members of the Penghu County Canoe Association, planned to spend about 12 hours crossing a 45-km stretch of water and to reach Tungshih township in Chiayi County before dark.
Two-and-a-half hours into to voyage, the team tried to regroup beside an islet but found that Chang and Wu were nowhere to be found.
A Coast Guard Administration (CGA) vessel watching the team at a distance picked up the remaining canoeists, who aborted the voyage and joined the vessel's crew for a search.
Three other CGA vessels, several fishing boats and three helicopters later joined the search but had to give up at dusk.
According to the CGA's unit in Penghu, an expanded search operation will be launched Friday, with assistance from some 10 vessels dispatched by CGA units on Taiwan's west coast.
Experienced canoeists in Penghu said that although they believed stamina would not be a problem for the team, the rough seas around Penghu, the tides and currents would have posed a grim challenge.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEFENDS REFERENDUM PLAN FOR KMT'S ILL-GOTTEN ASSETS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Thursday that it is the duty of the Executive Yuan to protect the nation's assets and added that the Cabinet will demand the return of ill-gotten party assets from the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to the national coffers.

Chang made the remarks after accepting 1.4 million signatures needed for the second phase of initiating a referendum on retrieval of the assets believed to have been siphoned off by the KMT into its coffers from the national treasury during the KMT's 55 years of authoritarian rule.

The signatures were presented by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, World United Formosans for Independence Chairman Ng Chiau-tong and Referendum Initiative Association Chairman Trong Chai.

Chang noted that he felt very moved to receive the signatures on behalf of the Cabinet because the referendum campaign was initiated by civic groups which are exercising their right to demand that the KMT return its ill-gotten party assets to the people and the country.

Describing the issue as not just the KMT's business, nor a fight between political parties, Chang said that whoever illegally possesses national assets, including the DPP, the Cabinet should reclaim them.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH RULES OUT IMPORTS OF BEEF WITH BONES

TEXT.P: A Department of Health (DOH) official said Thursday that without expert evaluation and approval, Taiwan will not import beef with bones from any country at present.

Cheng Hui-wen, director of the DOH Bureau of Food Sanitation, said the department decided recently to reopen Taiwan to imports of Canadian boneless beef from cattle under 30 months of age after prudent and scientific evaluation, but will not open Taiwan's doors to beef with bones from any country, including Canada or the United States.

Cheng made the remarks in response to a United Daily News report earlier that same day that the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) listed Taiwan May 28 as a country where the threat of Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) , or mad cow disease, is "under effective control" just like the U.S. and Canada.

The report has caused officials from the Council of Agriculture (COA) to worry that the U.S. and Canada might request Taiwan to open its doors to U.S. or Canadian beef with bones from cattle aged over 30 months on the grounds that Taiwan is at the same status as the U.S. and Canada in terms of mad cow disease control.
COA officials are worried that imports of beef with bones from cattle aged over 30 months could pose a threat to Taiwan's quarantine defense.

Cheng once again defended the DOH's decision to reopen Taiwan to imports of Canadian boneless beef from cattle under 30 months of age, saying that based on the average amount of beef consumed by the average Taiwanese, it would take 500 years for a Taiwanese to contract mad cow disease.

The Canadian government applied to the DOH in March 2004 for lifting the import ban and the DOH agreed to reopen Taiwan to Canadian beef imports with stringent restrictions June 23 after holding 11 rounds of consultative meetings with health experts in terms of BSE prevention measures unveiled by the World Health Organization and the OIE.
At present, Taiwan only allows beef imports from the United States, New Zealand, Australia and Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRTC LAUNCHES MAOKUNG CABLE CAR SOUVENIRS, COMMEMORATIVE TICKETS

TEXT.P: The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) launched a souvenir series and commemorative tickets Thursday for Taipei City's new Maokung cable car service in the tea-growing Mucha area, in association with the skyrail's inauguration slated for July 4.
According to a TRTC spokesman, the souvenir series contains 20 items in four categories, including accessories, stationery, collectibles and daily use articles.
The winner of the First Taipei Water Ink Exhibition, Tsai Yi-ju, was invited by TRTC to design the cover of the commemorative tickets to create artistic value for the tickets, the spokesman said.

The commemorative tickets will be sold for NT$399 (US$12.2) per set and the TRTC will issue only 1,399 sets. Each person can purchase only two sets of the tickets, which entitle passengers to ride the skyrail three times and gives unlimited MRT travel for a day.

The products will be sold at Taipei Metro souvenir shops, the Zoo Station on the Maokung cable car line, and on the TRTC's shopping Web site from July 4, the spokesman said, adding that there will be a provisional post office at the Zoo Station to provide mailing services and sell related postal products to passengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA ASKS OIE TO REVIEW TAIWAN'S MAD COW DISEASE RISK CLASSIFICATION

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) has asked the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) to review its stringent categorization of Taiwan as a country with "effective controlled risk" for mad cow disease, an official said Thursday.

As Taiwan has never had a case of mad cow disease, scientifically known as bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) , the official said the COA has asked the OIE to review its criteria and consider altering Taiwan's ranking.

According to the official, the OIE adopted a new classification system for BSE last year, which gauges only countries that have furnished the Paris-based world watchdog body for animal health with data and information on their domestic animal health situation for scrutiny.

Just 12 countries around the world have applied for classification of their BSE status, the official said, adding that five of them, including New Zealand and Australia, are recognized as having "negligible" risk of mad cow disease.

Taiwan and five other countries -- the United States, Canada, Switzerland, Chile and Brazil -- are ranked as having "controlled" risk of BSE, the official said, adding that the status of the 12th country is unclear.

Some opposition politicians have taken task with the government over the OIE's classifying Taiwan in the same category as the United States and Canada, where cases of mad cow disease have been reported.

They claimed that Taiwan's downgrading from BSE-free status to the same level as the United States and Canada is mainly because the Department of Health (DOH) has opened Taiwan to beef imports from the two countries under what they claimed is "political pressure."

Dismissing the opposition criticism as unwarranted, the official said the so- called "downgrading" is a wrong perception, since the new OIE BSE classification system has just been implemented for the first time.
As for linking Taiwan's ranking with its beef imports from the United States and Canada, the official claimed that such speculation is equally spurious and implausible.

Taiwan only allows imports of boneless beef from cattle under 30 months of age from the United States and Canada. According to the official, the OIE has excluded "boneless beef from cattle under 30 months of age" from any risk of spreading BSE.
According to the official, the OIE's classification of Taiwan as a "controlled risk" zone for BSE is probably connected with Taiwan's previous imports of bone powder from BSE-affected areas.
Even if the OIE rejects the COA's request to change Taiwan's status this time around, the official said, Taiwan will still apply for OIE classification next year.

Asked whether Taiwan's "controlled risk" status will prompt BSE-affected countries to pressure Taiwan to import their boneless beef from cattle under 30 months of age, the official said that is a question for the Department of Health (DOH) to consider. "I'm convinced that the DOH will never put local people's health at risk," he added.

BSE, which occurs in adult cattle, is one of a group of brain-wasting diseases (known as transmissible spongiform encephalopathies or TSEs) . Britain destroyed 3.7 million cattle in the 1980s and 1990s because of BSE, which has an incubation period of 3 to 5 years in cattle.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFERENCE ON CULTURE DIVERSITY HELD

TEXT.P: Academics from more than 10 countries are taking part in a two-day international conference on culture diversity under international trade regimes that started Thursday to discuss conflicts and difficulties between preserving cultural diversity and trade practices.

Taiwan is "rich in cultural diversity as it has been ruled by Spanish and Dutch" and is currently facing the challenge of globalization at a time when it is working hard toward developing a cultural creative industry, said Minister of Council of Cultural Affairs (CCA) Wong Chin-chu in her opening remarks.

On Oct. 20, 2005, the UNESCO General Assembly adopted the Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expression (CCD), which became effective March 18 this year. Taiwan has been paying great attention to the convention although it is not a U.N. member, Wong said.

The debate between preserving cultural diversity and international trade practices has been going on in Geneva, where the World Trade Organization (WTO) headquarters are located, said Deng Chen-chung, chief negotiator of Taiwan's Office of Trade Negotiations who was based in Geneva in his previous job.

In most countries, trade and cultural officials do not talk to each other often, Deng said, adding that even in Geneva, representatives from different countries know very little about the UNESCO convention.
"Currently, the WTO is not equipped to handle this issue, " he said, urging a mechanism between the WTO and UNESCO and clearer rules of the convention to be set up.

A total of 16 theses will be presented at the conference, and new rules to address cultural policy issues within the WTO framework in future trade negotiations will be explored. The participants are from New Zealand, Canada, India, Israel, Germany, South Korea, Hong Kong, France, the U.K., the U.S. and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKERS, EMPLOYERS MIXED ON BASIC WAGE HIKE: POLL

TEXT.P: In the face of an imminent hike in the minimum monthly salary from July 1, most workers and employers, unsurprisingly, have opposite viewpoints of the change, according to the results of a poll released Thursday.

Some 56 percent of companies surveyed are opposed to the hike, in contrast to as high as 68 percent of part-time workers who favor the increase, according to the Internet poll conducted by the 1111 Job Bank.

After lengthy negotiations, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) came up with a final decision last month to raise the hourly pay for part-timers from NT$66, in place since 1997, to NT$95 -- marking a rise of nearly 44 percent. The change is expected to benefit some 1.41 million workers, CLA officials said.

The survey also discovered that 24 percent of the companies questioned agreed with the government's minimum monthly salary adjustment. At the same time, 54 percent of part-timers responding to the poll voiced concern that they might lose their jobs as a result of the increase.

According to the survey, the medicine, farming and husbandry sectors employ the largest ratio of workers (66.7 percent of the total) who receive a basic monthly salary, followed by the sector related to daily consumption (65.7 percent) and traditional manufacturing (50.9 percent).

Questioned about what would be impacted the most by the hike, 72.6 percent of the businesses polled said they are most concerned about rising costs in health insurance premiums and retirement pensions, ahead of 69.9 percent and 45.8 percent that cited growing costs in workers' wages and ensuing declines in business earnings, respectively.

Asked what would be the main effect on society, 69.9 percent of small enterprises said the rise in the basic wage will increase operating difficulties for them. Some 57.4 percent expressed worry that it will worsen the jobless rate, while 51.8 percent said some companies might slash the number of their part-time workers.
The local job bank conducted the cyber survey June 14-27, collecting 432 valid questionnaires.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG DANCE TROUPE, AMERICAN COUNTERPARTS TO PERFORM IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Dance students from Tsoying Senior High School (TSHS) in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung and the Miami-based New World School of the Arts (NWSA) will stage a two-day joint performance at the Kaohsiung school beginning Friday, TSHS Principal Lin Chuan-yi said Thursday.
Students from NWSA's Department of Dance, led by department director Daniel Lewis, arrived in Kaohsiung earlier this week for a rehearsal Wednesday with the TSHS dance students, Lin said.
Since Kaohsiung and Miami established sister city ties in 1987, the two schools have engaged in extensive exchanges, Lin said.
Thus far, Lin continued, scores of TSHS graduates have pursued undergraduate studies at the NWSA.

A group of TSHS dance students and their NWSA counterparts staged a joint performance at Colony Theater in Miami earlier this month, attracting many Taiwanese expatriates and American nationals to admire their artistry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO DRUG PUSHERS SENTENCED TO LIFE

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court sentenced two drug pushers to life in prison Thursday, although their profits from four heroin deals totaled only NT$9,000 (US$273).
The court meted out the harsh sentences to Liu Pin-hung, 37, and Hsu June-hui, 41, for their repeated crimes in violation of the Statute for Narcotics Hazard Prevention.
The two men were caught peddling heroin-laced cigarettes in late November last year and early January this year.
Police said the two pushers bought heroin from a man in Taipei County's Panchiao City and used it to make heroin cigarettes for sale to prostitutes.
Although the two men netted only NT$9,000 through four deals, the judge ruled that their continuous criminal acts amounted to aggravated offenses and merited life imprisonment.
Liu and Hsu can appeal their sentences to the Taiwan High Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP AGAINST REFERENDUM ON DPP-DRIVEN U.N. BID

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) voiced Thursday its objections to the government's plan to pursue U.N. membership for the country under the name of "Taiwan, " describing the issue as nothing more than an election gambit maneuvered by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Chang Hsien-yao, a PFP lawmaker and director of the PFP's Policy Research Center, made the remarks in a news conference as an Executive Yuan panel is set to screen the issue Friday and come out with a final decision on whether it should be put to a referendum for the public to vote on alongside the 2008 presidential election.

Describing the planned move as a DPP scheme aimed at "rigging" a national election, Chang claimed that holding a referendum on Taiwan's U.N. cause at the same time as the presidential election will violate the "four noes" pledge made by President Chen Shui-bian in his 2000 and 2004 inauguration speeches.
The United States and Japan also oppose the DPP's referendum plan for the same reason, he pointed out.

Apart from that, such a referendum would be illegal and unconstitutional and would greatly undermine national security and interests, he said, adding that his party is firmly opposed to holding the referendum.

PFP lawmaker Lee Fu-dien suggested that the DPP administration first carry out constitutional amendments to change the country's official designation to "Taiwan" before it seeks to join the United Nations under that name.

Hu Chu-ching, a PFP member and a member at the Executive Yuan's public referendum screening panel, expressed concern over a possible negative response from the DPP, saying that the DPP might file an administrative petition in an attempt to overrule the panel's final decision if its vote outcome runs counter to the ruling party's stance.

Last year, the Appeals Review Committee under the Executive Yuan, without prior approval from the screening panel, ruled on its own that a DPP proposal on holding a public referendum to ask the Kuomintang (KMT) to return its ill-gotten assets to the state is lawful, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSING HUA UNIVERSITY TO START OVERSEAS VOLUNTEER PROGRAM

TEXT.P: National Tsing Hua University (NTHU) in Hsinchu City is set to launch its first ever international volunteer program from July 4 to Sept. 2 aimed at offering overseas service opportunities for university students, a school spokesman said Thursday.

Under the program, 31 students from around the country will go aboard to serve as volunteers in Chitwan, a mountainous area of Nepal, Medan and Banda Aceh cities in Indonesia, Qinghai Province in China and the Malaysian capital of Kuala Lumpur, according to the spokesman.
A voluntary service delegation comprised of eight students from

NTHU and six from the Taichung-based National Taiwan College of Physical Education, will first depart for the Nepali capital of Kathmandu to assist a Taiwanese medical mission, and will hold a three-week summer camp for secondary and elementary school students in the area July 4-Aug. 15, the spokesman said, adding that some 400 students have so far enrolled in the camp.

Eight NTHU students, in conjunction with staff of a community college in Hsinchu City, will later launch information courses on teacher training in the two Indonesian cities from July 10-24 with the goal of lessening the global digital divide.

An activity slated for July 20-Aug. 5 in Qinghai will bring together 55 students from both the Taiwanese and Chinese Tsing Hua universities as well as several other universities of the two sides to offer English and basic science courses to students at two middle schools in the northwestern Chinese province.

In addition, another NTHU volunteer group under the auspices of the National Youth Commission and the Overseas Compatriots Affairs Commission is scheduled to head for Malaysia in mid-August to offer supplementary curricula for students at a Taiwanese school in Malaysia Aug. 12-Sept. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: `NO DOWNGRADING OF SOVEREIGNTY' KEY TO OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY: MAC

TEXT.P: Whether Taiwan will take part in the 2008 Olympic torch relay hinges on respect for Taiwan's sovereignty, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Thursday.
Chen made the remarks a day after Beijing began to address Taiwan with its official title of "Chinese Taipei" used in the International Olympic Committee (IOC).
In preparation for the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Chinese officials had until Wednesday referred to Taiwan as "China Taipei" in an attempt to underline its sovereignty claim over Taiwan.
A Chinese official finally addressed Taiwan by its IOC-sanctioned title Wednesday only after the IOC wielded its clout, Chen said.
According to a formal agreement reached between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in 1989, China should have addressed Taiwan as "Chinese Taipei" from the very beginning.
From now on, Chen said, China should never again violate the 1989 cross-strait IOC agreement on Taiwan's moniker or designation.

As to whether Taiwan will join the Olympic torch relay, Chen said the core issue lies in sovereignty. Taiwan will consider allowing the torch onto Taiwanese soil only when its sovereign status is not downgraded.

On April 26, Taiwan rejected a China-proposed torch relay route that would have had the flame arriving in Taiwan from Vietnam April 30, 2008, and going on to China-controlled Hong Kong and Macau. The arrangement made Taiwan appear to be the start of China's domestic route for the torch relay. Taiwan's bottom line on the issue is that the torch should enter and exit the island via a third country, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH AUSTRALIAN NOBEL LAUREATE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian encouraged Taiwan people, particularly young academics, to learn from visiting Dr. Barry Marshall, who won the 2005 Nobel Prize in medicine.

Receiving Marshall at the Presidential Office, Chen expressed his admiration for the Australian physician-scholar's outstanding academic achievements in proving that the bacteria Helicobacter pylori is the cause of most stomach ulcers, reversing decades of medical doctrine which held that ulcers were caused by stress, spicy foods, and too much acid.

Noting that Marshall comes from a working class family in a small mining town in inland western Australia, Chen said Marshall has created the greatest possibility with limited resources under unfavorable circumstances.
"I look forward to seeing young Taiwan people draw inspiration from Marshall's success story, " Chen said, adding that he hopes Taiwan can nurture a Nobel Prize-winning medical expert in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 29, or the 15th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
48 B.C.: Julius Caesar defeats his brother-in-law and former ally Pompey at Pharsallus and thus becomes absolute ruler of Rome.
1880: France formally annexes the Pacific island of Tahiti (or Otaheite).
1911: Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands is born. He is the husband of Queen Juliana and a founder of the World Wildlife Fund.
1920: China joins the League of Nations.
1928: Peking is renamed Peiping.
1932: A group of Thais revolt against King Prajadhipok, forcing the king to change the government from an absolute monarchy to a constitutional monarchy, thus limiting the power of the king.
1944: China and Japan begin a major battle at Hengyang, a city in Hunan province, with Japanese troops using poisonous mustard gas in their attack.
1953: More than 1,400 mainland Chinese prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland write a blood letter to Presdient Chiang Kai- shek, asking him to allow them to go to Taiwan to join the Republic of China's armed forces.
1954: A total of 1,735 diamonds, with a total weight of 368.17 carats, are shipped to Taipei. The diamonds were stolen by the Japanese in mainland China during World War II.
1966: American planes bomb Hanoi and Haiphong for the first time in the Vietnam War.
1972: The US Supreme Court rules that the death penalty is unconstitutional.
1974: The ROC government announces the suspension of diplomatic relations with Venezuela, which recognized the Chinese communist regime.
1974: The 6th National Little League Baseball Tournament ends with the Li Teh team from Kaohsiung City designated to represent the ROC in the Asian playoffs.
1978: The ROC government approves a commercial agreement between flagship- carrier China Airlines and Cargo Lux and Lux Air of Luxembourg. The agreement makes it possible for CAL to extend its flight service to Europe.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo promulgates the new Commissioned and Noncommissioned Statute of the Armed Forces and the new Entertainment Tax Law.
1981: Hu Yaobang takes over as chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, succeeding Hua Guofeng.
1982: Premier Sun Yun-suan receives Richard Allen, senior counselor for foreign policy to the Republican National Committee of the United States.
1984: The Legislative Yuan approves the long-awaited and controversial Genetic Health Law, or Eugenics Bill, after a third reading.
1986: Argentina wins the World Cup soccer title again in Mexico, thanks to Diego Maradona, 25, who was directly or indirectly responsible for all the goals in the championship game.
1992: Mohamed Boudiaf, president of Algeria, is assassinated as he opens a cultural center in Annaba.
1994: The Peruvian Trade Office opens in Taipei.
1995: A department store collapses in Seoul, South Korea, killing 450 people and injuring 922 others.
1999: The ROC wins the right to host the annual global Information Technology conference in Taipei from June 12 to 14, 2000.
2000: Taiwan-based China Airlines signs an agreement with eight other regional airlines to establish a Pan-Asia Travel Portal website by the end of this year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man has only to watch over every minute detail connected with his daily life, not only of conduct and bearing, but even in minor details of dress, so as to produce an effect upon the public mind, which, without these influences, could only have been produced by fear."

DOC.HEADLINE: MISSING PENGHU KAYAKERS FOUND

TEXT.P: Two ocean kayakers who had gone missing during a sea journey from the outlying island of Penghu were found safe and sound Friday, rescuers said.

While Wu Chao-chen was sent back to Makung at 6: 30 a.m. after he was discovered by members of the coast guard, Chang Tien-ming was found at 7: 15 a.m. near Wangkung, Changhua County, by an Air Force helicopter and later airlifted to a Taichung airbase.
The pair were among a nine-member sea kayaking team who set off early Thursday from Penghu for a journey across the Taiwan Strait.
The team had planned to spend 12 hours crossing a 45-km stretch of water and to reach Chiayi County's Tungshih township before dark.
However, Chang and Wu were nowhere to be found when the team tried to regroup near an islet two-and-a-half hours into the voyage.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'HSICHIH TRIO' GET DEATH SENTENCE (UPDATE-1)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court handed down death sentences Friday for the three convicts in a brutal murder case in Hsichih, Taipei County in 1991 known locally as "Hsichih Trio, " marking a dramatic about-face on the court's 2003 acquittal ruling.
The three defendants -- Su Chien-ho, Chuang Lin-hsun and Liu Ping-lang -- can appeal against the latest ruling.
Each of the "Hsichih Trio" was given two death sentences in a third and final instance Feb. 9, 1995 after being convicted of robbery and brutal killing of Wu Ming-han and his wife March 24, 1991.

The country's then-top prosecutor repeatedly filed special appeals with the Supreme Court for retrial, but the appeals were all rejected. After many twists and turns, the Taiwan High Court finally approved in May 2000 an application by the trio's lawyer for a rare retrial of the case.

After more than two years of retrial, the high court acquitted the three men in January 2003 on the grounds that there were not sufficient evidence to prove the defendants' involvement in the brutal slaying of the couple.

In March that year, the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office appealed against the ruling and five months later, the Supreme Court revoked the "acquittal" ruling and demanded that the high court retry the case. The debate session ended May 18, 2007 and the panel of judges dealing with the case gave their verdict Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE TO FOUR TYPHOONS LIKELY TO HIT TAIWAN THIS YEAR: CWB

TEXT.P: Three to four typhoons are likely to hit Taiwan this year, close to the average number of 3.1, Central Weather Bureau (CWB) officials forecast Friday.

According to Wu Teh-jung, director of the CWB's Weather Forecast Center, for several consecutive years, the number of tropical cyclones forming in the northwestern Pacific Ocean has been below average.

With the trend expected to continue this year, the number of tropical cyclones likely to form in the northwestern Pacific Ocean is projected to range between 23 and 25, compared with the 50-year average of 26.7, Wu said.
CWB tallies show that damage caused by typhoons and heavy rain amounts to more than NT$17 billion per year on average, accounting for 85 percent of all damage due to climatic disasters.
CWB officials urged the public to take proper precautions ahead of the typhoon season and pay attention to typhoon information released by the bureau.
On this summer's weather, the officials predicted that it will be hotter than average, as it has been over the past several years.
Over the past 30 years, between July and September, an average of 18.3 days have seen temperatures rise above 35 degrees Celsius, according to CWB tallies.
However, between 1997 and 2006, there were many years in which the number of sultry days was higher than average, CWB officials said.
The number of days with a temperature of higher than 35 degrees Celsius totalled 44 in 2003, 37 in 1998, 36 in 2002, 33 in 2006, 30 in 2001, 29 in 2005 and 28 in 2004, they said.

During the 1997-2006 period, only three years saw a below average number of days with temperatures over 35 degrees Celsius: 1997, with five days; 1999, with 12 days; and 2000, with 17 days, they added.
