DOC.HEADLINE: RETRIAL OF 'HSICHIH TRIO' TURNED AROUND

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court (THC) handed down death sentences for the "Hsichih Trio, " Friday, reversing a "not guilty" verdict announced in January 2003 due to a lack of evidence.
The High Court panel handed down death sentences for Su Chien-ho, Liu Bing-lang and Chuang Lin-hsun -- known locally as the "Hsichih Trio" -- on charges of robbery and intentional murder.
The trio, who were incarcerated for 16 years on death row before being released in January 2003, are eligible to appeal the latest ruling.

High Court spokesman Wen Yao-yuan said during a news conference Friday that the judges decided to give death sentences to the trio based on the testimony of the fourth man, Wang Wen-hsiao, who implicated the other three as accomplices; results of cross-examination of the trio's confessions; and the results of investigations by the Institute of Forensic Medicine, Ministry of Justice of a kitchen knife that the attackers used on the victims.

Wen also said that the panel of judges discounted as "mere speculation" the opinions given by U.S.-based forensic scientist Henry Lee, who said in early May that based on photos of the crime scene he does not exclude the possibility that a single attacker was responsible for the double murder and rape.
According to Lee, given the different depths and angles of wounds on the two victims, a single kitchen knife could have produced all of the cuts, stab wounds and hacks.
The case stems from the March 24, 1991 robbery and murder of Wu Ming-han and his wife Yeh Ying-lan, who were found dead in their Hsichih, Taipei County, apartment. They had been stabbed 79 times.

Five months after the slayings, police arrested Wang Wen-hsiao, later known as the fourth accomplice. Police believed that Wang and three other men gang-raped Wu's wife before killing her with a kitchen knife taken from the kitchen.

Wang, who was a soldier at the time, was executed in 1992 after being sentenced to death by a military court. The other three, tried in civil court, were convicted of robbery, murder and rape and also sentenced to death. By 1995 the Hsichih Trio had exhausted all their legal appeals.

However, then-State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Han, was unsure of their guilt, and acting within his power as the state's chief prosecutor, made three appeals to the Supreme Court to retry the case. The high court rejected each of his motions, but in May 2000 the Taiwan High Court approved an application by the trio's lawyer for a rare retrial of the case.

In the ensuing retrial, the Taiwan High Court found that the defendants' confessions contained differing accounts of the events, including the time, motive, individual actions, and how the spoils from the robbery were to have been split up.

In January 2003, following two years and 31 hearings, the high court acquitted the three men on the grounds that there was insufficient evidence to prove the defendants' involvement in the brutal slaying of the couple.

In March of the same year, the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office appealed the High Court's ruling, and in August the Supreme Court revoked the "acquittal" ruling, saying that the Taiwan High Court judges had evaluated evidence in the case in defiance of time-tested rules, defied logic, failed to observe legal guidelines and had not done a thorough investigation into the case before rendering a verdict. The Supreme Court then demanded that the high court retry the case.

In the retrial in May this year, a prosecutor said the three defendants could have given confessions differing in the details of their accounts due to the prolonged delay between trials over the years, but claimed that truth and fact should not be overturned simply because of "trivial differences" in the defendants' verbal accounts.

Meanwhile, the trio's lawyer Su You-chen argued via a written statement in May that it is unacceptable and unjustifiable that the police should find that the trio were Wang's accomplices solely on the strength of the prosecutors' belief that it was "impossible for a sole predator to stab two persons 79 times."
The High Courts' latest hearings ended May 18, 2007. The panel of judges dealing with the case handed down their verdict Friday.
Upon hearing the latest ruling, a tearing Su Chien-ho, one of the trio, said he will appeal until his name is cleared because he did not do it.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD SEEK TO REJOIN U.N. IN MORE PRAGMATIC WAY: KMT HOPEFUL

TEXT.P: Allowing the Republic of China on Taiwan to re-enter the United Nations and other world bodies is a goal that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has long sought to achieve, KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.

That goal, however, should be pursued in a pragmatic manner with a flexible strategy, Ma said, adding that using a particular name in the U.N. bid, without giving thought to the possible consequences, may make people think there are political motives at work.

Ma was referring to President Chen Shui-bian's announcement earlier this year that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration will seek to have Taiwan rejoin the U.N. and other world organizations under the name "Taiwan."

Commenting on the United States' opposition to the DPP's plans to use a nationwide referendum to facilitate Taiwan's U.N. bid, Ma said he is not at all surprised that Washington opposes the DPP plans because the U.S. government has consistently been opposed to Taiwan's endeavors to join the U.N. under the name "Taiwan."
Ma said no individual or country has been able to represent Taiwan since 1971 when the ROC was forced to drop out of the U.N. after the U.N. gave the China seat to the People's Republic of China.
That was the reason why the KMT, Taiwan's ruling party until 2000, has ceaselessly sought to enable the ROC to re-enter the U.N., Ma said.

Ma stressed that he does not oppose the DPP's pushing for a referendum on seeking re-entry to U.N. and other world bodies, but believes firmly that the approach should be pragmatic and flexible, adding that in the end, participation is what really matters, not the name.

Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who was once a vice chairman of the KMT, said he agrees that Taiwan should seek to re-enter the U.N., and that there should be flexibility and negotiations on the name.
Wang added that the KMT's pushing for a "U.N. referendum" to be held in tandem with the 2008 presidential election will certainly be conducive to Ma's election.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER FORUM FOR DIPLOMATIC ALLIES TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 22th Forum of Speakers of the Legislative Bodies of the Central American and Caribbean Basin is scheduled to take place in Taipei July 2-4, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday.

Legislative speakers from Taiwan's six diplomatic allies Dominica, El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala, Panama, and Belize, as well as three vice speakers, will travel to Taiwan to attend the forum, according to Wang.
The speaker and vice speaker of Costa Rica, which broke off relations with Taiwan earlier this month, will not join the conference, Wang added.
Taiwan became an observer at the biannual forum in 1999, and first hosted the forum in Taipei in 2000, Wang noted, saying this is the second time that Taiwan has organized the event.

On July 2, Wang is slated to accompany the visiting speakers and vice speakers to visit President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, followed by a tour to the Hsinchu Science Park and a journey to Danshui in the northern county of Taipei later in the evening.

Wang said that the forum, to be held in Taipei, will help alleviate the mounting concern that Costa Rica's departure might have a domino effect on Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central and Southern America, and that it will further consolidate Taiwan's bonds of friendship with those countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved down 30 points to close at 8,808, with 41,445 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for August closed unchanged at 8,766, with 772 contracts traded, while September futures dropped one point to close at 8,733, with 204 contract transactions. December futures lost 31 points to close at 8,738, with 78 contracts traded, while March futures moved down 19 points to finish at 8,750, with none contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 8,838 for July, 8,766 for August, 8,734 for September, 8,769 for December and 8,769 for March.
Trade in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

July TE futures rose 0.7 points to close at 379.55, with 3,029 contracts traded, while August TE futures lost 0.1 points to finish at 376.75, with 27 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 3.05 points to close at 379.7, with one contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for any other months.

July TF futures moved down 10 points to close at 1,035, with 3,571 contracts traded, while August TF futures lost 11 points to finish at 1,029, with 131 contract transactions. September TF futures dropped 9.6 points to close at 1,032, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for any other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMITTEE REJECTS DPP INITIATIVE FOR REFERENDUM ON TAIWAN'S U.N. BID

TEXT.P: The Cabinet's referendum review committee turned down Friday the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) initiative to hold a referendum on the country's bid to apply to the United Nations under the name "Taiwan."
Committee chairman Kao Yung-kuang said the initiative was voted down 12-8 because the majority of committee members found that the initiative is invalid.

In objecting to the plan, some committee members argued that such a referendum is unnecessary as pushing for the country's inclusion in the United Nations is a policy already adopted by the government, according to Kao.

Other members mentioned that the United Nations is an organization where statehood is required for membership and that the country will need to amend its constitution to change its official name from "Republic of China" to "Republic of Taiwan" before it can apply to the United Nations under the name "Taiwan, " Kao said.
The initiative, sponsored by approximately 90,000 people, was submitted May 21 to the Central Election Commission (CEC) , where it underwent a preliminary screening.
The case was then forwarded to the referendum review committee, which held a hearing June 22, at which DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun was invited to brief the committee on the initiative.

The DPP hopes to have a referendum on the bid held alongside the 2008 presidential election in order to "make the world aware of Taiwan's 23 million people's desire to join the United Nations, " despite opposition from the United States.

Taiwan, which failed in its first attempt to gain membership in the WHO under the name "Taiwan" in May, is planning to apply a similar approach to apply for U.N. membership in September, despite the almost certain prospect of failure.

Officials at the U.S. State Department have reiterated that the United States does not support Taiwan's membership in international organizations that require statehood and that Washington "opposes any initiative that appears designed to change Taiwan's status unilaterally, " including a referendum on whether to apply to the United Nations under the name "Taiwan."
Also, the officials said the planned referendum would appear to run counter to President Chen Shui-bian's repeated commitments to the United States.

However, President Chen Shui-bian claims the U.N. bid and referendum plan do not violate his commitments but are aimed at maintaining the status quo and the basic human rights of the Taiwanese people.

Chen pledged during his 2000 and 2004 inaugural addresses that if China has no intention of using force against Taiwan, he will not declare Taiwan independence, will not change the official name of the country, will not include the "state-to-state" concept on cross-Taiwan Strait relations in the Constitution and will not promote a referendum to change the cross-strait status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.101 to close at NT$32.735.
A total of US$1.04 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.785 and fluctuated between NT$32.720 and NT$32.880.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG'S 'LOVE BOAT' CRUISE SERVICES SUFFER FROM DEFICITS

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government is considering raising ticket prices for the "Love Boats" plying the Love River, which passes through the port city and is one of the most popular tourist attractions in southern Taiwan, city officials said Friday.

The city government also plans to recall the right to sell tickets from private operators of the ferries, and to extend the cruise route in efforts to cut down on the deficits that it has suffered since the service began in May 2004.

There are 15 ferries servicing sightseeing cruises on the Love River. Although the service attracts tourists and generates a turnover of NT$18 million (US$546,860) a year, that income is still insufficient to cover the costs of fuel and outsourcing management.

Love Boat cruises attract some 410,000 passengers each year, with an average passenger occupancy of 1,190 people per day. The current cost of a single-trip ticket is NT$50 for adults, and NT$25 for children.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL BANK TO OPEN LIAISON OFFICE IN INDIA

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission recently approved an application by Mega International Commercial Bank Co. (ICBC) to set up a liaison office in Mumbai, India, an ICBC executive said Thursday.
The Cabinet-level commission also approved the ICBC's request to establish a branch bank in Pnom-Penh, Cambodia, the executive said.

The ICBC's decision to set up the liaison office in Mumbai is driven by a desire to collect business information and gain a better understanding of the needs of Taiwan business people investing in the Central Asian country, while its determination to set up the branch bank in Pnom-Penh is aimed at establishing a network for the improvement of the business services it offers Taiwanese businesses based in Cambodia, Vietnam and China, as well as expanding the overall scope of its business in Southeast Asia, the executive said.
Currently, the ICBC has a total of 28 overseas offices, including 18 branch offices, two liaison offices and two subsidiary banks, the executive noted.

At present, the First Bank is the only local bank which has a branch bank in Cambodia, while the China Trust Bank is the only bank which has a branch bank in New Delhi, India, according to the executive.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange were lower Friday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 9.62 points to close at 8,883.21.
The bourse opened at 8,932.18 and fluctuated between 8,932.95 and 8,849.04 during trading. A total of 5.46 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$153.82 billion (US$4.68 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 0.9 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.5 percent, construction issues at 0.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent, and textile stocks at 0.1 percent.

The three other major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 0.5 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 682 to 554, while 196 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN REFERENDUM COMMITTEE MEMBERS RESIGN AFTER INITIATIVE REJECTED

TEXT.P: Seven of a 21-member referendum review committee of the Executive Yuan resigned Friday after the committee turned down an initiative proposed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to hold a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan.

The seven are: Chen Chi-mai, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office; Chiang Kai-shih, a former Taipei city councilor; Hsu Yung-ming, a researcher with Academia Sinica; Lo Chih-cheng, executive director of the Institute for National Policy Research; and DPP supporters Lee Ming-chun, Huang Yu-lin and Tsai Hsien-hao.

The committee rejected the DPP-proposed U.N. referendum initiative for a variety of reasons, mainly because the administration has already been pushing for Taiwan's application to join the U.N. and because a set policy need not to be determined again by the people via a nationwide referendum.

Announcing the resignations, Chiang said that allowing the people to take part in a referendum is a primary reflection that a democratic country's sovereignty lies with the people, adding that no government, political party or individual has the authority to deny the people's right to take part in referendums.
Chiang said the committee's rejection of the DPP initiative was unconstitutional, illegal and runs counter to the democratic principle that a country's sovereign right lies with the people.
He said the committee's decision is unacceptable to the seven members, who in turn decided to quit the committee in an effort to express their "responsibility to history."
Earlier in the day, committee Chairman Kao Yung-kuang said the DPP initiative was voted down 12-8 because the majority of the committee members decided that the initiative is invalid.

DOC.HEADLINE: `SPECIAL AFFAIRS' TRIAL PROCEEDS BEHIND CLOSED DOORS: JUDGE

TEXT.P: The presiding judge handling trial of a case involving alleged misuse of President Chen Shui-bian's "special affairs funds" ruled Friday that the trial will proceed in private from now on.

Tsai Shou-hsun, head of the panel of judges, announced the decision after President Chen asked the Taipei District Court the day before to return confidential documents and other records that prosecutors took from his office to use as evidence in the "special affairs" embezzlement trial in which first lady Wu Shu-jen is a defendant.

Chen made the request in a letter addressed to the District Court and the presiding judge in terms of a constitutional interpretation issued by the Council of Grand Justices June 15, which confirmed the president's constitutional right to decide what is a state secret and his right to refuse to disclose it.

According to a Presidential Office press statement issued late Thursday, the documents Chen asked the court to return include invoices he used to justify reimbursement of expenditure from his "special affairs fund" between January 2000 and June of last year.

Chen also asked the court to return other documents and data, including electromagnetic records related to the case, based on his concerns that the nation's interests and safety could be affected by any leak of information contained in the files.
Prosecutors Eric Chen and Chou Shih-yu indicted Wu, along with three former and incumbent presidential aides, last November on separate charges of embezzlement, forgery and perjury.

The indictment accuses Wu of submitting invoices or receipts obtained from other people to claim reimbursement on a portion of the "special affairs funds" set aside for the president's discretionary use.
Chen defended the action on the grounds that he had to use other people's invoices to claim reimbursement from the "special affairs funds" because he used the money for "secret diplomatic missions."

The Presidential Office press statement also took issue with what it described as the court's "failure to protect the confidentiality of the documents, " saying that the judicial personnel in charge of the case failed to abide by their promise to keep the evidence from being publicized.

According to the constitutional interpretation delivered by 13 grand justices unanimously June 15, the president has the privilege to keep classified information concerning national security, national defense and diplomacy under wraps if he determines that disclosure could compromise national interests and security.

The grand justices further said that the presidential immunity includes the right to refuse to give testimony or produce evidence for that purpose in court. As to information the president has already provided to the court, he can still declare it to be classified information according to the law and the court should follow the law regarding classified information when such information is used in a trial.

Since the testimony given by the president and the information collected by the judiciary with regard to the "special affairs fund" case were related to his exercise of power granted by the Constitution, the Presidential Office press statement said the president is requesting the return of all those documents and records.

The district court continued court proceedings Friday, summoning defendants and witnesses for questioning. As in the past, the wheelchair-bound first lady applied for leave of absence, citing health reasons.

A district court spokesman said the panel of judges will decide whether to return the documents and records to the Presidential Office after listening to opinions presented by prosecutors and defendants and their lawyers.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREE OVERNIGHT BEACH PARTY JUNE 30 AT CHINSHAN

TEXT.P: Cube Production, a promotion company selling outdoor activities and concerts, will hold an overnight beach party from Saturday afternoon at Chusha Bay in Taipei County's Chinshan township -- about 40 minutes drive from downtown Taipei.
According to organizers, admission is free but participants cannot bring glass bottles to the beach and will be required to take one bag of trash with them when they leave the party.
This is the sixth consecutive year Cube Production has organized a large-scale outdoor dance concert at a beach resort.
Called "Summer Aquarium 2007, " the beach party will begin at 3 p.m. Saturday and last until 4 a.m. Sunday. Participants can enjoy the sunshine, the beach, live music, dancing, swimming and surfing.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE DIPSUTES ACCUSATION OF ALLOWING IN CHINESE WORKERS

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), reiterated Friday that he has never called for opening Taiwanese jobs to Chinese workers, and urged his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rival to stop making false accusations in this regard.
Ma made the comments during a 40-minute seminar with nearly 100 laborer representatives to hear from the file and rank.

In response to local workers' grave concern over whether Chinese workers would be allowed to work in Taiwan, Ma said that he has never made such a proposal and urged Frank Hsieh, DPP presidential candidate, not to continue leveling incorrect charges against him.
Speaking of the entry of foreign laborers, Ma opined that workers and the business community should negotiate to find a solution acceptable to both sides.

"But I have never called for an opening to Chinese workers, " he asserted, then added, "However, I do agree that Taiwan should catch up with the trends and open to Chinese tourists now that Taiwanese tourists make some 4 million visits to China each year."
"Attracting a large number of Chinese tourists to Taiwan will be one of my priorities if elected president in the 2008 election, " he said.
Regarding investment by Taiwanese companies in China, he said that he favors the free movement of capital, but would impose controls on exports of advanced technology.

Ma also reiterated his promise to set up direct transport, trade and postal links with China, saying that putting such services in place will effectively help the many Taiwan businessmen traveling between the two sides better overcome their family, economic and operational difficulties arising from the lack of such direct links.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAPER WINDMILL THEATRE INVITES PEOPLE TO JOIN ART PROJECT PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: The Paper Windmill Theatre, a local drama group, invited people to join a performance of its art project called "Art Project for Kids in 319 Townships -- First Mile Kid's Smile" aimed at presenting performances to children in remote areas financed with donations from the public, an executive of the troupe said Thursday.

The Paper Windmill Culture Foundation held a news conference Thursday to introduce its recruitment program that invited people aged over 18 willing to spend two days per month making changes for such children, to sign up for auditions.

Former Premier Tsai Ying-wen, National Youth Commission Chairwoman Cheng Li- chun and Mandarin Daily News Chief Editor Feng Chi-mei attended the news conference to promote the program, initiated by the foundation's executive director, Lee Yung-feng.

According to Luo Pei-an, supervisor of the foundation, the troupe started the project's first performance in Yilan County's Yuanshan township last December and has staged 29 performances for nearly 56,00 children in just six months.
The troupe performs when donations to the township for the performance reaches NT$350,000 (US$10,692) . Children do not pay to see the show, Luo said.
Without government subsidies, the project relies on donations from the public, Luo said, adding that the project has already received donations of more than NT$27 million from 4,384 contributors.

The troupe also initiated another activity in association with the art project in which 30 percent of the funds raised at each performance of the troupe are used to buy copies of the Mandarin Daily News for local schools, in order to encourage students to read, Luo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUANTAN ECOLOGICAL PARK ON ALISHAN TO OPEN IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Construction of the Yuantan Ecological Park in the Alishan National Scenic Area is near completion and the park is scheduled to open to tourists in October, a local tourism official announced Friday.

Chung Fu-sung, director of the Alishan National Scenic Area Administration, made the announcement at a press conference held upon the completion of the Yuantan Ecological Park's visitor service center.

According to Chung, the ecological park provides rich resources for outdoor teaching to schoolchildren because it is home to 45 bird species, six kinds of fish, 15 frog species, 25 species of fireflies, over 100 kinds of butterflies and more than 200 plant species.
He said visitors can find the entrance to the park near Juili No. 1 Bridge on Chiayi County's No. 122 Highway.
The park's name is derived from the Yuantan creek and is located on the border of Chuchi and Meishan townships in Chiayi County.

Built at a cost of NT$54 million, it covers an area of five hectares at an altitude of nearly 1,000 meters. The forest and the three cascades in the park provide an ideal retreat to avoid the summer heat.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO SUPERVISE IC PACKAGING INVESTMENT IN CHINA

TEXT.P: A Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislator urged the government Friday to closely supervise the operations of four local semiconductor testing and packaging plants whose investments in low-end products in China were just approved by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

Loh Chih-ming, together with former presidential adviser Huang Tien-lin and Taiwan Association of University Professors Deputy Secretary-General Hsu Wen-fu, made the appeal at a press conference held in Legislative Yuan.

Loh stressed that it is technically easy for the low-end semiconductor testing and packaging factories to upgrade to high-end plants, and the government's opening of low-end IC testing and packaging firms to break into China is giving the industry a free hand to develop in China.

Loh suggested that MOEA officials send professionals to attend the four companies' board meetings in order to further monitor whether there are any violations of their original investment applications.

Fan Liang-tung, executive secretary of the MOEA's Investment Commission, said MOEA officials will continue supervising the seasonal reports of these firms and will make investigative tours if necessary.

The four semiconductor testing and packaging plants -- Siliconware Precision Industries Co., Greatek Electronic, Walton Advanced Engineering Inc. and the Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Group -- had their investment applications, worth US$99.6 million, approved Thursday by the Investment Commission.
In return, the four plants promised to make additional investments in Taiwan worth NT$75 billion (US$2.28 billion) in three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WOULD WELCOME DPP ENDORSEMENT FOR ITS REFERENDUM PLAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) urged the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Friday to endorse a public referendum plan on Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations proposed by the main opposition party after a government committee rejected a referendum proposal that the DPP submitted.

KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih made the comments to reporters while answering questions on the issue after a referendum review committee under the Executive Yuan turned down earlier the same day a public referendum proposal initiated by the DPP on pursuing U.N. membership for the country in the name of Taiwan.
The DPP originally proposed to hold the referendum at the same time as the 2008 presidential poll.

If the DPP identifies itself with the country's official title of Republic of China, the KMT also welcomes its supporters to endorse the KMT-proposed referendum proposal calling for Taiwan's participation in world bodies and other international organizations under the name of the ROC, Taiwan or other feasible titles that ensure successful entry and national dignity, Wu said.
As long as the Central Election Commission approves the KMT's proposed referendum on Taiwan's U.N. bid by July 4, the party will proceed with its referendum plan as scheduled, he added.

Meanwhile, the opposition People First Party, an ally of the KMT in the "pan- blue alliance, " called the committee's rejection of the DPP-driven referendum proposal on Taiwan's U.N. cause "fair and reasonable, " on the grounds that it is meaningless to call a referendum on an issue that has already gained a high degree of national consensus.
According to PFP spokesman Lee Hung-chun, his party supports the decision by the Executive Yuan's referendum review committee to turn down the DPP's referendum plan by a vote of 12-8.
Taiwan's joining the United Nations is out of the question if cross-Taiwan Strait relations remain gridlocked, Lee pointed out.

The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the DPP in the "pan- green camp, " blasted the referendum committee for rejecting the DPP proposal and expressed deep regret about the development.

Speaking in a Legislative Yuan news conference, TSU legislative caucus whip Tseng Tsahn-deng insinuated that the committee has become a mouthpiece of China, as its decision conforms to Beijing's long-term objections to Taiwan's entry into the United Nations.

Although seven DPP-leaning referendum committee members resigned from the committee after the decision, which they called "unacceptable, " Tseng said that the TSU will continue promoting a public referendum on Taiwan's pursuit of U.N. membership and questioned why its people cannot directly have a say on it, given that 77 percent of them support the cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAOKUNG CABLE CAR TO BE INAUGURATED JULY 4

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government's Maokung cable car service in Mucha is slated to be inaugurated July 4 after evaluation of deficiency improvements, an official al of the city government's Transportation Department said Friday.
The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. will begin the service immediately after the inauguration ceremony, the official said.
The evaluation committee, comprised of experts and scholars invited by the city government, examined the cable car system June 14 and listed 16 minor items requiring improvement.
The TRTC and the city government's Public Works Department completed the minor improvements June 23, which were later confirmed by the committee, the official said.

According to the official, the system is 4.03 km long and has four stations: Taipei Zoo Station, Taipei Zoo South Station, Chihnan Temple Station, and Maokung Station. The system will be able to carry 2,000 passengers per hour or about 20,000 per day.
Peak hours of the cable car service's upward line are expected to be from 1 p.m.-2 p.m., with peak downhill hours to be from 4 p.m.-5 p.m.
Tickets will be NT$30 (US$0.92) for one station, NT$40 for two stations and NT$50 for three stations, the official said, adding that passengers can also pay with MRT Easycards.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO APPEAL AGAINST RULING ON U.N. REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) pledged Friday to appeal against a decision made earlier that day by the Cabinet's referendum review committee, which rejected the party's initiative to hold a referendum on the country's bid to apply to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan.
DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said the party will make the move next week in the hope that the initiative can be approved soon.
Noting that the initiative is sponsored by more than 90,000 people, Yu described the referendum review committee's decision as "against democracy" and "against public opinion."
Yu claimed the committee turned down the initiative because it is controlled by pro-Chinese unification members who "identify with China" and "deny Taiwan."

On U.S. opposition to the referendum plan, Yu claimed that the country's bid to use the name "Taiwan" to apply for U.N. membership does not involve changing the country's official name -- the Republic of China.

Yu said some countries, such as Macedonia, have used names different from their official titles to join the United Nations and claimed it is against the United States' founding spirit for Washington to object to the plan.

Once the appeal is filed, the case will be handled by an appeal review commission under the Executive Yuan, which is almost certain to reverse the decision of the referendum review committee, as the appeal review commission is controlled by the DPP, while the referendum review committee is controlled by the opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE URGES NOT TO `UGLIFY, BEAUTIFY' HISTORY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou called Friday for an objective revelation of historic events, saying that while writing a history, mankind should refrain from "uglifying or beautifying" the truth.
Ma, a former KMT chairman, made the remarks in an interview with the Taipei- based Broadcasting Corporation of China.

Introducing his new book, "the Spirit of Motherland, " published June 21, Ma said the book comprises stories of model figures who once lived In Taiwan and made contributions to the country, as well as significant historic events in Taiwan.
The reason he wrote the book is that he wants to give history its "true face, " Ma claimed.

The KMT has been faced with severe criticism over the years resulting from the 228 Incident of 1947 -- a notorious dark chapter in Taiwan's history perpetrated by the KMT under the leadership of late President Chiang Kai-shek, in which a popular uprising was brutally crushed by KMT troops.

Ma said people should not just wipe off all the contributions made by the KMT to the development of Taiwan because of one incident, or even because of the "white terror" era following the 228 incident, when the KMT brutally suppressed any form of political dissent.
The KMT "made mistakes, " but it also made contributions to the country, Ma said, adding that he is willing to offer an apology for the incident on the behalf of the party.

Citing similar examples in other countries such as Japan, Germany and China, Ma said Germany has made a good example in atoning for its crimes in World War II, while Japan has not attempted to do the same for its war crimes, while China has never appeared even slightly willing to admit to its faults in the bloody massacre it perpetrated in Tiananmen Square in 1989.
Compared with these acknowledged perpetrators of human atrocities on a massive scale, the KMT has "done something nicely by recognizing its mistakes," the former KMT chairman claimed.
Describing Taiwan people as diligent, pragmatic and very tolerant to people from overseas, Ma said the Taiwan people welcome everyone only if they come with sincerity and goodwill.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE PRODUCTS UNDERMINE TAIWAN'S TRADITIONAL INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: Imported Chinese products beat Taiwan's traditional industries with massive quantities and much cheaper prices, representatives of Taiwan's traditional industries said Friday.

Chien Lung-fu, Chairman of the Jih Sheng International Furniture Co., said Taiwan used to have 60 percent of the domestic market share in the industry, but said the market share has decreased to 40 percent since Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2001. China-made furniture have taken over Taiwan-made products with much cheaper prices due to its low production and material costs and the WTO's tariff-free policy on imported furniture.

Lee Wen-tzen, director of Taipei City's bedlinen industry association, said cotton quilts imported from China with poor quality priced at less than NT$1,000 per piece, has taken away Taiwanese producers' market.

Yiou To-er, general secretary of the Taiwan Ceramic Industry Association, said Taiwan used to have more than 100 ceramic production lines but now has only about 70 because Taiwan cannot compete with China's massive production of ceramics.

Taiwan Hosiery Manufacturers' Association Director-General Wei Fang-ta said nearly 80 percent of the domestic market share previously owned by Taiwanese manufacturers has been taken over by Chinese products.

Taiwan's imposition of provisional anti-dumping tax on imported China-made towels last year has given Chien, Wei and Lee hopes of seeking help through appeals for anti-dumping measures on Chinese products.

However, they were also warned by Yunlin Towel Industrial Technology Development Director-General Lai Yen-chou that measures taken too late -- such as the imposition of anti-dumping tax on China-made products -- will still hurt industries. Lai pointed out that the anti-dumping tax only revived five-eighths of sales.

Lee said the government is paying too much attention to big financial groups instead of caring more about traditional industries. The government took NT$31 billion (US$947 million) of the country's deposit insurance fund to solve a financial crisis of Taiwan's Chinese Bank at the beginning of this year, Lee said, adding that the amount could have been used to save at least 80,000 small- and medium-sized enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO SHOW MORE RESPECT FOR RIGHTS FOR IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: The government should show more respect for the basic rights of hundreds of thousands of migrant workers and immigrants in Taiwan, academic and social groups said in a seminar Friday.

The government of Taiwan "sees migrants as potential criminals and the cause of problems, while Canada does not," said Hsia Hsiao-chuan, a professor at Shih- shin University, at the seminar aimed at sharing Canada's experience in migrants' rights and community integration.

There have been a lot of social issues concerning the families of immigrants, namely foreign spouses, and their second-generation members, and social groups desperately need help from the government, said Chang Lai-hou, a representative from the Eden Foundation social welfare group.

Canada is a country of immigrants, which was why it has always paid great attention to its immigration law since 1869, the year the law came into effect, and to maintaining an open and discrimination-free mentality toward immigrants, said Ron MacIntosh, Executive Director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei (CTOT). Both Canada and Taiwan look at immigrants as a way to sustain the economy, but the situations of two countries are different as Canada is a vast land with small population while Taiwan is a small and densely populated country with limited resources, MacIntosh said.

"Canada recognizes the economic contributions of migrant workers. That is its fundamental difference from Taiwan, which sees migrants as potential criminals and the cause of problems, " Hsia said, noting that Taiwan has different treatment for residents and non-residents that is extremely discriminatory.

"In Taiwan, migrant workers are excluded from most laws and regulations. They are not allowed to transfer employers. The government gives the right to employers to mistreat migrant workers under the name of `management of migrant workers', " she added.

"It is difficult for immigrants to apply for residency. There are too many barriers for them to acquire citizenship. And they are not allowed to vote and work. Migrant workers don't have the rights to protest, either," she noted.

Currently, Canada accepts approximately 200,000 immigrants from all over the world annually. Half of those are temporary workers who mostly came from the U.S., Mexico, the Philippines and the Caribbean countries, said Patricia Nicoll, Director of CTOT's Visa and Immigration.
In terms of human trafficking victims, the Canadian government offers Temporary Resident Permits (TRP) , longer term permits and permanent status options to protect the victims' rights.
"What our government needs to understand is that good governance means not only effective border control but also the protection of basic human rights for non- citizens, " Hsia said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PORTLAND YOUTH PHILHARMONIC ORCHESTRA TO GIVE 3 CONCERTS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Portland Youth Philharmonic Orchestra from the American state of Oregon will stage a concert in the Kaohsiung Cultural Center July 4, the Kaohsiung city government's Bureau of Cultural Affairs announced Friday.

The orchestra from Kaohsiung's sister city will also perform at the Tainan Cultural Center July 5 and at the National Concert Hall in Taipei July 8 before proceeding to South Korea for a six-day tour.
The orchestra is recognized as one of America's premier youth orchestras. Its members range in age from seven to 22 and represent 70 different schools in the Portland area.

Mei-Ann Chen, the 33-year-old conductress of the orchestra, was born in Taiwan. She began to play the violin at age 7 and went to the United States at age 16. She received a double master's degree in violin and conducting.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST BETEL NUT CULTURE EXPO KICKS OFF IN KAOHSIUNG CITY

TEXT.P: The first Betel Nut Culture Exposition and Forum on the betel nut industry in Taiwan opened in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Friday, drawing attention of many domestic and foreign media outlets.

Activities, including a betel nut salesgirl fashion show and an exhibition of photos of "betel nut beauties" -- the young, often scantily dressed women hired to sell the mildly narcotic and carcinogenic nut -- took place at the venue to celebrate the opening.

The six-day exposition, to run through July 4, was organized by the Kaohsiung Business Exhibition Center to demonstrate the betel nut sub-culture in Taiwan, of which the betel nut girls are the most high profile facet.
The women represent a successful marketing strategy that turned the once plain and dull vending of betel nut into a festive money-earning business.

On the betel nut-related health issue, Dr. Liu Puo-en, a diet specialist, reported at the forum that he has found more than 70 percent of his patients suffer from obesity if they quit chewing betel nut.
Among these patients, Liu said, some of them get constipation and sexual dysfunction, suggesting that further research on betel nut's influence is required.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN NOBEL LAUREATE INSPIRES TAIWANESE STUDENTS IN SPEECH

TEXT.P: One cannot always be a winner, but sometimes one works harder when he or she gets rejected by others, Australian 2005 Nobel Prize for medicine laureate Barry Marshall told hundreds of Taiwanese high school students in a speech Friday.

Marshall, who concluded a four-day visit to Taiwan Friday, was awarded the Nobel Prize for medicine in 2005 along with his longtime collaborator Robin Warren for their discovery of the helicobacter pyroli bacterium and its role in gastritis and peptic ulcer disease.

In the one-hour speech, titled "Journey of a Nobel Scientist" and sponsored by the University of Western Australia, National Taiwan University and Australian Education International (AEI) , Marshall told the audience how he was "always interested in shortcuts" during the days when he developed his interest in science and "not very humble in college" in pointing out professors' mistakes.
Quoting historian Daniel Boorstin, he said, "The greatest obstacle to knowledge is not ignorance, it's the illusion of knowledge."

Marshall's discovery identified the great majority of gastritis and peptic ulcer cases, which were previously thought to be chronic infections caused by stress and dietary factors, as being caused by helicobacter pyroli and curable with antibiotics.
His findings were dismissed at first and to prove his theory, he experimented on himself, ingesting a turbid, foul-tasting solution of helicobacter pyroli.

"Taiwan is very much like me, " he said, referring to what President Chen Shui- bian told him in a meeting the previous day that Taiwan was also rejected in its World Health Organization (WHO) full membership bid, which was similar to what happened to Marshall's bold hypothesis.

In a 30-minute question-and-answer session after the speech, Marshall interacted with high school students who mostly came from Taipei City and encouraged them to always be curious about new things and work hard at "things that interest you."

DOC.HEADLINE: NCHC SUPERCOMPUTER RANKED 35TH-FASTEST IN WORLD

TEXT.P: A supercomputer owned by the National Center for High-Performance Computing (NCHC) has been ranked 35th-fastest in the world, a NCHC official said Friday.
The classification was released at the 2007 International Supercomputing Conference (ISC) currently held in Dresden, Germany.
It marks Taiwan's best performance in terms of high performance computing ability among the top 500 world list, the official said.

In Asia, Taiwan's high performance computing classification was ahead of China (43rd) and South Korea (53rd), but lagged far behind Japan (14th), which is represented by the Tokyo Institute of Technology.

With its high performance computing capability, the supercomputer of NCHC -- IBM System Cluster 1350 -- will be open for use by local industrial and academic sectors to help accelerate scientific research in meteorological phenomena, typhoon and flood prediction, energy exploration, medical imaging and engineering projects.
The NCHC will for the first time open the supercomputer as a high performance computing platform for a computing competition of university students later this year, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA WILL NOT HONOR CASH AID PLEDGES: TAIWAN REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 29 (CNA) 06/29/07 22:51:03 (By Jorge Liu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Countries that switched their diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China in the 90s will find that it is increasingly hard for China to honor the cash aid it has promised, Taiwan's representative to the United States Joseph Wu claimed Friday.
Wu's remarks were published Friday by the U.S. monthly "The Washington Diplomat, " which gave large coverage to Beijing's squeezing of Taiwan's diplomatic relations with other countries.
Wu claimed that Beijing recently lured away Taiwan's diplomatic ally Costa Rica with US$430 million.

Although Taiwan has "been sincere" in assisting Costa Rica's development, the Central American country has tried to "hide its real intention" in establishing ties with China, Wu said. "We have the feeling of being betrayed," Wu complained.

The report analyzed that Taiwan's official ties with Guatemala and Panama are also not looking good, as Guatemala President Daniel Ortega, a Marxist, established diplomatic ties with Cuba, China, North Korea and Vietnam in the 70s, and China remains the second-largest user of Panama Canal after the United States.

Wu admitted that although there is no sign of a domino effect on Taiwan's diplomatic relations with other countries, he said the Taiwan authorities are concerned about China's "cash diplomacy" targeting its diplomatic allies.

"Taiwan offers aid to diplomatic allies, not cash but service and development, " Wu claimed, adding that Taiwan extends agricultural, medical and economic development assistance to diplomatic allies in accordance with their needs.
Noting that China still has a poverty problem in some parts of the country, Wu claimed that the more it "buys" Taiwan's diplomatic allies, the more financial burden it suffers.
Regarding U.S.-Taiwan ties, Wu said that although the countries maintain no official relations, the United States is the most important friend of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO ORDER PROBE INTO BCC SHARE TRANSFERS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will order a probe into share transfers of the Taipei-based Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC) next Wednesday, government spokesman Shieh Jyh-wey said Friday.

Accusing the National Communications Commission (NCC) of dereliction of duty and illegally helping BCC new owner Jaw Shau- kong to chalk up illicit earnings, Shieh said the Executive Yuan will submit the case with evidence July 4 to the prosecution, and Jaw, along with NCC members, will be subject to investigation.

As to the question of whether the alleged NCC members will be suspended from their posts, Hsieh said the Executive Yuan has not yet to made a final decision on the issue as it is still compiling evidence against them.

Hsieh accused Jaw of setting up four dummy companies with suspicious funds in order to purchase the BCC shares from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -affiliated Hua Hsia Investment Holdings Co., which was in charge of managing the KMT's assets.
According to Hsieh, Jaw's dummy companies were opened to avoid a government regulation that "a natural person is banned from holding more than 10 percent of a broadcasting company's stocks."

Hsieh also accused the NCC of failing to carry out its duties, as the commission stamped its approval for the BCC share transfer to Jaw without carrying out substantial scrutiny of Jaw's funds and his four companies.
"The NCC has apparently committed malfeasance in an attempt to help Jaw rack up illegal profits," Hsieh claimed.

Earlier the same day, three lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lodged a suit against five NCC members with the Taiwan High Prosecutors' Office on charges of illegally allowing Jaw to profiteer by approving the BCC share transfer. "The five men are accomplices of Jaw," they argued.

In response to the lawsuit, the NCC issued a statement Friday urging political figures to stop "groundlessly defaming" and "rashly" taking legal action against others, claiming that such behavior "only expose their ignorance about the highly professional case and their ambition to meddle in freedom of speech enjoyed by media outlets."
"All political figures must assume political responsibility for distributing groundless accusations," the NCC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Justices Limit the Use of Race in School Plans for Integration
With competing blocs of justices claiming the mantle of Brown v. Board of Education, a bitterly divided Supreme Court declared Thursday that public school systems cannot seek to achieve or maintain integration through measures that take explicit account of a students race.
Voting 5 to 4, the court, in an opinion by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., invalidated programs in Seattle and metropolitan Louisville, Ky., that sought to maintain school-by-school diversity by limiting transfers on the basis of race or using race as a tiebreaker for admission to particular schools.
Wall Street Journal:A Shift in Dining Scene Nicks a Once-Hot Chain
On a visit to Marietta, Ga., last fall, TJ Palmer stopped into an Applebee's and ordered a bruschetta burger. "I didn't like it at all," she ays. After having visited the restaurant chain regularly for years, Ms. Palmer says, she rarely goes anymore. "It doesn't have anything that would make me want to come back."
Applebee's was once one of the country's hottest restaurant chains, but today it faces falling profits, a lagging stock and restless investors. In a business where fashions shift, Applebee's stayed too long with a formula that had worked in the past.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY TO GO AHEAD WITH U.N. BID: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will continue to push for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan in September despite a committee under the Executive Yuan rejected to have a referendum on this bid, an official from the foreign ministry said Friday.

Yeh Fei-bi, deputy chief of the Information and Cultural Affairs Department under the foreign ministry said Taiwan's bids to join the United Nations and other international bodies have been supported by a majority of people according to various polls, and the foreign ministry won't change tack.

A referendum review committee under the Executive Yuan rejected the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's initiative to call a referendum on Taiwan's bid to join United Nations under the name of Taiwan earlier that day on the ground that it has already been a government's policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 30, or the 16fth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Montezuma II, the Aztec sovereign of Mexico, is killed by Hernando Cortez, the Spanish invader who overthrew his empire and took him prisoner.
1815: Stephen Decatur, an American naval officer known for his heroic deeds in the Tripolitan War, the War of 1812, stops continued attacks by Algerian pirates by threatening to bombard Algiers.
1837: Use of the pillory is banned in Britain. The device is a wooden framework on a post, with holes for the head and hands, in which offenders were locked to be exposed to public scorn as punishment for petty crimes.
1859: A crowd of some 25,000 people hold their breath in stunned admiration as Charles Blondin, a daring 35-year-old Frenchman, crosses Niagara Falls balanced on a tightrope.
1894: Tower Bridge across the River Thames in London is opened by the Prince of Wales.
1934: Adolf Hitler eliminates all his political opponents in the "Night of the Long Knives" in Germany.
1943: U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur assumes his new post as commander of the Allied forces in the Southwest Pacific.
1950: U.S. President Harry S. Truman orders American forces to resist North Korean troops which are invading South Korea.
1963: Cardinal Giovanni Battista Montini is enthroned as Pope Paul VI. He was noted for easing regulations on fasting and interfaith marriages.
1971: Three Russian cosmonauts are found dead in their spaceship after a record- breaking 24 days in space which ended in oxygen failure in the final stage.
1977: The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO) is dissolved after 23 years.
1980: Hung Mao Cheng (Fortress of the Red-Haired People), formerly the British consulate at Tamsui, northern Taiwan, is returned to the Republic of China government after the expiration of a 113-year lease.
1983: Hsu Shih-hsien, mayor of Chiayi and Taiwan's first female mayor, dies of liver cancer at the age of 76.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Sten A. Akestam, president of the International Association of Lions Clubs, and six other top-ranking Lions officials.
1987: The construction of Feitsui Reservoir in Taipei County, with a price-tag of NT$14 billion, is completed.
1989: ROC Interior Minister Hsu Shui-teh and Vice Defense Minister Kuo Tsung- chin jointly preside over a ceremony marking the inauguration of a national boundary stone tablet inscribed with the words "Shield of the South China Sea" on Tungsha Chuntao (the Pratas Islands) in the South China Sea.
1990: East and West Germany merge their economies, with East Germany adopting the deutschemark as its currency.
1993: The ROC Executive Yuan approves an economic stimulus package to accelerate industrial upgrading and develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center.
1995: The U.S. government officially announces cancellation of the sanctions against Taiwan issued under the Pelly Amendment.
1996: South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo arrives in Taipei for a three- day visit.
1997: Britain hands Hong Kong back to the Chinese at the stroke of midnight, ending 156 years of colonial rule.
1999: The U.S. ratings agency Standard and Poor's gives the ROC's long-term foreign currency credit a rating of AA+, indicating its belief that the country has a high level of capability in fulfilling its financial commitments.
2000: A total of 251 sinologists from around the world meet at Taiwan's Academia Sinica to discuss the digital preservation of traditional Chinese literature and language archives.
2001: Senegalese President Abdoulaye Wade, accompanied by a high-profile delegation, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit to the ROC at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the conduct of government, the first bad principle to be avoided is cruelty. That is, the undue punishment of crimes committed through ignorance arising out of a neglected education."

A total of 17,810 public officials who were proclaimed winners in the May 14, 2007 mid-term elections by the Commission on Elections (Comelec) and by the provincial, city, district and municipal boards of canvassers all over the country will assume their posts at noon today as mandated by Article 18, Section 2 of the Constitution.
