The Japan Times Japan should defend U.S. from ICBM attacks: panel
Japan should be allowed to intercept intercontinental ballistic nissiles fired at the United States, a government panel agreed Friday, indicating the Constitution would need to be reinterpreted so the country could come to the defense of an ally under attack.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANTED REBAR GROUP FOUNDER REMAINS IN DETENTION IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 29 (CNA) 06/30/07 13:02:53 (By Chu Lu-sheng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Fugitive Taiwanese tycoon Wang You-theng remains in detention at an immigration holding center in San Pedro, California, awaiting the conclusion of a legal procedure regarding his illegal entry into the United States earlier this year, a Taiwan official said Friday.
Joseph Wu, Taiwan's representative to the United States, said his office has very limited information about Wang's case because judicial cases are not open to the public in the United States.
Wu made the remarks when asked about reports that Wang, founder of the Rebar Asia Pacific Group, might be released from the holding center in July.

Wang has been detained by U.S. immigration authorities since Feb. 2, when he tried to return to Los Angeles with both his Republic of China and Dominican Republic passports canceled, following a failed attempt to flee to Myanmar via Singapore.

Wang is suspected of having embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds from the group before fleeing with his wife, Wang Chin She-ying, to China late last year and then to the United States in January this year.
Taiwan authorities placed the couple on the country's most-wanted list Jan. 15 and have been seeking U.S. assistance to have them repatriated back to Taiwan to face charges.

In March, Taiwanese prosecutors indicted Wang and 106 others involved in the Rebar Group scandal on a long list of charges, including fraud, money laundering and insider trading, and are seeking a prison sentence of 30 years and an unprecedented fine of NT$1.71 billion (US$52.13 million) for Wang.

Fang Hsiao-wei, a practicing lawyer in Los Angeles, told the Central News Agency that the results of Taiwan's judicial trial over the Rebar Group scandal will be crucial to how long Wang will remain in the holding center.
Fang said based on his experience in handling immigration cases, Wang should have applied for permanent residency in the United States through his wife or children who hold U.S. citizenship.

However, the U.S. immigration authorities are not expected to approve Wang's application immediately but will await the outcome of his trial, Fang said, adding that the application can be rejected if Wang is convicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Justices to Weigh Detainee Rights; In Reversal, Court Agrees to Hear Case.
The Supreme Court yesterday reversed itself and agreed to consider whether detainees at Guantanamo Bay have been unfairly barred from the federal courts by the Bush administration and Congress, a move that may finally determine legal rights for foreign-born terrorism suspects.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MEN DIE IN LIGHT AIRPLANE CRASH IN TAITUNG

TEXT.P: A light aircraft crashed Saturday nearby a riverside park in the southeastern county of Taitung, causing the deaths of the pilot and an American passenger.
The RANS-S6 airplane fell straight out of the sky at around 9: 00 a.m. striking the ground nose first. It was flying over a farmer's field when it suddenly lost power, according to witnesses.
The pilot and passenger were seriously wounded when pulled from the wreckage. They died later at the Tzu Chi Hospital's Kuanshan branch.

Local police indicated that the light craft was owned by a private aviation association in Fenglin township in Hualien county, eastern Taiwan. The pilot, identified as Chen Chun-jung, 34, had flown light craft for over seven years.

The passenger, Jon Eric Hope, 21, from Arkansas, USA was a member of an English teaching program organized by the Taipei-based non-profit King Car Educational Foundation, bringing English language instruction to children living in rural areas on the island. Eric taught English at Jueisuei Elementary School in Hualien county.
The police said Eric was on a sightseeing tour in Taitung with some friends. There, he spotted the light craft, and requested a pleasure flight.
Police have contacted both Eric's parents in the U.S. with the assistance of the American Institute in Taiwan, and Chen's family members in Hualien.
A probe by the Civil Aeronautics Administration has been launched into the accident, according to police.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CROSS-STRAIT COMMON MARKET' WILL BRING DISASTER: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that if the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) advocacy of a "cross-strait common market" is put into practice, it will mark the beginning of a disaster for the nation.

President Chen made the remarks while touring Inotera Memories Inc., a joint venture between Taiwan's Nanya Technology Corp. and Qimonda AG of Germany that manufactures computer memory, in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan.

Chen noted that with nine months to go before the presidential election next year, Ma Ying-jeou, the KMT presidential candidate, has begun to promote the campaign platform of a "'92 consensus" and the "cross-strait common market."
Chen said that in view of the experience of other countries, the cross-strait common market" will mean the free flow of personnel, products and capitals between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
If such a market is established, Chinese laborers will be introduced into Taiwan, China's agriculture produce will flood Taiwan market, and Taiwan's capital will take flight to China, Chen said.
"This will lead to massive losses of jobs, decreased wages for laborers, poorer farmers and the speeding-up of the hollowing-out of the industry," he claimed.
"The cross-strait common market will mark the beginning of disaster, as Taiwan will be economically swallowed up by China, " the president said.
He also took issue with Ma's advocacy of turning Taiwan into a "free trade zone."
The president said Taiwan is a "sovereign and independent" country, and not a local government or special administrative region of any other country.
"The 'one China market," coupled with the 'free trade zone,' will downgrade Taiwan into an outlying free trade zone of China, " the president said.

The president also dismissed the so-called "'92 consensus, " which the KMT claimed is an agreement reached between Taipei and Beijing in 1992 that allows the two sides to have different interpretations of the meaning of "one China," saying that it was "non-existent." The KMT was still in power in 1992.
"The fact is that both sides of the Taiwan Strait reached an agreement on 'one China, ' but have not reached a conclusion on "different interpretations," he added.

He criticized the KMT for using the "cross-strait common market " and the "'92 consensus" to cover up its true intention of giving up the "national sovereignty" of Taiwan and paving the way for the eventual unification between the both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MANGO EXPORTS TO SOUTH KOREA EXPECTED TO JUMP 150%

TEXT.P: Fruit traders estimate that exports of Taiwan-grown Irwin mangos to South Korea will jump 150 percent over the 2006 level, after recent hot sales of the tropical fruit in that country, Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) officials said Saturday.

The Irwin mango, known as "Apple Mango" in Japan, has become more and more popular in South Korea since it was first exported there four years ago. Sales have increased year after year, with the price of the fruit tagged at around 5,000 won apiece -- the equivalent of NT$180 -- much higher than the price in Taiwan.

To further boost sales, the TAITRA recently organized a series of promotional activities with the cooperation of several major Korean traders at supermarkets and department stores in that country. During the nine-day promotion, a total of 120 tons of Irwin mangos were shipped from Taiwan to the neighboring country, TAITRA officials said.

According to the TAITRA, Japan and South Korea are two major markets for Taiwan- produced mangos. In 2006 the exports to Japan amounted to nearly 430 tons, while those to South Korea reached over 150 tons.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM COMMITTEE ACCUSED OF DEFYING PUBLIC OPINION

TEXT.P: Members of several civic groups accused the Cabinet's referendum review committee of defying public opinion Saturday over its rejection of an initiative raised by the ruling party to hold a referendum on the country's bid to apply to join the United Nations under the name "Taiwan."

The groups, including the Taiwan Society, the Taiwan North Society and the Taiwan United Nations Alliance (TAIUNA) , suggested that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) file for an interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices on the constitutionality of the committee, which is composed of representatives of various political parties in proportion to the number of seats the parties hold in the legislature.

Stressing that using the name "Taiwan" to join the United Nations is the only choice for the country, members of the groups criticized the committee's decision as "contrary to democracy" and made in defiance of the will of 77 percent of the people who are in favor of the referendum.

According to Chin Heng-wei, vice president of the Taiwan North Society, it is not feasible for the country to apply to rejoin the United Nations under the name "Republic of China, " whose U.N. seat was replaced by the People's Republic of China in 1971.

To counter the decision by the committee, Chin proposed that President Chen Shui-bian initiate a referendum on the U.N. bid using his right to call referendums on issues of "national security concern, " which are not required to obtain the committee's approval.

Lo Jung-kuang, secretary-general of the TAIUNA, said it is unfair that Taiwan's 23 million people should be excluded from the world body and he urged opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou not to block the DPP- promoted U.N. bid.

On Friday, the opposition-controlled committee voted down 12-8 the DPP-sponsored initiative calling for a referendum on the country's bid to apply to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan."

In objecting to the plan, some committee members argued that such a referendum is unnecessary as pushing for the country's inclusion in the United Nations is a policy already adopted by the government.

Other members mentioned that the United Nations is an organization where statehood is required for membership and that the country will need to amend its constitution to change its official name from "Republic of China" to "Republic of Taiwan" before it can apply to the United Nations under the name "Taiwan." The DPP is planning to appeal the committee' ruling next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. BID UNDER NAME 'TAIWAN' AIMS TO SAFEGUARD STATUS QUO: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 29 (CNA) 06/30/07 15:51:18 (By Chu Lu-sheng and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to the United States Joseph Wu said Friday that President Chen Shui-bian's plan to promote a referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name "Taiwan" is aimed at safeguarding the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.

During a speech delivered to a group of American academic and trade representatives, as well as Taiwanese expatriates living in Los Angeles, Wu said that the Taiwanese people want to join the U.N. under the name "Taiwan", which is not a move to change the status quo across the two sides of Taiwan Strait.
Chen stressed that the proposal does not violate his former commitment to U.S. government, and has nothing to do with changing Taiwan's official designation.

Wu said President Chen Shui-bian made a "four noes" pledge in his 2000 inaugural speech that so long as China has no intention of using military force against Taiwan, he will not declare independence, will not change the national title or flag, will not hold referendum on "independence versus unification" and will not enshrine the "state-to-state" theory in the constitution to define cross- Taiwan Strait relations.
Under the premise, Wu said the plan to hold a referendum on the bid to join U.N. as "Taiwan" should not be regarded as a move to change the status quo.

Noting that the world community is using the term "Taiwan" in documents related to the island, Wu said even an order that the American government gave its administrative branch in 2001 stipulated that "Taiwan" is the most appropriate term to mention this place and its government.

In related news, Wu said he will greet Vice President Annette Lu in Los Angeles when she makes a transit stop in the city en route to her Latin American tour earlier next month, and the reception will be in accordance with the formality agreed upon between the governments of Taiwan and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO RECEIVE SAME TREATMENT DURING TRANSIT STOPS: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 29 (CNA) 06/30/07 16:46:19 (By Chu Lu-sheng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu will received treatment consistent with that accorded to President Chen Shui-bian during planned stopovers in the United States, Taiwan's representative to the United States said Friday.

Lu is scheduled to make an overnight transit stop in San Francisco en route to Latin America next month and take part in some private activities at her hotel during her stay in the U.S. city, according to Joseph Wu.
On her way back to Taiwan after the Latin American visit, Lu will make a four- hour transit stop in Los Angeles, Wu said.

Lu is scheduled to depart July 2 from Taiwan for the visit covering three of the country's diplomatic allies, namely the Dominican Republic, Paraguay and Guatemala. The vice president is expected to return to Taiwan July 14.
In January, Chen also made an overnight transit stop in San Francisco en route to Nicaragua and stopped over in Los Angeles on his way home.

While in San Francisco, Chen met with American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond Burghardt and former U.S. Secretary of Defense William Perry, and had telephone conversations with top Washington officials and key U.S. Congress members.

DOC.HEADLINE: INFECTIOUS TB PATIENTS TO BE BARRED FROM TAKING LONG-HAUL FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Patients who suffer from infectious tuberculosis (TB) will be prohibited from taking long-distance international flights of over eight hours, starting from July 1, officials of the Department of Health (DOH) said Saturday.

According to the officials of the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the DOH, those who are infected with multiple drug-resistant TB will be barred from taking any flight, whether of short or long-distance, with the violators facing fines ranging between NT$10,000 (US$304) and NT$150,000.

CDC officials said patients with infectious TB should take medicine for two weeks, and those infected with multiple drug-resistant should complete a whole set of treatment and be proven as no longer infectious before boarding an international flight.
Regarding domestic flights, although the CDC has not imposed any restrictions on those suffering from infectious TB, officials urged them to wear surgical masks on board.
Meanwhile, the CDC is expected to offer a list of TB patients of these two types in September to facilitate the screening work of immigration agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA REGRETS OUTGOING REPRESENTATIVE'S CRITICISM OF GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday that it regretted criticism of the government by its outgoing representative to Singapore, which it described as an act "incompatible with the duty of a diplomatic personnel."
MOFA acting spokeswoman Yeh Fei-bi said Hu Wei-jen put himself above the interests of the nation, and that the ministry will "begin to review the matter."

Yeh made the remarks after Hu said in a recent interview with Singapore's Lianhe Zaobao that he didn't see eye-to-eye to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's policy to "cut links with China" and its drive to remove statues of former President Chiang Kai-shek in a bid to shed the last vestiges of the authoritarian rule under Chiang.
This is why he has decided to end his 35-year career as a public servant, Hu told the Chinese-language newspaper.
Yeh said the stance of the ministry is that Hu, while serving as Taiwan's top representative to Germany and Singapore, has sometimes expressed personal views at the expense of national interest.
Noting that Hu is still a representative to Singapore, the ministry regretted that he has made such "improper remarks, " Yeh said.
Hu is the oldest son of General Hu Tsung-nan, one of Chiang Kai-shek's commanders. Hu formerly served in the MOFA and as a deputy director of National Security Bureau.

Hu assumed his current post in June 2005. He was informed that he should prepare to step down in April. He is scheduled to return to Taiwan July 2. He has told the CNA that he will travel to the United States in September to serve as a visiting scholar at Harvard University.
Meanwhile, lawmakers reacted along party lines to Hu's remarks.
Both KMT Legislator John Chiang, a grandson of the late president, and People First Party Legislator Daniel Hwang, expressed admiration for Hu for his courage in expressing his views.
But DPP Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim and Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Ying Ling-ying said that stepping up the Taiwan-centric consciousness has become a political mainstay in Taiwan.
"If Hu cannot identify with the Taiwan-centric consciousness and cannot serve that cause, it may be better for him to leave at an earlier date," Hsiao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINIMUM WAGE HIKE TO COME INTO EFFECT SUNDAY

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has worked out five measures to help mitigate the impact on small- and medium-sized enterprises as the 9.09 percent minimum wage hike is set to put into practice Sunday.
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced earlier this month that the minimum wage will be raised to NT$17.280 (US$523) per month while the hourly wage will be NT$95.

About 1.41 million "marginal" members of the country's workforce -- including foreign laborers, part-time workers, senior citizens who have returned to the employment market after retirement and female workers -- are expected to benefit from the wage hike.

To offset the expected negative impact, the CLA has decided to subsidize owners of certain businesses, including fast-food chains, restaurants, supermarkets and gas stations, with a working staff of less than 50 people. The owners will be entitled to subsidies of NT$10 per hour per head when the staff members work less than 32 hours a week. This subsidy incentive will be implemented for one year on a trial basis.

The CLA has also decided to offer subsidies of NT$5,000 per month per head to owners of companies which employ disadvantaged workers, including physically and mentally challenged people and senior citizens.

To deal with the possibility that many workers may lose their jobs because of the hike in the minimum hourly wage, the CLA will also work to help disadvantaged workers in three-prong way by helping them find employment, receive vocational training and unemployment subsidies.
The food and accommodation allowance provided to foreign laborers working in Taiwan is raised from the current NT$4,000 per month to NT$5,000.
CLA vocational training subsidies will also be raised as the fifth measure to deal with the impact of the hike in the minimum wage, which had remained unchanged since 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST CHAIN CAFES HAVE SECONDHAND SMOKE, NOISE PROBLEMS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Most coffee chain stores in metropolitan Taipei were found to be unhealthy, with many being smoky or noisy, or their coffee products coming with creamer containing health-threatening trans fat, according to a survey conducted by the Common Health monthly journal.

The survey of LOHAS, or Lifestyles of Health and Sustainability, was conducted between May 25 and June 8 on eight large cafe chains in Taipei, including McCafe, Dante Coffee, IS Coffee, Barista Coffee, Mr. Brown Coffee, Ikari Coffee, Starbucks Coffee and Doutor Coffee. The survey results were released Saturday.

In the survey, whether or not the establishment had banned smoking was the leading indicator in determining whether a healthy dining environment was provided, according to the magazine. The survey shows that of the eight cafe chains, only Starbucks and MaCafe adopted a comprehensive "no-smoking" ban, while Mr. Brown allows smoking in semi-open spaces on its smoking floor separate from its non-smoking customers.

As for Doutor, IS, Ikari and Dante, the survey found that they enclosed a smoking zone in the innermost corners of their shops. Such measures ultimately allow harmful tobacco smoke cover the entire shop, said Han Po-cheng, a professor at Taipei Medical University who was invited to review the investigation.

Noise was also found a problem. A Common Health senior reporter, Hsieh Hsiao- yuan, said that within the cafes music was often found to be too loud to allow customers to talk with each other in a normal voice.
At some coffee shops, Hsieh said they measured sound levels at 65-76 decibels. They commented that sound occasionally exceeding 70 decibles is disturbing and unpleasant to humans.
The survey also found that meals in urban coffee shops mostly contain vegetables insufficient for a person's daily needs.
Regarding environmental protection, only Starbucks and Ikari were found to encourage customers to bring their own cups by providing coffee at a discount.

In general, the poll showed that Starbucks has the best no-smoking spaces, while Mr. Brown has the most comfortable space for customers, and Ikari provides the greatest variety in meals. All of the investigated cafe chains, excluding Starbucks, were advised to strengthen their measures on environmental protection and energy saving.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK OF TAIWAN, CENTRAL TRUST OF CHINA TO MERGE SUNDAY

TEXT.P: Two state-owned banks -- Bank of Taiwan and Central Trust of China -- will formally merge Sunday to become the largest commercial bank in Taiwan.

After the merger, the paid-in capital will reach NT$53 billion (US$1.6 billion) with total assets of NT$2.93 trillion and a market share of 10.86 percent. The outstanding deposits will reach NT$2.29 trillion with a market share of 11.04 percent, and outstanding loans will reach NT$1.67 trillion with a market share of 9.8 percent.
The combined number of employees of the two financial institutions will be about 8,200.
Officials of Bank of Taiwan said that they hope to provide more diversified financial products to become a leading bank in Taiwan.
Officials also said that the sign board and internal information system of Central Trust of China will adopt the name of Bank of Taiwan starting July 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT AGENCIES NO LONGER OFFER PAPER CUPS BEGINNING JULY 1

TEXT.P: From July 1, government agencies and schools will no longer offer disposable paper cups to visitors as part of efforts to reduce waste, officials of Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Saturday.

Those organizations and schools which violate the new rule will face fines ranging between NT$30,000 (US$914) and NT$150,000. However, the officials added, the government agencies can provide folded paper cups to the visitors.

Also beginning from the same date, the reward for recycling unused automobiles and motorbikes will be reduced, with the incentive for recycling junk cars of over 10 years old dropping from the original NT$3,000 to NT$1,000, while the reward for recycling disused motorbikes of more than seven years old decreasing from NT$1,000 to NT$300.
Those dumping their junk cars or motorbikes at any places will be fined between NT$1,200 and NT$6,000.
Meanwhile, disused keyboards and light bulbs should also be recycled and separated from general garbage starting July 1, EPA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA TO USE VIDEO CONFERENCING TO SERVE SOUTHERN ENTREPRENEURS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will soon use its video conferencing system to allow entrepreneurs in central and southern Taiwan participate simultaneously in the conferences held at its Taipei headquarters.

The movement forms part of the government's efforts to better serve central and southern regions of the country, middle and lower social classes, and small and medium-sized enterprises, a TAITRA official said Saturday.
Many business people living in central and southern regions have complained about their missing many trade conferences, seminars and exhibitions held at TAITRA's headquarter in Taipei.

TAITRA will set up nine video conferencing press rooms around Taiwan, including Hsinchu, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung, at the first stage, and then later expand the system to all of its offices abroad.

According to officials, businessmen living or working in central and southern Taiwan will be better able to participate in product exhibitions, trade and industrial forums, sales meetings or even distance-education thanks to this video conferencing system.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING HOURS OF NATIONAL PALACE MUSEUM TO BE EXTENDED

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum said Saturday that its Saturday opening hours will be extended to 8: 30 p.m. starting next month.
On Saturdays, there will be outdoor performances between 6 p.m and 7 p.m., providing visitors with yet one more leisure and cultural activity.
During opening evenings in July and August, students from the departments of music of various universities will be invited to perform at the museum.
Starting in September, the museum will invite performing groups to take part in the Saturday feast. Groups interested can check with the museum's Web site at www.npm.gov.tw for more information.
Current opening hours are 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: PTS SIGNS COLLABORATION MEMO WITH GERMAN-FRENCH TELEVISION STATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Public Television Service (PTS) signed a collaboration memorandum at a press conference Saturday with French-German public television station ARTE for program exchanges and further cooperation in the future.

ARTE, the first transnational public television station in Europe, which was launched in 1992, serves as a great model for PTS as it has been devoting most of its energy to culture and arts during its 15-year existence, winning accolades and becoming "the hope of television industry, " said PTS President Hu Yuan-huei before signing the memo with ARTE President Jerome Clemente.
"The ARTE experience" taught Taiwanese media valuable lessons in many ways, including television production, cultural diversity and reconciliation, Hu added.

ARTE, which boasts a NT$ 16 billion annual budget that comes exclusively from the French and German governments, had set from the beginning its goal to promote arts and culture, especially European culture, and encourage viewers to understand "how very different we are, and how similar at the same time, " said Clemente.

The birth of ARTE symbolized the reconciliation of Germany and France, which have fought each other for over a century, said Patricia Kortmann, Art/Event Coordinator of German Cultural Center in Taipei.

Jean-Claude Poimboeuf, Director of French Institute in Taipei, also pointed out that the creation of ARTE has been a small part of the European integration, and revealed just how large the scale of European integration is, and how hard Europe has tried to achieve unity.

Taiwanese director Hou Hsiao-hsien credited ARTE for its success in developing young film directors through funding and collaboration and hoped that the same efforts could be made at PTS, which has been collaborating with local young directors and making great efforts in promoting documentaries.
"Interaction between film makers and television during the collaboration process is still not running smoothly, but it isn't easy, and it has taken a lot for PTS to make it this far, "Hou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ANNUAL TRAVEL MARKET WORTH NT$340 BILLION: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's annual travel market is worth an estimated NT$340 billion (US$10.37 billion) , with nearly 71 percent of respondents to a recent survey saying they travel to relieve stress, pollsters said upon the release of their extensive research Saturday.

The survey was conducted by the Global Views Monthly journal to explore local people's travel activities and preferences. The telephone poll targeted residents between the ages of 20 and 60 in all 23 cities and counties on Taiwan proper.

A total of 815 valid samples were collected in the survey conducted from June 12-14. Among the randomly chosen respondents, 747 have made overnight domestic leisure trips in the past three years and 392 have made overseas pleasure trips during the same period. The poll has a confidence level of 95 percent.

On Taiwan's demographic map, the number of citizens aged between 20 and 60 is about 9.38 million. Of them, 66 percent have made leisure trips either at home or abroad, or both, according to the survey.
Extrapolating from the findings of the survey, including duration of their journeys and average spending, pollsters estimate the value of Taiwan's annual travel market at NT$340.2 billion.

According to the survey, 70.9 percent of the respondents said they define the most important function of travel as "rest and relieving of stress, " while only 33.7 percent cite "broadening knowledge horizons and gaining a better understanding of the world" as the top purpose of travel.

As to what makes an ideal trip, 95.7 percent said an ideal tour package should allow for "full mental and physical relaxation"; 94.2 percent said ideal pleasure trips should be "slow-paced and not hectic"; while only 8.6 percent said an ideal tour package should include as many tour destinations or tourist attractions as possible.

By age, more than 60 percent of those aged between 40 and 60 said fine-quality meals and lodging are key elements that make for an ideal trip, while only 38 percent of those aged between 25 and 29 cited fine-quality meals and lodging as important elements.

The survey also found taht nearly 70 percent said they prefer to take part in package tours organized by travel agencies, but 16.8 percent said they prefer "half self-help" travel, with travel agencies reserving air tickets and hotel rooms for them; and another 11.2 percent said they most like to go backpacking.

Among young adults, referring to those aged between 20 and 24, 37 percent said they don't like package tours organized by travel agenices and would only go backpacking or conduct "half self-help" tours.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE HEAD JOINS TRIATHLON RACE WITH 500 OTHER POLICE OFFICERS

TEXT.P: National Police Agency (NPA) Director-General Hou Yu-ih, at the head a team of nearly 500 police officers from around the country, joined in a triathlon Saturday on the Sun Moon Lake in the central county of Nantou.

The 15th "Uni-President Enterprises Cup" Triathlon, sponsored by the Uni- Presidential Enterprises Corp., Taiwan's largest food company, kicked off at the Ita Thao Pier on the scenic lake. The two-day event drew 3,420 athletes, making for the most crowded field of participants since the annual event began in 1992.

Hou said the NPA has been encouraging police officers to join the triathlon because the sport, consisting of swimming, cycling and running over various distances, matches regular police training routines. But it's not important for the police athletes to win the game, only that they complete the race, he added.
Hou and Nantou County Magistrate Lee Chao-chin both attended the Saturday competition, which is comprised of a 750 m swim, 20 km bike ride, and 5 km foot race.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAKKA GROUPS TO RALLY IN TAIPEI TO PUSH FOR 'HSIEH-YEH' PAIRING

TEXT.P: Hakka celebrities will rally at 228 Peace Park in downtown Taipei Sunday to drum up support for former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan to become the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) vice presidential candidate, organizers said Saturday.

The rally will be jointly organized by major Hakka groups, Taiwan Hakkas Association, the Hakkas Association for Public Affairs in Taipei and associations of Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli natives residing in Taipei City as well as grassroots Hakka organizations in Taipei City and Taipei County.
The DPP has nominated former Premier Frank Hsieh as its candidate for the 2008 presidential election. According to the DPP tradition, Hsieh is free to pick his running mate.

But divergent views on the pairing-up issues are rife within party ranks and among DPP supporters. While some people like to see Hsieh pick his strongest rival in the DPP presidential primary fray -- former Premier Su Tsen-chang -- as his running mate, others, particularly DPP Hakka members, expect Hsieh to team up with Yeh, a female Hakka politician.
Hsieh has been tight-lipped on his preferred choice, saying that premature exposure and imprudent handling of the issue could bring confusions and even draw backlash.
Yeh herself never hides her keen expectations for the DPP to nominate a Hakka to be its vice presidential candidate.

Yeh, who served as acting mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung for more than a year after Hsieh was transferred to serve as premier in early 2005, campaigned hard for Hsieh in the run-up to the DPP's presidential primary in early May. She has said on several occasions that if Hsieh offers to pick her as his running mate, she would not hesitate to accept it.
Yeh said nothing else than picking a Hakka as its vice presidential candidate can better manifest how serious and sincere th DPP is in heeding Hakka people's expectations and desires.
Yeh will attend Sunday's rally, but Hsieh himself cannot attend because of his busy schedule, organizers said.
Hakka is Taiwan's second largest ethnic group, accounting for about 21 percent of its total population. So far, there have not been a Hakka president or vice president in Taiwan.

At Sunday's rally, organizers said, the head of the Taiwan Hakkas Association will present a shouldering pole to Yeh to symbolize all Hakka people's expectations for her to shoulder the responsibilities of leading Taiwan to a brighter future and allowing Hakka people a greater say in national affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE EXPRESSES CONCERN TO U.S. OVER RADAR BUDGET MISUSE

TEXT.P: The Air Force Headquarters has formed a special task force to audit budget appropriation for an advanced radar system installation project and has expressed serious concern to U.S. military authorities over relevant budget misuse, an official said Saturday.

The Air Force officer made the remarks after the United Daily News reported earlier in the day that budget for the long-range early-warning radar system procurement project has been misused by the U.S. side.

According to the report, Raytheon Co., the manufacturer contracted by the U.S. military to build the new radar system for Taiwan, has commissioned a local helicopter company to transport construction materials and relevant equipment to an Air Force base in remote mountainous region in northern county of Hsinchu, known as Loshan Base.

The report said even though the helicopter company has not airlifted any material or equipment to Loshan Base during the period from late last year to May this year, it managed to get US$700,000 in monthly payment from the U.S. contractor. According to the report, the Air Force's radar budget has so far been misappropriated by more than NT$100 million.

The report further said that because of a legislative budget cut, the radar system procured by the Air Force has been changed from a long-range, early- warning one to a new surveillance type with a shorter detection range.

In response, the Air Force officer said that as mountain roads linking Loshan base to other parts of Hsinchu County have often been damaged by torrential rains, U.S. military commissioned the local helicopter firm to transport building materials late last year. But airborne transportation work has often been affected by poor weather conditions and other factors, such as protests by residents over helicopter noise.

As a matter of fact, the officer said, the U.S. side didn't formally begin airlifting work until April this year. However, Raytheon has continued to pay the helicopter firm with funds from Taiwan. The officer said the Air Force has on many occasions expressed concerns to U.S. military authorities and has stepped up budget auditing work, adding that the Air Force task force will also tighten monitoring of progress in the project to prevent any further delay.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:In Shift, Justices Agree to Review Detainees Case
The United States Supreme Court reversed course yesterday and agreed to hear claims of Guantanamo detainees that they had a right to challenge their detention in American courts.
The decision, announced in a brief order released yesterday morning, set the stage for a legal battle that could shape debates in the Bush administration about how to close the detention center, which has become a lightning rod for international criticism.
Wall Street Journal:China Launches Public Response To Safety Outcry
China is showing the first signs of fighting back against an avalanche of criticism and new restrictions based on safety concerns about its exports. But Beijing's task is made more difficult by both its awkwardness in the public- relations game and the increasingly hostile political environment in Washington.
Beijing's campaign illustrates how worried the Chinese are that the "Made in China" label not be tarnished further by the controversies over the safety of its products. In the first four months of the year, China shipped more than $95 billion of goods, or about 20% of its total exports, to the U.S., making the American export market a key plank in the country's overall economic strategy.

The TimesG Nightclub bomb alert issued two weeks ago
Nightclubs across Britain were warned they could be terrorist targets just days before yesterdays attempted double car-bomb attack in London, The Times has learnt.

La Repubblica: London scared again by terrorist attacks.
Two car bombs, which would cause serious damages if detonated, were found and dismantled Friday in London. The police accused Al Qaeda for the failed terrorist attack attempt.
